title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LATTES, , RAFFAELE, M.D.
description: LATTES--Raffaele, M.D. The Columbia University Department of Surgery mourns the passing of Dr. Raffaele Lattes, a trained surgeon in his native Italy who was a pioneer in the field of surgical pathology and a superb teacher and scientist. As a member of the Columbia faculty for more than 30 years, Dr. Lattes trained many of today's leaders in surgical pathology. During WWII he and his colleague, Dr. Virginia Frantz, developed a new cellulose - based hemostatic agent. Throughout his career, his contributions to the characterization of the pathology of soft tissue tumors have become the international standard. We will remember his wit and his generosity in making himself available for consultation with surgeons long after he retired. We extend deepest condolences to his family and friends. In lieu of flowers, his family has requested that donations be made to the Conrad G. Lattes Scholarship Fund at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons. Eric A. Rose, M.D., Chairman Columbia University Dept of Surgery Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OBADIAH, SMITH, , LAURA SHARONA
description: OBADIAH - SMITH -- Laura Sharona. On May 22, 2003. Loving wife to David and devoted mother of Jared and James Smith. Loving daughter to Valentine and Edward Obadiah, loving sister to Michel, loving daughter-inlaw to Susan and Richard Smith. Laura graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton and went on to earn a law degree from New York Law School. She was a member of Moot Court and admitted to the New York, New Jersey, and Washington, DC Bars. Laura practiced law for several years in the New York area until devoting herself to raising her two children. Beautiful, inside and out, Laura always made heads turn with her striking model looks, infectious laughs and boundless wisdom. A righteous and brave soul, Laura was loved by many and touched the lives of anyone she came in contact with. Laura was mature beyond her young years and provided sound guidance to her husband, family, friends, and all those that asked. Her very untimely passing has left a huge crater in the hearts and minds of those who knew her, but her drive, goodness, and all that she stood for will continue on through the family and children she leaves behind. We will all miss Laura terribly, but know that she will watch over and protect us always.

title: 'Clubland'
description: It was one of those brilliant autumn days in New York, the city radiant with luminous color. While the soothing afternoon light skipped gaily across the surface of the Hudson River, Peter Gatien's world was all grim turmoil. A couple of nights ago, in the early hours, the stony-faced Gatien saw his flagship venue in Chelsea, the Limelight, padlocked by the NYPD. Friday evening, just at the peak of business, and his temple of thump-thump-thump-located at the corner of Twentieth Street and Sixth Avenue in a weathered Victorian pile that once housed St. Peter's Episcopal church, then later a drug treatment center-was packed to the vaulted rafters with gyrating penitents hanging off the two tiers of metal balconies that surrounded the cavernous main floor. The irony wasn't lost on the revelers, who seemed to take a perverse delight in frolicking on the altar or sniffing blow in the pulpit. Out on the churning dance floor, the atmosphere was like the pagan party scene in some Hollywood biblical epic, the last fling of a primitive tribe threatened with extinction by powerful social trends few of its members could fully comprehend.

For days no one could talk about anything but ''The Matrix Reloaded.'' Before long, however, the sensational movie that was to be the future of film will be gone and pretty much forgotten -- and the ''future'' once again available to all comers.

title: QUICK BITE/Jersey City; Not for Filipinos Only
description: I had never eaten Filipino food, and what I knew about the Philippines could not fill a manila folder. Luckily, my friend Maria had sent me a list of suggested dishes. So, armed with that as a cheat sheet, I was ready for Little Quiapo, a small, charming storefront restaurant two blocks from the Hudson County Courthouse in Jersey City.

title: Organs Roar Back, All Pipes Blaring
description: ORGANS -- not those pipeless electronic devices that try to sound like pipe organs but real ones -- are making a comeback in American concert halls. At the same time, organists, largely confined to church residencies, have been dwindling in numbers as traditional liturgical forms have lost favor in some denominations. In 1985, there were 728 organ majors in music schools, the American Guild of Organists reported last year, but 15 years later there were only 527. It is a paradox that guild members will undoubtedly contemplate at their regional conventions in the coming weeks.

title: Shadow Over the Summit
description: Never mind African development, weapons proliferation and global trade, all of which figure prominently on the formal agenda. The reason people will be tuning in to this year's Group of 8 summit meeting in France is to see whether George will laugh at Jacques's jokes, slap Vladimir good-naturedly on the back, or even speak to Gerhard. Or whether he will simply hang out with his good pal Tony while grumbling at the others.

title: For Sticky Days, Inspired Desserts
description: A HEAVY meal is the last thing diners want on limp, humid days when the temperature is sizzling. But no matter how little people feel like eating, they can somehow always make room for dessert.

title: Arielle Greenberg, Robert Morris
description: Arielle Chaviva Greenberg, a daughter of Sandra M. Greenberg of Sunnyvale, Calif., and Dr. Seth N. Greenberg of Albany, is to be married today to Robert Nelson Morris, the son of Margaret Gorham Burroughs of Chatham, Mass., and Joseph D. Morris of Norton, Ohio. Dr. Kidder Smith, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate at the Phoenix Loft Gallery in Belfast, Me.

title: Forget Belmont, Tony Races Are Here
description: For the record, the 57th annual Tony Awards will feature competition in 22 categories, from best play to best original score, a curious category that will feature an epic showdown between members of the Charlie Daniels Band (for "Urban Cowboy" ) and the French composer Michel Legrand ( "Amour" ). Neither should worry too much about an acceptance speech.

title: The Week in the News: May 25-31
description: IRAQ: MORE EVIDENCE OF A TROUBLED SITUATION All along, American military commanders said the war would be the easy part; the problem would be the aftermath. Indeed, Gen. Eric K. Shinseki, the Army chief of staff, was slapped down by his civilian superiors for saying it would take hundreds of thousands of soldiers to secure the peace.

title: Tomorrowland
description: Each week, after reading almost everything in your magazine, I pass it on to a high-school teacher for her enjoyment. Your May 18 magazine, however, will be put on my bookshelf next to all my other wonderful books on architecture. What an issue of hope and beauty.

title: Weimar Whiners
description: Have you heard that it's 1933 in America? God knows I have. Three times in the last few weeks I have been told -- by a novelist, an art historian and a professor of classics at Harvard, none of them ideologues or cranks -- that the erosion of civil liberties under the Bush administration constitutes an early stage, or at least a precursor, to the kind of fascism Hitler brought to Germany. I first heard the 1933 analogy a few months back, when one of the nation's leading scholars of international law suggested at a meeting of diplomats that Bush's advisers were probably plotting to suspend the election of 2004.

title: A Northwest sampler: mountains, forest and sea
description: O.K., so it has a funny name. Chuckanut Drive -- it sounds like competition among squirrels to toss around the winter food supply. But a road that straddles the sea along a forested cliff, with mountain views around some turns and edge-of-the-continent glimpses from others, is much more than a punch line.

title: POSTINGS: At 59th and First, Outside Bridgemarket; A Colorful Mosaic Is Restored
description: A 26-year development saga at the Queensboro Bridge will come to an end Tuesday with a shock of strawberry red, swirls of Creamsicle orange, folds of burgundy so luscious you can almost sniff the bouquet and periwinkle points that glimmer like pearls when seen from the just the right angle.

title: A.B.A.'s High-Flying Spirit Lives in Nets and Spurs
description: What Byron Scott remembers most about the last days of the American Basketball Association is the look.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 35 of Arts & Leisure today about the process of selecting an artist to represent the United States at the Venice Biennale misidentifies the group that makes the final decision. It is the Fund for United States Artists at International Festivals and Exhibitions. (The Federal Advisory Committee on International Exhibitions makes a recommendation.)

title: Morningstar Buys Advisory Firm
description: Morningstar Inc., best known for its ratings of mutual funds, announced on Friday that it would expand the reach of its online financial advisory service by acquiring mPower, an advisory firm based in San Francisco.

title: In This Museum, Art Lives, And Is From New Jersey
description: ON the grounds of Dia:Beacon, the contemporary art center that opened last month in Beacon, N.Y., one important artwork remains hidden in plain sight. It begins in the parking lot and ends before the entrance. Sometimes, you can pick up its scent across the lot. It constantly changes in color and shape. In fact, it is alive. And it comes from central New Jersey.

title: Personal Business; Plant a Tree, and Watch Your Home's Resale Value Grow
description: THOMAS GLASGOWwas thinking more about aesthetics than about investments when he began sprucing up the yard of the small ranch-style house in Arlington Heights, Ill., that he and his wife, Denise, bought in 1996. He planted shrubs and perennials, removed overgrown evergreens and dying trees and cultivated a magnolia tree in the backyard. Two years later -- after spending less than $2,000 on the weekend projects and after making some minor cosmetic changes inside -- he said they had sold the house for $100,000 more than they had paid for it.

description: THE problem, up to now, has been the absence of genocide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRACOVANER, , LISKA
description: CRACOVANER--Liska, also known as March, Liska, May 30, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Arthur J. Cracovaner. Devoted mother of Linda Marsh. Born February 17, 1906. Hers was a lifelong love affair with New York City and the theater. She worked as an actress and model before her marriage in 1932. She was a play agent and produced numerous plays off-Broadway. Her work as a co-producer with Cheryl Crawford led to her involvement with the Actors Studio. Her home away from home, her commitment to Lee Strasberg and the Actors Studio was total and unconditional. She was affectionately referred to by its members as the Mother Superior of the Studio--raising money, encouraging newcomers and veterans alike and administrating the institution for close to 20 years. A lover of all the arts and all things beautiful, she will be dearly missed. She brought a touch of class to any room she entered. Service private. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to Dept. of Otolaryngology, New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, 310 East 14 St, New York City, 1003 >>AD#

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Surviving a Bullet To Lead a Full Life

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIVERMORE, , ROSEMARY J.
description: LIVERMORE--Rosemary J. 70, of Paramus, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died April 10, 2003. Beloved sister to Elizabeth Frankland, Anna Fitting, the late Jane Hague and the late William Livermore. A long-standing employee of Lord, Day, Lord and its successor Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, LLP. So considerate, so large-hearted, so genial, so efficient, so radiating all the best things of life, it seems impossible that she is gone. But, a woman of Rosemary's kindly regard for people and enthusiasm for the wholesome and uplifting things of life can not die. She has by her innumerable kindnesses built a monument in the hearts of all those who knew her. She will be sorely missed. Please attend a Memorial Service for family and friends: Saturday, June 7, 2003, 2:00 pm, Grace Church Brooklyn Heights, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201, 718-624-1850 or www. gracebrooklynheights.org >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROUSE, , WILLARD G. III
description: ROUSE--Willard G. III, on May 27, 2003, age 60, of Phoenixville, PA. Beloved husband of Susannah. Father of Molly, Anne, Tanner, Hadley, Griffin, Lydia, Traighe and Tilghman. Grandfather of Karly and Ella. Also survived by sisters Lee, Kathy, and Ellen and his brother Roth. A private memorial service will be held. On Monday, June 2 at 1:30 PM a celebration of Bill Rouse's life will be held at The Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts. All those who have known and worked with Bill Rouse over the years are invited to attend. The Kimmel Center is located at Broad and Spruce Streets in Philadelphia. In lieu of flowers, the family requests taxdeductible contributions to be made to the Willard G. Rouse III Memorial Trust, C/O Liberty Property Trust, 65 Valley Stream Parkway, Malvern, PA. 19355. For information, The Donohue Funeral Home, Wayne, PA., 610-989-9600. >>AD#

title: Three Dimensions of Beauty
description: IT'S warm spring day, and I'm hurtling around a bend coming dangerously close to the edge of a leafy, tree-lined road somewhere in the Hudson Valley. I drop the ear down a gear and, glancing out the window, spot a strange object in a nearby field.

title: Safety May Be the Intimidator's Legacy
description: A statue of Dale Earnhardt was erected in his hometown, Kannapolis, N.C., not long after he died in a crash during the 2001 Daytona 500. A few miles south, there is another significant monument to Earnhardt.

title: Funny Lines, Yes, but Oh, Those Plot Details
description: ARE you well versed in Orthodox Judaism and its various sects? Can you talk learnedly about the newest research on Parkinson's disease? Do you understand the Machiavellian tricks of politics -- payoffs, rigging votes -- where ''you owe me'' is the mantra for getting what you want?

title: Like a Person
description: Runner-Up, Lives

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IF you've seen Minnie Driver as the tarty British mistress on NBC's ''Will and Grace,'' you may be surprised to learn that in her first film, Pat O'Connor's CIRCLE OF FRIENDS (1995), she played the ugly duckling. This is a piercingly poignant drama about three college girls in 1950's Dublin -- the beauty (Saffron Burrows), the orphan (Geraldine O'Rawe) and the insecure plain Jane (Ms. Driver) -- learning about life, men, cleavage, sex and betrayal. Chris O'Donnell is the cute boy Ms. Driver's character adores, Colin Firth is the rich boy from back home, and that's a pre-''Cabaret'' Alan Cumming as the nerd the girls call ''creepy Sean Walsh'' -- Sunday at 8 p.m. on Family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAMUEL, , ELEANOR
description: SAMUEL--Eleanor. On May 26, 2003. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear beloved Ellie of Aventura, FL and Andover, NJ. Wonderful wife to Fred, loving sister to Marvin, devoted mother to Steven and Mark Tannen, adoring grandmother to Blake and Betsy. She was a great friend to all and will be in our hearts always. >>AD#

title: Introduction
description: While some readers admired the fresh looks in ''Tomorrowland,'' others complained that single-theme issues often leave them out in the cold. As mad-cow disease resurfaces in the news, several praised our account of a father's search for a treatment.

title: Suspect in '96 Olympic Bombing And 3 Other Attacks Is Caught
description: After leading investigators on one of the most exhaustive manhunts in history, Eric Robert Rudolph, the wily survivalist charged in the bombing at the 1996 Olympics and attacks on abortion clinics, was arrested this morning behind a supermarket, digging through a Dumpster.

title: For Hewitt, French Open Continues To Be Unkind
description: The French Open's weeklong run of sun came to an end today, with foreboding clouds and flashes of lightning above the stadium. But the biggest thunderclap came earlier, when Lleyton Hewitt's tournament came to an end.

title: Supermarkets Rated Best for Service
description: When it comes to customer service, consumers give the highest grades to supermarkets and packaged-food companies, a recent survey finds.

title: It's Not Easy Being Green When You're Deep in the Red
description: Environmentalists once praised William Clay Ford Jr., the chairman of Ford Motor , for making pro-environmental pronouncements on issues generally off limits in Detroit, like global warming.

title: Christie Raises the Ante, And Perhaps His Profile
description: SO how is Christopher Christie during? The answer could go a long way in determining New Jersey's political landscape over the next several years.

title: Where Pets Are Allowed, and Neighbors Are Furry
description: Some lucky East Village residents are getting free housing. And in true Manhattan style, the accommodations are both snug and ingenious.

description: First Place, Lives

title: Exit Carla, Stage Top
description: SHE drops to the stage nearly naked, riding a bedsheet that descends from the heavens. Then Jane Krakowski sings a siren song to Antonio Banderas, playing footsie with his telephone cord and havoc with his libido. Still singing, she rewraps herself in the sheet and travels -- upside down! -- back to the heavens.

title: When Costumes Come in Tubes
description: THE term Plain Jane does not exactly describe Jane Krakowski before she transforms herself into the kittenish Carla in the musical ''Nine.'' She has plenty of material to work with: soft green eyes, a mouth that easily warms to a pout or a pucker, and the sort of luminous skin that looks as if she bathes in milk.

title: America's Artist, 2003 Edition
description: ''MUSEUMS are like families: on the outside they're friendly and sweet, but just like families, some of them are dysfunctional,'' Fred Wilson said with a laugh. For more than a decade, Mr. Wilson, 48, who is this year's American representative at the Venice Biennale, has used museums around the world as his palette, reinstalling their collections, often using discoveries from their storage rooms.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution and Subaru WRX STi; Speeding Tickets Made Easy
description: EVER wonder what it would be like to drive one of those cool compacts tricked out for racing on the mean streets of Los Angeles -- the kind that the stunt men drove in ''The Fast and Furious''? No need to go further than your Mitsubishi or Subaru dealer, who are each selling ultra-high-performance versions of workaday compact cars for $30,000 or so.

title: Dreams, Deferred
description: IF this is a city of aspiration, Queens College is a focal point of the American dream.

title: Cowabunga, Dude, Let's Dive Into That Pizza!
description: THERE are no turtles like the old turtles. That's the opinion of Peter Laird, one of the creators of the original ''Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' comic book series and media franchise, which included three live-action films and a popular cartoon series that began in 1987.

description: TWO shocking tidbits of news, landing within a day of each other, have set off alarm bells here at the Jersey column.

description: Your cover photograph and Austin Bunn's article about the Ost-Kuttner apartment was a joke, right? I never knew that such zaniness reached the mostly august pages of the magazine. Keep up the fine satirical work!

title: Jayne Choi, Warren Su
description: Jayne Choi, a daughter of Kyung Ju Choi and Yong Shik Choi of Leonia, N.J., was married yesterday to Warren Harrison Su, a son of Hue Ya Su and Jung Ren Su of Cherry Hill, N.J. The Rev. Paul B. Raushenbush, an American Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Koo Yong Na, a United Methodist minister, took part in the service.

title: Rewards in Restlessness
description: A YEAR ago, I officially learned that I have attention deficit disorder, but I've known it since I was in my 30's. I'm 43 now.

title: Tiny Rental Cars
description: To the Editor: Your warning about the size of rental cars in foreign countries in ''The Grand Tour in a Rental Car'' (Practical Traveler, May 11) made me smile. Several weeks ago I was offered a Mercedes-Benz ''Smart car'' at a promotional rate by a friendly Sixt agent at the Charles de Gaulle airport. Having seen the car -- which is tiny enough to be parked at a right angle to the curb in leftover space -- I was a bit dubious. I asked to check it out.

description: This

title: The Old West, with a few wineries thrown in
description: Byron said it so nicely: ''To me, high mountains are a feeling, but the hum of human cities torture.'' In summer in southern Arizona, both the hum and the torture intensify as shimmering, relentless heat is reflected by radiating pavement and flaring tempers. So, like Byron, loving not man the less but nature more, I head for the high country.

title: Emily Kirschner, Mark Saks
description: Dr. Emily Rifkin Kirschner, the daughter of Dr. Bonnie Rifkin Kirschner and Dr. Carl Kirschner of Flemington, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Mark Ari Saks, a son of Dr. Norma Susswein Saks and Richard L. Saks of Cranbury, N.J. Rabbi Sandy Roth Parian will officiate at the North Maple Inn in Basking Ridge, N.J.

description: Empire Maker and Dynever, two strong contenders to upset Funny Cide's bid for the Triple Crown, turned in their final workouts yesterday for the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

title: Fishy Tales, or Have You Heard the One About . . .
description: WESTCHESTER fishermen have seen it all - or so they say. And the local bait shop is where people hear it all.

title: BUDGET OUTLOOK DIMS
description: Revenue from income and sales taxes will probably decline for a second consecutive year, state budget officials told the Senate and Assembly budget committees last week in revised projections for the fiscal year that ends June 30. ''It's an extraordinary situation,'' said David J. Rosen, the chief budget analyst in the nonpartisan Office of Legislative Services. The losses will be offset by unexpectedly high revenue from the newly overhauled corporate business tax. But officials had to lower the projections they made when Governor McGreevey submitted his proposed budget for next year. The treasurer, John E. McCormac, conceded that the estimates of three months ago were off by hundreds of millions of dollars. ''You can't spin this in a positive way,'' he said. ''Those are not little numbers.'' Laura Mansnerus

title: A Baltimore Without Hairspray or Diners
description: IN tonight's season premiere of ''The Wire,'' a Baltimore drug dealer discovers, to his horror, that hometown radio dies 30 miles out of town. So on his first trip away from Baltimore, he slinks into a Philadelphia rendezvous with ''A Prairie Home Companion'' pouring from the speakers. He may remind viewers of Wallace, the teenage character who last season gave up a rural safe haven to return to his housing project -- where he was pretty sure he would die -- because ''them [expletive] crickets don't let you sleep.'' Like the other characters on ''The Wire,'' these two have been made provincial by the big city. They're so hemmed in by segregation and lack of opportunity that they have no idea how trapped they are.

title: Habitats/111 West 117th Street; Actors Buy Harlem Home In Need of Sweat Equity
description: CHARLIE MARCUS and Cynthia Gray have bought a building in Harlem that is a total wreck. It looks as if it has been damaged by at least fire and flood, and maybe some other biblical-style disasters as well.

title: A Cultural Conundrum: The Chocolate Fortune Cookie
description: So completely does the citrus-flavored fortune cookie dominate the dinner tables of Chinese restaurants in New York, it is small wonder that its chocolate-flavored cousin survives at all. But there is such a thing as a chocolate fortune cookie, and for the last 10 years, it has popped up in pockets of neighborhoods, like Park Slope, Brooklyn, where it is usually met with delight or confusion.

title: Framer Seeks Return of Artworks He Forgot in Subway
description: ''Lost art portfolio containing paintings,'' declare the bright orange notices in the subway station at 79th Street and Broadway. A reward is offered, with a telephone number to call.

Is there a zone of bad health around Dr. Frist that puts him in constant demand? Or just a zone of P.R. flacks?

description: IN Buddy Guy's new album, ''Blues Singer,'' the consummate living performer of urban electric-blues, one of the most exuberant performers in American music, is put before you instead as an apparition with an acoustic guitar, the clichd lonely bluesman. For a few songs, like ''Hard Time Killing Floor'' and ''Can't See Baby,'' he's all alone. For the rest of the album, he's backed by an acoustic bass, an artfully rudimentary drum sound and a second acoustic guitar, instead of his regular electric band.

title: A Horse Is a Horse (Or Is It A Wheel?)
description: TRANSFORMATION is the theme of ''Man of La Mancha,'' and more than one is taking place onstage these days at the Martin Beck Theater. Near the beginning of the show, Cervantes, the imprisoned Spanish writer, changes into a character from his imagination, Don Quixote, the medieval (and deranged) knight. In the process, inanimate objects also change into noble beasts.

title: The Prodigious Pianist
description: Lang Lang, the young Chinese-born pianist, was nearing the reprise in his encore, ''Stars and Stripes Forever,'' at a concert in Milwaukee last year. He had whipped the audience up -- as usual, by playing bone-crushing music effortlessly and joyously, dashing from one end of the keyboard to the other, smiling and tossing around his bowl of black hair, seeming to have the time of his life. Then he slowed down a little, bending forward, as if preparing to leap up, ready to kick the music into a higher gear. The audience took this as a cue and started clapping in rhythm. Lang glanced toward the crowd, surprised. He had something else in mind. He plunged ahead, gradually upping the tempo and leaving the clappers behind. He ended in a torrent of thundering chords, the last one propelling his head backward, eyes skyward and arms out. He looked as if he had just been struck by a bolt from heaven, which is also how the audience reacted: people jumped to their feet, roaring in unison even before the sound of the last chord had died. They seemed to feel they had experienced something miraculous, too.

title: Putin Asks Europe to Open Borders to Russian Visitors
description: Having wined, dined and entertained about 45 global leaders long into Friday night, President Vladimir V. Putin shuttled Europe's heads of state to an opulent czarist palace outside St. Petersburg this morning to request politely that they open their borders wider to visiting Russians.

title: Iraqi Civilians Allowed To Keep Assault Rifles
description: In a significant retreat in American efforts to seize weapons held by Iraqi citizens, American and British officials said today that Iraqis would be allowed to keep AK-47 assault rifles in their homes and businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POWERS, , WILLIAM DOYLE
description: POWERS -- William Doyle. Retired attorney with the Bell System. A lifelong resident of Manhattan. Died on May 30, 2003, after an extended illness. He was 74. Mr. Powers was a 1950 graduate of Fordham University and received his bachelor's and master's degrees in law from New York University School of Law. From 1957 to 1990 he practiced law with several law firms and corporations, serving as general counsel for Nassau Recycling Corporation, an AT&T subsidiary headquartered in Columbia, SC. Mr. Powers was an independent equity trader from 1990 to 1993, when he retired. Surviving are his wife of 40 years, Marie Wallace Powers, two sons, Corbett and Christopher, and a brother, Richard of Baltimore, MD. A Knight of Malta since 1989, Mr. Powers was active in a number of charitable and civic organizations, including on the Boards of Casita Maria and Marymount College from 1961 to 1965. He was a cofounder of Pregnancy Help, Inc., and served on its Board of Directors and as Vice President since 1994. In 1993 Mr. Powers became a member of the Board of Directors of the Patrons of the Vatican Museum in Rome, Italy. An avid golfer, he and his family summered at Buck Hills Falls, PA, and was a member of its country club for many years. He recently joined the Lost Tree Golf and Country Club in Palm Beach, FL. Visiting at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave at 81 St, will be on Sunday from 7-9 PM, and on Monday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass will be at 10 AM, on Tuesday, at St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and 83rd Street. >>AD#

title: 'Good Kills'
description: As the mother of Cpl. Mark Evnin, who was killed in action on April 3, I am writing to say that it was only because several friends and family called to warn me about Peter Maass's article (April 20) that I did not happen upon it, and it was very upsetting to read when I finally dared to look at it. Although it sounds as if my son did not suffer much pain and was not aware that he was dying, it is still an image that will be very hard to forget. I think Maass could have left out my son's mumbled last words. Those last moments with the chaplain, while my son faded away, did not need to be described for your readers. He gave his life. Isn't that enough? Simply saying that the chaplain was with him when he died would have been sufficient.

title: In Love, Not War, A Badge Of Courage
description: EVER since Robert Siegel, the editor of The Onion, the satirical weekly, was a boy of 8 or 9, he has wanted a medal. Wars both fascinated and terrified him. ''I was sort of an uptight nerd and was afraid of the draft,'' said Mr. Siegel, who grew up in Merrick, N.Y., the son of school psychologists. ''I'd have nightmares about being in the front line of war, where they'd charge, swords drawn, into the fire, and I'd dream about how I'd sneak away and hide in the woods.''

title: Return Trips
description: To the Editor: This summer I will be making my 10th trip to the place I am hooked on, which is New York City. I dreamed of going there my whole life, but didn't get there until I was 40. I felt instantly at home. It was love at first sight. On my first trip, a tour bus operator in Brooklyn was astounded that I knew everything that was coming before we got there.

title: A Theory Of Everything
description: As President Bush meets other world leaders this weekend, and tries to patch things up between America and the rest of the planet, I find myself looking back and asking: What's been going on here? After 9/11 people wondered, ''Why do they hate us?'' speaking of the Muslim world. After the Iraq war debate, the question has grown into, ''Why does everybody else hate us?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, , HERMAN LOUIS
description: COHEN--Herman Louis. 80, died peacefully May 6, at home in Santa Rosa, CA. Formerly of Rego Park and Forest Hills, NY. Loving and devoted father of Jonathan, Amy and Diane. Father-inlaw to Julie and John. Brother of Lester Cohen. Doting grandfather to Ariel, Rebecca, Rachel and Matthew. Loving ex-husband to Rhoda Cohen. Donations to the St. Cecilia Chorus, New York, NY. Interment private. Memorial service Monday, June 16, 4 PM, John Jay College Admin Building, Room 603. >>AD#

title: A Mayor Without a Message
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came into office as a reformer: he said he wanted to transform government, and he had no political debts. Partly because of his great wealth -- he spent $74 million of his estimated $4.8 billion fortune on his 2001 campaign -- he won office without becoming beholden to municipal unions or the real estate industry, corporate lobbyists or ideologues of right or left.

title: Ivanchuk, Sharp but Shaky, Buckles Down for a Victory
description: Since the breakup of the Soviet Union, Vasily Ivanchuk has become the foremost player of Ukraine. Before his latest success, he was ranked 13th in the world. The book on Ivanchuk has always been that he can be extraordinarily brilliant, but self-destructively nervous and undependable.

title: Investing; Portfolio With Cachet, and Costs
description: PRIVATE money management, once reserved for the wealthy, is being offered to thousands of mutual fund shareholders with $50,000 or less to invest. But many financial advisers warn that the private management of assets, in what are often known as separately managed accounts, may not be appropriate for people of modest wealth.

title: No Way, Cla-a-a-a-y!
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on the DataBank page on May 18 about the performance of the financial markets misstated the number of weeks in a row that the Dow Jones industrial average had risen through Friday, May 16. It was three, not four.

title: Now in a Club Near You: Gamelans and Baby Talk
description: KAITO -- To the mainstream, punk rock now means bratty, funny songs by guys who jump around on MTV. So it's time for bands who remember how early punks wanted not only to distill rock but to boobytrap what was left. On ''Band Red'' (Spinart), the second album by the English band Kaito, the structures are simple while the music bristles. Catchy riffs are barbed with distortion, and Nikki Colk's voice moves from sass to quaver to shriek at the drop of an overactive hormone. In both music and words, Kaito constantly shuttles between attraction and animosity.

title: The Bioweapons Enigma
description: President Bush may be convinced that two trailers found in Iraq were used as biological weapons labs, but the evidence is far from definitive. Referring to the two trailers in an interview with Polish television before he departed for Europe last week, Mr. Bush said the United States had found weapons of mass destruction and banned manufacturing devices in Iraq. Reports from the Central Intelligence Agency and Defense Intelligence Agency support that view, but they are based on inconclusive information.

title: 300 Redux: To Yanks' Clemens, It's Another Day at the Office
description: When Roger Clemens talked about facing the young, dismal Detroit Tigers on Sunday for what could be his 300th victory, there was a soothing quality to his normally powerful voice. He talked more about Detroit than about the faceless Tigers, seemingly pondering that this city could be the place where he finally does it, finally barrels into the exclusive 300 club.

title: Unreconstructed
description: His Excellency Ismail Khan -- ruler of the ancient city of Herat, governor of the province, emir of the western territories and commander of Afghanistan's fourth military corps -- seemed fascinated by the woman with no arms. ''It's amazing -- she eats with her toes,'' he said, looking my way. The emir had allowed me to sit at his shoulder during his weekly public assembly, when hundreds of supplicants come to the great hall of the governor's compound and plead for him to intercede in their behalf. As usual, Ismail Khan was wearing a spotless white waistcoat, whiter even than his famous fluff of beard, thick as cotton candy. He sat at a simple desk beneath the adoring light of a grand chandelier. Uniformed men hovered nearby, ready to be dispatched on sudden errands. Other aides in suits and ties periodically brought papers for him to sign, removing each one the instant the emir's signature was complete and then bowing before backpedaling away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLAIR, , THOMAS S.
description: BLAIR--Thomas S., Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Directors of Blair Strip Steel Company, New Castle, PA, died of heart failure on Saturday, May 10, 2003, in Boynton Beach, FL. Mr. Blair was born April 15, 1922 in New Castle, PA, the son of George Dike Blair Jr. and Hazel Slingluff Blair. He graduated from The Hill School in Pottstown, PA and from Williams College in Williamstown, MA. During World War II, he was a research associate on the Manhattan Project, working in laboratories at Columbia University in New York City and at Oak Ridge, TN, primarily on processes for the separation of uranium isotopes necessary for the development of the atom bomb. Following the War, Mr. Blair was Associate Editor, handling technical articles, for ''The Iron Age,'' a weekly steel industry publication headquartered in New York City. In 1949 he returned to New Castle, becoming President of Blair Strip Steel Company, a position he held until 1984. After that date he continued as Chairman of the Board of the Company, and then in recent years as Chairman Emeritus. In other business activities, Mr. Blair served as a Director of The Columbia Gas System, Inc; Columbia Gas of PA; Columbia Gas of MD; Tuscarora, Inc; Matflo Corp; Southeastern Plastics Corp; The Union Trust Company; and The First National Bank of Lawrence County Pennsylvania. He is survived by his wife of 56 years Phyllis Emmerich Blair of Boynton Beach, FL and Williamstown, MA and by his three children: Joan Dix Blair of Williamstown, MA; George Dike Blair of New York City; and Hadden Slingluff Blair of Waitsfield, VT. Also surviving are his brother Robert Dike Blair of Middlebury, VT and two grandsons Rufus Wyer and Malcolm Wyer of Williamstown, MA. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERBER, , LOUISE CRAIG JACOBS
description: GERBER--Louise Craig Jacobs. Wife of the late Dr. Leon Gerber, mother of Robert of Bedford Hills, N.Y. and Merrell Eve and Edie Mackenzie of Vancouver, Canada, sister of Pearl and George, aunt and loving friend, passed peacefully at home in Laguna Hills, CA on Saturday May 24, one month to the day before her 88th birthday. Louise graduated Hunter High, Hunter College and Cornell University, with an MA in play production. An original member of the Actor's Lab in Hollywood, she worked regularly in radio while translating Bertolt Brecht's plays and teaching English to many prominent German artists who fled Nazi Germany. Upon returning to N.Y., she acted on Broadway and worked at the Phoenix Theater. She directed countless plays at the Chappaqua Drama Group and the Schoolhouse in Katonah and continued directing after moving to Laguna Hills, CA. Louise was a remarkable, brilliant woman who, as an artist and enlightened thinker, was a mentor to many. A second generation Isadora Duncan dancer, trained by Anna and Irma Duncan, she went on to train the next generation of dancers. Her sense of humanity and justice was present in everything she did. Louise was loved by many and we will cherish her always and celebrate her life: one lived so fully. >>AD#

On the day I arrive I invariably leave my flat as soon as I unpack and trek over familiar paths, my way of proving to myself that in a turbulent world, my personal universe is still intact.

title: S. Carolina Runner Wins Four Golds
description: Tiffany Ross, a sophomore at South Carolina, won four gold medals yesterday at the N.C.A.A. East Regional championships in Fairfax, Va. She won the 100-meter hurdles (13.12) and the 400 hurdles (55.89) and ran legs of the winning 4x100 and 4x400 relay teams.

title: The World; A River Rises Through It, Washing Away the Past
description: AFTER a decade of construction work, China will today close the sluice gates of the giant Three Gorges Dam and forever alter the landscape of its historic heartland.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation: Parts of Speech; The Bloody Crossroads of Grammar and Politics
description: IS there a grammatical error in the following sentence? ''Toni Morrison's genius enables her to create novels that arise from and express the injustices African Americans have endured.''

title: BackTalk; Gray Ghost Is Haunting Triple Crown
description: Native Dancer's descendants have won six Kentucky Derbies in a row and eight of the last nine. Funny Cide, a great-great grandson, has a chance to win the Triple Crown in Saturday's Belmont Stakes.

title: Is the Body More Beautiful When It's Dead?
description: UNLESS the Ohio Supreme Court takes his case, the Cincinnati photographer Thomas Condon will soon be returning to jail for corpse abuse. The crime conjures unsavory images of Victorian grave robbery and necrophilia. Mr. Condon said his intention, however, was to create works of art.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on May 18 about the Bard College SummerScape festival referred incorrectly to a work to be performed and to architecture there. Don Juan in Prague is an opera, not a film. The planning of the main auditoriums acoustical shell and molded balconies was a collaboration between Frank Gehry and Yasuhisa Toyota, not by Mr. Toyota alone.

title: A State Tradition Not to Be Celebrated
description: For many politicians in New Jersey, one public job is not enough. It's not enough for the 12 members of the state Legislature who are also mayors, or for at least 5 other mayors who are running for seats in the Senate or the Assembly in the primary elections to be held on Tuesday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Inna Dukach, Sean Altman
description: Inna Dukach, a soprano, is to be married this evening to Sean Altman, a pop singer and songwriter. Rabbi Helen Ferris will officiate at Sinapi's Ceola Manor, a caterer in Jefferson Valley, N.Y.

title: INVESTING WITH -- Mark L. Mallon And Charles A. Ritter; American Century Large Company Value Fund
description: ALTHOUGH they have lagged behind growth stocks this year, large-capitalization value stocks remain excellent long-term investments, say Mark L. Mallon and Charles A. Ritter, co-managers of the $210 million American Century Large Company Value fund.

title: The Chief's Record At Bristol-Myers
description: To the Editor:

title: Quit-Claim Deed and Title Insurance
description: Q -- Nine years ago I bought vacant land in the Bronx by way of a quit-claim deed, which conveys the full title that the grantor of the deed holds, whatever that may be, but not necessarily the full title to the property. Most title companies refuse to guarantee titles derived from quit-claim deeds because such deeds present a cloud on the ownership. Is there any way for me to get normal ownership of this land? . . . Nadia J. Cronyn, Manhattan.

title: Broadway Enjoys Its Moment
description: The piano perched on a platform above Duffy Square yesterday morning should have been the first sign that producers of this year's Tony Awards ceremony were serious about breaking their show's extended ratings slump.

title: Private Sector; An Apparent Heir at Xerox
description: URSULA M. BURNS doesn't play golf. She doesn't belong to the local country club. Small talk is not her strong suit. And she insists on being home on weekends.

title: A Suburban Icon, Still on Cruise Control
description: WHEN production of the first Dodge Caravan and Plymouth Voyager began in November 1983, the minivan was born. Soon it became a symbol of suburban living, the vehicle of choice for soccer moms from Atlantic Beach to Wading River and parked in lawn-bordered driveways across the country.

title: Take Me Out, Gracie, to Enchanged Brixton
description: RICHARD GREENBERG, the author of ''Take Me Out,'' about a baseball superstar who announces that he is gay, said in an interview last year in The New York Times: ''Baseball functions very much the way tragedy does. It's a symbolic realm that allows a lot of emotions to happen that wouldn't otherwise.'' This scene is from the current production at the Walter Kerr Theater, directed by Joe Mantello. In it, Mason Marzac (played by Denis O'Hare), a financial adviser who is gay, talks with his client, Darren Lemming (Daniel Sunjata), the superstar.

title: Kathryn Kaffke, Bert Harrell
description: Kathryn Clark Kaffke and Edward Scott Harrell were married yesterday by the Rev. Cameron Harkness, a Presbyterian minister, at Lockesly Manor in Millwood, Va.

title: A Star of the Video Game Screen
description: DANIEL JETTE says that when he saw a television commercial for the Lancer Evolution, he exclaimed to a friend, ''Hey, that's my car!'' Mr. Jette, a 21-year-old junior at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., has been racing an Evolution for more than a year, although Mitsubishi only recently began importing the car -- and although he does not actually have an Evo.

title: Corrections
description: A table last Sunday with an article about the performance of the college savings plans known as 529's referred incompletely to the return data calculated by Morningstar Inc. When mutual funds underlying the plans' portfolios were older than the portfolios themselves, Morningstar based the longer-term returns on the portfolios' current allocation of mutual funds. The portfolio returns assumed reinvestment of dividends and capital gains and included portfolio expenses, but excluded sales charges, enrollment fees and taxes.

title: Writing and Thinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about speculation that President John F. Kennedy, had he lived, might have avoided deeper military involvement in Vietnam mispelled the given name of a historian who has written that the Kennedy administration had completely rejected a political solution to the conflict. He is Fredrik Logevall, not Frederik.

title: Is There a Tony Doctor in the House
description: PITY the poor Tony Awards. Falling Nielsen ratings, industry ridicule, offended winners; you name it, the Tonys have suffered it in recent years.

title: Hook, Line and Therapy
description: Now that breast cancer is considered a chronic, treatable disease rather than a death sentence, programs of support are proliferating for the ever-increasing number of survivors, in New Jersey as elsewhere. One such program, Casting for Recovery, is a program with a twist.

title: Bryn Elliot, Scott Craven
description: Bryn Lisa Elliot, the daughter of Greta and Michael Elliot of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married in Manhattan last evening to Scott Anthony Craven, the son of Rosemarie D. Shefferman of Potomac, Md., and Dr. John E. Craven of Silver Spring, Md. Cantor Kerri Ben David officiated at the Yale Club of New York.

title: Teams May Be Great, but New Jersey Can't Win; With the Devils and Nets in Finals, Will the State Finally Get Respect?
description: Mayor Jim Cassella has been getting calls from reporters all over the country. Their questions are all along the lines of, ''What is East Rutherford?''

title: The Never-Ending Story
description: It was a Tuesday afternoon last June, on the kind of day we'd come to Cape Cod for. My husband and I were lying on beach towels, reading in the sun. Our 8-year-old son, Brian, was digging a hole. If he'd been in the water, we would have been watching his every movement. But we never worried about the sand. At some point, our 11-year-old daughter, Rebecca, announced, ''Mom, look at Brian.'' She sounded more as if she were tattling than worried, so it took me a few seconds to respond. When I sat up, I saw my son's legs poking out of the sand. They were blue.

title: Suffolk Democrats Nominate Steve Levy
description: The Suffolk County Democratic Committee has nominated Assemblyman Steve Levy, 43, as its candidate for county executive. Mr. Levy received a standing ovation after telling about 850 committee members during their May 22 convention at the Islandia Marriott that the voters deserved a county executive familiar with the workings of Suffolk's government, an oblique reference to his likely primary opponent, William Cunningham.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Sunday with a report about the marriage of Katherine Lien Hoa Chu and Jonathan Alden was published in error. It showed Chiu-Ti Liu and Dr. Ronald Jansen, whose marriage is reported today.

description: AARON DAVIS HALL  "Another Evening," a new collaboration between Bill T. Jones, Cassandra Wilson and Dr. Daniel Bernard Roumain. Convent Ave., at 135th St. (212) 650-7100. Today, 3.

description: IT was officially just a preliminary hearing at the Department of Transportation. But it had barely begun when the judge scolded the lawyers for D.H.L. Airways, the cargo airline for D.H.L. Worldwide Express.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   NACHIMSON, , MARGARET SCHLEIFER, M.D.
description: NACHIMSON -- Margaret Schleifer, M.D. Your 42nd birthday. Maggie, we miss you so. Loving Family and Friends >>AD#

description: To the Editor:

title: Madrid Card Opens Doors at a Discount
description: A new Madrid Card offers access to dozens of museums, rides on public transport, discounts at many restaurants, reduced entry fees at children's attractions and other benefits. Sold by the city tourism agency, the cards come in one-, two- or three-day versions, which cost $32.55, $48.84 and $63.95, at 0.86 euros to the dollar. Among the 40 museums and monuments in the Madrid region that admit cardholders at no extra charge are the Prado, the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum and the Reina Sofia National Art Center, as well as the Royal Botanical Gardens, the National Archaeological Museum, the Bullfight Museum and the Royal Palace. Included with the card is a pass for 5 or 10 trips on the city's subway and buses.

title: Dawn Baker, Henry Miller
description: Pamela Dawn Baker and Henry G. Miller, lawyers, are to be married today at the 200 Fifth Club in Manhattan. Judge Albert M. Rosenblatt of the New York Court of Appeals will officiate.

title: 'American Idol';
description: `AMERICAN IDOL'

title: Griese Finds Himself On the Waiver Wire
description: Brian Griese was once hailed as the replacement to John Elway as the Denver Broncos' quarterback. Tomorrow, he will be on the N.F.L.'s waiver wire.

title: Remembering Cannes 2003: Worst Festival Ever
description: FROM time to time here in Cannes, you will fall into conversation with a veteran of film festivals past, hardened by 20 or 30 May fortnights of Bandol and foie gras, black-tie screenings and late-night yacht parties, who will conjure memories of bygone glory and outrage -- of ''Rosetta'' in 1999, of ''The Tin Drum'' and ''Apocalypse Now'' in 1979, or even of the storied Cannes of 1968, when a group of French directors held down the curtain of the old Palais des Festivals at the start of a screening and brought the whole thing to a grinding halt.

title: To Preserve and Protect
description: SUMMER is the season for uncovering. Our shirts are sleeveless, our shoes are open, our legs are bare, as we throw off the confines of cooler weather and revel in the joys of the sun.

title: Evaluating New York's Best Regulars
description: It could be a bummer of a summer for New York baseball fans. The Mets and the Yankees have lost their best everyday players to serious injuries, the kind that not only affect pennant races but also wreck Hall of Fame careers.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Walking in His Father's Footsteps
description: Jim Burt Jr. remembers when he was 5 years old, being carried across the field by his jubilant father as the sun set on the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Physicians' Group Seeks World Free Of Tobacco
description: The world's largest organization of cancer doctors began its annual meeting here today by calling for the eventual elimination of tobacco from the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, , BERNICE KREINDLER (BUNNY)
description: COHEN--Bernice Kreindler (Bunny). Beloved and cherished wife of Dr. Ira Bernard Cohen, devoted mother of Amy Cohen Burack, and Bonnie Cohen Rooney and her loving husband William J. Rooney, loving grandmother of Jacob Burack, Kevin and Meghan Rooney, and devoted sister-in-law of Florence Kalvin. Bunny died after suffering from a long illness on May 30, 2003, at The Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center. It is with profound sorrow that her passing will be mourned by all of her many friends and family, who through the years have felt her beneficent presence. Services will be at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Monday, June 2 at 11:30 a.m. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Dr. Ira Bernard Cohen Internal Medicine Fund at Beth Israel Medical Center for the betterment of patient care, 16th Street and 1st Avenue, NY, NY 10003.

title: Business; In a Dull Economy, Avon Finds a Hidden Gloss
description: TO Andrea Jung, a persistently rotten economy is a beautiful thing.

title: Chirac to Call for a Shift From Battling Terrorism to Helping Poorer Nations
description: When President Bush and the other Group of 8 leaders gather to discuss the world's problems on Sunday and Monday, they will no doubt be hoping that this trim spa on the shores of Lake Geneva will be the source of something more than just cold bubbling spring water.

Funeral service Monday, June 2, at 12:30 PM, in Bernheim - Apter - Kreitz man, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ. Interment Riverside Cemetery. >>AD#

title: Camilla Calamandrei, David Rudofsky
description: Camilla Calamandrei, a documentary filmmaker in Manhattan, and David Bruce Rudofsky, a financial consultant in Mount Kisco, N.Y., were married last evening. Judith Wank, the assistant leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester County, N.Y., officiated at the Hancock Shaker Village in Pittsfield, Mass.

title: Courtney Hurley, Timothy Pierson
description: Courtney Howard Hurley, the daughter of Nancy Mae and Donald Hurley Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday on Martha's Vineyard to Timothy James Pierson, the son of Paula Morrison Pierson and James H. Pierson of Grand Rapids, Mich. Msgr. Dennis F. Sheehan performed the ceremony at Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Church in Oak Bluffs, Mass.

title: Mr. Fix-It
description: There are questions over which honorable people may differ. How to resolve a clash between civic and religious values? May you smuggle food into the movies? Would a decent society allow the production of 'X-Men' sequels? And there are answers that are simply -- to use a vulgar word -- wrong. In a bit of spring cleaning, I'd like to correct a few of my errors from the past year.

title: Private Sector; Out of the Lineup, but Still a Team Player
description: Donald J. Carty, who resigned on April 24 as chairman and chief executive at AMR, parent of American Airlines, isn't wasting any time hitting the career rehabilitation trail. In an interview last week on CNBC, he said he had been offered ''a lot of opportunity'' since leaving American in April, but he nonetheless showed his ties to his previous employer.

title: 'Shattered Dreams'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Buzz in the Bug World
description: TO Trenton Thunder fans, Richard Cooper is the man who takes the sting out of baseball, having lured hundreds of thousands of yellow jacket wasps to their demise over the last eight seasons at Mercer County Waterfront Park here.

title: In Search of a Seaworthy Moniker
description: RUSS EBERSOL keeps In Too Deep, his 25-foot Sea Ray powerboat, at the Wright Island Marina in New Rochelle during the winter months. The Mount Vernon resident is lucky to have one of the 140 slips, because he says there are waiting lists at many of the Westchester County marinas.

title: It's a Good Time to Be Bald
description: THOMAS CANNA sits stoically in a barber's chair and looks straight ahead at his reflection. In about an hour, he will be suited up and at bat for the first game of what will be a long and sweaty baseball season. Right now he is at Rocky's Barber Shop in Milford for a low-maintenance ''buzz cut.''

title: Monaco Motor Race a Glamorous Event
description: MONACO, May 31  A flawless 59.60-carat fancy pink diamond. A royal family, a black-tie ball, fashion models and movie stars in Ferraris and Jaguars, and massive yachts. An exclusive three-night party with star D.J.'s, dancers and circus acts.

title: The Last Word; Taking Wing
description: It is a truth imperfectly acknowledged that a certain type of book buyer is primarily interested in reading about herself. Slake the thirst of such readers for heroines who are spunky but not overconfident, wisecracking but not cynical, beleaguered but not downtrodden, and you may soon find yourself in possession of a good fortune all your own. That's the thinking (for publishers at least) behind the contemporary genre known as chick lit.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on April 13 with a Style & Entertaining article about Eric Villency, president of the furniture company Maurice Villency Inc., misattributed the design of the kitchen island and other metal pieces in the loft and the choice of style for cabinets and lighting in the kitchen. They were by David Hu, an architect, not by Villency or Michael Shen. The caption also misstated the ownership of the loft. It belongs to Michael Shen; Villency rents it.

title: Truth at The Hague
description: I am a Bosnian Muslim from Srebrenica, where more than 7,000 Muslims were killed by Bosnian Serbs in July 1995. I survived because at the time of the massacre I was in Potocari, some 15 miles away from most of the execution sites, working as an interpreter for the United Nations. My uncle, my 70-year-old grandfather, my best friend and almost all of my schoolmates were killed.

title: Orient and Occident, Swapping Choruses
description: EDWARD SAID'S ''Orientalism'' is one of the most influential academic books of its generation. It points out, in various ways, how the East was ''Orientalized'' by the West, how the subtlety of life in places as diverse as Japan, Java and the Middle East was seen through lenses that robbed it of its individuality, and how the East was stereotyped as a place of ''romance, exotic beings, haunting memories and landscapes, remarkable experiences.''

title: Nets Renewed Under Thorn And Scott
description: Jerry West takes no credit for bringing two of his favorite people together. West, the omnipresent symbol of the N.B.A., offered encouragement and, typically, spoke honestly.

title: Behind Enemy Lines
description: You referred to the items photographed in Iraq by Simon Norfolk for the May 11 Lives column as ''ordinary junk.'' The tank top might have belonged to a young girl running home to parents and caught in crossfire. The scarred boot found near an abandoned tank, the photo of a possible sweetheart and the well-worn toilet articles could have been left behind during an Iraqi soldier's desperate attempt at freedom, or they may have been all that a dead soldier left behind. Why demean personal things that belonged to real people? A much more appropriate term would have been ''artifacts of war.''

title: From Princeton To High School With Money
description: Forget James Gandolfini. Bag the Jon Bon Jovi worship. New Jersey is forging a new prototype for the Hollywood heartthrob. This time, he's riddled with brains.

title: In the Spirit and Taste of France
description: AN American flag hangs like an entreaty from a roadside sign marking L'Europe Restaurant. After two recent dinners there, I would venture this: With the Iraq war winding down, and the snubbing of things French no longer a sport, patriotic diners might want to invest a few dollars in the floundering economy by going out for a plate of escargots and a bottle of good Bordeaux.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Laying on of Hands: Stories, by Alan Bennett. (Picador, $11.) The playwright, screenwriter and one-quarter of the 1960's British comedy group Beyond the Fringe offers up three polished satirical tales about lonely people coming together in unlikely combinations -- a department store clerk who discovers romance with her podiatrist, for example, or an oppressed schoolteacher who finds love in the hospital at his father's deathbed. ''Bennett's brilliant and luminous'' prose ''is like stained glass: if you stare at it, you see things you missed,'' Christopher Buckley wrote here last year. Picador has also reissued Writing Home ($20), a revised and updated edition of Bennett's 1995 collection of critical writings and diaries, including an account of the eccentric Miss Shepherd, a former nun who lived in a van in his yard in London for nearly 20 years. Our reviewer, Ben Brantley, found this ''a rare, rich volume, replete with insights that demand to be memorized and quoted.''

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on May 18 described a federal investigation of accounting practices at Bristol-Myers Squibb. The article noted that the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, enacted last year, requires top company executives to swear to the accuracy of corporate financial reports and that Peter R. Dolan, the chairman and chief executive of Bristol-Myers, did so last August, only to disavow the company's reports in October.

title: Long Live Chamber Music: Two Festivals Do Their Part
description: MUSIC MOUNTAIN and Norfolk, nestled near each other in the Berkshire foothills, are both ready to usher in summer, even as they continue a friendly debate over which is the most senior citizen.

description: SKLARSKY--Samuel and Janice Parker. In tender loving memory of our beloved parents and devoted grandparents. We will always remember the beautiful life you gave us. Bonnie and Michael, Jill and Kenny; Grandchildren, Stephanie, Allison, Emily, Evan, David & Ale

Hepfer of Toronto. The Rev. Mark S. Anschutz, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich. The Rev. William A. Evertsberg, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the service.

description: To the Editor:

title: Along the Missouri, Life Ebbs and Flows
description: The ink had barely dried on the world's biggest real estate deal -- Napoleon selling the midsection of North America for about 3 cents an acre -- when a 55-foot keelboat and two oversize pirogues set out from here in May of 1804 to have a look at the American tomorrow.

title: Language Pitfalls
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Learning Spanish: A Tense Undertaking,'' (May 4): If Lili Wright has trouble learning the Spanish subjunctives, she ain't seen nothing yet. I suggest she try learning German, in which the nouns are subject to different endings depending on which of the four cases (nominative, genitive, dative and accusative) they are in.

title: Easier Entry to Britain For Cats and Dogs
description: Last month, Virgin Atlantic began flying cats and dogs from the United States to Heathrow Airport near London under the Pet Travel Scheme (PETS) in Britain. The service is being offered between Los Angeles and London for a three-month period and will be extended to all United States routes after that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILTON, , JULES
description: MILTON--Jules. On May 31, 2003, at age 80, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Beloved husband of 50 years to Muriel. Devoted father of Valerie (and Dennis) Bernstein and Sandra Milton. Adored Poppy of Allison, Lori and Jessica. Survived by his sister Ruth. >>AD#

title: Small-Producer Tastings
description: Four small North Fork producers that do not own wineries have pooled their wines in a sales room in Peconic.

title: A Wild and Aimless Beauty
description: IN the warm months people went to the waterfront. Middle-aged Polish women sunbathed on the loading docks. Spanish men with coolers and radios fished off the piers. Couples sat on the long bulkhead, and dog owners let their animals roam the lots around the abandoned warehouses. They all came for the breezes and the peace and the views, almost as good as the Brooklyn Heights Promenade but no freeway shaking the ground and water you could touch.

title: A Glimpse of the Tricolor
description: FLORENT Morellet discovered the Gansevoort meatpacking district the same way that many other people who did not happen to be meat cutters or wholesalers found it back in the 1970's, through the gay bars.

title: Jonas Karp, Stefan Lehmann
description: Paul Jonas Karp and Stefan Marcus Lehmann celebrated their partnership yesterday at the W Union Square hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Marcia Rappaport performed the commitment ceremony.

title: Kick Starting 'Gypsy': The ber Overture
description: CHRIS JAUDES has never seen ''Gypsy,'' though he performs what some call the biggest show-stopper in the musical. It doesn't actually stop the show; it starts it. He is the lead trumpet player in the production's 23-piece orchestra, and he plays the trumpet solo in the overture.

title: Paris in Full Color
description: THE Australian director Baz Luhrmann and his creative team are well aware of audiences' reaction to the first scene change in ''La Bohme.'' It occurs at the beginning of Act II, when the intimate black-and-white world of the doomed lovers on their rooftop at the end of Act I gives way to the chaotic streets of the Latin Quarter in Paris and a set that seems to have turned vibrant and full of color in the blink of an eye.

title: Broadway Enjoys Its Moment
description: The grand piano perched on a platform above Duffy Square yesterday morning should have been the first sign that producers of this year's Tony Awards ceremony were serious about breaking their show's extended ratings slump.

title: The Jersey Shore
description: It was 25 years ago that the singer Steve Lawrence stepped up to a craps table at the Resorts International Casino-Hotel and threw the first legal dice in Atlantic City. While some still rue the day casino gambling became legal there, it clearly changed what had become a dingy and dying town on the New Jersey Shore.

title: Pills
description: Runner-Up, Lives

title: Sports of The Times; Scott Is Overlooked Despite His Success
description: BYRON SCOTT is the most underrated head coach in the N.B.A. Three years as head coach of the Nets, back-to-back Eastern Conference championships, consecutive N.B.A. finals appearances. We're not talking about any franchise, mind you. We're talking about the Nets.

title: Take Me Out, Gracie, to Enchanged Brixton
description: THE setting of Rupert Holmes's biographical one-man play, ''Say Goodnight Gracie,'' is a kind of purgatory in which the comedian George Burns finds himself after his death in 1996 at the age of 100. Addressing God, he appears to be told to review his life in his own words, and if what he says is approved, he will join his wife and comic partner, Gracie Allen, who had died some years earlier. The title of the play refers to Burns's direction to Allen, at the end of their radio and television shows. In the production at the Helen Hayes Theater, directed by John Tillinger, Frank Gorshin plays Burns.

title: The World: Crossroads; Sharon Has a Map. Can He Redraw It?
description: ON a July day in 1979, a jeep bearing Israel's agriculture minister, Ariel Sharon, raced up a steep road to the West Bank settlement of Elon Moreh, where devout Jewish nationalists were explaining to me how Genesis contained their ancient ancestors' deed to this land from God.

title: Hip-Hop Mogul Puts on a Show to Oppose Rockefeller Drug Laws
description: In his newest incarnation as an agent for social change, the hip-hop impresario Russell Simmons need not appear at events he inspires. But many of those who did show up yesterday at what was billed as a ''Day of Action and Learning'' at the Public Theater on Lafayette Street in the East Village felt inclined or obliged to pay homage to the music Mr. Simmons promotes.

title: PRAISING ALLIANCE, BUSH ASKS EUROPE TO WORK WITH U.S.
description: President Bush affirmed today his commitment to the half-century relationship between Europe and the United States, but he indicated that he expected traditional allies that opposed him in the war on Iraq, like Germany and France, to conform to an American vision of a shared future.

title: Tax Cuts for Those Not in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: With Silver Bells and, Yes, Cilantro
description: ON a recent sunny day, Lucy Rivera stood with her friend and fellow gardener Janet Colon at the entrance to the Buena Vista Community Garden in Yonkers. From their vantage point by the chain-link fence, the two women surveyed rows of neat 4-by-8-foot raised beds set against the backdrop of the Hudson River and the New Jersey Palisades.

title: Ski Resorts For All Seasons
description: THIS time of year ski resorts morph into warm-weather playgrounds. Even with little or no snow, the spectacular scenery, the lifts and gondolas, and gravity's pull are still in play, encouraging mountain bikers, hikers and hang-gliders to challenge the mountains anew. Many resorts modify their equipment -- converting snowboard half-pipes to skateboard ramps, or toboggan slides to land luges -- or offer additional summertime activities like golf, tennis, water parks, kayaking or fly fishing. And many places now include year-round amenities like spas, wellness centers and children's camps.

title: Hope Wilson, Christopher Barton
description: Hope Graves Wilson, a daughter of Mr. and Frederick J. Wilson III of Wakefield, R.I., was married yesterday to Christopher Paul Barton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Blackshaw Barton of Oyster Bay Cove, N.Y. The Rev. Russell G. Ruffino performed the ceremony at St. Peter's by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Narragansett, R.I.

Joan was a light in every life she touched and will be remembered forever. >>AD#
