Lauren is mourned by her husband, Abdeladim Nouira; her daughter, Hanan Nouira; her mother, Ann Affriol; her brother, John Affriol; her sister-in-law, Hope Affriol; two nieces, Melinda Lauren and Patricia Ann Affriol, and her nephew, John Affriol Jr. Condolences may be sent to Affriol@AOL.com. >>AD#

title: Tomorrowland
description: Arthur Lubow's article ''How Architecture Rediscovered the Future'' described as ''stalled'' the Corcoran's plan for a building by Frank Gehry on its site across from the White House. However, although engineering surprises extended the initial design schedule, it has proceeded without interruption. So while we agree with your writer that the current economic climate is anything but helpful, we are confident that we will move forward on schedule as planned.

title: Christina Sharkey and Willie Geist
description: WHEN the families of William Russell Geist and Christina Elena Sharkey gathered in Puerto Rico for the couple's wedding last weekend, the bridegroom's father groused good-naturedly about his traditional role as dinner host for the out-of-town guests.

title: Climb. Slide. Lift. Fly. Repeat.
description: OF course John Selya gets tired.

title: Harvest of Campus Discards
description: What happens to all the junk left behind in college dormitories? Some of it is thrown away, of course, but a growing number of colleges and universities are holding their own giant yard sales. Money raised from the sale of furniture, never-worn clothing and unopened food often goes to charity. Last weekend, for instance, Penn State raised about $37,000 and gave $18,000 worth of food products to food banks, Fraser Grigor, the university's associate director for special projects, told The Associated Press.

title: Bicycle Builder Offers Guided Cycling Tours
description: This summer vacation season will be the first for Trek Travel, a division of the Trek Bicycle company that was launched last fall to operate cycling vacations in the United States, Canada and Europe. The trips use luxury hotels and restaurants and allow for different styles and levels of cycling. All participants are provided with the latest model of a road or hybrid Trek bicycle for use during the trip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GAULT, , MARK WILLIAM
description: GAULT -- Mark William. Passed away May 24th, 2003, at age 45. Beloved husband of Susie. Devoted father to Harry and Jack. He is survived by his parents, Phyllis and Jim, and by his brothers, Philip and Hugh. He was Worldwide Executive Vice President and Regional Director of McCann-Erickson North America, a position he assumed in January 2001. Previously he served as NY-based Director of Worldwide Accounts of McCann - Erickson World wide. Earlier, he was Chairman of McCann-Erickson Japan, the largest western agency in Japan and one of the largest agencies within the McCann-Erickson Worldwide network, and served as the agency's Asia Pacific Area Director as well. Previously he had been based in London, where he first joined the company, as head of the H.K. McCann/London agency and as a Director of Worldwide Accounts. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, June 3, at 3 PM, at Park Avenue Christian Church, at 1010 Park Avenue at 85th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made ''In memory of Mark Gault'' payable to the Collegiate School. Its address is 260 West 78th Street, New York, NY 10024, Attn: Development Office. >>AD#

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: It's a Sunny Day in Oklahoma This Time, O.K.?
description: AS the first theater in the country to get the rights to ''Oklahoma!'' since the dark, disappointing Broadway reinterpretation closed in March, the Gateway Playhouse here is paying no mind to the fashion of reinterpreting musicals by giving them sinister overtones. It has given us a sunny ''Oklahoma!''

title: JEFFERSON AND CLINTON WIN P.S.A.L. TITLES
description: Thomas Jefferson of Brooklyn won the boys' division and DeWitt Clinton of the Bronx won the girls' yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League's outdoor championships at St. John's University.

title: Corrections
description: A capsule guide with the Frugal Traveler column on May 11, about Cay Caulker in Belize, misstated the authors average daily expenses on her trip. They were $136, not $112.

title: Sabrina Kleier, Robert Morgenstern
description: Sabrina Whitney Kleier, a daughter of Michele and Ian Kleier of New York, was married on Thursday to Robert Adam Morgenstern, the son of Marsha and Martin Morgenstern of Holmdel, N.J. Rabbi David Posner officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Switzerland, Usually Calm, Erupts in Protest of G-8 Talks
description: This story was reported by Elaine Sciolino, John Tagliabue, Helene Fouquet and Alison Langley and was written by Ms. Sciolino.

title: Private Sector; English Major Makes Good on Wall Street
description: At the annual dinner of the Harvard Business School Club of Greater New York at the Waldorf-Astoria on Thursday, Henry M. Paulson Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Goldman Sachs Group, fell back on his college skills to deliver a speech that -- gasp! -- he had written himself.

title: Red-Sauce Singing
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Help Is on the Way
Going Uptown Down the Shore
description: GWEN PASTORELLI was thrilled to sell Cynthia Hartwig on this once-sleepy village in the shadow of Asbury Park that was better known as a staid Methodist retreat. It wasn't scripture, however, that lured Ms. Hartwig, who had been a cook at one of Philadelphia's premier seafood restaurants, to this shore community. It was the smell of success.

title: Take Me Out, Gracie, to Enchanged Brixton
description: IT may be a combination of Italian sunshine and wisteria blossoms, but the four women who rent a castle on the Mediterranean in Matthew Barber's ''Enchanted April'' fall deeply under the spell of their surroundings. The play, which takes place after World War I and is based on the novel ''The Enchanted April'' by Elizabeth von Arnim, is currently at the Belasco Theater, directed by Michael Wilson. In this scene, Lotty Wilton (portrayed by Jayne Atkinson) has asked her husband, Mellersh (Michael Cumpsty), an English lawyer, to come to the castle, owned by Antony Wilding (Michael Hayden).

title: Sand Is More Plentiful Than Sense
description: AS we head into another summer, the beaches have big problems. Half of Parking Field 5 at Robert Moses State Park is closed, maybe for the summer. Suffolk County has closed Smith Point outer beach to campers and recreational fishermen. The T.W.A. Flight 800 memorial is threatened by erosion. Houses have been lost at Dunewood on Fire Island.

title: Lisa Rufolo, Carmen LaBruno,
description: Lisa Mary Rufolo, a lawyer, was married yesterday to Carmen Victor LaBruno, the chief of police in Hoboken, N.J. The Rev. Fred Lentz performed the ceremony at St. Matthew Trinity Lutheran Parish Church in Hoboken.

title: Press Looks at Failure to Find Banned Weapons
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  Prime Minister Tony Blair faced sharp criticism today over the failure, to date, of American and British efforts to find weapons of mass destruction in Iraq, but senior United States senators of both parties said the invasion was nonetheless justified.

title: For the Job Hunt? Consider Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Huntington's Renaissance Faire Goes Dark
description: TWAS like a page out of history. Maidens crowned with flowery wreaths danced around a maypole. Knights in shining armor jousted and fenced in a verdant glen. A king and queen in regal finery paraded around their castle grounds, accompanied by a royal court. Despite the gray skies, the annual Renaissance Faire at the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship in Huntington shimmered through the mist like Camelot.

title: A Stately Span, a Fatal Lure
description: THE soaring majesty of the Brooklyn Bridge attracts thousands of admiring visitors every year, but that grandeur also lures dozens who seek out the bridge only to jump off its towers.

title: Tax Cuts for Those Not in Need
description: To the Editor:

title: Private Sector; It's Not Easy Being Green When You're Deep in the Red
description: Environmentalists once praised William Clay Ford Jr., the chairman of Ford Motor, for making pro-environmental pronouncements on issues generally off limits in Detroit, like global warming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBLUM, , ANNA
description: ROSENBLUM -- Anna. No vember 8, 1907-May 31, 2003. Formerly of Manhattan, late of Boca Raton, FL. Beloved wife of the late Murray, devoted mother to Richard and Carolyn and son-in-law Gary Koesten. Loving grandmother to Alan and Jared. She joins her husband, mother, father and two brothers in heaven. She will live on in the hearts of those she leaves behind, to be loved by them always. >>AD#

title: You Talkin' to Me? Less and Less These Days
description: Khadijah Davies could not help but let out a happy sigh last Wednesday as she stepped out of a yellow cab at 42nd Street and Eighth Avenues. Ms. Davies, a New Jersey resident in town for a convention, sighed because her taxi ride was so unexpectedly quiet.

title: In Vienna, Wild Kingdom Of Royalty
description: IN 1828, Vienna went mad over a giraffe. A gift from Egypt to the Imperial Menagerie at the palace of Schnbrunn -- the summer home of the Hapsburg monarchy -- the animal caused a sensation.

title: Amy Lilly, Prospero Gogo Jr.
description: Dr. Amy Margaret Lilly, a daughter of Barbara A. Lilly and Dr. Paul R. Lilly of Oneonta, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Prospero Barquero Gogo Jr., the son of Sylvia Regis Gogo and Dr. Gogo of Bradenton, Fla. Msgr. Paul E. Whitmore performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Wastepaper Camouflage
description: Sleek graphic paper bins from the Container Store are really just wastebaskets -- but wittily designed, nonetheless. They are made of matte translucent plastic with patterns that echo three classic types of lined paper: notebook, graph and computer readout. At $9.99 (containerstore.com), they are the perfect little end-of-the-school-year gift for teachers and tutors. After all, even when school isn't in session, neatness counts.

title: Trouts Abroad
description: FLY-FISHING

title: Colombia's Long Civil War Spreads Turmoil to Venezuela
description: More than ever, Colombia's 39-year-old civil war is spreading beyond its porous borders, bringing to its five neighbors a troubling brew of armed leftist rebels, right-wing death squads, drugs and refugees.

title: Italian Food Reveals Experienced Hand
description: YOU may not know the name Joseph Felicetta, but you very well could have tasted his food. Mr. Felicetta, the chef and owner of the newly opened Allegro in Sayville, has cooked in restaurants from Port Washington to East Setauket (Octopus Garden, Fusion Grill and Casa Rustica, among them). He was also the chef at the Bayport House when that restaurant was rated excellent in 2001.

title: Apollo and Orpheus, Glimpsed in Action
description: ''Pictures at a Virtual Exhibition''? It's clunkier than Mussorgsky's title for his mighty work, but it more or less captures the contents of three CD-ROM's issued by Culture 2000, a program of the European Union. The actual title is ''Images of Music: A Cultural Heritage.''

title: Quietly Expanding Our Nuclear Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Remodeling: Adventures in Inner Space
description: ''HOME improvement,'' according to a research report issued in February by Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies, ''has become the great national pastime.''

title: Arrests of Indian Teenagers Not Racially Motivated
description: Re ''Case That Won't Die Deepens Racial Split'' [May 25]: The article gave the impression that the Herricks community is divided along racial lines. Not every Indian resident perceives the arrests of 13 Indian youths at a Herricks school district playground as a racially motivated incident. The district staff called the police to prevent what was perceived to be a potentially serious situation, and the children just happened to be of Indian background.

title: A Memo to the Wachowskis From a Disappointed Fan
description: WHEN my 16-year-old son and I left the multiplex on opening night of ''The Matrix Reloaded,'' he shook his head in disappointment -- the same slow, sad gesture he'd made four years ago as we left the theater after seeing ''Star Wars: Episode 1 -- The Phantom Menace.'' No, the Wachowski brothers hadn't perpetrated anything as egregious as Jar-Jar Binks. But they had still dropped the ball, big time, and all that anticipation for ''The Matrix Reloaded'' now seemed like a bad fever dream.

title: Bush Presses Case on Iran and Korea at Economic Talks
description: EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, June 1  President Bush stepped onto French soil today to meet the European leaders who vociferously opposed the war in Iraq, but rather than rehash their differences he spent the day trying to increase pressure on two other nations he regards as major threats  Iran and North Korea  to give up their nuclear weapons programs.

title: This Film Festival Has Really Big Stars
description: TO celebrate its first birthday, the Cradle of Aviation Museum is going big -- real big -- with a film festival in its Imax Dome Theater.

title: The Winners
description: IN FEBRUARY, the editors of The Times Magazine, reviving an old tradition, invited high-school students across America to submit their original writing or photography for publication. The challenge behind the contest was to follow two formats seen in each week's edition of the magazine: a personal essay in the model of the Lives column or an image with accompanying text of the kind seen in the What They Were Thinking feature.

title: The Managerial Merry-Go-Round
description: Last winter 10 teams hired managers. Five of those teams had fired their managers after finishing in last place. One-third of the way through this season, all five of those teams are in last place. Three of the other five teams, on the other hand, are in first place, where none of them finished last season.

title: SAFETY BARRIERS SOUGHT
description: Two head-on accidents on Interstate 78 last weekend that killed four people and caused huge traffic jams prompted Transportation Commissioner Jack Lettiere to call for expanding a $15 million program to build new median barriers on some of the state's most treacherous highways. I-78, which runs from the Pennsylvania border to Newark, was one of the first roadways in the state to be fitted with the barriers, but there are none where the fatal accidents occurred, a transportation department spokeswoman said. Mr. Lettiere said he hoped to fit all of New Jersey's interstate highways with the guardrails, though the current plan finances them for only 100 miles of highway. Wendy Ginsberg

title: Stock Yields Are Higher Than Interest Rates. So What?
description: SEVERAL editors of investment newsletters have contended that stocks are undervalued, based on the market's current dividend yield. The argument, however, does not stand up to historical scrutiny.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-20

title: The Marketing of a Superbaby Formula
description: PARENTS who hire tutors to make sure their 3-year-olds can beat out the competition for the best nursery schools are now being told that the time to give their offspring an academic edge comes far, far earlier.

title: Ideas & Trends; The F.C.C. Gets Ready To Roll the Media Dice
description: IF all goes according to schedule, the five commissioners of the Federal Communications Commission will vote tomorrow on whether to relax the rules restricting the number, location and kind of media outlets one company may own in the United States. The three Republican commissioners have indicated they will support the changes, so they are expected to pass.

title: 'The Memory of All That'
description: Ican't claim it was love at first sight-not even from my side.

title: Arrow Electronics Cuts Work Force by 400
description: Arrow Electronics of Melville will cut about 400 jobs, or 3 percent of its global work force, the company said Wednesday. William E. Mitchell, the company's president and chief executive, called the cutbacks part of ''an evolutionary process critical to the success of Arrow.''

title: Music Listings
description: Classical/Opera

title: Clinging to His Coattails
description: DENNIS BASSO doesn't waste any time pretending he isn't just the tiniest bit famous. Last Wednesday night, at Cipriani on East 42nd Street, 800 people came to a party and a fashion show to celebrate his 20 years as a furrier, and Mr. Basso, who is to ranch mink what Liberace was to a candelabrum, swears he knows at least 750 of them on a first-name basis. There was Anna Wintour and Shelby Bryan. Rick and Kathy Hilton came, along with Lorraine Bracco, Helen Schifter and Denise Rich. Marjorie Gubelmann couldn't make it -- she was on her honeymoon -- but Donald Trump, Star Jones, Cindy Adams, Neil Sedaka and one Boardman sister did.

title: Take Me Out, Gracie, to Enchanged Brixton
description: NICHOLAS WRIGHT'S program note for his play ''Vincent in Brixton,'' which closed on May 4 at the Golden Theater, where it was directed by Richard Eyre, described the ''bits and pieces of evidence'' that place Vincent van Gogh as a boarder in London in 1873. Mr. Wright acknowledged, however, that the play ''goes much further than any biographer could in interpreting them.'' In this scene, Van Gogh (played by Jochum ten Haaf) quotes the French writer Jules Michelet as he talks with the widow Ursula Loyer (Clare Higgins), who has rented him a room in her house.

title: Fashion Tip: It's Cooler To Shed
description: THE sweltering, heat-seeking pantyhose. The necktie that envelops your sweaty neck like a noose. The stifling suit jacket that you would not dream of putting on until you are inside an air-conditioned building.

title: Perry Can Hold a Lead, Whatever the Conditions
description: Kenny Perry, the hottest player in golf, continued to play his way out of Annika Sorenstam's shadow today in the Memorial.

title: A Whodunit Wonders, So, Why Did He Do It?
description: THIS far into the pop-culture age, it's almost impossible to achieve ''riveting'' with a whodunit. So many movies, detective shows and page-turners have worked the format that it seems there are no surprises left; ''interesting'' is the best such fare is likely to manage.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Private Sector column last Sunday about Stars and Cars, a charity event in Detroit, misstated the career path of Robert A. Lutz, the co-chairman. He left Chrysler in 1998, then joined Exide Technologies; he was hired by General Motors in 2001 as a vice chairman. He did not join G.M. directly from Chrysler.

title: 2ND STUDY FINDS GAPS IN TAX CUTS
description: A new study by groups critical of the tax law that President Bush signed on Wednesday has found that 8 million mostly low-income taxpayers will not receive any benefit from the law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAUBEN, , ROBERT
description: HAUBEN--Robert, of Merrick, formerly of Fort Lee, at age 77, on May 23rd, 2003. Devoted father of Howard and Ronald. He was interred with his wife Ruth in Cedar Park Cemetery. >>AD#

title: The Foot Experts Are In
description: Ugly feet have apparently become a concern in the medical community, with doctors providing a sudden array of treatments and products to improve the looks of toes and ankles. Dr. Suzanne Levine, a New York podiatrist, offers a $225 Foot Facial, which includes a chemical peel, microdermabrasion and nail bleaching (212-535-0229). Those who prefer to tackle their toes at home can try a mentholated moisturizer called Foot Recovery Cream; it's by Dr. Ellen Gendler, a Manhattan dermatologist ($30; 800-223-7440). Tripod Labs, a company founded by three podiatrists, has come out with products for athlete's foot, nail fungus and other such ailments ($9.95 to $19.95 at www.tripodlabs.com). And Dr. Stuart Mogul, a foot surgeon in New York, goes a step further, with surgical makeovers for uneven toes, bulging bunions and other eyesores. Dr. Mogul's everyday tips can be found in his book, ''Perfect Feet'' (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, 2002), a quick big-picture guide to foot care, warts and all.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; Joys of Country Vacation Outlast a Single Summer
description: Kyliek Luke had a question of his own for the people from the Fresh Air Fund who had invited him on Tuesday to share his memories of his two-week vacation last year in upstate New York.

title: Evelyn Shen, Jason Tong
description: Evelyn Dawn Shen and Jason Ju-Chuan Tong were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Edward M. Halldorson at the Presbyterian Church of Chatham Township in Chatham, N.J.

title: Protesters On the Move, Geneva Shops Board Up
description: The Rolex store on Rodeo Drive here was not to be outdone by its neighbors.

title: Tomorrowland
description: An entire issue devoted to the new and to the future of architecture. Great! But all the examples still reflect traditional straight and square cubes within cubes. Not a single round dwelling in sight, except as possible ''temporary shelter'' in Problem Solver, by Seth Stevenson.

title: Laurie Manifold, Michael Pollak
description: Laurie Fraser Manifold and Michael Coghlan Pollak were married on Friday at the Municipal Building in Manhattan, where Jose Gonzalez, the chief of staff to the city clerk, officiated.

title: The World: Up in Smoke; The U.S. Bucks a Trend on Marijuana Laws
description: LAST week, Canada's governing Liberal Party introduced a bill that would decriminalize the possession of up to 15 grams of marijuana. ''Cannabis consumption is first and foremost a health matter,'' Justice Minister Martin Couchon declared. ''It should not result in criminal penalties.'' Under the new plan, a minor pot offense would be punished with a citation and a fine, much like a speeding ticket.

title: Memo to Barbie: You Aren't The Only Model Ken Knows
description: APOLOGIES to Barbie, but if her new best friend, Fashion Insider Ken, is so deep inside then how come he looks like a frump?

title: ARCHDIOCESE CUTS STAFF
description: In a rare move, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark has laid off employees in an effort to close a $3.5 million deficit in its $40 million budget. Forty-four of its 250 employees, or about 18 percent, were let go. The archdiocese includes 235 parishes and 173 schools, as well as its administrative offices in Newark. A spokesman attributed the shortfall to the poor economy. He said a furlough was last considered in the 1970's but was not imposed then. Karen DeMasters

title: Riding Around With the Car Broke Down
description: EVERY night in ''Movin' Out,'' John Selya may impress dance enthusiasts with his athletic barrel turns and double sauts de basque, but the best he gets out of the stage crew is ''Great driving, John.''

title: Keep Your Tired, Your Poor, Your Huddled Masses
description: STAR OF THE SEA

title: Commencement Speeches; Reflections on War, Peace, and How to Live Vitally and Act Globally
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: In the Glow Of the Planetarium
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Tuesday? Good Luck
description: AN imposing man, a grizzly bear in a leather jacket, stood sentry outside a black door on a side street here on a recent Friday night. Three young guys with matching spiky haircuts approached and grinned up at him. He didn't crack a smile. ''Itchy and Scratchy,'' said the bravest of the bunch. The bouncer chuckled at the password -- they were friends of the D. J. -- and let the three pass.

title: Award for Times Reporter
description: Elisabeth Rosenthal, Beijing correspondent of The New York Times, has been awarded the first Osborn Elliott Prize for Excellence in Asian Journalism.

title: Why Is Jonathan Simms Still Alive?
description: If Arthur Caplan, a medical ethicist, thinks that ''sometimes there is a choice worse than death,'' he is free to sign an advance directive specifying that he not be kept alive under such conditions. But where does he come off trying to impose this choice on people who object to it?

title: Tigers Hurt Weaver's Bid To Remain Yanks Starter
description: Jeff Weaver looked, sounded and acted like a tortured soul in a quiet clubhouse this afternoon, the portrait of an exasperated pitcher fighting for his job. He sat in a blue chair while reporters stood around him, his expression glum, his eyes like slits and his answers mostly brief. Weaver had been searching on the mound and continued to do so near his locker.

title: TORRICELLI APPOINTED
description: Former United States Senator Robert G. Torricelli has been named to oversee a court-ordered environmental cleanup at a property in Jersey City. His appointment as a special master was made by a federal district judge who found that the owner of the property, Honeywell International, was responsible for removing chromium-contaminated soil left by a previous occupant of the site. Mr. Torricelli, who described the project as ''staggering in scope,'' will be paid by Honeywell at a rate to be determined by the court. He returned to private life in January, having abandoned a re-election campaign amid persistent questions about his dealings with a wealthy campaign contributor. The Senate ethics committee admonished Mr. Torricelli last summer for accepting gifts from the donor, but he was never charged with wrongdoing. Laura Mansnerus

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Budget Sows Confusion in Local Schools
description: WHEN the Uniondale school district got the news that it was losing $2.6 million in state aid, educators prepared a budget with a proposed tax increase of 7.5 percent. But when $1.7 million was restored to the district at the end of April, the tax increase was reduced by almost 3 percentage points.

title: Central Park's Golden Age
description: If a well-tended park can bring to mind the gaudy spring of Shakespeare's sonnet, Central Park summons an epic of Homeric proportions. Taken all at once, it is grand, sweeping, nearly overwhelming. Fortunately, it is also digestible in small, delicious bites.

title: Costa Passes Yet Another Test of Endurance
description: Continuing his endurance march away from the main stage of the French Open, Albert Costa of Spain might have outdone himself tonight in a third-round match against Nicolas Lapentti of Ecuador.

title: In the Heat of the Day
description: IF Consolidated Edison has its way, the only Westchester residents with total control of summertime temperatures at home will be the ones who aim their fans at big chunks of ice.

title: Nancy Fann, Paul Im
description: Nancy Fann, the daughter of Jane J. Y. Fann of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Kuan-Huei Fann of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Paul Im, the son of Kum Jong Im of Jackson Heights and the late Sun Bin Im. The Rev. Gabriel Lee, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Raphael in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Masaki Hidaka, Richard Clattenburg
description: Masaki Hidaka, the daughter of Masano and Yoshiki Hidaka of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Richard Norris Clattenburg, a son of Ellen Clattenburg and Dr. Richard Clattenburg Jr. of Perkinsville, Vt. The Rev. R. Douglas Pitt, a retired Episcopal priest, officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Opera Fan, Bocelli Fan
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lure of the Roof
description: WHEN I first saw the house I ended up buying, I was greeted with a puzzle in the form of a short metal wall surrounding a flat portion of the roof. Before asking the requisite questions about gas versus oil and the existence of a sump pump, I inquired about the mystery wall and was told that the woman who lived there liked to sunbathe on tar beaches but was wary of rolling off the roof as she did.

title: Sharon Laments 'Occupation' And Israeli Settlers Shudder
description: The newspaper headline that caught the rabbi's eye was a pun on Shalom Ahshav, the Hebrew name of one of Israel's most dovish groups, Peace Now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOSS, , NEYSA. (NEE POST)
description: MOSS--Neysa. (nee Post) May 21, 2003 in London. Survived by her loving husband, Bernard, adoring son David and devoted sister Rosalyn Doggett and by her many dear friends and relatives in London, Auckland and the U.S. including her mother-inlaw Lillian Moss, brothers-inlaw Kenneth Doggett and Franklin Moss, sister-in-law Nancy Sills and nieces Laura and Naomi Doggett, Joanna Moss and Hannah Hammel. A creative artist, an awardwinning book designer, a kind, thoughtful and wise woman. We will miss her. >>AD#

title: Harvard Captures I.R.A. Title
description: In its fourth attempt in 107 years, Harvard's varsity heavyweight crew finally won the only collegiate rowing title missing from its list of accomplishments, the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's national championship.

title: The Spurs' Geezers Give All They've Got
description: P. J. Carlesimo was grasping, trying to figure out how a 37-year-old bench player could so dramatically alter the Western Conference finals. He ran his fingers through his full beard, then through his hair, before he finally yelled across the locker room.

title: In This Pool, a Single Lap Is a Workout
description: After the last boxcar rumbled along the High Line in 1980, imagination began riding the rails.

title: 'Public Places'
description: Naples Airport and I'm frightened. Coming after the black winter months in London and the weeks of filming on the icy Suffolk coast, the March light of Italy is blinding me. And the noise is confusing me. London and its airport must have been busy but I feel that we have emerged from near silence into this aggressive, lighthearted tumult. Years of disciplined dieting have left me stick-thin and as I shuffle the travel papers and passports and begin to worry about the baggage, I am aware that there's nothing much in the way of protection between my flame and the demands that are being made on it by this expedition. No ordinary journey for me or for the tall figure standing a little to the side, detached, aloof and rather grand but in fact carefully positioned so as not to be conspicuous and finding the place of maximum safety in this press of people. If I'm scared, he must be terrified. Not that he's showing it. Only a slight over-stillness and a too-studied air of relaxation betray him.

title: Nonstop Nosegays
description: Cascades of flowers, both real and artificial, are the ornament of choice this season for clothes and accessories alike. At Louis Vuitton, a pink rubber dress is decorated with clusters of rubber and tulle blossoms, recalling bathing caps of a bygone era -- sweet yet subversive (not to mention expensive: $6,150).

title: COOKING
description: In those hazy months after Sept. 11, as America's culinary dialogue downshifted into comfort-food mode -- code beige, Tom Ridge might have called it -- it was easy to start asking yourself: if we're all eating B.L.T.'s and macaroni and cheese, have the terrorists won?

title: Instead of Beating Ducks, Devils Eat Crow
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 31  In the first-class cabin of a flight from New Jersey to California on Friday, one of the items on the dinner menu was roasted duck. But when a passenger chose that entree, the flight attendant said there was none of it left.

title: Editors' Note; A Note to Readers
description: After today, For Better, For Worse, a column by Lois Smith Brady that periodically updates the lives of a couple who have been profiled in the Vows column, will appear in the Weddings/Celebrations pages of Sunday Styles.

title: TREFFINGER TRIAL TO START
description: Guilty pleas were entered last week by three men who are expected to testify against former Essex County Executive James W. Treffinger at his federal corruption trial, which is set to start on Tuesday. Michael DeMiro, who was special counsel to Mr. Treffinger, pleaded guilty to conspiring to obstruct justice. Matthew J. Kirnan, campaign treasurer, pleaded guilty to tax evasion. And Cosmo Cerrigone, a political supporter who was Mr. Treffinger's barber, pleaded guilty to accepting a salary for a no-show job of styling hair for patients at a county hospital. The judge in the case, John W. Bissell, ruled earlier last week that it would be heard at one trial, not two. A week earlier, after defense attorneys had asked for a postponement, the judge had proposed severing the case to limit the length of the trial. George James

title: Thanks, W. ('68)!
description: George W. Bush and the Class of 1968 celebrated their 35th reunion last week at the White House. From the alumni notes we've received, it sounds as if it was quite a night!

title: Classics, Updated

title: DINING IN
description: The cover photo of FOREVER SUMMER (Hyperion, $35) -- no, it's not a Beach Boys album but a new cookbook by Nigella Lawson, who now contributes a column to the Dining section of The New York Times -- shows her offering two handfuls of ripe tomatoes along with a sly come-hither look. And Lawson's fourth book is most inviting indeed, an eclectic collection of dishes designed to keep you feeling beachy-keen all year long. Her itinerary is mostly Mediterranean, including meze dishes (halloumi cheese flatbread pizza; grilled eggplant rolled around a feta, red chili and mint filling) and pasta dishes (penne with asparagus, lemon, garlic and parsley) that evoke the essence of summer. A Moroccan roast lamb features a wildly aromatic spice mix that promises to float you off on a waft of flavor. For the most part, though, Lawson favors lightness and simplicity. And color. The pages of her book are asplash with vivid hues, from the bold cerulean of a Curaao Blue Lagoon cocktail to the flecks of lime zest in a Margarita ice cream to the golden, turmeric-spiked broth of a lemon squash soup she calls, simply, ''Happiness.''

Before working at Buxton, he had been co-director of his family's boarding school, the former Manumit School in Pennsylvania in the 1940's. He taught at Buxton until he became ill a year ago. During the period of his illness, and long hospitalization, and after his return, Ben was marvelously alert, positive, irreverent and witty. In short, he was Ben-right up to the end. He leaves his wife, the former Magdalene Joslyn; a son, Dr. Graeme Fincke of Cambridge, MA; two daughters, Magdalene Sears of NYC, and Catherine Fincke of Brooklyn, NY; a step-daughter Mary Lathrop of NYC, and four grandchildren. He also leaves several nieces and nephews. Contributions in memory of Mr. Fincke may be made to the Buxton School for the Benjamin G. C. Fincke Scholarship Fund, 291 South St, Williamstown, MA 01267. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM, on Sunday, June 15th at the First Congregational Church in Williamstown. A reception at Buxton School will follow. >>AD#

title: George W. Bush and the Poet
description: GIVEN that the artistic muse of the Clinton administration was Linda Bloodworth-Thomason, the creator of the sitcom ''Designing Women,'' George W. Bush's appointment of Bo Derek to the board of the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts could hardly be faulted for breaking with tradition. Ever since Abraham Lincoln overruled his advisers to attend ''Our American Cousin,'' culture has been considered ladies' work in Washington -- first ladies' work. It was Jacqueline Kennedy who brought Pablo Casals to the East Room, not her husband, who celebrated his inaugural with a command performance by the Rat Pack. It is Laura Bush who invites writers to the White House, not the president, whose inaugural concert featured Andrew Lloyd Webber, Ricky Martin and Wayne Newton. (Where was Barry Manilow when the country needed him?)

title: How I Learned to Love Quotas
description: Not long ago, I had an unexpected opportunity to explain to Justice Sandra Day O'Connor why I've changed my mind about affirmative action. I had been invited to give a talk about racial preferences for the justices of the Supreme Court of India, who were in Washington on a judicial exchange program. When I arrived at the conference room, I found, to my surprise and alarm, that the assembled Indian justices were accompanied by their hosts, Justices O'Connor and Stephen G. Breyer, who decided at the last moment to come along for the discussion. The thought of presuming to give an academic lecture about affirmative action in front of the woman who represents the swing vote on the Rehnquist Court -- and who will soon decide the fate of affirmative action in America -- was too harrowing to contemplate. So I abandoned my notes and chose instead to appeal to O'Connor in personal terms, describing why I had long been skeptical of affirmative action in higher education and why I recently have come to support it -- not for moral or social reasons but for purely practical ones.

title: PRESCRIPTION DRUG BAN KILLED

Prescription drugs in Canada, where prices are regulated, often sell for one third to one half the cost in the United States. Karen DeMasters

title: GARDENING
description: Regarding the garden: whether I am in doubt, whether I am certain, when I am overly pleased with the arrangement of the disaster lying on the ground in front of me, when I am made sad by my ignorance which lead to the disaster lying on the ground in front of me, I turn to a book. A book about the garden is a gardener's best friend. Another gardener is not a gardener's best friend. Another gardener is very complicated. Other gardeners have all sorts of opinions about your garden, about their garden, about somebody else's garden and they are not afraid to voice them. And then again, another gardener in your garden, this whole relationship will be brimming over with feelings. They love yellow flowers so very much, you love blue flowers so very much; you both then try to love red flowers only a little. On it goes, so exhausting. Not so with my best garden friend, the garden book.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUTNER, , S.H.
description: HUTNER--S.H. 91, passed away June 1, 2003. Seymour Hutner received his undergraduate degree from City College in 1931 and his Ph.D. from Cornell University in 1937, with studies in microbiology, biochemistry and botany. Dr. Hutner worked at Haskins Laboratories, a non-profit research laboratory that has been located at Pace University since 1970, from 1940 until illness forced his retirement in 1998. Among his many research interests, he was a leader in the nutrition of protozoa. He also was a founder and very active member of the Society of Protozoologists and helped to train many high school and college students at Haskins Labs. Hundreds of scientists and physicians owe their first experience with science to him. Dr. Hutner is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Reed and Kathleen Hutner, who live in Baltimore; and was predeceased by his first wife, Reina, and his second wife, Margarita. title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: WIDER INQUIRY SOUGHT IN WOMAN'S DEATH Civil rights activists demanded yesterday that the Police Department examine whether no-knock search warrants and stun grenades are used more frequently against blacks and other minority residents. They also said the practices of the prosecutors and judges who deal with no-knock warrants should be examined. The demand came two days after an internal police report detailed mistakes that led to the May 16 police raid in which a stun grenade was tossed into the Harlem apartment of a black woman, Alberta Spruill, 57, who suffered a fatal heart attack. Her death has been ruled a homicide. Norman Siegel, a civil rights lawyer, and the police group 100 Blacks in Law Enforcement Who Care called on the department to release racial and ethnic data in the use of no-knock warrants and stun grenades. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POWERS, , WILLIAM DOYLE
description: POWERS -- William Doyle. Retired attorney with the Bell System. A lifelong resident of Manhattan. Died on May 30, 2003, after an extended illness. He was 74. Mr. Powers was a 1950 graduate of Fordham University and received his bachelor's and master's degrees in law from New York University School of Law. From 1957 to 1990 he practiced law with several law firms and corporations, serving as general counsel for Nassau Recycling Corporation, an AT&T subsidiary headquartered in Columbia, SC. Mr. Powers was an independent equity trader from 1990 to 1993, when he retired. Surviving are his wife of 40 years, Marie Wallace Powers, two sons, Corbett and Christopher, and a brother, Richard of Baltimore, MD. A Knight of Malta since 1989, Mr. Powers was active in a number of charitable and civic organizations, including on the Boards of Casita Maria and Marymount College from 1961 to 1965. He was a cofounder of Pregnancy Help, Inc., and served on its Board of Directors and as Vice President since 1994. In 1993 Mr. Powers became a member of the Board of Directors of the Patrons of the Vatican Museum in Rome, Italy. An avid golfer, he and his family summered at Buck Hills Falls, PA, and was a member of its country club for many years. He recently joined the Lost Tree Golf and Country Club in Palm Beach, FL. Visiting at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Ave at 81 St, will be on Sunday from 7-9 PM, and on Monday from 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass will be at 10 AM, on Tuesday, at St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and 83rd Street. >>AD#

title: Disparate Views Emerge Over North Korean Nuclear Strength
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 2  Conflicting statements by a senior Pentagon official, United States congressmen returning from Pyongyang and South Koreas president deepened the sense of uncertainty today about the Korean nuclear standoff and prospects for war or peace on the Korean Peninsula. At issue was how far North Korea had gone in developing nuclear weapons, the degree to which it was bluffing and the depth of the United States basic commitment to South Koreans veering between insecurity about their defenses and uncertainty about United States intentions mingled with edginess about the continued American military presence. President Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea caught the mood in ambivalent remarks timed for the 100th day of his presidency in which he seemed to dispute United States intelligence estimates that the North has one or two nuclear warheads. Although North Korea had told American officials that it had developed nuclear weapons and reprocessed spent fuel rods, Mr. Roh said in remarks broadcast by Korean television networks, the North "has not confirmed that to anyone else." The deputy secretary of defense, Paul Wolfowitz, said after seeing Mr. Roh that such uncertainty reinforced the need for "some way to verify what we know and those things we don't know." In the meantime, he said, "What we know suggests we should take what they say very seriously." Representative Curt Weldon, Republican of Pennsylvania and vice chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, stopping here after leading six members of Congress on a visit to Pyongyang, reflected the the impressions that North Korea has been spreading in recent months of both its nuclear potential and its desire for dialogue with the United States. Senior North Korean officials had not only admitted having nuclear weapons, he said, but had confirmed they were expanding their nuclear weapons program and moreover had almost finished reprocessing 8,000 spent fuel rods. That claim, if correct, would enable the North to build several more nuclear warheads in a matter of months. The disparate views of North Korean nuclear strength underlined major differences among influential Americans, and also between the United States and South Korea, over how to respond to the North Korean threat in terms of a buildup of forces in the South, aid to North Korea and negotiations toward a brand new agreement under which the North would again promise to renounce nuclear weapons. Some analysts believe the resulting tensions form the prelude to a new chapter in which North Korea's economic difficulties may also help decide the outcome. "We always talk about a critical juncture," said Kent Calder, director of Korean studies at Johns Hopkins University's School of Advanced International Studies in Washington, D.C. "We are clearly on the eve of something major. This year will be the beginning. It's juche twilight" -- a reference to the fading power of North Korea's philosophy of juche, meaning self-reliance. Some of the differences were clear from the contrast between the unbridled optimism reflected by the congressmen, including both Republicans and Democrats, and the preparations outlined by Mr. Wolfowitz for what he said would be a "united, immediate and devastatingly effective" answer to North Korean attack. Mr. Weldon said he and his congressional colleagues had left Pyongyang "hugging our hosts" after having managed "to interact as friends and human beings with the people and the leaders of North Korea." Although they did not meet the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, Mr. Weldon said, they had "extensive and lengthy meetings" with senior North Korean officials in which they had raised the issues of North Korean nuclear weapons, missiles and human rights "in a spirit of assuring the North Koreans that we can prevent the crisis" from "escalating into a nuclear war." He was convinced, he said, that "there is a window of opportunity" in which it should be possible to reach agreement with the North "without having to resort to military conflict." North Korean officials, he said, "feel let down" that they had not had the chance for "bilateral talks" with the United States, possibly in the context of multilateral talks. Mr. Weldon's remarks diverged sharply from United States efforts, promoted by Mr. Wolfowitz here and by President Bush at the Group of 8 meeting in France, at convincing North Korea there would be no alternative to five-party talks involving China, Russia, Japan and South Korea as well as the United States. Mr. Bush, after meeting China's president, Hu Jin Tao, said United States policy "hasn't changed" on the need to have all powers in the region at the negotating table. Mr. Wolfowitz outlined a program on the future of the American-Korean alliance that the United States command here has said will entail an $11 billion overhaul of American defense for South Korea. Any changes, he said, would necessarily affect the Second Infantry Division, a force of 16,000 troops, nearly half the 37,000 United States troops in the country, astride the invasion route between here and the line with North Korea, 30 miles to the north. It was time, he said, "to move beyond outmoded concepts or catch phrases such as the term 'tripwire,' " asSouth Koreans often describe the role of American forces in case of North Korean attack.Rather than keep a large force in one place, he said, "We place a great premium on mobility, and on the ability to move great distances rapidly." Mr. Wolfowitz was surprisingly critical of South Korea, however, for not contributing enough to its own defense. "South Korea could certainly do more," he said, observing that South Korea's defense budget was only about 2.7 percent of its gross national product of approximately $500 billion. "We're in this together, allies together," he said. "We're investing to increase our capabilities," adding "South Korea could do the same."

Exports in the month totaled $6.37 billion, compared with $3.87 billion in imports. A slide in Brazil's currency, the real, against the dollar and the dollar's weakness against the euro have helped Brazil's trade balance. The new left-leaning government is also promoting exports to compensate for the decline in foreign investment. description: WestPoint Stevens Inc., a maker of towels and bedding, filed for bankruptcy protection and said its chief executive, Holcombe T. Green Jr., had resigned as part of a plan to reorganize more than $2.1 billion in debt. The company, which makes Ralph Lauren Home, Martha Stewart and Joe Boxer bedding and bath products, has lost more than $103 million since 2001. The company, which is based in WestPoint, Ga., named its president, M. L. Fontenot, to replace Mr. Green. It listed $1.33 billion in assets and $2.16 billion in debts in Chapter 11 papers filed on Sunday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. WestPoint Stevens has arranged a $300 million loan from Bank of America N.A. to help finance its reorganization. New independent members will be added to the board of directors, the company said.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Sunday about college commencement addresses and a roundup of excerpts referred incorrectly to a speech by Kofi Annan, secretary general of the United Nations.

title: HOSPITALS FEARING MALPRACTICE CRISIS
description: A quirk in New York State law, a $140 million malpractice judgment and a recent ruling by the state's highest court have hospitals and insurers saying that malpractice premiums for hospitals are about to soar, and they are petitioning the Legislature to change the law.

title: It's Boeing Vs. Airbus In Big Battle Over Brazil
description: With a merger of Brazil's two leading airlines, Varig and TAM, now a near-certainty, the battle lines are being drawn between Boeing and Airbus Industrie over who will supply aircraft to the merged carrier, which will be Latin America's largest by far.

title: Unusual Use of DNA Aided in Serial Killer Search
description: In what appears to be the first use of DNA to extract details of a criminal suspect's appearance, investigators in the case of the Louisiana serial killer shifted their focus away from white suspects after an analysis of tissue from one of the crime scenes determined that the killer was probably black, the developer of the genetic test says.

title: Pakistani Legislators Approve Islamic Law for Province
description: The provincial assembly here, dominated by an alliance of religious parties, voted unanimously today to introduce Islamic law to the North-West Frontier Province, fulfilling an election promise that has worried the national government and its American allies.

title: Extension Of Rent Laws Finds Support
description: The last time that New York's rent laws were about to expire, in 1997, the battle in Albany was one of the testiest and most dramatic in years. Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the State Senate, vowed to eliminate the entire system, and tenant groups warned of widespread chaos, before an agreement was struck just hours after the laws expired.

title: Sports of The Times; Facts on the Ground As the Tour Churns
description: TOUCHED down at Charles de Gaulle early yesterday morning to the eye-opening headlines that Venus Williams and Jennifer Capriati had exited the singles draw of the French Open on Sunday, furthering my growing belief that significant change is in the air on the women's tennis tour.

title: Glamour Takes Another Peek At the Era of the Pinup
description: When fashion writers talk about glamour, it is never very clear what they mean. By proposing satin pencil skirts and rolled hair, do they expect that women -- with real jobs, time constraints and no Stork Club to run to -- will pay attention?

title: Newburgh Wins Four Events in Bronx
description: Newburgh (N.Y.) High School, led by Elize Coleman, won four events yesterday in the 47th annual Eastern States boys' interscholastic championships at Mount St. Michael Field in the Bronx. Coleman ran a personal best time of 21.66 seconds in winning the 200-meter dash and later anchored the Newburg 4x200 relay to first place in a swift 1 minute 27.12 seconds. The upstate New York school, with Jason Pearson on anchor, also won the 4x400 relay in 3:20.99 and the 100-meter dash with Mike Riullano in 11.11 seconds.

title: Yankees Name Jeter Captain
description: The Yankees named Derek Jeter today as their first team captain since 1995, announcing the appointment at a news conference before the first of three games against the Reds in Cincinnati.

title: Chill Therapy for Failing Hearts
description: Treating comatose heart attack victims by cooling them down, a relatively new practice, is effective because the cold not only slows the damage caused by the disruption of blood flow, but it also promotes the release of healing chemicals in the brain, a new study has found.

title: A Poet Raging Against Pretension (and Princeton)
description: THERE are dining room people and there are kitchen people. Gerald Stern is a kitchen person. He writes on a Formica table, looking on the languid waters of the Delaware River, which he calls his inspiration. He eats there. And he fulminates over the stove as the coffee bubbles up into his little Italian coffee maker, railing against the abstract wordsmiths whose linguistic dexterity mask soulless writing.

title: A New Twist at Lincoln Center
description: When Lincoln Center first began mapping its renovation a few years ago, its ambitious objectives -- and an initial price tag of $1.5 billion -- seemed to guarantee that its resident artistic organizations would all be staying put. Even the New York City Opera, long unhappy at the New York State Theater, was talking about building a new hall on campus. But the Metropolitan Opera opposed the idea of a new theater for City Opera, and ever since 9/11 the campuswide renovation has been steadily scaled back. Now the New York Philharmonic, one of the original occupants of Lincoln Center, intends to move to Carnegie Hall as soon as scheduling commitments allow, perhaps as soon as the 2006-2007 season.

title: MEMO PAD
description: Getting to Kabul Could Be All the Fun

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BEIL, , BARBARA
description: BEIL--Barbara. Seems like only yesterday, three years have passed. Rest in peace. Always in my heart. Shelly >>AD#

title: Manufacturing Showed Gains Last Month
description: Manufacturing activity increased in May, suggesting that the worst may be over for factories that slowed production during the war in Iraq, an industry report showed yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Seed Unit Sold
description: A onetime conglomerate, Savia, said it was selling 75 percent of its Seminis unit, the world's largest producer of fruit and vegetable seeds, to Fox Paine & Company, a private equity firm in San Francisco. Savia, which is based in Monterrey, Mexico, will receive $260 million for its shares. The sale of Seminis, which is in Oxnard, Calif., brings an end to the conglomerate, which was built by Alfonso Romo Garza, above, a Monterrey businessman. Mr. Romo Garza has been forced to sell his companies, including Mexico's largest insurance company, to pay off debt. He will continue as chairman and chief executive of Seminis. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PEROT SYSTEMS CORP., Plano, Tex., a computer services company, signed a 10-year contract with Blue Cross & Blue Shield of Rhode Island, a health insurer, worth at least $570 million for overseeing cash disbursements to vendors and claims processing.

title: Talking the Talk
description: To the Editor:

title: M.R.I. Could Prove Superior to Mammography
description: Another form of medical imaging appears to be better than mammography at detecting nascent tumors in women with a high risk of contracting breast cancer, scientists said here today.

title: Shows' Creators Say Television Will Suffer In New Climate
description: Hollywood writers and producers said yesterday's decision by the Federal Communications Commission to relax media ownership rules would damage the quality and creativity of network television by concentrating program development into fewer and fewer hands.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: DANGEROUS HEAT Children in Calcutta, above, cooled off in a canal of the River Hooghly as a heat wave continued. It has killed nearly 1,000 people across the country in the past three weeks, relief officials said. Most of those have been in southern Andhra Pradesh State. In the worst-hit district of Nalgonda, temperatures soared to 120 degrees in some places, said a top district administrator, Ram Prakash Sisodia.    (AP)

title: Sinkhole Closes Section of a Colorado Interstate
description: Floodwaters in Colorado have left a giant sinkhole in the middle of a major highway in the mountains and hundreds of residents of Vail cleaning up their water- and mud-soaked homes.

title: Senate Panel Inquiry on Iraq Weapons
description: With questions persisting about the failure to find unconventional weapons in Iraq, Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia and chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said today that his panel would conduct hearings this month on the issue.

title: Sticking Together, but Never Getting Too Close
description: Diane Coburn Bruning knows the value of music performed live for dance. All eight of the pieces presented by her Chamber Dance Project on May 28 at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College in Manhattan were accompanied by live music, a pleasure in itself. Ms. Bruning also knows how to put together movement and get the most from her dancers.

title: Lemieux Won't Leave Penguins
description: By The New York Times

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRESCHER, , MAYER
description: DRESCHER--Mayer. 91, died peacefully June 2. Devoted husband to Dora, loving father to Sol, Jack, and Murry. Loving father-in-law to Anne, and cherished Zayde of Daniel, David, Rebecca and Benjamin. Beloved brotherin-law of Bea and Martin Gayer. From Krastnystaw, Poland, he escaped the Nazi invasion, survived Siberian labor camps and war years in Buchara, Uzbekistan. Lost his parents, Yisrael and Esther, and sisters Chana and Rachel in the Shoah. Emigrated to Brooklyn in 1949 where he created a family that grew and flourished. Faithfully served as long time secretary, First Krastnystawer Benevolent Society. Retired to Sunrise, FL. Funeral services: June 3, 9:15 am, Star of David Funeral Home, North Lauderdale, FL. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRANEFIELD, , PAUL F., JR.
description: CRANEFIELD--Paul F., Jr., died May 31, 2003, age 78, after a brief illness. Son of the late Paul F. Cranefield and Edna Rothnick Cranefield, of Madison, Wisconsin. M.D., PhD., retired professor, Rockefeller University. Editor of The Journal of General Physiology from 1966 to 1995, where he worked incessantly to promote and publish studies at the interface between biology, chemistry and physics to obtain insights into fundamental mechanisms that underlie biological function at all levels. Medical historian and author of Science and Empire: East Coast Fever in Rhodesia and the Transvaal and Born Wanderer: The Life of Stanley Portal Hyatt. A founding director and supporter of La Mama Experimental Theatre, and at his death, Chair of The Kesselring Prize for playwrights at The National Arts Club. Avid bibliophile and collector, friend of the Rare Book Room at The New York Academy of Medicine, member of the Grolier Club, as well as The Century, Players, The Coffee House and Savile Club. Noted expert on authentic Hawaiian poi; seeker of balm in Gilead. Survived by several cousins. Interment in Rock Lake Cemetery, Lake Mills, Wisconsin. Memorial gathering in New York to be announced. >>AD#

title: Brighter Side Emerges With Age
description: Older people forget unpleasant images more quickly than positive ones, according to a study published yesterday.

title: Dayne Is Ready For Giants' Program
description: The Giants' off-season conditioning program could best be described as mandatory voluntary. Although veteran players are not required by contract to attend, an unexcused absence would leave them to contend with an angry coach.

title: Martha Stewart Expecting Federal Indictment on Criminal Charges
description: Martha Stewart faces imminent indictment on criminal charges, her company said yesterday, a result of an investigation into a personal stock trade that has weighed down her media and merchandising empire for more than a year.

title: These Days, Business Risk Is Often the Journey
description: When Sally Blower experienced chest pains and shivers before boarding her flight from London to Brazil in late March, she did not even consider canceling her trip. As production manager for a British auto-racing television show, missing her assignment to cover the Brazilian Grand Prix would have been ''unthinkable,'' she later said.

title: Bush, in Egypt, Finds Warmth And Wariness
description: President Bush arrived in the Mideast tonight for the first time in his presidency, preparing to face Arab leaders skeptical of American intentions in Iraq and to mediate between the Israelis and the Palestinians, a role he has long avoided.

description: To the Editor:

description: AUERBACH--Leonard. June 3, 2002. Loved and missed by your family. >>AD#

title: American and U.N. Envoys Meet in Baghdad
description: The head of the United States-led administration in Iraq and the new United Nations representative to Iraq met in Baghdad today and vowed to work together expeditiously "to create a democratic, independent and peaceful Iraq."

title: Scientists Race to Detect SARS, But First They Must Test the Test
description: As scientists and companies race to develop diagnostic tests to quickly determine whether a person has SARS, they face a big challenge: testing whether the tests themselves are accurate.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telecom Unit Sold
description: JP Morgan Partners Asia and another private equity firm, CVC Asia Pacific, edged out Telstra and nine other bidders to buy the telephone directories business of Singapore Telecommunications. The two companies will pay about 220 million Singapore dollars ($127 million) in cash for SingTel's Yellow Pages unit, which posted sales of 83.5 million Singapore dollars ($48 million) in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2002. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: A Peck of Pucker
description: Q. Why is it that when I bite into an apple, I get a very dry puckering feeling, almost as if I had ingested a small amount of alum?

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SINGAPORE: TELECOM UNIT SOLD JP Morgan Partners Asia and another private equity firm, CVC Asia Pacific, edged out Telstra and nine other bidders to buy the telephone directories business of Singapore Telecommunications. The two companies will pay about 220 million Singapore dollars ($127 million) in cash for SingTel's Yellow Pages unit, which posted sales of 83.5 million Singapore dollars ($48 million) in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2002. title: All the World Loves an Office Clerk
description: Keith Reddin's daffy new comedy, ''Can't Let Go,'' which had its premiere on Sunday at the Connelly Theater on the Lower East Side, seems to cry out to be critically dismissed. The story of a middling office clerk, Beth Williams, who is suddenly besieged by declarations of love by all of her co-workers, it doesn't say anything especially noteworthy about relationships or office politics.

title: Comcast Deal Is Delayed
description: The Comcast Corporation and Paul G. Allen, the chairman of Charter Communications Inc., agreed to delay Mr. Allen's planned purchase of Comcast's interest in the companies' joint cable television venture, Comcast said today.

title: Justices Reject Veterans' Suit Over Promises By Recruiters
description: The Supreme Court declined today to hear a case that sought the free lifetime medical care that was promised to some veterans of World War II and the Korean War.

title: Accounts
description: * Gold's Gym International, Venice, Calif., the chain of 650 gyms in 34 countries, to Henderson Advertising, Greenville, S.C., as the agency of record for the company and its franchisees. The assignment, with billings that were estimated at $15 million to $18 million, had been previously handled internally and on a project basis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANKL, , DANIEL R.
description: FRANKL--Daniel R. Died June 1st, 2003 at age 80. Professor Emeritus of Physics, Pennsylvania State University, 1963-1988. B.Ch.E. 1943, Cooper Union; Ph.D. 1953, Columbia University. Noted experimental physicist; Fellow, American Physical Society >>AD#

description: FELSEN--Esther. June 3, 1921--June 28, 1998. Five long years. Missed and remembered every day The Family >>AD#

description: AS Henny Youngman might have said, ''Take my exchange, please.''

title: For Egyptian City Where Leaders Meet, Peace Is a Business
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, June 3  Some of the people who live here, and a United Nations agency too, like to call this the City of Peace. The main highway, running between the sawtoothed ridges of the Sinai Peninsula and the coral-fringed depths of the Red Sea, is called the Peace Road. For people like Kerim Fayek, a tour operator, moreover, peace is business: in a town whose fortunes ebb and flow to the rhythms of the region's hostilities, peace brings dollars, war does not.

title: Nicotine Takes Toll on Newborns
description: Babies whose mothers smoke as few as six cigarettes a day during pregnancy appear to suffer nicotine withdrawal after birth, according to a study released yesterday.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE HAGUE: EX-PARAMILITARY LEADER PLEADS NOT GUILTY Franko Simatovic, the Yugoslav paramilitary leader whose secretive Serbian unit is accused of committing some of the worst atrocities in the Balkans in the 1990's, pleaded not guilty to charges of murder and "ethnic cleansing" at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Mr. Simatovic, an ethnic Croat, is accused of forming a "criminal enterprise" to evict non-Serbs from parts of Croatia and Bosnia. Mr. Simatovic's unit was the core of the Serbian police's special operations unit whose senior officers are accused of killing the Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic, in March.    Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Publisher Pulls Book About Atomic Bomb Creation
description: Little, Brown today withdrew a book about the creation of the atomic bomb after four authors complained that more than 30 uncredited passages in it are identical or nearly identical to passages in their works.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ATKINSON, , ETHEL M.
description: ATKINSON--Ethel M., 100, formerly of Bronxville, NY on May 31, 2003. Dear sister of Emily Quick of New Hampshire. Also survived by nephews and nieces. Interment at Ferncliffe Cemetery. >>AD#

description: WALLACH--Richard W. On June 1, 2003. He is survived by his devoted companion and fiancee, Marli Hinckley, his sons Roger and Jon from his marriage to Elinor Weshsler Levin and his five grandchildren Aaron, David, Michael, Matthew and Kyle. We will always miss you dearly. Contributions may be made in his memory to Ethical Culture Fieldston School, 33 Central Park West, New York 10023. Services Wednesday 10 am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: Playoff overtime has not been kind to Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur, and it was not kind again tonight.

description: Balazs Believes in South Beach

title: Poetry, Reggae and Rain; On a Jamaican Beach, a Literary Festival Defies Nature
description: As the Jamaicans say, ''Much respect is due.'' To whom? Maybe to the rain and sea.

title: From Distant Galaxies, News of a 'Stop-and-Go Universe'
description: New observations of exploding stars far deeper in space, astronomers say, have produced strong evidence that the proportions of the mysterious forces dominating the universe have undergone radical change over cosmic history.

title: Hewlett Says Plan for PC's Is Corporate Money-Saver
description: Hewlett-Packard plans to announce a technology initiative today that it says can reduce a corporation's cost of owning and managing personal computers at least 45 percent, by shifting processing power to a central bank of shared computers.

title: Hollywood Is Feeling Flush As Blockbuster Season Starts
description: The monsters of May have arrived and devoured, from expected blockbusters like ''X2: X-Men United'' and ''The Matrix Reloaded'' to bigger-than-expected openings for ''Bruce Almighty'' and last weekend's ''Finding Nemo.''

title: Roddick Changing Coaches
description: Andy Roddick has split with his longtime coach, Tarik Benhabiles, and will work with Andre Agassi's former coach, Brad Gilbert, during the grass-court season heading into Wimbledon, Roddick's agent, Ken Meyerson, said today.

title: Mad Cows, Sane Cats: Making Sense of the 'Species Barrier'
description: When thousands of cattle started collapsing from mad cow disease more than a decade ago in Britain, experts stated firmly that people would never get the disease from eating beef.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: No More Aid For Rescue Effort
description: Government officials suspended further aid to about 40 volunteers seeking survivors of an ice avalanche last September in North Ossetia, saying that all hope of finding anyone alive was lost and that melting ice had made the effort too risky. One hundred and six people remain missing. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUTLER, , ROSE
description: CUTLER--Rose. On June 2, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Allan. Loving mother of Stephen and Kenneth. Graveside service Wednesday, June 4th, 10AM at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, N.J. >>AD#

description: HANDY--Michael J. Director of the N.Y.C. Mayor's Office of Veterans' Affairs and, since, 1991, Board member of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross in Greater N.Y. He was a gracious leader and a generous volunteer who always had time to offer his expertise. Directors of N.Y. Chapter of American Red Cross >>AD#

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest May Increase Loan To $1.5 Billion
description: Qwest Communications International, the fourth-biggest United States local-telephone company, said yesterday that it might increase the size of a new loan 50 percent, to $1.5 billion, because of strong demand from investors. The loan, announced last week, is being arranged by Merrill Lynch & Company, Credit Suisse First Boston and Deutsche Bank. They will break it into pieces and sell the debt to investors. The first $1 billion will mature in 2007, with any additional portion due in 2010, said a Qwest spokesman, Tyler Gronbach. Qwest, restricted from selling bonds publicly because of accounting inquiries, will use the proceeds to pay off debt due this year, buying more time to meet payments on more than $22 billion in borrowings. The company was near bankruptcy in August before agreeing to sell its phone book unit for $7.05 billion. Shares of Qwest rose 21 cents, or 4.7 percent, to $4.70. The announcement was made after the close of regular trading.

title: Trying to sort out the broader trends behind the big surge in spending on TV commercials.
description: WHETHER or not Funny Cide wins the Belmont on Saturday, television sales executives are beaming about the Triple Crown they have scored in booking commitments for commercial time for the 2003-4 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERKMAN, , ALLEN H.
description: BERKMAN--Allen H. Manhattan School of Music offers its deepest sympathy to David Rahm, Chairman of the School's Board of Trustees, and his wife Susan Berkman Rahm, on the passing of her beloved father, Allen. Susan Berkman Rahm and her family are enthusiastic supporters of music and education. Their commitment to Manhattan School of Music has been demonstrated through their generosity of time and invaluable guidance to our school. We extend our most sincere and heartfelt condolences to all members of their family. Marta Istomin, President >>AD#

title: Virtual World of Support for Real World Woes
description: Shannon Pierce was distraught three years ago when she learned that her baby, Caroline, had Pierre Robin syndrome, a rare congenital disorder. In her desperate search for information, Ms. Pierce latched onto an increasingly common option for people grappling with little-known diseases, an online support group.

title: More Than Just One Knife
description: To the Editor:

title: BIOVAIL ACQUIRES PRODUCTS FROM WYETH FOR $130 MILLION
description: The Biovail Corporation, Canada's biggest publicly traded drug maker, bought the anxiety treatment Ativan and the heart medication Isordil from Wyeth for $130 million. Sales of both products reached more than $50 million in the United States last year. Biovail, which is based in Toronto, said the Ativan brand could be expanded in the United States. Wyeth will receive a payment from Biovail for the development of an Ativan product line as well as royalties on future sales of any Ativan-line extension marketed by Biovail in the United States.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: WORKERS VOTE ON AFFILIATION Nearly 2,700 Duane Reade workers who belong to an independent union have voted to affiliate with a new union, Local 338 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, based in Rego Park, union officials announced yesterday. The Duane Reade workers voted 344 for affiliation and 26 against. The Duane Reade workers are employed in 145 drugstores and were members of the Allied Trades Council, an independent union that once had been part of the Teamsters. Many Allied members said they were frustrated that their union appeared to be too weak to negotiate a contract with Duane Reade.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Rises
description: Brazil posted a trade surplus of $2.5 billion last month, raising the surplus so far this year to slightly more than $8 billion, the government said. Exports in the month totaled $6.37 billion, compared with $3.87 billion in imports. A slide in Brazil's currency, the real, against the dollar and the dollar's weakness against the euro have helped Brazil's trade balance. The new left-leaning government is also promoting exports to compensate for the decline in foreign investment. May's surplus compared with a surplus of $416 million a year earlier, while the January-May surplus of $8.05 billion was up from $1.9 billion for the period in 2002. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: 'Magic Mountain' of Marriage, Too
description: To the Editor:

We extend our heartfelt condolences to Jerry and Susan, Lauren and the entire Levine family on the loss of a beloved father, grandfather and uncle. Milton Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Daniel Reingold, Exec VP >>AD#

title: Editorial Observer; Re-educating the Voters About Texas' Schools
description: George Bush is more than two years gone from the Texas statehouse, but his signature can-do issue as a presidential candidate -- education -- showed increasing wear and tear as this year's legislative session ground to a close. For one thing, his state, like others, had to relax the testing standards for the new federal No Child Left Behind Act to avoid failing youngsters wholesale and subjecting schools to federal penalties.

title: The Powers Behind the Glory
description: Just off the corner of Man O War Avenue and Count Fleet Road, and behind the green, slope-roofed Barn 6 at Belmont Park, the star, the headliner, the main attraction, a striking chestnut, appeared. He was led by his groom and his hot walker, the two as conscientious as the Secret Service accompanying the president, and he strolled from his stall into the sunshine for his morning bath.

title: Standard Operating Procedure
description: The mystery of Iraq's missing weapons of mass destruction has become a lot less mysterious. Recent reports in major British newspapers and three major American news magazines, based on leaks from angry intelligence officials, back up the sources who told my colleague Nicholas Kristof that the Bush administration ''grossly manipulated intelligence'' about W.M.D.'s.

title: Straighten Up and Fly Right
description: Condor No. 250 kerplunked himself onto a low wall in front of the Bright Angel Hotel at the Grand Canyon's South Rim. This 2-year-old bird folded his wings, all nine feet of them, and fixed his flinty eyes on scores of tourists flocking around him. People approached and cameras flashed but the waist-high bird was unafraid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBIN, , DR. SAMUEL
description: RUBIN--Dr. Samuel of Fort Lee. Beloved husband of Frances (nee Maltz). Devoted father of Dr. Mark and Peggy Rubin, Marjorie and Daniel Levin. Loving grandfather of Emily, Rachel, David and Julie. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533. >>AD#

title: Those With Eye On Spitzer's Job Waste No Time At Starting Line
description: In the past month, Assemblyman Michael N. Gianaris has been a busy campaigner. He traveled to Sacramento, where contributors held a fund-raiser on his behalf. He has crisscrossed New York, attending the Erie County Democratic dinner in Buffalo and a kickoff event for the Young Democrats in Rensselaer County, near Albany. Just yesterday, he spent hours in his campaign office on the phone, calling potential donors.

title: Arab Leaders Skeptical, But Hope for Results
description: When President Bush opens a new Middle East peace quest with Arab kings, presidents and ministers, he will confront a region still trying to absorb America's occupation of Iraq and profoundly skeptical about Washington's will, or even ability, to press Israel into a settlement.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Reinsurer Posts Loss
description: The reinsurance company Munich Re said it lost 238 million euros ($279 million) in the first quarter, its fourth consecutive quarterly loss, partly as a result of weak capital markets that forced it to write down the value of its investments by 880 million euros ($1 billion). Munich Re's operating profit, which excludes one-time items, was 123 million euros, reversing a loss of 1.6 billion euros ($1.9 billion) a year earlier. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Orange County, Calif.; Southern California, and Hold the Los Angeles
description: Anyone with business in Orange County, Calif., quickly realizes that it is easier and wiser to consider the region as something other than a suburb of Los Angeles. For one thing, it can be a very long drive from downtown Los Angeles to the Orange County line -- not so much in distance (it is only 20 miles or so) as in time. Freeway jams, particularly at rush hour, can stretch the drive to well over an hour.

title: Some Sugar Diluted By a Tonic Of Bach
description: Most of the season, the Queen's Chamber Band devotes itself to the more antique end of the repertory, from the Renaissance through the early Classical era, and that's a sensible approach for an ensemble built around a harpsichord.

title: Bringing China In From the Cold
description: The loopiest aspect of the Group of 8 conclave in vian is the notion that global leaders are confronting the challenges of the 21st century in the absence of the nation that may well dominate the century.
