description: An oil and gas alliance led by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group signed a contract here today for more than $2 billion with a Russian-Japanese alliance, clearing the way for construction to start in coming weeks on Russia's first liquefied natural gas plant.

title: New Rules Give Big Media Chance to Get Even Bigger
description: As consumer advocates deplored yesterday's changes to media ownership rules as a blow to democracy, investors bought up shares of the biggest media companies.

title: Bird Cage on Head? To Your Health!; This Roadside Spectacle Is a Street Artist With a Mission
description: The other day in Harlem, Otis Houston Jr. sat near the southbound lanes of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive with a white metal bird cage on his head, one hand gripping a plastic steering wheel, the other holding a Cuban cigar case. A ballpoint pen was perched in his lips like a cigarette. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Jupitermedia Cancels Planned Trade Show
description: A technology trade show battle has been called off before it even began. Jupitermedia, a technology research company that planned to start a trade show to rival Comdex, has canceled its show, according to its founder. Jupitermedia was hoping to take advantage of the plight of Comdex's parent, the Key3Media Group, which has sought to reorganize under bankruptcy protection. Jupitermedia had booked space at the Mandalay Bay Convention Center in Las Vegas for next fall to run its trade show at the same time that Comdex is scheduled to take place just blocks away at the Las Vegas Convention Center. But according to Jupitermedia's chairman, Alan M. Meckler, the show has been canceled because of ''a contractual situation with Mandalay Bay.'' Mr. Meckler, who just months ago said he planned to put Comdex out of business, refused to explain the problem except to say, ''There's no contract and therefore there is no show. It's in abeyance. I can't really comment beyond that.'' Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Senate Passes Bill On Ballot Process
description: The State Senate passed a bill yesterday allowing candidates for state and legislative office to get on the ballot by gathering signatures rather than garnering delegates' support at conventions. The bill, approved 34 to 1, would also establish the second Tuesday in August as primary election day. In January, a federal judge ruled that the state's primary election system was unconstitutional after a lawsuit by challengers who had failed to get on ballots. The House approved an earlier version of the bill last week, and is expected to vote on the Senate bill before midnight tomorrow, the end of the legislative session. Gov. John G. Rowland has spoken in favor of opening up the process. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

All accusations against her were dismissed, and both parties agreed that she was not responsible or liable in her capacity as president. The article also misstated Mr. Garcia's title. He was an assistant to the vice president for academic affairs. He was not the vice president.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Ex-Paramilitary Leader Pleads Not Guilty
description: Franko Simatovic, the Yugoslav paramilitary leader whose secretive Serbian unit is accused of committing some of the worst atrocities in the Balkans in the 1990's, pleaded not guilty to charges of murder and ''ethnic cleansing'' at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague. Mr. Simatovic, an ethnic Croat, is accused of forming a ''criminal enterprise'' to evict non-Serbs from parts of Croatia and Bosnia. Mr. Simatovic's unit was the core of the Serbian police's special operations unit whose senior officers are accused of killing the Serbian prime minister, Zoran Djindjic, in March. Peter S. Green (NYT)

description: * Issuers of credit cards sent 4.89 billion solicitations to consumers through direct mail in 2002, down 2.4 percent from a record of 5.01 billion solicitations in 2001, according to research by the financial services practice of the Tarrytown, N.Y., office of Synovate. The decline in mailings was attributed to the uncertain national economy and world situation.

description: The United Nations weapons inspection office provided a postscript to its truncated mission today, suggesting in a new report that many open questions remain about whether and when Saddam Hussein's government destroyed its chemical and biological agents.

title: CABLEVISION TO SPIN OFF SATELLITE AND CINEMA UNITS
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation, the largest cable television operator in the New York area, approved the spinoff of its Rainbow D.B.S. satellite service and Clearview Cinemas theater chain. The company, which is based in Bethpage, N.Y., will contribute as much as $450 million to the new entity and invest an additional $114 million this year in Rainbow D.B.S. Cablevision's chairman, Charles Dolan, will be chairman of the new business, the company said. Cablevision's shareholders will receive stock in the new company, with details of the distribution to be disclosed later, Cablevision said. Cablevision stock rose $2.43, or 13 percent, to $21.79 a share yesterday.

title: U.S. Report Faults the Roundup Of Illegal Immigrants After 9/11
description: The Justice Department's roundup of hundreds of illegal immigrants in the months after the Sept. 11 attacks was plagued with ''significant problems'' that forced many people with no connection to terrorism to languish in jails in unduly harsh conditions, an internal report released today found.

description: It is a backstretch remedy that has tamed many ornery horses over the years: drop a goat or a cat into their stall and watch them find calmness in companionship. It apparently works for ornery trainers, too. Bobby Frankel was cool and confident once again yesterday morning at Belmont Park as he walked his beloved Australian shepherd from his barn to the track.

title: I.C.N. IS PLANNING TO BUY BACK ITS RIBAPHARM STAKE
description: I.C.N. Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy back for about $168 million the nearly 20 percent stake in Ribapharm Inc. that it sold to the public last year. I.C.N. owns about 80 percent of Ribapharm, a biotechnology company. Both companies are based in Costa Mesa, Calif. I.C.N., which in December tried to oust all but one of Ribapharm's directors because of a loss of confidence in the unit, said it would pay $5.60 a share for Ribapharm. The purchase price is a 10 percent premium over Ribapharm's closing price on Friday. I.C.N. said the offer price also represented a 20.2 percent premium over Ribapharm's one-month average closing price of $4.66 a share. Ribapharm's stock rose $1.14 yesterday, or 22 percent, to $6.22 a share.

description: Vivendi Universal SA agreed to sell its Spencer Gifts United States retail chain to a group of investors led by Gordon Brothers Group L.L.C. for an undisclosed sum as it seeks to reduce debt. Spencer Gifts, based in Egg Harbor Township, N.J., operates 700 stores specializing in odd and unique items like lava lamps, gag gifts and Playboy merchandise. The company had more than $400 million in sales last year, Gordon Brothers said.

title: National Briefing | Washington: They've Got Less Mail
description: The Postal Service said its revenue for the last three months was nearly a half-billion dollars less than expected because mail volume continued to be flat. The Postal Service has struggled to deal with declining volume, a weak economy and the repercussions of the terrorist attacks in 2001, including anthrax-laden letters sent to lawmakers in Washington. Mail volume has dropped, in part, because more people are beginning to use electronic mail and bill-paying services, officials said. Postal revenue for the third quarter of the fiscal year was about $16 billion, $483 million below expectations, the Postal Service said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: NATO Contract Suspended After Crash
description: Six days after the crash of a chartered Ukrainian jet killed 62 Spanish soldiers returning home from Afghanistan, the Spanish Defense Ministry announced that it had decided to suspend a transportation contract with NATO's logistics agency and use domestic aircraft to move troops. Turkish and Spanish accident investigators hope to determine why the Yakovlev-42, a passenger jet chartered through the logistics agency, known as Namsa, crashed into a Turkish mountain during a storm as it tried to land for a refueling stop. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Ethics Chief Retiring
description: The head of the state board overseeing judges' conduct announced his retirement yesterday. The administrator and counsel at the Commission on Judicial Conduct, Gerald Stern, 68, has held that post since the agency was created in 1974. He will be succeeded on July 1 by his deputy, Robert H. Tembeckjian. During Mr. Stern's tenure on the commission, he created a ''heightened sensitivity to judicial ethics throughout the court system,'' the chairman of the commission, Henry T. Berger, said. Mr. Stern said he would serve as part-time counsel to the commission for the next few months and planned to spend his retirement writing about judicial ethics. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Japan and France Back Off Tough Talk on Nuclear Arms
description: ÉVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, June 3 — A day after President Bush and the leaders of the major industrialized countries urged North Korea and Iran to curb their nuclear programs, saying they could employ "if necessary, other means" than the tools provided by international non-proliferation accords, the leaders of Japan and France strongly denied today that the phrase implied the possible use of military force.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: CISCO WILL SUPPLY GEAR TO BELLSOUTH Cisco Systems, the world's largest maker of equipment to link computers, won a contract to supply networking gear to the BellSouth Corporation, which wants to sell upgraded services to corporate clients. Cisco was chosen over Fujitsu to provide equipment that will allow BellSouth's business customers to send and receive phone calls and data at faster speeds, Bill Smith, BellSouth's chief product and development officer, said in an interview yesterday. He declined to disclose financial terms. Cisco is seeking more orders from American regional phone companies as corporations spend less on Internet gear such as routers and switches. Lucent Technologies Inc. , the biggest telephone-equipment maker in the United States, also won a contract to provide BellSouth with products that increase the capacity of networks, Lucent said in a statement. Terms were not disclosed. Cisco shares rose 39 cents, or about 2.4 percent, to $16.80. BellSouth shares rose 26 cents, to $26.77.   (Bloomberg News)

title: U.S. Administrator Seeks to Restore a Broken Economy
description: The top American civilian administrator in Iraq turned his attention to this country's shattered economy today, saying that joblessness ''is a tremendous problem'' but that he would not be ''blackmailed'' by thousands of former Iraqi soldiers who are protesting their new unemployment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBBINS, , RICHARD D., M.D.
description: ROBBINS--Richard D., M.D., F.A.C.S., Colo-rectal surgeon, died May 31, at home in his bed after a valiant eightmonth battle with pancreatic cancer. Graduate of Harvard and Bellevue/NYU. He retired from practice at Lenox Hill Hospital in '98 to return to an early passion--writing. He published over 70 short stories and was nominated for a PushCart Prize among others. An irreverent service will be held June 4, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, 5:30 PM. Dick leaves his beloved wife Carrie, brother Jim, niece Nancy, nephew David, niece-in-law Kristen, two collies and a smelly cat. Any donations may be made to the Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62 St., in Dr. Robbins' name.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Inquirer Names Editor
description: The Philadelphia Inquirer has named Amanda Bennett, the editor of The Lexington Herald-Leader in Kentucky since August 2001, to be its next executive editor. Ms. Bennett, 50, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal, replaces Walker Lundy, who announced his retirement last month, less than two years after accepting the job. An article on the Inquirer Web site quoted Ms. Bennett as saying that she intended to stay at The Inquirer until she retired. ''I feel like somebody's just handed me the keys to a Maserati,'' she said. Both The Inquirer and the Kentucky paper are owned by Knight Ridder. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Workers Vote On Affiliation
description: Nearly 2,700 Duane Reade workers who belong to an independent union have voted to affiliate with a new union, Local 338 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, based in Rego Park, union officials announced yesterday. The Duane Reade workers voted 344 for affiliation and 26 against. The Duane Reade workers are employed in 145 drugstores and were members of the Allied Trades Council, an independent union that once had been part of the Teamsters. Many Allied members said they were frustrated that their union appeared to be too weak to negotiate a contract with Duane Reade. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TERRY, , WALLACE
description: TERRY--Wallace. The staff of ''Parade'' magazine mourns the loss of a friend and colleague. In his nearly 15 years as a Contributing Editor to Parade, Wallace Terry helped its readers bridge a racial divide through coverage of civil rights and influential African-Americans, from entertainers such as Quincy Jones, Morgan Freeman, Stevie Wonder and James Earl Jones to newsmakers including photographer Gordon Parks, Marian Wright Edelman, founder of the Children's Defense Fund and, most recently, Dr. Ruth Simmons, president of Brown University. Wallace Terry should be remembered not only as a champion of civil rights but also as a proud and loving man and an ordained minister who cared deeply about his family, his friends, his neighbors. He will be dearly missed. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Janice, his children and grandchildren. Walter Anderson, Chairman Parade >>AD#

description: I.B.M., the world's largest computer-services company, won a seven-year contract to run a network of as many as 19,000 personal computers for the Swedish appliance maker Electrolux. The value of the contract is not being disclosed, said Jim Larkin, an I.B.M. spokesman. The computer maker will provide PC's and some software and will manage the network. The contract is expected to begin Aug. 1, I.B.M. said in a statement yesterday. Stratos Sarissamlis, an analyst with Meta Group, estimates the worth of the Electrolux deal at 180 million to 220 million euros, or between $211 million and $258 million.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cisco Will Supply Gear To Bellsouth
description: Cisco Systems, the world's largest maker of equipment to link computers, won a contract to supply networking gear to the BellSouth Corporation, which wants to sell upgraded services to corporate clients. Cisco was chosen over Fujitsu to provide equipment that will allow BellSouth's business customers to send and receive phone calls and data at faster speeds, Bill Smith, BellSouth's chief product and development officer, said in an interview yesterday. He declined to disclose financial terms. Cisco is seeking more orders from American regional phone companies as corporations spend less on Internet gear such as routers and switches. Lucent Technologies Inc., the biggest telephone-equipment maker in the United States, also won a contract to provide BellSouth with products that increase the capacity of networks, Lucent said in a statement. Terms were not disclosed. Cisco shares rose 39 cents, or about 2.4 percent, to $16.80. BellSouth shares rose 26 cents, to $26.77.

He graduated from St. Brendan High School in Brooklyn and was a securities trader with Allen & Co. in New York until his retirement. He was a member of the Security Traders Association of New York. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHERMAN, , DR. PAUL ALAN
description: SHERMAN--Dr. Paul Alan, of White Plains, died on June 1, 2003 at age 70. Born in Chicago on October 18, 1932 to Hyman & Miriam Rosenblith Slivnick. He received a PhD from Illinois Institute of Technology in 1961 where he majored in psychology. Dr. Sherman was an industrial psychologist. From 1979 to the present, he was the president of Paul Sherman and Associates, a national consulting firm, specializing in the treatment of executives with alcoholism and drug addictions. Since 1970, this organization has provided services to more than 350 small to multinational organizations in the public, private and non-profit sectors, in the service, financial, insurance and manufacturing fields. From 1965-1979 he served as director of special programs for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, where he developed, implemented and directed the ITT Alcoholism, Behavioral/Medical and Employee Assistance Programs. Throughout his professional tenure he received many accolades. His recognitions include, President of the Employee Assistance Professionals Association (formerly ALMACA) from 1976-1978, Advisor to the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAA) from 1974-1978 and he served as an expert witness for the US Senate Sub-Committee on Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse. Dr. Sherman has achieved media recognition as well with numerous television appearances including CBS Evening News with Dan Rather, Today Show, Not for Women Only and the Freeman Reports. He was also featured in The New York Times, Wall Street Journal and other leading professional magazines and newsletters. Dr. Sherman is survived by his wife Joan Louise (Root). In addition he is survived by sons, David Sherman (wife Elizabeth) of Manhattan, Dr. Scott Sherman (wife Leta) of Mar Vista, CA, daughters, Julie DeFreitas (husband Frank) of White Plains, and Laurie Walshin of New Canaan. Also surviving are grandchildren Benjamin, Sarah, Jessica, Trevor, Colin, Emily and Rebecca, and sister Charlene Gourguechon of Paris. He is predeceased by a brother Morton Slivnick. Funeral service will be held on Tuesday 11am at the Comunity Synagogue of Rye followed by interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery. For information, contact Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck at 914-381-1809, zionmemorialchapel.com. The family requests donations in Dr. Sherman's memory be sent to the National Council on Alcoholism & Drug Dependence (N.C.A.D.D., Inc.) 20 Exchange Place, Suite 2909, New York, NY 10005. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: SENATE PASSES BILL ON BALLOT PROCESS The State Senate passed a bill yesterday allowing candidates for state and legislative office to get on the ballot by gathering signatures rather than garnering delegates' support at conventions. The bill, approved 34 to 1, would also establish the second Tuesday in August as primary election day. In January, a federal judge ruled that the state's primary election system was unconstitutional after a lawsuit by challengers who had failed to get on ballots. The House approved an earlier version of the bill last week, and is expected to vote on the Senate bill before midnight tomorrow, the end of the legislative session. Gov. John G. Rowland has spoken in favor of opening up the process. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Acclaim's Chief Executive Resigns
description: Acclaim Entertainment, the maker of video games for machines like the Sony PlayStation 2, said Gregory E. Fischbach, a co-founder, had resigned as chief executive and was succeeded by Rodney Cousens. Mr. Cousens had been Acclaim's president and chief operating officer since January. Mr. Fischbach helped start the company in 1987 and had been chief executive since then, Acclaim said in a statement yesterday. He will remain co-chairman, Acclaim said. Acclaim has been reorganizing management and cutting costs to recover from three straight quarterly net losses, which it has attributed to poor-performing game titles. Its games include ''All-Star Baseball,'' ''Legends of Wrestling'' and ''Quad Power Racing.''

Now, however, Hong Kong's free society is about to encounter the most dangerous attack yet, and this one -- like SARS -- has its genesis in China.

title: The Abusive Detentions of Sept. 11
description: It was vital after the terrorism of Sept. 11 that the nation protect itself, arresting and investigating those who might have had a role. But it was equally vital that it avoid doing things we would later regret, like failing to grant detainees due process or abusing them either mentally and physically. Sadly, such caution was not exercised, according to a frank and blistering report by the inspector general of the Justice Department.

description: There are people who lose things, and people who find them, and sometimes, the two meet. In many cities, it is that simple: Excuse me, sir, you dropped this.

None of this would be especially noteworthy -- these country icons are hardly strangers to the top of the charts -- except that Mr. Cash and Mr. Jones are 71 and Mr. Nelson is 70.

title: Lemieux Won't Leave Penguins

Responding to a report published and broadcast over the weekend that Lemieux would seek to sell his share of the Penguins and become an unrestricted free agent so he could sign with a team like the Rangers, Lemieux issued a statement.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: JUPITERMEDIA CANCELS PLANNED TRADE SHOW A technology trade show battle has been called off before it even began. Jupitermedia, a technology research company that planned to start a trade show to rival Comdex, has canceled its show, according to its founder. Jupitermedia was hoping to take advantage of the plight of Comdex's parent, the Key3Media Group , which has sought to reorganize under bankruptcy protection. Jupitermedia had booked space at the Mandalay Bay Convention Center in Las Vegas for next fall to run its trade show at the same time that Comdex is scheduled to take place just blocks away at the Las Vegas Convention Center. But according to Jupitermedia's chairman, Alan M. Meckler, the show has been canceled because of "a contractual situation with Mandalay Bay." Mr. Meckler, who just months ago said he planned to put Comdex out of business, refused to explain the problem except to say, "There's no contract and therefore there is no show. It's in abeyance. I can't really comment beyond that."

title: New Tapas Menu Sets Off the   Fireworks
description: WHEN chefs become stars, diners have a right to develop suspicions. Will the demands of fame hurt the restaurant that put the chef on the map in the first place? Can anyone satisfy the demands of television and run a kitchen at the same time? Bobby Flay, the chef and a partner in Mesa Grill and Bolo, may be a notch below "bam" on the celebrity scale, but he is getting there. He has the cookbooks and the line of sauces and spice rubs. He has a series, "Food Nation," on the Food Network. Near-electrocution while competing on "Iron Chef" solidified his reputation as New York's Derek Jeter of the kitchen  brash and charismatic.

title: Bolstering the Palestinian Premier
description: It was gratifying to hear Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, say after the Arab summit meeting with President Bush yesterday that the five Arab states present oppose terror and will not finance or arm extremist Palestinian groups. But Arab states can do much more. They have one central task: to strengthen the new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas. This means conferring on Mr. Abbas the same authority they once gave Yasir Arafat and condemning violent groups like Hamas and their rejectionist agendas.

title: Beside Blossoming Fields, Where Poverty Grows
description: The shores of the broad lake that spreads across Africa's Rift Valley here were known to outsiders a long time ago as a place where white settlers disported themselves on emerald lawns and shaded verandas, misbehaving blithely in an adopted continent and calling themselves the Happy Valley set.

title: HERSHEY REPLACES 1936 WRAPPER ON ITS CHOCOLATE BARS
description: Hershey chocolate bars have a new look for the first time since 1936. The Hershey Foods Corporation has replaced the two-piece wrapper on Hershey's and Hershey's With Almonds bars with a one-piece wrapper that is sealed at the ends. Retailers have been selling candy with the new wrappers as they work through inventory, a spokeswoman, Christine Dugan, said. The new wrappers cost about the same to make as the old ones, Ms. Dugan said. Hershey is based in Hershey, Pa.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Egypt: Journalists Jailed For Libel
description: A court of appeals has upheld a one-year prison sentence for libel charges against Mustafa Bakri, editor in chief of the newspaper Al Osboa, and his brother, Mahmoud, who works for the paper. The independent weekly has close ties with some government officials and had been adopting an anti-Israel, anti-America, pro-Saddam Hussein editorials. The Bakris were accused of publishing libelous articles three years ago about the personal life of the leader of the small opposition Social Justice Party, Muhammad Abdel-Aal. Mr. Abdel-Aal himself is serving 10 years in prison for accepting bribes from a businessman. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Blair Denies Britain Distorted Intelligence Reports on Iraq
description: LONDON, June 4  Prime Minister Tony Blair told a boisterous session of the House of Commons today that charges that the government distorted intelligence reports to exaggerate the threat of weapons of mass destruction and justify war in Iraq were false. He said a parliamentary committee would investigate the matter and make public its findings.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Call For Special Prosecutor
description: Environmental groups asked Attorney General John Ashcroft to appoint a special prosecutor to convene a grand jury to look into possible conflicts of interest involving J. Steven Griles, left, deputy secretary of the interior. The groups said Mr. Griles, a former lobbyist for the oil, gas and mining interests he now regulates, had played a role in several decisions that directly affect his former clients and would receive $284,000 a year for four years from his former firm. Mark Pfeifle, a spokesman for the Interior Department, said that the government ethics office and a Senate committee had approved Mr. Griles's financial arrangements. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: MEXICO: DELINQUENT TELECOM DEBT One of Mexico's largest wireless telephone companies, Grupo Iusacell, missed a $25 million payment on its $350 million 2006 bond and promised to come up with a debt restructuring plan within the 30-day grace period. The operator, which is jointly owned by Verizon Comunications and the Vodafone Group , has about $815 million in total debt. The company has struggled for several years behind Mexico's dominant wireless carrier, America Movil , and faces well-financed competition from Telefonica Moviles of Spain, which is moving aggressively into the Mexican market this year. Some market analysts speculate that if Iusacell can work out a favorable restructuring plan with creditors, then Verizon may be willing to put new capital into the company. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: ALBERTSONS AGREES TO SELL TOYS 'R' US PRODUCTS
description: Toys ''R'' Us will sell its products in all Albertsons grocery and drug stores as the companies try to regain sales lost to Wal-Mart Stores. The agreement calls for Albertsons to sell only Toys ''R'' Us toys by the middle of 2004. Financial terms of the multiyear pact were not disclosed, but the alliance is expected to generate more than $100 million in sales each year by attracting customers who might not want to make a separate trip to Toys ''R'' Us, the chief executive of Toys ''R'' Us, John J. Eyler, said.

title: Study Shows More Failings Of Child Safety In New Jersey
description: Dozens of child welfare workers in South Jersey are responsible for the safety of 80 children each, more than three times the accepted national standard. In one case recently a single worker had to oversee the care of 156 children who had been abused or neglected or were deemed at risk of being harmed.

title: U.S. Begins to Excavate Bomb Crater in Search for Hussein's Remains
description: A team of American military engineers began an intensive effort today to excavate the site of a bombing on April 7 that military officials still think may have killed Saddam Hussein.

title: INDICTMENT SEEN IN STEWART CASE
description: Martha Stewart faces imminent indictment on criminal charges, her company said yesterday, a result of an investigation into a personal stock trade that has weighed down her media and merchandising empire for more than a year.

title: G.O.P. Chief's Idea for Raising Alabama: Taxes
description: Alabama's new Republican governor, Bob Riley, styles himself after Ronald Reagan, complete with a pompadour and campaign photos that show him on horseback. Philosophically, too, he is an avowed Reaganite who says he never voted for a tax increase in six years in Congress and was once named its most conservative member.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Police And Protesters Clash
description: A march outside a law enforcement convention in Seattle escalated into a confrontation between the police and protestors, with officers using pepper spray, concussion grenades and rubber bullets to break up the crowd. Protesters were voicing concerns about the Law Enforcement Intelligence Unit, a private intelligence-sharing organization, which is holding a seminar. Scott Moss, a spokesman for the Seattle police, said 12 people were arrested, and at least one protester reported minor injuries. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: On Camera but Unaware, Bush Displays His Fervor

What was surprising, because of an extraordinary mistake by Egyptian television, was that Mr. Bush would be caught unawares on camera today speaking about the Middle East with more bluntness, emotion and religious fervor than had been heard before.

But yesterday, when he nosed his sports utility vehicle in front of the barn of the most famous New York-bred in history, cameras clicked and requests from the news media came one after another.

HAMPTON, associate provost for academic affairs and dean for undergraduate studies at the University of Maryland, College Park. Dr. Hampton, 55, graduated from Princeton University and earned a master's degree and a Ph.D. in sociology at the University of Michigan. He also taught at Connecticut College and at Harvard Medical School. RUSSELL K. HOTZLER, who has served as interim president at York, was named vice chancellor for academic program planning at CUNY. Karen W. Arenson

title: The Beluga Is Blond, and the Taste Is Sultry
description: A month or so ago, a bizarre shipment of beluga from Bulgaria landed in Petrossian's New York warehouse. Instead of the usual mass of glittering charcoal-gray beads, ivory-colored caviar filled the tins. Until they are killed, sturgeon give no clue to the color of their eggs, which are usually gray to inky black and can be brownish or even gold, a color prized by czars and shahs. White caviar is the rarest. Armen Petrossian, the president of the company, which is based in Paris, knew about it and had tasted it previously. Petrossian let the Bulgarian beluga, from the mouth of the Danube, rest a few weeks, and began selling it last week. Or trying to. Customers at its shop at 911 Seventh Avenue (58th Street) are put off by the strange color, to say nothing of the price: $1,250 for 125 grams, about four ounces. Less than five pounds is available. Though they came from beluga sturgeon, the eggs are somewhat small. The flavor does not have the almost floral delicacy of most beluga but is more assertive and intriguingly smoky, as seems typical of white caviar.

Given Mr. Stone's self-cultivated reputation as a wild and crazy guy, you might expect ''Controlled Chaos'' to be full of thinly disguised juicy tidbits about this Oscar-winning filmmaker (best director for the 1986 ''Platoon'' and the 1990 ''Born on the Fourth of July'').

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Interest Rate Unchanged

title: Five Arab Leaders Vow Active Fight Against Violence
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, June 3  Five Arab leaders pledged to President Bush today that they would actively fight "the culture of extremism and violence" that has undercut peace efforts in the Middle East for years, promising to stanch the flow of money to the terrorist groups that have carried out suicide bombings against Israel.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CORDIANT CHANGE SOUGHT Active Value Managers, the largest shareholder of the Cordiant Communications Group , an advertising company, requested an emergency shareholder meeting to nominate new management. Cordiant has been exploring options, including a sale, this spring after it lost one of its largest clients. Active Value proposed Richard Wheatly, former chief executive of Jazz FM, to become executive chairman and Stephen Davidson, vice chairman of the bank WestLB, to become vice chairman.

title: Site of Egypt Summit Prospers During Peace
description: Some of the people who live here, and a United Nations agency, too, like to call it the City of Peace. The main highway, running between the saw-toothed ridges of the Sinai Peninsula and the coral-fringed depths of the Red Sea, is called the Peace Road.

title: Senate Co-President Wins New Jersey G.O.P. Primary
description: The State Senate's co-president, John O. Bennett III, whose status as New Jersey's highest-ranking Republican elected official has been imperiled by questions about his law firm's billing practices, survived a primary challenge today, handily defeating a conservative opponent.

title: Burmese Officials Deny Dissident Was Injured
description: Facing strong condemnation from around the world, officials in Myanmar denied today that Daw Aung San Suu Kyi had been injured when she was detained over the weekend in a crackdown on her pro-democracy movement.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GERSON, , IVAN D.
description: GERSON--Ivan D. ''A unique man.'' You will always be loved and never forgotten. Happy birthday in heaven, our dear Ivan. Hugs Mom, Dad and Adrienne

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Delinquent Telecom Debt
description: One of Mexico's largest wireless telephone companies, Grupo Iusacell, missed a $25 million payment on its $350 million 2006 bond and promised to come up with a debt restructuring plan within the 30-day grace period. The operator, which is jointly owned by Verizon Comunications and the Vodafone Group, has about $815 million in total debt. The company has struggled for several years behind Mexico's dominant wireless carrier, Amrica Mvil, and faces well-financed competition from Telefnica Mviles of Spain, which is moving aggressively into the Mexican market this year. Some market analysts speculate that if Iusacell can work out a favorable restructuring plan with creditors, then Verizon may be willing to put new capital into the company. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: COCA-COLA APPOINTS CHIEF MARKETING OFFICER
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it had named Daniel P. Palumbo chief marketing officer. Mr. Palumbo, 45, worked most recently as the senior vice president of the Eastman Kodak Company and president of its consumer imaging division. Mr. Palumbo will supervise Coke's marketing efforts around the world, the company said. He will report to Steven J. Heyer, Coke's president and chief operating officer. Mr. Palumbo will succeed Stephen C. Jones, who resigned in March to pursue other interests. Sherri Day (NYT)

title: West Europe Is Hard Hit By Strikes Over Pensions
description: A wave of strikes from France to Austria left much of Western Europe snarled today, as protesting workers shut down subway systems, ports, trains, toll roads and airlines.

title: Cash for the Kurds Is Assailed as Inadequate
description: Thirty million dollars arrived late last week to pay the April salaries of state workers in the independent Kurdish enclave, but the Kurds were disappointed.

title: How Others See Us, And How We Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard Work Opens College Door for Whole Class
description: When Damian Ramsey enrolled at the University Park Campus School here six years ago as a seventh grader, he could barely read a fourth-grade textbook or tackle a basic multiplication problem.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Offer Authentidate Service
description: The Microsoft Corporation said that it would offer AuthentiDate Holding's USPS Electronic Postmark service to users of Microsoft Word. Shares of AuthentiDate rose nearly 17 percent on the news. The postmark service will allow Microsoft Word users to verify the authenticity of electronic documents and to add time and date stamps, AuthentiDate said in a statement yesterday. AuthentiDate's agreement with Microsoft has no explicit dollar value and will allow the company access to Microsoft's customer base, Richard Reichgut, AuthentiDate's vice president for marketing, said in an interview. AuthentiDate, which developed its electronic postmark service through an alliance with the United States Postal Service, stores proof of an electronic document's status at a given time for up to seven years, certifying that it has not been altered, for example. Shares of AuthentiDate rose 53 cents, to $3.73. In another development yesterday, Microsoft and VeriSign Inc. will jointly develop security software, the companies announced. Their next-generation software will focus on improving access security for remote connections and wireless networks. The new platform is expected to be available later this year. VeriSign shares gained $1.01, or 6.8 percent, to $15.80. Microsoft added 24 cents, or 1 percent, to $24.88.

title: Add Wedge to the Name Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Steinbrenner Appoints Jeter Captain of the Yankees
description: Derek Jeter has been an established Yankees star for years, and the highest-paid player on George Steinbrenner's team since February 2001. But Steinbrenner, the principal owner, waited until today to make official what the players in the clubhouse already knew: that Jeter is the captain of the Yankees.

title: Remarks by Leaders at Mideast Summit
description: Following is a transcript of statements by King Abdullah of Jordan; the new prime minister of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas; Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and President Bush after a summit meeting on Wednesday in Aqaba, Jordan.

description: HANDY--Michael J. The Officers, Directors and Staff of the USO of Metropolitan New York extend deepest sympathy to the family of Michael Handy, a USO board member and friend, to the military personnel that we serve, for over ten years. Stephen J. Scheffer, Chairman R. Jeffrey Lobb, President >>AD#

title: Shuttle Board May Open Files For Congress
description: Congress is close to reaching an agreement with the commission investigating the Columbia space shuttle accident that could provide access to secret testimony concerning the disaster, the chairman of the House Committee on Science said today.

description: To the Editor:

title: He Made a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Finds Booster Seats Safer Than Seat Belts
description: In a car crash, a child in a booster seat has less than half the risk of injury of a child wearing only an adult seat belt, a study of more than 3,600 crashes has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINDLAY, , HARRIET JONES
description: FINDLAY -- Harriet Jones, died peacefully at her home in New Canaan, CT, on May 25th. She was 95 years old and had lived in New Canaan for 62 years. She pursued many interests during her lifetime, including Christian philanthropy, Bible studies, horticulture and gardening, antiques and art collecting, painting, farming, land conservation, historic preservation and photography. She was predeceased by her husband and her daughter, H. Lindsay Findlay. She is survived by two sons, David B. Findlay Jr. of New Canaan and H. Peter Findlay of Salisbury, CT, six grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 14th, at 11 am at the Congregational Church of New Canaan. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Mid-Fairfield Hospice, Wilton, CT, or to the New Canaan Garden Club. >>AD#

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: SEXUAL ABUSE CASE IS DROPPED The Rev. Paul Shanley, a Roman Catholic priest at the center of the sexual abuse scandal, will not be prosecuted in California because of problems with the evidence, a prosecutor said. There is no evidence that Father Shanley, who was accused of sexually abusing a minor at a Palm Springs inn in 1990, knew that his accuser was under 18 at the time, Sue Steding, an assistant district attorney in Riverside County, said on Monday. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAER, , HENRY
description: BAER--Henry. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Jeffrey R. Parker, President >>AD#

title: Campsite May Be Linked to Bombing Suspect
description: The authorities said today that they had discovered a campsite replete with deer hides, wild turkey remains and a high-powered rifle that they believe was the ''winter retreat'' of Eric R. Rudolph, who is charged with the bombing at the 1996 Olympics and attacks on abortion clinics.

title: DeLay Rebuffs Move to Restore Lost Tax Credit
description: The House majority leader, Representative Tom DeLay, said today that the House would not consider a Democratic measure to provide an increased tax credit to 6.5 million low-income families who did not receive it in the new tax law.

title: Iran Denies Claim of Halted Russian Nuclear Fuel Shipment
description: MOSCOW, June 4  British prime minister Tony Blair said today that Russia had pledged to suspend a planned shipment of nuclear fuel to Iran until Teheran accepts new international controls on its nuclear program, but Russia's top nuclear official quickly said that no such promise had been made.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPANIER, , JEFFREY P.
description: SPANIER--Jeffrey P. 62, died on Sunday, June 1, at his residence in Sag Harbor, NY. An architect and developer born in Great Neck, NY, Jeff is survived by his wife, Paula; siblings, Alan and Megan Jacob Spanier; parents, Irving and Elaine Spanier, and children Adam, Carmen, and Erin Spanier; grandson Jesse Dylan Evers, nieces Sarah and Rebekah Paster, and nephews Evan Paster and Kyle Jacob Spanier. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 81st St. and Madison Ave., on June 5, 7-9 PM; service Friday, June 6, 1:30 PM.

title: A Quiet Champion of Civil Rights
description: In his book ''Robert Kennedy and His Times,'' Arthur Schlesinger Jr. recounts the moment when Mr. Kennedy, then a freshly minted attorney general, took Burke Marshall up to Capitol Hill to meet James Eastland, the segregationist senator whose committee would have a lot to say about Mr. Marshall's confirmation as the new assistant attorney general for civil rights. ''I have Mr. Marshall outside,'' Mr. Kennedy said. ''He's going to put the Negroes in your white schools in Mississippi.'' Mr. Eastland said that he wouldn't stand in the way but that he himself could not possibly vote for him. As he put it, ''I'd vote against Jesus Christ if he was nominated for that position.''

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qualcomm To Invest $100 Million In China
description: Seeking to spread its mobile phone technology in markets outside the United States, Qualcomm Inc. will invest as much as $100 million in Chinese start-up companies that are developing products and services based on Qualcomm patents. The investment is part of $500 million set aside in November 2000 to help ventures using code division multiple access, or C.D.M.A., software, Qualcomm said in a statement yesterday. Qualcomm is seeking to bolster growth by investing in countries like India and China, where the mobile phone market is growing faster than in the United States. Shares of Qualcomm rose $1.33, or 4 percent, to $34.68.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUSACK, , RICHARD
description: CUSACK -- Richard. The Schoolhouse Foundation extends our heartfelt condolences to our esteemed Board member, John Cusack, on the passing of his father, Dick Cusack. To Mrs. Cusack, Anne, Joan, Billy and Susie, know that Robert Browning wrote ''make us happy and you make us good.'' Dick made his family very happy and they are very good. Kevin McCabe, Chairman Dennis Meheil, Exec. Board >>AD#

title: A Trip Back to the Contradictions of the Stormy 60's
description: ''When you feel you have right on your side, you can do some pretty horrific things.''

title: To Embattled Mayor, Tickets Are the Hottest Issue in Town
description: The Bloomberg administration has been under attack for weeks from critics who claim the city is trying to fix its fiscal problems with a ticket blitz that has swept up people for violating obscure laws. A pregnant woman resting on subway steps was handed a $50 summons for blocking commuters. A Bronx man sitting on a milk crate on the sidewalk was given a ticket -- fine to be determined -- for unauthorized use of the crate.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Comic Images Of Musicians
description: The Supreme Court ruled that the rock musicians Johnny and Edgar Winter, left, may not prohibit a comic book from using their images. The comic book, ''Jonah Hex,'' included the characters Johnny and Edgar Autumn, who were, the court said, ''depicted as villainous half-worm, half-human offspring born from the rape of their mother by a supernatural worm creature.'' The court held that the comic books were protected by the First Amendment because they caricatured rather than traded on the Winters' public images. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Study Says Drug Group Can't Help Alzheimer's
description: Anti-inflammatory drugs do not live up to their promise as a treatment for Alzheimer's disease, a study being published today finds.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sex Offender Sought
description: The police are seeking a convicted sex offender in an attempted rape that occurred Monday afternoon on Canal Street. The man, George Augustine, 67, approached a woman about 4 p.m., pretended to have a gun, and tried to rape her, the police said. But after a struggle, she escaped and called the police. Mr. Augustine, who was recently working as an elevator operator, has been convicted of attempted murder, sodomy, sexual abuse and assault, according to the State Department of Correctional Services. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, , REV. JAMES. FRANCIS
description: COLEMAN -- Rev. James. Francis, S.J. Beloved brother of Peggy Mitchell. Dear uncle of William Neff and Michael Mitchell. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel in Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road on Wednesday from 3:00-5:00 and 7:009:00. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 11:30 am in the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel. For info contact Farenga Bros., Directors, 718-654-0500. >>AD#

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Limits On Video Games
description: The federal appeals court in St. Louis struck down a St. Louis County ordinance that prohibited selling or renting some violent video games to minors. The appeals court reversed a ruling by the trial court. The appeals court said the county had failed to demonstrate that the ordinance was needed to protect children from psychological harm. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Grocers Face Off Again on the West Side
description: ARE you for Fairway? Or do you shop FreshDirect? Which side are you on, anyway?

title: British Energy Takes Big Write-Down on Nuclear Plants
description: British Energy, which owns eight nuclear power plants in Britain and part of the Three Mile Island plant in Pennsylvania, said today that it had drastically lowered its estimate of what its power plants were worth, leading to a loss of 4.3 billion ($7 billion) in the fiscal year ended March 31.

title: Broadband Use Has Its Risks, Study Finds
description: Besides speed, the most coveted feature of a broadband connection is that it is always on. But according to a study that is scheduled to be released today, those two advantages are exposing broadband customers to far greater risk than most of them realize.

title: Judge Strikes Toll Increases on City Bridges and Tunnels
description: ANew York State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan ordered the Metropolitan Transportation Authority today to roll back toll increases on several bridges and tunnels, saying that officials had deliberately misled the public about finances before they approved the increases.

title: The Wrong Fish
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUER, , MURRAY
description: LAUER--Murray. 88, died June 2, 2003. Survived by his wife Hilda; daughter Marilyn Sticklor, son-in-law Howard; grandchildren Dawn, Russell, Laurel, Amy. Funeral Wednesday, June 4, 11:30 am, Midwood Chapels, Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn. Interment Old Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield Gardens, Queens. >>AD#

title: Robert D. Cross, 79, President of 2 Colleges, Dies
description: Robert D. Cross, a historian who was briefly president of Hunter College and Swarthmore College, died on Saturday in Charlottesville, Va., where he lived. He was 79.

title: Only Thing Certain in Finals Is That Lakers Won't Repeat
description: The National Basketball Association finals are back, revitalized and juiced up, loaded with suspense for the first time since Michael Jordan sank his famous jump shot against the Utah Jazz in 1998. Amid a backdrop of interesting story lines, the San Antonio Spurs, having survived three taxing series in the wild Western Conference, play host to the Nets, runaway winners in the middling East, on Wednesday in Game 1 at the SBC Center.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the reluctance of some Polish citizens to participate in Poland's referendum on joining the European Union misstated the time of the voting. It is this Saturday and Sunday -- not Sunday and Monday.

title: A Little Fire Over a Steak
description: I'M usually of the ''less is more'' philosophy in cooking, but I am by no means anti-sauce, and there are times when anyone wants to make a good thing better. That is the case, I believe, with this rich, smoky sauce of chipotle chilies, bacon and tomatoes. It is an odd sauce: while the combination of ingredients is reminiscent of the one used for spaghetti all'amatriciana, the chipotle transforms it into something that needs not a tame pasta but a sturdy steak.

title: Keeping It Simple, Keeping It Fast
description: SUZANNE GOIN was searching her stamp-size kitchen for a grater. Up she went on her step stool, sifting through a cabinet filled with spice jars, then across the room, peering deep into a cupboard, digging among bowls. ''I know that I just saw it,'' she said, exasperated.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the reluctance of some Polish citizens to participate in Poland's referendum on joining the European Union misstated the time of the voting. It is this Saturday and Sunday  not Sunday and Monday.

title: Hostage Freed in Algeria Recalls 52 Days of Dread
description: Twice, Ingo Bleckmann thought he would never leave the Algerian Sahara alive -- the first time when he and his group were captured by six Kalashnikov-wielding men and then, nearly two months later, when he and 16 others were freed in a raid by the Algerian Army.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: SUSPECT IN SCHEME VANISHES A video store manager accused of stealing more than $109,000 in state lottery ticket proceeds has vanished, the authorities said yesterday. On May 29, a grand jury in State Superior Court indicted Patrick Garvey, 46, of Ocean City, the manager of Reel World Video in Ocean City, on charges of theft and money laundering. He is accused of failing to turn over more than $92,000 in lottery ticket proceeds collected in December. He also cashed in more than $17,000 worth of lottery tickets by scratching off thousands of instant lottery tickets to find the 67 winning instant tickets he redeemed, said John R. Hagerty, a spokesman for the State Division of Criminal Justice. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: George Heyman Jr., Philanthropist, 86
description: George H. Heyman Jr., a philanthropist and financier who was president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York from 1969 to 1971 and a trustee of New York University and its Medical Center in the 1980's and 1990's, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Muslims lament Israel's existence
description: PARIS:  If the American threat of preemptive military action against Iraq inflamed the Muslim world over the winter, the war itself fanned the flames, with a sharp new rise in hostility toward the United States, the latest Pew survey has found.

title: A Job for Ex-Presidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Burglary Spree
description: The police said yesterday that they were investigating a string of 13 apartment burglaries in a three-block area of the Upper West Side that began May 18. The thief enters through windows or fire escapes in the early-morning hours and takes cash, clothing, cellphones, cameras, jewelry, computer equipment and credit cards. Three of them occurred at 291 Central Park West, four on West 88th Street (two in one building), four on West 89th Street, and one on West 90th Street. Another occurred at 285 Central Park West. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: FIVE ARAB LEADERS VOW ACTIVE FIGHT AGAINST VIOLENCE
description: Five Arab leaders pledged to President Bush today that they would actively fight ''the culture of extremism and violence'' that has undercut peace efforts in the Middle East for years, promising to stanch the flow of money to the terrorist groups that have carried out suicide bombings against Israel.

title: Movement Seen for Change On Rockefeller Drug Laws
description: An effort to revise the Rockefeller-era drug laws picked up momentum today as New York's governor and two top legislative leaders sought to find middle ground on the issue, which has only led to quarrels in the past.

title: A Night Proving Designers Can Play Well Together
description: The American fashion industry got together on Monday night at the New York Public Library to congratulate itself, an opportunity it relishes almost as much as harpooning its own in the back, and just about everyone agreed that it was a marvelous time.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Suspect In Scheme Vanishes
description: A video store manager accused of stealing more than $109,000 in state lottery ticket proceeds has vanished, the authorities said yesterday. On May 29, a grand jury in State Superior Court indicted Patrick Garvey, 46, of Ocean City, the manager of Reel World Video in Ocean City, on charges of theft and money laundering. He is accused of failing to turn over more than $92,000 in lottery ticket proceeds collected in December. He also cashed in more than $17,000 worth of lottery tickets by scratching off thousands of instant lottery tickets to find the 67 winning instant tickets he redeemed, said John R. Hagerty, a spokesman for the State Division of Criminal Justice. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: 5 Americans Are Held 26 Hours By Iranians
description: Four United States soldiers and a civilian American contractor were detained for 26 hours by Iran's Revolutionary Guard this week after their boats apparently strayed into Iranian waters, military officials said today.

title: A Little Bean With a Lot of Wallop
description: THE green objects resting on top of bias-cut rectangles of raw king salmon belly at Craft are not a garnish. Nor are they pieces of basil branch or sprigs of a strange new hybrid parsley. They are sea beans. And, for something so small they are remarkable.

title: Turnarounds Are Drawing Prospectors To Japan
description: Proving that there is money to be made in Japan, Wilbur Ross, the American corporate turnaround artist, is selling a regional bank and a credit card company for $410 million, ''which is two times what we paid for them in February 2001,'' he said in an interview here today.

title: Corrections
description: The credit on yesterday's Op-Art, about Iraqi refugees, misspelled the artist's name. It is Lauren Redniss.

title: Orange County to Use Merrill Again
description: Merrill Lynch & Company won the right to work for Orange County, Calif., nine years after the county filed for bankruptcy over a bad bet on interest-rate derivatives, most of which were sold by Merrill.

title: Corrections
description: A thumbnail explanation on Monday about the selection of a block in Ozone Park, Queens, for The Times's series of articles about the lives of its residents against the background of New York City's fiscal crisis misspelled the name of another Queens neighborhood where two blocks had also been considered. It is Bellerose, not Belrose.

title: Richard Wallach, 75, New York Appeals Justice
description: Richard Wingard Wallach, a New York state appeals court justice for the last 17 years, died Sunday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 75 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Recipe: Anise Cookies
description: Adapted from "Paris Sweets," by Dorie Greenspan

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a shift in strategy by United Airlines as it prepares to emerge from bankruptcy referred incorrectly to a change planned by a rival, American Airlines. It plans to add seats and shrink legroom for passengers on about a quarter of its flights, not on all of them.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank's Rating Lowered
description: Standard & Poor's Ratings Services lowered the long-term rating outlook on Kookmin Bank, Korea's largest financial institution, from stable to negative. Standard & Poor's said the revision reflected concern over Kookmin's credit to small and midsize enterprises and its exposure to risky credit card loans. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Women Are as Scarce as Change at Vienna Orchestra
description: It might have been a scene from a century ago. Dressed in traditional men's concert attire, the members of the Vienna Philharmonic were performing a major orchestral work by a great Austrian composer before an audience of demanding Viennese patrons.

title: East Meets South at a Delta Table
description: In this town in the Delta, home of the blues and Muddy Waters, cooks are sizzling catfish and collards and crayfish every day and night. But you don't expect to find those home chefs stir-frying them or steaming them in a giant backyard wok.

title: Hilliard Returns, and Giants Hope He Can Stick Around
description: Ike Hilliard recites his surgical history matter-of-factly:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Accountability Is Focus of Rule Aimed at Chiefs Of Wall Street
description: In an effort to bolster accountability on Wall Street, securities regulators are expected to propose a rule today requiring the chief executives of brokerage houses to certify that the supervision at their firms is adequate to protect investors.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Vote To Ban Ephedra Sales
description: The Westchester Board of Legislators voted 17 to 0 Monday to ban the sale of ephedra, the dietary supplement blamed for the death in February of Steve Bechler, the Baltimore Orioles pitcher. County Executive Andrew J. Spano, who proposed the bill, said he planned to sign it next week. An herbal stimulant, the drug is commonly taken by weightlifters and dieters and can cause heart, nerve and brain damage. The law will take effect 90 days after the bill is signed. Sale of the drug to minors is already banned. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Recipe: Lemon Cake
description: Adapted from "Barefoot Contessa Parties!" by Ina Garten

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column on Monday about Broadway stars scheduled to perform today in a free concert in Shubert Alley misspelled the surname of the lead actor in the musical ''Urinetown'' and in the television series ''Ed.'' He is Tom Cavanagh, not Cavanaugh.

title: MetroStars' Pope Out Up to 8 Weeks
description: Eddie Pope, the heart of the MetroStars' revitalized central defense, will miss the United States national team's games in the FIFA Confederations Cup in France and the Concacaf Gold Cup. He will be out six to eight weeks after a magnetic resonance imaging scan of his left knee on Monday revealed a nondisplaced patella fracture.

title: An Investment Adviser Urges That El Paso Board Be Ousted
description: Shareholders pushing for a new slate of directors for the El Paso Corporation won an important round yesterday.

title: Ex-Trader at Enron Is Charged in California Power Case
description: Federal authorities arrested a former senior trader with the Enron Corporation yesterday, charging him in a criminal complaint with manipulating the California power market during the state's energy crisis two years ago.

title: Northwest Flight Attendants Sue Over Wage Concessions
description: Flight attendants at Northwest Airlines sued the company yesterday, accusing it of breaking a promise to compensate them this summer for millions of dollars in wage and benefits concessions negotiated a decade ago.

title: Juror in Priest Case Expresses Misgivings About the Verdict
description: A juror who in April helped convict a Roman Catholic priest of sexually abusing a teenage boy has expressed misgivings about the verdict and complained about facing ''undue pressure'' from other jurors to find the priest guilty.

title: World's View of U.S. Sours After Iraq War, Poll Finds
description: The war in Iraq may have been a military success, but it has only deepened international skepticism toward the United States, its global policies and President Bush, with even military allies voicing growing disappointment or suspicion, a new poll has found.

title: Bronx Mother, 23, Is Accused Of Fracturing Her Baby's Head
description: A 23-year-old Bronx woman has been arrested on charges of fracturing her infant's skull by throwing him against a television stand, although her husband denies that she harmed the boy on purpose.

title: Israel and Palestinians Promise First Steps in Peace
description: AQABA, Jordan, June 4  Under the firm hand of President Bush, Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, pledged today to begin dismantling some "unauthorized outposts" of settlements in the West Bank, and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian prime minister, declared for the first time that "the armed intifada must end."

title: A Haunted Family en Route to Murder
description: The family in ''Ordinary People,'' Judith Guest's novel and Robert Redford's film, is torn apart by grief over a child's death. The child who survived feels guilty, his mother has turned ice cold, and the parents' marriage is at the breaking point. Things should be that simple for the Bannisters in Paula Milne's ''Thursday the 12th,'' a two-part British mystery movie that begins tonight on Bravo.

title: Two TV Crew Members, or Their Remains, Sought in Iraq
description: A hand-painted sign along a busy highway near here and some burn marks on the asphalt mark the location of one of the early clashes between American and Iraqi forces. That volley of bullets has come under scrutiny because a television journalist died in the crossfire and two of his crew members are missing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, , DIANA
description: FRIEDMAN--Diana. On June 3, 2003. Age 96. Beloved wife of the late George. Loving mother of Robert Friedman, Rita Stern and mother-in-law of Carole. Dear sister of Ethel Feuer. Cherished grandmother of six and great grandmother of thirteen. Services Wednesday, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made a charity of your choice. >>AD#

title: Correction
description: An editorial on May 20 about the effort to win a fare-hike rollback from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority incorrectly stated that the authority dismissed a previous inspector general who was perceived as too aggressive in his investigations. The official served his full term.

title: Student Planners to Be Provided
description: More than 560,000 New York City students will receive free student planners, including a daily calendar and reference information, under a new program announced last week by the city's Department of Education.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Law Backs Nannies' Rights
description: Families hiring nannies and housekeepers through employment agencies will be required to sign a statement outlining the workers' rights under a bill Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed into law yesterday. The new law, sponsored by Councilwoman Gale A. Brewer and other council members, requires employment agencies to inform domestic workers of their rights to overtime, time off and other conditions of employment before being placed with a family. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Pentagon Official Defends Intelligence on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 — A senior Pentagon official scoffed today at suggestions that he and other Defense Department leaders had tried to tweak intelligence data to justify war against Iraq.

title: Now, the SARS Emotional Toll
description: The pace of new SARS infections is ebbing in East Asia, but the disease now appears to be taking a greater emotional toll than initially recognized, both on people infected and on the many more people who face discrimination because of their association with SARS victims.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SPAIN: TRAIN COLLISION KILLS 5 A freight train and a passenger train collided in southeastern Spain, killing five people, the state railway company Renfe said. It said 20 people were missing after the crash near the city of Albacete, the latest in a series of train accidents in Spain in recent months. A local government official earlier told Antena 3 television that more than 30 people had been treated for injuries. Spanish television showed firefighters battling a blaze in one of the train carriages. Mangled wreckage and derailed carriages lay beside the track. "This was a head-on crash, either because of a technical or human error," said Antonio Rincon, an official from the Albacete government. The passenger train, on its way to the southeastern coastal city of Cartagena from Madrid, had nearly 90 people on board, Renfe said. ( Reuters )

title: In the Paint
description: Malik Rose looked at his bare arms, wondering if he was missing an essential part of 20-something, N.B.A. life.

title: INSIDE

title: Sweet and Simple, a Thai Charmer in Williamsburg
description: A DECADE ago, Planet Thailand was just a little restaurant on Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. With bold graphics and stark colors, Planet Thailand, housed in a former Polish cafe, perfectly reflected the neighborhood's metamorphosis from a community of European immigrants to a bohemian center for artists and musicians.

title: U.S. Security Backlog Strands Many Refugees in Camps Abroad
description: More than 20,000 refugees approved for resettlement in the United States remain stranded in desolate camps in Africa, Asia and the Middle East as officials here continue to struggle to reduce the backlog of required security clearances, State Department officials say.

title: Thousands in Hong Kong Hold Vigil for Tiananmen Victims
description: HONG KONG, June 4  Thousands of Hong Kong residents held a candlelight vigil tonight to commemorate the students who died in the Tiananmen Square killings in 1989 and to call on their own government to preserve civil liberties here.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: ILLINOIS: SUSPENSIONS IN FOOTBALL MELEE Suspensions resulting from a drunken touch football game have been lifted for 15 of 20 junior girls at Glenbrook North High School. The 15 girls agreed to undergo counseling and promised not to profit commercially from the incident. The rest did not agree to the school's proposal, meaning that they will receive no academic credit for the nine days they will have missed.    Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Bankruptcy Is Changing Air Canada
description: The in-flight meals on Air Canada are still free, but not the new ''cinema combo'' of chocolate bars, licorice, Hagen-Dasz ice cream and mineral water, which the airline has begun selling on some of its North American flights in recent weeks. description: When the Yankees looked ragged on Sunday, they had a ready excuse: they were trying too hard to give Roger Clemens his 300th victory. Besides, they said, they ended up winning the game.

description: Judging by the ardent reception Seiji Ozawa received after conducting Puccini's ''Tosca'' on Saturday night at the Vienna State Opera, the music-mad Viennese public has embraced this international conductor of Japanese heritage who is concluding his first season as that company's music director. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STUDER, , LILLIAN (NEE ROSENBERG)
description: STUDER--Lillian (nee Rosenberg). Died peacefully at home on June 2, 2003 after a long illness. Lillian was born in Pittsburgh, PA and was a graduate of the University of Pittsburgh. After WWII, she moved to New York City where she worked for many years as an advertising copy writer for several prominent advertising agencies. She was actively involved in Advertising Women of New York where she held many offices during the years of her involvement. Lillian was a great lover of the arts with a particular passion for music. She was married to the late Irving Rudensky and previously, to the late Irving Studer. Lillian will be greatly missed by her many friends and family. She is survived by her brothers, Joseph (Ruth) Rosenberg of Silver Spring, MD, and Irwin (Mildred) Rosenberg of Pittsburgh, PA and her nephews and nieces, who had such a loving and special place in her heart, including Ira Zuckerman, Chuck Rosenberg, Linda Brown, Larry Rosenberg, and Ilene Price and their families. A memorial service for Lillian will be held on Thursday June 5, 2003 at 5:30 o'clock at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Her family requests that any donations in her name are made to Cancer Care, Inc of New York or The Humane Society of New York. >>AD#

description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg scaled back another of his threatened budget cuts yesterday, agreeing not to reduce staffing in as many fire companies as planned.

title: Gripped By Manu Mania
description: To Argentine sports fans, a Boca Juniors-River Plate soccer game is the equivalent of a Yankees-Red Sox matchup. Yet last Saturday, one day before this year's grudge match, the front pages of sports sections of the country's main newspapers focused on a basketball player who plays for a team nearly 6,000 miles away, in San Antonio.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Midtown Manhattan; Club and Hotel to Share More Than the Name
description: There is the City Club of New York, and there is the City Club Hotel. Both are linked to the building at 55 West 44th Street that was the club's clubhouse from its construction in 1904 until financial difficulties forced its sale in 1939.

title: Research Chief Will Leave First Boston
description: Alfred G. Jackson, the chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston's research division, will leave the firm in the coming months, officials of First Boston announced yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: WHITE PLAINS: VOTE TO BAN EPHEDRA SALES The Westchester Board of Legislators voted 17 to 0 Monday to ban the sale of ephedra, the dietary supplement blamed for the death in February of Steve Bechler, the Baltimore Orioles pitcher. County Executive Andrew J. Spano, who proposed the bill, said he planned to sign it next week. An herbal stimulant, the drug is commonly taken by weightlifters and dieters and can cause heart, nerve and brain damage. The law will take effect 90 days after the bill is signed. Sale of the drug to minors is already banned. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: IRAQ ARMS REPORT NOW THE SUBJECT OF A C.I.A. REVIEW
description: A top secret United States intelligence report last fall is now at the center of an internal C.I.A. review to determine whether American intelligence miscalculated the extent of the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's weapons programs. The report had concluded that Baghdad had chemical and biological weapons and was seeking to reconstitute its nuclear program.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Nickel Mine Strike
description: The nickel producer Inco said that it would not be able to honor some supply contracts as a result of a strike at its flagship operations in Sudbury, Ontario. The strike, involving 3,300 workers, began last weekend after talks on a new labor contract broke down. The Sudbury operations supply 9 percent of the world's nickel, used mainly to make stainless steel. Bernard Simon (NYT)

description: JERUSALEM, June 4  Jerusalem has elected its first ultra-Orthodox Jewish mayor, Uri Lupolianski, a rabbi and father of 12 who has pledged to improve city services and has refrained from confronting volatile political issues.

description: Spain's largest savings bank, La Caixa, is selling its 5 percent stake in Endesa, the country's biggest power company, for about 865 million euros ($1 billion) to reduce its equity holdings. The bank, whose full name is La Caja de Ahorros y Pensiones de Barcelona, is selling the stake through a sale of three-year bonds exchangeable from Aug. 11 into Endesa shares, said Javier Zuloaga, a Caixa spokesman in Barcelona.

description: The Rev. Shirley Bulah Stamps, whose parents' fight for her to ride a school bus became part of the 1954 Supreme Court case that ended school segregation, died on Wednesday in Wilmington, Del. She was 59.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Vernon: Youth Curfew Overturned
description: A federal appeals panel has overturned a curfew on youths under 18 in Vernon. The town's curfew, enacted in 1994, requires children be home by 11 p.m. on weekdays and by 12:01 a.m. on weekends. The curfew ends at 5 a.m. A resident, Janet Ramos, challenged the ordinance on behalf of her sons Angel and Richard. On Monday, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York ruled 2 to 1 that the authority to decide when children should be home resides with parents, not with local governments. ''Surely a parent can decide that a child must generally be home between midnight and 5 in the morning,'' Senior Judge Richard J. Cardamone wrote. But Judge Ralph K. Winter dissented, saying that the curfew helped parents in ''rebutting the 'all the other kids do it' argument.'' Paul von Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Mideast Dips to Sink a Chip Into
description: Do you like your hummus silky smooth or with more texture? Your eggplant dip as a pure or chunky? Sabra, of Astoria, Queens, offers those options and many more in about two dozen dips and spreads, many scoring high on the garlic scale. The company packs some items in big 17-ounce clear plastic tubs with attractive garnishes on top. (For entertaining, you can just remove the lid.) Two examples are hummus topped with pine nuts and olive oil and ''hummus Marrakesh,'' sprinkled with herbs and paprika. Some mayonnaise-based salads are available, including a tasty spreadable version with mushrooms. The products are kosher and come in containers of 7 to 8 ounces and 16 to 17 ounces, for about $2 to $5. They are sold at Food Emporium, Key Food and Zabar's in the New York area and in supermarket chains nationwide.

title: John Jay President to Step Down
description: GERALD W. LYNCH, president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice since 1977, will step down in the summer of 2004. Dr. Lynch, 66, joined the college in 1966 as an instructor and served as dean of students and vice president; he became acting president in 1975. The college is part of the City University of New York. During Dr. Lynch's presidency, John Jay has broadened its liberal arts and criminal justice programs. Next year it will add a master's in forensic computing and a Ph.D. program in forensic psychology. Karen W. Arenson

There is probably no town in this country that does not have a street, square or school named for her, the first Latin American to win the Nobel Prize for literature, and her poems and essays have long been part of the school curriculum.

The sponsor, Miller Brewing, has apparently decided it does not want the image of its largest brand to be defined by a sexual sell, especially when consumers do not seem to be buying.

title: A Trove of Old-Time Delights
description: Slow Food, which tries to preserve artisanal food, has issued ''The Slow Food Guide to New York City Restaurants, Markets and Bars,'' by Patrick Martins and Ben Watson (Chelsea Green, $20). It highlights places that use organic products and ingredients from local farms, and others that have been family-run for generations. It digs deep into neighborhoods all over and is excellent on ethnic shops and dining spots. Mr. Martins is the director of Slow Food U.S.A., and Mr. Watson works for the publisher. The contributors include food writers like Barbara Kafka, chefs like Mario Batali and a few publicists. The book will not be in stores until October, but it is now sold by Slow Food for $16 plus shipping; (212) 965-5640.

description: WHEN chefs become stars, diners have a right to develop suspicions. Will the demands of fame hurt the restaurant that put the chef on the map in the first place? Can anyone satisfy the demands of television and run a kitchen at the same time? Bobby Flay, the chef and a partner in Mesa Grill and Bolo, may be a notch below ''bam'' on the celebrity scale, but he is getting there. He has the cookbooks and the line of sauces and spice rubs. He has a series, ''Food Nation,'' on the Food Network. Near-electrocution while competing on ''Iron Chef'' solidified his reputation as New York's Derek Jeter of the kitchen -- brash and charismatic.
