title: Making an Antihero
description: Eric Rudolph, now charged with setting off bombs at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, a gay nightclub in Atlanta and abortion clinics in Atlanta and Birmingham, Ala., has a depressingly familiar rsum. Social isolation and youthful exposure to extremist social views were succeeded by a gradual disaffection with most of the institutions that usually lead to greater socialization, including school and the Army. It is a recipe for the terrible solitude of crazed righteousness.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Plead Guilty To Taking Bribes
description: Two construction officials pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to taking bribes from a contractor working on the new federal courthouse and the renovation of the main post office in Downtown Brooklyn. One man, Albert Pagano, 72, who was overseeing the courthouse project for the federal General Services Administration, accepted about $30,000 from the contractor, Nicholas Langanella, said Mr. Pagano's lawyer, Joseph Tacopina. Mr. Pagano said he failed to prevent Mr. Langanella from getting a construction contract even though he knew his company was unqualified. The other man, Victor Scallo, 62, who was supervising the post office reconstruction for the J. A. Jones Construction Group, said he had demanded $65,000 from Mr. Langanella in return for helping him win a multimillion-dollar contract to upgrade the grounds. Mr. Langanella pleaded guilty last week, prosecutors said. All three men will probably receive sentences of two to three years in prison, prosecutors said. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Marooned on Culture Island
description: Like the acoustics of Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center has never really worked. This island of culture stands apart from the city like a fortress, with an elevated plaza on the east offering a lukewarm welcome to one segment of society while concrete walls shut off the less fortunate segment represented by the public housing to the west. Centers like this deaden urban street life, bringing a rush of traffic and human activity all at one time and then lying almost dormant the rest of the day, like a stadium without a game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURKE, , DONALD P.
description: BURKE--Donald P. of Monmouth Beach, NJ formerly of Tinton Falls, NJ died on Monday, June 2, 2003 at Riverview Medical Center, Red Bank, NJ. Husband of the late Joyce Burke. Father of Michael J. Burke and Michael's fiancee, Gretchen J. Fitzer; Robert C. Burke, II and the late Sheila Anne Burke. Father-in-law of Laurie Deliman Burke. Brother of Robert C. Burke I and his wife Edna. Son of the late John W. and Julia A. Burke. Godfather of Gail Henry. Special friend of Rosemary Edelen. Mr. Burke was an industry-leading magazine editor and a long time resident of Monmouth County, NJ. He lived in Tinton Falls, NJ for 47 years before moving to Monmouth Beach, NJ one year ago. He was editor of Chemical Week, then a McGraw-Hill publication, retiring as acting editor-in-chief in 1989. His career with that New York City based publication began in 1950 when he worked as a senior editor; he became executive editor in 1973. He was a long-term member of Alcoholics Anonymous, associated with many local groups for more than two decades. At the time of his death, he was in his 26th year of sobriety. He served as an industry representative for the Department of Commerce at the Incheba Czechoslovakia, International Chemistry Fair in 1977. He was a contributing editor for the Encyclopedia Brittanica and Harper and Row's Encyclopedia of Science. Industry leaders and writers have cited his incisive writing for Chemical Week for its clarity, precision and accuracy. During World War II, he earned a spot in the Army Specialized Training Program, receiving a certificate from the Citadel in 1944 and studying at the University of Kentucky and the Brooklyn Institute of Technology. Later, he served in the Panama Canal Zone, separating from the service in 1946 with an honorable discharge as a technician 5th grade Company A 150th Infantry Regiment. After the service, he received a B.S. in chemistry and math from St. Peter's College, Jersey City, and did postgraduate study evenings at Stevens Institute of Technology, Hoboken, from 1947-1951. Visitation will be held at the Braun Funeral Home, 106 Broad St, Eatontown, NJ on Thursday, June 5, 2003 from 2-4 & 7-9PM. A funeral mass will be celebrated at St. Dorothea's R.C. Church, Eatontown, NJ on Friday, June 6, 2003 at 10:00AM. Interment will follow in Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Toms River: Birthday Campfire Led To Blaze
description: The third suspect in a huge forest fire last year pleaded guilty on Monday to building an illegal campfire that led to the blaze. It burned more than 1,300 acres last June and threatened hundreds of homes bordering the Pinelands Double Trouble State Park. The suspect, Christopher Walters, 20, of Beachwood, is to be sentenced on July 18. He and two companions -- one who has already pleaded guilty and another who was a juvenile at the time -- were celebrating the birthday of another friend when they built the campfire, the authorities said. The Mixing Bowl, formerly Kids in the Kitchen, is a well-equipped cooking school for children at 243 East 82nd Street. And it's not just about decorating cupcakes. Meredith Berman, a former nursery school teacher who runs the school, offers guidance about safety, hygiene and healthy eating and helps pupils make their own cookbooks. Hourlong classes are divided by age, from 2 1/2 to 8 or 9. The next four-week summer program starts July 7, with six-session courses in August and longer sessions in September. Courses cost $140 to $672. Single sessions, at $40, are taught on Wednesdays. Birthday parties can be scheduled. Information: (212) 585-2433 or www.kidsinthekitchennyc.com.

The measure is expected to raise $180 million for a state budget shortfall that had been estimated at $620 million and is in part because of rising medical costs. title: World Briefing: Asia

Truong Van Cam, better known as Nam Cam, was found guilty of murder, assault, gambling, running gambling dens, sheltering criminals and bribery. He is among 154 defendants, including several Communist Party officials, put on trial on organized crime charges. Mr. Cam's sentencing is scheduled for Thursday. He faces the death penalty.   (AP)

description: After Tim Duncan dunked over Aaron Williams with whiplash force four minutes into the fourth quarter tonight, he unleashed an uncharacteristic roar.

title: Another G.I. Dies in Violence-Prone Iraqi Town
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, June 5  United States military officials said today that an American soldier was killed and five others were wounded here Wednesday night when they were hit by a rocket-propelled grenade  the latest attack in a tense town where resistance against American occupation has been vocal and often violent.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS TO BUY GERMAN ELECTRONICS COMPANY
description: Johnson Controls Inc., a maker of automotive interiors, said it would buy a German automotive-electronics maker, Borg Instruments, to improve its European-built products. The acquisition will add to fiscal 2004 earnings, Johnson Controls said. It did not disclose the terms of the cash purchase. Borg, based in Remchingen, Germany, has 400 workers and had sales last year of 55 million euros ($64 million). Johnson Controls is based in Milwaukee.

title: Storage Methods Come and Go, but Tape Holds Its Own
description: WHEN it comes to storing data, magnetic tape would seem to represent the past, not the future. The basic technology is half a century old, and those rooms full of reel-to-reel tape machines that were once a symbol of computing power are all but gone.

title: Funny Cide Is Favorite To Complete Triple Crown
description: In a sport that reveres numbers, Funny Cide was assigned two more yesterday at the post position draw for the 135th running of the Belmont Stakes on Saturday: 4 and 1. The first New York-bred to win the Kentucky Derby will break from the No. 4 hole, and the track's oddsmaker, Don LaPlace, made him a 1-1, or even money, favorite to become the first gelding to win the Triple Crown.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Panel Clears Judicial Nominee
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee said that it had cleared a judicial nominee of wrongdoing in connection with questions raised by a private government watchdog group. The group, Judicial Watch, told the committee last month that it had evidence that the F.B.I. in New Jersey had improperly used organized crime informants in the 1990's at a time when the nominee, Michael Chertoff, was the United States attorney there. The White House has nominated Mr. Chertoff, now the head of the Justice Department's criminal division, to be an appellate judge for the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, and his confirmation is pending before the Senate. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: SARS Epidemic Winding Down, Health Officials Say
description: BEIJING, June 5  Sounding decidedly upbeat, international health officials declared here today that the SARS epidemic was winding down all over the world, including in China, the world's worst hit country.

title: For the Press, a Case That Is an Irresistible Draw
description: When Martha Stewart stepped out of the federal courthouse in downtown Manhattan yesterday after pleading not guilty to securities fraud and related charges, she was met by a light mist -- and an intense barrage of cameras. The travails of an unrepentant defendant who is both corporate titan and the most intimidating homemaker on earth have created a frenzy among news media outlets jostling for a share of the story.

title: Communications Central In a Small, Colorful Package
description: Danger now comes in 65,536 colors -- that is, the new T-Mobile Sidekick from Danger Inc. The Sidekick, a wireless communicator for telephone, e-mail, Web browsing and instant messaging tasks, first appeared last year with a monochrome screen but has upgraded to a 240-by-160-pixel color display. That is not the only improvement: the new Sidekick packs twice as much of everything under the hood. It now has 32 megabytes of memory and can hold 2,000 contacts and 50 text notes.

title: Scandal-Touched German Politician Dies in Parachute Fall
description: BERLIN, June 5 — A prominent German politician and member of the German Parliament who was accused of anti-Semitism last year and, more recently, embroiled in charges of financial wrongdoing, died in a parachute jump today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOSORESOW, , ANDREW PETER
description: KOSORESOW--Andrew Peter. Age 39, on June 1, 2003 at his home in New York City of heart failure. An adored Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Columbia University since 1997, he was an alumnus of Cathedral School, 1978; Collegiate School, 1982; Columbia College, 1985; and Stanford University, 1996 (Ph.D.). He had previously taught at the University of New Mexico and at Stanford University. He is survived by his mother, Claudia Kosoresow. Two Russian Orthodox services will be held: a memorial prayer service on Thursday, June 5th at 7:30PM; a funeral service on Friday, June 6th at 11:00AM. Both services will be held at: Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign, 75 E. 93rd St. at Park Ave., New York, NY 10128. Following the Friday service, interment will be conducted at: Novo Diveevo Cemetery, Smith Road, Spring Valley, NY.

title: The Media Goliath Just Got Bigger (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Cellphones Made Easy
description: Red phones, blue phones,

title: Blair Accused Of Distorting Intelligence On Iraqi Arms
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair, President Bush's chief ally in the war in Iraq, told a boisterous session of the House of Commons today that charges that the government distorted spy reports to exaggerate the threat of unconventional weapons and justify the war were false.

title: ISRAEL AND PALESTINIANS SAY THEY WILL TAKE FIRST STEPS IN QUEST FOR MIDEAST PEACE
description: Under the firm hand of President Bush, Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, pledged today to begin dismantling some ''unauthorized outposts'' of settlements in the West Bank, and Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian prime minister, declared for the first time that ''the armed intifada must end.''

title: Judge Orders Toll Rollback At Crossings
description: A State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan ordered the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday to roll back toll increases on several bridges and tunnels, saying that the authority deliberately misled the public about its finances before it approved the increases.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Rules On Meat Contamination
description: The Agriculture Department announced rules that officials said would help prevent ready-to-eat meats from becoming contaminated by Listeria monocytogenes bacteria in the plants where they are produced. Last year listeria-infested meat killed seven people and led to the recall of 27.4 million pounds of meat by Pilgrim's Pride of Pittsburgh, Pa. Consumer advocates said the new rules did not include automatic testing if listeria was found in a plant. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Aide Denies Shaping Data to Justify War
description: The Pentagon's top policy adviser held an unusual briefing today to rebut accusations that senior civilian policy makers had politicized intelligence to fit their hawkish views on Iraq and to justify war on Saddam Hussein.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspect In Sex Crime Is Arrested
description: A convicted sex offender wanted for the attempted rape of a woman on Canal Street was arrested yesterday morning on the Queensboro Bridge, the police said. The suspect, George Augustine, 67, was arrested around 9:30 a.m. on the Manhattan side of the bridge, the police said. Mr. Augustine, an elevator operator, was charged with attempted rape, assault, unlawful imprisonment, criminal possession of a weapon and menacing in connection with the attack Monday afternoon on the woman, who fought back. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center after his arrest, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Marking Tianamen, Hong Kong Crowd Opposes Security Law
description: Under a yellow crescent moon, thousands of Hong Kong residents held a candlelight vigil tonight to commemorate the students who died in the Tiananmen Square killings in 1989 and to call on their own government to preserve civil liberties here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BREGMAN, , HARRIET NEE FRANTZ
description: BREGMAN -- Harriet nee Frantz. Of Tenafly, NJ, on June 3, 2003. Beloved wife of Milton. Cherished and adored aunt. Services ''Wien & Wien'' 129 Engle St, Englewood Thursday 12:45 PM. Should friends desire contributions to the Englewood Chapter of Hadassah would be greatly appreciated. >>AD#

title: Post-Trojan War Turmoil in a Rarely Heard Rossini
description: These days, ''Ermione, '' Rossini's operatic tale of shattered love and violence in the wake of the Trojan War, is like an exotic bird. Sightings are rare, but when they occur, the viewer is often taken by the brilliant plumage, or in this case, the opera's dramatic scope, finely drawn characters and exquisite music.

title: On Video Games, The Jury Is Out And Confused
description: VICTORIA TAPLIN of Chevy Chase, Md., has struggled for years with the question of whether to let her two sons, Russell, 11, and Paul, 8, play video games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELL, , MAREN
description: DELL--Maren. Dan Klores Communications deeply mourns the loss of our colleague and friend Maren Dell. We will always remember her bright smile, warm spirit and dedicated work ethic. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, June 8, 11:30am at Goldsteins' Rosenberg's Raphael-Sacks Funeral Home, 310 2nd St. Pike, Southampton, PA, 215-927-5800 >>AD#

title: 3 Networks Left Vying for Rights
description: The International Olympic Committee does not know yet where the 2010 or the 2012 Games will be held, but by the end of this weekend, it will almost certainly know how much an American company will pay for their media rights.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Cost Of a Mine Strike
description: Inco Ltd., one of the world's biggest nickel producers, said profit would be reduced $20 million for each month that a strike continues at its operations in Ontario. Inco shut its Sudbury-area operations Sunday after 3,200 production and maintenance workers walked out over pensions. The mines produce about 9 percent of the world's nickel supply. Inco, which is based in Toronto, said on Tuesday that it would miss deliveries of nickel, copper and other metals because of the strike. The company and the United Steelworkers of America, which represents the workers, are at odds over improvements in pensions.

title: In Basel, Art Is Storage, And Storage Is Art
description: The Basel Museum of Contemporary Art had the usual problem: Much of its extensive collection was languishing in storage. The Swiss architectural firm Herzog & de Meuron -- the same enterprising team that decorated a Ricola cough-drop factory in France with pictures of yarrow leaves and converted a London power station into the Tate Modern -- solved it with a new architectural category, the Schaulager, or show storage.

title: Citing Vagueness, Judge Blocks Nassau County Smoking Ban
description: A federal judge today temporarily blocked Nassau County from enforcing its three-month-old ban on smoking in bars and restaurants, a law that helped inspire similar rules in other suburbs, New York City and the rest of the state.

title: Martha Stewart's Troubled World
description: When Martha Stewart took her company public in 1999, she designed her own stock certificates and served 3,000 breakfasts of scones, croissants and egg-and-herb-filled brioches at the New York Stock Exchange. That sort of attention to detail helped her parlay a small catering business into a billion-dollar empire. But her stunning career may be unraveling with her indictment yesterday on securities fraud and obstruction of justice charges. If she is brought down, the story will be one with Shakespearean overtones -- a woman who was so detail oriented that, even with a net worth of hundreds of millions, she could not resist an illegal stock trade that netted her $45,000.

title: Drug Maker's Vow to Donate Cancer Medicine Falls Short
description: When Novartis, one of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies, set out to give away a revolutionary cancer drug to people around the world who could not otherwise afford it, the company promised that no patient who needed the medicine would go without it.

title: Keeping on the Funny Cide
description: Break out the Champagne immediately for Funny Cide, the New York-born horse that has already won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness. By Saturday's Belmont Stakes, the third prong in racing's Triple Crown, it could be too late. Since Affirmed's sweep in 1978, eight horses have won the first two races but faded in the grueling third round in New York's longer race. So, Funny Cide admirers would do well to enjoy the pre-Belmont glow -- every golden hometown moment of it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Luxury Cars Stolen From Driveways
description: Members of a car-theft ring brazenly stole $1 million worth of luxury cars like Audis, BMW's and Mercedes-Benzes from garages and driveways in affluent communities, the Westchester district attorney's office said yesterday. Four men were arrested on Tuesday and charged with first-degree unauthorized use of a motor vehicle and third-degree grand larceny. Authorities said the ringleader was Robert Lue of Mount Vernon. Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester district attorney, said the ring was believed to be responsible for most of the luxury cars stolen in Rye, Scarsdale and Larchmont in recent months. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

title: European Central Bank Cuts Interest Rate
description: FRANKFURT, June 5  Answering the pleas of desperate European exporters and nervous public officials, the European Central Bank today cut its benchmark interest rate by a half point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKAF, , RICHARD
description: SKAF--Richard. The New York Times records with sorrow the passing of Richard Skaf, associated with The Times from December 1966 until retiring in December 1997. >>AD#

title: In Jerusalem, Thousands Rally Against Peace Bid; Palestinians Also Assail It
description: Tens of thousands of right-wing Israelis, many of them Jewish settlers, rallied tonight in the center of Jerusalem and vehemently denounced the prospect of a Palestinian state as sketched by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.

title: Navy's Father as Self-Destructive Hero
description: JOHN PAUL JONES

title: Prosecutors Have Reasons for Stalking Celebrities
description: Martha Stewart's lawyer wasted no time yesterday suggesting that his client had become a target for government prosecutors on account of her fame.

title: Despite Shuffle, Stewart Is Still in Charge
description: If Martha Stewart is looking for a new corporate role model, she may need to look no further than Steve Madden, the shoe designer who is serving time for securities fraud and money laundering.

title: Serena Williams Is Upset at the French Open
description: PARIS, June 5 (Reuters) - Belgian Justine Henin-Hardenne ended the grand slam dominance of Serena Williams on Thursday when she stunned the defending champion 6-2 4-6 7-5 in the French Open semi-finals.

title: Democrats, Seeing Dominance of Conservatives' Message, Form Group to Fight It
description: A group of Democrats are forming a political research institute in an effort to counter what they see as the domination of the national political debate by well-organized, well-financed conservatives at the White House, in Congress, in a variety of media and in policy institutes all over Washington.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Jerusalem Elects Its Mayor
description: Jerusalem has elected its first ultra-Orthodox mayor, Uri Lupolianski, left, a rabbi and father of 12 who has pledged to improve city services and has refrained from confronting volatile political issues. Rabbi Lupolianski, who was appointed acting mayor in February after the incumbent, Ehud Olmert, joined the national government, defeated Nir Barkat, a millionaire businessman, by 52 percent to 42 percent, according to unofficial results. In his victory speech, Rabbi Lupolianski promised not to alter the current balance between religious and secular Jews. His victory reflects the growing influence of the ultra-Orthodox in Jerusalem, who now account for around one-third of the city's 680,000 residents. Secular Jews also account for about a third, as do the Arabs who are concentrated in east Jerusalem. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Russia Pausing on Iran Nuclear Deal, Blair Says; Denial Follows
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said today that Russia ad pledged to suspend a planned shipment of nuclear fuel to Iran until the Iranian government accepts new international controls on its nuclear program, but Russia's top nuclear official said that no such promise had been made.

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''We have lived in denial of the violence of abortion for far too long. Today, we can stop some of this violence against children.''

title: Indoor Chic for the Outdoors
description: Outdoor fabric can be boring, with its awning stripes or solid colors in a choice of green or blue. But a new line of indoor-outdoor upholstery from Donghia is made of Sunbrella, a synthetic fabric, and comes in bold-colored patterns influenced by Guatemalan textiles, above. It is soft to the touch but resistant to water, mildew, sun and soil. The fabric is 54 inches wide and costs $59 to $89 a yard, to the trade only; (212) 935-3713 or www.donghia.com for the locations of showrooms. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Lurking Within the Hi-Fi Rack, a Hard Drive That Rips
description: Home audio components are catching the MP3 wave as the popular digital music format makes its way from hard drives and portable players into the living-room sound system. Although from the outside the new DA-9000 CDRW Jukebox from TDK looks like any other component for the home stereo, deep inside it spins a 20-gigabyte hard drive alongside a conventional CD system that can play and record standard and MP3 audio CD's.

title: Political Leaders Resisting U.S. Plan to Govern Iraq
description: Iraq's main political groups appear to be edging toward a confrontation with the American administrator, L. Paul Bremer III, over his decision not to allow Iraqis the right to form their own interim government during the American-British occupation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRAIGHT, , LADY DAPHNE MARGARITA
description: STRAIGHT -- Lady Daphne Margarita, wife of the late Whitney Straight and beloved mother of Camilla and Amanda, died peacefully at home in London on June 3, 2003. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINFIELD, , SUSANNE (EISMANN)
description: WEINFIELD--Susanne (Eismann) of NYC, on June 2, 2003 at age 77. Mother of Henry (Joyce) and Anthony (Barbara) Weinfield, grandmother of Paul, Saralena, Vera, Elizabeth, Catherine and Madeline. Donations to Simon Wiesenthal Center or Int'l Raoul Wallenberg Found. Information: Saul Colonial Home, Hamilton Square, NJ. >>AD#

title: Living Organ Donors
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable and Wireless Posts Loss And Plans to Pull Out of U.S.
description: Cable and Wireless, the struggling British telecommunications company, said today that it would cut 1,500 jobs, pull out of the United States and retool its corporate structure in a bid to salvage itself.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Convicted In Subway Murder
description: A jury found a man guilty of murder and robbery yesterday for his role in the fatal shooting of a sleeping passenger on a No. 2 subway train three years ago. The defendant, Ali Carrington, 27, of Queens, tried to steal a gold chain from the passenger, Louis Nixon, 28, with the aid of another man, Michael Amuso, on a northbound train on Nov. 7, 2000, the police said. Mr. Nixon, a United Parcel Service worker, was fatally wounded when one of the men, apparently frustrated in the robbery attempt, shot him once in the abdomen. Mr. Carrington, who was tried in State Supreme Court, faces 25 years to life in prison. Mr. Amuso's case is pending. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Islanders Tap Minors For Coach
description: Steve Stirling? You might have heard of him if you followed Austrian hockey back in the late 1970's when he was on that country's national team. Maybe you remember him from Boston University's powerhouse squads of 30 years ago. Or maybe you caught him playing junior hockey in London, Ontario.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading on Tuesday with a sports article about Viacom's decision to withdraw from the bidding on media rights to the 2010 and 2012 Olympic Games misstated the reasons given. The company, which owns CBS, said that it did not want to commit significant funds to events still years away -- not that it had doubts about the future strength of broadcast television.

title: Robert D. Cross, 79, President of 2 Colleges
description: Robert D. Cross, a historian who was briefly president of Hunter College and Swarthmore College, died on Saturday in Charlottesville, Va., where he lived. He was 79.

title: Catalog Tries to Win Bookstore Crowd
description: Kartell, the Italian-based furniture maker, gave photographers free rein to shoot from its collection. The result, ''kARTell: 150 Items, 150 Artworks'' (Skira Editore, $50), is both 280-page coffee-table book and catalog. Artists like Peter Lindbergh, Helmut Newton, Bruce Weber and Melodie McDaniel shot still lifes of the furniture, put it in fields and on streets and accessorized it with models. Vanessa Beecroft shot the Eros chair (above, $461) as a cradle for her son. Rizzoli, (800) 522-6657, carries the book; Kartell is at 39 Greene Street (near Grand), (212) 966-6665. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: MAYOR RESTORING HIS DEEPEST CUTS IN CITY'S SERVICES
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg backed away yesterday from $90.2 million in service cuts, abandoning plans to reduce trash pickups outside Manhattan, curtail library hours and slash a summer jobs program.

title: Virgin Mobile begins a campaign to make itself the premier wireless company for young people.
description: VIRGIN MOBILE USA hopes to jump-start its cellphone business among teenage and young adult customers with a campaign beginning tonight during the MTV Movie Awards.

title: Charity Collector Says Audit Showed Shortfall in Revenue
description: PipeVine Inc., a nonprofit organization that managed charitable giving through payroll deductions, issued a statement tonight laying the blame for its sudden collapse on Monday on accounting problems.

title: School's Out? Here's a History Lesson About Brooklyn-Queens Day
description: If you happen to attend public school in Brooklyn or Queens, chances are you are sleeping late and may never glimpse this article because today is all about leisure. If you are stuck in Manhattan, the Bronx or Staten Island, on the other hand, suck it up and get to class.

title: NASA's Foam Test Offered A Vivid Lesson in Kinetics
description: The recent test suggesting that falling foam at liftoff could have caused the damage that doomed the space shuttle Columbia was a jaw-dropping demonstration of the destructive power of something so light, a NASA official said today.

title: Chrysler Design Awards Dropped After 10 Years
description: THE Chrysler Group, which spent the last decade promoting design innovation as central to its car-selling strategy, quietly but abruptly ended its Chrysler Design Awards program on Monday, two days after announcing staff changes at the top of its marketing department. On Tuesday the company said it would post a second-quarter operating loss of $1.2 billion.

title: Justices to Rule on Schedule Of Campaign Finance Case
description: Within the next few days, possibly as early as Thursday, the Supreme Court will announce how it plans to handle one of the most daunting logistical challenges in the court's recent history: organizing and scheduling the appeals in the huge campaign finance case in a manner most likely to produce a coherent presentation and prompt decision.

title: Dear Darpa Diary
description: Unless you work for the government or the Mafia, it's a great idea to keep a diary.

title: Battling the Chaos in Schools' Arts Classes
description: At the Heritage High School in East Harlem, students in a class on three-dimensional art make life-size sculptures in the tradition of George Segal from chicken wire and papier-mch. In advanced band, students practice the theme from the movie ''Spider-Man'' on clarinets, flutes, trumpets, electric bass and drums.

title: In the President's Words: 'A Mutual Desire to Work Toward the Vision'
description: Following are excerpts from a press pool interview with President Bush yesterday aboard Air Force One, as provided by the White House. A complete transcript is online at nytimes.com/international.

title: Man, 22, Dies After Police Subdue Him With Spray
description: A 22-year-old man who officials said was high on drugs went into cardiac arrest and died in Washington Heights yesterday after police officers subdued him with pepper spray to stop him from attacking his father, the police said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Group Sues Money Advisers
description: The Sergeants Benevolent Association has sued its former investment companies, saying the firms caused the association's retirement fund to lose at least $27 million over two years. The suit, filed on Tuesday in State Supreme Court, accused Monitoring and Evaluation Services; its officers, John T. Renck and John J. Renck; and the investment adviser, Trainer Wortham & Company, of trading excessively in volatile stocks. The association, which represents about 10,000 active and retired police sergeants, hired the firms in 1993 and 1994 and replaced them last year, said the group's president, Edward Mullins. A spokeswoman for Monitoring and Evaluation Services said the firm had no comment. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Queens Man Pleads Guilty To Killing Filmmaker in '01
description: An independent movie producer from Queens who claimed that he had been distraught after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks pleaded guilty yesterday to manslaughter for killing and dismembering an Afghan-born filmmaker.

title: 2 Drug Bills Advance to Ease Access to Generics and to Add Medicare Benefits
description: A bipartisan group of senators, led by a conservative Republican, said today that they would push legislation to give consumers swifter access to low-cost copies of brand-name prescription drugs.

title: Questions on Choice of Foundation for Drug Program
description: Novartis says that its choice of the Max Foundation to run its ambitious program to give away Glivec was largely a result of the foundation's success establishing a bone marrow registry for leukemia patients.

title: Roving the Globe, Laptops Alight on Wireless Hot Spots
description: INSIDE the Waag, a former customs house and gallows that towers over the Nieuwmarkt here, the price of cappuccino continues to rise. Yet the wireless Internet access in the surrounding square is perfectly free.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Online Schools Drain Funds

title: Wizards Talk to Van Gundy
description: Jeff Van Gundy, the former coach of the Knicks, met yesterday with executives of the Washington Wizards to discuss their vacant head coaching position, according to two Eastern Conference officials. The Knicks, who hold the contractual rights to Van Gundy until July 31, gave the Wizards permission to speak with Van Gundy yesterday morning.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Crash Analysis Issued
description: The Taiwan government's Aviation Safety Council said in a report that it had found metal fatigue near the tail of a Boeing 747-200 that came apart in midair on May 25 last year, killing all 225 people aboard the China Airlines flight. The report provided further details of investigators' previously voiced suspicions about metal fatigue, but it did not say whether the problem caused the crash; a final report on the cause is to be issued next year.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Study Sees Trend In AIDS Virus
description: A percentage of gay men in King County infected with the virus that causes AIDS is on the rise, according to a study by the county, which includes Seattle. Researchers found that among gay men tested, the number who were H.I.V. positive increased 40 percent in 2002 from the previous year, though an increase in the number tested could account for part of the change, said James Apa, a county spokesman. Officials said if the trend continued the number of new infections could rise 60 percent in 2003. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Taking Technology to Extremes
description: IT was 1 a.m. and sunny when Ben Saunders, a young British adventurer, stumbled giddily into the mess tent at Camp Borneo, a way station for thrill seekers, scientists and extreme tourists 60 miles from the North Pole.

title: Sinking Roots in a Rented Space
description: IN the beginning, it was a series of featureless rooms bereft of moldings, free of style and afflicted with bland herringbone parquet floors. On the positive side, however, the one-bedroom apartment that Irwin Weiner found on West End Avenue at 104th Street hit the trifecta of Manhattan housing: It was well proportioned, relatively sunny and, best of all, astonishingly affordable. An inspired makeover was all it needed. And who better to accomplish it than Mr. Weiner, an interior designer who once dared to upholster a staid camelback sofa in artificial mink? (The client loved it.)

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: State Department Official to Lead Council on Foreign Relations
description: Richard N. Haass, director of policy planning at the State Department and a well-known combatant in the foreign policy battles of the Bush administration, is leaving the administration to become president of the Council on Foreign Relations, council officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRUSSEL, , MARC CHARLES
description: TRUSSEL -- Marc Charles, Educator, 53, of Gainesville, FL, died Tuesday, June 3, from a sudden heart attack. Born in Far Rockaway, NY, Marc grew up in Jacksonville, FL, moving back to his hometown, where he attended Lawrence Junior and Senior H.S. Marc graduated with honors from the University of Buffalo with a degree in social work, and continued his education at Buffalo St. College, where he received an MS in Special Ed. After teaching special needs students for 7 years he began a long-term career with Kaplan Educational Centers in 1982. During his 20-plus tenure with Kaplan, Marc dedicated himself to assisting high school and college students to continue and follow their dreams. Marc was a member of the Congregation B'nai Israel. He enjoyed traveling, photography and spending time with his family. He is survived by his loving wife, Susanne; his son Joshua, and his daughter, Ilyssa. Beloved son of Faye and Stanley Trussel of New Port Richey and son-in-law of Minna and the late Lawrence Schein of Cedarhurst, NY/ Gainesville, FL; cherished brother to Jayson and Debbie Trussel of W. Palm Beach and Sandra and Al Jackson of Treasure Island, FL. Services are being held Thursday, June 5th, Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY at 1:30PM. >>AD#

title: Generating Some Tension On the Way to Monte Carlo
description: The United States Bridge Championships being played in Memphis moved into the quarterfinal stage yesterday. The winners will represent the United States in world championship play in Monte Carlo in November, along with the Nick Nickell team, which qualified a year ago in a similar competition.

title: NPS PHARMACEUTICALS CANCELS ENZON BID
description: NPS Pharmaceuticals Inc., which agreed to buy a rival, Enzon Pharmaceuticals Inc., for $770 million in stock, said the companies had called off the takeover after failing to agree on a final price. NPS wanted to renegotiate the terms of the acquisition, the companies said. Enzon will be paid a termination fee of 1.5 million shares of NPS stock, worth about $35.6 million based on yesterday's closing share price. The acquisition, announced in February, would have given NPS a sales force, some cancer treatments and royalties from medicines like Peg-Intron, a liver drug. NPS is based in Salt Lake City, and Enzon is based in Bridgewater, N.J.

title: A Garden of Twisted Trees And Giant Dwarfs
description: WHEN Martin Brooks was 14, he and his father, a doctor who loved to garden, tried to cross an eggplant with a tomato. Mr. Brooks fell in love with trees a few years later, when one of his professors at the Delaware Valley College of Science and Agriculture showed him a picture of a weeping mountain ash. (It was the weeping part that got him.) In 1958, he bought 60 acres here and started the Martin Brooks Rare Plant Nursery, with trees so intriguing that one client, arriving by helicopter, spent $1 million in an afternoon.

title: Verizon to Reveal Customers in Piracy Case
description: In a victory for the record industry, Verizon Communications said yesterday that it would turn over the names of four online subscribers accused of illegally copying music over the Internet to an industry trade group after a federal appeals court rejected its request for a delay pending a final decision in the case.

title: Empty Nesters Helping New Nesters
description: JOSHUA BEATON, a 27-year-old graduate student, was about to sign a lease on a $1,300 one-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn last summer when his father made him an offer he couldn't refuse.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Proper Introductions

title: Women in the Ring
description: To the Editor:

title: Up to 40 Taliban Guerrillas Are Killed in a Major Defeat
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, June 5  Up to 40 Taliban guerrillas and seven Afghan government soldiers have been killed in the Taliban's worst defeat since it was driven from power by an American-led coalition in 2001, officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEIDER, , LIBBY SALESKY
description: SCHNEIDER--Libby Salesky. Passed on June 3, 2003 at age 86. Loving wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother to Jeffrey (deceased), Stanley and Gary. Loving motherin-law to Elyssa and Willa. Cherished sister of Jules (deceased) and Jessie. Adoring Nana to Alexis and Dustin. A simple, unassuming woman devoted to family and friends. Donations to the American Cancer Society. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: COST OF A MINE STRIKE Inco Ltd. , one of the world's biggest nickel producers, said profit would be reduced $20 million for each month that a strike continues at its operations in Ontario. Inco shut its Sudbury-area operations Sunday after 3,200 production and maintenance workers walked out over pensions. The mines produce about 9 percent of the world's nickel supply. Inco, which is based in Toronto, said on Tuesday that it would miss deliveries of nickel, copper and other metals because of the strike. The company and the United Steelworkers of America, which represents the workers, are at odds over improvements in pensions. (Bloomberg News)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Loan For Steel Maker
description: The British steel manufacturer Corus Group said its bankers had agreed to terms of a new loan that will be backed by shares in its Dutch subsidiary. The loan will replace a 1.4 billion euro ($1.6 billion) credit facility that expires in January of 2004. The credit ratings of Corus were cut to below investment grade last year. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: BLAIRSTOWN: STRIKING TEACHERS ORDERED TO RETURN Hours after teachers went on strike yesterday morning in the North Warren Regional School District, a state judge ordered them back to work today. A meeting between the school officials and the teachers' union, the New Jersey Education Association, has been scheduled for tomorrow. Classes were canceled and more than 1,000 students from Blairstown, Frelinghuysen, Knowlton Township and Hardwick were sent home. The union represents 109 teachers, aides, secretaries and custodians who have been working without a contract for a year, said Karen Joseph, a union spokeswoman. The union wants annual raises of 4.3 percent but the district has offered less, she said.    (NYT)

title: Comically Finding Romance In the Days of Don Quixote
description: ''Don Quixote,'' that nuttiest of balletic comedies, returned to American Ballet Theater's repertory with performances on Monday and Tuesday nights at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Ten Most Wanted Is Back, but Mostly Ignored
description: When Ten Most Wanted straggled across the Kentucky Derby finish line in ninth place last month, Wally Dollase was dumbfounded.

title: INSIDE
description: Exaggeration on Iraq Denied

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about possible candidates for New York State attorney general misidentified two men flanking Charlie King, a Manhattan lawyer and possible candidate. They were Aldon James, president of the National Arts Club, at his left, and State Senator Malcolm A. Smith -- not Joseph S. Grabarz Jr. and City Councilman Robert Jackson.

title: A 'Black Cloud' Engulfs Sosa
description: Mike Noble, who today is wearing his lifetime of loyalty to the Chicago Cubs on his jacket and on his cap, shakes his head every few minutes as he remembers the big dark blob inside Sammy Sosa's broken bat.

title: Former Xerox Executives Settle Charges With S.E.C.
description: Six former top officials at the Xerox Corporation agreed today to pay more than $22 million for their roles in the massive accounting fraud at Xerox from 1997 to 2000.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 28 about the Italian composer Luciano Berio misspelled the maiden name of his widow, who was his third wife. She is Talia Pecker Berio, not Packer Berio. (His second wife, who also survives, was Susan Oyama.)

title: Martha Stewart Indicted by U.S. On Obstruction
description: Martha Stewart was indicted yesterday on charges of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and securities fraud, all linked to a personal stock trade she made in 2001.

title: Revisions Urged for Campaign Finance Rules
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board yesterday proposed a way to allow candidates who pay for their own campaigns to participate in its campaign finance program, as long as they abide by the program's spending limits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GONZALEZ, , OLIVE R.
description: GONZALEZ--Olive R. On June 3, 2003 at the age of 86. Widow of Edward W. Gonzalez, beloved and devoted mother of Edward W. Jr., Peter W. and Susan G. Lyons. Grandmother of Donna Brackin, Olivia and Paul Lyons, Peter Gonzalez and great grandchildren Adam and Lindsay Brackin and Liam Endres. She is also predeceased by her granddaughter Brooke Gonzalez. She lived a good life and will be missed deeply. A memorial service will be announced. >>AD#

title: 2 Agencies in a Tie For the Grand Effie
description: For the first time since 1984, there was a tie for the top prize when the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association presented its annual Effie Awards, which recognize effectiveness in advertising.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 16 about a complaint from France saying that it was a victim of a campaign of disinformation fed by Bush administration officials referred incorrectly to an April exchange between Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Charlie Rose of PBS. Mr. Powell replied "yes" when Mr. Rose asked if there would be consequences for France's opposition to the war in Iraq. Mr. Rose did not ask whether France would be punished.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISEMAN, , MARJORIE F.
description: ISEMAN--Marjorie F. The Writers Room wishes to express its deepest sympathy to the friends and family of Marjorie Iseman, a beloved member, trustee and friend of The Writers Room for more than 20 years. >>AD#

title: Product at Center of the Trading Case Shows New Promise
description: Erbitux, the experimental cancer drug developed by ImClone Systems, was shown to shrink tumors at a conference here on Sunday. Today it helped inoculate ImClone from any ill effects of Martha Stewart's indictment.

title: 3 States Sue E.P.A. to Regulate Emissions of Carbon Dioxide
description: Carbon dioxide emissions from cars and power plants should be regulated as an air pollutant because they contribute to global warming, three Northeast states said yesterday in a federal lawsuit against the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Economic Report Sends Dow Above 9,000
description: The three-month rally in stocks gained new strength yesterday, as a positive economic report sent the Dow Jones industrial average above 9,000 for the first time since August.

title: Players Weigh In On Fallout From Cork
description: Six, eight and then 10 Seattle Mariners stopped, stood around a black couch in the visiting clubhouse here and stared at the television as if they were watching O.J. Simpson cruising in a white Ford Bronco again. They were watching a replay of Sammy Sosa's corked bat sail across the field, listening to announcers discuss why Sosa would use an illegal bat and then continuing the discussion among themselves.

title: False Hope in a Bottle
description: Seven months ago, I made the decision to hasten the end of my wife's life. Susan lay in an irreversible coma and had not been fed for 10 days; she was being kept alive solely by fluids. An old family friend stopped by with advice that no one in the medical profession had been able to offer.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cuts At China Maker
description: The maker of crystal and tableware Waterford Wedgwood said it would cut more than 10 percent of its British work force and move production of earthenware out of Britain to cut costs. Manufacturing of Johnson Brothers, a line of moderately priced tableware, is being relocated to Asia. Johnson, founded in 1883, was bought by Wedgwood in 1968. The move will eliminate 1,058 jobs and close two factories in England. Overall profit for the year ended March 31 was up 14 percent, to 64.2 million euros ($75.3 million), but profit in the unit that includes Johnson Brothers was down 69 percent, to 3 million euros. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: INVESTOR GROUP MAKES OFFER FOR ELDER-BEERMAN
description: A group of investors has offered to pay $5.50 a share to acquire the Elder-Beerman Stores Corporation, a department store chain. The offer from EB Acquisition values Elder-Beerman at about $63.7 million, said Erin Caffrey Braun, a spokeswoman for the group. The bid is 7.4 percent higher than Elder-Beerman's closing price on Tuesday of $5.12 a share. Elder-Beerman's board has not responded to a letter sent May 20 regarding the offer, EB Acquisition said. EB Acquisition, led by a developer, Daniel S. Summers, said it would keep Elder-Beerman's headquarters in Dayton, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPANIER, , JEFFREY P.
description: SPANIER--Jeffrey P. 62, died on Sunday, June 1, at his residence in Sag Harbor, NY. An architect and developer born in Great Neck, NY, Jeff is survived by his wife, Paula; siblings, Alan and Megan Jacob Spanier; parents, Irving and Elaine Spanier, and children Adam, Carmen, and Erin Spanier; grandson Jesse Dylan Evers, nieces Sarah and Rebekah Paster, and nephews Evan Paster and Kyle Jacob Spanier. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 81st St. and Madison Ave., on June 5, 7-9 PM; service Friday, June 6, 1:30 PM. >>AD#

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Lap Dancers: Would Proust Have Done That?

title: War Crimes Indictment of Liberian President Is Disclosed
description: President Charles Taylor of Liberia, widely viewed as a wellspring of the violence that has ravaged West Africa, has been indicted on war crimes charges by a special court in Sierra Leone that accused him of ''bearing the greatest responsibility'' for a decade's worth of murders, mutilations and rapes in the neighboring country.

title: Taking Off on a Wing And a Balancing Act
description: Antoine de Saint-Exupry's ''Little Prince'' is a book that children might have written for their parents. Its tiny space traveler, in search of means to protect a beloved rose, evokes not so much a child's world as a child's world remembered. Whimsy is this story's engine: nonsense tempered by wistfulness, nostalgia, self-deprecation and innocence recalled from a distance.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Job Cuts At Akzo
description: Akzo Nobel, the largest chemical maker in the Netherlands, will cut about 200 positions as it tries to increase the efficiency of its surface-chemistry business, which sells additives for detergents, farm products and paints. The unit, which has about 2,200 employees, will cut 120 of its North American workers, most of them in production. About 80 mostly administrative, sales and research jobs will be eliminated in Europe, Akzo said. Akzo, based in Arnhem, is cutting jobs as the additive market becomes more competitive.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Senators Negotiate on Pact To Extend Child Tax Credit
description: Under pressure to provide an increased child tax credit to minimum-wage families, senators from both parties engaged in fierce negotiation today over a proposed agreement that would also satisfy Republican demands to extend the credit to families making $150,000 a year.

title: Planned Job Cuts Declined in May, Survey Says
description: Employers in the United States announced plans in May to cut 68,623 jobs, the smallest number of intended layoffs in 30 months and a sign that the worst round of job losses may be over, a private survey has found.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a woman who was cut in the face by intruders while working in a Brooklyn office misidentified the employer of the victim and the former employer of a witness. It is Nassau Consulting, a social services group that works with recent Polish immigrants. (Michael M. Obregon, a lawyer, has a satellite office that shares space and one employee with that group.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINDLAY, , HARRIET JONES
description: FINDLAY -- Harriet Jones, died peacefully at her home in New Canaan, CT, on May 25th. She was 95 years old and had lived in New Canaan for 62 years. She pursued many interests during her lifetime, including Christian philanthropy, Bible studies, horticulture and gardening, antiques and art collecting, painting, farming, land conservation, historic preservation and photography. She was predeceased by her husband and her daughter, H. Lindsay Findlay. She is survived by two sons, David B. Findlay Jr. of New Canaan and H. Peter Findlay of Salisbury, CT, six grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, June 14th, at 11 am at the Congregational Church of New Canaan. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Mid-Fairfield Hospice, Wilton, CT, or to the New Canaan Garden Club. >>AD#

title: Computing's Lost Allure
description: To the Editor:

title: The 9/11 Memorial (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Debt Sale Deal
description: Henry Paulson, the chairman of the Goldman Sachs Group, agreed to work with China's biggest lender to dispose of as much as $1.2 billion of bad loans, extending the investment bank's lead as the top buyer of Asian distressed debt. Goldman and the state-owned Industrial and Commercial Bank of China will dispose of 8 billion to 10 billion yuan of loans ($968 million to $1.2 billion), Mr. Paulson said at a news conference in Beijing. China's banking regulator, Liu Mingkang, told the country's four biggest lenders last week to act quickly to reduce about $220 billion of bad loans.

title: Bush and Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Poll shows U.S. isolation : In war's wake, hostility and mistrust
description: PARIS:  The war in Iraq has widened the rift between the United States and the rest of the world, with a steep plunge in Americans' views of their traditional allies and a further surge of anti-Americanism in Muslim countries, a global opinion survey shows.

title: A Fugitive Croatia General Is a Hometown Favorite
description: A visitor disembarking before the high stone walls of this ancient Adriatic port quickly sees a 10-foot poster by the quay-side city gate. It shows a young man in a black-collared shirt with an intense gaze and rather prominent ears. ''A Hero, and Not a Criminal'' proclaims the poster.

title: George Trescher, Fund-Raiser (and Fun-Raiser), Dies at 77
description: George Trescher, a formidable fund-raiser who for more than three decades organized money-raising parties and other pleasant events for some of New York's top charities and companies, died today at Beth Israel North Hospital in Manhattan. He was 77 and lived in the Murray Hill neighborhood of Manhattan.

title: 94% of School Budgets Pass, Most of Them More Expensive
description: Undeterred by the prospect of higher taxes, New York State voters overwhelmingly approved increases in school spending, according to election results released yesterday.

title: A Watchdog That Doesn't Bark (And Won't Chew Your Shoes)
description: Until now Aibo, a robotic dog made by Sony, had tried to simulate only the companionship that pet ownership offers. Now a new software package opens the possibility of giving Aibo another canine skill, turning it into a kind of electronic watchdog.

title: DaimlerChrysler Stock Declines After Company Forecasts a Loss
description: Shares of DaimlerChrysler declined yesterday after the company said that its Chrysler unit would lose about $1.17 billion this quarter because discounts reduced revenue.

title: Iraq's Weapons: A Vital Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Citywide Sales Tax Increase Takes Effect
description: One minute after midnight yesterday, it got more expensive to shop in New York City as an increase in the city sales tax took effect.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: EMI Sues Bertelsmann On Napster Investment
description: EMI Recorded Music, the fifth-largest music company in the nation, sued Bertelsmann yesterday over its investment in Napster, the Internet file-sharing network, charging that it contributed to widespread copyright infringement by backing the service. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, is the second to be filed in a month by a major recorded music company against Bertelsmann. Last month, Universal Music Group, the world's largest record company, filed suit, making many of the same claims. The suits highlight the music industry's frustration with Bertelsmann over its investment in Napster in October 2000, which helped propel Internet piracy, the suits say. Lynette Holloway (NYT)

title: On the Reservation, the Web Plays Dream Maker
description: ISOLATED on the coast of northwest Washington, the Makah Indians are accustomed to making do with little. In the winter, when the fishing industry slows down, more than half the 1,200 residents of the 47-square-mile reservation are unemployed. There is no traffic light in the reservation's town, Neah Bay. It takes nearly two hours driving along a narrow, winding road to reach the nearest city, Port Angeles.

title: Drug Use in Nightclubs
description: To the Editor:

title: To Rockaway by Water, Without Owning a Boat
description: Manhattanites seeking to hit the beaches this summer will soon have a new option: a 45-minute boat ride to the Rockaways.

title: A Danger to the West, and a Danger From It
description: ''Frontline/World'' on PBS takes a look at global change on the local level. Sometimes a first-world force is arriving in a remote place, and at others something worrisome is heading our way. Tonight one segment explains how a new scourge, television, is disturbing the peace in the Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan, and another examines how violence between Muslims and Christians in Philippine villages might mean bloodshed on a larger scale.

title: A Casual Evening Stroll With a Sultry Singer
description: ''Another Evening'' delivered just what that low-keyed title promised on Friday night at Aaron Davis Hall at City College. Bill T. Jones and his dancers spent some time onstage with Cassandra Wilson, the sultry-voiced jazz singer; Curtis Lundy, the jazz bassist; and Dr. Daniel Bernard Roumain, the composer and music director of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company. Simple, repeated lines of text, spoken by Mr. Jones and occasionally by Ms. Wilson, helped to link the elements and created an atmosphere of plain-spoken surrealism.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Economic Growth
description: Australian economic growth accelerated in the first quarter as consumers spent more on cars, clothes and alcohol. Gross domestic product rose 0.7 percent after growing a revised 0.3 percent in the previous three months, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said. Treasurer Peter Costello said growth was likely to slow in the second quarter because the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome and weak global growth would crimp exports.

title: Ashcroft Defends Detentions as Immigrants Recount Toll
description: Two very different views of the Justice Department's campaign against terrorism came into stark focus today, as Attorney General John Ashcroft was sharply criticized following a report that the authorities mistreated illegal immigrants arrested after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: FOUR DIRECTORS AT ADELPHIA COMMUNICATIONS TO RESIGN
description: The Adelphia Communications Corporation, the troubled cable operator, said yesterday that four directors who served on the board when the Rigas family still controlled the company would step down. Leslie J. Gelber, Pete J. Metros, Dennis P. Coyle and Erland E. Kailbourne, who was chairman and interim chief executive, will resign. The directors said in a statement that they were leaving as the company moved to form a new independent board. Four independent directors and the new chief executive, William T. Schleyer, now sit on the board, and the company said it had hired an executive search firm to find other candidates. Adelphia, which ousted its founder and members of his family from executive positions, is trying to recover from an accounting scandal that led it to file for bankruptcy protection a year ago. The company, which was based in Coudersport, Pa., is now located in Greenwood Village, Colo.

title: Albany Looks Again at Lobbyist Disclosure Rules
description: As Assembly Democrats continued to raise questions about influence-peddling at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, leaders in both houses expressed optimism today that the Legislature would pass a bill this year to require people who lobby state agencies and authorities to disclose their clients, earnings and expenses.

title: A House Restored, An Author Revisited; Thomas Wolfe Shrine Returns
description: Flames gorged on Julia Wolfe's prim dining room in the family boarding house that her son Thomas lampooned as the forlorn Dixieland in ''Look Homeward, Angel.'' They devoured the massive Eastlake mantelpiece and Mission chairs and tables, melted the brass clocks and silver, and destroyed 200 of the house's 800 artifacts, while damaging many others throughout the 29 rooms.

title: Microsoft Leader Tells Workers of I.B.M.-Linux Threat
description: In a long e-mail message to Microsoft employees yesterday, Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive, singled out International Business Machines as the company's chief corporate rival and the rise of free software like Linux as a threat to Microsoft's lucrative portfolio of products.

title: The Poor Held Hostage for Tax Cuts
description: Millions of low-income families were cruelly denied child credits in the administration's latest detaxation victory. Now, with consummate arrogance, Republican leaders in Congress are threatening another irresponsible tax-cut bidding war as the price for repairing the damage. ''There are a lot of other things that are more important than that,'' said Tom DeLay, the House Republican majority leader, signaling that revisiting the child-care issue will open the door to even worse deficit-feeding tax-cut plans. Mr. DeLay at least offered unabashed candor instead of the crocodile tears of other Republicans. They are now embarrassed over the furor that low-income families were deleted in the final G.O.P. deal on the tax-cut boon weighted so shamelessly last month to favor the wealthiest Americans.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: NEW RULES ON MEAT CONTAMINATION The Agriculture Department announced rules that officials said would help prevent ready-to-eat meats from becoming contaminated by Listeria monocytogenes bacteria in the plants where they are produced. Last year listeria-infested meat killed seven people and led to the recall of 27.4 million pounds of meat by Pilgrim's Pride of Pittsburgh, Pa. Consumer advocates said the new rules did not include automatic testing if listeria was found in a plant. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOODMAN, , HOWARD
description: GOODMAN--Howard. A decade, but unforgettable like your yacht, the ''Q.M. II''. Mara's other home, England, launching new ''Q.M. II''. Miss buddy Ben Joelson, TV ''Loveboat'' creator. Love, Roni, Mara and Justin, Twin brother, Sy and family, Sister, Joan and Kulick famil

title: McDonald's Prepares To Shift Strategies
description: The McDonald's Corporation is expected to disclose a new approach soon for its advertising after an extensive ''beauty contest'' among its major agencies.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Game 1 Analysis; There's No Need to See Any More From Nets
description: Once in a while, a special team comes along, a remarkable bunch of overachievers able to win hearts, buck the morning line, capture a nation's imagination and win an improbable championship over a prohibitive favorite.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Immigration Bill Advances
description: The House approved a measure that would speed the pace of naturalization for noncitizens in the military. The bill, which passed 414 to 5, would allow immigrant soldiers to apply for citizenship after serving one year. The current waiting period is three years. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: WHITE PLAINS: LUXURY CARS STOLEN FROM DRIVEWAYS Members of a car-theft ring brazenly stole $1 million worth of luxury cars like Audis, BMW's and Mercedes-Benzes from garages and driveways in affluent communities, the Westchester district attorney's office said yesterday. Four men were arrested on Tuesday and charged with first-degree unauthorized use of a motor vehicle and third-degree grand larceny. Authorities said the ringleader was Robert Lue of Mount Vernon. Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester district attorney, said the ring was believed to be responsible for most of the luxury cars stolen in Rye, Scarsdale and Larchmont in recent months.    Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

title: U.S. Investor Drops Bid For TV Unit Of Kirch
description: Three months after striking a landmark deal that would have put Germany's largest television broadcaster into foreign hands, a Hollywood investor, Haim Saban, abandoned his bid today after failing to come to terms with creditors of the broadcaster's bankrupt parent, KirchMedia.

title: Mideast Leaders Look Homeward
description: AQABA, Jordan, June 4  Locked in conflict, fearing for their very existence as nations, Israelis and Palestinians have for generations prized national unity, deferring or papering over internal disputes about the means and ends of their struggles.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Unusually Close Assembly Race
description: A day after the Democratic primary for a seat in the General Assembly, Assemblyman Joseph V. Doria Jr., left, a fixture in the Legislature for 24 years, was still waiting to learn whether he had been denied the nomination. Mr. Doria was trailing by fewer than 100 votes. According to state election figures, Anthony Chiappone led all candidates for the seat, in Hudson County, with 10,065 votes. Mr. Doria had 9,978, Louis Manzo received 9,967 and Elba Perez-Cinciarelli had 9,139. The top two candidates receive the party nomination, but several election districts had not yet tallied their votes as of yesterday afternoon, and state officials said the results might not be certified until tomorrow. David Kocieniewski (NYT)

title: U.S. Agrees to Redeploy Troops Far From North Korea Border
description: TOKYO, June 5  After weeks of tense discussions, the United States and South Korea agreed today to redeploy American troops far away from the demilitarized zone that separates North and South Korea, where they are highly vulnerable to attack from the North.

title: Many Say Europe Needs More Than Just a Rate Cut
description: With Europe's biggest countries stagnating and its currency soaring, the European Central Bank has been thrust into a new, not entirely comfortable role: economic savior for the Continent.

title: Mickie Most, Record Producer And Pop Impresario, Dies at 64
description: Mickie Most, a leading British pop record producer of the 1960's and 70's who recorded the Animals, Donovan, Herman's Hermits and others, died on Friday at his home in London. He was 64.

title: McDonald's Prepares to Shift Strategies
description: The McDonald's Corporation is expected to disclose a new approach soon for its advertising after an extensive "beauty contest" among its major agencies.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 17 on Bus Near Chechnya
description: MOSCOW, June 5  A woman blew up a bus carrying airmen and military personnel early today as it paused at a railroad crossing west of Russia's separatist Chechnya province, killing herself and at least 17 others and wounding perhaps 16 more.

title: Thriving Kurdish Trade in Fake Passports Slumps as Fewer Choose to Flee the Region
description: It is unusually quiet in this corner of this sprawling marketplace, where a line of shop windows advertise compact discs. The shelves are empty, for the most part. As everyone here knows, this is the site of the passport market or, more accurately, the former passport market.

title: F.S.U. Quarterback Gambled, Friend Says
description: A childhood friend of the former Florida State quarterback Adrian McPherson told a Leon County jury in Tallahassee, Fla., yesterday that just as McPherson was preparing to play Notre Dame last season, he called to ask him to place a $1,000 bet on Miami against West Virginia.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Blairstown: Striking Teachers Ordered To Return
description: Hours after teachers went on strike yesterday morning in the North Warren Regional School District, a state judge ordered them back to work today. A meeting between the school officials and the teachers' union, the New Jersey Education Association, has been scheduled for tomorrow. Classes were canceled and more than 1,000 students from Blairstown, Frelinghuysen, Knowlton Township and Hardwick were sent home. The union represents 109 teachers, aides, secretaries and custodians who have been working without a contract for a year, said Karen Joseph, a union spokeswoman. The union wants annual raises of 4.3 percent but the district has offered less, she said.

title: Honors
description: * Carla Michelotti, executive vice president and general counsel at Leo Burnett Worldwide, Chicago, was named chairwoman of the American Advertising Federation, Washington, for 2003-4. Ms. Michelotti, who was vice chairwoman for 2002-3, succeeds Mark Dacey, senior client partner for media and entertainment at Korn/Ferry International, New York. Jack Griffin, president and publisher at Parade, New York, was named vice chairman for 2003-4. Burnett is part of the Publicis Groupe. Parade is owned by Advance Publications.

title: Voting by Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: On Dark and Stormy Nights, A Keyboard Lights the Way
description: The EluminX keyboard from Auravision glows in the dark, thanks to an electroluminescent panel that provides soft backlighting for its clear plastic keys.

title: The Research; Startled by His Visual Prowess, a Gamer Set His Study in Motion
description: ALTHOUGH Daphne Bavelier and Shawn Green, researchers at the University of Rochester, were gratified to see their article appear in the journal Nature last week, they never expected to see it cause such a stir.

title: Iraq's Weapons: A Vital Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian SARS figures put in perspective
description: MANILA:  For all the death, misery and fear caused by SARS, this century's first new disease looks relatively minor when compared with other scourges in Asia.

title: Ashcroft Goes to Capitol Hill to Defend Antiterror Policy
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  Attorney General John Ashcroft vigorously defended his Justice Department today against charges that it had mistreated illegal aliens in the hunt for potential terrorists.

title: The 9/11 Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Father of the iMac Wins Designer of the Year Prize
description: The British public helped elect Jonathan Ive, above, as the Design Museum of London's first designer of the year. Mr. Ive, the vice president of industrial design at Apple Computers and the father of the iMac, left, was awarded $40,000. Alice Rawsthorn, director of the museum, helped select the nominees, all born or based in Britain. The others were the jewelry designer Solange Azagury-Partridge; the designer Tord Boontje; and Rockstar Games, which designed the Grand Theft Auto video game. ''It was complicated to know what criteria to use,'' said the fashion designer Paul Smith, who was on the jury, along with the Australian designer Marc Newson; Paola Antonelli, a curator at the Museum of Modern Art; and Emily King, a design historian. A show on the finalists is at the Design Museum through June 29; www.designmuseum.org. CHEE PEARLMAN

title: The Media Goliath Just Got Bigger
description: To the Editor:

title: Middle East Mediator: Big New Test for Bush
description: Two events forced George Bush's decision to sit under a tree this afternoon, finally acting as the essential mediator between the fierce hawk who leads Israel and the new, untested and struggling prime minister of the Palestinian Authority.

title: Executive Editor of The Times and Top Deputy Step Down
description: Howell Raines and Gerald M. Boyd, the top-ranking editors of The New York Times , resigned yesterday morning, five weeks after the resignation of a reporter set off a chain of events that exposed fissures in the management and morale of the newsroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHART, , HENRY C.
description: COHART--Henry C. The Board of Directors and staff of North Shore Child and Family Guidance Center mourn the passing of Henry Cohart, devoted husband of Board member Beatrice. We offer our sincere condolences to the entire Cohart family. Rochelle Lipton, President Marion Levine, Executive Director/CEO >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Thursday about a revision in the new tax law that will prevent millions of minimum-wage families from receiving a $400 child credit misstated the tax situation of families earning less then $10,500. While they are exempt from federal income tax, many do pay Social Security and Medicare taxes.

title: Deal Reunites Early Makers Of Hand-Helds
description: Reuniting the pioneers who created the first successful hand-held computing device with the company they left in anger, Palm Inc. agreed today to acquire Handspring, which Palm's founders started as a rival five years ago.

title: Bush Rallies Troops on Way Home From Mideast
description: DOHA, Qatar, June 5  President Bush ended a seven-day, six-nation trip this morning that took him from the concentration camp sites of Poland to the czars' palaces of St. Petersburg to a global economic conference in the French Alps to Middle East peacemaking on the edge of the Red Sea. For a president who doesn't love to travel, the trip was Clintonian  two countries nearly every day and a new bed to sleep in most nights.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KLM Traffic Declines
description: May passenger traffic fell 10 percent at KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, as the spread of severe acute respiratory syndrome and slowing economies discouraged people from flying, the airline said. The proportion of seats filled fell 3.5 percentage points, to 73.7 percent, from May of last year as the Amsterdam-based KLM cut seating capacity 5 percent, it said. The decline followed a 7 percent drop in April traffic. Cargo traffic rose 8 percent.

title: 122 Years Later, Lawmen Are Still Chasing Billy the Kid
description: For more than 120 years, Pat Garrett has enjoyed legendary status in the American West, a lawman on a par with Wyatt Earp, Bat Masterson, even Matt Dillon. As sheriff here in Lincoln County in 1881, Garrett is credited with shooting to death the notorious outlaw known as Billy the Kid, a killing that made Garrett a hero. For years, a patch bearing his likeness has adorned uniforms worn by sheriff's deputies here.

title: Technology Briefing | People: Yahoo Names New Marketing Chief
description: Yahoo said yesterday that it had named Cammie Dunaway of the Frito-Lay Company as chief marketing officer. The previous marketing chief, John H. Costello, accepted a job at Home Depot Inc. Ms. Dunaway, 40, helped manage the Doritos, Cheetos, Lays and Ruffles brands of snacks at Frito-Lay, a unit of PepsiCo, for the last 13 years, Yahoo said in a statement. She will join the company later this month. Ms. Dunaway is taking over marketing as Yahoo is trying to get more Internet surfers to use its search engine and generate more revenue from fee-based offerings, including its online dating service. The company started a national advertising campaign for its search engine last month, after redesigning the service in April. Mr. Costello, Yahoo's previous chief marketing officer, left in October 2002 to become chief marketing officer of Home Depot. Yahoo shares rose $1.04, or 3.6 percent, to $29.59.

The offer price is 34 percent above Odd Job's closing price on Tuesday. A year ago, Odd Job changed its name from Mazel Stores Inc., adopting the name of the 75 closeout retail stores it operates. title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CUTS AT CHINA MAKER The maker of crystal and tableware Waterford Wedgwood said it would cut more than 10 percent of its British work force and move production of earthenware out of Britain to cut costs. Manufacturing of Johnson Brothers, a line of moderately priced tableware, is being relocated to Asia. Johnson, founded in 1883, was bought by Wedgwood in 1968. The move will eliminate 1,058 jobs and close two factories in England. Overall profit for the year ended March 31 was up 14 percent, to 64.2 million euros ($75.3 million), but profit in the unit that includes Johnson Brothers was down 69 percent, to 3 million euros. description: The Fleming Companies, a grocery distributor, won permission in bankruptcy court to sell its 31 Rainbow Foods stores and 9 remaining Richmar Foods stores for a combined price of $138.5 million. Roundy's Inc. will buy the Rainbow Foods stores for $86.5 million and will assume about $35 million for leases. Save Mart will pay $41 million, including $14 million in assumed liabilities, for six Richmar locations. A Kroger Company unit will buy the remaining three for $11 million. Judge Mary F. Walrath of United States Bankruptcy Court approved the sales at a hearing yesterday in Wilmington, Del. Fleming, which is based in Lewisville, Tex., sought protection from creditors in April after losing a contract with its largest customer, Kmart.

title: Confronting Mideast Spoilers
description: One of the most distressing elements of the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians has been the self-centered way in which each side has viewed the dispute. The Israelis have insisted on their need for security without acknowledging the damage their West Bank settlement program has done, while the Palestinians have focused on lost land and personal suffering as they dismiss the ruinous impact of their terrorist attacks. Neither side has even seemed to try to grasp how the other feels.

Today such is not the case. Naturally, teachers would like more respect. The United Federation of Teachers in New York City and other teachers' unions are making a push to have their members seen not as a labor group but as ''professionals.'' Yet they seem not have thought out why the position of teacher has diminished in stature so drastically.

The mistake will reduce earnings by the equivalent of 11 Canadian cents a share. TransAlta's shares fell 77 Canadian cents, to 17.98 Canadian dollars ($13.16) a share, on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
