title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SERBIA: WAR-CRIMES SUSPECT TO STAND TRIAL A former head of Serbia's state security apparatus will be sent to the United Nations war-crimes tribunal at The Hague within days to face charges of forcing Muslims and Croats from their homes, officials said. The tribunal indicted the suspect, Jovica Stanisic, and his associate, Franko Simatovic, on May 1, charging them with taking part in a "joint criminal enterprise" aimed at driving out non-Serbs from parts of Croatia and Bosnia in the 1991-95 wars. Mr. Simatovic, transferred to The Hague last week, pleaded not guilty Monday to all charges. Serbia has been stepping up its cooperation with the tribunal to win international aid and support.

title: Leadership at The Times
description: If anyone ever needed to measure the dedication of The New York Times's employees to this newspaper, the level of anguish generated by the Jayson Blair incident is a pretty good standard. The discovery that one young reporter had faked or plagiarized a large number of articles drew extensive news coverage, but the publicity outside the paper paled next to the anger and soul-searching within. This week, Howell Raines, the executive editor, and Gerald Boyd, the managing editor, decided that the backwash from the Blair affair was keeping them from providing the effective leadership The Times needs. Yesterday, they resigned.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: VOTE ON CLASS SIZE IS URGED A coalition of groups has joined the New York City teachers' union in calling for a ballot initiative that would require the Education Department to decrease class size throughout the school system. Under the initiative, voters would decide whether to amend the City Charter to require limited class size. Many city classrooms have more than 30 students. Besides the union, the United Federation of Teachers, the coalition includes the Community Service Society, the advocacy group Acorn, the Alliance for Quality Education, the United Parents Association and other groups. The coalition would have to collect at least 45,000 voters' signatures to put the question on the ballot. A spokesman for Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday, "By moving ahead with our Children First reforms we are continuing to reduce class size in our city schools." Voters approved a similar referendum in Florida last year, but legislators have not determined how to pay for reducing class size. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: MGM Mirage Will Close Online Gambling Unit
description: MGM Mirage said this week that it would close its online casino division at the end of the month because of an ''unclear'' legal and political climate with regard to online gambling. The company said it would record a loss of about $5 million in the second quarter for discontinuing operations. ''We set out to prove that online casino gaming could be implemented with the same high standards of regulatory integrity as land-based operations,'' said Terry Lanni, the chief executive of MGM Mirage. ''We were successful in demonstrating a working model.'' The casino operator, based in Las Vegas, said it would re-establish the unit if online gambling were legalized in the United States. A House committee passed a bill last month to curb online gambling, and a nearly identical bill has been introduced in the Senate.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Posts Net Loss
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that it had its second consecutive quarterly loss as sales increased at the slowest pace in more than a year. The net loss was $4.4 million, or 2 cents a share, in the fourth quarter ended May 25, compared with net income of $17.1 million, or 9 cents, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 1.4 percent, to $425.3 million, according to the company, which makes chips to lengthen battery life and enhance sound in mobile phones. The outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome in Asia stalled a recovery in demand for electronics, the chief executive, Brian Halla, said in an interview. Sales will accelerate as the number of new SARS cases declines over the next several months, he said. National Semiconductor shares fell 37 cents, to $24.31.

title: New I.B.M. Supercomputer To Begin Its Weather Work
description: The nation's most powerful supercomputer for weather forecasting is scheduled to go online today, I.B.M. said yesterday, a machine that may eventually rival the Japanese Earth Simulator as the world's fastest supercomputer.

title: Chicagoans Step Lively
description: To the Editor:

title: Hevesi Says M.T.A. Funds Can Support Fare Rollback
description: In a new analysis of the finances of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi has concluded that the agency could afford a partial rollback of transit fares, to $1.75, through the end of this year and could keep open dozens of token booths scheduled to be closed.

title: The Compelling Logic of the Used-Car Faithful
description: EVERYONE knows the person who will buy only a new car, whether for the assurance that it wasn't abused or scratched by another human being or for that new-car smell. But a growing group of buyers insists that brand-new cars are a foolish waste of money. They have caught on to something: overall, used cars are better than they used to be.

title: Unions Back Research Plan For Energy
description: Ten labor unions, including the steelworkers and auto workers, urged presidential candidates yesterday to back a 10-year, $300 billion research plan that would promote energy efficiency, reduce dependence on foreign oil and preserve manufacturing jobs.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Monsoon Rally
description: The Bombay Stock Exchange index of 30 stocks rose 45.71 points, or 1.4 percent, as the annual monsoon season arrived, easing concerns about a heat wave in the largely agricultural country. Hindustan Lever, the Indian subsidiary of Unilever and the country's largest consumer goods company, rose 2 percent. Parts of India, mainly in the south, have been reeling under a heat wave that has been blamed for 1,000 deaths. India's economy slowed last year because of a lack of rainfall, and analysts expect consumer spending will recover as more normal weather leads to a recovery in the rural economy. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Chinese Shipwrecks Yield Treasures and a Dispute
description: Emory Kristof could not believe his eyes. Crammed into a nondescript house in suburban Los Angeles were 10,000 pieces of Chinese porcelain and pottery, some 2,000 years old, so densely packed that any movement threatened to send them crashing to the floor. Some were encrusted with coral, evidence of their hidden life for centuries under the sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SULLIVAN, , ROSEMARIE ASTONE
description: SULLIVAN--Rosemarie Astone died at her home in Atlanta, Georgia on Tuesday, May 27, 2003. Rosie was a devoted mother, grandmother, and educator who treasured her family and her wonderful friends. She lived by The Golden Rule and loved and respected all people regardless of their background or station in life. Rosie will be remembered for her kindness and generosity. A graduate of Hunter College in New York, Rosie served in the Atlanta Public Schools for over 25 years. Interment following funeral services in Atlanta, GA. will be Pinelawn Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Memorials may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 225 N. Michigan Avenue, Suite 1700, Chicago, Il. 60601-7633. For information H.M. Patterson & Son, Spring Hill 404-876-1022 >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Kelly Says Arrest Appears Proper
description: The police officers who used pepper spray on a man who later went into cardiac arrest and died appear to have followed proper procedures, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, left, said yesterday. The medical examiner's office said there appeared to be no physical injuries leading to the man's death, Mr. Kelly said. But an official cause of death has not yet been released, and there were conflicting accounts as to how dangerous the man was. On Wednesday in Washington Heights, a woman described as the man's girlfriend called 911 and said the man, Jose A. Mateo, was behaving violently and having a bad drug reaction. Mr. Mateo was attacking his father when the officers arrived, the police said. But Mr. Mateo's father, also named Jose Mateo, said yesterday that he was unaware his son had taken drugs, and he denied that his son had attacked him. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Steakhouses in New York come in every shape and size. Fairway, the supermarket, has come up with something new, a steakhouse grafted onto a grocery store, with a direct line of supply from the butcher counter downstairs to the Fairway Cafe upstairs. The cafe, which continues to serve breakfast and lunch, has extended its hours, putting out the white tablecloths at 6 p.m. and serving all-American steakhouse fare until 9:30.

title: Times's 2 Top Editors Resign After Furor on Writer's Fraud
description: Howell Raines and Gerald M. Boyd, the top-ranking editors of The New York Times, resigned yesterday morning, five weeks after the resignation of a reporter set off a chain of events that exposed fissures in the management and morale of the newsroom.

title: Miscellany
description: * Reebok International, Canton, Mass., signed a marketing agreement with the rapper 50 Cent to create a line of athletic shoes, called the G-Unit Collection by Rbk, which 50 Cent will promote. He is the second entertainer after the rapper Jay-Z to market a signature line of Reebok footwear, which had been limited to athletes. Reebok and Foot Locker will sponsor a summer concert tour with Jay-Z, 50 Cent, Missy Elliott and other performers.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: 3 COMPANIES PLAN PACKAGE OF CALLING MINUTES SBC Communications , BellSouth and their mobile telephone joint venture, Cingular Wireless, plan to sell a package of calling minutes that for the first time could be used for both mobile and home phone calls. SBC and BellSouth, both leading providers of local phone service, are seeking to win back business from wireless carriers, including Cingular. SBC and BellSouth lost a combined 497,000 local lines in the first quarter as some customers started using cellphones, exclusively, to save money. The plan, called MinuteShare, is being tested in Texas and will be available later this year, SBC and BellSouth said yesterday. The alliance underlines phone companies' desire to attract customers in a shrinking market by linking products. Wireless companies like Cingular sell calling packages that include 900 minutes for as little as $39.99 a month. Under MinuteShare, a Cingular customer paying a fixed monthly fee for a certain number of minutes could use those minutes to make long-distance calls over the SBC or BellSouth networks, an SBC spokesman, Michael Coe, said. He declined to say how much the new call package would cost. SBC shares rose 35 cents, to $26.53. BellSouth shares fell 14 cents, to $26.89.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Split Decision: Two Minds About a Second Home
description: HE likes to go away to the country and play carpenter. She likes to stay in the city and check out nightclubs. He finds the open air invigorating. She finds it suffocating. So when the weekend rolls around, Thierry Noyelle and Sonya Heller look forward to their Victorian farmhouse in the Catskills as a retreat -- from each other.

title: Dance's Musical Heartbeat
description: George Balanchine wanted to create ballets, he once said, in which you could see the music and hear the dance. And he came close. ''Music was more important to him than dance,'' said Hugo Fiorato, the veteran principal conductor of the New York City Ballet. ''Who would think of making a really great ballet to Strauss waltzes? Or Sousa marches, for God's sake? But he did. The man had such an imagination. He was a pretty accomplished pianist and loved music above all.''

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: An Effort To Save Water
description: With the Western drought putting pressure on states to find adequate supplies of water, Gov. Bill Owens signed a series of bills to keep more of Colorado's water in Colorado. The core of the package is a ballot initiative asking voters to approve $2 billion in bonds for water projects, including some that would repair and renovate state reservoirs to bank more water from the Colorado River, a prime source of water for seven Western states. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is good news today, but we are not yet there. Now that we know SARS can be contained the goal is to eliminate it as a public health threat.''

title: When the Boss Becomes an Icon
description: Perhaps the heaviest burden Martha Stewart must bear after her indictment on federal charges of securities fraud and obstruction of justice is the weight of her sullied corporate image. She is of course not only the founder, largest stockholder and (until Wednesday) chief executive of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, she is its public face and primary, perhaps only, resource. The company's stock has dropped in value by two-thirds since she became implicated last year in the insider stock trading scandal for which she is now charged. Without her there is no company, or at least no company that anyone could identify. While she is hardly the first magnate to have an eponymous company, there may be only one previous business chief whose personal image has been so inextricably bound up with an enterprise: Walt Disney.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Forsaking Health to Join the H.I.V. Club
description: Far and away the most important selection in NewFest 2003: The New York Lesbian and Gay Film Festival, celebrating its 15th anniversary, is Louise Hogarth's alarming documentary, ''The Gift.'' This film, to be screened at the New York University Cantor Film Center tomorrow evening, examines the increasing ineffectiveness of safer-sex education in urban gay culture and the resulting rise in H.I.V.-infection rates among younger men.

title: Leading Iraqi Shiite Cleric Emerges to Meet U.S. Ally
description: Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sestani, one of the most senior Shiite clerics in Iraq and the world, stepped into the political fray for the first time since the war today, meeting with a Kurdish leader who has enjoyed close ties to Washington and calling for elections to a national assembly for Iraqis to produce a new constitution.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: European Central Bank Cuts Rates by Half a Point

title: George Trescher, 77, Master of Fund-Raising
description: George Trescher, a formidable fund-raiser who for more than three decades organized glittering celebrations and other special events for some of New York's top charities and companies, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital North in Manhattan. He was 77 and lived in the Murray Hill neighborhood of Manhattan.

title: Tom Ridge Agrees Terror Alerts Need Honing
description: Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge acknowledged today that the government's much-criticized color-coded terrorism alert system needed adjustment and said his department would try to create a system that allowed for the level of alert to be raised for specific regions or industries, rather than for the whole country.

title: Han Seems Unfazed by the Layout or the Field
description: In 1998, a young South Korea golfer captured her first career victory at the L.P.G.A. Championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEWART, , ELIZABETH JEAN
description: STEWART--Elizabeth Jean. 88, died May 28 in Anaheim, CA. Jean was Reverend Emeritus of Christ Church Unity in Anaheim, which she founded in 1962. Among many beloved survivors: nephews, Richard Decius of Napa, CA, Steven Stewart of Baltimore, MD, Robert Boyd of Hilton Head, SC and a niece, Nancy Rearick of South Glastonbury, CT. Services June 10 at 11 a.m. at Christ Church Unity, Anaheim. >>AD#

title: Discovering The Rarities Of the 1900's
description: New York's spring auctions of 20th-century decorative arts, which start today at Sotheby's and continue through next Friday, feature a mishmash of works by the obscure and the famous, including Arne Jacobsen, Charles and Ray Eames, George Nelson, Frank Gehry and George Nakashima.

title: Another Attack in Central Iraq Kills Another U.S. Soldier
description: Khalil Muhammad said he heard the explosion just after midnight. Within seconds, the sound of American rifle fire confirmed his fears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PFIFFERLING, , NANCY
description: PFIFFERLING -- Nancy. Of Brooklyn, age 56, passed away June 1, 2003 of lung cancer. Survived by beloved husband Joe, producer ''ABC News 20/20'', and brother Neil Lehane. Celebratory Mass June 14th, 2003, 9:30 am Fontbonne Hall Academy, Bay Ridge where she taught languages for over 30 years. Contributions in her memory to Joan's Legacy, 27 Union Square West, Suite 205, New York 10003. >>AD#

title: A Girl Born To Lead, Fighting The Odds
description: The stoic mysticism of Niki Caro's cool-handed charmer ''Whale Rider'' -- in which the young Pai must overcome resistance as she tries to assume her destiny as the leader of a tribe on the New Zealand coast -- is wickedly absorbing. Much of the film's power comes from the delicate charisma of Keisha Castle-Hughes, making her acting debut as Pai.

title: Corrections
description: The New Economy column in Business Day on May 19, about the wiki, a technology for online interaction, omitted an author of ''The Wiki Way,'' a manifesto and how-to manual. Ward Cunningham's co-author was Bo Leuf.

title: Vatican Traveler in Croatia, Reaching 100, Trips, That Is
description: As Pope John Paul II touched down today for a five-day tour through this predominantly Roman Catholic country, all the usual props were in place.

title: Harvard Chief, at Commencement, Vows Change
description: Speaking on Harvard's 352nd commencement day, Lawrence H. Summers, the university's president, pledged today to reshape the undergraduate experience, including the core curriculum.

title: Article 2003060692274242025 -- No Title
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, June 6 - On the second day of presentations by the three networks competing to buy the media rights to the 2010 Winter and 2012 Games, NBC Sports bore gifts.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: TELECOM STAKE SOLD The British telecommunications company Cable and Wireless sold its stake in the Hong Kong phone company PCCW as part of a strategy to exit unprofitable markets. Cable and Wireless sold the stake, 652 million shares that represent about 14 percent of the company, for about $400 million. The company held the shares on its books at 235 million ($390 million) as of March 31. On Wednesday, Cable and Wireless said it would exit the United States, and concentrate on business in Britain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLAMM, , MAE
description: FLAMM--Mae. Born May 1, 1923, died June 5, 2003. Widow of the late George. Loving mother of Michael and Bruce. Dear mother-in-law of Judy and Kathy. Devoted grandmother of Matthew, Evan, Andrew and Rachel. Beloved aunt of Phyllis Genkin and Beverly Rauch. Graveside service Sunday, June 8, 10AM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. >>AD#

title: READER'S DIGEST NAMES EXECUTIVE TO OVERSEE PUBLISHING
description: The Reader's Digest Association, publisher of the magazine, yesterday named Laura McEwen vice president and publishing director, a new position. Ms. McEwen, 43, was previously publisher of Bertelsmann's YM magazine. She will oversee the publishing and advertising of Reader's Digest, a magazine with a monthly circulation of 12 million, and the company's other publications, a spokesman, William Adler, said. The Reader's Digest Association, based in Pleasantville, N.Y., spent the last two years investing in its main magazine's content and circulation, and now the company wants to increase advertising, Eric W. Schrier, the association's president for North America, said. Ms. McEwen will start at Reader's Digest on June 23, Mr. Adler said.

title: 'Far and Near' -- 'Le Corbusier and Claude Parent'
description: Henry Urbach Architecture

title: Scientists Say Flooding Mine Will Derail Lab
description: Scientists behind a proposal to turn a former gold mine in South Dakota into a vast underground laboratory said yesterday that they would abandon their proposal if the mine was allowed to flood.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR FALLS. The dollar fell as a surge in jobless claims heightened speculation that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates. In New York, the dollar settled at $1.1843, up from $1.1689 on Wednesday.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A listing by critics of The Times of Broadway shows nominated for Tony Awards, along with shows closing this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Play Pool by the Rules? Not Us
description: A FEW months ago, my husband and I bought a pool table. We had our reasons. Our daughter and son would use it. Their friends would use it. Our house would fill up with raucous teenagers, the way it did last year, when our son was holding weekly low-stakes poker games.

title: Drug Money Laundered Into Gold, U.S. Says
description: They bought the gold in Manhattan, in Midtown's storied diamond district. But they did not want it for show, the authorities said. They were drug dealers, who bought the gold with ill-gotten cash and had jewelers rework the precious metal so that it was disguised and turned into everyday objects like belt buckles, wrenches, screws and other hardware.

title: Acquiring Vision But Losing Stability
description: Before I had any idea what the movie was about -- before the opening credits even concluded -- ''The Eye'' had already reduced me to a state of trembling, goose-bumped dread. Oxide and Danny Pang, the Thai-born, Hong Kong-based twins who directed this spooky, efficient exercise in terror, use simple and precise techniques to scare you before you even understand what there is to be afraid of. There are a few computer-generated effects -- half-translucent, ghostly figures passing through walls, for instance -- but the Pang brothers' preferred special effect is the camera itself, with its limited point of view, its mobility and, most of all, that innocent-looking focus ring attached to the lens.

title: In Fight Against Prom Night Drinking, Schools Try Prohibition on Limousines
description: Climbing into the plush seats of a white stretch limousine, often with a secret stash of alcohol in the trunk, has long been part of the prom night experience here in this wealthy suburb.

title: Classy Chassis, Unleaded Love
description: ''2 Fast 2 Furious,'' a new seatbelt-awareness film that opens nationwide today, features two very fine and touching performances, both of them by cars. Indeed, the movie, directed by John Singleton from a script by Michael Brandt and Derek Haas, can be seen as something of a love story, in which a pair of tricked-out Mitsubishis -- a cute purple Spider convertible and a sinewy yellow Evolution -- carry out a high-speed courtship as they dart and frolic along the highways of South Florida. Then, at what should be their moment of consummation, these two frisky vehicles are replaced by a pair of domestic hotrods (an orange Dodge and a blue Chevy), one of which crashes onto the deck of a yacht.

title: On Camera, On the Road
description: If you drive a company car or truck, someone may be watching. Several companies now install cameras inside company-owned vehicles to promote safe driving by their employees and to record accidents in order to clarify what caused them. DriveCam Video Systems of San Diego, which holds three patents on its system, goes beyond video. Its palm-sized unit, mounted behind the rearview mirror, captures what the driver sees and hears as well as four directions of G-forces created by unusually hard braking, sharp acceleration, hard cornering and collisions.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: HOME VIDEO
description: Like a wave of the title helicopters, ''Black Hawk Down'' has landed this week in a three-disc DVD special edition ($39.95) from Columbia TriStar. Extra features are at battalion strength for Ridley Scott's film about the ambush of American troops in Mogadishu, Somalia, in October 1993. Mr. Scott and many others contribute to three separate audio commentaries. A documentary about the making of the film runs 150 minutes, seven minutes longer than the movie. Two documentaries, from the History Channel and the PBS ''Frontline'' series, examine the real battle of Mogadishu.

title: Fast Times at Giants' Minicamp
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 5 - In their last Super Bowl season two years ago, no one would have called the Giants a fast team.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Riverstone Networks Reports Wider Loss
description: A maker of computer-networking equipment, Riverstone Networks, which last month delayed filing its annual report so it could finish an accounting inquiry, said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter net loss widened to a range of 15 cents to 17 cents a share as sales fell in Asia. Revenue for the period, ended May 31, fell to a range of $12 million to $13 million from $30.1 million, Riverstone said. The total net loss was $18.6 million to $20.7 million. The company had a net loss of $15.9 million, or 13 cents a share, a year earlier. The company said it would release full first-quarter results after the market closes on June 19. Riverstone was scheduled to file its 10(k) report on May 30 and delayed the filing after the Securities and Exchange Commission in April asked the company for some accounting data and said it might open a formal investigation. Riverstone shares fell 24 cents, or 13.8 percent, to $1.50.

title: A Horrific Crime and a Town's Painful Soul-Searching
description: The crime was unspeakable: on June 7, 1998, a black hitchhiker was picked up by three white men in an East Texas town and taken into the woods, where he was beaten and chained by his ankles to the rear bumper of their pickup truck. He was dragged nearly three miles along rural roads, his body gradually tearing to pieces before his head and right shoulder were severed from his torso by a roadside culvert. A pathologist later testified that the victim, 49-year-old James Byrd Jr., was probably conscious until the end.

title: Bar Mitzvah Motivators
description: To the Editor:

title: Only Through a Lens Did a Master Emerge
description: Charles Sheeler picked up a camera around 1910, at the age of 27. He had trained as a painter at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and had been to Europe three times: twice in 1904 and 1905 with his teacher William Merritt Chase, and again in 1908-9, with his best friend, the artist Morton Schamberg. Sheeler was up to speed with the latest developments in Paris and edging his way toward a competent Cubist style that culminated in his inclusion in the 1913 Armory Show.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Regrouping on a Labor Effort to Elect a Democrat
description: A new labor-backed group that aims to help elect a Democratic president by mobilizing nonunion voters announced a new board yesterday, two weeks after its three directors resigned in a split that rocked organized labor.

title: AOL Time Warner Cancels Auction for Book Division
description: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that it was canceling the auction of its book publishing division because it could not attract a high enough price.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Crackdown on Imports Is Felt in Dairy Aisles
description: Like countless specialty groceries scattered across New York, the Gourmet Plaza in Brighton Beach is a neighborhood favorite for immigrants hungry for a taste of home. Russian pop music throbs as shoppers navigate the store's crowded aisles, inspecting Cyrillic-lettered price tags and buying Russian cheese.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the Fashion page on Tuesday about the work of Bruno Bernard, a photographer known as Bernard of Hollywood, misstated the date of a picture he took of Jayne Mansfield. It was 1959, not 1949.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: June 5, 2003

title: Popeyes Ends Ties With Hill, Holliday
description: Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits, the chain of more than 1,670 restaurants in 22 countries, is parting ways with the New York office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, which had handled the account since 1996. Although billings were not disclosed, Popeyes spent $22.3 million last year to advertise in major media, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GEORGIA: U.N. OBSERVERS KIDNAPPED Three United Nations observers, one of them German, monitoring a truce between Georgia and its pro-Russian breakaway province, Abkhazia, were kidnapped with their translator in a gorge dividing the two, a United Nations spokeswoman said. A United Nations contingent of 100 observers is monitoring a truce between Georgia and Abkhazia, which proclaimed itself a separate state in 1993 after the breakup of the Soviet Union but is not recognized by any country or international body. About 250,000 Georgians fled the region when separatists, backed by mercenaries and arms from Russia's northern Caucasus region, drove out Georgian government troops in the 1990's.   ( Reuters )

title: For the Homeless, a Gentler Approach; Police and Outreach Group Join Forces to Patrol and Offer Help
description: Police Officer Michael Venckus has been doing homeless outreach work since 1991. He has arrested many vagrants over the years, and sent thousands of others to shelters, detox centers and hospitals. He has seen the city's homeless population rise and fall, and has witnessed varying approaches to the problem, like sealing subway tunnels, ignoring the homeless and arresting them.

title: Tightening a Very Large Belt
description: As grim as New York State's finances are these days, they provide an opportunity to clean up excesses, remedy bad management techniques and simply fix some of the crazy ways the state loses money. Here are a few ideas, some new and some alarmingly old.

title: Larry Clark; '178th Annual Exhibition'; David Askevold
description: Larry Clark

title: Corrections
description: The Quick Escapes column on May 23, about musical theater in Seattle, misstated the location of ''Hairspray'' last summer. It was at the Fifth Avenue Theater there, not at the Intiman. A correction last Friday misstated the name of a musical now playing at the Intiman. It is ''The Light in the Piazza,'' not ''The Light in the Plaza.''

title: Using Technology to Develop Arab-Jewish Ties
description: Can Israel's drive to develop its technology sector as the nation's economic crown jewel help overcome generations of animosity between Arabs and Jews?

title: Advertisers And Wall St. See an End To Turmoil
description: Wall Street analysts said yesterday that the five weeks of turmoil at The New York Times that led to the resignation of its top two editors had not rattled investors, and the paper's advertisers said they were undeterred.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Circuits yesterday with an article about a project to provide Internet services on the Makah Indian reservation in Washington State misspelled the given name of a trainer and the town where she was working. As the article reported, she is Tracey Rascon, not Tracy; the town is Neah Bay, not Neal Bay.

title: Doubts Crop Up Over Chrysler Turnaround Plan
description: Little more than two years ago, DaimlerChrysler dispatched a talented Mercedes-Benz executive, Dieter Zetsche, to turn around its ailing Chrysler unit.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Windfall From Christo

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Carrier Acquires Port
description: The world's largest shipping company, the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company, bought a new container port in India from the Adani Group for $195 million in cash as the company expands its business to capitalize on economic growth in Asia. P&O, based in London, will pay for the acquisition of the port, Mundra International Container Terminal Ltd., by selling 54.6 million new shares at 220 pence each to raise 120 million ($199 million).

title: National Briefing | West: California: City Bans Bow Fishing
description: The Imperial Beach City Council has voted unanimously to ban fishing with a bow and arrow from the city's pier and beaches. Imperial Beach, just north of the Mexican border, was the only town on the California coast that permitted the practice. Lifeguards, swimmers and surfers have said that bow fishermen posed a threat to those enjoying the waters around the pier. If reconfirmed by the City Council later this month, the ban will begin at the end of July. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FRIEDLANDER, , KURT A.
description: FRIEDLANDER--Kurt A. June 6, 1999. Your spirit always with us. Beloved husband and father. Missed and loved forever. Pie and Poohsie >>AD#

title: Duped And Betrayed
description: According to The New Republic, Senator Zell Miller -- one of a dwindling band of Democrats who still think they can make deals with the Bush administration and its allies -- got shafted in the recent tax bill. He supported the bill in part because it contained his personal contribution: a measure requiring chief executives to take personal responsibility for corporate tax declarations. But when the bill emerged from conference, his measure had been stripped out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TIFFT, , JANE
description: TIFFT--Jane. Douglas Elliman mourns the loss of our dear friend and colleague Jane Tifft of our 137 Waverly Place office. She will be greatly missed. >>AD#

title: Ashcroft Seeks More Power To Pursue Terror Suspects
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft today defended the Justice Department's detention of hundreds of illegal immigrants after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and urged Congress to give the authorities still greater power to pursue terrorism suspects.

title: Pope, in Croatia, Has Message for Women's 'Special' Role
description: DUBROVNIK, Croatia, June 6  Pope John Paul II beseeched women here today to pay heed to what he called their "lofty vocation" as wives, mothers and nurturers, saying they possessed a special sensitivity that was needed in the modern world.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: State Bond Rating Cut
description: Fitch Ratings, which assesses the creditworthiness of securities, yesterday downgraded New York's general obligation bonds to AA- from AA, putting New York among the seven lowest-rated states in the country. Analysts at the rating agency said the $92.8 billion budget passed by the State Legislature last month relied too much on borrowing to pay current bills. The budget also pushed the state's already high level of debt even higher, they said. Claire Cohen, the agency's top analyst of state bonds, said that there was little hope the state would reduce spending, since the Legislature had rejected most of the $2 billion in spending cuts that Gov. George E. Pataki had proposed and had raised taxes to restore them. She added that the $4.2 billion in new borrowing would simply forestall cuts, which made future shortfalls inevitable. ''It's kind of a bridge to nowhere,'' she said. ''That's where our concern was.''

title: Afghans Kill 40 Taliban Militants in Fierce Border Fights
description: Afghan government soldiers killed 40 Taliban fighters in three southern border villages, in one of the deadliest instances of increased rebel activity this year, officials said today. Seven government soldiers were also killed in the battle, they said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Media Stake Acquired
description: Effecten-Spiegel, a German holding company and publisher of financial magazines, bought 5 percent of the filmmaker and sports merchandiser EM.TV & Merchandising. Effecten-Spiegel, based in Dsseldorf, bought EM.TV shares on the stock exchange over several years for a total of 10.9 million euros ($12.9 million) because it saw it as ''a very interesting investment'' especially after EM.TV teamed up with other investors to buy the German sports TV channel DSF, Bolko Hoffmann, chief executive of Effecten, said.

title: Holdings of Municipal Bonds Show a Rise
description: Personal holdings of municipal bonds rose 3.4 percent in the first quarter to their highest level in more than a decade as investors sought low-risk investments.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hamden: Book Thief Is Returned To Prison
description: A man convicted last year of stealing rare books and other documents from Yale was returned to prison on Wednesday. Corrections officials had been monitoring him since his release from a halfway house. Investigators from the F.B.I. and the state police major crime squad searched his home Wednesday night. But no reason for the man's return to prison was announced except to say that it was ''no longer appropriate for him to be in the community release program,'' a State Department of Correction spokeswoman said. The man, Benjamin Winfield Johnson, 23, was convicted two years ago of stealing more than $1.5 million worth of rare library items, including letters by Thomas Jefferson. The items were stolen when Mr. Johnson was working as a summer intern at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Yale. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

description: HISTORIC Hope Township, in the rural northwest corner of New Jersey, is one of those quaint Colonial villages -- a cluster of limestone houses with steeply pitched roofs, built astride a picturesque millstream -- that should be famous, yet never quite made it as a stop on the American tourist trail. For many of Hope's homeowners, that obscurity is just fine.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 3 Companies Plan Package Of Calling Minutes
description: SBC Communications, BellSouth and their mobile telephone joint venture, Cingular Wireless, plan to sell a package of calling minutes that for the first time could be used for both mobile and home phone calls. SBC and BellSouth, both leading providers of local phone service, are seeking to win back business from wireless carriers, including Cingular. SBC and BellSouth lost a combined 497,000 local lines in the first quarter as some customers started using cellphones, exclusively, to save money. The plan, called MinuteShare, is being tested in Texas and will be available later this year, SBC and BellSouth said yesterday. The alliance underlines phone companies' desire to attract customers in a shrinking market by linking products. Wireless companies like Cingular sell calling packages that include 900 minutes for as little as $39.99 a month. Under MinuteShare, a Cingular customer paying a fixed monthly fee for a certain number of minutes could use those minutes to make long-distance calls over the SBC or BellSouth networks, an SBC spokesman, Michael Coe, said. He declined to say how much the new call package would cost. SBC shares rose 35 cents, to $26.53. BellSouth shares fell 14 cents, to $26.89.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Order To Ease Jail Crowding
description: A judge has given Marion County until July 8 to reduce crowding in the county jail. County officials will probably move several hundred inmates into private jails and increase home detention and work release. The order is a response to a suit filed by the Indiana Civil Liberties Union asking Judge Sarah Evans Barker of Federal District Court to cap the jail's population at 1,134 and fine the county, which includes Indianapolis, $40 a day per inmate beyond that capacity. The jail's population reached 1,664 in late May. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Congo War Zone Awaits French Troops Skeptically

title: DELTA'S BUDGET ARM ADDS CROSS-COUNTRY ROUTES
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that Song, its new low-cost airline, would start flying between Los Angeles and two cities in Florida on Sept. 3. The new routes, to Orlando and Tampa, reflect Song's entry into transcontinental flights. Its two main rivals, JetBlue and AirTran, are increasing service from the Los Angeles area to cities on the East Coast. Each of Song's new transcontinental routes will have two round-trip flights a day. The choice of markets follows Song's strategy to expand into routes heavily traveled by people going on vacation. Song started operations on April 15 with a flight between New York City and West Palm Beach, Fla. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Vote On Class Size Is Urged
description: A coalition of groups has joined the New York City teachers' union in calling for a ballot initiative that would require the Education Department to decrease class size throughout the school system. Under the initiative, voters would decide whether to amend the City Charter to require limited class size. Many city classrooms have more than 30 students. Besides the union, the United Federation of Teachers, the coalition includes the Community Service Society, the advocacy group Acorn, the Alliance for Quality Education, the United Parents Association and other groups. The coalition would have to collect at least 45,000 voters' signatures to put the question on the ballot. A spokesman for Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday, ''By moving ahead with our Children First reforms we are continuing to reduce class size in our city schools.'' Voters approved a similar referendum in Florida last year, but legislators have not determined how to pay for reducing class size. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: New Job For Ex-Official
description: Human Rights Watch today announced the appointment of Jorge G. Castaeda, the former foreign minister of Mexico, as the first Latin American member of its board of directors. In making the announcement, the organization, based in New York, praised Mr. Castaeda for having ''helped reorient Mexico's human rights policy 180 degrees.'' Although his aristocratic political style had made him one of this country's most polemical figures, Mr. Castaeda is widely credited with pressing Mexico's first democratic government to submit to the authority of international rights conventions. He was also the architect of a proposed migration agreement between Mexico and the United States that aims to win new rights for undocumented Mexicans living in the United States. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: On New Golf Courses, Nature Wins a Round
description: ON a grassy bluff 100 feet above the Pacific Ocean, you can see for at least 14 miles in each direction, from the windswept dunes and rolling hills along the shore, straight out across the sea toward Japan. The wind can blow so hard here that the rain comes in great horizontal gusts across the dunes. But there's a wild beauty to all the drama, with thick clouds scudding above the waves and the beach grasses and blooming thickets of gorse swirling in the wind. Dozens of different shades of green and gold blanket the hills, from the bright yellow Scotch broom to the deep green pines to the golden brown grass along the fairways.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telecom Stake Sold
description: The British telecommunications company Cable and Wireless sold its stake in the Hong Kong phone company PCCW as part of a strategy to exit unprofitable markets. Cable and Wireless sold the stake, 652 million shares that represent about 14 percent of the company, for about $400 million. The company held the shares on its books at 235 million ($390 million) as of March 31. On Wednesday, Cable and Wireless said it would exit the United States, and concentrate on business in Britain.

The commission noted that the judge, John R. Jarosz of the Paris Town Court, failed to supervise his wife adequately, adding that he received 10 letters from the state comptroller's office that his monthly reports and remittances had been late. His wife, Jean, resigned in July 2002, and Judge Jarosz repaid the money in December 2002. A message left for Judge Jarosz was not returned. Winnie Hu (NYT)

description: However abstract, art always represents something -- a set of values or a system of beliefs if not any recognizable object. For Frederick J. Brown, whose painting is the subject of a 30-piece retrospective at the Studio Museum in Harlem, the question of representation -- the what, how, who and why of it -- has driven a restless, three-decade quest. From 60's-style formalism to Neo-Expressionist narrative to portraits of great jazz and blues musicians, he has pursued representational possibilities with adventurous verve.

description: SCHER--Jack O. Of Faber, VA. Dynamic and loving, Jack O. Scher died peacefully in his sleep, at home, on the evening of June 4, 2003. He was 76 years old. He is survived by his wife Judith Geller Scher, three children-Liza, Adam and Emily. Two stepchildren-Batsheva and Dorothy, and four grandchildrenIsabella, Nicole, Matthew and Noah Jai. Jack was the founding publisher of six medical specialty newspapers: OBGYN News, Pediatric News, Internal Medicine News, Family Practice News, Skin and Allergy News and Clinical Psychiatric News. After he sold his medical publishing business, he became a spiritual book publisher of Sathya Sai Baba books. Jack was a unique and fascinating person, always ready to learn new things and help those in need. He had a great sense of humor and a remarkable zest for life. title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: RIVERSTONE NETWORKS REPORTS WIDER LOSS A maker of computer-networking equipment, Riverstone Networks, which last month delayed filing its annual report so it could finish an accounting inquiry, said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter net loss widened to a range of 15 cents to 17 cents a share as sales fell in Asia. Revenue for the period, ended May 31, fell to a range of $12 million to $13 million from $30.1 million, Riverstone said. The total net loss was $18.6 million to $20.7 million. The company had a net loss of $15.9 million, or 13 cents a share, a year earlier. The company said it would release full first-quarter results after the market closes on June 19. Riverstone was scheduled to file its 10(k) report on May 30 and delayed the filing after the Securities and Exchange Commission in April asked the company for some accounting data and said it might open a formal investigation. Riverstone shares fell 24 cents, or 13.8 percent, to $1.50.    (Bloomberg News)
