description: CRUDE OIL GAINS. Crude oil rose after an Iraqi official said looting at a pipeline may delay exports through Turkey. In New York, crude oil for July delivery gained 69 cents, or 2.3 percent, to $30.74 a barrel.

title: On the Road to Falluja
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, June 6  The road home for the Spartan Brigade is through Falluja. The mission is to put an end to the attacks that have plagued American troops in this town 40 miles west of Baghdad.

title: A Tale Explained as Well as Told
description: Like a wave of the title helicopters, "Black Hawk Down" has landed this week in a three-disc DVD special edition ($39.95) from Columbia TriStar. Extra features are at battalion strength for Ridley Scott's film about the ambush of American troops in Mogadishu, Somalia, in October 1993. Mr. Scott and many others contribute to three separate audio commentaries. A documentary about the making of the film runs 150 minutes, seven minutes longer than the movie. Two documentaries, from the History Channel and the PBS "Frontline" series, examine the real battle of Mogadishu.

title: European Regulators Seek More Evidence in Microsoft Inquiry
description: European competition regulators are seeking more evidence in their investigation of Microsoft, a move that is almost certain to delay further the five-year-old antitrust inquiry.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Chicago

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Third Suspect In Rap Shooting
description: The police yesterday arrested the third suspect in the shooting of a hip-hop performer and a member of his entourage on April 25. The suspect, John Mingo, 32, was charged with second-degree murder in the attack on Eric Mangrum, 28, who died shortly afterward, and Ezekiel Jiles, 27. Mr. Jiles, who performs under the name Freaky Zeeky, was shot in the chest and abdomen and later recovered. The shooting took place after a traffic accident on 21st Street near Fifth Avenue escalated into a dispute. Two other men have been arrested in the shooting. Herndon Williams, 22, was charged with second-degree murder on May 17, and Chauncey Dillon, 29, was arrested on April 30. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Woman Robbed By Men With Fake Badges
description: A woman who answered her door at 2:30 p.m. yesterday was bound with duct tape and robbed by two men wearing fake badges around their necks, the police said. They stole cash and jewelry from the home, on 27th Avenue in Linden Hill. The woman was not injured. The police said one of the men was about 30, 5-foot-8, 185 pounds, with brown eyes and short brown hair. The other was about 30, 5-foot-10, 175 pounds, with medium-length dirty blond hair. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: This Classic Is a Bargain Hunter's Day at the Races
description: When the crowd files out of Belmont Park tomorrow evening after the Belmont Stakes, many people will head home with lighter pockets. They may complain about the narrow loss they suffered in one race, the bone-headed ride their jockey delivered in another or any number of lost wagers, but it is doubtful any will attribute their financial setback to the cost of a day at the races or to the greed of the New York Racing Association. It is a little hard to gripe about what may be the last great bargain in sports.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about research on mad cow and other brain diseases that sometimes jump from species to species misstated findings on mice bred with genes to produce human prions, the proteins that can lead to such disorders. So far, the mice appear resistant to the diseases; they have not come down with chronic wasting disease (found in deer and elk) or new-variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (found in humans).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, , MILDRED FREE MAN
description: SOLOMON -- Mildred Free man. Died peacefully on June 5, 2003. Dearly beloved wife of Leon Solomon and the late Robert Freeman. Devoted mother to Douglas and Ruth, Randall and Flora, and Keith and Marianne. Adoring grandmother to Hank and Amy, Zachary and Dana, Howard, Melissa, Robert, Jesse, Robyn and Daniel. Loved and respected by her family and friends. We will miss her zest for life. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOSCATO, , MARION H.
description: MOSCATO--Marion H. The officers, staff and members of the Alumni Federation of Columbia University are deeply saddened by the passing of its staunchest supporter and director, Marion, on June 4, 2003. Prior to her retirement in 1983, she was an associate director with the University's Development and Alumni Relations Department and the executive secretary of the Alumni Federation. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family and many friends. Viewing will be Sunday from 2-6pm at Halvey's Funeral Home, 24 Willow St, Beacon NY. 1-845-831-0380. The funeral service will be held 10AM on Monday at St John the Evanelist's Church, 31 Willow Street, also in Beacon, NY. Jessie Mygatt on behalf of Columbia University Alumni Federation >>AD#

title: Intelligence, or Rumor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Vows column in The Metro Section on May 25, about the wedding of Rudolph W. Giuliani and Judith Nathan, included an erroneous reference from the couple's spokeswoman to "Deliver Me," the song that introduced the first dance. It was performed by the Bob Hardwick Sound Orchestra, not by the soprano Sarah Brightman.

title: Sales at Intel Are Largely on Track for Quarter
description: Intel, the world's largest chip maker, narrowed its forecast yesterday for second-quarter revenue.

title: Justice Dept. Bans Event By Gay Staff
description: The Justice Department has barred a group of employees from holding their annual gay pride event at the department's headquarters, the first time such an event has been blocked by any federal agency, gay rights leaders said today.

title: Connecticut Legislators End With New Bills, but No Budget
description: Like a batter who often reaches base but seems incapable of hitting home runs, Connecticut's legislature ended its annual lawmaking session today having passed a bevy of small bills but without a budget that Gov. John G. Rowland would sign.

title: A Modernist's Lens
description: ''The Photography of Charles Sheeler,'' a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum, presents rare vintage prints made by a pioneer of American modernism who was better known for his paintings. His ''Doylestown House -- Stove, Horizontal,'' above, was taken around 1916-17.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on May 26 about the redesigned $20 bill due in the fall reversed descriptions of two features on the current one. It is Andrew Jackson's right eyebrow that is darker than on the previous bill and his left eyebrow that was described as having morphed into a giant albino caterpillar. The article also reversed references to the new bill: Jackson seems to be missing his left shoulder, not his right, and the words ''Twenty USA'' and ''USA Twenty'' are on his left side, not his right.

title: This Time, Mariners Seek a Better Ending
description: It might seem dangerous to mention the 2001 Seattle Mariners around the 2003 Mariners. The 2001 team tied a major league record with 116 victories, a remarkable regular-season display that seemed a little hollow after the Yankees punched them out of the postseason. Winning 116 games but not a title made the Mariners feel like the 18-year-old who was destined to be prom king until he left the dance at 9:15 p.m.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: INDIANA: ORDER TO EASE JAIL CROWDING A judge has given Marion County until July 8 to reduce crowding in the county jail. County officials will probably move several hundred inmates into private jails and increase home detention and work release. The order is a response to a suit filed by the Indiana Civil Liberties Union asking Judge Sarah Evans Barker of Federal District Court to cap the jail's population at 1,134 and fine the county, which includes Indianapolis, $40 a day per inmate beyond that capacity. The jail's population reached 1,664 in late May. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Amateur Choruses Welcome Contemporary Composers
description: Classical audiences tend to view music of the 20th century (to say nothing of the 21st) with mistrust. And yet that music has established a firm foothold in one area: the amateur chorus.

title: Rockets Woo Van Gundy
description: In what essentially amounted to a recruiting trip, the Houston Rockets took Jeff Van Gundy and his wife, Kim, around Houston yesterday.

title: 'Chemical Ali': Is He Dead, or Still Alive?
description: The Iraqi military commander known as ''Chemical Ali'' for his role in using chemical weapons against the Kurdish minority may still be alive, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today.

title: Change in Lineup Gives Matsui a Fresh Outlook
description: When Hideki Matsui returned to his locker after his best game as a Yankee tonight, his name plate was turned backward. On it, his teammate Robin Ventura had written ''OH 55,'' a reference to Sadaharu Oh, the greatest home run hitter in Japanese history and Matsui's uniform number.

title: Shopping List | Market Essentials
description: ATTENTION summer shoppers: The season for farmer's markets, flea markets and yard sales has officially begun. Committed weekend shoppers know the rules: Get there early and be prepared. For the serious this means comfortable shoes, a steady focus and carryalls large enough to hold the essentials -- and the great unexpected find. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: Trade Is Almost Done To Aquire Lefty Bat
description: The Yankees will acquire a left-handed hitter soon, the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, promised on Wednesday, and a deal for one seemed very close today.

title: Swiss Maker of Luxury Goods Suffers From Currency Shifts
description: On the same day the Swiss government reported that its export-dependent economy contracted in the first quarter, Compagnie Financier Richemont provided the proof.

title: Finance Law To Be Argued In September
description: The Supreme Court will hear oral arguments on the new campaign finance law on Sept. 8, a month before the start of its fall term and time enough to decide the case before the election season starts next year.

title: A Good Girl Takes a Walk on the Wild Side (and Is Tripped Up)
description: If ever a movie star embodied the lean-and-hungry look that actors consider synonymous with street credibility, it is Adrien Brody, whose character, Jack, in ''Love the Hard Way'' suggests something sleek and predatory scuttling through an alley to gnaw on a piece of fetid garbage. With his darting rat eyes, raspy voice, sly smirk and street hustler's swagger, Jack revels in the fact that he is bad news.

title: New Chief for Arch Unit
description: Ralph Jones, who led the directors and officers insurance unit of the Chubb Corporation, was named the chief executive of the United States business of the Arch Capital Group. Mr. Jones, 47, will run the Arch Insurance Group, which sells property, casualty and professional liability coverage in the United States, Arch Capital said. At Chubb, he was responsible for selling more than a third of the company's policies. Arch Capital, which has one-tenth of Chubb's market capitalization, is based in Bermuda.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Finding Magic At the Met

title: School Is Canceled as Strike Enters Third Day
description: Teachers on strike at a northwestern New Jersey school district defied a judge's order yesterday, refusing to work for the second day in a row and forcing the district to close school today.

title: Glavine's Elbow Is Hurt As Mets Lose Two Games
description: It looked bad for the Mets after their first loss yesterday to the Milwaukee Brewers. After the second defeat, things looked much worse. Not only did the Mets lose both games of a doubleheader, 8-7 and 5-3, before 19,048 fans at Shea Stadium, but they also lost their prize pitcher, 37-year-old Tom Glavine, to an inflamed elbow on his pitching arm. It was not immediately clear if Glavine, who exited in the second inning after surrendering five runs, would be able to make his next start.

title: Council Ponders Next Step After Mayor's Budget Move
description: Now that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has rescinded $90 million of his most unpopular proposed budget cuts, City Council officials struggled yesterday to figure out how they could save even more services.

title: Mother Faces Murder Charge In the Death Of Her Baby
description: The police arrested a Harlem woman yesterday on a murder charge in the death of her infant daughter.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Unemployment Rate Rises to 9-Year High
description: WASHINGTON, June 6  The unemployment rate rose to 6.1 percent in May, its highest level in nine years, the Labor Department reported today, as the worst jobs slump since the early 1980's continued to spread across the economy.

title: New Video Releases
description: About Schmidt

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOSORESOW, , ANDREW PETER
description: KOSORESOW--Andrew Peter. Age 39, on June 1, 2003 at his home in New York City of heart failure. An adored Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Columbia University since 1997, he was an alumnus of Cathedral School, 1978; Collegiate School, 1982; Columbia College, 1985; and Stanford University, 1996 (Ph.D.). He had previously taught at the University of New Mexico and at Stanford University. He is survived by his mother, Claudia Kosoresow. Two Russian Orthodox services will be held: a memorial prayer service on Thursday, June 5th at 7:30PM; a funeral service on Friday, June 6th at 11:00AM. Both services will be held at: Cathedral of Our Lady of the Sign, 75 E. 93rd St. at Park Ave., New York, NY 10128. Following the Friday service, interment will be conducted at: Novo Diveevo Cemetery, Smith Road, Spring Valley, NY.

title: Robert Adams -- 'Commercial/Residential'
description: Roth Horowitz

title: People
description: * Ami Brophy was named executive director at the Clio Awards, New York, part of VNU. She succeeds Andrew Jaffe, who is leaving after six years in the post to open Compass Consulting, Norwalk, Conn. Ms. Brophy had been vice president and publisher at Adweek magazine, New York, published by the VNU Business Publications USA unit of VNU.

title: 'May'
description: Directed by Lucky McKee

title: Hilfiger Posts Loss; Big Charge Is Cited
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation, the clothing company, posted a net loss yesterday in its latest quarter, hurt in part by a big charge. Even so, the company still beat analysts' expectations by 3 cents a share, excluding special items.

title: A Hopeful Moment in the Mideast?
description: To the Editor:

title: When Palm Does a Deal, Prices Get Crazy
description: THAT is it about Palm Inc. that produces irrational prices?

title: Bryant May Need Shoulder Surgery
description: Kobe Bryant has a tear in the tissue around his right shoulder socket that may require surgery. The labrum tear was discovered during a magnetic resonance imaging examination Wednesday, the Lakers said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BB&T, Winston-Salem, N.C., a bank and insurance broker in the Southeast, said it had agreed to buy Stharco, Kingsport, Tenn., an insurance broker. Terms were not disclosed.

title: In the Homebody Wake: Lots of 'Bush Slept Here' Places
description: President Bush's aerobic seven-day, six-nation trip, which ended today with a visit to American troops here, took him from the concentration camp sites of Poland to the czars' palaces of St. Petersburg, a global economic conference in the French Alps and Middle East peacemaking on the edge of the Red Sea. For a president who does not love to travel, the trip was Clintonian -- two countries nearly every day and a new bed to sleep in most nights.

title: Man Acquitted in Terror Case Says Co-defendants Will Be Cleared
description: A man acquitted on Tuesday in a terror case here said that he was grateful to the American justice system and that he was confident his co-defendants would eventually be cleared as well.

title: Baseball's Greatest Hits
description: Cheating is inherent in the game of baseball. After I hurt my arm in 1976, I couldn't get enough velocity on my sinker. So I cut out part of my glove, on the outside near the thumb hole, and stitched in a piece of an emery board. I was able to pitch for five more years instead of having to drive a school bus.

title: Where the Humble Pot Is a Cultural Pinnacle
description: No one can accuse the Japanese of not loving pots; Japan is probably the most ceramics-conscious country in the world. A special reverence for crafts pervades Japanese aesthetics. (Before Westernization arrived in the mid-19th century, there was no word in the language for ''fine arts.'') And the making of pottery is considered on a par with painting, sculpture and architecture.

title: A Nobel Peace Laureate Under Attack
description: A year ago there was hope that democracy might come to Myanmar. In May 2002, the military junta released Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the world's most famous political prisoner, after 19 months of house arrest. The government promised to grant its citizens full freedoms and agreed to hold talks about opening up the political system. These gestures won Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, a reprieve from international pressure while the world waited to see whether the promises would be kept. They were not, and sanctions are once again needed to force the government to keep its word.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Confusion Fills the Air After Judge Ends Nassau County Smoking Ban
description: Three months ago, Nassau County became the first place in the region to ban smoking in all bars and restaurants. Today, on wooden tables and plastic countertops across the county, the ashtrays were back.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: AN EFFORT TO SAVE WATER With the Western drought putting pressure on states to find adequate supplies of water, Gov. Bill Owens signed a series of bills to keep more of Colorado's water in Colorado. The core of the package is a ballot initiative asking voters to approve $2 billion in bonds for water projects, including some that would repair and renovate state reservoirs to bank more water from the Colorado River, a prime source of water for seven Western states. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Argentine Leader Calls for Impeachment of the Supreme Court
description: Argentina's new president, Nstor Kirchner, has called on Congress to reinstate impeachment proceedings against the nation's widely hated Supreme Court, accusing justices of ''holding the country's governability hostage so as to obtain personal or institutional advantages or guarantees.''

title: Chicago Journal; Debating a Distant Homeland's Future
description: Though much of the city has not heard of it, there is an election beginning here Friday.

title: Nurse Testifies Priest Raped Her in Rectory
description: In graphic detail, a registered nurse told jurors in a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday that a Roman Catholic priest invited her to a rectory in Bedford-Stuyvesant in 2000 to advise her about annulling her marriage, raped her on a couch and then blithely asked for a ride back to where he was staying.

title: Lisa Sanditz -- 'Season Tickets'
description: CRG Gallery

title: ROADWAY CUTS PROFIT OUTLOOK FOR QUARTER AND YEAR
description: Roadway, the largest trucking company in the nation, cut its second-quarter profit forecast by at least half, in part because of lower-than-expected shipments for retailers. Its shares fell 17 percent. Roadway gets more than half of its shipments from retailers and wholesalers, which typically pay higher prices for time-sensitive service, the chief financial officer, J. Dawson Cunningham, said. The company was also hurt by price cuts amid competition for freight, he said. Roadway reduced its earnings estimate to 33 cents a share, from 65 to 79 cents in April. Stock in Roadway, based in Akron, Ohio, fell $6.43, to $31.16. Roadway also lowered its full-year profit estimate to a range of $2.36 to $2.60 a share. The April forecast was $3.10 to $3.60.

title: Repair Plan For Reactor With Leaks
description: The managers of a Texas nuclear plant with two leaks at the bottom of its reactor vessel told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today that they were backing away from their top theory on how the leaks developed. But, they said, they were nearly ready to fix them anyway.

title: German Politician, Facing Inquiry, Dies in Parachute Fall
description: A prominent German politician and member of Parliament who was accused of anti-Semitism last year and, more recently, embroiled in charges of financial wrongdoing died in a parachute jump today.

title: Facing a Suspension, Sosa Enjoys the Moment
description: For 140 minutes, Sammy Sosa had sunshine. He had soft winds tickling the ivy on the walls of Wrigley Field. He had his patch of grass in right and many of the 28,713 fans in his pocket. The second pitch he faced today caught too much of the plate, and he laced it up the middle for a single and the Chicago Cubs' first run of the game.

title: Senators Reach Agreement On Drug Plan for the Elderly
description: Several influential senators announced today that they had reached a bipartisan agreement on legislation to provide prescription drug coverage to the elderly, through the traditional government-run Medicare program and through newer private health plans.

title: Martha Stewart Uses Web to Tell Her Side of Story
description: She has been indicted and deposed and made to march before tabloid paparazzi, but Martha Stewart is now taking her case to the people, electronically.

title: Dow Makes Small Gains as Nasdaq Slides
description: Stock prices closed mixed on Wall Street, as traders took profits during afternoon trading in advance of the weekend. Early in the session, major market averages surged, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index rose above 1,000 for the first time in almost a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DJU, , DR. MEI YU
description: DJU--Dr. Mei Yu, 96, died peacefully on June 4, 2003. Funeral service Saturday 11:00am Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave. (exit 17 Saw Mill) Dobbs Ferry, NY. Visiting 10-11am >>AD#

title: Bush Tells Troops the Truth Will Emerge About Weapons Hidden by Hussein
description: President Bush, addressing American troops from the military camp where the war in Iraq was run, insisted today that evidence shows that Saddam Hussein was capable of unleashing biological agents and that the full truth about his destructive weapons would emerge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCOLLA, , JOSEPH
description: MARCOLLA--Joseph, 89, on June 4, 2003. Husband of the late Marguerite Beattie Marcolla. Survived by his children Nancy Fankhanel of Wilton, CT, and Michael Marcolla of Ghent, New York >>AD#

title: Former Executive Editor Named To Top Job During Transition
description: Joseph Lelyveld is returning to the top job in the newsroom he left when he retired in 2001, but this time he will be executive editor for the interim.

title: A Car Show Just for 'Orphans'
description: RAILROAD tracks split the Depot Town section of Ypsilanti, but trains highball through and don't stop anymore. Out on the edge of town, General Motors' giant Willow Run plant stands shuttered. This is postindustrial America. What better place for a group of ghost cars to sputter back to life?

title: Ubud Journal; Bomb That Killed 202 Goes On Destroying Lives
description: I Made Degun, a woodcarver who creates cats, koala bears and kangaroos for the trinket trade, sat at the lowest rung of what seemed to be the infinite tourism boom in Bali. His inexpensive souvenirs, snatched up by visitors who ventured to this artistic town by the vanful, gave him a new way of life: a house with a second story, a motorcycle to ferry the goods to market, even a modest shop in his front yard.

title: City Cleared on Making Diesel-Soot Study
description: New York City does not have to study the health effects of soot from diesel sanitation trucks, the state's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: 36 Hours | Richmond, Va.
description: RICHMOND is changing its mind about Abraham Lincoln. This spring the unthinkable happened: a Lincoln statue went up in a downtown park, not far from the bronzes of Robert E. Lee and his generals on Monument Avenue. About 100 members of the Sons of Confederate Veterans staged a protest, but most of the city took it in stride. Richmond remains mindful of its historic role as the Confederate capital, and in its lovely gardens, preserved buildings and heirloom recipes, it treasures its Southern traditions. At the same time, it lives in the present, cultivating its role as a commercial and artistic center in the New South. Recent arrivals mingle with the old families in lovely neighborhoods, and rafters take to the white water of the James River as it flows through downtown. Budding musicians and artists perform or open studios, and movie crews shoot scenes for Hollywood. Richmond's pantheon is widening with its outlook. ELIZABETH OLSON

title: LILLY WAIVES REPAYMENT OF LOAN TO ISIS PHARMACEUTICALS
description: Isis Pharmaceuticals, a drug developer whose experimental cancer medication failed in a study, said yesterday that its partner, Eli Lilly, had waived repayment of a $21 million loan used to build a manufacturing plant for the drug, Affinitak. In March, the companies said the drug did not help patients live longer in a test that was part of the last research phase required for approval. As part of the agreement, Lilly will not be obligated to buy some of the product from Isis or pay for expenses incurred if the plant, in Carlsbad, Calif., is idled, Isis said. Isis can still use the plant to make other medicines.

title: ImClone to Reapply for Drug Approval
description: ImClone Systems said yesterday that it would reapply in the second half of this year for approval of Erbitux, the cancer drug whose initial rejection by the Food and Drug Administration led to the insider trading scandal that ensnared Martha Stewart.

title: Dead Toddler Had Suffered Past Abuse
description: Prosecutors and child welfare officials are investigating the death of a 21-month-old child who had previously been abused by his parents, but who had been returned to them in recent months by foster care workers.

title: Sin City
description: Pirates and other family fare couldn't bring enough tourists, so Las Vegas has gone back to its Sin City roots.

title: Market Essentials
Troops Arrive in Congo
description: The new multinational force comes with a mandate to enforce law and order.

title: Art Smart
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Scandal's Toll: The Shake-Up at The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Buyout Financing Changes
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the buyout firm, is considering how it can raise money from individual investors to finance takeovers, a partner, Johannes Huth, said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Telecom Investment
description: Telefnica Mviles, the wireless arm of Telefnica of Spain, announced yesterday that it would invest $1.5 billion in its operation in Mexico through 2005. The airline is a distant second to the Mexican giant Amrica Mvil in the market. Telefnica Mviles has fewer than three million customers in Mexico but hopes to increase that to six million to seven million by 2006. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; 'I Didn't Know' Is Familiar Refrain
description: WHEN Sammy Sosa said he didn't know the bat was corked, the line had a resonance that sounded familiar. It was from a 1940's song, ''I Didn't Know the Gun Was Loaded.''

title: Elizabeth Fowler, 95, Dies; Drifted 10 Days in Lifeboat
description: Elizabeth Fowler, who wrote a harrowing book about being the only woman among 35 passengers on a lifeboat in the Atlantic Ocean for 10 days during World War II, died on May 30 at a convalescent home in West Orange, N.J. She was 95.

title: Failings at NASA Extend Well Beyond Foam Hitting Columbia, Panel Reports
description: NASA's problems go far beyond falling foam, according to an early outline of the report by the independent panel investigating the accident that doomed the shuttle Columbia and its crew.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''As usual, the American pressure was counterproductive. They got the man to say what they wanted him to say, but they didn't consider the implications on the ground.''

title: Drug Makers to Expand Panel On Joint Research on Cancer
description: A proposal for pharmaceutical industry collaboration on cancer drug research took a small step forward yesterday when industry executives agreed to establish a larger task force to study the idea, executives involved in the matter said yesterday.

title: A Quadruplet's Death in Pennsylvania Leads to a Hovel and an Investigation
description: Four years ago, Tamra Seymore, 41, had quadruplets three boys and a girl.

title: A Cozy Booth for a Conversation, if You're a Party of One, That Is
description: The Verizon pay phone technicians who pulled up to the northwest corner of West End Avenue and 100th Street yesterday had no idea they were participating in a major New York City preservation project.

title: Proceed With Caution. Slippery When Heard.
description: Lots of bands write songs that grow on you, but Radiohead seems more interested in songs that shrink. Its new album, ''Hail to the Thief'' (Capitol), is full of restless compositions that turn over and over, becoming more elusive with each change. The longer you listen, the less familiar they seem.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about George H. Heyman Jr., a philanthropist and financier, misstated the location of Townsend Harris High School when he graduated. It was then in Manhattan. (It is now in Queens.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NUGENT, , FRANK
description: NUGENT--Frank, on June 6, 2003. Member of the Screen Actors Guild and Army Veteran of WWII. Beloved husband of Elizabeth (nee McMahon). Loving father of Nancy Nugent Miklos, Frank Jr., Bill, Andy and the late Brendan. Cherished grandfather of thirteen. Dear brother of Donald, Joseph and Marie Schneider. Reposing Saturday 7-9PM and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM at Riverdale-onHudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:45AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BLANKE, , RUTH PALMER
description: BLANKE--Ruth Palmer, of St. Louis, MO, Warwick, NY and Hobe Sound, FL, died March 4, 2003 at Jupiter Island, FL. A memorial service will be held June 8, 4pm at the Old School Baptist Meeting House, Downtown Warwick, NY

title: Emotional Night At '73 Anniversary
description: The largest ovation was not for Willis Reed or Walt Frazier, nor for Earl Monroe or Dick Barnett. The introduction that got the entire crowd, starting with Reed and Frazier, off its feet was for a woman seated among the familiar faces. Geri DeBusschere, the wife of the Knicks' Hall of Famer Dave DeBusschere, drew the applause and the tears when she was introduced representing her husband at the 30th Anniversary Championship Celebration of the 1973 Knicks championship team last night at the N.B.A. Store in Manhattan.

title: Shuttle Tests Seem to Back Theory That Falling Foam Caused Accident
description: An enormous gas cannon fired a piece of foam against a copy of a space shuttle wing here today and put cracks in a leading-edge panel and in an adjoining seal. Those results could add further weight to the theory that the shuttle Columbia was doomed by the impact of a falling piece of insulating foam 81 seconds after being launched.

title: U.N. Envoy Will Try to Visit Burmese Dissident Held by Junta
description: A United Nations envoy arrived today in Myanmar and said he would press for the release of the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who is in detention after a violent clash that the United States said might have been instigated by the government.

title: Court Report Faults Chief Judge in University Admissions Case
description: The chief judge of the federal appeals court in Cincinnati, which narrowly upheld the use of the race-conscious admissions program at the University of Michigan last May, acted improperly in handling the case, an internal court report has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRESCHER, , GEORGE
description: TRESCHER -- George. The patients and staff of the AIDS Care Center of the New York Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our friend. George was very wise in the ways of New York. After taking our program to heart more than a decade ago, he shared that wisdom to nurture our growth. We will miss his loyal support and counsel. Jonathan Jacobs, M.D., Executive Director Samuel Merrick, M.D., Medical Director

title: Ex-Informer Admits to Fraud As He Helped F.B.I. on a Case
description: A former F.B.I. informer admitted in court today that he helped mastermind a pyramid scheme that bilked scores of investors of at least $73 million while he was helping federal investigators in another case, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the recent rally in stocks referred imprecisely to the period for the run-up in the three main stock gauges. They have each gained more than 20 percent since the recent bottom of the market on March 11, not ''since March.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRYNIN, , TERRY
description: TRYNIN--Terry, 97 years old, of Brooklyn, NY on June 3, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Honey. Mother of Jane Feder and mother-in-law of Al Feder. ''Mama'' to Richie and Bobby and Linda and Malka and ''Great Mama'' to Kenny and Lauren and to Shaya, Sara Rachel, Chana Rifka, Menachem and Chaim. She was feisty and super smart and knew more than all of us put together. >>AD#

title: As Iraqis' Disaffection Grows, U.S. Offers Them a Greater Political Role
description: The imam at one of Baghdad's largest mosques urged more than a thousand listeners today to wage a jihad, or religious war, against American occupying forces in Iraq.

title: F.T.C. RECOMMENDS REJECTING H&R BLOCK SETTLEMENT
description: H & R Block's proposed settlement of lawsuits by Texas customers who say they were charged excessive interest on tax-refund loans is not in the public interest and should be rejected, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday in court papers. Block has agreed to pay as much as $311 million in rebates and legal fees to resolve the class-action suit over the Rapid Refund program. A judge in Kingsville, Tex., will decide on June 24 whether to approve the accord, which about split $26 million among 700,000 Texans who would also receive coupons worth $74.90 in tax services for five years. ''The coupon settlement of uncertain and likely low value is inadequate,'' F.T.C. officials said in a release. The agency filed a brief yesterday opposing the settlement, which is similar to one a federal judge in Illinois rejected in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRITT, , WILLIAM
description: BRITT--William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Britt, associated with The Times from July 1983 until retiring in December 1994 >>AD#

title: Scott Is Playing Down His Players' Criticism
description: SAN ANTONIO, June 6  When San Antonio ended the Nets' playoff winning streak at 10 games in Game 1 on Wednesday, the Spurs inadvertently created an off-the-court problem for the Nets when some players started second-guessing their coach, Byron Scott, in the news media.

title: HAMAS BREAKS OFF TALKS ON STOPPING ATTACKS ON ISRAEL
description: Leaders of the militant Islamic group Hamas broke off cease-fire talks today with Prime Minister Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, saying he had failed the Palestinian people in a speech at a meeting with Israel by demanding an end to the armed uprising and expressing compassion for Jewish suffering.

title: Congress Examines Loan Requests by Small Businesses After 9/11 Attack
description: Congressional investigators are looking into whether the Small Business Administration responded adequately to requests from New York City business owners for loans to help them recover from the physical or economic impact of the September 2001 terrorist attack.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Interest Rate Cut
description: Denmark's central bank pared its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, to 2.15 percent, the lowest in almost two centuries. The reduction aims to keep the currency, the krone, stable against the euro after the European Central Bank cut the rate on the euro by the same amount, to 2 percent, on Thursday. Denmark rejected joining Europe's common currency in a referendum in 2000.

title: The Margins Are Minuscule At Open Trials in Memphis
description: Two of the four quarterfinal matches played on Thursday in the Open Trials in Memphis were desperately close.

title: Sleepless and Litigious in 7B: A Co-op War Ends in Court
description: A bond salesman named David Pullman has recently joined the ranks of people looking for an apartment in Manhattan. He is not married, has no pets, does not smoke, and would prefer to live on the Upper West Side because he likes to run in Central Park. All in all, he appears to have the makings of a model tenant.

title: Harmonic Convergence at Carnegie Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Charged In Death Of Woman Hit by Van
description: A woman who had just walked out of a church in Queens on Thursday night was struck and killed by a car driven by a man who the police say was drunk and had struck another woman 10 minutes earlier.

title: Faria Wins Long Island Open
description: Ron Faria survived a four-over-par final round of 74 and finished with a 54-hole total of 209 to win the Long Island Open at the Bethpage Red Course in Farmingdale, N.Y. Faria, who started the day tied for sixth, shot 66 in the morning on the way to the title, which earned him $7,000.

title: Keep the Umbrellas Handy. Yesterday's Sun Was a Mirage.
description: Four women lounged on green park benches yesterday at Branch Brook Park in Newark, their babies sleeping in strollers parked around them and their older children running in the sunshine at the playground nearby. Then someone said it would rain this weekend, and the news almost jolted them out of their sunny tableau.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: DNA EVIDENCE WINS A MAN HIS FREEDOM A Chicago man, Dana Holland, 35, who served 10 years in prison for rape but was exonerated in January because of DNA evidence has been released. Judge James Linn of Cook County cleared his record of charges of attempted murder, armed robbery, aggravated kidnapping and aggravated battery in a related case. He was sentenced in 1993 to 90 years in prison for the rape of a woman who was eight months pregnant, but DNA evidence proved that he could not have been the assailant.   Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Pataki Seeks Extension of Power Plant Law
description: With just eight days left in the legislative session, Gov. George E. Pataki renewed his calls today for extending a state law that governs the approval of new power plants, adding yet one more item to a growing heap of legislative matters that seem unlikely to be resolved this year.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the second day of Shavuot, the Jewish Feast of Weeks, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, , MILDRED FREE MAN
description: SOLOMON -- Mildred Free man. Died peacefully on June 5, 2003. Dearly beloved wife of Leon Solomon and the late Robert Freeman. Devoted mother to Douglas and Ruth, Randall and Flora, and Keith and Marianne. Adoring grandmother to Hank and Amy, Zachary and Dana, Howard, Melissa, Robert, Jesse, Robyn and Daniel. Loved and respected by her family and friends. We will miss her zest for life. >>AD#

title: Some Analysts Of Iraq Trailers Reject Germ Use
description: American and British intelligence analysts with direct access to the evidence are disputing claims that the mysterious trailers found in Iraq were for making deadly germs. In interviews over the last week, they said the mobile units were more likely intended for other purposes and charged that the evaluation process had been damaged by a rush to judgment.

title: As Cities' Budgets Shrink, Criminal Justice Feels Pinch
description: The Portland police budget has been cut by more than 10 percent in the last three years, and the strain is showing.

title: Personality Married To Artistry
description: Henning Rbsam is good company. His dances are set to unusual music -- from lieder to daffy rock classics -- that pleases the ear and engages the mind. His dancers are not just proficient technically but also full of engaging personality. And his costuming is brightly imaginative. Those values spoke loudest in an informal program on Tuesday night at a studio theater at City Center, but the choreography itself was never far behind.

title: NBC's Olympic Run Is Extended to 2012 With $2 Billion Bid
description: NBC Sports held on to its Olympic franchise today by winning a three-way auction for the United States media rights to the 2010 and 2012 Olympic Games with a record bid of $2 billion. It was augmented by a nearly $200 million deal for General Electric, NBC's parent, to become a worldwide Olympic sponsor. The bid was made even though the sites for those Games have not yet been determined.

title: In Yale Bombing, F.B.I. Is Said To Search Home of a Parolee
description: Agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which is investigating who detonated a crude bomb inside Yale Law School last month, were looking for explosives and flammable materials when they searched a home of a former university employee on Wednesday night, the former employee's lawyer said today.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: JOBLESS RATE RISES Confirming recent signs of weakness in the Canadian economy, Statistics Canada reported that unemployment climbed to 7.8 percent in May, from 7.5 percent in April and well above analysts' expectations. The soft employment data contributed to a sharp decline in the Canadian dollar, which traded at 73.69 United States cents, down from 74.39 cents on Thursday, its highest level in more than six years.

title: Sosa Receives Eight-Game Suspension
description: Sammy Sosa received an eight-game suspension from Major League Baseball yesterday for using a corked bat in a game on Tuesday. He quickly appealed the decision in hopes of reducing the punishment, a process that also allows him to keep playing for the Chicago Cubs.

title: New increases expected as vacations begins : Still paying a high price for a 'roaming' cell phone
description: PARIS:  Ted Matheny, a lawyer based in Paris, travels about one week a month for business, racking up mobile phone charges of about 400 a month.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose after a government report showed United States payrolls fell less than economists expected last month. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1704, down from $1.1843 on Thursday.

title: Striking It Poor: Oil as a Curse
description: The pipes are already laid in southern Chad, where they snake south underground through tropical forests from the oil fields of Doba to a marine terminal off the coast of neighboring Cameroon. At the port of Kribi, the 660-mile pipeline will empty up to 250,000 barrels a day of coveted crude into tankers waiting to transport the unctuous black gold to Western markets.

title: French Soldiers Arrive in Congo With a Tough Mission
description: Starting at daybreak, four planeloads of French soldiers touched down at the airport here today, the first of 1,400 troops dispatched by the United Nations Security Council to restore law and order to this provincial town, ruled by a series of ethnic militias since war erupted in Congo in 1998.

title: Chief of Tenet-Owned Hospital Is Indicted
description: A federal grand jury has indicted the chief executive of a California hospital owned by a subsidiary of the Tenet Corporation, the for-profit hospital chain that has recently drawn intense regulatory scrutiny.

title: Mets End Seattle Streak; Glavine May Skip Start
description: Ichiro Suzuki finished his round of batting practice, picked up his glove and trotted out to right field yesterday afternoon. Suzuki and the Seattle Mariners carried baseball's best record into last night's game, but they had never played the Mets, and Suzuki wanted to gauge the outfield conditions at Shea Stadium. As a coach positioned behind second base hit fly balls, Suzuki raced in or back, and even caught one behind his back.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Party Drops Support
description: A left-wing party allied with President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, left, has withdrawn from his governing coalition, complaining that ''he is not keeping his pledge to the people'' of change and that he had failed ''to do away with the neo-liberal economic policies he inherited from the previous government.'' Leonel Brizola, the leader of the Democratic Labor Party, also invited leftist dissidents from the president's own party to join his rebellious bloc, but that loss of support has already been compensated for by the decision of two larger parties on the center and the right to enter Mr. da Silva's coalition. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; Downloading Music Over the Internet Without Feeling Like a Criminal
description: Hardly a week goes by without another salvo in the music wars, which have been going on now for years. And week by week the shape of the struggle seems to change.

title: Beliefs; The Ten Commandments can be seen as a covenant with God and as rules for life.
description: Religious and court calendars converged this week. Jews prepared for yesterday's holiday of Shavuot, recalling God's gift of the Ten Commandments at Mount Sinai. In Alabama, a federal appeals court heard arguments about the constitutionality of a monument bearing those same commandments in Alabama's judicial building.

title: Quiet Series By Kariya Deafening For Ducks
description: Paul Kariya's statistics look like binary code: 0-1. In hockey terms, the numbers mean no goals and one assist in the Stanley Cup finals, and they do not compute well for Kariya's role as the captain and star left wing of the Anaheim Mighty Ducks.

title: Constitutional Crises
description: Sept. 11 exposed a weakness in our constitutional system that our framers could not have foreseen. If United Flight 93 had reached its likely target, the Capitol, instead of crashing in Pennsylvania, hundreds of members of Congress might have been killed. Congress would have been unable to function just at the time we need it most. We were fortunate to have been spared this additional disaster. But we should act to fill our constitutional gap. Continuity in Congress must be protected.

title: Tyco Investors Sue Merrill Over Research
description: Investors in Tyco International Ltd. sued Merrill Lynch yesterday, contending they were misled by biased research from an analyst, the investors said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: A Trash (And Maybe Sewage) Bin
description: Toronto already sends all of its trash to Michigan. Now it wants to send its sewage as well. Toronto officials and Republic Services, a waste company that operates a landfill just south of Detroit, have struck a deal, pending a vote this month by Toronto's council. Many Michigan residents and politicians are already upset that the state began taking all of Toronto's trash at the beginning of the year -- 180 truckloads a day -- and a petition campaign begun by Senator Debbie Stabenow, a Democrat, garnered more than 38,000 signatures in five days. Free trade laws, though, make it hard to do much to stop the southward migration of waste. Under the plan, Toronto would send 56,000 to 76,000 tons of sewage to the landfill in the next four years. Caitlin Nish (NYT)

title: The Real Leo Strauss
description: Recent news articles have portrayed my father, Leo Strauss, as the mastermind behind the neoconservative ideologues who control United States foreign policy. He reaches out from his 30-year-old grave, we are told, to direct a ''cabal'' (a word with distinct anti-Semitic overtones) of Bush administration figures hoping to subject the American people to rule by a ruthless elite. I do not recognize the Leo Strauss presented in these articles.

title: A Scandal's Toll: The Shake-Up at The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Wal-Mart Plans To Shield Covers Of 4 Magazines Aimed at Women
description: Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that it would partly obscure the covers of four women's magazines sold in its checkout aisles. The decision appears to be an effort to sell as many copies as possible while addressing concerns expressed by some customers about racy cover lines on some of the magazines.

title: Unemployment Rate Rises To a 9-Year High of 6.1%
description: The unemployment rate rose to 6.1 percent in May, its highest level in nine years, the Labor Department reported today, as the worst jobs slump since the early 1980's continued to spread across the economy.

title: A Scandal's Toll: The Shake-Up at The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Harmonic Convergence at Carnegie Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MERRILL LYNCH & CO., New York, said it would sell its telephone brokerage business in Japan to UFJ Tsubasa Securities Co., , for $11 million in stock.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: LIECHTENSTEIN: DEMOCRACY OR MONARCHY? Two members of the Council of Europe will visit Liechtenstein in July to investigate whether the tiny principality can still be considered a democracy, the government in Vaduz announced today. Two-thirds of the people of Liechtenstein voted in March to make changes to the Constitution to give their ruling prince, Hans-Adam II, more power. Opponents contend that the changes now mean the Alpine country is a monarchy and no longer eligible for membership in the Council of Europe. The parliamentarians, Michael Hancock of Great Britain and Erik Jurgens of The Netherlands, will end their two-day visit on July 4. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEMING, , CHARLES E.
description: HEMING--Charles E. Died on June 6, 2003 at home in Scarsdale, NY of heart failure. Beloved husband and best friend of Barbara (nee Krueger). Father of Michael C. Heming of Larchmont, NY, Lucy Hutchinson of Alexandria, VA, and Amanda Minsky of Santa Barbara, CA: his children from his first marriage to Olga Landeck Rothschild. Grandfather of Amanda and Sam Hutchinson, Julia Heming, Nina, Henry and Anna Minsky. Brother of Delia Cantor, Harriet Simpson, and the late Joan Frank. Born in NYC March 1, 1926, graduated Phillips Academy, Andover, MA 1944, Princeton University, 1948, and Columbia University School of Law, 1950. Served in the U.S. Naval Reserve 1944-46. Partner at Wormser Kiely Galef & Jacobs in NY since 1982. Past president of the New York State Bar Association (1986-1987), past president of the New York State Bar Foundation, member of the American College of Trust and Estate Counsel, member of the Association of The Bar of The City of New York (past chairman of the Committee on Lectures and Continuing Education, and Committee on Trusts, Estates and Surrogates Courts). Trustee of the Village of Scarsdale (1972-1976) and chairman of the Town Club. Past president of the Amateur Ski Club of New York. The family will receive at home on Sunday, June 8th at 5pm. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Ramapo Anchorage Camp, P.O. Box 266, Rhinebeck, NY 12572. >>AD#

title: Owner of London Complex Says It May Have Bidders
description: Potential bidders are circling the Canary Wharf Group, the holding company for the huge office and retail complex that over the last two decades transformed a derelict stretch of East End docks into a new financial center.

title: IMCLONE CUTS ESTIMATE ON TAX LIABILITIES BY $19 MILLION
description: ImClone Systems Inc. reduced estimates for withholding tax liabilities by nearly $19 million, to about $41.2 million yesterday. It previously said the liabilities, related to the failure of its former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, to pay state and federal taxes, would be as much as $60 million on its Dec. 31 balance sheet. ImClone, which is based in New York, also said yesterday that earnings would be reduced by $30.3 million, which is more than its March estimate of $23.3 million. The estimates exclude potential penalties and interest rates that may be imposed, the company said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jobless Rate Rises to 6.1%, Reaching a Nine-Year High

title: Justice Dept. Draws Heavy Criticism Over Cancellation of Gay Rights Event
description: Democrats and civil rights advocates condemned the Justice Department today for barring a gay pride event planned by department employees, and called on Attorney General John Ashcroft to reverse the decision.

title: Hung Jury in Trial Of Florida St. Player
description: The misdemeanor gambling trial of the former Florida State quarterback Adrian McPherson ended yesterday in a hung jury.

title: In Georgia, a Taste of Poor Housing Around the World
description: Under a sapping Georgia sun, Tammia Bartlett, a volunteer tour guide in a turquoise polo shirt, led a small group of visitors today toward a mass of dilapidated shacks made of rusty tin and scrap wood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, , ESTELLE FELD
description: MARCUS--Estelle Feld. Died at her home in Mt. Vernon, NY, on June 6th. Devoted wife of the late Frank P. Marcus. Loving mother of their three children: Ivan G. Marcus, of New Rochelle, NY; Marris J.M. Kramer, of Manchester Centre, VT; and Leonard S. Marcus, of Brooklyn, NY. She is also survived by five grandchildren and three great - grandchildren. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon on Sunday, June 8, at 9:00 AM. >>AD#

title: A Scandal's Toll: The Shake-Up at The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Given Second Try, Nets Solve Duncan
description: Byron Scott earned his first N.B.A. finals victory as a coach tonight.

title: Plan to move troops south of Seoul aims at more mobility : U.S. broadens Pacific focus
description: UIJONGBU, South Korea:  U.S. forces will consolidate at major bases in a two-phase plan that calls for them to withdraw south of Seoul and well beyond North Korean artillery range, according to the Pentagon and South Korea's Defense Ministry.

title: MCDONALD'S U.S. SALES ROSE 6.3% IN MAY
description: The McDonald's Corporation, the world's largest hamburger chain, said sales in the United States rose 6.3 percent in May, the most in one month in four years, driven by demand for Happy Meals and new items like salads with Newman's Own dressings. Sales at restaurants open at least 13 months increased for the second consecutive month after declining for more than a year. Such same-store sales fell 1 percent in Europe, compared with a 6.4 percent increase in May 2002. Sales in the Asia, Pacific, Middle East and Africa regions declined 6.1 percent. Same-store sales exclude results from new and closed restaurants. Total sales rose 12 percent in May, to $3.9 billion, McDonald's said. Global same-store sales increased 2.2 percent, in contrast to a 1.4 percent decline in May 2002. The company began using dressings by the actor Paul Newman, added fruit and yogurt to children's Happy Meals and simplified the cooking procedures to speed service. Stock in McDonald's, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., rose $1.78, or 9.2 percent, to $21.06 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Pataki Needs New Blood
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Deal Is Reached On Khmer Rouge Trials
description: After six years of difficult negotiations, officials of the United Nations and the Cambodian government signed an agreement setting out a format for trials of surviving top leaders of the Khmer Rouge, the brutal regime responsible for the deaths of 1.7 million people from 1975 to 1979. The agreement must still be ratified by the United Nations and the Cambodian Legislature and is likely to face many hurdles before any trials are actually convened. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Desegregation Plan Upheld

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Saturday about Janet Collins, a former prima ballerina of the Metropolitan Opera House, misstated the precedent for black artists there. Louis Armstrong, Billie Holiday and several other performers at a jazz concert in 1944 were the first; Ms. Collins first appeared in 1951.

title: Organization Investigated On Charities
description: Attorney General Bill Lockyear of California has opened a formal investigation into the collapse of PipeVine Inc., a nonprofit organization that managed employee charitable giving programs for companies and United Way organizations.

title: Corrections
description: Aheadline on Wednesday about a study that found widespread discrimination against SARS victims misstated the area studied. It was Hong Kong, not all of China.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday showing monthly advertising sales at Martha Stewart Living omitted a label. The figures, the latest available, were through April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARTH, , LOUISE
description: BARTH--Louise. Died on June 6, 2003. Loving wife of Ben. Mother of Bob, Betsy, Rich and Bruce. Grandmother of Tyler, Marissa, Jessica, Emily and Alex. Mother-inlaw of Suzie and Joseph. Sister of Marvin. Her family will always miss her. Funeral services Sunday, June 8, 11:30AM, at Zion Memorial Funeral Home, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, N.Y. 914-381-1809. >>AD#

title: A Stranded Dolphin Is Pulled From the Surf on Long Island
description: An ailing dolphin found beached on the shore of Little Neck Bay was taken to a Long Island animal rehabilitation center last night.

title: New Tools for Arms Control
description: As if the idea of a nuclear-armed North Korea were not alarming enough, consider the prospect of Kim Jong Il's exporting surplus plutonium and long-range missile components to other rogue states and terrorists. It is easy to see why world leaders at the recent Group of 8 summit meeting in France declared the spread of such unconventional weapons to be, along with international terrorism, ''the pre-eminent threat to international security.''

title: Lois Rosenfield, 78, Theatrical Producer
description: Lois Fried Rosenfield, a theatrical and film producer with her husband, Maurice, died on May 25 at her home in Glencoe, Ill. She was 78.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Coal Takeover Approved
description: The world's fourth-biggest coal exporter, Xstrata, won approval yesterday from shareholders of M.I.M. Holdings for a takeover that was valued at 3.44 billion Australian dollars ($2.3 billion). Xstrata will increase coal sales by half and cut dependence on South African mines as a result of the deal. Xstrata received the backing of 59 percent of shareholders at a meeting in Brisbane, Australia, where M.I.M. is based. It needed 50 percent. The proposed takeover was opposed by M.I.M.'s managing director, Vince Gauci, and Platinum Asset Management, which owns more than 50 million M.I.M. shares. Xtrata is based in Zug, Switzerland.

title: Wells's Effort Has Old-Time Feel to It
description: The Yankees had not played at Wrigley Field for 65 years, and their ghosts were everywhere. Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio and Bill Dickey helped win the World Series here. Babe Ruth called his shot here -- or did he? Even the modern Yankees were caught up in it.

title: Medicare Aide Voices Doubts On Adding Drug Benefits
description: The top Medicare official said today that the Bush administration had ''significant disagreements'' with a bipartisan Senate proposal to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare, and he reaffirmed President Bush's desire to encourage elderly people to join private health plans by offering them extra drug benefits.

title: 2 Men Indicted In Conspiracy That Involved Hired Killings
description: Prosecutors say the two men were known as Hitman Manny and the Getaway, and that they carried out four murders-for-hire in the early 1990's in Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Clemens Won't Let Cough Stop Him
description: Roger Clemens sounded congested this morning, and he has been fighting a cough and head cold for several days. ''I'm not even going to talk about that,'' he snapped, sitting in the dugout at Wrigley Field. ''I've pitched in worse shape than this, believe me.''

title: Grief Takes to the Street for Funeral of Immigrant Slain by Officer
description: The box was made of unfinished compressed wood, with exposed nail heads.

title: CHUBB SAYS RULING TO REDUCE 2ND-QUARTER NET INCOME
description: The Chubb Corporation said that losing an arbitration decision related to a 1995 fire claim will lower second-quarter profit by $17 million, or 10 cents a share. Chubb, a property and casualty insurer, also predicted that storms in April and May would cost it $49 million, or 28 cents a share, after tax. The losses would be higher than the $7 million in losses that it reported in the second quarter of last year. Chubb, based in Warren, N.J., reaffirmed its earnings forecast of $4.60 to $5 a share for 2003.

title: Oracle Takes $5 Billion Jab at PeopleSoft
description: Oracle, the huge business-software maker led by Lawrence J. Ellison, made a $5.1 billion hostile takeover offer yesterday for PeopleSoft in a conspicuous effort to extinguish one of its biggest rivals.

title: Airlines' Unwanted Fleet Grows in the Desert
description: No better barometer of the fortunes of the airline industry exists than 1,200 acres of parched brown earth here, baking at 102 degrees.

title: Harmonic Convergence at Carnegie Hall (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Raids On Insurgents
description: Colombia's security forces struck against both left-wing rebels and right-wing paramilitaries, arresting 34 rebels in a sweep of a northern town and killing 12 right-wing paramilitary fighters in a clash east of the capital, Bogot. The rebels, members of Colombia's two Marxist groups, were captured by hundreds of police officers who swooped into a small village in Guajira Province. Meanwhile, in an army offensive near Puerto Gaitn, a town east of Bogot, troops killed 12 members of a paramilitary force. The paramilitaries normally fight the guerrillas with help from rogue army units, but President lvaro Uribe has vowed to fight the paramilitaries as aggressively as the rebels. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil prices rose as Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico met to discuss a cut in production. In New York, crude oil for July delivery rose 54 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $31.28 a barrel.

title: Historic West Village Building Is Evacuated
description: About 20 residents of a landmark apartment building in the West Village were evacuated last night after it was discovered that part of its foundation wall had collapsed. The building, at 16 Charles Street near Waverly Place, is the former home of the poet Elizabeth Bishop.

title: Rounds of Lies
description: Revelations that the Americans apparently used the threat of Iraqi weapons of mass destruction as a pretext for war have outraged the global public. But the opponents of war in Berlin and Paris have remained silent in hopes of renewing the dialogue with Washington.

title: Six Horses, One Favorite and Two Views on Belmont Outcome
description: I'm having a very hard time figuring out the outcome of today's Belmont Stakes. Will Empire Maker win by 4, 6, 10, a dozen lengths, maybe more? Decisions, oh, the decisions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWINGER, , MELVIN
description: SCHWINGER -- Melvin. Of Emerson, N.J. Formerly of Westbury, N.Y. On Friday, June 6 at the age of 74. Beloved husband of the late Thelma. Loving father of Valerie, Seth, Susan and Glenn. Devoted brother of Aaron and Lorelei. Special grandfather of Tara, the ''light of his life '' and a friend to many. A Certified Public Accounant for over 40 years, Mel's true testimony to his clients was his caring nature and professional ability. He was always in their thoughts throughout his long illness. Services at Gutterman's, Park Avenue, Hackensack NJ 201 - 489 - 3800, Sunday, 10:30AM. Interment at Wellwood Cemetery, Pine Lawn, Long Island. Shiva at home of Seth and Susan Schwinger, 7 Hickory Lane, Closter, N.J. Sunday through Tuesday. >>AD#

title: READ-RITE SHARES TUMBLE ON REPORT OF CASH SHORTAGE
description: Shares of the Read-Rite Corporation, a maker of computer disk-drive parts, fell 39 percent after the company said a lack of cash to buy materials would cause a drop in sales and a wider fiscal third-quarter loss than had been expected. The company, based in Fremont, Calif., did not say how much wider the loss would be. The cash shortage is forcing it to extend a three-week employee furlough by another week while it tries to raise money, the company said. It did not say how many employees were laid off or how much of a loss it expected. Read-Rite's cash declined by 97 percent, to $4.2 million, as of March 30 from $126.7 million at the end of 2001, according to its regulatory filings. The company's stock fell 49 cents, to 76 cents a share, on the Nasdaq.

title: Delay Seen in U.S.-Philippine Joint Mission
description: In a setback to the campaign against terrorism in the Philippines, the commander of American forces in the Pacific said today that a joint mission with Philippine troops to combat Muslim rebels will likely be postponed for six months.

title: A Scandal's Toll: The Shake-Up at The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCELROY, , DAVID BROWN
description: McELROY -- David Brown formerly of Brookville, NY and St. Louis, MO died peacefully on May 12, 2003 in Hobe Sound, FL. He was 95 years old. He was married for 49 years to the late Marjorie LeBoutillier Iglehart of Old Westbury, New York. Mr. McElroy was born March 17th 1908 in St. Louis, MO son of the late Warren F. McElroy and Estella Brown McElroy. He was educated at the St. Louis Country Day School and Princeton University where he was a member of the Cottage Club and where he lettered on the squash team. After graduating from college in the spring of 1930, he began a distinguished career in banking and investment banking that ultimately led to prominent positions of Senior Vice-President and Treasurer at the J.P. Morgan Company and Senior Partner and Treasurer at Clark, Dodge and Company. He served in World War II as a special representative in Monrovia, Liberia for Pan American World Airways. He will always be remembered for his kindness, keen intellect and sharp wit. He is survived by his son, John, loving daughter - in - law, Christine and three grandchildren, Fielding, Dane and Stefan all of Hinsdale, Illinois. A memorial service will be held November 21st, 2003 at the Christ Memorial Chapel, Hobe Sound, Florida. Contributions may be made in his memory to Hospice of Martin & St. Lucie, Inc., 1201 S.E. Indian St., Stuart, FL 34997. >>AD#

title: Ferrero Back in Final; Unseeded Verkerk Makes It on First Try
description: It was a day when logic was respected at Roland Garros: Albert Costa finally ran out of tricks and energy, losing the first two sets against the pretournament favorite, Juan Carlos Ferrero, then losing the third one, too.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Retail Sales Fall
description: Retail sales in Hong Kong fell 15.2 percent in April from April 2002, the biggest decline in four years, partly as a result of the SARS outbreak, the government said. The decline, to 12.7 billion Hong Kong dollars ($1.6 billion), came after a revised decline of 6.1 percent in March. The outbreak of SARS, which has caused more than 280 deaths in Hong Kong, affected tourism as well as domestic spending as travelers avoided the island and stayed home.

description: The United States Air Force Academy announced fundamental changes today in the way it will respond to sexual assaults, instituting a policy in which a complaint will automatically prompt a formal criminal investigation but victims will no longer have the option of remaining anonymous.

description: If Visa USA does not give away $5 million at the Belmont Stakes today, its executives could be forgiven if they stopped trying.

description: AS Quebec's most distinguished movie director and screenwriter, Denys Arcand has etched a jagged path through life along much the same curve as his province's over its last four tumultuous decades.

description: As New Jersey authorities continued to investigate the death of a 21-month-old boy whose parents had already been found to have abused their children, social work experts said yesterday that the case highlighted the difficulty of determining when it is safe to return children to a family with a record of child abuse.

description: In case you missed it -- and most New Yorkers did -- the first round of hearings called by the charter revision commission is over. The now-annual charter revision exercise is becoming as routine as a change of hair color for Cher. Nevertheless, this year the end product could create an upheaval in city politics.

title: Court Backs Town's Policy Desegregating Its Schools
description: In a closely watched case on the use of race in assigning children to public schools, a federal district judge in Boston yesterday upheld the constitutionality of a school desegregation policy that racially mixed Lynn, Mass., voluntarily adopted 15 years ago.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Protecting Mahogany
description: The government has issued strict new rules to further inhibit the export of mahogany from the Amazon, requiring loggers to file a ''sustainable development'' plan before they can cut down trees. The action came just days after the United States refused to allow the entry of nine shipments of the rare and expensive tropical hardwood, contending that the lumber, which had been held for 15 months pending a judge's ruling, was harvested in Brazil, the source of half the world's mahogany, in violation of international treaties. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on May 30, about differences between Europe and the United States over the war in Iraq, mischaracterized the Dutch position on the war. While the Dutch prime minister, Jan Peter Balkenende, did not sign the ''letter of eight'' European leaders expressing support for the United States, he later said he backed American action against Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 14 about a New York State Court of Appeals decision giving co-op boards more power in removing an apartment owner referred imprecisely to the background of David Pullman, the owner in the case. He received an undergraduate degree at the University of Pennsylvania in 1983 and says he took graduate classes at the Wharton School of Business there; he did not complete a graduate degree there.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Treaty With Jewish Group
description: The German Parliament unanimously ratified a government treaty with the country's leading Jewish organization, the Central Council of Jews, putting their relations on a formal legal footing and giving the organization the same legal status as the predominant churches. The accord had been signed by the government and German Jewish leaders in January. Speakers from all sides hailed the treaty as another step toward normality after the Holocaust. Germany will provide about $3.55 million annually to the Jewish community, which now numbers around 100,000 people, to help train rabbis and teach Jewish rites. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Belmont Is Bracing For a Rainy Day
description: With the forecast calling for a 70 percent chance of showers on Long Island beginning today from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m., Funny Cide's quest for a Triple Crown may come over a sloppy or muddy racetrack at Belmont Park.

title: The Wait for Mutombo Is Worth It for the Nets
description: About a month ago, Dikembe Mutombo began watching the San Antonio Spurs' playoff games religiously. He knew the Nets were surging, even as he rode the bench, and he sensed that it was San Antonio's year in the West. With his gaze set firmly on Tim Duncan, the league's most valuable player, Mutombo studied his footwork, his moves on the block, his tendencies on the perimeter and how the opposition defended him.

description: Gambling revenue in Nevada fell 6.9 percent in April from a year earlier, the state's Gaming Control Board said yesterday.

description: Americans think of Tony Blair, their steadfast wartime ally, as a prime minister guided by his convictions. Yet on the decision he describes as Britain's most momentous in a generation -- whether to adopt Europe's single currency -- Mr. Blair has acted like an equivocating suitor who consults an abacus before deciding on marriage.

title: Syria's Shades of Gray
description: The United States has probably never been more engaged in the Middle East than now, with an American army of occupation in Iraq and President Bush promoting a Israeli-Palestinian road map to peace. Yet the Bush administration has virtually ignored Syria, which physically links Iraq and Israel, except to single it out as a target of occasional bellicose threats. There has been no question of constructive engagement with Iraq's most powerful Arab neighbor. Instead Syria is seen merely as an unofficial adjunct to the Axis of Evil, ripe for reform if not outright invasion.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Rises
description: Confirming recent signs of weakness in the Canadian economy, Statistics Canada reported that unemployment climbed to 7.8 percent in May, from 7.5 percent in April and well above analysts' expectations. The soft employment data contributed to a sharp decline in the Canadian dollar, which traded at 73.69 United States cents, down from 74.39 cents on Thursday, its highest level in more than six years. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Abuzz Over Carnegie, Philharmonic Shines
description: Before Thursday night's concert by the New York Philharmonic, the first new program offered since the stunning announcement this week that the orchestra will be moving to Carnegie Hall, you could see people huddled together talking about the news and its implications. Some even seemed to be glancing wistfully around Avery Fisher Hall.

title: UNILEVER NAMES PRESIDENT FOR COSMETICS DIVISION
description: Unilever said yesterday that it had named Kevin Boyce to be president and chief executive of Unilever Cosmetics International, the maker of fragrances like Lagerfeld and Calvin Klein. Mr. Boyce succeeds Paulanne Mancuso, who resigned at the end of April. Mr. Boyce, 47, joined Unilever in 1986, and he is currently president and chief executive of Unilever Canada in Toronto.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Dna Evidence Wins A Man His Freedom
description: A Chicago man, Dana Holland, 35, who served 10 years in prison for rape but was exonerated in January because of DNA evidence has been released. Judge James Linn of Cook County cleared his record of charges of attempted murder, armed robbery, aggravated kidnapping and aggravated battery in a related case. He was sentenced in 1993 to 90 years in prison for the rape of a woman who was eight months pregnant, but DNA evidence proved that he could not have been the assailant. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Trading Revenue Up Sharply at Banks
description: Commercial banks' revenue from trading securities and derivatives rose 64 percent in the first quarter as investors bought more contracts to hedge risks from a pending war in Iraq, a government agency said yesterday.

description: More than 13,000 of the Arab and Muslim men who came forward earlier this year to register with immigration authorities -- roughly 16 percent of the total -- may now face deportation, government officials say.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Senate approval of a plan that would change the way refiners blend gasoline misidentified an additive made from corn, and the headline misstated an objective of the plan. The additive is ethanol, not methanol. The plan would double its use, to at least five billion gallons a year; it would not double the amount of ethanol in gasoline.

description: Government officials said yesterday that they had decided to expand the number of Medicare patients who qualify to receive an expensive medical device that is implanted in the chest to help protect against fatal heart rhythms.
