description: Five members of the Big East Conference with Division I-A football programs have filed a lawsuit against Boston College, the University of Miami and the Atlantic Coast Conference, seeking monetary damages and an injunction preventing the two colleges from joining the A.C.C.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Liechtenstein: Democracy Or Monarchy?
description: Two members of the Council of Europe will visit Liechtenstein in July to investigate whether the tiny principality can still be considered a democracy, the government in Vaduz announced today. Two-thirds of the people of Liechtenstein voted in March to make changes to the Constitution to give their ruling prince, Hans-Adam II, more power. Opponents contend that the changes now mean the Alpine country is a monarchy and no longer eligible for membership in the Council of Europe. The parliamentarians, Michael Hancock of Great Britain and Erik Jurgens of The Netherlands, will end their two-day visit on July 4. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Let Cameras in the Courtroom
description: A state court judge in Manhattan heard arguments this week in a lawsuit by Court TV seeking to allow cameras into New York courtrooms. The suit challenges a state law making it a crime to televise court proceedings under virtually any circumstances. The United States Constitution requires that criminal and civil trials be open to the public. In the modern world, television cameras make it possible for the public to observe the justice system. New York's law should be struck down.

title: Working Mothers Swaying Senate Debate, as Senators
description: Like working mothers everywhere, Blanche Lincoln spent her spring vacation tending to all the little things that fall by the wayside when she is busy on the job.

title: Plans by Iran For a Reactor Pose Concerns About Arms
description: A new report from the International Atomic Energy Agency reveals that Iran is planning or building previously unacknowledged nuclear facilities -- including a heavy water research reactor -- that could give it a variety of technological options for the production of nuclear weapons.

title: Former Mayor Faces 10 Years in Prison
description: Former Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport, Conn., could be sentenced to as many as 10 years in prison and fined $150,000 if a federal judge agrees with a recommendation government prosecutors filed yesterday in New Haven.

title: Freshman Wins 3,000-meter run
description: Nicole Blood, a Saratoga Springs freshman, won the girls' 3,000-meter run last night at the New York State Outdoor Interscholastic Championships at Union-Endicott High School, near Binghamton.

title: Britain Keeps Its Distance From the Euro, at Least for the Time Being
description: When Britons finally decide whether or not to join the European single currency -- whenever that may be -- they will ultimately be making a political choice about where they belong: in Europe or someplace on its fringes.

On this chilly morning in February he was working on his set and costume designs for ''HereAfter,'' a highlight of American Ballet Theater's current season. His other projects for the spring included Woody Allen's new movie ''Anything Else'' and Mr. Allen's new play ''Writer's Block,'' and productions of ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' on Broadway and ''Love's Labour's Lost'' at Stratford, Ontario. There was also the Metropolitan Opera's ''Salome'' for next season.

title: June 1-7; Good Times For Abortion Foes

Republican control of Congress and the White House gives them an opening to enact new limits on abortion. And by the time the inevitable legal challenges to these laws reach the Supreme Court, they believe, new, more sympathetic faces will be on the bench.

title: Investing; Whole Foods' Run May Slow
description: WHEN G. Peter Wilson travels, he carries part of his local Whole Foods Market with him. Tucked in his suitcase beside his shirts and socks are plastic bags of oatmeal, muesli and dried fruit. Back home in Carlisle, Mass., he stops at Whole Foods, the natural-foods supermarket, twice a week as he commutes to his job as an accounting professor at Boston College.

The only difference is that he finally admits that the real problem is people, not the erosion. The ocean is no respecter of buildings and it is these that Mr. Stoddard wants protected to the tune of millions of dollars of taxpayers' hard-earned money.

description: SOME political careers in Trenton ended on Tuesday, and some will crash in November. But one casualty that will cause no mourning is the odd marriage of John O. Bennett and Richard J. Codey.

title: See Them Now
description: In the early 19th century, you could not have gone far in New Jersey without seeing a bobcat. For the century before that, whales were so prevalent along the Atlantic and Delaware Bay coasts of the state that people searched for businesses that could use parts of the numerous whales being caught. By the 20th century, though, things changed. Overfishing killed off much of the whale supply, and the cutting down of forests forced bobcats to move away in search of new habitats. By the late 20th century, both species needed protection to survive here.

title: Katherine Yu, Robert Wone
description: Katherine Ellen Yu, the daughter of Jing Ja Yu and Myoung Joon Yu of Vernon Hills, Ill., was married yesterday to Robert Eric Wone, a son of Aimee Won and William Won of Brooklyn. Judge Raymond A. Jackson of the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, for whom the bridegroom was a law clerk, officiated at the Wyndham Northwest Chicago Hotel in Itasca, Ill.

title: Who Pays?
description: My 1-year-old son and I were shopping in a bookstore that also sells coffee. In order to take my son's jacket off, I began to set my coffee down on a display, at which point he struggled, knocked my cup out of my hands and spilled coffee over several books. Should I pay for the damages, or did the store assume that risk by combining food for the body and mind? Randall Terrell, Austin, Tex.

Hurlock of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Louis de Romanet de Beaune, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony in the Chapel of Santa Croce in Sasso, Italy.

title: Suddenly Popular
description: Mark McDonough has a boyish face, outsize eyebrows that dance like dragonfly wings when he speaks and an awful lot of money. He makes a point of not revealing how much -- not to me at least, or to you. But he has more than he will ever need. Because he did not earn the money himself, however, he has a rather complicated relationship with it. He sometimes calls the money ''the monster that jumped into my bed.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOEMAN, , LINDA H.

description: The first thing Jose Santos thought when he woke up yesterday at his Long Island hotel was, ''I'm going to go win the Triple Crown,'' he said.

title: Migrations
description: MY INVENTED COUNTRY

title: A Gay Bar Run by a Straight Family
description: THE men Thomas Magliochetti spent years with fixing wires in underground passageways knew he was blunt and self-willed, but when they heard what he wanted to do with his life savings, they assumed he had taken leave of his senses. On an unpopulated strip of Route 22 in Brewster, Mr. Magliochetti, with help from his ex-wife, girlfriend and daughters, was going to open a gay bar.

title: Adding Health Precautions To the Travel Checklist
description: A RECENT cartoon in The New Yorker showed an older couple sitting in their living room, the man engrossed in a newspaper. The woman says to him, ''Let's update our will and go on vacation.''

title: Stadium Is No Fit Place for a Field Day, Music Fans Say
description: It is an 81-mile drive from Calverton, on Long Island, to East Rutherford; 70 miles as the crow flies. Manhattan traffic lengthens the trip between these dissimilar points, one marked by acres of open farmland and the other by highway interchanges and sports complexes.

title: The Electronic Trail Marker
description: Hikers, bikers and other trail users, among the biggest potential beneficiaries of the Web, can now download pages of trip-specific information that in the past they would have had to seek out in one of the countless regional trekking guides straining the local bookstore's shelves. But they can save more than a few pounds worth of wood pulp and a few miles on their odometer by logging on. To hear one account, the Web has the potential to save outdoorsy types from mortal danger -- as in flying bullets.

title: At Last: Miles Live at the Blackhawk
description: BJORK -- There's a new version of ''Volumen,'' her DVD collection of videos, put out on her own label, One Little Indian. Titled ''Greatest Hits: Volumen 1993-2003,'' it contains six new videos since its last edition in 1998, and it compounds the sense of how deep this curious biped really is: easy sex and the celebration of success (basic tropes in pop videos) are nowhere to be found here -- though she seems to be obsessed with the body, in an analytical way, and these films (by Spike Jonze, Michel Gondry, the design group M/M and others) weren't made on the cheap. They are extraordinary: full of fable-like suggestions that machines are alive or that forest groves contain books which write themselves.

title: Shikha Anand, Vijay Nayak
description: Dr. Shikha Gaind Anand, the daughter of Kamal and Brij Anand of Franklin Lakes, N.J., was married on Friday to Dr. Vijay Kumbla Nayak, the son of Anuradha and Suresh Nayak of Houston. Pandit Ram Chander Bhatter, a Hindu priest, officiated at the the Wadsworth Mansion in Middletown, Conn.

title: Barenboim's Marathon: A 32-Sonata Test
description: BEETHOVEN may be the classic example of a young creative genius who at once embraced and transformed tradition. This stance comes through stunningly in his early piano sonatas, especially the first 8 of the monumental 32.

title: 'Gentleman Revolutionary'
description: Abiographer can feel a moment's hesitation when it comes to introducing his subject, for every traditional means has its drawbacks. If the hero appears in medias res , in the midst of some great action, the reader may feel manipulated, even coerced: his attention is being claimed before it has been earned. If the story of a life begins where the life does, in a cradle, then the reader might experience a sense of delay: he wished to read about great men, not infants. For the biographer of Gouverneur Morris, it is perhaps best to let him be introduced by a woman.

title: Corrections
description: The L.I.@Work column on May 4, about a proxy battle for control of Farmingdale-based Misonix Corporation, misstated the amount of Misonix stock purchased by Chapman Capital, a California hedge fund. It was 6.4 percent of outstanding shares, worth about $528,000, not 6.5 percent and about $1 million. The column also misstated the purchase date. It was April 2, not April 1.

title: Exchange-Traded Funds Are Now in Favor
description: Exchange-traded funds have taken over much of the market in international investing formerly controlled by closed-end funds, according to a new study.

A dancer, she taught dance to generations of students in New York's public schools and settlement houses. Great-great-aunt to Isaac Foster Friedman. >>AD#

title: CRIME
description: Peter Lovesey loves strong women, cerebral killers and diabolical puzzles -- the very ingredients that make THE HOUSE SITTER (Soho, $24) one of the most cunning mysteries in his Inspector Diamond series. The story opens with a strategic stroke of misdirection, when a woman in a white bikini is strangled while sunbathing on a crowded public beach on the Sussex coast. The ingenious plot delivers its first twist when the bathing beauty turns out to be a criminal profiler working on the case of a serial killer who dispatches his victims with a crossbow and dispenses clues from Coleridge's ''Rime of the Ancient Mariner.'' Being ''the kind of murderer who plans his crime like an architect, every detail worked out, measured and costed,'' the Mariner is a fit adversary for Peter Diamond, although no more of a handful, it seems, than the spirited women who play key roles in this shape-shifting case. The tough-minded homicide detective is entranced by the murder victim, whose keen brain and lusty sexual appetites are revealed in her journals, and bowled over by Anna Walpurgis, the earthy rock star he must protect from the Mariner. Never a slave to gender politics, he also makes a buddy of Inspector Henrietta Mallin, a brisk, boisterous, cigar-smoking colleague who can match him in pigheadedness and teach him how to take a joke.

title: The Life and Death of Foundations
description: A bill pending in the House of Representatives would force the nation's foundations to pay out more money in grants every year, providing a bonanza for nonprofit organizations that depend on foundation support. Advocates of the change say they want foundations to make a greater contribution to national needs at a time when the economy is sputtering, wealthy individuals are reducing their charitable contributions and government resources are stretched. But some leading foundations are terrified that the seemingly innocuous bill would virtually ensure their demise by forcing them to spend down their endowments faster than they can make money through investments. The foundations may well be ''crying wolf,'' but Congress needs to explore the consequences carefully before making a potentially momentous change.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PICKERING, , MERCEDES (MECHY) ALFONSO
description: PICKERING--Mercedes (Mechy) Alfonso. On April 28, Mechy Pickering died suddenly in Buenos Aires, Argentina, while visiting her sister. Mechy, born in Cuba in 1916, moved to the U.S. in 1928 with her parents. A graduate of St. Joseph's deCluny, Madrid, Spain, and the Aikin School, St. Petersburg, FL. She arrived in New York in the late 1930s and pursued a successful career as a fashion model. Here she met her husband, Richard Pickering. Active in the New York social world, they wintered in Havana, Palm Beach and Miami, following their race horses. A supporter of animal causes, and especially fond of dogs, she always had at least one canine companion. Later in life, Mechy joined the Couture Department at Bergdorff Goodman, where she was a top sales person for 28 years, retiring in 2002. Predeceased by her husband Richard, her older sister, Rosa Maria, and her brother Antonio. Mechy is survived by her sister Blanca Schutt and nephew Edward Schutt, of Buenos Aires, and her niece Alicia Johnson of Virginia. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 19, at 5 PM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue. Friends are welcomed. >>AD#

title: 'Long for This World'
description: It was a big old pleasant high school gym, built in the twenties and not much disturbed by renovation. The iron rafters met at a shallow angle at the roofline, and the tall windows were made up of a dozen big panes, each reinforced with chicken wire, and the two ancient clocks sat on opposing brick walls, ratcheting their works forward with an audible whir, hiss, clunk. The gym smelled nostalgically of varnish, sweat, and paint, but it was not an obsolete or shabby place. An electronic scoreboard reading garfield - visitors - quarter - fouls - time out had been added on the east wall, and a recent grant from FareWatchers.com had supplied the courtside officials with a new Huston-Marke computerized scoring system, a sleek blue box that sat beneath the long scorers' table and extended its heavy gray cables to an outlet hidden under the bleachers. The purple Garfield bulldog, wearing its studded collar, snarled up from the court's center circle, and the backboards were regulation glass, and the nets were in good repair, and when the boys played here a riotous, explosive sort of crowd would gather, and the breakaway rims actually got some use, and once in a while - once a decade or so - someone would appear who was so obviously superior to the rest of the boys that his future would be discussed with the frank and half-informed calculation any phenomenon inspires. The boys' team often played in the state tournament and had won it six years ago, and its purple banners hung from the rafters, drifting sideways when the big purple entry doors were left open to the hall.

title: Money 2003
description: It's probably too late to invoke an updated version of that old Chinese curse: May you live in volatile times. We already do. But that's not to say that every one of us is riding the same wave, economically speaking -- or even that our own individual waves are all that big or dynamic. What we're in the midst of collectively is, to borrow a term economists use, idiosyncratic volatility. Which means that however the broader economy is moving -- maybe even up -- its component parts can be experiencing significant and wildly differing swings in fortune. As Harris Collingwood explains in ''The Sink-or-Swim Economy,'' the march toward ever-increasing efficiency at the macro level has meant spreading volatility around at the micro level. And that's what this issue is about: some individuals or groups cresting, others living in the trough. The newly rich in ''Suddenly Popular,'' by Stephen J. Dubner, have inherited their windfalls, putting them in the vanguard of the largest transfer of private wealth in history, while the states' governors and other local public officials in ''Drip, Drip, Drip,'' by Matt Bai, are inheriting only woe from Washington these days. To future generations, Peter G. Peterson argues, the Republican administration, in its tax-cutting zeal, is bequeathing debt, deficits and a legacy of abandoned fiscal stewardship. Elsewhere in these pages, Matthew Brzezinski, a contributing writer, recounts his own bankruptcy; Mitch Epstein, a photographer, offers pictures from the demise of Epstein Furniture, his family's business. A series of What They Were Thinking photographs presents both halves of pairs in which one is up, the other down. Home isn't the only place caught in the tidal pull of the American economy, obviously, and Peter Maass, in ''Meet the New Boss,'' introduces us to Dathar Khashab, who is (still) doing quite nicely as an engineer in Iraq's oil industry. But if there's one body that can always be counted on to thrive, it is that very set of people who explain why all these things happen to us: economists themselves. See ''Ivy Envy,'' by Mark Levine, for a look at how one university hopes to ride its economics department to the top.

title: Lacquer on Everything
description: Like the spare and prescribed movements of a Japanese tea ceremony, the stories in THE LAWS OF EVENING (Scribner, $21), Mary Yukari Waters's first collection, present a deceptively smooth and elegant surface. Underneath this unruffled exterior, however, the smallest nuances convey real depth of feeling. ''The Laws of Evening'' moves in a cohesive arc from ''Seed,'' in which the drumming made by a procession of Chinese prisoners announces the end of a housewife's cloistered prewar life, to ''Mirror Studies,'' which observes the popularity of nostalgic ''wartime'' cuisine among jaded city dwellers. In between, a series of Japanese men and women grow old in the wake of their generation's great calamity. Alone late in life, the narrator of the title story spends evenings wandering the grounds of a temple, her mind floating through a world gone pleasantly abstract: ''Having little left to lose, little left to desire, had lifted her onto a halcyon mountaintop from which she saw all the sufferings of mankind blending beautifully, like tiny trees, into the landscape below.'' In ''Aftermath,'' a war widow struggles to salvage her memories in a country that seems bent on forgetting as quickly as possible, while ''Rationing'' explores the demands strong emotions place on a father and son unaccustomed to such exercise: ''It reminded him of track days: anguish escalating unbearably in oxygen-deprived lungs, the blind rush down the homestretch on legs that were too slow.'' Measured, deliberate and often nearly plotless, these stories require a certain patience, and the delicacy of their construction is not always apparent until the second reading. But such effort is amply repaid. You come away from this collection wondering, like the scientists in ''Mirror Studies,'' ''Isn't life a resilient force . . . turning the worst of its disasters into something like this?'' Mary Park

title: The Back Page; Play Ball! (Just Don't Get Caught)
description: FOR as long as there has been sport, there has been cheating and few sports have developed as rich a history in chicanery and fraud as baseball. Some of these smudges on the game's reputation were made brazenly: the Chicago Black Sox scandal of 1919, for instance, or Pete Rose's gambling. Other cases have been decidedly less grand, as when rubber balls came bouncing out of a broken bat, or when a pitcher dropped an emery board on the mound. And of course, many tactics occupy that gray area of sport where aggression and dirty play, ingenuity and flat-out cheating blur. Sammy Sosa's corked bat falls squarely outside that gray area, but even his eight-game suspension, which was immediately appealed after being handed down on Friday, is not likely to provide an object lesson for other players. Cheating, after all, is steeped in tradition. Highlights from some of baseball's greatest moments in foul play follow. TOM ZELLER

title: Deficits and Dysfunction
description: I have belonged to the Republican Party all my life. As a Republican, I have served as a cabinet member (once), a presidential commission member (three times), an all-purpose political ombudsman (many times) and a relentless crusader whom some would call a crank (throughout). Among the bedrock principles that the Republican Party has stood for since its origins in the 1850's is the principle of fiscal stewardship -- the idea that government should invest in posterity and safeguard future generations from unsustainable liabilities. It is a priority that has always attracted me to the party. At various times in our history (especially after wars), Republican leaders have honored this principle by advocating and legislating painful budgetary retrenchment, including both spending cuts and tax hikes.

title: Ivy Envy
description: A street-level marquee on the mottled limestone facade of a onetime hat factory just east of Washington Square Park, in Greenwich Village, advertises the current attractions at the Bottom Line cabaret. Bohemian spirits have congregated at the nightclub since 1974, when the opening-night party drew Mick Jagger, Carly Simon and Janis Ian. In those days, a college kid might have been presumed to be more enthralled with folk rock than with finance. No longer. Now, several flights up, in a warren of cramped offices, the bottom line is disputed in ways that would spin the heads and glaze the eyes of aged hippies. There, in the halls of New York University's department of economics, a group of data-crunching devotees of things macro and micro have become leading characters in a drama of academic empire building -- and brand building -- that has captivated aficionados of the sporting world of higher-octane higher education. Last August, N.Y.U. served notice of its ''white-hot ambitions,'' in the words of Richard Foley, the school's dean of the faculty of arts and sciences, by announcing its Steinbrenner-like acquisition of eight new economists and its intention to pursue another dozen or 15 over the next few years. N.Y.U.'s higher-ups are betting on economics, the abstruse and insular discipline that Thomas Carlyle dubbed ''the dismal science,'' to set the tone for something the school's new president, John Sexton, a man temperamentally incapable of understatement, calls ''a new paradigm for the American university.''

And so we have arrived at Jimmy Kimmel's wide-eyed realization that virtually no whim, however inane, will find itself punished by the network suits. ''We did a lot of things that even we were surprised we were allowed to do,'' he marvels in the Trio documentary ''Uncensored Comedy.'' title: Midwood Takes New York City Softball Championship
description: Midwood High School Coach Artie Leitner thought this would be a rebuilding year because his softball team had lost five starters to graduation. Almost one month into the season, pitcher Dawn Duggan thought the Hornets would have difficulty advancing past the quarterfinals in the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs. Yesterday, they became New York City champions. Duggan, a junior who pitched every inning of every game this season, scattered six hits and the freshman Jo Marie Sinagria scored the games only run as sixth-seeded Midwood of Brooklyn defeated top-seeded Tottenville of Staten Island, 1-0, at St. Johns University to win its first city championship. At the beginning of the year, I thought that this team had a lot of potential, but I never expected anything like this, Leitner said. The Hornets (23-7) scored in the third inning. With runners on first and second and two outs, left fielder Lauren Kantouris hit a sharp single to right field off Tottenvilles Allison Castellucci. Sinagria, running from second, stopped at third, then saw that the ball had been misplayed in the outfield and headed home. The throw from the outfield was on line but late, and the Hornets had the lead. But they had to sweat out the final four innings as Tottenville (19-3) put runners in scoring position in three of them. With two outs in the seventh, Nicole Composto singled to right field and advanced to second on an error with two outs. But Duggan struck out pinch-hitter Joanna Pellicchia on three pitches to seal the victory.

As the chairman of the Internet job board known as Monster, Taylor has built a central hub for the world's job seekers and located it just down the hall from his large corner office. Actually, the hub is somewhat less grand than it sounds: a brightly lighted room, dense with the fug of electronic heat, lined with rows of Dell computer servers. These are the company's databanks. Monster currently has about 26.5 million rsums on file and lists about a million help-wanted ads from employers every month. ''Each of these servers can do 480 job searches a second,'' Taylor said as we paused in front of some blinking equipment on a recent afternoon. ''We get two million visitors per day and 30,000 new rsums. People come here quietly and stomp around looking for work. They're here right now.''

title: The Sink-or-Swim Economy
description: What is it with this economy, anyway? Going strictly by the numbers, the most recent recession has been mild in comparison to previous downturns. Since the economy peaked in March 2001, the major markers of economic health -- industrial output, personal income and wholesale and retail sales -- have all traced smaller declines than in the average post-World War II recession. That's why many economists, among them Jeffrey Frankel, a professor at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, are inclined to dismiss today's complaints about economic stress and anxiety. ''People got spoiled by the 90's boom,'' Frankel says. ''They forgot what recessions are like.''

title: Prospect Theory
description: From the infamous Dutch tulip hysteria of the 17th century to the Great Depression to the dot-com crash, wild bouts of speculation have occasionally inflated big fat financial bubbles that soaked investors when they burst. Daniel Kahneman, a professor at Princeton who was the first psychologist to win the Nobel in economics (which he was awarded last year for studies he conducted with Amos Tversky), has attributed market manias partly to investors' ''illusion of control.'' Kahneman recently explained the basic weirdness of the dot-com bomb to The Financial Times: ''A high percentage of investors knew it was a bubble and still invested because they thought they could get out in time.'' Why did so few heed the alarms? According to Kahneman's ''prospect theory,'' most of us find losses roughly twice as painful as we find gains pleasurable. This radical precept subverts much of ''utility theory,'' the longstanding economic doctrine that says we weigh gain and loss rationally. When combined with the reality that some market winners display the same recklessness as some victorious gamblers -- a phenomenon that Richard Thaler, an economist at the University of Chicago, calls ''the house-money effect'' -- the market is often revealed to be downright loony. Indeed, the findings of ''behavioral finance'' in recent years have increasingly challenged the fundamental rationality assumed by defenders of ''efficient markets,'' those who believe Eugene Fama's famous dictum that prices ''fully reflect available information.'' Fama, another economist from the University of Chicago, is saying that you can't get ahead of the market by building a clever model, because you can't predict the news that will affect prices. (As for the crazy players, Fama has contended that big-time rational arbitrageurs counterbalance them.) So, as stocks have shown some new life this spring, can you put your trust back in the market?

title: Was the Intelligence Cooked?
description: The latest vogue in Washington is the proposition that it really doesn't matter whether Saddam Hussein maintained an arsenal of unconventional weapons in recent years. American troops may not have uncovered any evidence of the weapons of mass destruction the Bush administration was warning about, the argument goes. But they have found plenty of proof that Iraq suffered under a brutal dictator who slaughtered thousands, perhaps tens or hundreds of thousands of his own people, and that is reason enough to justify the invasion. We disagree. We are as pleased as anyone to see Saddam Hussein removed from power, but the United States cannot now simply erase from the record the Bush administration's dire warnings about the Iraqi weapons threat. The good word of the United States is too central to America's leadership abroad -- and to President Bush's dubious doctrine of pre-emptive warfare -- to be treated so cavalierly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRANEFIELD, , PAUL F.

Professor Cranefield, a valued member of The Rockefeller University research community for more than 35 years was a pioneer in the study of cardiac physiology. His research was directed toward a deeper understanding of cardiac arrhythmias and their relation to heart disease. His activities as a medical historian were a reflection and extension of his research interests. He will long be remembered for his contributions to the scientific understanding of cardiac physiology and pharmacology, as well as for his deep commitment and skill as a teacher. Fuentes, the new superintendent of the state police, pledged last week to win back the trust of New Jerseyans by assigning troopers to combat street crime in dangerous urban neighborhoods. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Fresh Kills Environmental Study
description: New York City does not have to conduct further studies on the health effects of soot from diesel sanitation trucks, the state's highest court has ruled. Beginning in 1999, in preparation for the closing of the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, the city used diesel trucks to transport waste from Manhattan to New Jersey. The state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, argued that the city should have studied the environmental impact of particulate emissions as small as 2.5 microns. Instead, the city studied larger emissions. The state appeals court found on Thursday that there was no technologically feasible method to evaluate the smaller particulate emissions at that time. A spokeswoman for the city's Sanitation Department, Kathy Dawkins, said its trucks in Manhattan and the Bronx switched to ultra-low sulfur diesel fuel last year to reduce emissions and would expand that to all its routes in the next few years. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KADUSON, , JACK
description: KADUSON--Jack. 89, of Farmington, ME, formerly of Roslyn Heights, Long Island, New York, died Thursday in Farmington. He was born April 29, 1914, in New York City, the son of Abraham and Ethel (Kushner) Kaduson. He received his education in New York schools. On May 7, 1942, he married Elaine Rodman in New York City. He was a U.S. Army veteran, having served in the Asiatic Pacific Theatre during WWII. He was a member of the motion picture team and served as a writer and unit manager. His division was responsible for the filming of Ryukyus Campaign (Okinawa Operation) and showed the release of allied POW's and Japanese war criminals. They also filmed during the encephalitis B disease, endemic to Okinawa, Japan, and shared the coverage with the Surgeon General, Washington, DC. During his service, Mr. Kaduson also interviewed Tokyo Rose. His business career included working in the world of advertising. He was employed by Gimbel Brothers. He then worked in retail sales and was employed by Schenley Distilleries and the Seagram Co. He returned from retirement to work at Cue and New York Magazine. Mr. Kaduson enjoyed playing golf, listening to music, reading, attending the theater with his wife, family vacations and making people laugh. His greatest gift was his sense of humor. Following retirement, he studied art and philosophy. He will always be loved and remembered by his family, friends and caregivers for his devotion to being a good provider, his Saturday outings with his daughters, his work ethic, honesty and never-fading sense of humor. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Elaine, of Farmington, formerly of Long Island, NY; two daughters: Karen Calloway and her husband, John, of Avon, Maine, and Lynne Kaduson of New York; a sister-in-law, Shirley Davis of California; a cousin-in-law, Sandy Grappel of Florida; one niece, several nephews and many dear and loving friends from New York, Michigan, Florida and Maine. He was precedeased by a brother, Bill Kaduson, and brother-in-law, Ira Rodman. A memorial service will be held Tuesday morning, June 10, 2003, at 11 a.m. from the Wiles Funeral Home, 137 Farmington Falls Road, Farmington, with Rabbi Susan Bulba Carvutto of Temple Beth El of Augusta. Following services, all are welcome to a fellowship reception in Mr. Kaduson's honor at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be given in his memory to the Franklin County Animal Shelter, RR 1, Box 1413, Farmington, ME 04938. Committal services will be held in the future at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, New York. >>AD#

She zeroed in as he sobered considerably in recognizing her: ''Sister Mary,'' he cooed, kissing the hand of Mary Scullion. In minutes, Marshall was back in the coils of Project Home, Sister Mary's relentless program credited with drastically shrinking Philadelphia's population of the chronically homeless. Crafted from Sister Mary's 25 years of homeless advocacy, the program was ready to steer Marshall to a roof of his own, buttressed with medical and social services tailored to his needs.

title: Failed Governance, Failing Oceans
description: The oceans under United States jurisdiction cover about 4.5 million square miles, an area even greater than the land mass of America itself. But while Congress has enacted broad laws providing for the stewardship of America's public lands -- its national parks, forests and wilderness -- there is no overarching law governing the oceans, nor is there a single government agency focused on their well-being. That is one big reason that America's oceans are in such trouble -- their estuaries polluted, their shorelines consumed by development, their once abundant fish populations in free fall.

description: An Op-Ed article yesterday about Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, and Helen Thomas, the journalist, misstated her current employer. It is Hearst Newspapers, not United Press International.

title: Art Cooper, Who Transformed GQ Magazine, Is Dead at 65
description: Art Cooper, who in nearly 20 years as editor of GQ magazine helped to transform it into a showplace for literary journalism, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 65.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HASCHEMEYER, , RUDOLPH HARM
description: HASCHEMEYER -- Rudolph Harm, on June 8th, at age 72. Retired professor at Weill Medical College at Cornell and Rogosin Institute. Beloved husband of Selma Haschemeyer. Father of Theodore, & Andrew Haschemeyer and Julie Haschemeyer Doran. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., Wednesday, 7-9 PM. Interment Golden, IL. >>AD#

title: Iraq's Weapons, Our Intelligence
description: To the Editor:

title: Hunting Clues, Anthrax Investigators Drain Maryland Pond
description: Federal authorities began draining a small pond today in a municipal park near Frederick, Md., searching for evidence in the unsolved anthrax mailings that killed five people and inflicted illness on 17 others in 2001, the F.B.I. said.

title: Bush Again Vows U.S. Will Find Illicit Weapons
description: President Bush said today that he was ''absolutely convinced'' that the United States would find proof that Iraq had chemical and biological weapons programs, brushing aside any doubts about the primary justification he offered before the war for removing Saddam Hussein from power.

title: British Envoy Sees Allies Running Iraq In Near Term
description: The senior British envoy to Iraq reaffirmed today that the occupying powers intended to run the country for the foreseeable future, with Iraqis restricted to an advisory role.

title: Stun Guns Closer for Planes
description: Stun guns may be permitted on airplanes to protect against hijackers, the Transportation Security Administration says in a report to Congress.

title: Glass That Glows and Gives Stock Information
description: Hordes of entrepreneurs and giant companies compete to make consumer electronic devices faster, multifeatured and able to process mind-boggling amounts of data. But David Rose is betting there is money to be made heading against the crowd. His company, Ambient Devices, a start-up in Cambridge, Mass., is producing devices that display limited information in ways that can be understood with just a glance.

title: Wieden Leads Honors At Commercials Show
description: Offices of Wieden & Kennedy won the most honors in the agency category at the 12th annual show sponsored by the Association of Independent Commercial Producers in New York, recognizing work on television commercials.

title: Foster Care In New Jersey Is Called Inept
description: In July 2002, a federal judge in southern New Jersey approved a plan for an expert to assess the state child welfare agency's handling of 500 randomly selected children in foster care. It did not take the expert long to discover the extent of the agency's problems: 120 of the case files were missing so much information -- sometimes, for instance, whether the child was even still in foster care -- that they had to be thrown out of the study.

title: WARNACO WINS RIGHT TO MAKE CALVIN KLEIN BATHING SUITS
description: The Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, which bought the designer brand Calvin Klein in February, awarded the Warnaco Group the right to make some bathing suits under the Calvin Klein label. Terms were not disclosed. Warnaco will make, distribute and sell swimwear under the CK Calvin Klein trademark worldwide starting in January, the companies said. Warnaco, which also makes Calvin Klein jeans and underwear, accounted for about 36 percent of the royalty, design and other fees the brand generated last year, Van Heusen said in a regulatory filing. Retail sales of Calvin Klein items last year exceeded $3 billion, the company said.

title: Webdenda
description: Missy Altergott was named management supervisor at McClain Finlon Advertising , Denver. She had been account director at Deutsch LA, the Marina del Rey, Calif., office of Deutsch, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Gloria Baker was named media director at Media Logic , Albany, succeeding Dennis Nikles, who left, the agency said. Ms. Baker had been account manager at the United Way of Massachusetts Bay, Boston. Susan Baron , managing director for the Integrated Marketing Group at the New York office of the Meredith Corporation, was named publisher at Meredith's American Baby Group division, succeeding Marjorie Gladstone, who left, the company said. Cinecitta Studios S.p.A. , Rome, is promoting its facilities, used to shoot movies and television programming, for the production and postproduction of commercials and music video clips. The effort is being headed by Carole Andre-Smith , the chief international marketing adviser. Also, an office to help Madison Avenue work with Cinecitta is being opened in New York, headed by Debbie Brenner. DDB Worldwide , New York, hired four employees. Karen Sullivan was named to the new post of director for creative services; she had been vice president and director for creative services at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, which is being closed by the Publicis Groupe. Carmine Coppola and Michael Sullivan were named art directors; they had been art directors at Publicis Worldwide, New York, also part of Publicis. Yimbo Ma was named copywriter; he had been copywriter director at Publicis Worldwide. Jorge Del Mazo was named global business director for the marketing service group at Euro RSCG Life NRP , New York, part of Euro RSCG Life. He assumes some duties that had been handled by John Quick, who left, the agency said. Mr. Del Mazo had been executive vice president for the health care practice group at Marina Maher Communications, New York. Euro RSCG Life is part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas. The Hallmark Channel promoted five employees in the New York office to vice presidents. They are: Terri Corcoran , who becomes vice president for advertising sales and alliance marketing; Lorri Esposito , vice president for traffic services; Lorianne Sabatino , vice president for direct response and paid programming; and Michelle Treiber , vice president for pricing and planning. Also, Michelle Castle , director for Detroit area advertising sales, was named vice president for ad sales, responsible for Michigan and Ohio; she will continue to work from Troy, Mich. Hallmark is part of Crown Media Holdings. Kathleen Harrington was named to the new post of senior vice president for public affairs and director for policy outreach at the Washington office of Porter Novelli . She had been assistant secretary for public affairs at the United States Department of Labor. Porter Novelli is part of the Omnicom Group. Health Learning Systems , Parsippany, N.J., part of CommonHealth, hired several employees. Richard Alexander was named medical writer; he had been group leader for the immunology research group at Advanced Viral Research, Yonkers, N.Y. Antionette Campo was named editor; she had been a freelance copy editor at Medical Actions Communications, Parsippany. Jeffrey Fisher was named executive vice president and medical director for business development, a post he will also hold at Adient, also part of CommonHealth; he had been executive vice president and medical director at MPE Communications, Parsippany, part of the Torre Lazur-McCann Healthcare Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Kenneth Hoerner was named senior graphic designer, succeeding Corinne West, who left, the agency said. Mr. Hoerner had been a freelance graphic designer. Jeannine Lee was named program director; she had been senior account executive at Adient. CommonHealth is part of the WPP Group. Christine Levesque was named to the new post of executive vice president for communication, marketing and government affairs at the New York office of Gemstar-TV Guide International . She had been senior vice president for communication and marketing at Rainbow Media Holdings, New York, part of the Cablevision Systems Corporation. Monica Lyons was named to the new post of broadcast buying supervisor at O'Leary & Partners , Irvine, Calif. She had been senior broadcast buyer at the Newport Beach office of Doner. Ted Manger was named senior planner at Merkley Newman Harty & Partners , New York, part of the Omnicom Group. He had been group planning director at Bozell in New York, which was merged into Lowe & Partners Worldwide by the Interpublic Group of Companies. Geoff Potter was named to the new post of vice president for corporate affairs at Leo Burnett USA , Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide division of the Publicis Groupe. He had been public relations manager at a Chicago law firm, Jenner & Block. Promax and BDA , Los Angeles, an organization for promotion, marketing and broadcast design executives, presented awards during its annual conference last week in Los Angeles. Micki Byrnes , director for marketing and promotion at WKYC-TV, Cleveland, won the Pinnacle Award, to recognize ``lasting contributions'' to the entertainment industry. And Rick Sirvatis , president and chief operating officer at GM Mediaworks, New York, won the Chairman's Award, to recognize ``outstanding work'' in promotion, marketing and design. WKYC-TV is part of the Gannett Company. GM Mediaworks is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Rolling Stone magazine, New York, hired two employees. Louis Muckle was named advertising fashion director, succeeding Lora Logan, who left, the company said. Mr. Muckle had been an advertising salesman at Harris Publications, New York. And Hugh Jamieson has been named fragrance and grooming manager, succeeding Joey Jacobson, who left, the company said. Mr. Jamieson had been fragrance and grooming director at GQ magazine, New York, part of the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications. Rolling Stone is published by Wenner Media. St. John & Partners , Jacksonville, Fla., promoted two employees. Lori Blackburn , senior account executive, was named account supervisor. And Mary Ann Carroll , assistant account executive, was named public relations account executive. Schenkein , Denver, promoted one employee and hired two others. Meme Moore , senior account executive, was named senior writing executive. Brady Foster was named account coordinator; she had been public relations manager at ServiceMagic.com, Golden, Colo. And Brandy Henley was named account coordinator; she had been account executive at Hayworth Creative Advertising and Public Relations, Ormond Beach, Fla. Amy Spreadborough , a director at Leopold Ketel & Partners , Portland, Ore., was named a partner. Amy Swearingen was named to the new post of vice president for strategic planning and client development at Pohly & Partners , Boston. Ms. Swearingen had been a marketing consultant and before that worked at agencies like GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of the Omnicom Group. Unreal Marketing Solutions , Narberth, Pa., hired two employees as account managers. Blake Harrison had been account executive at Paradigm Visions, Langhorn, Pa. And Michael Iannelli had been client services manager at the ICT Group, Inc., Newtown, Pa.

title: 'Virtual World' of Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Although Kidd Does It All, Nets Need Him to Do More
description: In the clarity of morning, Jason Kidd awoke from another Spurs nightmare and knew what he and the Nets had to do in Game 4.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Talks With Kidnappers
description: Georgian officials held talks with kidnappers demanding $3 million in ransom for the release of four United Nations staff members abducted last week, but they failed to secure their freedom, officials said. The four were part of a team of military observers monitoring a cease-fire between Georgia and Abkhazia, a province that broke away from the country in 1993. Unidentified gunmen seized the four -- two Germans, a Dane and the group's Georgian translator -- in a remote gorge in a Georgian-controlled part of Abkhazia. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

title: Senate Sponsors of Medicare Drug Bill Provide Details
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  Architects of a Senate bill adding drug benefits to Medicare set forth details of their proposal today, with a growing sense of confidence that some such plan would soon become law.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GREENBRIER COS., Lake Oswego, Ore., a maker and maintainer of railroad cars, said it would build more than 2,400 rail cars worth $120 million for TTX Co., Chicago, and Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corp., Fort Worth.

title: Key Skeptic Says Britain May Vote in 2004 on Euro
description: In a major address that said as much about the power plays at the top of the British government as its intentions toward Europe, Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, said for the first time today that Britons might vote in a referendum next year on joining the European single currency.

title: Sports of The Times; Want Pressure? Try a Game 7
description: You could cut the tension with a puck. And the Devils did. Three times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   APPEL, , CHERI, M.D.
description: APPEL--Cheri, M.D., on June 8, at age of 101. Wife of the late Dr. Benjamin Segal. Mother of Mimi S. Daitz and Anthony Pell. Grandmother of Sebastien & Victoria Pell and Benjamin C. Daitz. >>AD#

title: Monkeypox Casts Light on Rule Gap for Exotic Pets
description: The Web site for the federal Department of Agriculture provides guidelines for the importation of pets. Dogs must be vaccinated against rabies. Cats going to Hawaii are to be quarantined for 130 days. Animals like sheepdogs that will be used with livestock have to be free of tapeworm.

title: NBC Left Its Competitors No Chance
description: The displays at the Olympic Museum in Lausanne, Switzerland, contain memorabilia like Jesse Owens's sneakers from the 1936 Olympics; the fencing togs and swords of Baron Pierre de Coubertin, founder of the modern Olympics; and various torches, some of splendid design, some simple and one that looks like bathroom plumbing equipment. Even the blue swimsuit of Eric Moussambani, the brave yet hapless swimmer from Equatorial Guinea who competed at the 2000 Sydney Games, is celebrated.

title: America Online decides that two agencies are better.
description: CAN the agency that urges consumers to ''Just do it'' on behalf of Nike just do it for the struggling America Online division of AOL Time Warner? And can the agency accomplish that daunting task with a second shop sharing the client?

title: INSIDE
description: Boeing Shops for Jet Site

title: Ripple Effect of Turmoil Seen in Financial Markets
description: The turmoil at Freddie Mac, one of the largest mortgage finance companies, is creating ripples through financial markets and could threaten the robust housing market that has brightened an otherwise dreary economy, analysts said.

title: Behind Malpractice Awards Are Real Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking the Perfect Piano Piece, in Spruce
description: The big, curved rim of Steinway piano No. K0862 had been parked since early March in a hot, dark room, aging so it would never pop out of shape. Soon it would emerge, and workers would start putting things inside, from tiny hammers that strike the strings to the 340-pound cast-iron plate that anchors them.

title: A Student of Leadership to Lead the State Police
description: IT is hard to understand how controversy could swirl around Col. Joseph R. Fuentes, the newest superintendent of New Jersey's State Police. He is the model of decorum, sitting stiffly in a green suit in an office that is so neat it looks as if it passed a military inspection. On his desk is a row of books all on one theme, leadership. There are the framed pictures of the State Police band on the wall, a revolver in a glass case, books celebrating the history of the State Police and a pile of blue folders on his desk that he reads while being driven to and from his home.

title: Teaching Art and Science: The Twain Meet (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLAN, , LAWRENCE
description: POLAN--Lawrence. Beloved husband of Shirley. Loving father of Jeffrey. Dear brother of Joyce Potter. Cherished brother-in-law of Bob and Edith Weinstein. Loving uncle of Dr. Seth, Robert, Warren, Rachel, Stephanie, Perri, Julian and Dr. Clifford and Dr. Lee. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 11:30 AM, Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Boy Arrested With Loaded Gun At School
description: A 15-year-old boy was arrested yesterday morning after taking a loaded .38-caliber handgun to his high school, the police said. He was discovered by school safety agents at a metal detector at Norman Thomas High School, at 111 East 33rd Street, Sgt. Dennis Ferber said. As of last night, the police had not charged him, Detective Robert Price said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Could It Be Less Boring?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KORENSTEIN, , RITA
description: KORENSTEIN--Rita. On June 7, 2003 with her loved ones at her bedside. Beloved and devoted aunt, great-aunt, sister and daughter. All who knew her know she was a special lady. She will be greatly missed. Contributions to a charity of your choice in her name would be appreciated. >>AD#

title: Species and Language
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush to Prohibit Building Roads Inside Forests
description: The Bush administration said today that it would reinstate a Clinton-era rule that prohibits building roads in 58.5 million acres of protected national forests. But the administration wants to allow governors to seek exemptions from the rule, which environmental groups said would open the way for logging and drilling on millions of acres.

title: Chief Executive Resigns At Lowe New York
description: Paul Hammersley, chief executive of the New York office of Lowe & Partners Worldwide, resigned, the agency said yesterday, four months after another senior manager was named to top posts there.

title: Greenspan Predicts High Natural Gas Prices Into Next Year
description: WASHINGTON -- Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan predicted tight supplies of natural gas and high prices for a prolonged period Tuesday, largely because -- unlike oil -- the U.S. market is unable to draw on world gas supplies easily.

title: Of Mad Cows and Sane Cats
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Falls
description: Brazil's industrial output declined in April for the first time in 11 months, after the highest interest rates in four years discouraged expansions and made it more onerous for businesses to hold inventories. Industrial production fell 4.2 percent in April from the same period a year ago on declining output of durable consumer goods, the national statistics agency said. Exports of cars, steel and fuels helped the expansion in Brazil's manufacturing industry in the past year. However, the highest borrowing costs since 1999 have curbed demand for household goods, economists said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIERSON, , DR. WILLARD J.
description: PIERSON--Dr. Willard J. On June 7, 2003, Resident of West Hempstead. Beloved husband of the late Joy Kell Pierson. Devoted father of Mark, Mary Jean and Arthur. Loving brother of Vaughn. Cherished grandfather of Alexander, Ian and Sean. Renowned Research Professor at City College in New York City. Specialized in Oceanography and Meteorology. He received many accolades in his fifty year career. Proud W.W. II Veteran Army Aviation Cadet. Reposing at Krauss Funeral Home Inc., 1097 Hempstead Tpke. Visiting hours Tuesday 2-5 and 7-10 and Wednesday 2-5PM. Religious service 7:30PM at Wesley United Methodist Church, Franklin Square. In lieu of flowers make donations in his memory to: Wesley United Methodist Church, 619 Fenworth Boulevard, Franklin Square, New York 11010. >>AD#

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: POLICE AND FIRE BENEFITS FUND TO CLOSE About 1,900 active and retired police officers and firefighters in Denver could be left without health coverage at the end of the month, when the Denver Fire and Health Fund closes. The fund, set up in 1977, let members choose doctors and dentists, but it has struggled with rising costs and large claims. Union officials said members had at least two other options available. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: MORTGAGE CONCERN IN BROAD SHAKE-UP
description: Freddie Mac, the big buyer of mortgage loans, fired its president yesterday, contending that he failed to cooperate with an internal investigation into its accounting practices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEINES, , MORTON
description: SCHEINES--Morton, 72, died of pneumonia, June 8, in New Milford, CT. This dedicated cineaste and soft-hearted curmudgeon is survived by his wife Tricia, his son Prof. Richard of Carnegie Mellon Univ., his daughter Elizabeth, a film archivist, & brother Joseph, as well as by 5 loving but irreverent grandchildrenEmily, Robin, Katie, Max and Lea. Memorial service-Ethical Culture Soc., 2 W. 64 St, NYC, 3:30 Wednes. June 11. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERLITZ, , CHAIM, RABBI
description: GERLITZ--Chaim, Rabbi. The Officers, Trustees and congregation of Temple Israel of Riverhead join his beloved wife, Malka and his family in mourning this very special man. Our spiritual leader since 1986, Rabbi Chaim was a master reader of Torah and an incomparable teacher of children and adults. Our services were filled with music as he led our congregation with his lovely singing voice. Rabbi Chaim was tireless and generous to a fault when helping family, friends and congregants. His and Malka's hospitality was legendary. His warm and welcoming nature will be greatly missed, and we have lost a friend and someone with whom we shared many experiences. Richard Israel, President >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRIGGS, , BASIL MANLY JR.
description: BRIGGS--Basil Manly Jr. On Saturday, June 7, 2003, of gastric carcinoma. B.A. Williams College, M.S. Sloan School at the Massachusets Institute of Technology. Son of Basil Manly Briggs of Bloomfield Hills, MI, and Mary Ellen Brademas, M.D., of New York City. Grandson of Eleanor Budd of Bloomfield Hills and the late Walter O. (Spike) Briggs and great-grandson of the late Walter O. Briggs, former owner of the Detroit Tigers and Briggs Stadium. Stepson of Janet Briggs and of John Brademas, former member of Congress from South Bend, IN, and House Majority Whip, and President Emeritus of New York University. Brother of Katherine Goldberg of Bloomfield Hills, Jane Murray of Los Angeles and John Briggs of Boston. Brother-in-law of Tom Goldberg, Clarke Murray and Robin Briggs. Uncle of James and Briggs Goldberg and Cameron and John Murray. Friend of Surjit Jhaj, Adilson Araujo and Merril Robinson Seichter. Funeral Mass at St. Hugo Chapel, Bloomfield Hills, Wednesday, June 11. Burial at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Southfield, MI. >>AD#

title: Christian Bands, Crossing Over; A New Breed of Rockers Broadens Its Appeal by Skipping the Sermons
description: The Revelation Room, across from the Sonic drive-in restaurant on Highway 19 here, is the only place to see live music in a dry county. It is open only on Saturdays. Admission is $7; sodas are 50 cents. On a recent Saturday the headliner was Anberlin. Its five members, ages 16 to 26, were scruffy, hip, unwashed, malnourished road warriors constantly cracking inside jokes. Like any other rock band.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Tried and True or Being New
description: It's a rare band that can measure its history in decades, and for those that do, the choices don't go away. Reinvention or refinement? Keep up with the latest or stick with what has worked before? Steely Dan, founded in 1972, and Metallica, founded in 1981, find their own answers on new albums.

title: Uncle Joe Smiles Down on a Family of Old Lefties
description: As audience members take their seats at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center for Jules Feiffer's uneven but gnawingly thoughtful new play, ''A Bad Friend,'' the face of Stalin looks out over the stage from three separate screens. A sturdy, uncomplicated portrait drawn against a Soviet-red background, the image has a benign, almost paternal quality. It isn't the kind of heroic iconography that a despot like Stalin -- or Saddam Hussein -- generates in his own land for his own inflation. It doesn't provoke awe or fear; nor, as we might expect today, is it a lampoon.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertising Unit Sold
description: The Cordiant Communications Group said it would sell its 77 percent interest in the German advertising agency Scholz & Friends for 22.4 million euros ($26.3 million). Cordiant, based in London, has been shedding assets and is re-evaluating its corporate strategy after the loss of a key client. The WPP Group of Britain is interested in Cordiant, and could make a bid for the company this week, executives close to both ad agencies said. Some equity holders, worried that a WPP bid would destroy the value of Cordiant shares, have proposed that Cordiant management be replaced instead. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: On Return to L.I., Kidnapping Suspect Is Arrested
description: A man accused of abducting his former girlfriend to Virginia last month and sexually assaulting her until she escaped back to Long Island two weeks later was captured on Sunday when he tried to break into her home, the Nassau County police said yesterday.

title: The Pain Of Pain, Persistent And Chronic
description: The sharp pain in my right knee has shot me over the falls. I have a new respect for the camel that invented the cumulative burden.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: Pope Ends Trip
description: Pope John Paul II ended the landmark 100th foreign trip of his papacy by telling the people of Croatia, where he spent the last five days, that he remembered their ''sufferings caused by the war, which are still visible on your faces.'' He was speaking to a huge crowd in the Adriatic coastal city of Zadar and referring to the bloody struggles between Croats and Serbs in the early 1990's. During the trip, which took a visible physical toll on the 83-year-old pope, he repeatedly urged Croats to move past their turbulent history. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLKENFELD, , LENORE
description: WOLKENFELD -- Lenore. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member Lenore Wolkenfeld. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Gary Miller, Chairman of the Board >>AD#

title: When Women Quit Smoking
description: Women who quit smoking have more improvement in lung function compared with men who quit, a government study appearing in the current American Journal of Epidemiology has found.

title: Contraband Is Big Business in Paraguay
description: Judging by this country's trade figures, Paraguayans would seem to be a nation of ferocious chain smokers.

title: Iraqi Leaders, to Show Unity, Meet in Kurds' Area
description: A week after meeting two prominent Shiite leaders in the southern city of Najaf, the Kurdish leader, Massoud Barzani, gathered Iraqi opposition figures here today in Iraq's north in a show of unity that included some criticism of the American occupation.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: KOREAN RAIL LINKS PLANNED South and North Korea are to open two rail links and allow trains to pass into each other's territory for the first time in more than half a century. The links will be opened in a ceremony on Saturday. One will tie Seoul with a planned industrial park near the North Korean city of Gaesong. The other is on the eastern coast. James Brooke (NYT)

title: A Thin Veneer for Fat Children
description: Nearly a third of mothers surveyed did not realize that their children were overweight, researchers say. And among many of those who did, they were much more likely to see it as a problem in girls than in boys.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: RULING ON SCHOOL BUSING The State Supreme Court overturned a trial court decision to make the state reimburse DeKalb County $105 million for 24 years of busing to desegregate its schools. By law, the state pays counties to transport students to "the school to which they are assigned," but it argued that the students were not attending their assigned schools. The students chose magnet schools or volunteered to go to schools outside their districts to increase racial diversity. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Before Kisses and Snickers, It Was the Treat of Royalty
description: At first glance, it looks like a small chip of concrete, except the center is brown.

title: For Sale: Short Stories for the Long Ride Home
description: Ever since the day it opened, and for obvious reasons, the subway has been as much a supermarket as a means of transportation.

title: Miscellany
description: The Starcom MediaVest Group, Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe, opened a division named Play, specializing in marketing through video games. Tim Harris and P. J. MacGregor, who had worked together at the Starcom IP division of Starcom MediaVest, were named vice presidents at Starcom MediaVest and directors at Play.

description: East Meets West as Partners or Duelists

title: BUSH WILL ACCEPT IDENTICAL BENEFITS ON MEDICARE DRUGS
description: In a tactical retreat, the Bush administration told Congress today that it would accept equal prescription drug benefits for people in the traditional Medicare program and those who join private health plans.

title: Devils Hoist Stanley Cup Again
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 9 - The Devils exorcised the Stanley Cup ghosts of 2001 tonight.

title: Suit Over Sale of Clayton Homes to Buffett
description: Orbis Investment Management Ltd., a Bermuda-based money manager, asked a Delaware court yesterday to help it block Warren E. Buffett's $1.7 billion purchase of Clayton Homes Inc., a mobile-home maker in which Orbis has a 5 percent stake.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gigure Would Trade Trophy for Cup
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 9 - When Jean-Sebastien Giguere of the Anaheim Mighty Ducks received the Conn Smythe trophy as the most valuable player of the Stanley Cup playoffs tonight, he became only the fifth player to win the award while playing for a losing team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RAVEN, , CLAUS (BORN RAWITSCHER)
description: RAVEN--Claus (born Rawitscher) of Clifton, NJ. Holocaust survivor born in Berlin, Germany. Age 81, on June 7, 2003. Beloved husband of 60 years to the former Rahel Karlsberg. Devoted father to David Raven and Diane Raven Reilly. Beloved father-inlaw of Michele and Patrick. Special ''Pop'' to Leah, Dan, Ben, and Sonni. He beautified New Jersey with his landscape designs. He nourished us with his wit, warmth and cuisine. Founder and leader of the Raven Tennis Group. Services on Wednesday at 1:00PM at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ (973-779-3048). Contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. >>AD#

title: Yanks Ready Itinerary For Two Journeymen
description: The Yankees lost twice at Wrigley Field last weekend, and there was an obvious goat in each nationally televised game. On Saturday, Juan Acevedo served up a three-run homer to spoil Roger Clemens's chance at his 300th victory. On Sunday, Charles Gipson was picked off first base for the final out in a one-run loss.

title: For Greenspan, A Time to Cut Or to Surprise?
description: By signaling that he is prepared to cut interest rates once again, Alan Greenspan has entered what many analysts consider to be dangerous territory in one of the most difficult battles he has fought as chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Wal-Mart's June Sales Up
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the world's largest retailer, said yesterday that June sales at stores open at least a year were rising within its expectations as shoppers bought more groceries.

title: Diverting the War on Terrorism
description: The recent dust-up over Republican attempts to gerrymander the Texas Congressional map had an overlay of old-fashioned political silliness and skulduggery. What is coming to be known as the Tom DeLay Power Perpetuation Act failed famously when more than 50 statehouse Democrats fled to Oklahoma, where they hid out until the bill died, depriving the Republican majority of a quorum. But it turns out that officials in Washington and Austin, desperate to round up the Democrats, made a platoon of Keystone Kops out of federal and state law enforcement agents. That is no laughing matter.

title: Ailing Peripheral Arteries Can Bear Ominous Warnings
description: Peripheral artery disease is a common progressive disorder that interferes with circulation to the legs, particularly in people over 55. Sufferers have a greatly increased risk of heart attack or stroke, and of dying within a decade.

title: Bush Remains 'Optimistic' On Mideast Peace Efforts
description: Despite a wave of bloodshed over the weekend in the Middle East, President Bush said today that he remained ''optimistic'' about forging peace between the Israelis and Palestinians and that he would follow through on the promises he made to both sides on the Gulf of Aqaba.

title: FAO SAYS CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER WILL LEAVE COMPANY
description: FAO Inc., the toy seller that emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy in April, said the chief financial officer, Raymond P. Springer, will leave the company later this year. Jerome Kollar, the senior vice president for finance, will assume Mr. Springer's responsibilities. The toy retailer, based in King of Prussia, Pa., filed for bankruptcy protection in January. It also announced that it appointed Douglas Coltharp, Brian McDermott, Charles Norris and David Walsh to its board.

title: People
description: Cameron Day was named Chrysler brand creative director at the Troy, Mich., office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, assuming duties that had been handled by Bill Morden, vice chairman and chief creative officer. Mr. Day had been creative director on the Land Rover account at GSD&M, Austin, Tex., also part of Omnicom.

title: Bunia Journal; Mortal Combat Rages, but 'Mortal Kombat' Rules
description: The whiz of bullets overhead had barely died down when the boys of Bunia went to the movies.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Korean Rail Links Planned
description: South and North Korea are to open two rail links and allow trains to pass into each other's territory for the first time in more than half a century. The links will be opened in a ceremony on Saturday. One will tie Seoul with a planned industrial park near the North Korean city of Gaesong. The other is on the eastern coast. James Brooke (NYT)

title: SARS and Inventory Trouble Lead Motorola to Cut Estimate
description: Motorola Inc., the world's second-biggest mobile telephone maker, reduced sales and profit forecasts for the year yesterday, blaming excess inventory and the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome in Asia.

title: FLORIDA POWER OFFICER NAMED HEAD OF ALLEGHENY ENERGY
description: Allegheny Energy Inc. named Florida Power and Light's president, Paul Evanson, as chief executive. Alan Noia left as chief executive in March. Mr. Evanson, 61, will also become chairman and president on June 16, Allegheny said. Mr. Evanson had been president of Florida Power and Light since 1995 and had been the chief financial officer for its parent, the FPL Group. The company received $2.4 billion in loans in February to avert insolvency after defaulting on debt and energy trades last year. Allegheny, which is based in Hagerstown, Md., closed its New York City energy-trading office in April.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Islamic Militants Arrested
description: The Federal Security Service said it had arrested at least 50 members of the radical Islamic Liberation Party at a Moscow factory where they had been in hiding. The underground party, which advocates merging central Asia and western China into an Islamic caliphate, has ties to Afghan and Uzbek extremist groups and is labeled a terrorist organization in Russia, which accuses it of aiding Chechen separatists. A security service spokesman said the party's Moscow leader, a Kyrgyz national, was captured, along with plastic explosives, TNT and hand grenades. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: From Welfare to (Course) Work; Students on Benefits Help Write Their Own Rights
description: When Shawnta Alston graduated from high school in Queens three years ago, she planned to go to college. But her family's welfare caseworker wanted her to pick up trash on Staten Island to help meet the family's workfare requirement.

Though they squabble and tattle and threaten to throw up, there is something passive about them. Sometimes they go as limp as clothes in a hamper. Each has only one facial expression, and they have no voices to call their own.

description: The Bush and Blair administrations are trying to silence critics -- many of them current or former intelligence analysts -- who say that they exaggerated the threat from Iraq. Last week a Blair official accused Britain's intelligence agencies of plotting against the government. (Tony Blair's government has since apologized for January's ''dodgy dossier.'') In this country, Colin Powell has declared that questions about the justification for war are ''outrageous.''

title: R.J. REYNOLDS FINANCE CHIEF RESIGNS AFTER 11 MONTHS
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Holdings Inc. said its chief financial officer, Richard Bogan, resigned after joining the company in July. He was replaced by Dianne Neal, vice president for investor relations. Mr. Bogan, 52, left to pursue other business opportunities, a spokeswoman, Maura Payne, said. In April, R. J. Reynolds, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., cut its annual profit forecast by almost half and suspended its share-repurchase program.

title: Surprise Role for Ex-Senator: Male Breast Cancer Patient
description: A loose-fitting shirt hid the scar and concave area that former Senator Edward W. Brooke spoke of as he moved his hand across the space from his right armpit to the center of his chest. In his 83 years, life has held plenty of unexpected turns for Mr. Brooke, the Massachusetts Republican who in 1966 became the first African-American elected to the United States Senate since Reconstruction.

title: Unusual Pentagon-Boeing Deal Is Attacked
description: Conservative and liberal groups have joined to oppose a $20 billion plan by the Bush administration to lease air refueling tankers from the Boeing Company, calling the arrangement a ''sweetheart deal'' and asking that Congress investigate the arrangement.

description: The announcer skipped from Richard Smehlik to Jiri Bicek when announcing the Devils' scratches before tonight's game, and hard-boiled hockey fans knew exactly what that meant.

As a Republican congressman, Bob Riley had a nearly perfect record of opposing any legislation supported by the liberal Americans for Democratic Action.

title: Beyond Mideast Promises
description: A rare and alarming collaboration took place on Sunday: three Palestinian terror groups carried out a joint attack at an entrance to the Gaza Strip, killing four Israeli soldiers. Two of the groups, Hamas and Islamic Jihad, are militantly Islamic. The third, Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, is associated with Fatah, the nationalist movement of Yasir Arafat. The attack came the day after Mr. Arafat belittled the peace summit meeting attended by the Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas.

title: Elam Davies, 86, Chicago Church Leader
description: The Rev. Dr. Elam Davies, pastor emeritus of the Fourth Presbyterian Church of Chicago, who helped it build a major church-sponsored community services institution on the city's Near North Side, died Friday in Bethlehem, Pa., where he had retired in the 1980's. He was 86.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Arrested In Bank Robberies
description: A Manhattan man was arrested yesterday in connection with 12 bank robberies and attempted bank robberies in Manhattan since the end of March, the police said. Oswaldo Planas, 33, of East 97th Street, has not been charged yet, Detective Robert Price said. He returned to try to rob three of the banks twice, the police said. He is suspected of robbing or trying to rob Fourth Federal Savings Bank on Second Avenue on March 27 and May 4, Chase Bank on Lexington Avenue on April 7, Fleet Bank on Broadway on April 17 and again on May 13, HSBC on Broadway on May 1, Country Bank on Second Avenue on May 16 and May 23, Chase Bank at Lincoln Plaza on May 28, Washington Mutual on Broadway on May 30, and two banks on June 3, Citibank on Broadway and Emigrant Savings Bank on Lexington Avenue. In each case, he passed a note to a teller, but did not display a gun, Detective Price said. It was not known how much money he stole. Tina Kelley (NYT)

description: A brutal attack on Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her pro-democracy supporters a week ago has put an end to a faint spring in Myanmar and signals a return to the harsh repression of the past, diplomats and political analysts say.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: AUTO VENTURE TO START Japan's Nissan Motor Company and China's third-largest automaker said they would start their previously announced automobile joint venture on July 1. Nissan has said it will put 8.6 billion yuan ($1 billion) into the venture with the China Dongfeng Motor Corporation, making it the biggest single foreign direct investment in China's auto industry. The venture plans to have six models by 2006. The partners said the new company, to be called the Dongfeng Motor Company, was valued at 16.7 billion yuan ($2 billion). (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Appeals Court Upholds Ruling Against City
description: A federal appeals court yesterday upheld a ruling that New York City had failed to meet its legal obligation to provide services to about 30,000 poor people with AIDS. Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. of Federal District Court in Brooklyn ruled in 2000 that the city had violated the federal Americans With Disabilities Act and provisions of state law and the state's Constitution. He also ruled against the state for not ensuring that the city complied with the laws. He found that recipients faced excessive waits in getting services like rent assistance and that the city's case managers had too many cases. Yesterday, a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit upheld the decision. For more than a year, the city has been working to comply with the original ruling, and while compliance remains incomplete, advocates say services have significantly improved. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: In Europe, 2 Sides to Weak Dollar
description: With the dollar looking so anemic, a lot of European companies, particularly those that depend on exports beyond the euro zone, have been moaning lately. But some, notably in retailing, have been groaning all the way to the bank.
