title: Anyone in the O.R.?
description: With the recent award of $140 million in a medical malpractice case, and strikes by surgeons in several states, the issue of malpractice insurance and its drain on the profession is impossible to ignore. Insurance premiums need to be lowered, laws must be enacted to produce reasonable awards and stifle frivolous lawsuits, and jurors and patients must learn that a poor outcome is not synonymous with malpractice.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Landfill Company To Be Acquired
description: Terra Firma Capital Partners, the buyout fund formed by the former Nomura Securities financier Guy Hands, plans to buy the Waste Recycling Group, Britain's largest landfill company, for 315 million ($518 million). This will be the first deal executed by Terra Firma since Mr. Hands formed the fund in early 2002. It has raised about 1.4 billion euros ($1.6 billion). The British water company Kelda Group, which holds a 45 percent stake in Waste Recycling, has agreed to the Terra Firma deal, as has the board of the landfill company. Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: Of nearly 17,000 students who took one or both of the examinations for teacher certification in New York State in the 2001-02 academic year, 94 percent passed, according to data posted on the State Education Department's Web site yesterday.

description: As an opening gesture to comply with the new American-led peace initiative, Israeli soldiers drove to a hilltop here in the West Bank and tore down what the Israeli Army described as a watchtower adjacent to a settlement.

description: President Hamid Karzai said today that there was no Taliban resurgence in Afghanistan, but that threats remained from foreign terrorists, whom he blamed for the attack two days ago on a bus full of German peacekeepers.

description: An 11-year search for a fugitive charged with shooting a Linden, N.J., police officer during a robbery in 1992 has ended with his capture in a shootout during a robbery attempt in Lima, Peru, the authorities said here today.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Security Agency Planned
description: The Department of Homeland Security says that it has created a national cybersecurity division to prepare for and respond to Internet attacks against government networks and some private-sector networks. The department is expected to name a director for the unit sometime this summer, officials said. The division, which will have 60 employees, will work to identify and reduce potential threats and vulnerabilities to attacks over the Internet. It will also provide technical assistance in planning for a recovery from such attacks and will issue alerts and warnings. ''Cybersecurity cuts across all aspects of critical infrastructure protection,'' said Tom Ridge, the secretary of homeland security.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Metromedia Recovery Plan
description: Metromedia Fiber Network, a bankrupt data network operator controlled by the billionaire John Kluge, said yesterday that it would seek approval for its recovery plan in August and change its name to AboveNet. Metromedia, based in White Plains, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in May 2002 with more than $5.35 billion in debt. Under Metromedia's plan, its unsecured creditors would get 90 percent of the reorganized company's shares, court papers show. Current Metromedia shareholders would get nothing. The company is to seek court permission on July 2 to send the plan to creditors. If the creditors agree, Metromedia said, it intends to seek final court approval on Aug. 14, clearing the way for it to leave Chapter 11. In June 2002, Metromedia said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating accounting practices that led the company to say it would restate results for most of 2001. Accountants at KPMG refused to approve an audit of Metromedia's books.

title: McGreevey Signs Law Easing the Rules for Auto Insurers
description: After campaigning for years about the need to lower New Jersey's steep auto insurance premiums, Gov. James E. McGreevey signed a bill into law today that is intended to ease regulations on auto insurers and, eventually, to provide modest rate reductions to some drivers.

title: The Young and Not So Reckless
description: Unless one has been accused of murdering a well-to-do intimate on Mykonos or in certain stretches of western Connecticut, the arrival of Vanity Fair generally does not set off feelings of apprehension. But when the July issue, with the cover line, ''It's Totally Raining Teens!'' turned up on the sixth floor of 120 Walker Street in Chinatown last week, the occupants were struck with an immediate sense of queasiness.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Police And Fire Benefits Fund To Close
description: About 1,900 active and retired police officers and firefighters in Denver could be left without health coverage at the end of the month, when the Denver Fire and Health Fund closes. The fund, set up in 1977, let members choose doctors and dentists, but it has struggled with rising costs and large claims. Union officials said members had at least two other options available. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Israeli Forces Strike in Gaza
description: GAZA, June 10 — A senior official of the militant group Hamas was wounded today after Israeli helicopters fired seven rockets at a jeep he was traveling in here, Palestinian witnesses said. Two people were killed and 27 others were injured in the attack, which is seen as a serious blow to efforts to get the American-backed Mideast peace plan on track.

title: Judge's Lawyer Says Payoffs Were a Setup by Prosecution
description: Documents unsealed yesterday in the case against a Brooklyn judge accused of accepting money and gifts to fix divorce cases show that the payoffs for which videotaped evidence exists were made by a lawyer who was cooperating with the prosecutors, the judge's lawyer said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bus Operator Acquired
description: Chow Tai Fook Enterprises Ltd., which has interests in jewelry, telecommunications and property, will acquire a second bus operator in Hong Kong by purchasing Citybus Ltd. for 132 million ($219 million). Chow Tai Fook, which is based in Hong Kong, plans to buy Citybus from Stagecoach Group P.L.C., Britain's No. 3 bus and train operator, and take over 44 million ($73 million) of debt. Chow Tai Fook already owns New World First Bus Services Ltd., the city's third-largest bus operator. Citybus and New World First Bus are the island's main bus operators.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CROATIA: POPE ENDS TRIP Pope John Paul II ended the landmark 100th foreign trip of his papacy by telling the people of Croatia, where he spent the last five days, that he remembered their "sufferings caused by the war, which are still visible on your faces." He was speaking to a huge crowd in the Adriatic coastal city of Zadar and referring to the bloody struggles between Croats and Serbs in the early 1990's. During the trip, which took a visible physical toll on the 83-year-old pope, he repeatedly urged Croats to move past their turbulent history. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: Under the Overcast Skies
description: The clouds may have broken as you read this. But if the past few weeks are any indication, the overcast will gather again, and rain will fall until the sun, heavily rationed, peeks out just long enough to make it clear how much we are missing. The weather services say that the gray weather has been caused by a dip in the jet stream and an onshore flow of cold air from the Atlantic. People who know Moscow say we've been having a Moscow spring, and people who know Iceland claim that the low clouds make them think of its southern coast. We all have dank antecedents to draw on.

title: Accounts
description: Brown & Williamson Tobacco, Louisville, Ky., which sells cigarette brands like Kool and Lucky Strike, placed in review the consolidated media planning and buying duties on its account. Media planning had been handled by various agencies; media buying had been handled by MediaCom, New York, part of the Grey Global Group. Although billings were not disclosed, Brown & Williamson, part of British American Tobacco, spent $51.2 million to advertise in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres. The review is being managed by Advice and Advisors, New York.

description: When Jean-Sbastien Gigure of the Anaheim Mighty Ducks received the Conn Smythe trophy as the most valuable player of the Stanley Cup playoffs tonight, he became only the fifth player to win the award while playing for a losing team.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Ruling On School Busing
description: The State Supreme Court overturned a trial court decision to make the state reimburse DeKalb County $105 million for 24 years of busing to desegregate its schools. By law, the state pays counties to transport students to ''the school to which they are assigned,'' but it argued that the students were not attending their assigned schools. The students chose magnet schools or volunteered to go to schools outside their districts to increase racial diversity. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Broker Posts Profit
description: Merrill Lynch posted its first profit in Japan in three years as it pared an unprofitable brokerage business for individual investors in the world's second-biggest economy. Merrill estimates it earned net income of 973 million yen ($8.2 million) in the year ending March 31, 2003, a spokesman, Takayuki Inoue, said. The result compared with a 59.9 billion yen loss in the year earlier, when it booked one-time costs of restructuring its businesses.

title: Nursing Wounds
description: Thanks to news coverage, advertising campaigns and word of mouth, an increasing number of people are aware of the nation's nursing crisis. Hospitals around the country are reporting full-time shortages of registered nurses as high as 19 percent. Nurses are being recruited from as far away as India and the Philippines. Industry experts say that by 2020, this country could have 800,000 fewer nurses than it needs.

title: Baryshnikov Focuses, Naturally, on Baryshnikov
description: At 55, Mikhail Baryshnikov has found his true center. Appearing as a solo dancer in a fine new touring program he calls ''Solos With Piano or Not . . . an Evening of Music and Dance,'' he places the emphasis where it belongs: on himself.

(A news crawl on ABC's ''Good Morning America'' early on Monday even provided an answer: ''mutual intellectual'' attraction.)

description: For a generation, Haley Barbour has been a pillar of the Washington Republican establishment: a two-term party chairman, an adviser to presidents, a prodigious fund-raiser, a campaign strategist and a highly paid lobbyist for tobacco companies, pharmaceutical manufacturers, communications giants and others.

She will be remembered by all who knew her for her sharp intelligence and administrative aplomb. May her memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman >>AD#

title: So a Work's First Hearing Isn't a Beginning of the End
description: For a composer there is nothing more frustrating than waiting for other ensembles to take up a new work that has received a promising premiere. Sometimes it's harder to get those essential second, third and fourth performances than to get the initial commission. The main goal of the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble's adventurous Second Helpings series is to give a New York hearing to works commissioned and performed elsewhere. The last concert of this season's series took place on Saturday afternoon at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea.

title: In Britain, Rivals Uneasily Share Stage to Discuss the Euro
description: LONDON, June 10  As close and yet apart as Britain and Continental Europe, Prime Minister Tony Blair and the chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, sat side by side today at a rare joint news conference, beginning a campaign to promote a new consensus on Europe in a land historically aloof from the land mass across the English Channel.

title: Management Practice Enabled Huge Fraud, 2 Investigations Find
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chairman and chief executive of WorldCom, ran the company in a manner that fostered a long and extensive fraud executed by other senior executives, according to findings of two detailed investigations released yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Hikers Find Missing Boy's Clothes
description: The shoes and clothing of a boy from Littleton who vanished in October 1999 were found in the mountains. The boy, Jaryd Atadero, 3, was hiking with his sister, 6, and a church group when he ran ahead and disappeared. His father, Allyn Atadero, identified the clothing that hikers found on Friday 500 feet from the trail where Jaryd was last seen. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Orange: Probe Of Police Misconduct Ends
description: The Orange Police Department said yesterday that it had completed its investigation of six employees suspected of possible sexual misconduct. The department has concluded that only one employee, Police Officer Jose Taverner, 33, will be allowed to keep his job. Officer Taverner agreed to be suspended without pay for 30 days starting today. Mitchell R. Goldblatt, the town's first selectman, said Officer Taverner's misconduct, unlike that of the others, was not while he was in uniform or on duty. Last month, a civilian dispatcher and four police officers, including the assistant police chief, resigned in connection with the charges. The department has not detailed the misconduct. Meanwhile, a criminal investigation involving some of the same employees is continuing in neighboring Seymour. Alison Leigh Cowan (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Caliper To Acquire Zymark
description: The Caliper Technologies Corporation, which makes devices and systems for laboratory experiments, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Zymark Corporation for $72.7 million in cash and stock to gain access to software and robotics used by laboratory workers. Caliper will pay about $57 million in cash and 3.15 million common shares for Zymark, part of the Berwind Company, which is based in Philadelphia, Caliper said. Zymark, based in Hopkinton, Mass., had $65.4 million in revenue in 2002, Caliper said. Caliper gains Zymark's worldwide network to sell its technology, Caliper's chief financial officer, James Knighton, said. Caliper plans to move its headquarters to Hopkinton from Mountain View, Calif., after the transaction is completed. Kevin Hrusovsky, Zymark's chief executive, is set to become Caliper's chief executive, Caliper said. Michael Knapp, the chief executive and a co-founder of Caliper, will become chief technical officer.

title: Rival Says Oracle-PeopleSoft Deal Raises Antitrust Concerns
description: A three-way tug of war emerged yesterday when J. D. Edwards & Company made remarks that could put PeopleSoft, which plans to acquire J. D. Edwards, in a decidedly awkward position while it tries to fend off a hostile takeover from Oracle.

title: North Korea Says It Seeks To Develop Nuclear Arms
description: North Korea declared today for the first time that it was seeking to develop nuclear weapons so that it could reduce the size of a million-man army it can no longer afford.

description: Saying that he has brought school construction costs under control, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that one of the city's leading construction companies had agreed to build a long-delayed addition to Queens Vocational High School at a cost that was nearly 30 percent lower than the city has paid for recent school building projects.

title: Corrections

title: Corrections

She is Diane Vaughan, not Vaughn -- of Boston College, not Boston University. In some copies the article also misstated the year of the initial launching of the Columbia. It was 1981, not 1979.

description: LISBON, June 10 — Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that broad progress was being made in deploying Western forces and Iraqis to restore order in Iraq, though he conceded that there would be no quick end to a wave of violence there.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Mint Employees Seek Changes
description: Thirty-two women who work at the United States Mint in Denver have filed a class-action complaint with the Treasury Department, citing years of workplace gender discrimination and harassment. Of the 528 employees at the Denver mint, 127 are women. The complaint does not seek any punitive damages, and a lawyer for the women said their goal was to change practices at the mint. The mint said it took the accusations seriously. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: U.S. Troops in Afghanistan Kill 4 Taliban Suspects Near Border
description: American troops killed four suspected Taliban members in a three-hour gun battle on the Pakistani border, a military spokesman said today. The soldiers were on patrol when they came under attack shortly before dawn today, Col. Rodney Davis said. There were no American casualties.

title: PENN NATIONAL OFFERS MIXED OUTLOOK ON EARNINGS
description: Penn National Gaming Inc. raised its second-quarter profit estimate, but lowered its outlook for the year . The company, based in Wyomissing, Pa., said that it would earn 38 cents a share this period, more than its earlier estimate of 33 cents. Penn National is laying off workers and trimming marketing in Illinois after the state approved a casino tax increase starting next month. Pretax severance costs of $1 million at its Hollywood casino in Aurora, Ill., and $6.3 million in additional taxes will reduce earnings for the year. The company lowered its forecast to $1.29 a share from $1.31.

title: Retired Commando Chief Is Chosen to Lead the Army
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld broke with precedent today by reaching out to a retired Special Operations commander as his choice for Army chief of staff, sending an unmistakable signal of his desire to reshape the oldest and largest armed service.

title: For Mrs. Clinton, One Day, 200,000 Copies
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's memoir apparently set a record for first-day sales of a nonfiction book, selling about 200,000 copies on Monday, according to its publisher, Simon & Schuster.

title: Love Wins Out Against The Gods
description: Just moments into the overture of Rameau's miraculous final opera, ''Les Borades,'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Monday night, you knew you were in for a long, full evening of utterly vibrant music making. Under the conductor William Christie, an incomparable interpreter of this 18th-century French master, the musicians of Les Arts Florissants brought crackling rhythmic brio to the jaunty music. With two Baroque horns playing hunting calls from a low balcony to the left of the pit and two Baroque woodwinds erupting in dizzyingly virtuosic flights from the opposite balcony, you experienced the French Baroque equivalent of Surroundsound.

title: Albany Leaders Reach Accord On Ephedra Ban
description: State legislative leaders reached agreement today on adopting a ban on over-the-counter sales of the herbal supplement ephedra, which would make New York only the second state to do so even as Congress considers tightening restrictions on the product.

title: A Grim High Wire for Indian Girls
description: Some of the more unsettling images in ''Starkiss: Circus Girls in India,'' a documentary by the Dutch team of Chris Relleke and Jascha de Wilde, show smiling young girls in pink spangled miniskirts executing the grueling stunt that gives the movie its title. In the starkiss, a performer attached to a dangling rope by a bit in her mouth turns herself into a human top spinning wildly in midair. In one scene several rotating girls are choreographed into a kind of aerial ballet. The stunt is painful to master, one of them explains, because the early weeks of training leave the mouth and neck raw and aching, but eventually the body adjusts.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Drug Dealers Plead Guilty
description: Three reputed members of a Mexican drug cartel and an official with the government of Belize who was accused of aiding them have all pleaded guilty in federal court to narcotics trafficking charges. The cartel is accused of smuggling thousands of pounds of cocaine into the United States by ship. Two of the reputed cartel members, Victor Manuel Adan Carrasco and Oscar Moreno Aguirre, pleaded on Monday in federal court. Last month, Jorge Manuel Torres Teyer, whom prosecutors described as a high-ranking cartel director, and Liston McCord, of the Belizean fishing commission, pleaded guilty. All four men face a maximum sentence of life in prison. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Singapore Tightens SARS-Control System
description: Singapore may be off the World Health Organization's list of countries affected by SARS, the deadly respiratory virus, but the authoritarian island state, in an attempt to prevent the kind of relapse seen in Toronto, is toughening its already strict disease-control regimen.

But he made clear he did not intend to disarm the fighters, many of them children.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: MILITARY BUSINESS ACQUIRED The military electronics company L-3 Communications Holdings said it had agreed to buy the military aviation services unit of Bombardier to raise international sales and increase contracts with the United States military. L-3, which is based in New York, valued the deal at about $90 million and said it would add to earnings this year and next. The acquisition of the unit, which has about $80 million in annual revenue, is expected to be completed by the end of the third quarter.

title: A Japanese Heart Beating In a New American Work
description: That cultural exchange fosters artistic inspiration has been an article of faith at least since the late 19th century, when international expositions awakened artists from Debussy to W. S. Gilbert to the wonders of the Far East. Today such exchange is often formalized through programs and institutions, like the 96-year-old Japan Society, which in 2001 selected Lee Hyla as the first beneficiary of a new music-commissioning program.

title: Donald Regan, 84, Financier and Top Reagan Aide, Dies
description: Donald T. Regan, the steel-willed financier who was Treasury secretary and, later, an uncommonly powerful chief of staff to President Ronald Reagan until his bitter departure in 1987, died yesterday in Virginia. He was 84 and lived in Williamsburg, Va.

title: Flooding of S. Dakota Mine Stalls Plans for Laboratory
description: Severely hurting the chances of turning a former gold mine in South Dakota into an underground laboratory, the owner of the mine yesterday turned off its pumps, allowing water to begin accumulating in tunnels 8,000 feet below the surface.

title: Four Bidders Seen for Italian Yellow Pages
description: The auction of the directory business of Telecom Italia, Italy's dominant telephone company, has attracted bids from four consortiums that include many of the leading names in private equity investing, according to executives close to the transaction.

title: Corrections
description: A sports chart on Sunday comparing baseball players by the frequency of their home runs misidentified two men's teams in some editions. Richie Sexson plays for the Milwaukee Brewers, not the Chicago White Sox. Troy Glaus plays for the Anaheim Angels, not the White Sox.

title: The Monkeypox Warning
description: The outbreak of monkeypox in individuals who have handled exotic pets in the Upper Midwest and Northeast poses little danger to the general population -- there is no evidence it has spread from one human to another. But if it is not contained, the disease could become rooted in animal populations in this country. That could lead to periodic outbreaks like the one the United States is experiencing now or, even worse, the disease could mutate and become easily transmissible among humans. The episode has raised troubling questions about the adequacy of the nation's defenses against imported animal diseases. Most of all, it raises warning flags about the sale of exotic wild animals for pets.

title: Whittling at Forest Protections
description: From Day 1, as part of its general rollback of environmental protections, the Bush administration has sought to unravel the intricate tapestry of rules and regulations that have shielded the national forests from excessive logging and other commercial activity. In the last six months alone, the administration has finalized or proposed new rules that would short-circuit environmental reviews, restrict public participation in land-use decisions and weaken safeguards for endangered species. The White House says current rules are cumbersome and thwart other worthy purposes, like preventing forest fires. But the environmental community suspects, not without reason, that the administration's basic objective here is to open more of the forests to its friends in the timber industry.

title: Subpoenas Issued in Inquiry Into Sign Company Run by McGreevey's Ex-Aides
description: A federal grand jury investigating a billboard business run by two former top aides to Gov. James E. McGreevey has served subpoenas on the Democratic State Committee and the New Jersey secretary of state's office, according to lawyers involved in the case.

title: Immersed in the Dialogues of Beethoven
description: It must have been disappointing to the planners of the new concert series Free for All at Town Hall that even giving tickets away could not fill the 1,500-seat auditorium for either of their first two presentations this spring. But news of this worthy series seems to be spreading, and all the tickets for Sunday evening's recital by the cellist David Finckel and the pianist Wu Han were snatched up in two hours that afternoon, organizers said.

title: U.S. Archaeologists Paint a Mixed Picture of Looting Damage
description: Significant archaeological sites have been looted of tens of thousands of objects since the beginning of the war in Iraq, although some of the most famous of them have escaped unscathed, American archaeologists who surveyed the country last month reported today.

title: The Second Book of Poetry
description: Publishing a first book of poetry is not easy, but publishing a second can be even harder. Barnard College and W. W. Norton have created an award to honor -- and publish -- a second collection by a woman. The first award will go to REBECCA WOLFF for her book ''Figment.'' She will receive $1,500, and Norton will publish her book next April. The prize is part of ''Women Poets at Barnard'' and replaces a prize Barnard formerly awarded with Beacon Press for a first collection by a woman poet. ''A second book more firmly establishes a poet,'' said JILL BIALOVSKY, vice president and senior editor at W. W. Norton, who has published two books of poetry herself. ''As publishers, we thought it would be interesting for us to find poets we would want to nurture.'' SASKIA HAMILTON, a poet who directs Barnard's ''Women Poets'' program and teaches English there, said Ms. Wolff's book was chosen from among 50 submissions. Karen W. Arenson

title: Britain Says Use of Paxil By Children Is Dangerous
description: British drug regulators warned yesterday that GlaxoSmithKline's popular antidepressant Paxil causes depressed children to become more suicidal and should not be prescribed for them.

description: GARMISCH, Germany, June 11 — Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld called on the Atlantic Alliance today to find new ways of combating "the nexus of terror and weapons of mass destruction," which he called "the biggest threat" facing the countries of both "old" and "new" Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SERRANO, , BRAULIA. (NEE VAZQUEZ, ROMAN)
description: SERRANO -- Braulia. (Nee Vazquez - Roman). Died peacefully at home in New York City on June 4, 2003. Predeceased by husband Manuel Serrano-Martinez and son Victor Manuel Serrano. Born May 26, 1913 in Humacao, Puerto Rico, daughter of Benedicto Vazquez-Sosa and Dominga Roman-Gonzalez. She moved to New York in 1929. Survived by her children, Luz Maria Ruiz of Charlottesville, VA., Rafael Serrano of New Windsor, N.Y. and George Serrano of New York City. Also survived by her brother, Julio Vazquez-Roman, Grandchildren, Mary Anne Pace, Frank and Paul Ruiz, LuAnn Decker, Ralph and Andrew Serrano, 16 Great - Grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. She will always be remembered for her devotion to her family and her generosity to family, friends and strangers. >>AD#

After an intermission, eight dancers spill across the stage in a tumultuous cascade of shifting heaps and lifts that evoke struggles for domination.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: New Chief For Weapons Inspections
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan appointed Demetrius Perricos, a veteran weapons inspector, to be the acting executive chairman of the United Nations Monitoring, Verification and Inspection Commission upon the retirement of Hans Blix at the end of next month. A permanent replacement for Mr. Blix is not likely to be selected unless a new Security Council resolution resolves the issue of the return of inspectors to Iraq, according to a United Nations statement. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: The Rich Source Of Indulgence
description: WILLIAM EWART GLADSTONE, the great Victorian prime minister, called clotted cream ''the food of the gods.'' George Blake, a Briton who spied on his own country and now lives in exile in Moscow, said recently that the only thing he really misses from his homeland is clotted cream to crown the Christmas pudding that he makes for himself every year.

title: Watercress for Sandwiches That Can Spice Up a Tea Party
description: Watercress, which likes to keep its feet wet and flourishes in cool ponds and along stream banks, is best when very fresh. Some growers in the Greenmarket have watercress with a particularly lively, peppery flavor. At Union Square through the end of the month, Berried Treasures, left, has it for $2.50 a bunch on Fridays. On Saturdays, Eden Brook has wild watercress, $2.50 a bunch. Delicate French watercress that is stunningly sharp yet has a trace of sweetness, $12 a pound, will be available all summer at D'Attolico's Organic Farm on Saturdays in the Grand Army Plaza and Greenpoint markets in Brooklyn.

She is a lobbyist for Boeing on commercial aviation issues only, not on military-related matters.

title: Rumsfeld Sees Progress in Bringing Order to Iraq but No Quick End to Violence
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that American-led military forces and Iraqis had made broad progress restoring order in Iraq. But he said there would be no quick end to a wave of violence, which he attributed to remnants of Saddam Hussein's government and to criminals freed from jails not long before its collapse.

title: Read My Lips
description: Democrats have been groping for a way to counter George Bush's maniacal tax cuts, which are designed to shrink government and shift as many things as possible to the market. May I make a suggestion? When you shrink government, what you do, over time, is shrink the services provided by federal, state and local governments to the vast American middle class. I would suggest that henceforth Democrats simply ask voters to substitute the word ''services'' for the word ''taxes'' every time they hear President Bush speak.

A Chocolate Cafe on the fourth floor will be open during the run of the show, through Sept. 7, serving confections like the hot chocolate bread at right. description: NBTY Inc. agreed to buy the vitamin business Rexall Sundown from Royal Numico for $250 million. The sale is expected to be completed in the third quarter, a Numico spokeswoman, Elvira Luykx, said. The company, based in the Netherlands, is selling its vitamin units to focus on infant and clinical nutrition. The acquisition is the fourth in the past year for NBTY, which is based in Bohemia, N.Y. Numico bought Rexall Sundown, based in Boca Raton, Fla., in 2000 for $1.8 billion, and it paid $2.5 billion for the General Nutrition Companies in 1999 . It has since written down the value of those businesses by more than 1.5 billion euros ($1.8 billion).

title: Ugandan's Key to White House: AIDS
description: President Bush today embraced the president of Uganda, Yoweri Museveni, for his success in fighting AIDS, but said nothing publicly about what the White House views as Uganda's less inspiring role as a weapons supplier to militias in Congo's five-year-old civil war.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Hotel Stake Sold
description: A Goldman Sachs Group venture in Thailand sold its 41 percent stake in the Rajadamri Hotel Company, the owner of the Regent Hotel in Bangkok, for 801 million baht ($19 million). The Goldman venture, which also includes the Bangkok Hotel Holdings Company, sold the stake to the SCB Securities Company of Thailand. SCB sold 12.55 percent of the stake to Royal Garden Resorts, also of Thailand, which raised its stake in Rajadamri to 42.8 percent. The Regent, one of Thailand's most prestigious hotels, was the subject of a bidding war involving Goldman in 1999.

title: A Visitor to Toronto Is Stricken With SARS
description: A North Carolina man who visited Toronto last month has come down with SARS in another sign that the respiratory disease may be spreading here once again.

title: Larry Craig's Air Force Antics
description: Now and then a member of the House or Senate will do something so obnoxious that it calls the country's attention to one of the more repugnant aspects of Congress's normal operating procedures. Now it is Senator Larry Craig, a conservative Idaho Republican who advertises himself as a strong supporter of America's military. For the past month he has frozen hundreds of Air Force promotions, including those of pilots who risked their lives over Iraq, to bludgeon the Pentagon into transferring four additional C-130 transport planes to an Air National Guard base in Boise.

title: PeopleSoft Won't Go to Court To Stop Takeover Bid After All
description: PeopleSoft Inc., the target of a hostile takeover by Oracle, reversed plans yesterday to sue Oracle after having threatened to do so only a day earlier.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: BETTER-THAN-EXPECTED QUARTER FOR MICRON Micron Technology , the No. 2 maker of computer memory chips, said yesterday that its current quarter was going "a little bit better" than expected, because of strong chip production and cost-cutting. A company spokesman, Kipp A. Bedard, speaking at a Bear Stearns technology conference in New York, also said that Micron customers had indicated that they were shipping more personal computers this quarter than they had expected. Micron is cutting costs as part of a restructuring that stems partly from the worst downturn in demand for semiconductors on record. The chip company, which plans to close a Virginia plant, cut some product lines and trimmed its work force but has not posted a profit in more than two years. Mr. Bedard said Micron now expected to beat its earlier projections for production growth. In March, the company told investors to expect third-quarter production to grow by a percentage in the "midteens" over the second quarter. Mr. Bedard said the company expected capital spending to be close to $1.1 billion, rather than the $1 billion it had previously forecast. Shares of Micron rose 84 cents, or 6.8 percent, to $13.15. ( Reuters )

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: BID FOR GROCERY CHAIN One of Britain's largest retailers, Tesco, agreed to buy the C Two-Network grocery chain in Japan for 139 million ($229 million), entering the world's second-largest food market as growth in the British markets slows. Tesco, based in Cheshunt, England, is offering 3,400 yen ($28.79) for each share of C Two-Network, 27 percent more than the closing price on Monday. C Two-Network, based in Tokyo, does business under the brand names Tsurukame, Foodlet and Kamechuru.

title: HOCKEY: Stanley Cup Analysis; Devils and Wings Elite Teams of the Era
description: In June 1995, the Devils and the Detroit Red Wings met in the Stanley Cup finals, and the Devils were the surprising winners in a four-game sweep. At the time, it seemed like little more than a singular event in a competitive National Hockey League that had seen new champions almost every year after 1988, with different teams opposing them more often than not.

description: Euro RSCG MVBMS in New York withdrew yesterday from a review for the creative and strategic planning parts of the account of Subway Restaurants, thereby giving up assignments the agency had handled since March 2000. Although billings were not disclosed, Subway spent $218.6 million to advertise in major media last year, according to TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, part of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

There were snowy-haired older gentlemen, come to taste dishes they remember fondly and had not seen on menus for years; first-generation immigrants with a long-established propensity for the evening's fare; heavily tattooed young cooks; culinary students and curiosity seekers looking for the shock of the new.

title: Supermajority Rule
description: The appointment of judges with life tenure is a unique event in the American democratic system. Members of Congress and the president stay in power only if they convince voters to re-elect them -- and even popular presidents have to quit after two terms. But life-tenured federal judges serve for decades.

McCann, a former senior executive of Merrill Lynch who briefly oversaw its stock research operation, was named yesterday as a vice chairman of AXA Financial, the American unit of the big French insurer AXA. title: Black Group in South Africa To Buy Stake in Gold Mines
description: Gold Fields, one of the world's largest gold miners, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 15 percent stake in its South African operations to Mvelaphanda Resources for 4.1 billion rand ($516.4 million). The transaction is one of the biggest so far in South Africa's six-year effort to expand the role of blacks in owning and operating the country's gold industry.

title: Acevedo Is Gone; Contreras Is on D.L.
description: The Yankees restructured their pitching staff yesterday with one expected move and one unexpected move. They released Juan Acevedo, an anticipated transaction since he failed miserably in relief of Roger Clemens on Saturday in Clemens's bid for his 300th victory, and in a surprising development, they put Jos Contreras on the 15-day disabled list with a strained right shoulder.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Court Allows Same-Sex Marriages
description: Toronto announced that it would begin issuing marriage licenses to gay and lesbian couples after an Ontario appeals court's decision to permit legally binding same-sex marriages. The decision by the court, similar to two other high court decisions in Quebec and British Columbia in recent years, can still be challenged by the federal government in the Supreme Court. But the federal government put up no legal contest to a gay couple who said they planned to get married immediately. The Ontario Court of Appeals ruled that the federal law limiting marriage to heterosexuals violated the 1982 Charter of Rights and Freedoms, part of the Constitution. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Industrial Use Rises
description: Canadian industrial companies worked harder in the first quarter, using 82.8 percent of their capacity, as the lowest mortgage rates since the mid-1950's increased demand for housing and building materials. Capacity utilization, industrial production as a percentage of possible output, rose 0.3 percentage point in the quarter, Statistics Canada said. The government's statistics agency also cut its fourth-quarter estimate to 82.5 percent from 82.9 percent.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Indictments In Mob Case
description: A reputed captain of the Genovese crime family and 19 others were indicted yesterday on charges of racketeering, state law enforcement officials said. The charges involve loan-sharking, gambling, sports betting and drug distribution in central and northern New Jersey. The organized crime network, which operated out of the Blue Collar Inn in Garwood, in Union County, was supposedly headed by Ludwig (Ninny) Bruschi, the captain, for the North Jersey faction of the Genovese crime family based in New York, the authorities said. The indictment for Mr. Bruschi alleges that he supervised and approved loans at an interest rate of 156 percent per year. Repayment of the money was enforced by implied threats of violence, officials said. Maria Newman (NYT)

title: JetBlue Orders Regional Jets From Embraer for $3 Billion
description: The JetBlue Airways Corporation said yesterday that it was ordering 100 regional jets for $3 billion from Embraer, the Brazilian aircraft maker, in order to give its fleet more flexibility in adding routes.

title: NBC Hires FX Executive to Revamp Its Hit Machine
description: NBC, whose leadership in prime-time television has shrunk over the last two seasons, began a long-expected shake-up of its entertainment division yesterday, bringing in the probable successor to its entertainment chief, Jeff Zucker, while removing two executives most responsible for selecting prime-time shows.

description: HEMING--Charles E. The partners, associates, counsel and staff of Wormser, Kiely, Galef & Jacobs LLP note with sorrow the passing on June 6, 2003 of our partner and friend, Charles E. Heming, and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Barbara, and his family. Charles was one of the ''best and brightest'' and his loss will be felt deeply by us all. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: A grouping of thumbnail sketches on Sunday with a front-page article about efforts by interest groups to influence the selection of the next Supreme Court justice included an erroneous reference to the background of a potential nominee, Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit. (The error also occurred in a front-page article on Dec. 27.) Judge Alito is not a former clerk for Justice Antonin Scalia.

title: Reading Senator Clinton
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's new book, ''Living History,'' is a reminder that the memoir -- and especially the midcareer political memoir -- is an inherently insincere art form. Every autobiographical writer struggles with the question of how to create a portrait of the self. But for Senator Clinton, the portrait she is trying to create is both personal and political. Too personal, and the political self is compromised. Too political, and she risks sounding like a campaign poster. How she balances those two Hillarys creates the real tension in her book, not what she says about her wayward husband and Monica Lewinsky.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Brewer Bought
description: The Danish brewer Carlsberg bought the closely held Dali Beer Group, its second acquisition in about five months in southern China's Yunnan Province. Carlsberg and Dali, one of Yunnan's biggest brewers, declined to disclose the price. Carlsberg, based in Valby, Denmark, has been brewing beer in China since 1991. Dali, which makes a beer called CangEr Dali, has 41 percent of Yunnan's beer market, a Carlsberg spokeswoman said.

title: Plan for Congress to Examine Iraq Data Is Dismissed by G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 — Congressional Republicans today dismissed Democratic demands for a full, formal inquiry into United States prewar intelligence on Iraqi weapons programs, and rejected the idea that the Bush administration had "hyped or cooked" its information to make a case for war.

title: Senate Judicial Panel to Weigh Another Contentious Nomination
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  The bitter ideological fight about judicial nominations pitting Senate Democrats against the White House and Senate Republicans is expected to escalate on Wednesday, when the Judiciary Committee takes up the nomination of Bill Pryor, Alabama's attorney general.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURNS, , JOHN STUART
description: BURNS--John Stuart. On June 8, 2003. Born in Atlanta, a neighbor of Margaret Mitchell, a Yalie, a New Yorker and, finally, a resident of Cutalossa Road, Bucks County, PA. A patron of The Metropolitan Opera, fine restaurants and co-founder of a great wine cellar (remember the Leonardo Da Vinci). A wonderful, civilized beacon in an otherwise unstable world, Jack was loved by all who knew him. We will all miss his fine (wicked) sense of humor and gentle, good nature. AlexAnder and George needed someone with whom to share a fine Bordeaux and so they called him to table this past week. Jack, we knew and loved ye. Libby, Curt, Laure, Henry, Liz, Andy and Eric >>AD#

title: Bush Urges Congress to Approve Drug Benefit Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  President Bush today visited the home state of the speaker of the House, J. Dennis Hastert, in a push to get Congress to pass a Medicare prescription-drug plan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Survives Fall From Bridge
description: A 19-year-old man jumped from the mid-span of the Brooklyn Bridge just before midnight last night and survived, the authorities said. Two Coast Guard officers said they were patrolling under the bridge when they saw several police boats gathered, and they spotted the young man after they heard someone screaming for help. They pulled the man out of the water and described him as very cold, with cramps in his legs. At mid-span, the height of the roadway on the bridge is 135 feet tall. The officers were not sure if the man he had broken any bones or suffered any internal injuries. ''It was kind of shocking,'' said one of the Coast Guard officers, Chief Jeff Dyer. The man was taken to Pier 16, where he was treated. He was then taken to Bellevue Hospital Center in stable condition, said Detective Carolyn Chew. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Ice Cream Outreach
description: Eli Zabar, above, is serving soda fountain fare from a window on the sidewalk at Eli's on Third Avenue near 80th Street. He offers more than a dozen homemade ice cream and sorbet flavors, including pecan pie, peppermint stick, brownies and cream, summer berry and green apple; $2.75 for one scoop, $3.50 for two. Also, smoothies, milkshakes and malteds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHN, , LEON
description: KAHN--Leon. We mourn the loss of Leon Kahn, a native of the Shtetl of Eishyshok, partisan, Holocaust survivor, successful businessman and dedicated friend. Our condolences to his family. Dr. Yaffa Eliach, Shtetl Foundation David Eliach, Yitzhak and Shoshana Sonenson >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: TV MERGER EXAMINED The British Com- petition Commission may delay its report to the government on Granada's proposed acquisition of a smaller television company, Carlton Communications , to consult rivals on new concessions offered by the companies. The antitrust authority, which is scheduled to give its opinion on the merger to the trade and industry secretary, Patricia Hewitt, by June 25, is looking at new proposals for concessions, said Josie Gray, a spokeswoman for the commission. She declined to comment on their nature. (Bloomberg News)

title: Mother Charged With Murder In Death of Boy, 21 Months Old
description: A New Jersey woman with a history of abusing her children was charged yesterday with first-degree murder in the death last week of her 21-month-old son, the authorities said.

title: Teacher of the Year
description: An economics teacher at Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn, SHELDON MELTZNER, has been named Junior Achievement's 2003 National Teacher of the Year. He is the first New York teacher to receive the award, which includes a $2,000 cash prize. ''Under his direction, students have seen the light and leave with a better understanding of our economic system,'' said SAUL BRUCKNER, Murrow's principal.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Ballad Of Billy The Kid, Cont.
description: Gov. Bill Richardson said the state would assist in an investigation to determine if Billy the Kid was actually killed by Sheriff Pat Garrett in 1881. Governor Richardson said he would rely on volunteer help with forensic testing and DNA expertise, as well as from the state police and local historians. Once the evidence has been gathered, the governor will hold hearings and make a decision about how Billy the Kid died. He said the benefits to the state and to history outweighed any costs incurred. Mindy Sink (NYT)

description: WorldCom Officials Resign In Wake of Investigations

title: Irate Members Of Congress Talk of Inquiries Into Freddie Mac
description: Members of Congress promised today to investigate Freddie Mac, the government-chartered buyer of home mortgages, and they gained an influential ally, Alan Greenspan, in their efforts to end the company's special exemptions from securities laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLZMAN, , MYRNA (COHEN)
description: HOLZMAN--Myrna (Cohen). On June 6. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Alfred Holzman. Cherished sister of Shirley Carlin. Devoted mother of Patricia Holzman and Bonnie Tucker. Loving mother-inlaw of Francois Bohn and Jeffrey Tucker. Adored grandmother of Joanna Tucker. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends and will be remembered for her hospitality, generosity and her wonderful sense of humor. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Alzheimer's Foundation. Private funeral services were held today.

title: Judging by Where You Sit
description: Ideology matters when choosing judges -- perhaps too much, as the battles between President Bush and Senate Democrats show. But how much does ideology matter once judges are on the bench?

title: A Museum Tends the British Melting Pot
description: At each end of Brick Lane in the East End of London, little plastic flags offer visitors a warm welcome to Banglatown. With its textile shops, travel agencies, restaurants and halal butchers serving a thriving community of Bangladeshi immigrants, this bustling street could well have been transplanted from the Indian subcontinent.

title: A Midtown Korean With Downtown Verve
description: THE aroma of wood smoke, sweet and penetrating, makes a powerful first impression at 36 Bar and Barbecue, a tiny, enormously appealing Korean barbecue restaurant. It rises from the metal baskets, filled with chunks of glowing charcoal, that are sent to each table in the course of a meal. The incenselike smoke, mingled with the scent of beef or scallops sizzling on a copper mesh grill, has an intoxicating, even paralyzing effect on diners entering the restaurant. It sets off every pleasure alarm in the American palate, keenly attuned to the artistry of the grill.

title: After Criticism, House Republicans Rewrite Head Start Provision
description: Facing intense criticism as they work to reshape Head Start, House Republicans today rewrote a provision of the bill that had attracted the most opposition from child welfare advocates.

title: 2 WorldCom Executives, Faulted in Bankruptcy Inquiry Report, Resign
description: Michael H. Salsbury, WorldCom's general counsel, and Susan Mayer, the treasurer, resigned yesterday, a day after a bankruptcy court examiner's report raised questions about their roles in the company's collapse.

title: OPEC Leaves Oil Production Levels Unchanged
description: DOHA, Qatar, June 11  Responding to high oil prices and the continued uncertainty about the return of Iraqi oil exports to world markets, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to leave current levels of oil production unchanged at 25.4 million barrels a day.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Keeps Raid Papers Sealed
description: A judge decided yesterday that the press did not have the right to see sealed documents on the mistaken police raid on Alberta Spruill's home. The documents are application materials submitted before a search warrant is approved. Ms. Spruill, 57, above, suffered a heart attack and died after the police threw a concussion grenade into her Harlem apartment on May 16. Newsday, The New York Times and The Daily News petitioned the court. Justice Brenda S. Soloff of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, denying the petition, wrote that there was no ''significant need'' to unseal the documents because ''virtually every fact'' had already been released by the police in their recent report on mistakes in the raid. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NONNENMACHER, , CARL EUGEN, AKA CARL EUGEN NORRIS
description: NONNENMACHER--Carl Eugen, aka Carl Eugen Norris was born in Brooklyn, NY, May 29, 1909. He died Friday June 6, 2003 at the age of 94 of natural causes at 300 Willow Valley Lakes Dr., Willow St., PA. He was the son of the late Eugen and Marie Hubler Nonnenmacher. His elementary education was in the public schools of New York City; his secondary education in New Jersey. After the graduation form Ramsay High School in Ramsay, NJ, he attended and graduated from Pratt School of Fine and Applied Arts in Brooklyn, NY Class of 1930. He owned and operated his own business, Intramural, Inc., in New York City-specializing in interior design for public areas in corporate headquarters' buildings and apartment complexes. He was a member of A.S.I.D., American Society of Interior Design. At his retirement in 1983 he moved to Charlotte, NC where he lived until 1988 when he moved to Willow Valley Lakes Manor, Lancaster, PA. He was a member of the First United Methodist Church, Lancaster, PA. He is survived by a sister, Frieda Nonnenmacher of North Bergen, NJ, a brother, Richard Nonnenmacher husband of Virginia of St. Cloud, FL and two nieces, Linda Doyle of Bainbridge, GA and Nancy Raymer of Madison, WI. He was preceded in death by a brother, Herman Nonnenmacher. Funeral services will be private, interment will be at Gracelawn Memorial Park, Wilmington, DE. >>AD#

description: In the 160,000-year-old fossilized skulls of three Ethiopians  two adults and a child  scientists think they see for the first time the faces of the immediate ancestors of modern humans.

title: Former Chief Of ImClone Is Given 7-Year Term
description: A federal judge yesterday sentenced Samuel D. Waksal, the founder and former chief executive of ImClone Systems, to more than seven years in prison for securities fraud, perjury and other crimes he committed while orchestrating ImClone stock trades for himself and family members at the end of 2001.

title: Reyes's Arrival Is Special Moment for the Mets
description: A handful of veteran Mets gathered around the plush sofas in the visitors' clubhouse this afternoon at the Ballpark, the Texas Rangers' home, to watch ''American Pie 2'' on the large-screen television dominating one end of the room. A few feet away, a television cameraman made his way to the empty locker with the No. 7 jersey hanging in front of it. A broadcaster noted that it was Mickey Mantle's number. The Mets' future was arriving any moment.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Aggressive Fish Landed
description: A 38-pound Asian bighead carp caught at a seven-acre pond is the first of the species to be found in the Chicago area. Tom Trudeau, a Lake Michigan Fisheries Program manager, said someone probably placed it in the McKinley Park pond. Asian carp, an aggressive fish that can grow to 80 pounds, have been making their way north into Illinois after escaping fish farms in Mississippi and Arkansas. Illinois built a $1.6 million electric fence in a ship canal last year to keep the fish out of Lake Michigan, where they might deplete native species. The pond where the carp was found has no outlet to Lake Michigan. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: BRUNSWICK BUYS GAME MAKER FOR $34.5 MILLION
description: The Brunswick Corporation acquired Valley-Dynamo L.P. for $34.5 million. Valley-Dynamo, based in Richland Hills, Tex., makes commercial and consumer pool, foosball and table hockey products. Brunswick, based in Lake Forest, Ill., said it was attracted by Valley-Dynamo's brand recognition. The company will seek to expand sales of Valley-Dynamo products and reduce costs by adding it to its Brunswick Billiards division.

title: Mr. Freeman, You Look Divine
description: In 1898 a prominent black minister named Henry McNeal Turner wrote an essay titled, ''God Is a Negro.'' When even some of Turner's fellow members of the African Methodist Episcopal denomination objected, he replied in print that ''every other race of people since time began'' envisioned God in its image. ''Why should not the Negro,'' he concluded, ''believe that he resembles God as much so as other people?''

title: Israeli Missiles Kill 5 Palestinians in Gaza
description: In two airstrikes that further damaged an already fragile Middle East peace plan, Israeli helicopters today rained missiles on cars carrying Hamas militants. Five Palestinians were killed, but the prominent Hamas leader who was the main target survived and vowed revenge from his hospital bed.

title: Critic of Burmese Junta Not Hurt, Envoy Says
description: A United Nations envoy said Myanmar's pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, showed no sign today of having been injured in an attack on her supporters that killed and injured scores of people.

description: We Prefer Marshing the Mellow

title: Making the Case Against the Cake
description: THE case against wedding cake is easy. It's made at nearly every wedding, by nearly all the guests. About an hour before the end of the party, along with sequined purses and lipstick-smeared napkins, each table is graced by identical sticky, gluey slices. Which, unless the couple has gone terribly wrong with their choice of band, will still be languishing when the guests have gone.

title: New Dean at Jewish Seminary
description: DR. STEVEN M. BROWN has been named dean of the William Davidson Graduate School of Jewish Education at the Jewish Theological Seminary, effective July 1. He will succeed DR. ARYEH DAVIDSON, who was the school's first dean and supervised its transition from a department within the graduate school.

title: French Strike Against Cuts In Pensions Jams Traffic
description: Striking government workers tied up traffic in Paris today for the third time in a month to protest a bill that would slash retirement benefits. Legislators may vote on it within a few weeks.

title: Here Comes the Cake (And It Actually Tastes Good)
description: CHANCES are, you'll see some wedding cake this summer. Some 4.6 million people marry each year in the United States. Most do so between May and October, and a big cake is still the showpiece of most wedding receptions. In 2002, Americans spent almost $2 billion on wedding cake, according to the Association for Wedding Professionals International.

title: Three Slaying Victims Called 'Clean, Hard-Working People'
description: Grieving relatives of the three people shot to death Monday in a quiet Queens neighborhood opened the morning papers yesterday hoping for more details about the puzzling slayings and some hint of who the killers could be.

title: Women, Embracing Across Generations, Find Life in Memory
description: As with just about everything written by Marguerite Duras, her two-character play ''Savannah Bay'' wears its haunting quality on its sleeve. Its refracted dialogue, its evanescent scene-setting, the wary dance of its characters and their obliquely recalled memories of erotic love and death are meant to seduce you with life's most titillating mysteries and to provoke a curiosity about form and content in narrative art.

title: Make a List
description: Politics and ideology are often blamed for giving us poor judges. But neither can be removed from the judicial selection process. The trick is to devise a system that limits their influence.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Debt Agreement Advances
description: The Asia Pulp and Paper Company, which is negotiating with creditors over $6.4 billion in debt, said as many as one-third had signed a rescheduling agreement. Asia Pulp, which is based in Singapore, has reached agreement with 20 percent to 30 percent of its creditors, Joel Hogarth, a lawyer for the company, said. Asia Pulp won agreement earlier in Jakarta from the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency and export credit agencies from countries including Germany and Japan. Under Indonesian bankruptcy law, the company needs the approval of 67 percent of creditors for the restructuring to go ahead.

title: Jailed Religious Leader in China in Poor Health
description: BEIJING, June 11  The jailed leader of an evangelical Christian sect has severe health problems as a result of beatings and mistreatment in prison, according to relatives and supporters.

title: A Summertime Red That's Friends With Charcuterie and Chicken Salad
description: OF the two styles of Valpolicella -- the thick and jammy and the more traditional light and berried -- I prefer the lighter. This is a splendid red wine to drink during the summer months because it has lovely character. Fresh berries and herbs pronounce themselves, and while the flavor is not concentrated, the structure of the wine is ample. Its aromas will hang around to surprise you, even on the second glass.

title: Egan Refuses to Reveal Decisions On Priests in Sex Abuse Inquiries
description: A year after America's Roman Catholic bishops promised a new openness in addressing a sexual abuse scandal, Cardinal Edward M. Egan has declared that he will not publicly disclose the outcome of the internal investigations of New York Archdiocese priests accused of molesting minors.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Flextronics Will Close Some Plants
description: Flextronics International, the world's largest maker of electronics for other companies, will close more circuit-board plants because they are losing money, the vice president for finance, Thomas J. Smach, said yesterday. ''We continue to lose 2 to 3 cents a share each quarter after some pretty heavy restructuring,'' Mr. Smach said at Bear Stearns's technology conference in New York. ''We do plan on closing a couple more factories.'' He did not say how many jobs would be cut. Flextronics, based in Singapore and with offices in San Jose, Calif., previously said a decision about plant closings would come this quarter. The company shut factories in California and Sweden in December. The plants make boards for mounting chips and electronic components.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: After $1 Billion, Soros Exits
description: The billionaire philanthropist George Soros has effectively shuttered the Russian operations of his Open Society Institute, saying the nation has weathered the crises of its birth and no longer needs outside support to survive. Mr. Soros, 72, has poured some $1 billion into promoting democratic causes in Russia, starting during Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reign as Soviet leader in 1988. Mr. Soros said at a news conference that he continued to worry that Russia's handful of billionaire financiers and industrialists would become a shadow government, stifling the move toward democratic rule, but predicted that their interests were too varied to band together to control Russia's future. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Five Powerful Little Words
description: With six days left in the legislative session, New York State's lawmakers still have time to close a very large gap in the lobbying laws. The scandalous loophole allows powerful lobbyists to peddle their clients to state agencies and authorities in secret. Assemblyman Alexander Grannis and State Senator Frank Padavan have proposed a five-word addition to the state's lobbying law that would extend it to cover attempts to influence any official action. If it was passed, lobbyists would have to report the money spent on efforts to get contracts from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for subway cars or from the State Board of Elections for voting machines, to name a very few contracts worth an awful lot of money.

title: Arena Is Not a Fan Of Confederations Cup
description: The United States leaves today for France to play in the FIFA Confederations Cup and Coach Bruce Arena, echoing comments from his European counterparts, said the tournament comes at a difficult time for his top players.

title: U.S. Opens Criminal Inquiry Into Freddie Mac
description: Freddie Mac was notified that it is the subject of federal securities and criminal investigations today, two days after it fired its president and chief operating officer and accepted the resignations of its other two top executives.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Lowers Forecasts
description: Texas Instruments, the world's largest maker of cellular phone chips, cut second-quarter sales and profit forecasts yesterday as demand in Asia fell short of its expectations. Sales will increase about 5 percent from the first quarter's $2.19 billion and profit will be about 6 cents a share, the company said in a statement. Net income was 5 cents on sales of $2.16 billion a year earlier. Last month the company, which is based in Dallas, reaffirmed profit and sales projections it made in April. Texas Instruments on May 5 predicted profit of about 8 cents a share, and a sales increase of about 7 percent from the first quarter. Texas Instruments will cut 250 jobs in Japan, in addition to the 1,250 workers the company said in April that it would lay off. Shares of Texas Instruments rose 17 cents, to $20.39.

title: Bush Rebukes Israel for Attack in Gaza
description: President Bush sharply rebuked Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's government today after it tried to kill a Palestinian militant leader, asserting that the Israeli action undermined recent Middle East peace efforts.

title: PRESCRIPTION PLAN DRAWS SKEPTICISM
description: The government is facing considerable skepticism from managed care companies and drug makers as chances grow that Congress will pass legislation to provide prescription drug coverage to the elderly.

title: Court Affirms Need to Limit Judges' Rights To Free Speech
description: New York's highest court ruled today that limitations on judges' right to free speech were necessary to preserve the public's confidence in the judiciary's fairness and impartiality.

title: Travel Slump Makes Prices Right for Hotel Buyers
description: Of the 282 hotels in the United States that fly the Sheraton or Four Points by Sheraton flag, only one in six is actually owned by Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc., the company that controls the Sheraton brand and several other well-known hotel trademarks.

title: Spectacular Bid Is Dead at Age 27; Crown Attempt Was Foiled by a Pin
description: Spectacular Bid, a charcoal gray colt whose attempt to win the Triple Crown in 1979 was waylaid on the morning of the Belmont Stakes by a mysterious safety pin, died Monday at age 27.

title: Robbed of White Knight Role, Council Changes Horses
description: Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, lost a game of dominoes to an 88-year-old on Monday at a center for the elderly in Washington Heights. He visited the sea lions at the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn yesterday. Today he plans to visit a prenatal care clinic in Harlem.

title: Miso Marries Sesame
description: SESAME seeds and miso, each widely used in Japanese cooking, lead to stunning results together. The five-minute dressing made from this duo is one of my favorite recent discoveries. I cannot seem to get enough of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCH, , JACK
description: HIRSCH--Jack. Heartfelt condolences to the Hirsch family on the loss of Jack Hirsch, husband of Gladys, father of Stuart and Bryan, brother of Benjamin Hirsch and our beloved Reverend A. Asher Hirsch, Golden Founder and Director of Religious Affairs at Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem. As a Diamond Founder of the Medical Center together with his wife Gladys, Jack inspired many to follow his lead. Involved in nurturing the future of the Jewish community, he set a high standard and will be greatly missed. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The family requests that donations be made to Shaare Zedek Medical Center. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem >>AD#

title: For Fathers Who Prefer the Bar to the Grill
description: With the dollar's slide, even having a couple of drinks at Bar Hemingway in the Ritz hotel in Paris is a splurge. So do the next best thing: mix yourself a drink at home and page through ''The Cocktails of the Ritz Paris'' by Colin Peter Field (Simon & Schuster, $19.95). With the light sophistication of a Cole Porter song, Mr. Field, the head bartender at Bar Hemingway, gives cocktail history and lore with advice on concocting drinks. The book, linen-bound with charming illustrations by Yoko Ueta (including martini-swilling rabbits and kangaroos), is not an encyclopedia, but still might make a nice Father's Day gift. Mr. Field spends pages on the martini but does not tell how to make the classic version. The recipes are given in proportions, in tenths, not in spoons or ounces. He describes a New Age martini without alcohol, but that recipe is another mystery.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: MINT EMPLOYEES SEEK CHANGES Thirty-two women who work at the United States Mint in Denver have filed a class-action complaint with the Treasury Department, citing years of workplace gender discrimination and harassment. Of the 528 employees at the Denver mint, 127 are women. The complaint does not seek any punitive damages, and a lawyer for the women said their goal was to change practices at the mint. The mint said it took the accusations seriously. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bid For Grocery Chain
description: One of Britain's largest retailers, Tesco, agreed to buy the C Two-Network grocery chain in Japan for 139 million ($229 million), entering the world's second-largest food market as growth in the British markets slows. Tesco, based in Cheshunt, England, is offering 3,400 yen ($28.79) for each share of C Two-Network, 27 percent more than the closing price on Monday. C Two-Network, based in Tokyo, does business under the brand names Tsurukame, Foodlet and Kamechuru.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, , ANNA
description: GREENBERG--Anna. A memorial service will take place on Friday, June 20 at 11AM at the Reform Temple of Forest Hills, 71-11 112 St, Forest Hills >>AD#

title: U.S. Tries to Counter Anti-American Protests Due in Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 11  The United States mounted a public relations offensive today in anticipation of some of the biggest expressions of anti-Americanism here in years.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the dismantling of a rusty tower by an Israeli settlement in the West Bank as a gesture of compliance with the American-led peace initiative misstated the origin of Israeli control of the territory. During the 1967 war, Israel seized the West Bank from Jordan and took Gaza from Egypt, not from the Palestinians.

title: Euro Brings Blair and Rival Together, if Not in Accord
description: Like a metaphor for Britain and continental Europe close and yet apart -- Prime Minister Tony Blair and his finance minister, Gordon Brown, sat side by side today at a rare joint news conference, opening a campaign to promote a new consensus on Europe in a nation historically aloof from the landmass across the English Channel.

title: Suspected Case of Monkeypox Is Investigated in New Jersey
description: State health officials said today that they were investigating a suspected case of monkeypox in an 11-year-old boy who moved last week to North Jersey from Indiana.

title: Mussina Puts Yankees, and Himself, Back on Track
description: As Mike Mussina finished his follow-through, he saw and heard Richard Hidalgo hammer a line drive toward third base, and he crouched while he awaited the outcome. If the smash found a hole, the Houston Astros would grab the lead. If the liner settled in someone's glove, the Yankees would still be ahead by a run and Mussina could exhale.

title: Liberty Bounces Back Against Rockers
description: The Cleveland Rockers defeated the Liberty in its season opener on May 31. The Liberty players left the court embarrassed and humiliated after a 24-point loss before 7,317 fans at Gund Arena in Cleveland.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Irish Move To Close Nuclear Plant
description: Ireland took its long battle against a British nuclear plant to an international court in The Hague, asserting that the Sellafield complex on Britain's northwest coast pollutes the Irish Sea with radioactive waste. It also charged that international transports of nuclear waste to the on-site waste treatment plant created a risk of a terrorist attack. Hearings at the court, the Permanent Court of Arbitration, may last until the end of the month. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Accusations Flying in Nassau Over Reassessments of Property
description: Nassau County's chief assessor accused a review board today of undermining the fairness of the new countywide reassessment by cutting the valuations on many properties to less than market prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GESTAS, , GILBERT
description: GESTAS--Gilbert. Age 70. On June 7, 2003. Antiquaire, Veteran of France, Raconteur, Bon Vivant and Friend to All. Beloved partner of Craig Morrison. Devoted brother of Guy, Yvonne, Jeanine, Heugette and Jean Claude. A Mass and celebration of his life will be scheduled at a later date. >>AD#

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Wire One To Sell Unit To Gores
description: Wire One Technologies, a videoconferencing services provider whose shares have risen 36 percent in the last year, will sell its video equipment resale business to the Gores Technologies Group for as much as $25 million. Wire One's chief executive, Richard Reiss, said in an interview yesterday that Gores would pay $22 million in cash and a $1 million note for Wire One's Video Solutions unit. Gores, a closely held buyout firm, may pay an additional $2 million if the business meets projections, he said. Selling the equipment unit will allow Wire One to focus on adding customers to its Glowpoint service, which lets clients hold videoconferences with television-picture quality, using a high-speed network, Mr. Reiss said.

title: 4 Arrested in Plot to Bomb Embassies and Resorts in Thailand
description: The police have arrested four suspected members of a terrorist group that planned to bomb embassies and resorts in Thailand, officials said today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Like a Sliver of Sashimi on Clinton Street
description: EVEN before WD-50 opened in April, it glowed under a blazing spotlight as the centerpiece of Clinton Street's thriving restaurant culture. Almost lost in its shadow are the unusual little restaurants that continue to spring up on Clinton from Houston to Rivington.

title: PeopleSoft Bid Mirrors Lofty Goals of Oracle Chief
description: Lawrence J. Ellison, the 58-year-old chairman of Oracle, whose hobbies include yachting and piloting jet-fighter planes, has earned his reputation as one of the most flamboyant and outspoken executives in corporate America.

title: Phil Niekro to Clemens: Been There, Done That
description: Phil Niekro has walked where Roger Clemens is walking, and he has stalked what Clemens is stalking. Eighteen years ago, Niekro chased his 300th victory with the Yankees, and like Clemens's pursuit, his chase proved futile for a while.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: General Says He May Surrender
description: The third-most-wanted war crimes suspect at the international war crimes court in The Hague said he would talk to investigators from the court and surrender for trial if he could not convince them of his innocence. Ante Gotovina, a former Croatian Army general, was indicted by the United Nations court in July 2001 for atrocities against ethnic Serbs committed when Croatian forces swept through the Krajina region in 1995. Mr. Gotovina made the offer of a possible surrender in an interview with the Croatian weekly Nacional. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: U.S. Resolution on World Court Revives Hostility
description: An American resolution that would extend United States citizens' immunity from the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court has rekindled some of the trans-Atlantic hostility that led to the diplomatic debacle over the Iraq war.

title: Suicide Adds Latest Twist To 5-Year-Old Murder Case
description: When Heyward and Ellen Brown were found bludgeoned to death inside their ransacked Long Island home more than five years ago, the police suspected it was a burglary. But almost from the start, the pieces did not all appear to fit: the burglar alarm had not been tripped, for example, and the middle-class neighborhood was generally safe.
