title: G.O.P. Leader Brushes Off Pressure by Bush on Taxes
description: A powerful Republican leader in the House today dismissed pressure from the White House to pass a Senate bill that would provide child tax credits for low-income working people. The action highlights a potential clash between President Bush's desire for legislative achievements ahead of next year's election and demands from conservatives in his party.

title: Venturing Beyond Beethoven's Sonatas
description: For the last few years the Mannes College of Music has extended its academic year with a series of summer performance institutes devoted to a handful of specialties, each of which includes master classes and public concerts. The first, which opened with a faculty recital on Sunday evening and runs through Saturday, is the Mannes Beethoven Institute, now in its third year. Still to come are series devoted to the keyboard repertory more generally and to the classical guitar. (For the record there is also a series of workshops on advanced music theory.)

title: Suicide Blast Kills 16 in Jerusalem; Israel Strikes Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, June 11 - A Palestinian bomber disguised as an Orthodox Jew detonated himself tonight on a crowded bus, killing 16 other people, wounding nearly 100 and dealing another blow to the newly born American-led plan to find peace between Israelis and Palestinians.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The S.E.C. takes aim at hidden commissions that are said to mask the true cost of mutual funds.
description: CONGRESS should tighten the rules on ''soft dollar'' commissions by limiting the types of services that mutual funds can obtain with such payments, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in a report released yesterday.

title: City Gets Pledge of $30 Million For a School Principals' Institute
description: A leading New York City business organization has pledged $30 million to finance a new training institute for school principals, Caroline Kennedy, the school system's chief fund-raiser, announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Forces Detain 400 Iraqis in a Large-Scale Roundup
description: THULUIYA, Iraq, June 11  American forces completed their largest combat operation in Iraq since the fall of Baghdad today, with more than 3,000 soldiers backed by fighter jets, armored vehicles and patrol boats surrounding a 30-square mile peninsula north of Baghdad that is said to harbor gunmen attacking American soldiers.

description: Although they look like ordinary office buildings from the outside, the two buildings that constitute the International Toy Center at Fifth Avenue and 24th Street work to a very different rhythm: Their corridors and showrooms are either almost empty or they are teeming with buyers and salespeople.

title: Archdiocese of Louisville Reaches Abuse Settlement
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Louisville announced yesterday that it would pay a settlement of $25.7 million to 243 people who say they were sexually abused by priests, religious brothers and employees of the Kentucky archdiocese.

title: Shelters Win Right to Evict Rule Violators
description: Homeless men and women who are repeatedly disruptive and noncooperative may be evicted from city shelters, a New York State appellate court ruled yesterday.

title: As Monkeypox Rises, Smallpox Vaccines Will Be Offered
description: Federal health officials are expected to announce today that smallpox vaccinations will be made available to certain people who have been exposed to prairie dogs and other animals infected with monkeypox in recent days.

title: 8 Men Are Charged With Gang Violence
description: Eight Brooklyn men who the authorities said terrorized Russian immigrants with escalating violence over several years were indicted yesterday on charges that included racketeering, illegal gambling, loansharking and running an Ecstasy ring.

title: Agreeing to Protect Giant Treasures, but How?
description: President Bill Clinton stood at the base of a towering 1,000-year-old tree here three years ago and proclaimed the creation of the Giant Sequoia National Monument, thus making Art Gaffrey's life a splendid misery.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Steady Quarter At Cadbury
description: Cadbury Schweppes, one of the world's largest soft drink producers and a leading maker of sweets, said earnings in the first half of the year were unchanged because of poor market conditions, particularly in the beverages market in the United States and the Asia-Pacific region. Cadbury said its Americas Beverages division, which accounts for about 70 percent of sales, would be ''modestly'' ahead of last year, but that it had been affected by poor weather and weak consumer spending. Its drink brands include Dr Pepper, 7Up and Red Fusion. The chief executive of Cadbury Schweppes, Todd Stitzer, said earnings had made progress in the first six months of the year, but that growth was offset by the cost of acquisitions.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BRONX: POLICE OFFICERS INJURED IN CRASH Two police officers, responding to a police call for assistance, crashed their patrol car early yesterday, the police said. One had a broken ankle, and the other bruises. The officers' names were not released. The circumstances of the crash, into a tree near the corner of Bailey Avenue and Van Cortlandt Avenue West, were not disclosed. The officers were listed in stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center, the police said. Other officers had called for assistance responding to an armed robbery of a 49-year-old man, and they arrested two 16-year-old boys. The man was not injured, and a third suspect may have escaped.

title: Another Concert on Long Island Airfield Is Canceled
description: The week after permit problems forced a major outdoor music festival to be moved to Giants Stadium from a former airfield on the East End of Long Island, organizers yesterday canceled a three-day concert that had been scheduled at the same site in August.

title: NEWELL RUBBERMAID NAMES NEW CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Newell Rubbermaid Inc. promoted J. Patrick Robinson to chief financial officer. He succeeds William T. Alldredge, who will retire at the end of the year. Mr. Robinson, 47, joined the company in June 2001 as controller from AirClic Inc., where he was the chief financial officer. Mr. Alldredge, 63, has been with Newell Rubbermaid for 20 years and was named chief financial officer in January 2001, the company said. Mr. Robinson spent 18 years at the Black & Decker Corporation, where he worked with Newell's chief executive, Joseph Galli. Newell is based in Atlanta.

title: Going for Depth Instead of Prep
description: IMAGINE a school where the principal hates tests as much as the kids do. Easy school, right?

title: Powell Visits Argentina and Finds It Wary on Foreign Policy
description: Argentina's new government greeted Secretary of State Colin L. Powell politely but cautiously today, expressing hopes for a more constructive United States role in the country's economic recovery while sidestepping any ties to Washington's foreign policy objectives.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Police Officers Injured In Crash
description: Two police officers, responding to a police call for assistance, crashed their patrol car early yesterday, the police said. One had a broken ankle, and the other bruises. The officers' names were not released. The circumstances of the crash, into a tree near the corner of Bailey Avenue and Van Cortlandt Avenue West, were not disclosed. The officers were listed in stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center, the police said. title: CLOSING OF INTERNET UNIT MAY COST SPRINT $475 MILLION
description: The Sprint Corporation said it would have pretax costs of as much as $475 million to close its Internet-site management operation and eliminate 500 jobs. The company will record $300 million of the costs, or 20 cents a share, at its local- and long-distance unit this quarter, Sprint said. The Internet unit had reduced annual net income by 10 cents a share. The company, based in Overland Park, Kan., will also have costs of 1 cent a share at its long-distance and wireless units related to severance packages for three former employees, it said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYON, , ALICE
description: LYON--Alice, age 68, on June 6, 2003, of Sag Harbor, NY. Beloved wife of Larry Perrine. Loving mother of Cecil and Maya Auchincloss and sister of Dr. Lilla Lyon. Alice was the granddaughter and daughter of diplomats and lived the world over. She spoke five languages, painted, entertained with flair and loved her friends and family with a depth and loyalty unmatched. She worked for the C.I.A., acted in movies, sold real estate and served her community. All who met her knew she was the loveliest, gentlest, kindest soul they had known. A memorial service will be held for Alice on Tuesday, June 17 at 12 noon at Christ Episcopal Church in Sag Harbor, NY, followed by a reception at Channing Daughters Winery in Bridgehampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978-7048. >>AD#

It showed Jonathan Becker, a photographer for Vanity Fair, not Francesco Galesi, a director from 1992 to 2002.

title: Ice Cream Outreach
description: Eli Zabar, at right, is serving soda fountain fare from a window on the sidewalk at Eli's on Third Avenue near 80th Street. He offers more than a dozen homemade ice cream and sorbet flavors, including pecan pie, peppermint stick, brownies and cream, summer berry and green apple; $2.75 for one scoop, $3.50 for two. Also, smoothies, milkshakes and malteds.

title: Knicks' Houston Has Knee Surgery
description: Allan Houston had arthroscopic surgery on his right knee yesterday. The operation, which took place at Beth Israel Hospital, is considered routine and was done to clean out loose pieces of cartilage and to stimulate growth of the cartilage, according to Dr. Norman Scott, the Knicks' team physician, who performed the operation.

title: Party for Devils? More Confetti, Less Asphalt, Fans Say
description: Twelve hours after the New Jersey Devils won the Stanley Cup, the team's owners said today that they had not yet figured out exactly how to celebrate.

title: Mayo From Spain, Wearing a Juice Box
description: For this year's picnics, consider packing neat boxes of mayonnaise and aioli from Spain, which do not need to be refrigerated until they are opened. Made by ArteOliva, they come in packs of three, with 4.2 ounces of dressing in each box. Though the labels say they are made with olive oil, the main component is sunflower seed oil. The mayonnaise is not as sweet as Hellmann's, and the aioli is tangy but not aggressively garlicky. You are likely to use every drop. At Dean & DeLuca the mayonnaise is $4, at Fairway the mayonnaise is $2.49, the aioli $2.79.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Noisy Car Alarms
description: The City Council's committee on environmental protection has scheduled a public hearing on the enforcement of the noise code and whether legislation should be drafted to ban the sale and installation of audible motor vehicle alarms. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (718) 217-4969.

title: Cuba Pop Star Defects to U.S. By Walking Across Border
description: One of Cuba's leading pop stars, Carlos Manuel, defected after crossing a bridge spanning the Mexican-United States border over the weekend and was released today by immigration authorities in South Texas.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Three-Way Extradition
description: In a decision hailed as strengthening international justice, the Supreme Court upheld the extradition of an Argentine ex-navy officer to Spain on charges of torture, genocide and terrorism during Argentina's 1976-1983 military dictatorship. The Argentine, Ricardo Miguel Cavallo, was arrested three years ago in Cancn. The Spanish judge Baltasar Garzn, who tried to extradite the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet to Spain to face charges relating to crimes committed during his rule, sought Mr. Cavallo's extradition. Human rights experts said the extradition of Mr. Cavallo would be the first time someone accused of rights abuses in one country would have been sought for trial in a second nation and extradited by a third. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Case Against Lawyer Is Dropped
description: A divorce lawyer whose cooperation led to the arrest of a Brooklyn judge on charges of accepting gifts in return for fixing divorce cases had all charges against him dismissed yesterday, at the request of prosecutors.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Teacher Charged With Sex Abuse
description: A teacher at a Bronx intermediate school was arrested yesterday and charged with sodomy, sexual abuse, and endangering the welfare of a child, the police said. The teacher, Gary Coleman, 51, of Webster Avenue in the Bronx, was arrested after three boys, ages 12, 13 and 14, said they had been sexually abused by him several times between December 2002 and May 2003, at the school where he teaches, Intermediate School 158, at 800 Home Street in Morrisania. The children reported the abuse last Friday, the police said. Mr. Coleman was an unsuccessful Conservative Party candidate for State Assembly this year, according to The Bronx Beat, a newspaper published by Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism. Tina Kelley (NYT)

description: We start the morning with a packet of sample papers, on which students have had 20 minutes to respond to the statement ''The world is getting better all the time.''

title: Panel Weighs M.T.A. Appeal Of Rulings to Roll Back Fares
description: Lawyers for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority told an appeals court in Manhattan yesterday that recent court rulings ordering a rollback of fare and toll increases were misguided judicial attempts to meddle with the authority's budgeting powers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HADIKS, , DEAN
description: HADIKS--Dean, 50, died suddenly June 8, 2003. A loving and passionate husband to Cheryl, father to Ari, brother to Milton and son to Themis Revis. Dean was a dedicated psychologist who worked as the director of psychology at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn and also maintained a private practice. Dean was a thinker, a poet and an adventurer. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends, co-workers and patients. The family will be home on Thursday evening June 12 and his life will be celebrated at the Hadiks' home on Sunday, June 15 at 4 p.m. >>AD#

title: SAFEWAY TO REDUCE ADMINISTRATIVE STAFF BY 13 PERCENT
description: Safeway Inc. is eliminating about 13 percent of its administrative positions to lower costs. About 252 of the 940 jobs being cut were open and will not be filled, the company said. More than 400 employees were laid off yesterday, while the remaining will be terminated over the next year, a spokesman, Brian Dowling, said. The loss of customers to discounters had led Safeway, based in Pleasanton, Calif., to try to lower employee expenses. The company expects same-store sales, which have declined each of the last four quarters, to drop about 0.5 percent this quarter.

title: S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING FISCHER IMAGING ACCOUNTING
description: The Fischer Imaging Corporation, a maker of X-ray equipment, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun investigating its accounting. The S.E.C. subpoenaed records related to the company's financial statements for 2000, 2001 and the first three quarters of 2002, said the chief financial officer, Stephen Burke. The company, which is based in Denver, alerted regulators to its accounting problems. Fischer Imaging, whose machines are used to screen for breast cancer, said in April that it would delay filing its 2002 financial report and that it might have to restate results because of the way it had been recognizing revenue.

title: Afghan Refugees Weave a Story In War Rugs Made in Pakistan
description: Afghan refugees in Pakistan made rugs depicting Kalashnikov rifles, guided missiles and MIG jets during the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan from 1979 to 1989. When the Soviets left, war-rug production stopped. Now refugees near Peshawar, Pakistan, are making small matlike rugs showing cartoonish images of American tanks and helicopters. The spelling is often incorrect, as above, ''Afghans liderated from terrorist.'' ''We sell a lot of them,'' said Chris Walter, the owner of Yayla Tribal Rugs, a wholesale company in Cambridge, Mass. ''We can have them made to order if we want.'' But no two are alike. Buyers include military officers as well as civilians like Peter Roy, a lawyer in Ellsworth, Me. ''Having a war rug on the floor always breaks the ice when discussing politics,'' he said. The rugs ($200 to $400) can be seen at Kea Carpets and Kilims, 477 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, through June. Information: (718) 222-8087. They are also available for $185 to $225 from www.rugreview.com, or (603) 744-9191. ABC Carpet & Home has 50 rugs costing $100 to $1,000; 888 Broadway (19th Street), (212) 473-3000. Some people, like Leslie Stroh, publisher of Rug News in New York, say to buy them for love, not money. ''There's no collectible nature to them,'' he said. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Gaming Pros and Cons
description: Re ''On Video Games, the Jury Is Out and Confused'' (June 5): No lawyer would allow me on that jury. Video games are addictive -- the more violent, the more so -- and that's reason enough to quell any doubt over studies that find peripheral positive effects.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Police Rescue Man In Harbor
description: A man who said he had jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge was rescued from New York Harbor last night after passengers on the Staten Island Ferry reported hearing his cries, the authorities said. It was the second time in two nights that someone claiming to have jumped from the bridge survived. Last night about 10:15, the police pulled a man in his 30's from the 60-degree water near Governor's Island, about a mile from the bridge. He said he had jumped from it, said an officer who was on a boat near the one that rescued the man. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center in stable condition with an injured shoulder. ''He was just trying to stay up with one arm,'' the officer said. ''He wouldn't have made it much longer.'' Just before midnight on Tuesday a 19-year-old man jumped from the mid-span of the bridge and was rescued by the Coast Guard.

title: Takeover Turmoil in Business Software Has Users Concerned
description: To Angelo Privetera, chief information officer of HDR Inc., an architectural consulting firm based in Omaha, there was no downside to the news last week that PeopleSoft, a maker of business software, was planning to acquire J. D. Edwards, one of its rivals.

title: Venezuelan Opposition Courts Working Class
description: The working-class neighborhood of Catia in the western end of metropolitan Caracas, with its jumbled brick houses and towering projects, is said to be fiercely loyal to President Hugo Chvez and sharply opposed to those who call for his removal.

title: Light on Its Feet, With Practiced Moves
description: The Kila lamp (above) looks like a robotic dog or possibly a bird, but its designer, Harry Allen, says his inspiration was roller skating. ''The lamp spins on its axis as if it had been practicing that move in the roller rink for decades,'' said Mr. Allen, who has a master's degree in industrial design from Pratt Institute and who also designed the interiors for the Moss store in SoHo. The metal, plastic and rubber Kila (in red only) is $14.99 at Ikea; to order, (800) 434-4532. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: Shelter, by the Rules
description: When a New York State appeals court cleared the way for the city to start enforcing nearly decade-old regulations on conduct in its shelters this week, it re-opened an old debate on the extent to which society can hold the homeless responsible for improving their own condition.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Killings Of Defense Executives Linked
description: The police said they had linked the separate assassinations Friday of a businessman chosen by the Kremlin to consolidate Russia's air-defense companies, and, hours later, of an official at one of the air-defense subsidiaries involved in the merger. The Kremlin appointee, Igor Klimov, was under orders to eliminate duplication and waste in more than 40 businesses producing air-defense systems. He was shot outside his Moscow apartment after what the police said could have been a robbery attempt staged to cover a contract murder. The official of the subsidiary, Sergei Shchitko, was shot as he sat in a car outside a Moscow cafe. A wave of contract murders of politicians and businessmen has swept the city in recent months. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Editors' Note
description: On May 11 The Times published an extensive report about plagiarism and fabrications by Jayson Blair before his resignation as a reporter for The Times a week earlier. The detailed account centered on articles written during and after October, when Mr. Blair began receiving national assignments. An editors' note with that account said The Times would continue spot-checking Mr. Blair's earlier articles and invited readers to report any discrepancies to retrace@nytimes.com.

title: Battle Brews Over E.P.A. Post As Top Contenders Emerge
description: The White House is narrowing its search for a successor to Christie Whitman as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, people close to the process said today, as Democrats prepare for a bruising nomination fight.

title: Retiring Army Chief of Staff Warns Against Arrogance
description: Gen. Eric K. Shinseki, the Army chief of staff who pushed his tradition-bound service on a difficult path toward transformation, retired today, warning against arrogance in leadership.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Annie Lennox, a Dog Collar And, of Course, Shaggy

title: Baggage Handler Is Charged With Smuggling Handguns
description: A baggage handler at Newark Liberty International Airport smuggled at least 18 handguns on flights from Alabama to New Jersey, where he sold them to criminals, the authorities said today.

title: Vandalism and 'Improvements' Mar Great Wall
description: Look up at any hill crest around this remote village and there looms the Great Wall, China's most cherished landmark, the elegant brown stones of its crumbling face and watchtowers receding majestically into the distance.

title: E-Mailing Around an Open Fire: Campgrounds Go Wireless
description: Hitting the road this summer may mean spending more time on the Interstate than on the Internet, but options for wireless connectivity are expanding for travelers. Kampgrounds of America, known to drivers across the land as KOA, recently began outfitting some of its 500 sites with Wi-Fi access, enabling campers to browse for s'mores recipes even as the marshmallows are roasting.

title: Bush Under Fire in Congress for Criticizing Israel
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Supporters of Israel in and out of Congress assailed President Bush today for criticizing Israeli attacks on Palestinian militant groups as the administration worked to protect its Middle East peace initiative from a new cycle of violence.

title: In a Tax Battle, McGreevey Criticizes Casino Executives
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey today raised the stakes in his showdown with New Jersey's casino industry, unveiling a campaign-style radio ad that accuses ''millionaire casino C.E.O.'s'' of shirking their responsibility to help the state close its budget gap and forcing homeowners, older residents and middle-class families to pay higher taxes.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: 'Matrix' Film Banned
description: ''The Matrix Reloaded,'' the science-fiction hit, has been banned, the censorship director, Madkur Thabet, said, because the film is violent and because it raises controversial issues about human creation ''linked to the three monotheistic religions that we respect and which we believe in.'' The film's violence threatened ''social peace,'' he said, but he praised its technical effects. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Gregory Peck, a Star of Quiet Dignity, Dies at 87
description: Gregory Peck, whose chiseled, slightly melancholy good looks, resonant baritone and quiet strength made him an unforgettable presence in films like "To Kill a Mockingbird," "Gentleman's Agreement" and "Twelve O'Clock High," died late Wednesday or early Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 87.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Court Voids Loans Linked To Suits
description: In a blow to a new industry that lends money to people in exchange for a stake in their lawsuits, the state Supreme Court declared two contracts for such loans void. The plaintiff in the case, Roberta Rancman, had borrowed $7,000 from two finance companies at interest rates of more than 180 percent a year. The contracts Ms. Rancman signed required her to repay the loans only if she won or settled a personal injury suit. The court based its decision on a centuries-old but seldom enforced prohibition on investing in lawsuits by others. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Land Deal Seems to Resolve Salt Lake City Plaza Dispute
description: After a four-year battle between free-speech advocates and the Mormon Church, Salt Lake City has agreed to a plan that gives the church the right to restrict behavior on a downtown plaza that has been a public easement in exchange for the church's giving the city two acres of land for a new community center.

title: House Democrats Look for G.O.P. Votes to Defeat Tax Cut
description: Democrats pushed today for enough votes to defeat a large tax-cut bill that House leaders are bringing to the floor on Thursday, accusing Republican leaders of including child tax credits for low-income families in the bill only as a ploy to enact bigger cuts for wealthier taxpayers.

title: Bergman Reimagines Ibsen's Haunted Widow
description: The ''living dead,'' her son calls her, a ghost in her own house. And sure enough, when we first see Mrs. Alving in Ingmar Bergman's truly macabre production of Ibsen's ''Ghosts'' at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, she brings to mind someone who might be called Keeper of the Crypt in an old British horror movie, the kind set in Victorian times amid smothering velvet curtains.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Flights Restored
description: Cathay Pacific, the dominant airline in Hong Kong, said it would restore 170 flights a week to various destinations starting in July, in the expectation that passengers will return now that severe acute respiratory syndrome is fading away. Cathay will then be operating nearly 700 flights a week, or 71 percent of its schedule before SARS. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: President's Rival Still In Jail
description: Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, the main opposition party, was brought to a Harare court in shackles for a bail hearing on capital treason charges. But the hearing was adjourned, and he spent a sixth night in jail. Mr. Tsvangirai was arrested Friday after his party called for national work stoppages to demand the resignation of President Robert Mugabe. Mr. Tsvangirai already faces a possible death sentence on separate treason charges in an alleged plot last year to kill Mr. Mugabe. The party's secretary general, Welshman Ncube, arrested on Friday with Mr. Tsvangirai, was released on Tuesday when prosecutors dropped new treason charges against him, his lawyer told reporters. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: New Yorkers Have Growing Pessimism About the City
description: Dispirited by job losses, tax increases and service cuts, New Yorkers say they are increasingly pessimistic about their city, according to the latest New York Times poll.

title: Turn Back the Clock For a Speedy Recovery
description: Q. Do I need a system-recovery program like Roxio's GoBack if my computer has the System Restore function as part of Windows XP? How do the two programs differ?

title: Mets Dismiss General Manager Phillips
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., June 12  The Mets fired Steve Phillips, their general manager, today and named his assistant, Jim Duquette, to replace Phillips for the remainder of the season.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KLEIN, , BERNARD L.
description: KLEIN--Bernard L. You will be loved forever. Your spirit is always with us. Alice Klein and Family >>AD#

title: Rumsfeld Says Iran Is Developing Nuclear Arms Under Guise of Civilian Program
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld warned today about Iran's nuclear activities and called on the Atlantic alliance to find new ways of combating ''the nexus of terror and weapons of mass destruction,'' which he called the biggest threat facing the countries of both ''old'' and ''new'' Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SYMONDS, , MARGARET PRESTON
description: SYMONDS--Margaret Preston, 91, formerly of Wilton, CT, died on June 7 in Peterborough, NH. She was the wife of the late George W.D. Symonds and the mother of the late Robert H. Symonds. Her two sons, George D. Symonds of Sheldon, ND and David P. Symonds of Key West, FL; and a daughter Frances S. Riggs of New Ipswich, NH survive her. She leaves four grandchildren: Adrienne W. Symonds & Margaret P. Symonds of RI and Tristan Riggs & Cooper Riggs of NH. She was a graduate of the Brearley School, attended Vassar College and was a tireless fundraiser for the NY Philharmonic Orchestra and the Wilton Public Library. She lived in Wilton with her husband for 60 years and will be dearly missed by those who knew and loved her. A burial service will be held in Wilton at the Hillside Cemetery, Route 33 on Saturday, June 14 at 1 PM. >>AD#

title: Park Trust Favors More Playing Fields for Pier 40 Over 3 Proposed Redevelopment Projects
description: Three ambitious redevelopment proposals for Pier 40, an almost peninsula-size structure at the foot of Houston Street, were rejected Monday by the board of the Hudson River Park Trust, which announced that it would instead take over operation of the pier and build more playing fields.

title: Mexico Repays Last Bond From Crisis
description: Mexico announced today that it was paying off the last of its $35 billion in Brady bonds, in a symbolic end to the 1980's debt crisis.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Tycoon's Trial
description: Yang Bin, an orchid tycoon once ranked as the second-richest man in China, went on trial for commercial crimes. Mr. Yang, who also holds Dutch citizenship, developed a large flower, agriculture and real estate trading company based in the northeastern city of Shenyang. He was also selected by North Korean leaders to build a proposed free-trade zone on that country's border with China. But he was arrested for bribery and misusing agricultural land. His trial comes at a time when the authorities are cracking down on several businessmen who depended on political patronage for licenses and bank loans. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

description: Gaming Pros and Cons

description: GODZILLA: DESTROY ALL MONSTERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKAF, , RICHARD A. SR.
description: SKAF--Richard A. Sr. Passed away on June 2nd, at home after a brief illness. He is survived by his wife and children. He was born in Brooklyn, NY. He was the son of Anna and George Skaf. Survived by a sister and a brother, and several nieces and nephews. He was a member of TypoPublishers Union Local #

title: Bush's Political Science
description: What do weapons of mass destruction and stem cells have in common? The controversy over the Bush administration's representation of Saddam Hussein's arsenal seems like dj vu to those of us who followed the president's first major policy decision two years ago: research on human embryonic stem cells, which may have the potential to treat many major diseases.

title: Editors' Note
description: On May 11 The Times published an extensive report about plagiarism and fabrications by Jayson Blair before his resignation as a reporter for The Times a week earlier. The detailed account centered on articles written during and after October, when Mr. Blair began receiving national assignments. An editors' note with that account said The Times would continue spot-checking Mr. Blair's earlier articles and invited readers to report any discrepancies to retrace@nytimes.com.

title: U.S. Investigating Mystery Death Of Iraqi Being Held as a Prisoner
description: Military investigators have been called in to determine whether United States troops were responsible for the death of an Iraqi prisoner of war last week, defense officials said today.

title: United Technologies Agrees to Buy Chubb
description: The United Technologies Corporation, the maker of Pratt & Whitney jet engines, agreed last night to buy Chubb of Britain, one of the world's largest security companies, for about 600 million ($1 billion) in cash.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Beverly Bailis Karp, 72, Movie Producer
description: Beverly Bailis Karp, a producer of films and plays and a co-producer of the film ''My Dinner With Andr,'' died on Tuesday at her home in New York. She was 72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALTER, , ELLEN FLORENCE
description: HALTER -- Ellen Florence, Long time resident of Bronxville died on June 9, 2003. Wife of the late Rev. Howard Halter, former pastor of the Village Lutheran Church in Bronxville. Mrs. Halter was Professor Emeritus of Art at Concordia College in Bronxville. Friends may call at the Westchester Funeral Home, Inc., Eastchester, Thursday from 5-8 PM. Service in the Village Lutheran Church, Bronxville, Friday June 13, at 3PM. Friends who wish may contribute to the Village Lutheran Church, 172 White Plains Road, Bronxville, NY 10708, Concordia College, Bronxville, NY or the New Rochelle Humane Society. >>AD#

title: Royal Bank Is Acquiring Churchill
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland said today that it had agreed to buy the Churchill Insurance Group from the Credit Suisse Group for 1 billion ($1.7 billion). The Royal Bank will also repay 100 million of Churchill's debt.

title: Gaming Pros and Cons
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Looking beyond free trade as a solution to helping the developing world.
description: SINCE the Iraq war, developed nations like France and the United States seem to be vying to show that they care about the world's poor. The events of Sept. 11, 2001, made us all more aware of the deprived state of citizens around the world. The difficult aftermath of the war has also shown us that overthrowing a dictator is not enough to ensure security, economic opportunity and sustained decency.

title: Sports of The Times; After Three Games of Standout Play, Parker Starts to Act His Age
description: IF David Stern had had his way, Tony Parker would not have played for San Antonio as a 19-year-old last season and Jason Kidd would probably not have been in the overstated position of defending his honor as point guard nonpareil against the kid with the fast training wheels last night, when the Nets evened the N.B.A. finals at 2-2 with a 77-76 victory over the Spurs at Continental Arena.

title: She Talks. He Talks. Let's Go to the Videotape.
description: Life somehow seems fuller in two dimensions than it does in three in Kate Robin's ''Intrigue With Faye,'' a new sex comedy in which, yes, lies and videotape figure prominently.

title: After 18 Years, a Free Man and a Jubilant Mother
description: For 18 years, Frida Restivo says, she never doubted the innocence of her son John and never gave up the fight to exonerate him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUPERBERG, , ETTA OLIVEN
description: KUPERBERG--Etta Oliven. Died on Wednesday at her home, she was 82. She was born in New York City, and lived in Brooklyn, NY for most of her life. Etta was a secretary for Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company in NYC for 19 years, retiring in 1985. Etta will be missed by all who loved her. Burial services will be private. Family will receive visitors at 2PM Friday, June 13 at her home. She is survived by her husband David, of 61 years; two sons Mitchell and Nelson; a daughter Roberta Rosenfeld. Also survived by a brother Seymour Oliven, two grandchildren, six great-grandchildren and predeceased by her sister Rose Lichtman. Anderson & Campbell Funeral Home, Manchester, NJ are assisting the family. >>AD#

description: Health Plans Force Workers To Pay More for Treatments

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP., Armonk, N.Y., one of the world's largest computer-services companies, said it won a 10-year, $647 million contract to run the computer network and provide consulting for the Finnish paper maker M-real Oyj.

title: Maurice Rosenthal, 98, Composer, Conductor and Interpreter of Ravel
description: Maurice Rosenthal, a French composer and conductor who was a student of Ravel and a vigorous champion of French composers from Offenbach to Messiaen, died on June 5 at his home in Paris. He was 98.

title: The Cellphones We Ought to Have
description: In last weeks edition of Circuits, I reviewed super-simple cellphones. I gave top honors to the Kyocera 2325, where every useful feature is a single button-press away.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Banker Cautious On Rate Cut
description: The president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, suggested three interest rate cuts by the bank in the last six months may be enough to revive the economies of the dozen nations using the euro currency. ''It is too early to again discuss further steps,'' Mr. Duisenberg said in a televised interview Tuesday night. Asked if the bank had room to lower rates further, he said, ''I don't know that.'' The bank cut borrowing costs last week by half a point, to 2 percent, the lowest level for any country in the 12-state euro region in more than 50 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TARNOFF, , ANNA
description: TARNOFF--Anna. Age 96. Beloved mother of Jerry (Nancy) and Harriet (Leonard) Holtz. Adored grandmother of Marcy Klein, Margery Tarnoff, Michael, Douglas and Jonathan Holtz and dear great grandmother. Funeral service private. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CROSS, , WILLIAM JOHN
description: CROSS--William John. Of Orford, NH on June 1. Beloved husband of Judith Haslam, loving father of John, Tiffany and Alexandra, devoted grandfather of William, Katherine, Evelyn and Elliott. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, September 6, at 11 AM, at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Bedford, NY. >>AD#

title: Israeli Forces Take Aim at Hamas for Third Strike in 24 Hours
description: Anew round of violence erupted in the Mideast today as Israeli helicopters fired missiles at a car in Gaza City, killing a senior official of the militant group Hamas and at least six other Palestinians, news agencies reported.

title: Another 4 Days of Stress Start Today
description: Earlier this week, Jerry Kelly talked about what makes the United States Open different from any other golf tournament.

title: Drama Finds a Palestinian Filmmaker
description: When Hany Abu-Assad was directing ''Rana's Wedding,'' a film about a young Palestinian woman who resists her father's attempts to marry her off to a man of his choosing, a typical day began with a discussion among the crew members and their driver about where it was possible to film.

title: Council Irked at Mayor's Call For Tax-Free Shopping Weeks
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called on the City Council yesterday to approve two tax-free weeks on clothing sales, leading Council officials, who said they had long planned to do so anyway, to speculate that he was trying to take credit for the move.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERINI, , JOHN D.
description: PERINI--John D. Former Executive Vice President at Merrill Lynch, died June 2nd at his home in Cambridge, NY. He was 64. Mr. Perini spent 33 years at Merill Lynch where he founded and built a financial trading team into one of the industries' largest and most lucrative global trading operations. He was responsible for the development and implementation of Merrill's Securities Lending Business, Tri-party Repo Operation and the Municipal Bond Proceeds Reinvestment Program. In 1991 he moved to Cantor Fitzgerald as Managing Director where he developed an on-line investment product called Safety Cash. Due to Safety Cash's success he was recruited by the Swiss banking giant UBS to develop a global on-line variation which was dubbed Swiss Gold. As a wellknown and highly respected securities professional he was called upon to appear as an expert witness by the Congressional Committee on Banking and Finance. During the last few years he dedicated his time to his family and farm in upstate NY. John D. Perini will be remembered by his Wall Street peers as a man of exceptional ingenuity, fierce loyalty and impeccable integrity. He is survived by his wife, Dieta; his parents, John and Mayme Perini; his son John, and daughters, Monica and Maria; and four beloved grandchildren, Bryce, Alanya, Stephanni, and Jillian. A memorial service is planned for Saturday, June 28 at 2:00 pm at St. Lukes Episcopal Church in Cambridge, NY. In lieu of flowers please send donations in memory of John D. Perini to the Leonard P. Zakim Center for Integrated Therapy at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, 10 Brookline Place West, 6th Floor, Brookline, MA 02445. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: A calendar entry in the Metro Briefing column on Monday about a New York State Senate hearing on stiffening penalties for people who repeatedly drive while intoxicated misstated the day of the hearing. It is tomorrow; it was not Monday. A corrected listing appears in the column today, on Page B6.

title: Got Milk? Hula Hoop? It's a Record!; He's Guinness's King Of Strange Feats, All for Inner Peace
description: Several years back, Ashrita Furman learned that someone had set a world record for tree-eating, so he naturally began ingesting a bigger one -- a birch near his home in Jamaica, Queens -- by chopping it up in a kitchen blender. He was soon stopped by his Indian guru, Sri Chinmoy.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about the new College Sports Television channel misstated the affiliation of Scott Novak, who discussed programs it will show. He is vice president of Dan Klores Communications, a public relations agency, not of College Sports Television.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''So what do we do now -- tell me! Every time there is a line of hope, we get socked in the teeth.''

title: XEROX PLANS $3.1 BILLION RECAPITALIZATION
description: The Xerox Corporation plans a $3.1 billion recapitalization to strengthen its balance sheet and to repay and terminate its current bank facility. Xerox, which is based in Stamford, Conn., is raising money after its first profitable year since 1999. Xerox plans to issue about 40 million shares of common stock valued at $434 million based on Monday's closing price of $10.84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COURTNEY, , RENEE (BORN SALAMA)
description: COURTNEY -- Renee (born Salama), exemplary culinary artist, died peacefully on June 10, 2003. She is mourned by her daughters, Heather Perrin and Cherryll Hopcraft, and by her grandchildren, Roanne, Martin, Brent, Mark and Barney in England. She is survived by her beloved sister, Vicky Namad in New York, and her dearest brother, Dr. Max Salama in Egypt, as well as numerous devoted nieces and nephews. Service Thursday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. >>AD#

title: Bring On the Fat Files: Hard Drives With Room to Spare
description: They say you can't be too rich or too thin, and if they were talking about hard drives they might say you can't be too big. For those who work with digital video, music or photo files, it can seem as though no hard drive is capacious enough. Googie, a Danish company, makes external hard drives with a hefty measure of data storage space.

title: Iraqis in Iran: Unwanted in Both Countries
description: Saad Kavarizadeh remembers that miserable day long ago in Baghdad like no other.

title: In Ancient Skulls From Ethiopia, Familiar Faces
description: In the 160,000-year-old fossilized skulls of two adults and a child found in Ethiopia, scientists think they see for the first time the faces of the immediate ancestors of modern humans.

title: 2 PC Makers And Sun Cut Deal for Java
description: Sun Microsystems moved a step closer today to making its Java programming language a force in personal computing when Hewlett-Packard and Dell Computer agreed to include Java software with their desktop and laptop computers.

title: Prosecutors Investigating Freddie Mac
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they had begun a criminal investigation into Freddie Mac, the second-largest finan cier of home mortgages, after the company fired its president for failing to cooperate with an internal investigation into its accounting. The company also disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission had opened a formal investigation into it.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. provokes new rift with EU by pushing for world court exceptions
description: With relations still strained over the war in Iraq and other issues, the United States has warned European Union countries not to lobby actively against a U.S. campaign for bilateral national agreements that put U.S. citizens beyond the reach of the new International Criminal Court.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Man Charged In Insurance Scheme
description: The police charged a Chicago man with six counts of aggravated battery and three counts of insurance fraud in a scheme in which the bones of homeless people were broken to fake accidents for insurance claims. Investigators said the man, Michael Garner, 39, used an ax to break the arms or legs of about a dozen people, then took them to the sites of pre-arranged car accidents. Mr. Garner made hundreds of thousands of dollars in the two years he led the scheme and the homeless victims made hundreds, the police said. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: An Acoustic Tape Measure for Deep-Sea Archaeologists
description: THERE'S the derring-do version of underwater exploration the sea dog with the power saw, cutting through the hull of a ship to find hidden gold. And then there are the deep-sea archaeologists, who want to explore submerged sites while causing minimal damage, making detailed maps that mark each minute change as artifacts are painstakingly removed.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cymer Cuts 2nd-Quarter Sales Forecast
description: Cymer Inc., which makes lasers that imprint computer chip designs on silicon wafers, said yesterday that sales this quarter would be as much as 14 percent below the company's forecast because demand dropped. Second-quarter sales will decline to $58 million to $61 million, missing the $67.6 million estimate given in April, Cymer said. In the quarter a year earlier, sales were $73.7 million. Cymer has pared its product line and reduced spending on plants to lower the amount of sales needed to turn a profit. The company cut 130 jobs, a 15 percent reduction, in April after first-quarter sales missed its forecast. Cymer had net losses in the last two quarters, and the cutbacks will save about $1.5 million in each period, the chief financial officer, Nancy J. Baker, said in an interview. No additional cuts in the work force of 720 are planned, she said. Orders for some lasers have been delayed because Cymer customers like ASM Lithography and Nikon still have plenty of those products on hand, the chief executive, Robert P. Akins, said in an interview. Shares of Cymer fell 74 cents, or 2.3 percent, to $31.90.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: F.B.I. Official Retiring
description: Kevin P. Donovan, who has headed the New York office of the F.B.I. for 15 months, announced yesterday that he was retiring. In his 25-year career, Mr. Donovan, an assistant director of the F.B.I., has overseen some of the bureau's most prominent cases. He was a commander of its investigation into the 1998 bombings of United States Embassies in East Africa, the 2000 bombing of the destroyer Cole and the kidnapping last year of Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter. Mr. Donovan, who is to leave his post on July 31, will join Johnson & Johnson as director of security. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Miscellany
description: * RLM Public Relations opened a third office, in Los Angeles, joining the original office, in New York, and the office in Washington, also recently opened. Richard Laermer, chief executive, moved to Los Angeles from New York.

title: The Nets Are Not Going Away
description: With 72 seconds left in Game 4, Kenyon Martin went straight at the basket three times while Tim Duncan was breathing right behind him.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: CALL FOR CHIEF JUSTICE TO QUIT Less than a week after President Nestor Kirchner called on Congress to impeach the Supreme Court, saying it was "holding the country's governability hostage," the tribunal's newest member urged the chief justice, Julio Nazareno, to resign. Mr. Nazareno, who is already facing congressional hearings to remove him from office on the ground of malfeasance, was accused of "putting respect for the judicial branch at risk" by violating "norms of decorum" in responding to Mr. Kirchner's proposal with a derisive vulgarity. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: A New Mix: MP3 Players For the Car
description: ANYONE who has ever made a mix tape to play on a long drive knows the hypnotic effect of combining cars, motion and music: it's just you and the road and Steve Earle cranked up all the way as the mile markers fly by and stress melts away. Even when stuck at a traffic light, you can car dance by wiggling around in your seat and singing the background vocals on ''Stop! In the Name of Love.''

title: Team Effort: 6 Astro Pitchers, 0 Yankee Hits
description: Roy Oswalt ambled to the Houston dugout after throwing two pitches in the second inning last night at Yankee Stadium, done for the evening because of a strained right groin muscle. The Yankees did not have a hit or a run off Oswalt, which seemed inconsequential because there were eight long innings left.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column yesterday about a show on Frank Sinatra to be directed by Des McAnuff and planned for Radio City Music Hall in October referred incorrectly to two of Mr. McAnuff's previous projects, ''The Who's Tommy'' and ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.'' They were musicals, not movies.

title: Tests Show Need to Overhaul Shuttle Checks, Official Says
description: Tests suggest that damage to the space shuttle Columbia's wing that may have led to the craft's destruction was so subtle that NASA will have to develop very detailed inspection methods to detect such flaws before and during flights, the agency's administrator said today.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: IOWA: SATAN CHARGE RISKS LIBEL VERDICT Church officials who said a member of the congregation was moved by "the spirit of Satan" may be sued for libel, the state Supreme Court ruled. Jane Kliebenstein, a member of the United Methodist Church in Shell Rock, sued its district superintendent and members of the church's parish committee after they circulated a letter associating her with Satan. The court rejected the church's religious freedom defense, ruling that the phrase has "a common, and largely unflattering, secular meaning" suggesting wickedness, cruelty and viciousness.

title: Generations Meet on Team That Seeks World Title for U.S.
description: The Open Trials, which ended in Memphis on Monday, determined that one team representing the United States in the world championships this year will have two great veteran players and four rising stars. Bobby Wolff was a member of the famous Aces team and has won 11 world titles in the last 33 years. One of these, the 2000 Senior Teams, was with his current partner, Dan Morse, who has many credentials at world and national levels. Their teammates, with whom they captured the Reisinger Teams in Phoenix last November, are Adam Wildavsky, Doug Doub, Steve Landen and Pratap Rajadhyaksha, all making their world championship debuts. Their nonplaying captain is Ralph Cohen.

title: Supporters Object to Efforts To Alter Ground Zero Plan
description: A coalition of civic and planning organizations said yesterday that Daniel Libeskind's plan for the World Trade Center site is in danger of being undermined by business and community groups that have proposed changes to it and by the companies that hold leases to the site.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Airline Shares Sold
description: Israel sold 60 million shekels ($13.6 million) in shares and options in the initial public offering of El Al Israel Airlines Ltd., about an eighth of what the government had aimed to raise. The government sold 15 percent of the airline, with options to buy shares of an additional 77 percent, said Eyal Gabbai, head of the Government Companies Authority. The government planned to sell 49.9 percent of El Al in its first sale of state assets and raise as much as $113 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lead Poisoning Subsides
description: A long, steep decline in lead poisoning among New York City's children continued last year, the city health commissioner reported yesterday, thanks in part to efforts to educate parents, doctors and landlords. But lead poisoning remains concentrated in poor communities, said the commissioner, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, and one in four new cases occurred in foreign-born children. Last year, there were almost 4,000 new cases of children under age 6 with what are considered ''elevated'' lead levels in their blood, and more than 500 under age 18 with levels at least twice the threshold considered elevated. Those figures represent declines of 70 percent to 80 percent since 1995. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Tax Cuts, by Their Real Name
description: To the Editor:

title: Leader of Effort to Recall California Governor Is Named in Dispute Over Campaign Finances
description: A California congressman leading an effort to recall Gov. Gray Davis is caught in his own controversy, facing accusations that he has financed the effort with ''soft money'' checks, in violation of the new federal campaign finance law.

title: Rumsfeld Says Belgian Law Could Prompt NATO to Leave
description: BRUSSELS, June 12  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld effectively threatened Belgium today that it risked losing its status as host to NATO's headquarters if it did not rescind a law that has been used to lodge accusations of war crimes against American officials.

title: Managers Fired At Youth Unit In New Jersey
description: In the biggest shake-up of New Jersey's child welfare agency since the death of a 7-year-old Newark boy in January, the special assistant assigned by the governor to reform the office has dismissed 10 of its highest-ranking administrators and managers, state officials said.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: BANK OUTLOOK LOWERED Standard & Poor's, the credit-rating agency, cut its outlook on the Hong Kong subsidiary of Bank of China to negative. The change means the agency is more likely to lower its long-term rating of BBB+ for the unit. The agency cited concerns about how the unit was approving loans, pointing out that the bank has forced a borrower, New Nongkai Global Investments Ltd., into bankruptcy a little less than a year after extending it a loan of $270 million, with $95 million of that still outstanding as of June 5. The downgrading is a humiliation for the Bank of China, one of China's four main state-owned banks; all of them are plagued with bad debts on the mainland. Bank of China made an initial public offering of shares in the Hong Kong unit last summer, with UBS Warburg, Goldman Sachs and Bank of China International as the lead managers. The former chief executive of the bank unit, Liu Jinbao, was recalled to Beijing last month and is reportedly under investigation. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Bush to Back Measures on Generic Drugs
description: President Bush plans to announce measures today intended to speed the introduction of generic versions of brand-name drugs, according to people who have been briefed on the proposals, which are similar to ones endorsed by a Senate panel yesterday.

title: Seo's Arm and Floyd's Bat Carry the Mets to Victory
description: Jae Weong Seo of the Mets had a five-run lead tonight when he faced Rafael Palmeiro, the most recent entrant into the 500-homer club, with a runner on and two outs in the Texas half of the fifth inning. Palmeiro, who has a hamstring injury, chopped a slow roller to the left of the mound and struggled down the first-base line. Seo leapt off the mound, skidded on one knee to barehand the ball and threw out Palmeiro.

title: Would-Be Olympians Gather in New York
description: With the 2004 Athens Olympics rapidly approaching, the New York City Fencing World Cup is carrying added significance. The World Cup is a leading Olympic qualifying tournament, and the preliminaries at Columbia University yesterday trimmed the number of women and mens sabre fencers from 300 to 128.

title: Power and Charge Play to Scoreless Tie
description: The last-minute blues that infected the Power last year disappeared, at least for one game. The Power produced a 0-0 tie last night against the Philadelphia Charge in a Women's United Soccer Association game at Mitchel Athletic Complex in Uniondale, N.Y.

title: The Civil Service Faces an Overhaul
description: The Bush administration is moving quietly toward the most sweeping reform of the Civil Service system in a generation, a mammoth turnabout that would empower the Pentagon to scrap and replace the way it hires, pays, promotes and disciplines its roughly 750,000 civilian workers. The House has already rubber-stamped a plan proposed by Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, who wants the ''flexibility'' to become in effect the potentate of payroll. Under that bill, Mr. Rumsfeld and his managers would have final word on the merit, demerit and pay raises of workers, who would have minimal recourse to appeal. Workers are understandably anxious about this work force revolution, warning of a retreat toward the 19th-century spoils system of patronage and cronyism.

title: Opening Russian Society
description: When George Soros's Open Society Institute set up shop in Russia in 1987, the Communist Party still ruled, and hopes for greater democracy seemed linked to the uncertain political future of Mikhail Gorbachev. Mr. Soros's bold ambition was to nurture a broader base for democratic transformation. To a remarkable extent, he succeeded. The progress of Russian democracy has plainly been uneven. Yet rudiments of a grass-roots democratic culture clearly exist there today, and Mr. Soros's visionary philanthropy deserves at least some of the credit. Now, after more than 15 years and nearly a billion dollars spent promoting democratic institutions and activism, the institute is winding up its Moscow operations.

title: Downward Spiral in the Mideast
description: As soon as the new Middle East peace initiative was announced, it was clear that violence by its opponents would follow. Less clear was whether those who have backed the road map would have the political courage to withstand the assault.

title: All Promise, No Soup
description: At a press briefing yesterday, Gov. George Pataki, the Senate majority leader Joseph Bruno and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver got together to pat themselves on the back about something they declared as big news. Campaign finance reform? No. Expansion of the lobbying law? No. Instead, it was agreement on a bill to ban video voyeurism.

description: Four United Nations employees kidnapped last week in a secession-minded region of the country were released by their abductors on Tuesday night and returned here to the capital today.

description: The House is poised to pass a bill that would give corporate lobbyists one of their most sought-after goals on Capitol Hill: a sweeping rewrite of the rules governing class-action lawsuits.

title: Word for Word on the Web, Isaac Newton's Secret Musings
description: JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES called them ''fascinating'' and read them in taxis. Albert Einstein called them ''unique treasures.'' But for roughly 300 years, just a handful of people had ever seen Isaac Newton's voluminous writings on alchemy and theology. Now that is changing, thanks to a group of scholars who are making them available on the Internet.

title: OPEC Leaves Production Levels Unchanged
description: Responding to high oil prices and the continued uncertainty about the return of Iraqi oil exports to world markets, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to leave current levels of oil production unchanged at 25.4 million barrels a day.

description: Pat LaFontaine was driving home to Long Island yesterday when he received the news that he had been elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame.

description: Treasury Secretary John W. Snow said yesterday that he was not concerned by the dollar's 19 percent decline against the euro over the last year and denied that stance put him at odds with either President Bush or the ''strong dollar'' policy.

description: ''What's the opera tonight?'' a passerby asked a Central Park policewoman on Tuesday night.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Madison: Principal Faces Sex Charges
description: The principal of a Catholic high school was arrested yesterday and charged with criminal sexual contact and endangering the welfare of a child, the Morris County prosecutor's office said. The principal, Frank D. Mattiace, 66, of Montville, was arrested at Bayley-Ellard High School in Madison, said Lt. Jeffrey S. Paul of the prosecutor's office. The victim, a 17-year-old boy, complained to his parents about the principal's behavior, and they contacted the Madison police, said Lieutenant Paul, declining to elaborate on the charges. Mr. Mattiace was released after posting $50,000 bail, Lieutenant Paul said. He was forbidden to have contact with the victim and to have any unsupervised contact with children under 18. A message left at Mr. Mattiace's home was not answered last night. Msgr. James L. Fallon, the school's chaplain, said the principal intended to continue in his position. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: DEY TO PAY $18.5 MILLION TO SETTLE FRAUD ALLEGATIONS
description: Dey Inc., a unit of Merck of Germany, agreed to pay $18.5 million to the United States and Texas to settle Medicaid fraud allegations, the Justice Department said yesterday. The company, which is based in Napa, Calif., and manufactures prescription drugs for the treatment of respiratory diseases, submitted false price information and caused providers to submit inflated reimbursement claims, the Justice Department said.

title: Idaho Senator May Release Some Air Force Promotions
description: Under pressure from the White House, Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, said today that he would relent on some of the 850 Air Force promotions that he has blocked.

title: 'La Bohme' Is to Close After 228 Performances
description: Baz Luhrmann's daring modern restaging of the Puccini opera ''La Bohme'' will close on June 29, its producers said yesterday. The production, which cost about $8.5 million to mount at the Broadway Theater, recouped only about a quarter of that investment.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sirius Satellite Names Financial Chief
description: The broadcasting company Sirius Satellite Radio hired David J. Frear as chief financial officer yesterday after taking two steps to bolster its financial condition and keep the company operating next year. Mr. Frear, 46, previously spent four years as chief financial officer of the Savvis Communications Corporation, a provider of data-networking services, which he left in February. He starts Monday and will succeed John Scelfo, who left in April after two years at the company. Sirius restructured about $636 million in debt in March and received a net $126 million earlier this month from a stock sale.

title: Democrats to Study Pataki Administration Use of Authorities
description: The Assembly's Democratic majority has begun an inquiry into the Pataki administration's use of public authorities for patronage appointments and the lobbying of authorities by the governor's former aides and political allies.

title: DNA Evidence Frees 3 Men In 1984 Murder of L.I. Girl
description: When 16-year-old Theresa Fusco was found raped and strangled near the roller-skating rink where she worked, ripples of anxiety spread across Long Island. Not only was the crime horrific, but it took place around the same time that two other teenage girls vanished from places nearby.

He was 87.

description: Apparently in a sign of dissatisfaction with the progress on the search for illegal weapons in Iraq, the Bush administration is turning to a former top United Nations weapons inspector to provide advice on how to more effectively focus the hunt, officials said today.

title: Age, Language, Rock 'n' Roll
description: When it was announced that this week Steely Dan was releasing its ninth studio album, the news came as something of a surprise. After all, it took the band 20 years to release a follow-up to their 1980 ''Gaucho'' album. That follow-up, ''Two Against Nature,'' won Steely Dan its first-ever Grammy, for album of the year in 2001, beating Eminem for the night's top award (not to mention for risqu lyrics, in Steely Dan's case about incest and statutory rape).

title: McDonald's Campaign Embraces a Loving Theme
description: Eager to capitalize on a crumb of sales momentum after years of shortfalls, foul-ups and blunders, the McDonald's Corporation is taking a new creative direction in its advertising and marketing, based on persuading fast-food fans to rekindle their onetime love affair with the struggling restaurateur.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Security Chief In U.N. Custody
description: Jovica Stanisic, once the feared chief of Serbia's secret police, was sent to the United Nations prison in The Hague to face charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity. A close ally of the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, the former police chief's arrival was notable because he was one of the main organizers of secret police and paramilitary actions against civilians in the Serbian wars against Bosnia and Croatia. He had been indicted with his deputy, Franko Simatovic, now also at The Hague. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Quizno's Evaluates Aspects of Its Account
description: Quizno's, the chain of sandwich shops, has placed in review the various assignments that make up its account, including advertising, which has been handled by Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York since 1999.

title: CONTINENTAL AND KLM AIRLINES TO EXTEND PARTNERSHIP
description: Continental Airlines and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that they had extended their marketing partnership, called a code-share alliance, until 2010. They also said that they had agreed to expand the cities involved in the partnership. Continental will put its code on KLM flights to an additional 22 cities. This is subject to government approval. In a code-sharing alliance, airlines can book passengers on each other's flights, and passengers can choose which frequent-flier program is credited for the miles flown. Passengers who are members of one airline's executive club program can use the lounges of a partner airline. Northwest Airlines is also a partner with Continental and KLM, and it will remain part of the alliance in the extended agreement, the companies said. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: Introducing New Faces and Talent From Brooklyn
description: A combination trade show and public exhibition of Brooklyn design talent will start tomorrow at St. Ann's Warehouse (38 Water Street) in Dumbo and run through Sunday. More than 100 of Brooklyn's own will show, among other items, furniture, rugs and tableware. Kenneth Adams, president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, wants to spotlight emerging as well as established local talent. For hours and more information: www.brooklyndesigns.net or (718) 875-1000, extension 124. The aluminum and plexiglass Infinity hanging lamp ($425), above, is from Martel Fabrication; sales@martelfab.com. Another exhibitor, 3 Square, will show off its 3-Hi bookshelf, below, in walnut ($1,700). It also comes in maple and in one- and two-shelf versions at Foundation, 329 Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn; (718) 403-9757. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

title: National Briefing | West: California: Antismoking Message Aimed At Gays
description: The state unveiled two antismoking advertisements that will appear in publications for gay men and lesbians. It is the first time that the state has used tax money from an antitobacco initiative to reach gay audiences. Officials said that the prevalence of smoking among gay men and lesbians was 70 percent higher than among the general population. ''The state's lesbian and gay communities smoke at distressingly high rates,'' said Dr. Diana M. Bonta, the state health director. One advertisement says that smoking is the No. 1 killer among gays, lesbians, bisexuals and transgendered people. The other says tobacco companies promote their products among gays. Two tobacco companies have challenged the campaign in federal court. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHERBATOW, , PRINCE ALEXEI PAVLOVICH
description: SCHERBATOW--Prince Alexei Pavlovich. We are sorry to inform you that the Honorary Chairman of the Russian Nobility Association in America (RNA), Professor of History, Prince Alexei Pavlovich Scherbatow passed away at 6pm on June 10, 2003 in NYC. Alexis Scherbatow was born in St. Petersburg on November 14, 1910 and was a descendant of the ancient Rurik Dynasty. Together with his family he immigrated in 1920 and lived for many years in Europe before moving to the United States where he gained renown as a professor of history and genealogy expert. He served in the US Army from 1943 to 1945 on the European front. Prince Scherbatow headed the RNA for many years and upon his recent retirement was appointed Honorary Chairman and Director for Life of this organization. Many honors and tributes were awarded to him by Russian, American and European organizations in recognition of his contributions to the study and teaching of history. Outgoing, generous to a fault and endowed with inherent Russian charm Alexis Scherbatow was blessed with a delightful sense of humor that pervades the pages of his extraordinary life in a soon-to-be published memoirs. Funeral service will be held at: Bishop's Synod of the Russian Orthodox Church, corner of Park Ave and 93 St, NY, NY Friday June 13, at 7:30 pm. The funeral mass will take place at the same location at 10am on Saturday, June 14. The interment will be at the Holy Trinity Russian Orthodox Monastery in Jordanville, New York. >>AD#

title: U.S. Official for Iraq Leaving New Constitution Up to Iraqis
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  The American administrator for Iraq described a hands-off approach today to the writing of a new constitution for the country, saying that if the Iraqi drafters favor even a return to socialism, "that will be their business."

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Call For Chief Justice To Quit
description: Less than a week after President Nstor Kirchner called on Congress to impeach the Supreme Court, saying it was ''holding the country's governability hostage,'' the tribunal's newest member urged the chief justice, Julio Nazareno, to resign. Mr. Nazareno, who is already facing congressional hearings to remove him from office on the ground of malfeasance, was accused of ''putting respect for the judicial branch at risk'' by violating ''norms of decorum'' in responding to Mr. Kirchner's proposal with a derisive vulgarity. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: REGAL ENTERTAINMENT TO PAY ONE-TIME CASH DIVIDEND
description: The Regal Entertainment Group, one of the world's largest movie theater chains, said yesterday that it would pay investors a one-time cash dividend of $5.05 for each share they hold. The dividend is payable July 1 to shareholders of record on June 20, the company said. Regal, which operates United Artists Theatres, Edwards Theatres and Regal Cinemas, said last month that it would use the proceeds from the sale of $200 million in convertible senior notes for the dividend. The company will pay out about $715 million. Quarterly payments of 15 cents a share, which began in December, will be reduced to 12 cents, the company said in May. Regal, which is based in Centennial, Colo., is scheduled to pay its regular dividend tomorrow.

title: Hidden Game: Pursuit of the Perfect Club

title: Japan to Spend $16.5 Billion to Save Bank
description: The Japanese government announced today that it would spend $25 billion to ease private pain: $8.5 billion to buy bonds issued by corporations and $16.5 billion to all but nationalize one of the nation's largest banks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Pickle Company To Pay Back Wages
description: The Tuv Taam Corporation, a producer of pickles, blintzes and hummus, agreed yesterday to pay up to $860,000 in back wages to 200 workers to settle charges that it paid less than minimum wage, sometimes 20 percent less. Tuv Taam, which is in Williamsburg, also agreed to pay $215,000 in damages, said Eliot Spitzer, the state attorney general. In the settlement, Tuv Taam did not admit wrongdoing. Mr. Spitzer had accused the company of violating state and federal wage laws from 1996 to 2001. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Israel Presses Its Assault on Hamas, Killing Leader in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, June 12 — Israel pressed ahead with airstrikes against Hamas militants today as helicopters blasted a car with rockets in Gaza City, killing seven people, including a Hamas leader who was targeted, along with his wife and 3-year-old daughter.

description: Four years after arguing that humans probably got the AIDS virus from butchering chimpanzees for food, the same researchers say they have traced the origin back one step further: to the monkeys that the chimpanzees ate.

description: The Bush administration has decided to place teams of American inspectors at major seaports in Muslim nations and other smaller, strategically located foreign ports to prevent terrorists from using cargo containers to smuggle chemical, biological or nuclear weapons into the United States, senior administration officials said.

title: SALERNO NAMED CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF AVIS AND BUDGET
description: The Cendant Corporation, the travel and real estate services company, said yesterday that it had named F. Robert Salerno as the chief executive of its Avis and Budget car-rental business. Mr. Salerno, 52, had served as president and chief operating officer of the car-rental group since Cendant acquired Budget in November, Cendant said. David Siegel led Avis before leaving in March 2002, said Ted Deutsche, a spokesman. title: Let Flies Keep Out, Let Summer Fly In
description: UNLESS your 6-year-old pokes a hole in it, a tipsy dinner guest leans too hard on it or -- as happened during an early scene in ''The Wizard of Oz'' -- a violent wind rips it from its hinges, you are liable to take your screen door for granted. Sure, the slapping sound echoes in your memory like the melody of a childhood summer. And, sure, the striking plate or the hydraulic door-closer needs an occasional maddening adjustment. But for the most part, it is just there, letting breezes in and keeping mosquitoes and hornets out, a curtain of frame and mesh that guards the border between domesticated air and something slightly wilder.

Pryor, Alabama's attorney general, who has gained prominence as an outspoken opponent of legalized abortion and as an advocate for a greater Christian influence in government, told skeptical Democrats on the Judiciary Committee today that his personal views would have no bearing on his performance if he is confirmed as a federal judge.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Four Killed and One Hurt In Separate Incidents
description: Four men died from gunfire in Brooklyn, and a fifth was near death after a fistfight in Manhattan, all the victims of violent altercations between Tuesday afternoon and sunrise yesterday, the police said. About 4:30 p.m. Tuesday, an unidentified 28-year-old man sitting in a car in Bath Beach was shot to death. About an hour later, Khamar Clarke, 16, was fatally shot on a street in East Flatbush. Just before 10 p.m., Eugene Byrd, 20, was shot in front of a building in Crown Heights, and he died at Kings County Hospital Center. After 1 a.m. yesterday, an unidentified man involved in an argument with four other men in Borough Park was shot to death. And outside the Copacabana nightclub in Manhattan, an argument ended in a punch, and the victim, also unidentified, fell to the ground, hit his head and was taken to St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital. He is likely to die, the police said. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: An Architect's World Turned Upside Down

But in the clinic's cafeteria on Monday, Mr. Graves was wearing a polo shirt in the cerulean blue he has made famous on everything from high-rise apartment buildings to Target spatulas as he lunched with a band of elderly ladies in wheelchairs.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BANKER CAUTIOUS ON RATE CUT The president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, suggested three interest rate cuts by the bank in the last six months may be enough to revive the economies of the dozen nations using the euro currency. "It is too early to again discuss further steps," Mr. Duisenberg said in a televised interview Tuesday night. Asked if the bank had room to lower rates further, he said, "I don't know that." The bank cut borrowing costs last week by half a point, to 2 percent, the lowest level for any country in the 12-state euro region in more than 50 years. (Bloomberg News)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: SIRIUS SATELLITE NAMES FINANCIAL CHIEF The broadcasting company Sirius Satellite Radio hired David J. Frear as chief financial officer yesterday after taking two steps to bolster its financial condition and keep the company operating next year. Mr. Frear, 46, previously spent four years as chief financial officer of the Savvis Communications Corporation, a provider of data-networking services, which he left in February. He starts Monday and will succeed John Scelfo, who left in April after two years at the company. Sirius restructured about $636 million in debt in March and received a net $126 million earlier this month from a stock sale.   (Bloomberg News)
