The bid was being prepared by Bream Investments, a group set up for the takeover by Robin Saunders, an American-born banker who is the head of WestLB's finance unit in London. Bream has until June 18 to meet a deadline set by Britain's takeover panel to either make or abandon the bid. AWG said it would discuss a higher bid, and a spokesman for Bream said the group is looking for alternative backers. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Science: British Groups To Study Nanotechnology
description: The British government has commissioned the Royal Society and the Royal Academy of Engineering to study the fast-growing field of nanotechnology and make recommendations on how it should be regulated, the two science groups said yesterday. Nanotechnology deals with materials whose size is measured in nanometers, or billionths of a meter, which is the realm of molecules. The study will look at current research, where the field is likely to be in 10 years, and longer-term prospects, according to Prof. Ann Dowling, an engineering expert from Cambridge University who will direct the study. The report is expected to be done by next April. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bank Outlook Lowered
description: Standard & Poor's, the credit-rating agency, cut its outlook on the Hong Kong subsidiary of Bank of China to negative. The change means the agency is more likely to lower its long-term rating of BBB+ for the unit. The agency cited concerns about how the unit was approving loans, pointing out that the bank has forced a borrower, New Nongkai Global Investments Ltd., into bankruptcy a little less than a year after extending it a loan of $270 million, with $95 million of that still outstanding as of June 5. The downgrading is a humiliation for the Bank of China, one of China's four main state-owned banks; all of them are plagued with bad debts on the mainland. Bank of China made an initial public offering of shares in the Hong Kong unit last summer, with UBS Warburg, Goldman Sachs and Bank of China International as the lead managers. The former chief executive of the bank unit, Liu Jinbao, was recalled to Beijing last month and is reportedly under investigation. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

The bank went into insolvency after Nick Leeson, a British trader at its Singapore branch, incurred losses of more than $1 billion. The court said the auditing firm bore responsibility for failing to identify some transactions from November 1992 to April 1994, before the biggest losses. Deloitte faces a 130 million ($217 million) claim from Barings's liquidator. Alan Cowell (NYT)

An editors' note with that account said The Times would continue spot-checking Mr. Blair's earlier articles and invited readers to report any discrepancies to retrace@nytimes.com.

title: The University of California Names Insider as President
description: The University of California Board of Regents today chose an insider, Robert C. Dynes, to be the new president of the nine-campus university system. For the last seven years, Dr. Dynes has been chancellor at the University of California at San Diego.

title: The Man Behind The Wienermobile
description: The industrial designer Brooks Stevens (right), who coined the phrase ''planned obsolescence,'' made the Skytop Lounge car (above) in 1947 for the Milwaukee Road's Olympian Hiawatha train service. A decade later he followed with the Oscar Meyer Wienermobile. Some might call Stevens a sellout, but ''he never intended to be anything else,'' said Glenn Adamson, curator of the Milwaukee Art Museum show on the designer. Highlights include the original wide-mouth peanut butter jar (1934), the Miller Beer High Life logo and a Formica pattern with boomerangs. Through Sept. 7; $6 admission to the museum. A 15-minute tour of a restored Skytop outside the museum addition designed by Santiago Calatrava is $5 for adults; (414) 224-3200 or www.mam.org. CRAIG KELLOGG

title: David Brinkley, Elder Statesman of TV News, Dies at 82
description: David Brinkley, whose pungent news commentaries, delivered with a mixture of wry skepticism and succinct candor, set the standard for network television for generations, died at his home in Houston late Wednesday. He was 82.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Restaurants Protest New Rules
description: A restaurant trade group charged yesterday that the city was hurting New York restaurants with higher fines and arbitrary new health inspections. The group, the New York State Restaurant Association, said in a lawsuit filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn that the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene adopted the new rules in March without adequate public notice and that they were intended to raise money rather than ensure public health. Two restaurants, Marco Polo Ristorante in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and Brooks 1890 in Long Island City, Queens, joined the suit. Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the health commissioner, said restaurants were notified well in advance about the rules. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Mets on Their Way to a Home-Grown Infield
description: The Mets minor league system has taken some hits over the last five years, losing top prospects in trades for AL LEITER, MIKE PIAZZA, MIKE HAMPTON and ROBERTO ALOMAR. Yet when the Mets promoted the top prospect JOSE REYES this week, it gave them three-quarters of a home-grown infield.

description: After years of pursuing legal action against Midwestern and Southern power plants for their emissions, New York State has settled a pollution case in its own backyard.

description: After a decade of soaring spending on prescription drugs, employers and health plans are forcing their workers to pay more for most drugs and refusing payment entirely for certain medicines that they reject as not essential.

title: A.C.C. Puts Off Expansion Vote As Big East Seeks a Dialogue
description: The presidents of the nine Atlantic Coast Conference universities again delayed a vote on expansion yesterday, even as their counterparts within the Big East Conference requested a face-to-face meeting between the two sides in an effort to derail the A.C.C.'s expansion plan.

description: There was magic onstage Tuesday night at the New York State Theater. New York City Ballet's all-Balanchine program offered a many-faceted view of the choreographer. But this was also an evening of sensational dancing, both loud and quiet.

description: In a symbolic rebuke to the Bush administration, the member nations of the Organization of American States have for the first time voted to exclude the United States from representation on the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, considered the most prestigious human rights monitoring body in the Western Hemisphere.

description: The Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association, the upstart labor group that has been an irritant to bigger, more powerful unions over the last decade, is now after its biggest prize yet: the 14,000 mechanics at United Airlines.

title: An Ergonomic Keyboard Has Typists Floating on Air
description: Unlike owners of desktop computers, laptop users are generally stuck with the keyboard supplied by the manufacturer. Owners of some laptops made by Apple, however, now have a choice. The TouchStream MacNTouch keyboard from FingerWorks not only rearranges the keys into what the company claims is a more ergonomic layout, but also allows users to direct the cursor and enter commands with hand gestures.

title: Manchester Journal; For English Fans, Soccer Could Lose Its Spice
description: If the soccer star David Beckham leaves England, along with his exotic hairstyles, his feuds with his boss, his multitude of endorsements, his fancy sarongs and his slinky fashion plate of a wife, what will there be left for people here to discuss?

title: Entering a Dream Landscape (But, Really, It's a Store)
description: ''If I had wanted a retail space, I would have hired a retail architect,'' said Carlos Miele, far right, a Brazilian fashion designer who has opened shop on West 14th Street. So Mr. Miele hired Hani Rashid and Lise Anne Couture, above right, of the New York firm Asymptote. ''I like to work with people who aren't easily labeled,'' he said. For his first store outside Brazil, he wanted a space where fashion, architecture and art could meet -- reflecting his own interests as couturier and performance, installation and video artist. Asymptote (known for virtual environments, furniture and exhibitions) has renovated the trading floor for the New York Stock Exchange, and created HydraPier, an exhibition pavilion in the Netherlands. For Mr. Miele, the architects made a dreamy, melting landscape, above, whose Arctic palette makes the intricate clothing -- body-baring fashions blending primitive and high-tech materials and processes -- appear like a chimera. The store's drippy heat-formed plastic ceiling and swirl-patterned epoxy floor echo work of Brazilian modernists like Oscar Niemeyer and Roberto Burle Marx. The punctured form of its centerpiece, a sensuous altar, pays respect to Mr. Miele's peekaboo clothing. Carlos Miele, 408 West 14th Street, (646) 336-6642. CATHY LANG HO

title: In Iraq, Things Really Aren't That Bad
description: Two months after the fall of Saddam Hussein's regime, Iraq is widely depicted as a nation in chaos, with armed gangs dominating Baghdad's streets amid a widespread breakdown of public services. Having returned from Iraq two weeks ago, I believe this picture is distorted. In fact, we may soon look back at the postwar looting as only a bump in a long road.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suspect Held In String Of Burglaries
description: The police yesterday arrested a man believed to be the so-called Spider-Man burglar responsible for at least 11 burglaries on the Upper West and East Sides over the past month. The suspect, Rufus Graham, 40, was arrested early Wednesday morning on West 45th Street after he jumped from the window of a commercial building after what the police called an unsuccessful burglary attempt. Hours after his arrest, detectives released a sketch of the suspect in a string of 25 burglaries, most of which took place on the Upper West Side, because they were not yet certain if Mr. Graham was involved. Mr. Graham later confessed to 11 of the burglaries, they said. He has a record of arrests dating back to 1985 for burglary, larceny and drug sales, the police said. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Soldier's Life For Harry
description: Prince Harry, 18, the younger son of Prince Charles and Diana, the Princess of Wales, and third in line to the British throne, finished his last day at Eton School, and his father's office disclosed that he would apply to the Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst and pursue an army career. Like his brother, William, 20, now a student at St. Andrews University in Scotland, Harry will spend a so-called gap year abroad before beginning his military studies. At Eton, Harry overcame discipline problems to rise to the top rank of officer cadet. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: GROUP LED BY GOLDMAN IS INVESTING IN BORDER MEDIA
description: Goldman Sachs said yesterday that it was investing in Border Media, which operates radio stations along the border between Texas and Mexico. Goldman Sachs is making the investment through its urban investment group, a fund that invests in minority-owned businesses, together with a fund operated by Darby Overseas, a Washington-based investment company, and BBVA, the big Spanish bank. The total investment is $15 million. Border Media, based in Houston, operates six Spanish-language radio stations, including two that it recently acquired in Laredo and the Rio Grande Valley. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Knicks Are Thinking Big Now
description: At almost every basket in the Knicks' training facility today, a hopeful prospect stood sweating, finishing off a nearly two-hour workout and hoping that he had caught someone's eye. But the reality was that when the Knicks pick at No. 9 on June 26, they have bigger targets in mind.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Review Possible For Water Facility
description: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has agreed to sponsor legislation requiring an additional environmental impact review on an important supplier of New York City's water. A plan for a water filtration plant in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx has drawn fire from environmentalists. The plant would treat contaminated water from the Croton Watershed in Westchester in an effort to comply with federal water-treatment guidelines. The review, which will evaluate other possible sites in Westchester and Manhattan, is expected to take six months. With less than two weeks left in the legislative session, an Assembly vote is expected soon. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: POZEN SAYS DEAL WITH GLAXO MAY BE WORTH $160 MILLION
description: Pozen Inc., an unprofitable developer of migraine drugs, said yesterday that it might gain as much as $160 million from an agreement with GlaxoSmithKline to develop new treatments for headaches. Glaxo, Europe's biggest drug maker, will have rights in the United States to market migraine treatments based on Pozen's MT 400 formulation. The agreement gives Pozen, based in Chapel Hill, N.C., its first revenue. The company is seeking to develop drugs and license them to bigger pharmaceutical partners. Glaxo will pay Pozen $25 million this year and as much as $55 million total over the next few years if they meet certain goals. If products are approved, Glaxo will also pay Pozen as much as $80 million in royalties on sales.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Lawyer Urges Bail
description: A lawyer for the jailed opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, urged a judge in Harare to release his client, arguing that the government of President Robert Mugabe was using Mr. Tsvangirai's imprisonment to silence the most potent challenge to the president's 23-year rule. The lawyer, George Bizos, said that if Mr. Tsvangirai were not released, the court would have abused its power by ''keeping political opponents silent.'' Mr. Tsvangirai has been in jail since last Friday, when he was arrested on treason charges after his party, the Movement of Democratic Change, organized days of demonstrations and strikes demanding that Mr. Mugabe resign. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
description: India's industrial output rose 4.9 percent in April, aided by a rise in consumer spending that increased growth in the manufacturing sector. Manufacturing, which accounts for 80 percent of the industrial output, grew 5.0 percent. The rate of increase declined from earlier months, when it exceeded 6 percent, but was higher than the 4.1 percent a year earlier, according to the report, which was released by the Central Statistical Organization. Growth was retrained by a strike by truckers, which disrupted shipments of industrial goods, the report said. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Shaking Off 250 Years of Dust at Early Music Festival
description: If you take a seat at a bar in a downtown Boston restaurant this weekend, don't be surprised if you happen to overhear some people heatedly debating, say, the influence of Pythagorean theory on musical composition and instrument design during the Renaissance, as happened to me the other day. The 12th Boston Early Music Festival and Exhibition is under way. The city, already a center of the early-music movement, becomes its mecca when this acclaimed biennial gathering brings hundreds more musicians, instrument makers, scholars and publishers to town.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: City Clerk Charged In Gun Trafficking
description: A city clerk has been charged with selling 27 illegal guns to undercover police detectives over the past 15 months, the authorities said yesterday. The police traced one of the 9-millimeter guns to a nonfatal shooting that occurred on Oct. 13, 2001, in the 73rd Precinct. The clerk, Lester Battle, 28, a seven-year city employee who works in the Human Resources Administration, was arrested on Wednesday outside the Brooklyn office where he works. The authorities said that in one case, Mr. Battle, of 70-38 Parsons Boulevard, in Queens, sold three guns outside his office during his lunch break. He was charged with 11 counts of criminal sale of a firearm and other charges. Mr. Battle's brother, Saiyd Pryor, 21, who lives at the same address, was also arrested, the police said. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: A Pair of Young Lovers On a Well-Known Balcony
description: Sir Kenneth MacMillan's production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' is a sumptuous spectacle with few opportunities for all-out dancing or nuanced characterization. Three casts at American Ballet Theater made the most of the crucial balcony scene, which perfectly embodies the rhapsodic Prokofiev music in its sweeping runs, brief clings and soaring lifts. The portrayals of the doomed lovers were generally less distinctive.

description: An article yesterday about New York State's settlement of a pollution case against the past and current owners of a coal-fired power plant in Stony Point, N.Y., misstated the amount to be spent by the current owner, Mirant New York, to reduce emissions. It is about $100 million, not $1 million.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blair Shuffles Ministers
description: One of Prime Minister Tony Blair's closest ministers, John Reid, the leader of the Commons, replaced another Blair ally, Alan Milburn, as health secretary in a cabinet shake-up that also ends the historic post of lord chancellor. Lord Irvine, the current lord chancellor, announced his retirement, and Mr. Blair used the opportunity to incorporate the ancient office's responsibility for the judiciary into a new department of constitutional affairs. Mr. Milburn attributed his surprise decision to resign to family reasons. Peter Hain, now secretary for Wales, succeeds Mr. Reid. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Trying to Escape From Custody, Iraqi Prisoner Is Shot to Death
description: An Iraqi prisoner died today of gunshot wounds suffered when he tried to escape from a coalition-run camp in Baghdad, the United States Central Command said. Another prisoner who tried to escape was recaptured.

title: 'Jet Lag'
description: Directed by Danile Thompson

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEEDS, , MORTON
description: LEEDS--Morton. June 13th 1984. Miss your quick wit, warmth and good humor. Always with lov

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cordiant Shareholders To Meet
description: The Cordiant Communications Group, the troubled British advertiser, said it would hold an emergency shareholder meeting on June 28, to allow investors to vote on the sale of its Australian and German assets. The loss of a key client earlier this year sent Cordiant into a tailspin, and the company is now shedding units and considering a sale. Cordiant has been actively evaluating a range of more detailed proposals, including possible offers for the company or a recapitalization plan, the company said. The WPP Group said earlier this month it was evaluating a bid for Cordiant. Active Value Managers, which holds 14 percent of Cordiant's stock, has asked for the company's management to step down and proposes injecting capital into the business. The company also said net debt rose 33 percent to 201.2 million ($335.5 million) in the four months ending April 30. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: XO MAY CHANGE BID FOR GLOBAL CROSSING TO CASH
description: XO Communications said yesterday that it might offer $700 million in cash for Global Crossing, the bankrupt optical network operator, after an initial offer, which included notes and warrants, was spurned by Global Crossing's creditors. XO, controlled by the financier Carl C. Icahn, said it also might offer $472.5 million for the company's bank debt, on the condition that Global Crossing cancels an agreement to sell control to Singapore Technologies Telemedia. Creditors on Tuesday backed a plan to sell majority control of the company to Singapore Technologies Telemedia, saying rival bids would make it harder for Global Crossing to exit Chapter 11.

title: Do-Ho Suh
description: Lehmann Maupin

title: The Twilight Outlaws of Foley Sq.; When Courts Close, Doo-Wop and Daredevils Emerge
description: When the sun dips low on the horizon, and the judges, lawyers, clerks and stenographers head for home, other New Yorkers take over Foley Square in Lower Manhattan: skateboarders, doo-wop singers and, of course, the homeless.

title: Leo Strauss's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: U.S. Deports Ex-Judge
description: Abdi Ali Nur Mohamed, a former Somali military judge, was ordered deported from the United States by an immigration judge in San Diego. American agents discovered that Mr. Mohamed, an asylum seeker who arrived in the United States in 1990 and lived there legally, according to officials of the Department of Homeland Security, had been accused of atrocities in Somalia years ago. The officials said he had participated in the execution of civilians near the city of Hargeisa during the dictatorship of Muhammad Siad Barre, who was overthrown in 1991. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Funds For Acquisitions
description: The building materials company Lafarge said it would raise 1.28 billion euros ($1.5 billion) by selling new shares to buy cement and aggregates businesses in Europe and North America. The company, which is based in Paris, has designated 20 percent, or 256 million euros ($301 million), for purchases to take place by the end of the year, according to a Lafarge spokesman, Philippe Hardouin. The remaining funds will be used to strengthen the company's financial structure and eventually to conduct medium-sized acquisitions, not exceeding 300 million euros each, Mr. Hardouin said. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Drought Emergency
description: Gov. Bill Richardson has declared a state of emergency because of a yearlong drought. Mr. Richardson signed an executive order on Wednesday creating a 12-member panel to work on the problem. The declaration makes the state eligible for federal money and lets it spend money on firefighting and water supplies. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Californians May Give Up Their True Love, S.U.V.'s (Officially, Anyway)
description: If sales are any indication, Californians love their sport utility vehicles. By one count, they bought more than 440,000 last year. The S.U.V. is also the vehicle of choice for nearly half of the state's 120 legislators, though many live nowhere near dirt roads or icy peaks.

title: Saudis Fire Clerics Who Preached Intolerance
description: The government of Saudi Arabia said today that it has fired several hundred Islamic clerics and suspended more than 1,000 others for preaching intolerance, part of a broader campaign against terrorism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REGAN, , DONALD T.
description: REGAN--Donald T. 1918-2003. Wally Findlay Galleries deeply mourns the death of our esteemed friend and painter. Donald Regan's third phase as a painter captured his subject matter with simple gestures and innocent perspective. His painting was a medium for his contemplation, cherished memories and a way to touch the heart. We have been privileged to have known him and to represent him as an artist. Our deepest sympathy to his loving wife, Ann, and to his family. James R. Borynack, Chairman and CEO and the entire Wally Findlay Galleries Staff >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: WEST MILFORD: MAN CHARGED IN BEAR SHOOTING A homeowner, Patrick Flynn Jr., who shot a 400-pound black bear that was drawn to his house by the smell of pork chops, was charged yesterday with unlawfully injuring an animal. The summons from the state's Department of Environmental Protection carries a fine of between $100 and $300. Although Mr. Flynn told the authorities that on June 5 he shot the bear in self-defense, an examination indicated that the bear  which was later euthanized  was retreating when it was shot. The case is scheduled to be heard in Municipal Court on July 1. (AP)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Action On Air Force Promotions
description: The Senate approved promotions for 127 Air Force captains and majors that Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho, had blocked. Mr. Craig, who is fighting the Air Force over stationing four C-130 cargo planes near Boise, relented on the 127 officers, but continued to delay action on 85 colonels and generals. Christopher Marquis (NYT)

title: David Brinkley
description: David Brinkley once puckishly defined the secret strength of television news: ''When there is no news, we give it to you with the same emphasis as if there were.'' More beguilingly, Mr. Brinkley, who died on Wednesday night at the age of 82, had the grace to let the viewer in on this secret with open wit and almost no broadcast bombast. In fact, anyone who witnessed the black-and-white era of TV news could relish the downtime when Mr. Brinkley would be left with little more to offer than his signature wryness. Waiting for the next balloon drop at one of the 60's political conventions, he smilingly summarized the gathering with a head bob of emphasis as ''the first convention of the space age -- where a candidate can promise the moon and mean it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKLAR, , LEO J., M.D.
description: SKLAR--Leo J., M.D. Died peacefully with devoted family at his side on June 12, 2003. Beloved husband and best friend of Rita Gruber Sklar. Loving father of Susan and Fred Drath, Peter and Joyce, and Patty and Steven Greenstein. Cherished Poppi of Caroline and David Perel, Matthew and Rachel, Vanessa, Gabrielle, Keith and Michele. Graduate of the University of Maryland and Georgetown Medical School. A Major in the U.S. Army Medical Corp. during WWII in the Pacific Theatre. Received Bronze Star with clusters and other honors. Practiced internal medicine for forty years in Lawrence, N.Y. Leo will be remembered as a gentle and kind man. He was loved, respected and admired by all who knew him, personally and professionally. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 11:30AM Friday.

title: IN MAJOR ASSAULT, U.S. FORCES STRIKE HUSSEIN LOYALISTS
description: American forces attacked an enemy camp in Iraq today, killing scores of fighters in the deadliest operation since President Bush declared on May 1 that the major fighting was over.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cuts For Carmaker
description: The chief executive of Volkswagen, Bernd Pischetsrieder, said that cost reductions were needed at the company as economic growth in the company's main markets stagnated. ''All expenses must be reviewed,'' Mr. Pischetsrieder said. ''Each worker can and must make a contribution to ensure the future.'' Mr. Pischetsrieder said he did not expect the economies of Western Europe, the United States or South America to improve in the short term.

title: U.N. Renews U.S. Peacekeepers' Exemption From Prosecution
description: In the face of polite but firm opposition from the European Union, the Security Council today approved a one-year renewal of a 2002 measure exempting United States peacekeepers from the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court.

title: A Technology Stock Offering Is Up 25%
description: Shares of FormFactor rose more than 25 percent yesterday, a day after the company, a maker of computer chip testing equipment, raised $84 million in the first initial public offering by a United States technology company this year.

title: Bush Announces an Easing of Rules on New Generic Drugs
description: President Bush announced new rules today that make it easier to introduce lower-cost generic versions of prescription drugs, intensifying his efforts to address health care issues ahead of next year's election.

title: Gregory Peck
description: Motion picture stars have always occupied a special village of celebrity, where they perform the great service of giving the residents of an urban and mobile planet some common acquaintances to gossip about. Once they stop making films and retire from the public sphere, they are lost to the village, as good as dead. Yet at the same time the recyclable art form they practice gives them a sort of limited immortality.

title: Top Discus Thrower Will Miss the Finals
description: Six weeks ago, Gabor Mate, a 24-year-old Auburn senior from Hungary, threw the discus 219 feet 9 inches. That was the longest ever by a college athlete and the second longest in the world this year.

description: HUSAIN--Dr. Syed Qasim, son of Dr. Abid Husain and Dr. Anwari Husain, passed away in Staten Island on June 6, 2003 unexpectedly. My father graduated from M.I.T. and the University of Liverpool, England with a PhD in Pure Mathematics. At M.I.T., he was a student of the esteemed Professor John Nash, who went on to receive a Nobel Prize. Professor Husain taught at several universities that included Fordham University, the University of McMaster, King Saud University, Riyad, Saudi Arabia and Rajshahi University. He leaves behind his wife, Shahzadi Meerza and two daughters, Zainab Husain and Kauser Haider. From Allah we come, and to Him we must return. The Family can be contacted at 718-984-0345. >>AD#

The official did not say the United States wanted the agency to refer the issue to the United Nations Security Council; rather he said such a referral was not anticipated.

description: ''You have to be crazy to run this town because we're a bunch of crazy people. You've got to kick down doors. Rudy's crazy, and he was effective. Bloomberg doesn't have the gusto to really deal with issues in an aggressive manner.''

title: AMERICA'S RECORD ON NATION BUILDING
description: Washington has long invested heavily in its armed forces' ability to fight wars, and has seen a remarkable return on that investment. Yet there has been no comparable progression in American competence at stabilizing and rebuilding societies emerging from tyranny and war.

title: Shooting for 300
description: Weather permitting, Roger Clemens will try for his 300th victory tonight against the St. Louis Cardinals -- his fourth attempt in two weeks to reach a lofty plateau occupied by only 20 major league pitchers. Viewed strictly as theater, his quest obviously becomes more compelling with each failure. From a personal standpoint, though, Clemens would just as soon win the game and end the suspense. We're inclined to agree.

title: Mets Tell Phillips: Enough Is Enough
description: The Mets put General Manager Steve Phillips on notice last October, failed to support him this season and, almost mercifully, dismissed him from his job yesterday in what is likely to be one of the first moves in the dismantling of a last-place team. Jim Duquette, the team's senior assistant general manager, was named Phillips's interim replacement.

title: U.N. Says Hunger Threatens Southern Africa Despite Plenty
description: Despite a bumper crop of grain and plentiful rains this harvest season, food shortages remain a serious problem in large pockets of southern Africa, a United Nations agency reported today.

title: Maker Admits It Hid Problems In Artery Device
description: A division of one of the country's largest makers of medical devices pleaded guilty yesterday to 10 felonies, admitting that it lied to the government and hid thousands of serious health problems, including 12 deaths, caused by one of its products.

title: Climbing the Assassin Career Ladder
description: For those who thought Seijun Suzuki's high-strung, lawless and watchably frenzied shoot-out drama ''Branded to Kill'' (1967) was hard to follow, his femalecentric hybrid remake/sequel ''Pistol Opera,'' which makes marginally more sense, will come as a relief. Or should I say ''relive,'' because that is the goofy subtitled translation of what Dark Horse (Masatoshi Nagase), one of the hit men in this competition of killers, utters to the beautiful heroine, Stray Cat (Makiko Esumi): ''Soon, I'll relive your anxiety with the relief of death.''

title: Van Gundy Wants Ewing With Him
description: Jeff Van Gundy, the former Knicks coach recently hired by the Houston Rockets, said yesterday that he wanted to add some of his former assistants to the Rockets and at least one former player, Patrick Ewing.

title: Builder Agrees To Stabilize Buddhist Site It Damaged
description: A $200 million construction project in Lower Manhattan will remain shut down for several more days after a judge ordered engineers yesterday to come up with a plan to stabilize a Buddhist temple next door that had been so severely damaged by vibrations that the city ordered it vacated.

title: Residential Real Estate; 188 Co-op Units Planned for Ex-Factory in Astoria
description: Work is under way to turn the former Eagle Electric Company factory and warehouse site in Astoria, Queens, into a co-op complex with 188 apartments. The conversion, which includes new construction, is a departure from the overwhelming pattern in recent years of developing for-sale units as condominiums.

title: David Brinkley, 82, Newsman Model, Dies
description: David Brinkley, the wry reporter and commentator whose NBC broadcasts with Chet Huntley from 1956 to 1970 helped to define and popularize television news in America, died on Wednesday night at his home in Houston. He was 82.

title: Phillips Departs and, Suddenly, the Mets Are a Hit
description: In a season of blowouts and embarrassments, the Mets cast a rare victory amid more turmoil tonight.

title: Writing and Speaking Earn Millions for the Clintons
description: WASHINGTON, June 13  The husband is retired, but his wife brings in a steady salary. Indeed, they are sufficiently well-off that he is able to travel the world, addressing groups whose work he admires, like the Australian Council for the Promotion of Peaceful Reunification of China in Sydney and the German Union of Small and Medium-Sized Companies in Munich.

title: Brodeur Is Named League's Top Goalie
description: In a 10-year career that has included three Stanley Cup championships, it is difficult to call a star goalie overlooked. But that has been the perception of Martin Brodeur of the Devils, who, until tonight, had not won a major individual award since the Calder Trophy as rookie of the year in 1994.

title: A Tycoon Whose Trade Was the Past
description: ''Before there was Martha Stewart, there was Wallace Nutting,'' said Thomas Andrew Denenberg, the curator of American decorative arts at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art here. ''He invented what he called 'Old America,' a constellation of moneymaking endeavors based on an idealized past.''

title: A Coach Is Ousted, This One for Betting
description: Rick Neuheisel will be fired as the football coach at the University of Washington, Athletic Director Barbara Hedges said yesterday, a move that would make Neuheisel the fourth prominent college coach to lose his job amid allegations of misconduct in the last three months.

title: World Cup To Skip New York
description: Four years after filling the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif., with more than 90,000 people for the Women's World Cup final, organizers have downsized their ambitions for the 2003 soccer tournament, placing the Oct. 12 championship game at the new Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif., which has a seating capacity of 27,000.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Discipline For 9 In Crime Lab
description: Nine employees of the crime laboratory of the Houston Police Department were disciplined for errors in analyzing DNA and other evidence, giving false information to state auditors and failures in supervision and record keeping. The laboratory shut its DNA unit in January after a state audit found many similar problems. The discipline ranged from one-week, two-week and ''indefinite'' suspensions to resignations or retirements. Two grand juries are considering potential criminal charges. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: John Ashcroft and Gay Pride
description: Last week, the Justice Department said its gay employees' group could no longer hold its annual Gay Pride Month celebration. After a storm of protest, the department has now relented, but it has downgraded the event to unofficial status and wants the group to pay for it. The decision is wrong, and it calls into question whether John Ashcroft understands his duties as head of the Justice Department. He should restore the gay pride event to its full former status.

title: House Passes Limit on Big Class-Action Suits
description: The House today passed a bill that would limit most big class-action lawsuits to federal courts and might make it easier for corporate defendants to delay the progress of suits that judges have already certified.

title: It's Back to the Parking Lot for the New Jersey Devils' Stanley Cup Celebration
description: The celebration of the third Stanley Cup win in nine years by the New Jersey Devils is set for Saturday in the parking lot of the team's home ice at Continental Arena in the Meadowlands.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: ECONOMY QUICKENS IN NEW YORK REGION The Federal Reserve's regular survey of economic conditions nationwide found "fairly widespread signs of a pickup" in the New York region. The signs included a strengthening labor market, increased activity in the real estate market and hints of improvement in financial-sector hiring. The survey, called the Beige Book and published eight times a year, also found bankers reporting increased demand for loans, especially for home mortgages. The anecdotal findings, released late Wednesday, come two weeks after the New York City's unemployment rate dropped for the second straight month. Jason Bram, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said, "It still leaves open the question is this the beginning of a trend or is this just a good month?" Janny Scott (NYT)

title: Olympic Hopefuls Gather in New York
description: With the 2004 Athens Olympics rapidly approaching, the New York City Fencing World Cup is carrying added significance. The World Cup is a leading Olympic qualifying tournament, and the preliminaries at Columbia University yesterday trimmed the number of men's and women's sabre fencers to 128 from 300.

title: It's Dark, Seductive and Rich. Who Can Resist?
description: When warm weather arrives, Hollywood makes car-chase movies. Museums put on shows like ''Chocolate,'' a meandering, mildly educational tribute to the beloved bean, whose genus name, Theobroma, means ''food of the gods.''

description: HADIKS--Dean, Ph.D. Respected administrator, accomplished researcher, admired supervisor, gifted clinician, trusted friend and beloved husband and father. title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT RISES India's industrial output rose 4.9 percent in April, aided by a rise in consumer spending that increased growth in the manufacturing sector. Manufacturing, which accounts for 80 percent of the industrial output, grew 5.0 percent. The rate of increase declined from earlier months, when it exceeded 6 percent, but was higher than the 4.1 percent a year earlier, according to the report, which was released by the Central Statistical Organization. Growth was retrained by a strike by truckers, which disrupted shipments of industrial goods, the report said. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Troubled Child Welfare Agency Gets a New Leader
description: As part of a sweeping set of changes at the top of New Jersey's troubled child welfare agency, state officials announced today that they had hired a nationally recognized administrator with a history of reforming failed child welfare systems to be the agency's new director.

title: From Australia, a Thinking Man's Hood
description: The action-comedy heist film ''The Hard Word'' is amusingly gamy, an anecdotal crime film that's an antidote to the pile of overly slick robbery pictures of the past few years. Unlike such gaudy, gleaming toys -- in which the hoods have access to so many devices and fleets of automobiles that you wonder why they couldn't just retire on the resources they're spending on pulling off the crimes -- ''The Hard Word'' is set in an Australian showroom of broken dreams.

title: Lincoln Center Loses Official Who Oversaw Redevelopment
description: In the latest blow to Lincoln Center, Peter M. Lehrer, a construction executive, resigned yesterday as chairman of its redevelopment project, calling the project wasteful and badly managed.

title: For Victims' Kin, a Painful Reminder
description: Every Wednesday and Sunday, Candice Karol visits the grave of her son Aaron C. Karol, who died three years ago in a dormitory fire at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J. She says she never plans to stop making those visits.

title: Tending a Beautiful Legacy of a Melancholy Life
description: MONEY does not buy happiness, as the life of the tobacco heiress Doris Duke illustrates. But it can buy beauty, and it is the beauty -- the grand mansions, the parks and artwork -- that remains of Ms. Duke's life. Those who waged pitched battles over her fortune in court have died or given up or been paid off. Her legacy of eccentricity and loneliness and vast wealth is something those who now handle her memory and her money would like us to forget. The caretakers have taken over. It is all about beauty now.

title: JURY AWARDS HONEYWELL $30 MILLION IN PATENT LAWSUIT
description: A federal jury has awarded Honeywell International $30 million in a lawsuit against two units of Matsushita Electric Industrial over a patent for video camera technology. The jury, in St. Paul, found that the units, JVC in the United States and Victor in Japan, had infringed Honeywell's patent for a circuit chip used to create the equivalent of electronic film in video camcorders. Victor made the cameras, which are sold in the United States by JVC, a Honeywell spokesman said. Honeywell, based in Morristown, N.J., sued Victor and JVC in 1999, one of a series of lawsuits over the camera technology, a Honeywell spokesman said. The verdict was returned on Monday.

description: The closely watched initial public offering of India's largest carmaker, Maruti Udyog, got off to a resounding start today with the number of bids surpassing the number of shares on offer within a few hours.

title: A Woman Who Hides in Plain Sight From the Nazis
description: The documentary ''The Nazi Officer's Wife'' could just as easily have used the title of another recent film, ''Identity.'' For it is the question of identity that runs through this ever-deepening story, which takes its name from Edith Hahn Beer's autobiographical 1999 book, ''The Nazi Officer's Wife: How One Jewish Woman Survived the Holocaust,'' about hiding in plain sight in Austria and Germany in World War II.

title: House Expands Child Credit As Part of a Larger Tax Cut
description: The House voted today to increase child tax credits for 6.5 million low-income families, but only as part of a larger $82 billion tax-cut bill that provides 96 percent of its benefits to middle- and upper-income taxpayers.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 13  The head of South Korea's largest oil refiner was convicted of accounting fraud today and sentenced to three years in prison.

title: The Vanishing Uranium
description: President Bush cannot be pleased to know that his State of the Union address last January included an ominous report about Iraq that turns out to have been based on forged documents. The incident is an embarrassment for Mr. Bush and for the nation, and he should now be leaning on his aides to explain how they let fabricated information about Iraq's nuclear weapons program slip into his speech. The answer might help explain whether Washington deliberately distorted intelligence to rally the nation for the war against Iraq.

title: Goal Is to Lay Cornerstone at Ground Zero During G.O.P. Convention
description: Rebuilding officials said yesterday that they hoped to complete a review of the environmental impact of the proposed construction at the World Trade Center site by next April. This would allow them to lay the cornerstone of a 1,776-foot tower in August 2004, during the Republican National Convention.

Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the National Briefing column yesterday about the trial of a former college student in Georgia charged with having beaten a fellow dormitory resident misstated the verdict. He was convicted of assault and battery, not of violating the state's new hate crime law. (He has since been acquitted of the hate crime charge.)

title: CHRYSLER PLANS LOWER-PRICE VERSION OF ITS PACIFICA
description: Chrysler said yesterday that it would offer a lower-price version of its Pacifica, a new station wagon, as it tries to more than triple monthly sales of the car. The new version, to begin production in July, will cost less than $30,000, down from about $38,000 for models that started selling in April, the company said. Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, expects Pacifica sales in the United States to rise to about 8,000 to 9,000 a month by the end of the year. Sales through May totaled 4,828. It has said it wants to sell about 100,000 Pacificas a year.

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; Torre Reinvents Himself as Yanks' Caretaker
description: Joe Torre called himself the caretaker of the Yankees after the darkest and bleakest game they have played for him, a warm, gentle way to describe what he does as the manager. Manager sounds formal, but caretaker? A caretaker sounds like a person who mows the infield grass, washes the uniforms, answers the phones, does whatever is necessary.

title: The Next War
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 13  After American M-1 tanks rolled into Baghdad to depose Saddam Hussein, a question was raised as to where the United States might fight next. Would American forces continue their march to Syria? Or would the Bush administration step up the military and political pressure on Iran?

title: 36 Hours | Montreal
description: IF you crave a family trip featuring high culture and haute cuisine but don't want the hassle or the jet lag -- not to mention the air fares -- of Europe, Montreal has it all. Though it is predominantly a French-speaking city, Montreal is not just for Francophiles. It is a cosmopolitan melting pot with more than 100 different ethnic groups. From the earthy appeal of Little Italy and Chinatown to the bohemian chic of Boulevard St. Laurent to the grand elegance of Sherbrooke Street, Montreal has much to offer. Moreover, you will feel fabulously wealthy, given the current exchange rate ($1.36 Canadian to $1 United States). In the warm months, the city plays host to an endless series of festivals and events: highlights include the Canada Grand Prix this weekend, the International Jazz Festival (June 26 to July 6); Just for Laughs, a comedy festival (July 10 to 20); and the Montreal World Film Festival (Aug. 27 to Sept. 7). NANCY M. BETTER

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Forecast Cut For Chip Sales
description: The Semiconductor Industry Association says chip sales will grow only 10.1 percent this year, to $154.9 billion, down sharply from its November 2002 forecast of an increase of 19.8 percent. The announcement was made on Wednesday as part of the association's annual midyear forecast. According to the association, the chip industry will achieve a compound annual growth rate of 9.8 percent from now to 2006, and in that year will return to 2000 sales levels. The association forecast that semiconductor sales would increase 16.8 percent next year, to $180.9 billion, followed by a 5.8 percent increase, to $191.5 billion, in 2005. In 2006, chip sales will rise 7 percent, to $204.9 billion, a bit higher than in 2000. The brightest spot in the forecast involved dynamic random access memory, or DRAM. While the association forecast only 2.9 percent growth in 2003, DRAM sales are expected to rise 43 percent in 2004. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

description: Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who is a contender for president, is pledging to make the United States independent of Mideast oil in 10 years. Mr. Kerry accused the administration of evading its responsibility by offering Americans a choice between drilling in Alaska and developing hydrogen cars. Mr. Kerry proposed using royalties that energy companies pay for drilling rights to finance research into renewable energy and fuel-efficient vehicles. Adam Nagourney (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLEISS, , DR. JOSEPH L.
description: FLEISS--Dr. Joseph L. On Thursday, June 12, 2003 in Ridgewood, NJ. Formerly of Wayne, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Isabel Bogorad Fleiss. Cherished father of Arthur, Deb, Liz and Phyllis. Loving grandfather of Amir, Yamit, Eden, Shanna, Sarah and Jesse. Brother of Israel and devoted son-in-law of Lillian and the late Leo Izenberg. Dr. Fleiss was former professor and chair of the division of Biostatistics at the Columbia University School of Public Health. He has written two seminal works in the field of biostatistics ''Statistical Methods for Rates and Proportions'' and ''The Design and Analysis of Clinical Experiments''. He has authored over 150 papers on the application of statistics in fields ranging from psychiatry and cardiology to dentistry. He is a fellow of the American Statistical Association and a recipient of a gold medal award from the American Public Health Association. In 1997, he was awarded a lifetime achievement award from Harvard University for contributions to mental health statistics. Funeral services, Friday, June 13, 1PM, at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13-01 Broadway, Fair Lawn NJ. Contributions in his memory can be sent to the Isabel Bogorad Fleiss Cultural Arts Fund, C/O, Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., 1 Pike Drive, Wayne NJ 07470. >>AD#

James Mallord William Turner himself, his brush raised like a wizard's staff, seems to preside over the show, as he did over British Romantic art nearly two centuries ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENBERG, , EMIL
description: EISENBERG--Emil. 90, of 80 Salisbury Street, Worcester MA., died Thursday June 12th at UMASS Medical Center after a long illness. Mr. Eisenberg leaves his wife, Lillian H. Eisenberg, a daughter, Denise Rich of New York City, a stepdaughter Helen Ann Browdy of Atlanta, Georgia, a stepson Lawrence E. Cohen of Worcester, a son-in-law Thomas J. Dokton of Boston, three grandchildren Nicole Dokton Dunn of Melbourne, Australia, Daniella D. Rich of New York City, Ilona M. Schachter of New York City and four great grandchildren. Mr. Eisenberg was predeceased by his wife of 53 years, Gery Diamant Eisenberg who died in 1989; his daughter Monique L. Dokton, his granddaughter Gabrielle Rich Aouad and three brothers Henry, Zigg and Jack. Mr. Eisenberg was born on December 24, 1912 in Tarnov, Poland. He was the son of Wolf and Jula Eisenberg. He left Germany in 1933 for Paris, France where he and his three brothers established a fur business with offices in London, New York and Paris. Mr. Eisenberg, his wife Gery and daughter Monique left for New York City in 1940. In 1942, Mr. Eisenberg and the family left for Worcester. Concurrent with moving to Worcester, he founded the family shoe business (Desco Shoe Corporation) in New York and Webster, MA. Prior to its sale in 1988, Desco employed over 1500 people in six factories throughout the United States. He was also a coowner of Jefferson Cable and Wire in Worcester. In 1991, he co-founded Worcester Partners Ltd., an investment management company located in Webster, MA. Mr. Eisenberg was active in community affairs over the years. He was a member of the Masons, the Worcester Tennis Club, Mt. Pleasant Country Club and an incorporator of the Worcester Art Museum. Mr. Eisenberg was a lover of fine art and classical music. He frequently attended the Worcester Music Festival. In 1976 he established a vocational high school for girls in Tel Aviv. In 1999, through donations by the family, the assisted living residence of the Jewish Healthcare Center was named after Emil and Gery Eisenberg. The funeral will be held on Friday June 13, 2003 at 12 PM at Temple Emanuel, 280 May Street Worcester, MA. Burial will follow at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Eisenberg Assisted Living Residence, 631 Salisbury Street, Worcester, MA. 02609 or Temple Emanuel, 280 May Street, Worcester, MA. Funeral home, Perlman Funeral home, 1026 Main Street, Worcester, MA. 01603, 508-756-2200. >>AD#

title: MIDWEST EXPRESS CONSIDERING CHAPTER 11 FILING
description: Midwest Express Holdings, which operates Midwest Airlines of Milwaukee, may seek bankruptcy protection if it is unable to reduce labor costs and plane payments in the third quarter or earlier, the company said. The company is considering a Chapter 11 filing, which would shield it from creditors while it reorganizes its debts, a spokesman, Dennis O'Reilly, said. Midwest Express is trying to cut costs by renegotiating labor contracts with its pilots and flight-attendant unions and by lowering plane lease and debt payments. Mr. O'Reilly declined to say how much savings the airline was seeking.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Help For Credit Unit
description: The Hyundai Automotive Group is coming to the rescue of Hyundai Card, one of Korea's troubled credit card companies. Hyundai Motor, Kia Motors, Hyundai Capital and INI Steel, all part of Hyundai Automotive, are buying shares valued at 454.7 billion won ($381 million) in Hyundai Capital Services, the motor vehicle financing company that owns Hyundai Card. Share prices of Hyundai Motor, which is investing 195.2 billion won ($163 million) in the company, dropped 3.7 percent on the Korea Stock Exchange. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Muslims Face Deportation, But Say U.S. Is Their Home
description: They are husbands and fathers, working immigrants who have been in New York for years. Some are married to women with green cards, and some have children who are American citizens. But because they are from predominantly Muslim countries, they say, they face deportation even though they have only small glitches in their citizenship applications.

title: Bishops Uneasy on Whom to Protect
description: In Roman Catholic dioceses from New York to California, many bishops are still torn between their public promises to resolve the child sexual abuse scandal with openness and accountability and their instinct to protect their assets, priests and reputations.

title: Connecticut Governor Paying $9,000 to Settle Ethics Complaint
description: HARTFORD, June 13  Gov. John G. Rowland, whose administration was already facing ethical and legal problems, agreed today to pay almost $9,000 to settle an ethics complaint in which he was accused of paying well below the going rental rate to stay in vacation homes owned by people who have business with state government.

title: Starlight Above, Fireplace Below
description: WHEN high winds knocked out the power at their Whidbey Island home on Easter Sunday five years ago, John and Delores Teutsch had a backup plan for getting dinner on the table. The couple, who were gathered with their children and grandchildren for the holiday weekend, walked out the kitchen door and built a roaring blaze in their outdoor fireplace, which is tucked into a glacial-stone wall on their patio.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The magic name of Plcido Domingo did not turn Domingo, this singer's town-house restaurant, into a standing-room-only attraction. So Mr. Domingo devised a new production. Working with Richard Sandoval, the chef and owner of Maya, he turned Domingo into Pampano, with a menu devoted to the seafood-based cuisine of Veracruz, Mexico. Things are looking up.

title: Shades Of the Past
description: Three big old movies arrived on DVD from Warner this week. Coming from the 1980's, Philip Kaufman's ''Right Stuff'' (1983) and Sergio Leone's ''Once Upon a Time in America'' (1984) shared restoration issues peculiar to their era. Nearly 30 years older, ''Giant'' (1956), George Stevens's Texas saga starring Rock Hudson, Elizabeth Taylor and James Dean in his last film, presented its own problems, said Ned Price, vice president of Warner's mastering department.

title: Heinz's Earnings Decrease 54%
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings slumped 54 percent after the company spun off businesses and higher marketing spending failed to increase sales of frozen foods.

title: On Eve of Vote, Czechs Seem to Lean Toward Joining Europe
description: At the height of their fealty to the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia's Communists built a jarring statue of Stalin on a riverside bluff in this graceful capital. Today, a massive steel metronome ticks back and forth on the plinth Stalin once occupied, swinging left to a sign that says ''No,'' and right to one that says ''Yes.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Industrial Acquisition
description: Schneider Electric, a leading supplier of industrial power supplies, said it would buy TAC a Swedish company that supplies automation equipment for buildings, for 371 million euros ($436 million) from the EQT investment fund. Schneider, which is based in France, will also assume 51 million euros ($60 million) in TAC debt. EQT investments is the buyout arm of AB holding company, which is run by Sweden's billionaire Wallenberg family. Schneider said the purchase would strengthen its operations in building automation, an $11 billion dollar market with a growth rate averaging 6 percent a year. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: A.C.C. Hits a New Bump
description: The attorneys general of Virginia and West Virginia yesterday lent their names and influence to a lawsuit filed by five Big East Conference universities against Miami, Boston College and the Atlantic Coast Conference, the latest maneuver in what has become a loud and visible effort to stop the A.C.C. from expanding.

title: 2 WPP Divisions to Merge
description: Two agencies that are part of the WPP Group said yesterday that they would combine worldwide media services.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Bribery On Jet Deal Alleged
description: Britain's largest defense company, BAE Systems, denied reports in the British newspaper The Guardian that it was involved in attempts to bribe Czech politicians while bidding to sell the Czech Air Force billions of dollars worth of supersonic jet fighters. A company spokesman termed the allegations ''groundless'' and a ''complete fabrication.'' The newspaper quoted two Czech legislators who said they had been offered bribes and cited documents showing that the United States government had complained to the British Defense Ministry of ''corrupt practice'' in BAE's bid. The Czech government canceled the contract in August, after floods put pressure on public spending. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Fighting Crime, Flashing Charm
description: In ''Hollywood Homicide'' Harrison Ford plays Joe Gavilan, a veteran Los Angeles detective with money troubles, three ex-wives and a goofy, undisciplined young partner. Gavilan, in other words, is a walking cop-movie clich, something Mr. Ford seems happy to acknowledge.

title: No Repeat As Yanks Display Good Side
description: There was enthusiasm in George Steinbrenner's voice yesterday morning as he spoke about the coming Yankee game. ''Today will tell a story,'' Steinbrenner, the principal owner, said in a telephone interview. ''If we win today, we beat them in a series, and that's very important. If we come back today, we redeem ourselves.''

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Profit Up 18%
description: Adobe Systems, one of the the world's largest makers of software for publishing and graphic design, said after trading closed yesterday that fiscal second-quarter earnings increased 18 percent. Its shares fell as much as 10 percent, however, on news that the company expected third-quarter profit to miss forecasts. Second-quarter net income rose to $64.2 million, or 27 cents a share, from $54.3 million, or 22 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Sales in the second quarter, which ended May 30, rose less than 1 percent, to $320.1 million. Adobe's sales have suffered from a decrease in spending by advertising agencies that use its programs. Third-quarter sales will be $300 million to $315 million, with profit at 22 cents to 25 cents a share, Adobe forecast. Analysts expected profit of 26 cents and sales of $309 million, according to Thomson Financial. Shares of Adobe, which is based in San Jose, Calif., fell as low as $32.30 in extended trading after the report. They closed at $35.98 in regular trading after gaining 16 cents.

title: Optimistic Investors vs. Pessimistic Bosses
description: FROM the top of corporate America, things look awfully glum. But those not in executive suites seem to be more optimistic.

title: Briefly Noted
description: ITALY: BOMB FOUND ON PLANE The police found an explosive device on a plane waiting to board passengers for a domestic flight at an airport in eastern Italy, officials said. The explosive was found under a seat on an Alitalia plane that had flown to Ancona from Rome and was scheduled to make a return trip. A fire department official at the airport said the police had received an anonymous call alerting them about an explosive. They removed the device and safely exploded it, the official said on condition of anonymity. Italy has been on high alert for terror attacks since the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States. The country has a history of domestic attacks by radicals.

title: Israel Presses Assault on Hamas With Gaza Missile Strikes
description: JERUSALEM, June 13 - Israel pressed its campaign against Hamas militants tonight, with attack helicopters delivering two more missile strikes in Gaza. The attacks come a day before American monitors are scheduled to arrive here to prop up a new peace plan now badly weakened by nearly a week of violence.

title: Students Roil Iranian Capital in 3rd Night of Protests
description: A third night of student protests outside Tehran University's dormitories exploded into the surrounding middle-class neighborhoods early today, with large gangs of students fighting running street battles against vigilantes armed with sticks and chains. At one major intersection demonstrators hurled bricks at trucks of riot policemen who were rushing to lift barricades and douse fires protesters had ignited in the streets.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Firefighters Settle Dispute
description: A nine-month labor dispute that produced angry clashes between union leaders and the governing Labor Party ended when firefighters voted to accept a 16 percent pay raise over two and a half years in return for taking steps to streamline the service. The government had had to call out the army to man fire stations across the country for days at a time during the union's strikes, and public sympathy waned. The union had sought a 40 percent increase. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Interest Rate Cut
description: The Reserve Bank of South Africa said that it would cut interest rates by 1.5 points, a move that had been anticipated for several weeks. The cut, to 12 percent from 13.5 percent, comes after the bank raised rates four times in a year to fight inflation. But several weeks ago an economist discovered that the statistical analysis used to determine the nation's inflation rate had relied on old figures, making the inflation rate seem higher than it actually was, by almost a percentage point in the past year, leading to speculation that rates would be cut when the Reserve Bank's monetary policy committee met. The local markets had anticipated a one point cut, but the extra half point brought a lift to the bond market and the rand held firm against the dollar despite fears that lower interest rates would weaken it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Economy Quickens In New York Region
description: The Federal Reserve's regular survey of economic conditions nationwide found ''fairly widespread signs of a pickup'' in the New York region. The signs included a strengthening labor market, increased activity in the real estate market and hints of improvement in financial-sector hiring. The survey, called the Beige Book and published eight times a year, also found bankers reporting increased demand for loans, especially for home mortgages. The anecdotal findings, released late Wednesday, come two weeks after the New York City's unemployment rate dropped for the second straight month. Jason Bram, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said, ''It still leaves open the question is this the beginning of a trend or is this just a good month?'' Janny Scott (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, , JOSEPH, MD.
description: GREENBERG--Joseph, MD. On June 11, 2003 died peacefully with his loving family at his side. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Paula and Marlon Dennis and Janis Heller. Adoring grandfather of Sloane Heller and Noah Dennis. You will be in our hearts forever. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for the Fund Dedicated to Melanoma research for Dr. Jedd Wolchok. Services today, Friday 11:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: The National Federation of Coffee Growers of Colombia in Bogot has named a team of agencies owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies to handle advertising and marketing duties on its account, which had been largely dormant. Billings were estimated at $9 million.

description: Federal authorities said today that they planned to use stricter standards for identifying and locking up terrorist suspects in light of concerns raised in a recent report that hundreds of illegal immigrants were mistreated after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

description: The puzzling thing was that he studied so much recently, his family said, as if he was planning on having a future.

description: The YES Network announced yesterday that it would sue Time Warner Cable to prevent it from implementing a plan that would require some subscribers in New York City and New Jersey to pay extra for YES.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Ex-Detective Sentenced For Murder
description: A former New York City police detective was sentenced yesterday to a prison term of 25 years to life for murdering a fellow officer in 2001. The detective, Ezra Leslie, 45, of Central Islip, was convicted of killing his next-door neighbor, Sgt. Gwendulina Brodie, with five gunshots from his service pistol. They had argued over an affair between Mr. Leslie, who was married, and Ms. Brodie's sister, Tanya. In the sentencing in Suffolk County Court, Judge Stephen L. Braslow called Mr. Leslie ''dangerous and arrogant.'' Mr. Leslie said he would appeal. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Universal Health Coverage Gains
description: The legislature has given initial approval to a bill to provide health coverage to all residents by 2009. Gov. John Baldacci announced the plan last month and is widely expected to sign it quickly. The plan would create a semiprivate agency that would start in July 2004 to provide private coverage to the nearly 180,000 uninsured residents, as well as businesses, the self-employed and municipalities with 50 or fewer employees. Premiums would be based on income, family size and the particular features wanted. Employers would pay up to 60 percent of an employee's premium. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Funny Cide to Run In the Haskell
description: Funny Cide will race next in the $1 million Haskell Invitational at Monmouth Park in Oceanport, N.J., on Aug. 3.

title: A German Who Found Pragmatic Beauty in Small-Town America's Homes
description: No one knows what Fritz Vogt did during the first 48 years of his life in Germany, where he was born in 1841. In his last 10 years as an itinerant artist in upstate New York, however, he earned himself a minor niche in American folk art history. A small, choice selection from the more than 200 portraits of rural and small-town homes that Vogt made, now on view at the American Folk Art Museum, reveals an architectural draftsman whose formal ingenuity, disregard for conventional perspective and sharp eye for detail delightfully animated an otherwise quaintly mundane, illustrative genre.

title: Romance of the Horseshoe Crab
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, just before the new moon, I checked the tides for Provincetown, Mass. Spring tide was at noon and again around midnight. Perfectly civilized times. We could relax at the White Horse, brunch at Little Fluke, dine at the Red Inn, and still catch most of the action.

title: Shopping List | Summer Kitchen
description: GROWING hungry in the summer rental and no takeout for miles? Then bring in some kitchen essentials and start exploring local produce, fish and meat markets. Recipes requiring minimal effort for maximum results should also help. And when releasing the inner cook, remember that necessity is the mother of inspiration and invention. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: FUNDS FOR ACQUISITIONS The building materials company Lafarge said it would raise 1.28 billion euros ($1.5 billion) by selling new shares to buy cement and aggregates businesses in Europe and North America. The company, which is based in Paris, has designated 20 percent, or 256 million euros ($301 million), for purchases to take place by the end of the year, according to a Lafarge spokesman, Philippe Hardouin. The remaining funds will be used to strengthen the company's financial structure and eventually to conduct medium-sized acquisitions, not exceeding 300 million euros each, Mr. Hardouin said. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Dingell Plans 25th Term
description: Quashing rumors that he might retire, the longest-serving member of the House, Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, said he planned to run for re-election. Roll Call, a Capitol Hill newspaper, listed Mr. Dingell on Wednesday among Democrats considering retirement. ''While the thought of a Congress without me might make a few corporate malefactors sleep better at night, the only list I am on is the list of members who plan to be re-elected to the 109th Congress,'' he said. Mr. Dingell, who turns 77 next month, has been in the House since 1955.

title: We Need More Tickets, Not Fewer
description: The guy was driving his cream-colored Rolls-Royce Corniche along West Broadway in SoHo. Actually, to call it driving is giving him too much credit. Bobbing and weaving is more like it. Several times, he nearly hit parked cars. Once, he almost veered into oncoming traffic.

title: As Alliances Take Shape, Iraq Balances New Unity On a Fragile Foundation
description: In 1919, when the British adventurer Gertrude Bell pondered the threat of disintegration in Iraq from the ethnic and religious strife that prevailed as its boundaries were drawn, she saw the inchoate state slipping toward the abyss.

title: Immigrant Life in All Its Jagged Rhythms
description: ''Manito,'' Eric Eason's debut feature, was made with very little money, a fair amount of skill and a great deal of heart. Most of the action unfolds in a single day in the Upper Manhattan neighborhood of Washington Heights, and Mr. Eason, using a hand-held camera and a largely new or nonprofessional cast, brilliantly captures the pulse of daily life in working-class, immigrant New York: the hectic rhythms of labor, leisure and family life, the stresses and pleasures, the anxieties and hopes. He has a quick-moving, incisive eye that captures little details of gesture and dcor -- the way a young boy imitates his father's impatient morning alarm-clock slap, the magic by which a rented catering hall is transformed into a sacred place -- and also an ear finely tuned to the nuances of talk.

title: After 3 Years, 2 Charged With Murder in College Dorm Fire
description: For more than three years, as burns and injured lungs healed and surviving classmates graduated, questions went unanswered about who had started a late-night fire in a dormitory at Seton Hall University that killed three students and injured more than 50 others.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: British Nanotechnology Study
description: The British government has commissioned the Royal Society and the Royal Academy of Engineering to study the fast-growing field of nanotechnology and make recommendations on how it should be regulated, the two groups said Wednesday. Nanotechnology deals with materials whose size is measured in billionths of a meter, which is roughly the size of molecules. The study will look at the state of current research and where the field is likely to be in 10 years and beyond, said Professor Ann Dowling, an engineering expert from Cambridge University, who will lead the study. It will also consider environmental and social implications. The report is expected to be completed by April. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Foam Questions Remain, Shuttle Investigator Says
description: The accepted theory of why a piece of foam broke off the shuttle Columbia's external fuel tank, presumably inflicting the fatal damage to its left wing, is ''hokum,'' the chairman of the investigating board said today.

He was 87.

description: The French electronics company Thomson lowered its profit forecast because of poor results at its television-making operations in the United States and said it would cut more than 1,200 jobs in Marion, Ind., and Circleville, Ohio. The company, which produces televisions for General Electric and RCA, said its solid performance in Asia and Europe could not offset its losses in the United States. Thomson said it expected operating profit to shrink to 140 million euros ($166 million), below its previous forecast of 200 million euros. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: 2 Charged In Pension Fraud
description: The Atlanta police have arrested two people in an investigation into fraud in the city's pension system, and more arrests may be forthcoming, city officials said. Lasheika Smith, a former city pension department employee, is accused of diverting some $68,000 in pension payments into a fraudulent checking account after the pensioners' deaths. A friend of Ms. Smith's, Howard Hill, ws also charged in the case. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: NEW LEADER IN RAMSEY CASE The Boulder district attorney, Mary Keenan, has hired a retired police detective, Tom Bennett, to lead her office's investigation into the 1996 death of 6-year-old JonBenet Ramsey. Ms. Keenan's office took over the investigation in January, and in April she said that she believed an intruder might have killed the girl. An earlier investigation by the Boulder police focused on John and Patsy Ramsey, JonBenet's parents. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHMAN, , SHIRLEY
description: FISHMAN--Shirley. Devoted mother and Mental Health Leader died on Thursday at her home in Moriches, Long Island at the age of 73. Shirley was born in Brooklyn, NY, and moved to Manhattan and Long Island with her husband, Sidney who predeceased her on October 17, 1996. Prior to her retirement she was the Administrative Director of the Washington Square Institute, located in Greenwich Village, NYC. During her over 25 years of service at the Institute she was an instrumental force in its growth and development. Her intellectual capacity and sensitivity will be remembered fondly by everyone she ever met. She is survived by her sons, Michael Coleman, and Dr. Kenneth Coleman, her stepchildren, Amy and Gary Fishman, and her brother, Dr. Bernard Frankel. She will be dearly missed by her family and the many lives she has touched. A graveside service will be on Sunday, June 15th at 1:00 PM at Beth Moses Cemetery in Pinelawn, L.I., (631-249-2290), Reception to follow. >>AD#

title: Freddie Who?
description: Because it's a quasi-governmental institution serving a broad public purpose, many people have assumed that Freddie Mac -- formerly the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation -- would be impervious to the scandals shaking corporate America. That is not the case. Last Monday, three senior officers departed in the midst of an accounting scandal that will almost certainly invite new regulation of the company's behavior.

title: CONTEMPORARY ART:A SPECIAL REPORT : A young artist in Umbria re-examines contours of Photorealism
description: TODI, Italy  Of all recent art movements, few were execrated by the modernists so virulently as Photorealism. The painters and sculptors of this school, which emerged in the United States in the mid-1960s, produced more or less exact copies of photographs (or in the case of sculptures, often direct body casts), recording seemingly banal city scenes, suburban streets, storefronts, diners, consumer goods, automobiles and motorcycles, with phenomenal adeptness, but with a disconcerting level of emotional detachment.
