It is being marketed by the Corcoran Group and the Aguayo & Huebener Realty Group, not by Corcoran alone. Peter Noonan of Corcoran is a sales agent for it, but not the only one.

title: No Concession From I.B.M. In Linux Fight
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that it had no intention of reaching a quick settlement with the SCO Group, a small company based in Lindon, Utah, in a legal fight that is causing concern among the many corporations that use the increasingly popular Linux operating system to handle some computing chores.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Court Backs Veteran On Gulf Illness
description: In a ruling that could help thousands of veterans receive compensation for what they contend is gulf war syndrome, the High Court in London rejected an appeal by the Ministry of Defense of a decision by a war pensions tribunal that a former parachute regiment medic was a victim of a disabling disease related to his service in the Persian Gulf war of 1991. The judgment did not identify the disease by name, but it upheld the claim by Shaun Rusling, 44, above, a former Army parachute regiment medic who is chairman of the Gulf War Veterans Association, that the depression, eczema, fatigue, nausea and breathing problems he experienced after returning from combat were attributable to his military service. Mr. Rusling's lawyer, Mark McGee, said the ruling would make it easier for other gulf war veterans to pursue their claims, but a Ministry of Defense spokesman said that despite the decision, ''the judge expresses no opinion on whether gulf war syndrome exists.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Police in Thailand Seize Radioactive Material
description: Authorities in Thailand, acting on information from American investigators, seized a large amount of radioactive material from a Thai man, breaking up a plot to sell it to terrorists. He was peddling it for use in so-called dirty bombs, according to American law enforcement officials.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about growth in advertising spending misstated the Interactive Advertising Bureau's tally of the amount spent last year on Internet advertising. It was $6 billion; $1.6 billion was the figure for the fourth quarter.

title: National Briefing: South
description: GEORGIA: COURT RULES FOR BOMB SUITS The state Court of Appeals has ruled that negligence lawsuits filed against the Atlanta Olympic committee by victims of the 1996 Olympic bombing may go to trial, reversing a lower court's ruling. The committee had argued that it was shielded from liability, but the court said a jury should decide that issue. The victims have said that the organizers failed to adequately clear the area after a warning was called in. One person was killed and 111 were wounded. The suits also name the suspect in the bombing, Eric R. Rudolph, who was arrested in North Carolina on May 31. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Democrats Split On Challenging Iraq Arms Hunt
description: The war in Iraq is once again dividing the Democratic Party, with Congressional leaders and presidential candidates struggling over how strongly to challenge President Bush about the failure so far to find biological or chemical weapons.

title: TWO CREDITORS OFFER FORMICA $175 MILLION IN AID
description: The Formica Corporation, the countertop maker, said Cerberus Capital Management and Oaktree Capital Management had agreed to invest $175 million to help the company get out of bankruptcy. The transaction would cut Formica's bank debt to about $127 million from more than $300 million, court papers show. Formica's secured lenders support the deal, which is subject to higher offers and to approval from the United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan. Cerberus and Oaktree are the company's two largest unsecured creditors, Formica said. The company, based in Warren, N.J., said it expected to emerge from bankruptcy next year. It sought bankruptcy protection in March 2002 to restructure more than $816 million of debt.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: 'Yes' Seen In Europe Vote
description: An early voter survey taken by Czech Television showed voters giving overwhelming support to the country's bid to join the European Union, despite a tepid campaign by political leaders. In the first day of a two-day nationwide referendum, 84 percent of voters interviewed said they had cast ''yes'' ballots. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Draft For Europe
description: SABMiller, the British beer maker, said that it would start selling Miller Genuine Draft beer in Eastern Europe to meet increasing demand for Western beers and revive sales of the brand. The brewer, which is based in London, will introduce the brand in Hungary, Romania, Slovakia, the Czech Republic, and Poland, as well as in Italy, a spokesman said. SABMiller, which bought the Miller Brewing Company in July for $5.6 billion, is expanding the brand into Eastern Europe as beer consumption in the region outpaces that of the European Union and as Miller loses ground to Anheuser-Busch in the United States.

title: Hussein's Image Is Banned in Public, Except on Money

description: For nearly two years, many Arab and Muslim immigrants have been consumed by anger and despair as they have watched the arrests, detentions and deportations that have accompanied the hunt for terrorists since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Judge Allows Construction To Resume Next to Temple
description: A Supreme Court judge agreed yesterday to allow work to resume on construction of a 50-story apartment building in Lower Manhattan following efforts by the developer to shore up a damaged building next door that houses a Buddhist temple.

title: Some Doubts About Logic Of Senate Plan For Drug Aid
description: You will not find the prescription drug benefit plan approved by the Senate Finance Committee in any textbook on health insurance. The bill has the support of senators from both parties, but its features leave some economists baffled.

title: Belgium Resists Pressure From U.S. to Repeal War Crimes Law
description: Belgium's government reacted angrily today to mounting American pressure to rescind controversial war crimes legislation, arguing that the country had already addressed Washington's concerns.

title: The Knicks Size Up a Russian Prospect
description: Somewhere in the Knicks' equipment room was a T-shirt fit for a 7-foot-5, 303-pound frame. The Knicks have been waiting a long time for a player to fill out the size XXXXL shirt.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Muslim League Suspends Rome Imam
description: The Italian branch of the Muslim World League suspended the imam of Rome's mosque for supporting Palestinian suicide bombers in a sermon last week. The remarks of the imam, Mahmoud Ibrahim Maoussa, an Egyptian, drew harsh criticism from Interior Minister Giuseppe Pisanu, who said Italy's mosques must be freed from ''recruiters for holy wars and foreign interests.'' Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Game 5 Analysis; Yes, He's Unemotional, but Duncan's Power Is Felt by Nets
description: The next time someone remarks that Tim Duncan does not show enough emotion -- that he is Spock in high-tops -- tell the misguided soul to stop repeating what he heard on ''SportsCenter'' and to look at the scoreboard.

title: Swiss Central Banker Lowers Outlook
description: Switzerland's economy, now in recession, will not improve until investor confidence returns, the chairman of the Swiss central bank, Jean-Pierre Roth, said today.

title: Sculpting Soviet Giants, Watching Them Fall
description: AMONG the many distinctions he has racked up in his 85 years -- hero of Socialist labor, Goethe Prize laureate, winner of the Lenin Prize -- there is one that Lev Kerbel would just as well forget: excepting perhaps Saddam Hussein's sculptor, it is doubtful that any other living artist has seen as many of his or her works wrecked by mobs.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Loss At Resort Operator
description: The French resort operator Club Mditerrane said yesterday that it lost 29 million euros ($34.4 million) in the first six months of its fiscal year as sales fell 4 percent. Excluding one-time costs related to restructuring, the company posted operating income of 12 million euros, up from an operating loss of 4 million euros a year earlier. Club Med said reservations for this summer are down 13.5 percent, reflecting the downturn in the tourism industry. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Religion Journal; Of Bart and Homer, and the Many Ways of Faith
description: There are many types of religious believers, and according to the Rev. Shawn Galyen, every one of them mirrors the faith of some character or other on ''The Simpsons.''

title: Security at Our Ports
description: To the Editor:

title: Poll Says Majority Agree With Indictment of Martha Stewart
description: With Martha Stewart's post-indictment publicity drive in high gear, a majority of New Yorkers queried in a poll this week said they thought she was guilty and should be punished.

title: J. S. Galbraith, 86, University Official And History Scholar
description: John Semple Galbraith, a historian of 19th-century Britain whose tenure as the second chancellor of the University of California's San Diego branch in the 1960's secured its position as an equal member of the university system, died on Tuesday in San Diego. He was 86.

title: Sports of The Times; Decision to Be Daring Translates Into a 63
description: ON the 17th hole, Vijay Singh was already seven under par for the round and had a chance to break the United States Open scoring record of 63, but when he missed a birdie putt there, Rocco Mediate, one of the other golfers in his threesome, spoke up.

title: Westchester Takes Fight Against Drinking to a Younger Group
description: Ten eighth graders in Mamaroneck, N.Y., were suspended after a group of them were caught drinking at their graduation dance last Friday, school administrators said yesterday. One student was hospitalized overnight for alcohol poisoning.

title: Democrats Want to Suspend A Change in Student Aid Rule
description: Several Democratic members of Congress yesterday called for the suspension of a bureaucratic adjustment that will likely increase college costs for millions of families.

title: Islam and the Unveiled Photograph
description: A Florida judge ruled last week that a Muslim woman could not pose for a driver's license photograph in a veil, with only her eyes peering out. The state, the judge wrote, had a ''compelling interest'' in identifying its drivers; she rejected the arguments, supported by Muslim organizations, that the decision threatened ''religious liberty.''

title: On Being an Anchorman
description: When they learned how to send pictures through the air, out came a new creature called the anchorman. God knows where that term originated. Some of us who have held the position have never liked it, but there it is.

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; 300/4,000; Two Milestones and a Tearful Celebration for Clemens
description: Roger Clemens knew he would not throw another pitch as he trudged off the mound with a one-run lead and two outs in the seventh inning, but, of course, he still did not know his fate. That could explain why Clemens looked a little cautious and a lot spent. He was not a legendary pitcher who had won his 300th game yet. He was still in limbo, legendary limbo.

title: Sir Bernard Williams, 73, Oxford Philosopher, Dies
description: Sir Bernard Williams, the lightning-witted Oxford professor who is credited with reviving the field of moral philosophy and was considered by some to be the greatest British philosopher of his era, died on Tuesday in Oxford. He was 73 and lived at All Souls College, Oxford.

title: Pre-Olympic Success For Elite Sister Act
description: They are not quite the Serena and Venus Williams of fencing, but 20-year-old Sada Jacobson and her 17-year-old sister, Emily, are getting close.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Street ball is all about freedom. That's the one thing you need, to show your God-given ability -- freedom. All a street player needs is a green light.''

title: The Boys Who Cried Wolfowitz
description: We're now up to Day 87 of the largely fruitless hunt for Iraq's unconventional weapons. Allegations keep piling up that the Bush administration tried to scam the world into war by exaggerating evidence of the Iraqi threat. One critic has pronounced it ''arguably the worst scandal in American political history.'' So you might reasonably ask a supporter of the war, How do you feel about that war now?

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Attacks Hamas Again

title: W.H.O. Lifts SARS Alert in China Regions
description: The World Health Organization removed its travel advisory in four Chinese provinces today in a sign that the SARS virus is slowly being contained.

title: 63; Singh Ties Record And Shares Lead With Furyk
description: This United States Open has forced open the record book.

title: Watson Still Close To Lead
description: Tom Watson remained in contention after today's 72 left him at three under par for the tournament, four strokes behind Vijay Singh and Jim Furyk. With 36 holes remaining, Watson still believed that at age 53, he could become the oldest United States Open champion.

title: Officer's Blood Alcohol Level Was Over Limit in Fatal Crash
description: An off-duty Union County police officer whose car jumped a median on a state highway last month and struck an oncoming car head-on, killing himself and five others, had a blood alcohol level more than three times the state's legal limit, according to the results of two toxicology reports.

title: Songwriting Hit Makers Donning Their Laurels
description: Phil Collins, Little Richard, Van Morrison and Queen were inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame on Thursday night at the Marriott Marquis in Times Square in a ceremony sprinkled with music and television stars.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: ELECTRONICS JOB CUTS The French elec- tronics company Thomson lowered its profit forecast because of poor results at its television-making operations in the United States and said it would cut more than 1,200 jobs in Marion, Ind., and Circleville, Ohio. The company, which produces televisions for General Electric and RCA, said its solid performance in Asia and Europe could not offset its losses in the United States. Thomson said it expected operating profit to shrink to 140 million euros ($166 million), below its previous forecast of 200 million euros.   Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Ex-Mayor Gets 37 Years In Prison for Abusing 2 Girls
description: Philip A. Giordano, a former three-term mayor of Waterbury and a United States Senate candidate, was sentenced today to 37 years in federal prison for having oral sex with two young girls while in office.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Downgraded
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered the long- and short-term credit ratings of Bayer, the drug and chemicals maker. Moody's said the downgradings were based on expectations of weak operating profits in the short term, restructuring costs and risks from lawsuits over the company's anticholesterol drug, Baycol. Although Moody's said its outlook on the ratings was stable, it said it expected further downgradings if the lawsuits resulted in substantial damages against Bayer. Bayer said that the downgrading was ''incomprehensible'' and that the company had good liquidity and had cut costs. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Born in the U.S.A. Is No Guarantee
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 13  Globality cannot be found in the dictionary but it has become Commissioner David Stern's favorite new word. It has something to do with the synergy between American basketball and the world, and how he eventually wants Guam and Chechnya in the N.B.A. finals.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hong Kong Says Trade Pact Will Meet W.T.O. Rules

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Dr. Richard A. Gardner, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, misstated his position at Columbia University. He was a clinical professor of psychiatry in the division of child and adolescent psychiatry -- an unpaid volunteer -- not a professor of child psychiatry.

title: CONTEMPORARY ART:A SPECIAL REPORT : An expansion of museums in U.S.
description: NEW YORK  Despite drastic cutbacks in government and private funding for nonprofit institutions, Contemporary art aficionados have reason to celebrate with the opening or expansion of several Contemporary art museums in the United States.

title: Examining Terrorism's Roots And Taking Aim at Its Myths
description: NO END TO WAR

title: New No. 24 Is a Star For Yankees
description: Ruben Sierra, the Yankees' unlikely hero last night, wears No. 24. Tino Martinez, the last Yankee to wear that number, returned to Yankee Stadium for the first time in almost two years. But Martinez has moved on, and so, it seems, has Sierra.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about an exhibition on Anne Frank at the Holocaust Museum in Washington misstated the day of the opening ceremony. It was Wednesday; Thursday was the public opening.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday about ''Tycoon: A New Russian'' referred incorrectly in some copies to the legal situation of Boris Berezovsky, a Russian businessman who inspired the film's central character. Russia has requested his extradition from Britain on fraud charges; he has not been extradited.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: New Leader In Ramsey Case
description: The Boulder district attorney, Mary Keenan, has hired a retired police detective, Tom Bennett, to lead her office's investigation into the 1996 death of 6-year-old JonBenet Ramsey. Ms. Keenan's office took over the investigation in January, and in April she said that she believed an intruder might have killed the girl. An earlier investigation by the Boulder police focused on John and Patsy Ramsey, JonBenet's parents. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Atimeline chart on Thursday showing the frequent confluence of diplomatic efforts and explosions of violence in the Mideast referred incorrectly to the suicide bomber who attacked in Tel Aviv on April 30, killing three people. He was a British citizen of Pakistani descent, not a Palestinian.

title: Rebuilding the Mets Is Now Duquette's Challenge
description: Often as a child, Jim Duquette would see his father arrive home from coaching the baseball and basketball teams at Wahconah High School in Dalton, Mass., distraught from another loss.

title: Queens Man Is Arrested in 4 Sex Attacks
description: A Queens man was arrested yesterday in connection with three attacks against women in Hollis two months ago and a 1998 rape.

title: Case Could Redefine Board Members' Liability
description: The short but lucrative stint Michael Ovitz served as president of the Walt Disney Company is now haunting directors of other companies as well as current and former members of Disney's board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, , HARVEY
description: ROSEN--Harvey. The officers, governors and members of the New York Cardiac Center mourn the loss of their colleague, Harvey Rosen, on June 10th and extend our condolences to his family. Richard Glazer, President >>AD#

title: Stem Cell Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Carnage and Clues Are Left in Camp Destroyed by U.S.
description: The men arrived in this barren corner of western Iraq only two days ago, local residents said. Attracting little attention at first, they pitched tents on an isolated stream bed five miles from this ancient Euphrates River farming town.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on June 5 about prospects for Martha Stewart's businesses misidentified the town where she began her catering business. It was Westport, Conn., not Greenwich.

title: Runners' Teamwork Shows in Photo Finish
description: Among the beauties of track and field is that it changes its character for meets like the N.C.A.A. outdoor championships. What is essentially an individual sport becomes the ultimate team experience.

title: Sports of The Times; Kidd Would Be a Great Mentor for Parker
description: THE Nets played their final home game of the season last night. The more chilling thought, for Nets fans, is that Jason Kidd may have played his final game with the Nets, the franchise he brought back to life.

title: Rowland Agrees to Fine and Fees For Underpaid Vacation Rentals
description: Gov. John G. Rowland, already on the defensive for ethical and legal problems plaguing his administration, agreed today to pay almost $9,000 to settle an ethics complaint. The State Ethics Commission had said he paid well below the going rental rate to stay in vacation homes owned by people who have business with the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOCH, , SELMA
description: KOCH--Selma. Passed away June 12th after 96 wonderful years. Wife of the late Henry. Mother of Peter and David (Phyliss). Mother-in-law of Peggy, aunt of Ann Smith. Sister of the late Peggy Reinstein. Friend of Ellie Silverman. Grandmother of Jackie, Danny and Robert, Richard, Steven and Susan. Greatgrandmother of ten. Services Sunday, June 15th at 11:45AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her name may be made to Visions or New

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Debt Deal Challenged
description: Oaktree Capital Management and Gramercy Advisors said yesterday that they would not go along with a proposed debt repayment plan for the Asia Pulp and Paper Company. Asia Pulp and Paper, which is based in Indonesia, has been wrangling with creditors over repayment of about $14 billion of debt. The company and government agencies representing 11 nations negotiated a preliminary agreement covering about half of that earlier this week. But secured creditors, including Oaktree and Gramercy, object to what they say are lenient terms.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HERZSTEIN, , JEAN L.
description: HERZSTEIN--Jean L. June 14, 2002. One year ago today. Miss you so much. Love, Bob >>AD#

title: Rival Kurdish Parties to Merge In Bid for Influence in New Iraq
description: Iraq's two main Kurdish political parties agreed this week to try to put their rancorous past behind them and merge their local administrations in a bid to wield greater influence in Iraq's national politics.

title: Israel and Palestinians Resume Talks Despite Violence
description: JERUSALEM, June 14  After a week of ferocious bloodshed, Israeli, Palestinian and American officials worked today to calm the region and salvage an international peace plan with a series of weekend meetings.

title: Trade Pact on Gene-Altered Goods to Take Effect in 90 Days
description: A new global treaty that imposes restrictions on exports of genetically modified seeds, animals and crops is set to take effect, injecting a new element into already heated international disputes over agricultural biotechnology.

title: Failing to Reach a Slam Bid, But Saved by a Rare Error
description: When, in a head-to-head match, a player discovers that he has failed to reach an excellent slam contract, a small voice in his head hopes for intervention by the gods of the game. Perhaps they can arrange for the result to be canceled. The prayer is hardly ever answered, but it was a week ago in the semifinal stage of the Open Team Trials in Memphis.

title: Favoring Cubans
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Court Rules For Bomb Suits
description: The state Court of Appeals has ruled that negligence lawsuits filed against the Atlanta Olympic committee by victims of the 1996 Olympic bombing may go to trial, reversing a lower court's ruling. The committee had argued that it was shielded from liability, but the court said a jury should decide that issue. The victims have said that the organizers failed to adequately clear the area after a warning was called in. One person was killed and 111 were wounded. The suits also name the suspect in the bombing, Eric R. Rudolph, who was arrested in North Carolina on May 31. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Charge Against Webber Is Dropped
description: Federal prosecutors in Detroit dismissed obstruction of justice charges against Chris Webber, the Sacramento Kings forward, and his father, Mayce, on Thursday, but still plan to prosecute them on felony charges of lying to a grand jury.

title: City Schools Make Some Gains In Math and Reading Tests
description: New York City public school students posted modest gains on citywide English and math tests this year, but the overall picture remains bleak with almost 60 percent of students failing to meet reading and writing standards and even more falling short in math.

title: In Wake of Criticism, Nature Conservancy Changes Policies
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  The Nature Conservancy, the world's richest environmental group, has announced far-reaching changes on Friday to its conservation practices and internal policies, responding to recent criticisms from Capitol Hill, the media and some of the organization's members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIAMS, , EDA DUNSTAN
description: WILLIAMS--Eda Dunstan. The National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York records with deep regret the death of its distinguished former Board Member. Anna F. Duff, President >>AD#

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Priest Deported To Italy In Abuse Case
description: The federal authorities extradited a Mexican Roman Catholic priest to Italy, where he faces charges of sexually abusing children. The attorney general's office said the priest, Edgar Gaudencio Hidalgo, 47, was accused of sexual abuse while working near Naples in 1997. He was arrested last year at a church outside Mexico City on a warrant issued by an Italian judge in November 1999. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: When Democracy Flees
description: To the Editor:

title: MERGER OF FIRST DATA AND CONCORD FACES MORE SCRUTINY
description: Antitrust regulators reviewing the First Data Corporation's proposed $7 billion acquisition of a rival, Concord EFS Inc., have requested more information about the merger plans. The companies said yesterday that they planned to respond promptly to the Justice Department request. First Data, based in Denver, and Concord, based in Memphis, expect to close the deal this year.

title: Inquiry Into Toddler's Death Cites Communication Failures
description: After a review of the case files for a 21-month-old former foster child who died after being returned to parents with a history of abuse, New Jersey's child welfare agency has determined that there were lapses in communication between caseworkers and service providers. But the agency stopped short of saying that the gaps contributed to the child's death.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 1 about President Bush's visit to Krakow, Poland, during his seven-day trip to Europe and the Middle East misstated the ranking of that city's Jewish community among those in Europe just before World War II. With approximately 70,000 Jews, it was not the largest. Warsaw had 500,000.

title: Senior Wins Discus At High School Meet
description: Lindsay Grigoriev of Laurel, Md., hurled the discus 153 feet 4 inches and won the gold medal yesterday at the Adidas Outdoor Track and Field Championships, the unofficial national high school title meet, at North Carolina State University in Raleigh.

title: Millionaire's Husband Faces a Theft Charge
description: A Long Island electrician who married the widow of a slain Manhattan millionaire finished his sentence for drunken driving yesterday. But no sooner had he stepped out of jail in Riverhead than he was arrested again on a charge of stealing $43,000 of electricity.

title: Coming Unraveled: The Iraq Story
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korean Executive Given 3-Year Prison Term
description: The effective head of the third-largest conglomerate in South Korea, the SK Group, was sentenced today to three years in prison. The case has highlighted the government's recent crackdown on corruption within the family-run conglomerates, known as chaebol, that have dominated the Korean economy for decades.

title: Hong Kong Says Trade Deal Won't Break W.T.O. Rules
description: A senior Hong Kong official said today that a nearly completed free trade agreement between Hong Kong and mainland China would comply with World Trade Organization rules. But he refused to rule out the possibility that some provisions might have the effect of helping locally owned companies more than the subsidiaries of multinationals.

title: Coming Unraveled: The Iraq Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Priest Abuse Panel Draws Ire With Comments
description: A remark comparing some Catholic church officials to the Mafia by former Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma, who is leading a national review board looking into the priest sexual abuse scandal, has infuriated members of his panel and prompted some to consider asking him to resign.

title: Kerr Needs Little Time To Deliver For Spurs
description: Steve Kerr made his way slowly off the court, his teammates already long gone. He conducted a radio interview, signed autographs and got a hug from the film director Penny Marshall before finding his way to the locker room.

title: A Growing Fury in Iran
description: Iran's unpopular and economically failing Islamic dictatorship now faces serious challenges from several directions. University students question its legitimacy in the streets. Reformist politicians seek wider powers for the elected Parliament. Washington, now a military force in the region with troops in neighboring Afghanistan and Iraq, demands an end to Tehran's nuclear weapons development and support for terrorism.

title: Army Romeo Tells Angry Juliets, Dozens of Them, That He Is Sorry
description: The United States Army colonel whom scores of women accused of simultaneously romancing them and promising to marry them apologized for his behavior through his lawyer yesterday. But he also said their reactions had been too visceral and that it was excessive for them to try to destroy his career.

title: Sharing a Town, Uneasily; Vigilance About Bears Is Second Nature
description: Soon after their dog was attacked by a black bear here in 1999, Susan and Lee Kuchenreuther put up floodlights to illuminate their backyard at night. The mayor, Robert Moshman, tries to keep bears from raiding his garbage cans by storing meat scraps in a plastic bag in the refrigerator until garbage-collection day. And the elementary schools have started bear-alert and bear-safety programs and have asked neighbors to call if they see a bear headed toward a school.

title: 5-Year Hunt Fails to Net Qaeda Suspect in Africa
description: A recent urgent terrorism alert in Kenya is the latest frustrating chapter in a five-year international manhunt for one of the world's most wanted Qaeda suspects, American and Kenyan officials say.

title: Financial Disclosures Put 3 Candidates and Clintons In Same Realm as Bush
description: Three of the four Senate Democrats who are seeking their party's presidential nomination are millionaires in the same league of personal wealth as President Bush, financial disclosure statements released today show.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Police Fire On Workers Protest
description: At least two people were killed and 26 wounded in the capital, Phnom Penh, when the police opened fire on a crowd of rock-throwing garment factory workers who were demonstrating for higher wages, the police said. They said that one protester was shot to death and one policeman killed when he was hit on the head with a rock, and that most of those injured were police officers. The clash took place after five days of peaceful demonstrations as the police went on heightened alert ahead of a week of international meetings. The foreign ministers of the 10 members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations are to meet in Phnom Penh on Monday and are to be joined on Wednesday by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and other foreign ministers. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker Buys Debt
description: The Irish drug maker Elan Corporation said that it had bought back 40 percent of the debt that could have forced it to give up control of the company. Elan said that by repurchasing the bonds before they matured, it reduced the price to $494 million from $1 billion. If they had been allowed to mature, the price could have been enough to give control of the company to the holders of the so-called poison-put debt. Also, in a meeting in Dublin on Thursday, Elan shareholders voted to approve the sale of two drugs to King Pharmaceuticals of Bristol, Tenn., for $750 million. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about rebuilding at the World Trade Center site misstated the goal of development officials in setting an aggressive environmental review schedule. It is to start construction next summer, not to lay a cornerstone for the first tower during the Republican National Convention. (State officials had considered that at one point, but they recently decided not to do so, a spokeswoman for Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday.)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas last Saturday about problems that arise from mining of oil, gas and minerals in poor countries referred imprecisely to conclusions in a report commissioned by the World Bank on the link between investment and governance. The report said such projects were ''likely to lead to bad development outcomes for many if not most of the bank's clients.'' It did not say the projects had essentially done more harm than good.

title: Coming Unraveled: The Iraq Story
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: New Berlusconi Inquiry Reported
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi is being investigated by magistrates for suspected tax fraud and false bookkeeping involving his media company Mediaset, Italian newspapers reported. Mr. Berlusconi's lawyers denied the charges and expressed dismay that the newspapers learned of the case before they did. A statement from Mediaset termed the investigation another instance of political persecution. Mr. Berlusconi is on trial in Milan on charges of bribing judges. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Coming Unraveled: The Iraq Story
description: To the Editor:

title: One Prairie Dog Plays Critical Role in Wisconsin
description: Contact with one prairie dog has accounted for more than half of the 34 human cases of monkeypox in Wisconsin, a state health official said yesterday.

title: Last-Minute Excuses
description: A phantom bill has been floating around the New York State Capitol that would give a very hefty financial break to developers of a giant mall in Syracuse. Gov. George Pataki has denied that it is his bill, but he has a lot of connections to the entire development plan. As described by The Times' James McKinley Jr., the main developer has contributed a bundle to Mr. Pataki's campaigns. And several of the governor's former aides are busily lobbying for the mall.

title: Hong Kong and SARS
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NATIONAL CITY CORP., Cleveland, said it had agreed to purchase the National City Center from Prime Group Realty Trust, Chicago, a developer of office buildings, for $80 million.

title: PeopleSoft Files Suit In Fight With Oracle
description: PeopleSoft Inc., which is trying to fend off a $5.1 billion hostile bid from the Oracle Corporation, filed a lawsuit yesterday contending that Oracle was interfering with PeopleSoft's contracts with customers and engaging in unfair trade practices.

title: The Way to Choose Federal Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: AS U.S. FANS OUT IN IRAQ, VIOLENCE AND DEATH ON RISE
description: American troops fanning out to reinforce allied control of Iraq came under attack again today in at least three separate places north of Baghdad. Retaliating, they killed at least seven people, military officials said.

title: Mexican Wealth Gives Texas City A New Vitality
description: Unemployment in this small city on the southern tip of Texas hovers around 15 percent. Incomes are half the national average, and many people sell grapefruit and melons from the back of battered pickup trucks to make ends meet.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the television news anchor David Brinkley yesterday misspelled the name of a colleague on early ABC broadcasts of ''This Week.'' She is Karen Elliott House, not Elliot.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on May 20 about flooding and landslides in Sri Lanka misstated the amount of aid that Norway had pledged. It was about $1 million, not $100,000.

title: Burke Marshall Memorial
description: A memorial for Burke Marshall, an assistant attorney general in charge of the Justice Department's civil rights division in the 1960's who died on June 2, will be held at 6 p.m. on Wednesday at the Yale Club, 50 Vanderbilt Avenue, in Manhattan.

title: SHUTTLE INQUIRY FINDS NEW RISKS
description: As NASA tries to eliminate the dangers of falling foam insulation that apparently doomed the shuttle Columbia, independent investigators say they have found problems with four other shuttle components that could threaten future missions. These problems, the investigators say, suggest that NASA may be playing down early warning signs about a range of hazards.

title: An Oxymoron: Europe Without Christianity
description: Next week, leaders of the European Union will meet in Greece to vote on a proposed constitution that will govern the lives of 450 million Europeans. The most agitated debate at the convention that produced the draft focused on the preamble, specifically whether God in general, and Christianity in particular, ought to be mentioned among the sources of the ''values'' that produced a common European culture and heritage.

title: CONTEMPORARY ART:A SPECIAL REPORT : The irresistible glitz and lure of Contemporary creation
description: NEW YORK  Everybody is rushing to buy Contemporary art these days. It is the hottest game in town. At Christie's on May 13, they sold $68.78 million, $10 million more than Impressionist and Modern art a week earlier. Buyers feel comfortable with it because it looks so familiar. Many of the art works were the kind of stuff you see in kitchens and bathrooms. Only it's Art, and that makes them more expensive.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer's Shares Surge
description: On their first day of trading, shares of the British reinsurer Benfield soared from 250 pence to as much as 298 pence, valuing the company at the equivalent of $1.15 billion. The sale was the London Stock Exchange's largest initial public offering of 2003, and analysts said it might signal renewed stirrings of investor enthusiasm for such sales, which have been sharply curtailed by the retreat in stock markets in recent years. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSENTHAL, , JUDY C.
description: ROSENTHAL--Judy C. June 14, 1996. ''A thing of beauty is a joy forever; its loveliness increases; it will never pass into nothingness.'' Mo

title: Decision on Bail for Zimbabwe Opposition Leader Put Off
description: A judge in Zimbabwe's capital, Harare, today postponed ruling on a bail request in the trial of Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of the country's opposition party. Mr. Tsvangirai is charged with treason, for which he could be sentenced to death if convicted.

title: Pataki Rejects Bus Garage Below Trade Center Memorial
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said this week that he personally opposed the underground bus-parking area that planners have proposed building beneath the memorial to victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Coming Unraveled: The Iraq Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready for Their Reverse Dunk, Mr. DeMille
description: All street basketball players dream of making the pros, of flashing their baddest moves in front of the cameras and wowing millions of viewers the same way they impress their playground fans. But for every player who makes it, countless others fall short and watch their dreams rattle off the rim.

title: Washington Monument: He Takes It Personally
description: Not so long ago, a sitcom about a gay actor who gets elected to Congress would have seemed too daring to schedule during primetime. Network executives would have feared boycotts by gay groups and Christian conservatives alike.

title: Mets' Bats Boom In Post-Phillips Era
description: Steve Phillips did not have much time to enjoy Jos Reyes, and certainly he had not witnessed an intimidating Mets offense in years. Now that he is gone, the Mets are, for the moment, thriving.

title: 'Easter Island'
description: The decisive moment for Germany's fleet in the Great War was, indisputably, its illtimed arrival at the Falkland Islands. Having avoided detection by the Allies for three months since the outbreak of hostilities, it was their great misfortune to head straight for the Falklands just hours after the British fleet put in to coal there. Had they borne in and launched an offensive, they would have caught the British in the disarray of refueling. Instead, and for unknown reasons, all eight ships, under the command of Vice Admiral Graf Von Spee, tried to flee. Compounding this fatal decision was atypical weather-a bright, cloudless sky hung overhead; there were neither the usual fog banks nor the low-lying squall clouds to afford even momentary concealment. The British, with their superior cruisers, were quick to pursue. From all sides gunfire bombarded the Germans. After three hours of battle, Von Spee's flagship, the Scharnhorst, turned over on her beam, heeled gradually to port, and slid into the icy Atlantic, a cloud of black smoke shooting up from the boilers as she submerged. Only a coal collier, which was later interned in Argentina, and the small cruiser Dresden, which was to be run down and blown up in three months, escaped the fiery battle. Within hours, the rest of the squadron met its fate at the bottom of the sea.

title: Come Step Inside My Monet (or Renoir, or Manet)
description: J. SEWARD JOHNSON JR., an heir to the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune, has been making life-size metal sculptures for four decades. His subjects, drawn from everyday life, include a man reading the newspaper, a policeman writing a ticket and teenagers playing Frisbee. A book about his art is aptly titled ''Celebrating the Familiar.'' Though hundreds of his works can be found in public spaces across the country, the best known is the bronze businessman who for years sat on a bench in Liberty Plaza, sorting through the contents of his open briefcase, half a block from the World Trade Center. After Sept. 11, the photographer Susan Meiselas came across the sculpture unscathed amid the wreckage of the Twin Towers and captured the dust-covered survivor on film, an emblem of fortitude in the face of catastrophe. Mr. Johnson hopes to rededicate the piece as a memorial someday.

title: What Would Ernst Lubitsch Have Done?
description: A famous sign on the wall in Billy Wilder's office asked, ''What would Lubitsch have done?'' Wilder meant the question as a tribute to Ernst Lubitsch, his master, mentor and sometime boss -- a comic filmmaker whose elegant and effortless command represented, to Wilder and many others, the apogee of cinematic wit, sophistication and technical precision. These qualities are what critics mean when they talk about ''the Lubitsch touch,'' which is also the name of the three-week retrospective that began on Friday at Film Forum. The phrase, which honors Lubitsch's light tone and meticulous pacing, also implies a limiting judgment, as if he were, in the end, little more than a playful, skillful technician. It would never do, of course, to speak of ''the Lubitsch vision,'' ''the Lubitsch ideology'' or ''the Lubitsch Weltanschauung'' -- such talk would be soundly and justly mocked in one of his pictures -- but his unerring jokes and deftly plotted conundrums have an undertow of unsettling wisdom. His vaunted style is indeed a way of seeing the world, and his acute observations of human behavior add up to something like a theory of human nature.

description: GOLDFARB--Gene Stanley. Died peacefully on Tuesday, June 10, 2003 at his home in Palm Beach. The son of Frances and Samuel J. Goldfarb, he was born in Chicago, IL. on July 31, 1926 and raised in New York. He graduated from Columbia Grammar School, and attended Syracuse University and New York University. A successful businessman, he was a manufacturer and wholesaler of childrens', junior and womens' clothing. As Chairman of the Board of House of Perfection, Inc., he developed and expanded the company founded by his father in 1934. He owned and operated manufacturing facilities in the states of Virginia, West Virigina, Tennessee and South Carolina, and also provided work for 21 independent contractors on an annual basis. His youngest daughter, Ellen Goldfarb, serves as President and Chief Operating Office in this third generation, familyowned business. Gerie Goldfarb was known for his generosity to family and friends, and made annual contributions to the U.J.A.-Federation, Ben Gurion University, State of Israel, Albert Einstein College, American Jewish Congress, United Way of Palm Beach and Greenwich, CT., United Negro College Fund, Anti-Defamation League, Hillel Foundation, Technion Israel Institute, AIPAC, Good Samaritan and Saint Mary's Hospitals, Founder of the Kravis Center and many others too numerous to mention. He chaired the U.J.A.-Federation Appeal for the childrens' clothing industry in N.Y.C. for several years and contributed to the Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall. He was a member of Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, N.Y., of Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., and the Palm Beach Country Club. He spent his summers in Greenwich, CT. He was an accomplished sportsman and ardent golfer, and a generous and devoted friend and family man. He is survived by his wife, Judith Ellen Goldfarb, his daughters, Lauren Steiner, and Ellen Goldfarb, three grandsons, Nicholas and James Steiner, and Ryan Goldfarb. Also surviving are two brothers, Murray (wife Bobby), and Alan (wife Sarah) Goldfarb, two nieces, Susan and Amy, and three nephews, David, John and William Goldfarb.

title: Holocaust Documentaries: Too Much of a Bad Thing?
description: THE turning point may have come in 1985 with ''Shoah,'' Claude Lanzmann's nine-and-a-half-hour epic of death camp survivors, Nazi officials, Polish bystanders, righteous gentiles and meticulous historians hunched over aging documents. It marked -- if it did not initiate -- the moment when documentary filmmakers started giving their full attention to Hitler's planned extermination of the Jews. ''When I began exploring how films have grappled with the Holocaust in 1979, there were merely a few dozen titles to warrant attention,'' Annette Insdorf writes in her encyclopedic study ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust.'' But for the book's third edition, published this year, she lists, together with the fiction films, 69 documentaries made since 1990 alone -- a rate of almost one every two months. Elsewhere she estimates that there are at least six completed Holocaust documentaries that do not get distribution for every one that does. And the stream has continued at flood tide into 2003. Last month ''Secret Lives,'' Aviva Slesin's emotionally complex film about Jewish children hidden by gentile families during the Nazi era, opened in New York. Shortly after, PBS showed Charles Guggenheim's ''Berga: Soldiers of Another War,'' about Jewish-American soldiers captured by the Germans. ''Bonhoeffer,'' Martin Doblmeier's intellectual, spiritually suffused account of the anti-Nazi German theologian Dietrich Bonhoeffer, is opening on June 27, two days before A & E broadcasts Liz Garbus's ''Nazi Officer's Wife,'' the biography of a Jewish woman who survived by assuming an Aryan identity and marrying a Nazi party member.

I was near the end of my trip. I laid tired eyes on the cathedral and Casa Rosada, the impressive pink government house, and on a statue with an Argentine flag; farther along, I saw speeding taxis and rare book stores. I was both exhausted and giddy with the romance of the city, for I had also just spent a week drinking gallons of espresso and eating dulce de leche (a caramel-like jam that I almost became addicted to) and staying out in clubs until 4 each morning in this 24-hour city. My head was filled with the brilliantined nostalgia of tango shows. Then something happened that told me just how good a time I was having and how far compromised my judgment had become by a diet of caffeine and sugar and tango.

title: Norway's Wild Western Isles
description: The fish bubbles and spatters in the wide pan. We're cooking cod for dinner here in Reine, a village in the Lofoten Islands of Norway, way up above the Arctic Circle. Good thing, too, for a story about the Lofotens should begin with fish, and best with cod. In winter, cod like this come here to spawn by the tens of millions. It was the spawning cod that brought human beings to these Arctic islands some 10,000 years ago, and fishing is still the only real industry. Lofoten people have fought small wars over fish; scaffoldlike cod-drying racks cover nearly every rocky knoll in every fishing village; and when local children want a snack, they lovingly gnaw away at dried cod.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEHMAN, , RABBI EMERITUS DR. ROBERT L.
description: LEHMAN--Rabbi Emeritus Dr. Robert L. In New York City, on June 13, 2003. It is with great sadness that the Officers, Board of Trustees, Clergy and the entire membership of the Hebrew Tabernacle Congregation deeply mourn the sudden passing of our beloved and esteemed Rabbi Emeritus Dr. Robert L. Lehman. Born in Germany, he emigrated to the United States in 1938. Rabbi Lehman was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and was ordained from Hebrew Union College in 1954. He served with distinction as our Rabbi for 41 years. After his retirement he served as an interim Rabbi at both Or Chadash in Vienna, Austria, and later at Temple Israel in Lawrence, LI. Rabbi Lehman earned his Doctor of Ministry degree from the New York Theological Seminary in 1985. As a member of the Central Conference of American Rabbis he served on several of its national committees. He was President of both the New York Association of Reform Rabbis and the American Federation of Jews from Central Europe. He worked tirelessly on the Executive Committee of the World Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors. Rabbi Lehman is survived by his devoted wife Loni and their daughter Sharon, as well as his many friends and devoted congregants of the Hebrew Tabernacle. We will miss his wonderful and joyful presence in our congregation and in our lives. Funeral services Monday, June 16, 11 AM, at the Hebrew Tabernacle Congregation, 551 Fort Washington Avenue, NY, NY, at West 185 St. Contributions in memory of Rabbi Lehman can be sent to the Hebrew Tabernacle. Stephen L. Berkowitz, Rabbi Michael Kruk, Cantor Mark S. Hamburgh, President >>AD#

title: The News From Spain
description: How 17th-century Spanish painting came to influence late 19th-century French art is brilliantly illuminated in MANET/VELZQUEZ: The French Taste for Spanish Painting (Metropolitan Museum of Art/Yale University, $75). Spanish paintings, with their blend of mysticism and earthy naturalism, were prized for their scarcity in France at the start of the 19th century, when few had actually been seen. Soon thereafter, Napoleon plundered hundreds of these paintings from Spanish churches, palaces and monasteries, and for the first time these works by Velzquez, Zurbarn, Goya and Murillo were exhibited in Paris. Even when the war loot was returned to Spain after Napoleon's abdication, the paintings stayed in the public eye as the core of the Prado, formed in 1819. Spanish bounty ricocheted once more to France, purchased this time by King Louis Philippe, who put his 400 paintings on view in the Galerie Espagnole at the Louvre in 1838 (10 years later politics once again ousted the ruler and the paintings). Gary Tinterow, a curator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, argues that direct contact with these anticlassical works infected young French artists with the germ of modernism. Delacroix, ruminating on Velzquez, recorded in his journal around 1824, ''I'd like to spread some nice oily, thick paint across a brown or red canvas.'' That same visceral quality about Spanish painting would grip Manet, who after visiting the Prado in 1865 wrote about a portrait by Velzquez: ''There's nothing but air surrounding the fellow, who is all in black and appears alive.'' Hilarie M. Sheets

title: SUBPOENAS ISSUED

Levinsohn, who held top positions in the McGreevey 2001 campaign and the first year of his administration, are under federal investigation in connection with a multimillion-dollar billboard scandal. Authorities are investigating whether the men used their political clout to raise their billboard company's profit. One subpoena requires the Democratic State Committee to release records about a business contract signed by Mr. Taffet. The other seeks information from the secretary of state's office about the oath of office Mr. Levinsohn took when sworn in as deputy attorney general during the administration's transition period.

title: Beyonc With Herself (And Herself)
description: BEYONC FEATURING JAY-Z; LIL' KIM FEATURING 50 CENT -- ''Crazy in Love'' (with Beyonc and Jay-Z) and ''Magic Stick'' (with Lil' Kim and 50 Cent) are two strong singles, but only one of them is a strong collaboration. What carries ''Crazy in Love'' (Sony) is the blaring horn sample that crescendos as a multitracked cacophony of Beyoncs sing the chorus. The rap from Jay-Z, as it often does on his guest spots (''Butterfly,'' ''Frontin'''), seems pasted just after the middle of the song as an afterthought. What carries ''Magic Stick'' (Atlantic), on the other hand, is the interplay between Lil' Kim and 50 Cent, especially on the catchily tone-deaf chorus. Unlike many rap collaborations, it is clear that the two are actually singing the same song about the same thing at the same time.

title: My Son, the Cyborg
description: Why, exactly, was it front-page news (and Starbucks-line conversational fodder) that playing ''first-person shooter'' video games enhances visual skills? Maybe it had that tang of the counterintuitive that makes certain stories from academia attractive far beyond it: Hey, violent video games can be good for you! Maybe it was a consolation prize for parents whose kids can't get enough of games like ''Grand Theft Auto 3,'' ''Rogue Spear'' and ''Medal of Honor,'' where the object is to terminate with extreme prejudice as many enemies as you can. Regular players of action video games may be wreaking virtual mayhem, but they also have awesome peripheral vision and can keep track of lots of objects at once (though not necessarily the ones their parents want them to keep track of). But maybe the article -- which was based on a relatively small study done by a neuroscientist at the University of Rochester -- carried a charge for other more complicated reasons.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/New 4Matic in Mercedes Wagons; Full-Time All-Wheel Drive, And So Smooth It's Invisible

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE

Desiree (Angela Bassett), who went up north to act but found fame only in infomercials, is back for a visit, just in time to meet the real estate developers who want to turn Plantation and its predominantly black neighbor, Lincoln Beach, into a glitzy resort destination. In SUNSHINE STATE (2002), John Sayles, who never flinches at the dark side, draws a portrait of an oceanfront community on the verge of losing its soul. ''The important thing is to keep that smile on your face,'' Marly says, recalling her days as a theme-park mermaid, ''even if you're drowning'' -- Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: How 15 Minutes Became 5 Weeks
description: THREE years ago, The New York Times Magazine asked me to do a story on the newest form of mass entertainment in America -- the phenomenon I called the mediathon, ''a relentless hybrid of media circus, soap opera and tabloid journalism we have come to think of as All Calamity All the Time.'' All-consuming news stories have been a staple of our culture even further back than the Lindbergh kidnapping, but the advent of competing, 24/7 cable news networks and the Internet had produced a thicker, faster-paced infotainment spectacle by the mid-1990's. The klieg lights would burn brightly for days, weeks, even months -- sometimes offering illumination, sometimes not -- and then flame out. Either the drama would reach its denouement or the public would simply grow bored and change the channel, seeking a fresh story and perhaps a smarter Kato Kaelin.

Since 1997, more than 20 insurance companies have fled the state, claiming New Jersey's labyrinthine regulations rendered the market unprofitable. Mr. McGreevey said the new bill eases the state's regulations and will lure some of the companies back to the state. It will eventually lower auto insurance rates, he said. The legislation also cracks down on insurance fraud. Wendy Ginsberg

title: 'Liars and Saints'
description: They were married during the war, in Santa Barbara, after Mass one morning in the old Mission church. Teddy was solemn; he took the Mass very seriously. Yvette, in a veiled hat and an ivory dress that wasn't a gown, was distracted by the idea that she was in California, without her father there to give her away, and she was about to change her life and her name. "I, Yvette Grenier, take you, Theodore Santerre ..." It all sounded formal and strange, as if someone else were saying the words, until she realized with surprise that it was her.

They had been to their Daddy and Me class, where they ate pizza and talked about why Mack needed to work harder at listening. Then, father and son had compiled a list of the dopiest songs ever. The problem arose recently when I was asked to choose one Mahler symphony to represent them all. Every time I pondered it, I froze, and I never did find a solution. But since Lorin Maazel and the New York Philharmonic are presenting the Second, the ''Resurrection,'' beginning on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall, let's settle on it for now.

title: Old Books and Antique Maps Near New Art in Beacon
description: Debra Adamsons, who managed and owned Bruised Apple Books in Peekskill with Scott Sailor, picked the riverfront town of Beacon to set up a new store of used and rare books, which opened last month. Dia:Beacon, the contemporary art museum also opened there in May, and the once scrappy town has attracted a crowd of artists to establish studios and galleries. Creekside Books, Ms. Adamson's new store sells used books, from $2 paperbacks to rare leatherbound sets. It has a collection of antique prints of the Hudson River, old maps of areas along the Hudson, illustrated classics and vinyl records. Ms. Adamsons said she is not particularly worried about the competition posed by online sellers like Amazon. ''People who buy secondhand books want to see the book,'' she said. ''They want the thrill of discovery.'' Creekside Books and Music is at 532 Main Street, Beacon, (845)831-1760. Yilu Zhao

title: A Mighty Wind
description: The buzz on Cape Cod is grim as summer approaches. There is little talk about beach permits or Kennedy sightings and much talk about dead birds littering beaches, jellyfish clogging waterways and tourism collapsing. Even Walter Cronkite, America's minence grise, has issued a dire warning from his second home on Martha's Vineyard. ''I'm very concerned about a private developer's plan to build an industrial energy complex across 24 square miles of publicly owned land,'' Cronkite intoned in a radio and television ad recently broadcast across the Cape.

title: Choreographing With a Camera
description: WHEN Matthew Diamond left New York for Los Angeles in 1987 to become a television director, he had no idea how much he'd miss dance. But after many years as a dancer, choreographer and director of his own company, he wanted to try something new. He landed work directing sitcoms and soap operas. Then in 1991, Judy Kinberg, a founding producer of Thirteen/WNET's ''Dance in America'' series, asked him to direct Paul Taylor's ''Speaking in Tongues.'' ''It gave me a chance to combine everything I care about,'' he said.

title: Looking for Statements? Try the 30's
description: HERE's what some recent dance performances have told us: The economy is faltering. Societies are disintegrating. War looms. People are forced to make choices against their wills. Yet dreamers still dream of social harmony.

title: From the Meadow to the Backyard
description: I HAVE always loved the common mullein, Verbascum thapsis, since I first saw it in cow pastures and along the roadsides where I grew up in Maryland. Its big, fuzzy, gray rosettes appeared the first year, taking over some bare patch in the grass. A year later, up shot a four- or five-foot candlestick covered with pea-size buds that opened into lemon-yellow flowers.

title: Sensory Overload In Naples
description: IN Naples, the motorino rules. Pedestrians, cars, even buses meekly yield to the buzzing scooters piloted by daredevils whose average age appears to be somewhere around 13. The essential lesson the seasoned traveler has learned about crossing Italian intersections -- step off the curb with a confident attitude and the traffic will stop -- would mean suicide in Naples. There the red light is a concept beneath consideration, as is the distinction between sidewalk and street, and the only observable rule of road etiquette requires you to look cool and unrattled after coming within inches of being flattened by a swarm of schoolboys on motorbikes. Even the considerable pleasures of strolling the scenic, palm-lined waterfront along the Bay of Naples are somewhat tempered by the fact that the broad, cobblestoned riviera presents the youthful speed demons with an irresistible challenge.

title: Visiting A Room in Show Tune Heaven
description: NORMAL-LOOKING people go a little crazy when they visit ''Original Cast Recordings,'' an exhibit at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts that traces the history of the cast album. Middle-aged moms randomly break into song. Men in suits tap dance. Obsessive fans graffiti the walls. And the loud show music playing on a continuous loop adds to the sense that you're in an upscale madhouse.

title: No 'Torah Scholar'

title: Playing With History
description: QYour new play, ''A Bad Friend,'' which just opened at Lincoln Center, tells the story of a family of dedicated Communists trying to survive in Brooklyn in the 1950's, the heyday of McCarthyism and conformity and bobby socks.

title: Ranks of the Rich Narrowed in U.S.

title: The Beginning of Modern Humans
description: One of the essential attributes of modern humans is to wonder about the origins of modern humans. The wondering may now have become a little more precise. Scientists from the University of California at Berkeley have announced the discovery of three skulls in Ethiopia that have nearly modern features and that can be precisely dated to 160,000 to 154,000 years old. The date is as critical as the cranial features, which were painstakingly reconstructed over six years. The skulls roughly coincide with what genetic evidence suggests is ''the origin of modern human variation,'' as one scientist puts it, and they date from a period when the fossil evidence for hominids is extremely thin. The discoverers of the skulls place them in a subspecies of Homo sapiens called Homo sapiens idaltu. Idaltu means elder in Afar, the local language in the region where the skulls were found. We belong to Homo sapiens sapiens.

title: When Rent Control Just Vanishes; Both Sides of Debate Cite Boston's Example
description: With rent-stabilization regulations in New York set to expire on June 16, the usual suspects are doing their heartfelt best to frame the debate. In one corner are tenant advocates, who say that rent regulations cushion thousands of people from the abyss of poverty. In the other corner are landlord advocates, who say that the regulations stifle any free-market impulses to build and rehabilitate housing.

title: Thai Spot Handles Westerners Tenderly

Chains, franchises and fast-food operations are the norm at shopping centers. Independently owned restaurants are unusual. But the stand-alone Thai Green Leaf, at 27 Carmans Road in front of the Sunrise Mall in Massapequa (516-799-8666), has successfully bridged the gap. It has accomplished that since opening late year by serving not authentic scorching preparations but ''Thai-style cooking,'' or Thai dishes slightly tamed to American tastes.

He schedules meetings with a backup plan in mind, and sometimes uses the midnight hour to catch up on his work.

Stock options helped technology start-ups grow by luring talent and helping companies reduce salaries and taxes. When reformers suggested that companies count those shares as an expense, effectively diluting their reported earnings, the valley mobilized to fight them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLE, , JAMES A., JR.
description: COLE--James A., Jr., 80, retired Texaco marine executive, died of cancer at home in New Canaan, CT on June 5. Mr. Cole, born in Floral Park, NY, graduated from Kings Point Merchant Marine Academy '43 and New York University '49. During WWII he served in the Merchant Marine. His 37-year career with Caltex and Texaco included years in Bahrain, England and France. After retiring as VP of Texaco's Marine Dept, he was a director of the American Bureau of Shipping and other marine companies. Survived by his wife of 56 years, Jean (Pardee), children: Peter (Belinda), David (Sharon), Geoffrey (Linda), and Amy (Mark Buehler), five grandchildren, & sister Betty O'Rourke. Coach Don Chaney is strongly considering two interim head coaches, Terry Stotts of Atlanta and Dennis Johnson of the Los Angeles Clippers, as his final assistant. Crickets are part of the specialized diet for tarantulas, and for birds, snakes and monkeys here. As such, the insects are a tiny part of the highly specialized business of feeding smaller creatures to larger ones.

description: He heard the knocking at his door a few minutes before 10 a.m. yesterday, and for once, Roger Clemens wished it would stop. He had been a 300-game winner for less than than 12 hours and been asleep for only 6. Clemens let his trainer, Brian McNamee, keep knocking for 15 minutes.

title: The Key To My Father
description: Let's get something straight right away: my father was hopelessly unhip. He was the corporeal embodiment of an Air Supply eight-track. He'd come home from work, shed the powder-blue suit with reversible vest, the tie so polyester it would melt during heat waves, the V-neck Hanes undershirt of startling white, the gray socks bought by the dozen at Burlington Coat Factory. He'd don a logo T-shirt that was compulsorily a size too snug, if you know what I mean, and shorts that were, uh, short, like something John McEnroe wore at Wimbledon in 1979.

In the weeks we were there, we'd only seen the sun sporadically, and always, it seemed, on a day when we were traveling.

title: The Glass Flowers
description: Like many great works of art, Harvard University's collection of glass flowers -- officially, the Ware Collection of Blaschka Glass Models of Plants -- has about it an air of magnificent obsession. It's impossible to gaze at the colors, textures and inexplicable sensuality of these all-glass botanical replicas without wondering at the maniacal passion and skill that must have gone into creating them. The flowers were commissioned in 1885 as tools for the study of taxonomy and botany, and some are accurate down to details invisible to the naked eye.

title: Mary Kemper, Gary Wolf

Wolf of New York, were married last evening in Kansas City at the Kemper Contemporary Museum of Art, which was founded by the bride's parents. Rabbi Joshua Taub officiated at the ceremony in which Lynne Buckley-Quirk, a Christian Scientist, took part.

title: Totems and Crepes in the South Pacific
description: AT 4:30 p.m. on the South Pacific atoll of Ouva, night was already falling, and so was a warm tropical rain. Emboldened by my accomplishments in spin class back home, I was determined that my husband, Brad, and I would bike the seven and a half miles from our guest house on this island in New Caledonia to the Pont de Mouly, a bridge that connects the lower third of the island to the larger main section of land. I was less interested in what lay across the span than in what ran underneath. Ouva, a flat comma of sand and palm trees, arcs around one of the South Pacific's largest lagoons -- 13.5 square miles -- and at Mouly the water funnels from it through a narrow channel in a rainbow of tropical blue hues.

title: Anaheim's Offense Exposes Mets' Roach and Burnitz
description: The Mets' infield had finished tossing the ball around after Jason Roach's warm-up pitches tonight when Ty Wigginton carried the ball to the mound. He gave it to Roach, a rookie, slapped him on the backside with his glove and offered words of encouragement. Wigginton, the rookie third baseman, is what passes for a Mets elder statesmen these days.

title: Editors' Note
description: Until this week, the Residential Sales column has calculated time on the market differently for Westchester entries than for those in other areas. Outside of Westchester, time on the market was computed through the date of a sales agreement; for Westchester it was computed through the closing date. The effect was to overstate, by comparison, the length of time Westchester homes were on the market. The discrepancy was discovered when arrangements were being made for an additional brokerage firm, active elsewhere in the metropolitan area, to submit information for possible inclusion in the Westchester listings.

description: LEVINSON--Rose, 95, in Tamarac, FL, on June 5th, 2003. Formerly of NYC. Proud first generation American who lived the 20th century. Adored, loving and devoted mother to Marcy and to Elyse Mintz. Caring grandmother to Janna and Claudia and great-grandmother to Emily, Jared and Tauby. One of the first women to be licensed in the State of New York as an insurance adjuster in the early 1950s. Active in the Fulton Senior Citizen Center in Chelsea and in local Board of Elections. Traveled in the US, Canada and Mexico as well as in the Caribbean, Europe and Southeast Asia. She loved New York and Florida and was loved by her friends. title: The Art of a Neverland Called 'Asia'
description: ''ASIA'' doesn't exist; it never did. It's a fantasy, a fiction, one of those words the ancient Greeks put on their maps to indicate everything ''out there'' to the East. Nor is there such a thing as ''Asian art,'' though San Francisco has just opened a $160.5 million museum devoted to it.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sutton Place; Prestigious Address With Villagelike Feel
description: ELEANOR AND LEONARD GARBIN raised two children on a 14-acre property in Pound Ridge, a picturesque Westchester town on the Connecticut line. But when a three-year stint living in downtown Cincinnati convinced the two that they were city dwellers at heart, they embraced the convenience of a Manhattan co-op apartment just a few steps from the East River.

title: The Vicissitudes Of Literary Reputation
description: Most literary reputation is fragile and fleeting, and the reputation of poets especially so. Their stock is traded on a Nasdaq of singular cruelty and volatility. We still read Hemingway and Fitzgerald, for example, but who reads Edna St. Vincent Millay, in her lifetime just as celebrated as her two contemporaries? Almost as famous was Edwin Arlington Robinson, whose best-selling Arthurian trilogy -- ''Merlin,'' ''Lancelot'' and ''Tristram'' -- is something that few readers now would want to linger over, particularly if they were hoping to stay alert enough to drive or operate heavy machinery.

description: Weeks

title: The Poor as a Handy Distraction
description: The gravest questions of fiscal responsibility for the nation are being ignored in the freakish sideshow now under way in Congress over yet another tax cut in these fiscally difficult times. President Bush and the Republican leaders should be candidly debating the $2 trillion-plus mountain of deficits and debt they are rolling onto the backs of future generations through the administration's serial tax cuts. Instead, they are obsessed with the 2004 election cycle, wrangling over how best to throw a last-minute bone to low-income Americans shortchanged in last month's tax giveaway to the most affluent Americans.

title: PRIVACY HEARINGS
description: The Privacy Study Commission will hold more hearings this week to solicit opinion on what information gathered by government agencies should be made public under the year-old Open Public Records Act. The commission is looking into questions like whether people's addresses, which are part of the records of many public agencies, should be made available to the public under the act. The first hearing was held last Monday. The second is set for tomorrow in the student center at Rowan University in Glassboro and a final one will be held Tuesday in the student center at Montclair State University. Each hearing will last from 4 to 7 p.m or as long as necessary to hear everyone who appears to testify.Shortly after the open records act was signed last summer, Gov. James E. McGreevey issued an executive order banning the disclosure of most addresses. He later rescinded the order and requested the commission look into that and other privacy issues. Karen DeMasters

title: It's Not the Porn, It's the Color Scheme
description: Eighth Avenue in Chelsea does not blush easily. On this predominantly gay strip, images of chiseled hard bodies stare down from storefront windows and flesh-toned billboards. No fewer than six shops carry pornographic movies and bawdy accoutrements.

title: Too Picturesque for Its Own Good?
description: The Castle is nice, of course, the Charles Bridge sublime, even with tourists bouncing beerily off one another. But the Prague I like is summed up in an indoor passageway off Wenceslas Square, the city's downtown. Strung from the ceiling is a grand equestrian statue of Good King Wenceslas. He is suitably erect and heroic. His problem, apparently unnoticed by him, is that he is mounted not on the horse's back but on its belly -- and the horse, judging by the dangling tongue, is dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMS, , ADELAIDE B.
description: ADAMS--Adelaide B. 93, of New York City, and formerly of Wilton, CT, died peacefully on June 13th after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Daniel P. Adams, and sister of the late Marjorie P. Starr. Cherised mother of Nancy Adams Downey and Marjorie Adams Cooke. Devoted mother-in-law of Robert N. Downey and Caswell Cooke. Loving grandmother of Anne, Nathan, Daniel Jackson and Elizabeth, and four great-grandchildren. A lifelong New Yorker, attended The Brearley School and Vassar College. As Chair of the Research Committee for The Daughters of the Cincinnati's 1978 publication, ''A Salute To Courage,'' she traveled around the country, researching in libraries, private papers, historical societies and universities for almost 12 years to help create a collection of the American Revolutionary War experiences of all the officers on The Daughters of the Cincinnati's roster. Also a member of The Holland Dames, The Colonial Dames of America, and the Huguenot Society. A Memorial Service at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, (73rd St), will be at 11 AM, on Tuesday, June 17th. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The Scholarship Fund of the Daughters of the Cincinnati, 122 E. 58th St. NY, NY 10022, or Amnesty International, 322 8th Avenue, NY, NY 10001. >>AD#

title: Concordia Shortstop Drafted by Pro Baseball
description: Most of the small number of athletes who make it from college to the big leagues do so from the springboard of a brand-name sports school like the University of Arizona or Indiana University. But Concordia College-Bronxville, which has only 660 students, has cobbled together an enviable track record of players who have been drafted by Major League Baseball, all from its relatively small Division II baseball program.

title: Hoping for a Curtain Call

title: Dumb Comedy: The Hardest Kind
description: DUMB comedy -- as Rodney Dangerfield, one of its most eminent practitioners, might say -- gets no respect. And there are, all too frequently, very good reasons for that, as Troy Miller's ''Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd,'' a new prequel to the Farrelly Brothers' 1994 moron masterpiece, ''Dumb and Dumber,'' sadly demonstrates. Although stupidity is an essential element even of ''sophisticated'' comedy (classical farce depends on its characters' capacity to get more or less everything wrong), it's not so easy to sustain an audience's interest in, and amusement at, characters as relentlessly and intractably clueless as Harry and Lloyd. It's child's play to score off idiots -- they don't play much defense -- but one-sided games tend to make spectators head for the exits early.

title: A Mutt With a Pedigree
description: Apparently the public is clamoring for stuffed shirts -- at least when they take the form of a friendly mongrel. A patchwork plaid dog, created by a J. Crew designer out of leftover fabric scraps, was photographed for the cover of J. Crew's latest catalog and then displayed in the window of one of its stores in Manhattan. Though it was not for sale, customers soon began asking the inevitable question: how much is that doggie in the window?

At the Avon Salon & Spa in Manhattan, girls ages 11 to 19 can choose from a children's menu of facials and hair services ($45-$98, 212-755-2866). The Jurlique Spa, left, offers a free Mini-Discovery Facial to children whose parents have scheduled a grown-up version of the same (212-752-1980). At Walt Disney World in Orlando, the Grand Floridian Resort & Spa invites girls to unwind after a long day on Space Mountain with My First Facial, a 25-minute cleansing ($65, 407-824-2332). Or they can try a 90-minute head-to-toe package called Minnie Spa at the nearby Saratoga Springs Resort & Spa with a facial, a manicure and a pedicure ($110, plus gratuity; 407-827-4455).
