title: Metro Briefing | New York: Long Island: Two Die In Fiery Crash
description: Two people were killed and a third injured when their BMW burst into flames after colliding with a van yesterday in Valley Stream, the Nassau County police said. A New Jersey man who was driving the van fled the scene, and was later arrested, according to the authorities. The crash occurred at 5:19 p.m. when the 1999 BMW was turning from East Merrick Road on to Cornwell Avenue and was struck by the van, a Chevrolet. The BMW veered out of control and slid sideways, hitting a parking meter and utility pole on the north side of Merrick Road. The BMW became engulfed in flames, but not before a witness ran to the wreckage and pulled the unconscious body of the driver free, investigators said. The two other occupants were pronounced dead at the scene. The driver was taken to a nearby hospital, but his condition was not known early this morning, according to Officer Adele Burke, a police spokeswoman. The police identified the driver of the van as Howard Antosofsky, 42, of Teaneck. They said his wife and five children were in the van when the crash occurred. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: MINNEAPOLIS: MILLIONS FOR THE GUTHRIE
description: While many states are drastically cutting their arts budgets, Minnesota has approved a bond issue that includes $25 million to help pay for an imposing three-stage complex for the Guthrie Theater. Gov. Tim Pawlenty signed the authorization bill on Thursday. Construction is to start late this summer, and the complex, its estimated total cost at $125 million, is expected to open in 2005. The Guthrie, founded in 1963, is one of the leading regional theaters in the United States and a center of cultural life in and around Minneapolis. The theater's artistic director, Joe Dowling, said new complex would allow the Guthrie to continue presenting classic drama while offering more space for touring works, new plays and educational programs. ''To say we are overjoyed is an understatement,'' he said. The French architect Jean Nouvel has completed a design for the complex, which will overlook the Mississippi River. Theater officials have raised $64.5 million from private donors, and Charles Zelle, board chairman, said he would try to make up the remainder by a combination of cost-cutting and additional fund-raising. STEPHEN KINZER

Mr. Haddad, an immigrant from Syria at the turn of the century later became Publisher and Editor-in-Chief of the one of the first Arabic journals in New York, called As-Sayeh, which means ''The Traveler'' in Arabic. As-Sayeh was the journal that gave voice to a band of renowned authors and poets which constituted what was then called the ''Pen Club'' during the '30s and '40s. This club included Kahlil Gibran and Nadra Haddad. She was married to Fred C. Abdelnour on February 1, 1946, a private investor and owner of Frederick's of Greenwich for over 45 years. Survived by her sister Rae Haddad and brother Jerry Haddad; her three children, Bill Abdelnour, Beverly Ryan, Bonnie Verbitsky; four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Lila Abdelnour and her husband were two of the founding members of the Church of Our Savior in Rye, NY.

Both parties promised voters in the last election that they would do something to help the elderly pay the fast-rising cost of prescription drugs, a benefit that is not covered by the existing Medicare program. The main difference was that Republicans wanted to do it through private health plans and market competition while the Democrats simply wanted to strengthen the government's traditional Medicare program.

title: Leighton Rees, 63, of Wales, Who Threw Darts, Deftly
description: Leighton Rees, an imposing Welshman who became the world's first professional dart-throwing champion, died on June 8 in Pontypridd, South Wales. He was 63.

title: Unionist Leader Survives Hard-Liners' Challenge in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 16  David Trimble, Northern Ireland's most prominent Protestant politician, survived a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionists tonight, but the vote left his party deeply divided over whether to participate fully in the province's peace efforts.

title: DMZ Twist: U.S. Plans Unsettle North Korea
description: When the Pentagon announced its plans to pull American troops away from the border with North Korea, attention focused mostly on South Korea and its objections to losing the protection of the so-called tripwire. What was largely overlooked were the protests from the party that felt most threatened by the change: North Korea.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about a show of Turner seascapes at the Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., misstated the first of the artist's given names. He was Joseph Mallord William, not James.

title: Jailing in Russia Is a Reminder That Spy Wars Still Smolder
description: When Moscow revealed last week that a Russian intelligence officer who had settled in the United States had been lured back home and arrested, the news was the talk of American and Russian veterans of the intelligence battles of the cold war, who viewed the incident as evidence that an old-fashioned spy war has quietly flared anew.

title: Stock Sales Planned For the Week Ahead
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: G.I.'s Offering Carrots to Iraq As Well as Stick
description: American troops pressed forward today in a new campaign combining military raids against suspected supporters of Saddam Hussein with high-visibility relief projects for Iraqi civilians. Commanders said they hoped that the two-sided approach would help eradicate armed resistance against American forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHUBERT, , ILENE SENTER
description: SCHUBERT -- Ilene Senter. Adored wife of Robert A. Schubert. Loving mother of Emily. Beloved daughter of Leila. Cherished sister of Michael and Lisa and their children Andrew and Vicky. Your indomitable spirit will be with us forever. Services will be 11 AM, today, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pine Brook Blvd, New Rochelle. Donations may be made in Ilene's memory to the National Cancer Foundation.

title: Defining Hamas: Roots in Charity and Branches of Violence
description: To most Israelis, Hamas is a terrorist group and little more, the core of Palestinian hatred that explodes against Israeli civilians who are innocently shopping or riding on buses. When talk of any peace accord nears, Hamas advocates the ideological extreme: no compromise on a Palestinian state, based on Islam, that stretches from the Mediterranean east to the Jordan River. It talks often of driving all Jews from the land.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Fatally Stabbed
description: An argument apparently turned deadly on the Upper West Side early yesterday, the police said. A man in his 20's was found stabbed twice in the chest in front of a store on Amsterdam Avenue near 96th Street after a fight with two other men -- Jorge Benavides, 18, of West 94th Street, and Faustino Leal, 20, of Amsterdam Avenue, the police said. The victim, whose name was not immediately released, was pronounced dead at 3:50 a.m. at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Mr. Benavides and Mr. Leal were arrested and charged with second degree murder. Sami Mozep, 27, the owner of the store, Finest Deli Grocery of New York at 720 Amsterdam Avenue, said that the victim collapsed in front of his store around 2 a.m. He said his workers told him that the victim had fled El Mariachi restaurant at 710 Amsterdam Avenue. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Hot Seat's New Occupant at Philadelphia Inquirer
description: Amanda Bennett, the editor of The Herald-Leader in Lexington, Ky., was racing to catch a plane to a Knight Ridder conference in Dallas on May 12 when her publisher informed her that she was being diverted to the East Coast.

title: White House Letter; A Diplomatic Success, And Cheney's Daughter
description: Liz Cheney, a deputy assistant secretary in the State Department's Near East bureau who also happens to be the daughter of the vice president, slipped quietly into her Foggy Bottom office a little more than a year ago and has kept her head down since. Like her father, Ms. Cheney rarely gives interviews, doesn't like to have her picture taken and thrives in the background.

title: Tribal Truths
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Texas Frees 12 on Bond After Drug Sweep Inquiry
description: In the same warm third-floor courtroom where she was convicted three years ago, Kizzie White was told this afternoon to go home. She searched the packed room for her son, Cashawn, 6, who had lived with relatives since she went to prison and who, for the rest of the afternoon, kept one small hand touching her -- her hand, her ear, her neck.

title: Schumer Praises Work for Safer Penn Station, but Wants More
description: With $100 million in federal funds allocated to improve security along the labyrinth of railroad tracks and tunnels leading to Pennsylvania Station, a top official of the Department of Homeland Security joined Senator Charles E. Schumer on a tour of the station yesterday, and both said the work was off to a good start.

title: Kennebunkport Notebook; Vacationing, if He Must, In White-Wine Territory
description: Last summer, when President Bush was in the scorching August heat in Texas, a reporter asked him why he voluntarily suffered through the hottest month in one of the country's hottest corners.

title: Hume Cronyn, Compelling Actor Of Stage and Screen, Dies at 91
description: Hume Cronyn, one of the foremost character actors of the American stage and screen for more than 60 years, died on Sunday at his home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 91.

title: Questions The Doctor Never Asked
description: The patient walked slowly into my office, took off his hat and collapsed into a vinyl chair.

title: Bush Issues Federal Ban on Racial Profiling
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 - President Bush issued guidelines today barring federal agents from using race or ethnicity in their routine investigations, but the policy carves out clear exemptions for investigations involving terrorism and national security matters.

title: 3 Are Named to Board of Agency Directing Rebuilding of Downtown
description: Three people were appointed yesterday to fill vacancies on the board of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the agency that is overseeing the rebuilding of downtown. The three included the second relative of a victim of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center to be appointed to the board.

title: 30 More Schools Citywide Will Receive Federal Aid
description: More than $500 million in federal aid for impoverished schools will be distributed more widely in New York City this fall, particularly on Staten Island, under a change in eligibility requirements approved by the federal Department of Education.

title: House Discloses Itself to Be Poorer Sibling of the Senate
description: Compared with the millionaires' club in the Senate, many leaders in the House of Representatives have wealth more in line with that of successful middle managers, according to their financial disclosure forms.

title: Pentagon Voice (and Index Finger) Is Retiring
description: Victoria Clarke, the Pentagon's highly visible spokeswoman during the Sept. 11 attacks and wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, will retire on Friday, officials said today.

title: Chairman Resigns at Tierney DeGregorio
description: Tony DeGregorio has resigned as chairman and chief creative officer at Tierney DeGregorio Advertising in Philadelphia after two years in the post, the agency said yesterday.

title: Dereliction Of Duty
description: Last Thursday a House subcommittee met to finalize next year's homeland security appropriation. The ranking Democrat announced that he would introduce an amendment adding roughly $1 billion for areas like port security and border security that, according to just about every expert, have been severely neglected since Sept. 11. He proposed to pay for the additions by slightly scaling back tax cuts for people making more than $1 million per year.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Pneumonia Shots for the Masses
description: Doctors have been working for years to persuade more older Americans to get the flu vaccine. Now a new study suggests that policymakers consider broadening the guidelines on who should get the vaccine against another common killer, invasive pneumococcal disease.

title: Clarity and the Bishops
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Decline In Savings
description: Assets held by Japanese individuals fell a record 1.9 percent in the fiscal year that ended in March, the third consecutive decline, according to the Bank of Japan. The drop is a result of falling wages and the collapse in stock prices. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: There's Lots of Blame To Share on the Nets
description: The fluttering confetti fell like taunts on the Nets' hanging heads as they witnessed another championship celebration that was not for them. Crushed by the Spurs' 88-77 triumph Sunday in Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals, some Nets walked disgustedly off the SBC Center court into an uncertain future.

title: WPP makes another offer in its fight with Publicis for control of Cordiant.
description: SIR MARTIN SORRELL, the acquisitive chief executive of the WPP Group, is stepping up his already aggressive push to win control of a smaller competitor, the troubled British agency company Cordiant Communications Group.

title: Hunt Imperils Polar Bears In Bering Sea, Report Says
description: Polar bears that traverse the floating ice between the Russian Arctic and Alaska are being shot in rising numbers by poachers on Russian shores, according to a new report by federal wildlife biologists in the United States, and the killing could greatly diminish the bear population if it is not slowed.

title: Trading Briefcases For Baby Strollers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Spurs Show Kidd What's Missing In New Jersey
description: THIS city is still glowing from the excitement of winning the N.B.A. championship. The franchise won its second title since 1999, but that title was won during a lockout-shortened season. After Sunday's victory over the Nets, an usher proudly proclaimed, ''No asterisk on this one.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALL, , AGNES (NEE FINNIE)
description: HALL--Agnes (nee Finnie). On June 13, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Thomas J. Devoted mother and motherin-law of Thomas and Linda Hall. Loving grandmother of Carolyn, Tom and his wife Kim, and great-grandmother of Amanda Grace. Dear sister of Isabel Finnie. Services Wednesday, 11 AM, at Grace Church, East 10th St and Broadway, NYC. Entombment Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Salvation Army or Cabrini Center for Nursing and Rehabilitation. >>AD#

title: Europe, Christians and History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIASTRO, , JOAN
description: PIASTRO--Joan, 90, June 14, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Mishel Piastro; violinist, concert master and conductor of the NY Philharmonic. Private services. For information Dapson - Chestney Funeral Home, Rhinebeck, phone (845-876-6000). >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARRAN, , WILLIAM R.
description: MARRAN--William R., of Vero Beach, FL and East Hampton, NY died on June 14th after a long and hard fought battle with Alzheimer's disease. Born in 1923 to Marcelle and Francis Marran. He received a BA from the University of Pennsylvania, Wharton Business School, Class of 1948, where he rowed for the Varsity Crew Team. Served as president of WR Marran's Sons until 1995. Bill pursued his love of rowing and the outdoors throughout his life. He was a spirited individual whose greatest enjoyment was foraging for clams, watercress and wild mushrooms and giving them away to friends and family. He was a member of the Sayville Yacht Club, the Huntington Country Club, the Devon Yacht Club and the John's Island Club. He is survived by his wife Ethel Kennedy Marran, his children Liz, Lynn, Jack, Laura, and Paul Marran, (he is predeceased by his son William R. III 1988) and by nine grandchildren. Also surviving are Bill's sister, Marjorie Feeney and his brother, John Marran. A private family burial will take place on John's Island, FL and a memorial service will be held in August in East Hampton, NY. >>AD#

title: Privileged Life in Peril For 2 Mortgage Giants
description: Until last week, most Americans familiar with Freddie Mac or Fannie Mae probably had a vague image of benevolent government agencies helping young couples get their first mortgages. But after Freddie Mac replaced its top management, it became clear from the severance pay that this was no ordinary government work. Bureaucrats do not receive $24 million golden parachutes.

title: Those Intriguing Nanotubes Create the Toughest Fibers Known
description: By lining up tubes of carbon, scientists have produced the toughest fibers known, natural or synthetic.

title: City to Miss State Deadline On Teachers
description: After three years of striving to meet a state mandate that all public-school teachers be certified by this September, New York City has concluded that it cannot meet the deadline and is seeking a two-year extension.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Maker To List Shares
description: A maker of high-end semiconductors, the NEC Electronics Corporation, will list its shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on July 24. Spun off from its parent, the NEC Corporation, last November, NEC Electronics needs to raise funds to remain competitive with competitors in the United States, Germany, Japan and South Korea. The company will seek to raise 88 billion yen ($749.7 million) to help pay for its investments in next-generation wafers. Another high-technology company, the Seiko Epson Corporation, also announced details of its planned public offering, fueling optimism that the Japanese equity market will continue to rebound from the 20-year lows hit earlier this year.

title: Court Says U.S. May Withhold Detainee Names
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  A sharply divided appeals court ruled today that the Justice Department was within its rights when it refused to release the names of more than 700 people arrested for immigration violations in connection with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: Charges Are Brought In Smuggling Deaths
description: Federal prosecutors say the organizer behind the nation's deadliest smuggling case was a 25-year-old Honduran immigrant who told a judge she spoke no English and until recently worked at Levi's. ''She's the general,'' a prosecutor said of the woman, Karla Chavez, who along with 13 others was named in a federal indictment stemming from the deaths of 19 illegal immigrants.

title: Curb Appeal: Seduction From the Ground Up
description: She ravished his eye with her sandals. Honestly, that's what the Bible says. In Bethulia, an ancient Jewish city besieged by the army of Nebuchadnezzar, a widow of bravery and beauty took it upon herself to enter the enemy camp. According to legend, the widow, Judith, entered the tent of Holofernes, the general who led the invasion, and then, aided by maidservant and some lovely footwear, she managed to lop off his head.

title: Sensualist Meets His Match
description: One of the astonishing achievements of Soviet culture was the transformation of Alexander Scriabin -- pre-revolutionary sensualist and half-mad mystic explorer -- into a worker-hero for all people. In Moscow's music conservatories, Scriabin grew biceps and affected a heavy hammer. As Scriabin the forward-looking theorist bloomed, the dripping tropical heat of his late sonatas and orchestra pieces cooled. What had swayed suggestively became tough and clear-eyed.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the views of some black religious figures and scholars on the portrayal of God by a black actor in the movie ''Bruce Almighty'' referred incompletely to the biblical phrase ''hair like lamb's wool,'' which some black ministers cite as evidence that Jesus was black. While it is found in at least one translation of the Bible (the New English Translation), it is in the Book of Daniel, which was written before Jesus was born.

title: On Writing Well (With a Consultant)
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Concern Will Halt Sales Of Artery Device Linked to Deaths
description: The Guidant Corporation said yesterday that it would stop selling a device that helps treat a weakened blood vessel in the abdomen without surgery. The news came only days after the company pleaded guilty to 10 felonies and admitted it had concealed thousands of problems linked to the product, including 12 deaths.

title: Skepticism for Pataki's Late Government-Revisions Package
description: With the legislative session set to end on Thursday, many lawmakers, lobbyists and legislative staffers, on both sides of the political aisle, reacted with skepticism today to Gov. George E. Pataki's proposals to shine light on the inner workings of government in Albany.

title: Stand Clear of the Closing Doors, or Else Buy Them
description: It is a dark and rainy day, and on a wind-swept industrial lot along the Harlem River, a serious-looking man with a briefcase and a cigarette dangling from his lips is making a transaction.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We have to get an agreement with Israel in order to get an agreement with Hamas. And we have to get an agreement with Hamas in order to get an agreement with Israel.''

title: Asia Finds Its Voice on Myanmar
description: After arresting the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in a violent attack on her supporters late last month, Myanmar's military junta has finally reaped the broad international opprobrium it has long deserved. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations yesterday broke with its dubious tradition of not criticizing member governments and urged Myanmar, formerly known as Burma, to release Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi.

title: Council to Vote on Suspending Awning Violations
description: City Council officials, responding to complaints from merchants that the city is being overly picky about their signs, said yesterday that the Council would vote on a six-month moratorium on citations to businesses that violate laws about what may appear on the awnings of their establishments.

title: Any Questions? Spurs' Popovich Had Answers
description: SAN ANTONIO, June 16 - Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich wanted to relish the moment. He wanted to go on and on about what he and his improbable band of champions had accomplished. Four measly questions were not enough.

title: Maker to Halt Sales Of a Medical Device
description: The Guidant Corporation, which admitted last week that it had concealed thousands of problems linked to one of its medical devices, including 12 deaths, said that it would stop selling the product, which helps treat a weakened blood vessel in the abdomen. But it said the 18,000 patients who have the device are safe because the problems centered on the system used to insert it, not the device itself.

title: A Festival To Make Deadheads Grateful
description: Music fans at rock festivals are, by and large, abused by sound, security, visibility, parking, aggressive advertising and ugly surroundings. But the organizers of the Bonnaroo festival -- built on jam-band rock and expanding that genre beyond recognition -- are aiming much higher.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: State Gets Nearly $24 Million For Security
description: Connecticut will receive nearly $24 million in federal grants to hire and train police officers as well as what are known as ''first responders'' to terrorism, its United States senators, Christopher J. Dodd and Joseph I. Lieberman, announced yesterday. The Department of Homeland Security awarded $21 million to the state Department of Public Safety to improve responses to terrorism. The state also received a $2.5 million grant from the Justice Department that includes hiring grants of $150,000 each for the towns of Clinton and Stratford for more law enforcement personnel. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Lincoln Center Says Orchestra Is Breaking Lease
description: Lincoln Center executives said yesterday that they told the center's directors that the New York Philharmonic's surprise proposal to move to Carnegie Hall amounted to a breach of contract.

title: How to Be the Perfect Parent (And Drown Yourself in Guilt)
description: For more than a century, millions of American parents have relied on a library of advice books written by experts on virtually every aspect of their children's health, safety and behavior.

title: 50% of Dealers Willing to Sell Handguns Illegally, Study Says
description: A study released today by researchers at U.C.L.A. says half of firearms dealers questioned in an undercover survey were willing to allow buyers to make ''straw purchases'' that could violate federal law.

title: DELTAGEN STUDIES ALTERNATIVES AFTER 2 EXECUTIVES QUIT
description: Deltagen Inc., a biotechnology company that has closed units and laid off workers in an effort to stay in business, said that it lacked funds to repay a $5 million loan, that its top two executives quit and that it might file for bankruptcy. The company, which last week said its main landlord would require lease payments after ending an accord, will explore options including alternate financing or bankruptcy, Deltagen said. Joseph M. Limber, the chief executive, and John Varian, the interim chief financial officer, resigned two months after taking the posts. They will continue as consultants, the company said. The resignations follow those on Friday of two board members Philippe Chambon and F. Noel Perry, who represented two of the three lenders of the short-term loan, which comes due July 1. Deltagen, based in Redwood City, Calif., markets tools and services designed to help pharmaceutical companies develop drugs.

title: State and Microsoft Settle
description: Microsoft agreed yesterday to pay as much as $21 million to settle a lawsuit accusing it of overcharging West Virginia consumers for its Windows operating system.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MAN DIES AFTER FLEEING THROUGH WINDOW A man died yesterday after falling from a fourth-floor apartment in Upper Manhattan that the police were investigating for drugs, the authorities said. About 4:15 p.m., an officer at 470 West 150th Street in Sugar Hill saw a man leave and re-enter an apartment that the police said was a known drug location. As the officer arrested the man, Andres Abando, 37, another man in the apartment fled through a rear window. That man, Juan Carlos Sanchez Vasquez, 30, of Manhattan, was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said they found drugs and paraphernalia at the apartment. Mr. Abando was charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Jacob's Pillow Opens With Disparate Vintages
description: The opening of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival was as distinctively relaxed yet classy as ever, with something new, old and in-between on the program on Saturday night at the Ted Shawn Theater.

title: At Last, Ready for Its Close-Up
description: Dr. Eduardo Carrillo, a cheerful, ruddy-cheeked man who could charm the eyelashes off a pit viper, has had the great fortune of seeing jaguars in the wild at least two dozen times.

title: The Evolving Peppered Moth Gains a Furry Counterpart
description: In the deserts of the Southwest, among the towering saguaros and the spiny cholla cactuses, rock pocket mice hop and dash in search of a meal of seeds. But while these mice may seem to scamper haphazardly across the desert floor, their arrangement in nature is strikingly orderly.

title: Silver Aide Takes Leave After Arrest In Rape Case
description: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver placed his counsel, J. Michael Boxley, on indefinite unpaid leave today, five days after Mr. Boxley was charged with rape.

title: Top M.L.S. Rookie Finally Breaks Through
description: ALECKO ESKANDARIAN paused for a few seconds, the static from his cellphone the only audible sound.

title: Piazza Says He Expects To Return This Season
description: Mets catcher Mike Piazza, out since May 16 with a torn groin muscle, said today that he was close to beginning the last phase of his rehabilitation -- swinging a bat and playing defense -- and that he expected to play again this season.

title: Players Scrambling After Football Is Cut
description: Jeff Gomulinski was sitting in the reception area of the football office at Fairfield University, talking about the 20 or so Division I colleges that had expressed an interest in him as a punter, when he was told he had a phone call.

title: Short Supply of Natural Gas Is Raising Economic Worries
description: The economy has been cool, and so has the spring in much of the country. Nonetheless, the United States is facing its most severe shortage of natural gas in a quarter-century.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, a picture caption on Sunday about same-sex marriages in Canada misspelled the surname of a man celebrating with his new spouse and misstated the location of the celebration. The man was Michael Leshner, not Lechner. The couple were in Toronto, not Montreal.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the jazz trombonist Jimmy Knepper yesterday omitted a survivor. He is a brother, Robert R. Knepper of Lakewood, Calif.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ameritrade Buys Accounts
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation, one of the biggest discount brokers by customer trades, said yesterday that it had bought 16,500 online accounts from Mydiscountbroker.com of Dallas for about $4.2 million. Ameritrade, which is based in Omaha, said in April that it hoped to acquire most of the 20,000 accounts of Mydiscountbroker.com, a smaller rival, which is being closed by its parent, the SWS Group, the owner of Southwest Securities. The purchase price may be adjusted after the accounts are reviewed, Ameritrade said. The company said last week that it expected to earn 9 cents to 11 cents a share in its fiscal third quarter, more than the average of 8 cents that had been forecast by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial, as customers resume buying stocks.

title: Refusing to Recant, Keating Resigns as Church Panel Chief
description: Refusing to back down from his blunt words about Roman Catholic bishops, Frank Keating, former governor of Oklahoma, resigned yesterday as chairman of the church-appointed panel that is seeking to resolve the sexual abuse scandal involving priests and minors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINGERHUT, , SARAH
description: FINGERHUT -- Sarah. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the mother of its esteemed member, Mrs. Hannah Frankel. Heartfelt sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

title: Contemporary Music From a Flexible Ensemble
description: As ensemble names go, Trio Plus Vienna seems a bit puzzling at first, like a nonmathematical equation or a name for a trendy coffee. It is parsed this way: the core of the group is a trio, but the roster expands when the programming demands other players, hence the Plus. And the three musicians - Martin Zalodek, violinist, Peter Sgaischek, violist and Nikolaus Straka, cellist - all were born and trained in Vienna, and are now members of the Vienna Philharmonic.

title: CHUBB TO SELL SHARES AND EQUITY UNITS FOR $1.2 BILLION
description: The Chubb Corporation, the property and casualty insurer based in Warren, N.J., plans to sell $1.2 billion worth of new equity, it said yesterday. Chubb will offer 13.5 million common shares and 16 million equity units for $25 each. It also expects to grant underwriters an option to purchase up to 2.025 million more shares and as many as 2.4 million additional equity units. The offering follows similar sales by other insurers, which are raising funds to replenish reserves and take advantage of a surge in prices. Chubb said it would use the funds for general corporate purposes. The company's stock price rose 5.1 percent yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday about the Father's Day plans of Sgt. Jim Dupont, a marine in Iraq, and his family back home reversed the names of two daughters in some copies. Lindsey was at the left and Susie at the right.

title: Ballet Theater Chief Quits
description: In the latest sign of management turmoil at American Ballet Theater, Elizabeth Harpel Kehler, the executive director, has resigned, the company said yesterday. She was the third person to serve in the post in the last three years.

title: Sierra Still Has Big Bat, but Not a Big Head
description: Ruben Sierra knew where he was headed, and he was not getting there through Norfolk, Atlantic City and Cancn. Sierra was certain his career was taking him to Cooperstown, and he was not shy about saying so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCGONAGLE, , HENRY J.
description: McGONAGLE--Henry J., 62, of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Died peacefully on June 15, 2003, at his home in Newburyport, MA, surrounded by wife Kathie; daughters Lisa and Dara; son-in-law Dany; beloved infant granddaughter Elia; sisters Betty and Rita; and brothers-in-law Bill and Dick. Dear friend of Matt and all who knew his wit, charm, intelligence, and above all, kindness. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, , IRENE
description: SHAPIRO--Irene. On June 15, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Devoted mother of Dani Shapiro and mother-inlaw of Michael Maren. Dear sister of Dr. Morton Rosenberg and the late Rosalyn Copleman. Cherished grandmother of Jacob Maren. Services Tuesday, 11:15AM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. For Shiva information, contact Michael@netnomad.com. >>AD#

title: Sharon Vows to 'Hound' Hamas, Which Rejects a Cease-Fire Bid
description: In a speech to Israel's Parliament, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon warned today that Middle East diplomacy would stall if ''terror runs rampant,'' and he pledged to ''hound the terrorists'' until Palestinian security forces cracked down on them.

title: Iran Is Urged To Sign Pact Giving Power To Inspectors
description: With Iran facing growing pressure to be more forthcoming about its nuclear program, the United Nations top nuclear weapons inspector, the Russian foreign minister and a group of European Union ministers today urged it to sign a protocol that would give inspectors the right to conduct more intrusive examinations of its facilities.

title: Any More Questions? Spurs Had the Answers
description: Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich wanted to relish the moment. He wanted to go on and on about what he and his improbable band of champions had accomplished. Four measly questions were not enough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETRIE, , ELIZABETH M.
description: PETRIE--Elizabeth M. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of our dear friend, Elizabeth M. Petrie. Elizabeth served on the Whitney Museum Board of Trustees from 1981 through 1991. During her tenure, she provided the Museum with much guidance and insight through her leadership of the Building Committee and membership in the Executive and Leadership Gifts Committees, among others. Her generosity to and support of the Whitney Museum, especially the Library Fellows, made her a well respected and beloved member of our Whitney Family, and she will be deeply missed. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to her children, Janet Hallstrom Scurria and Theodore A. Hallstrom II, and her entire family. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Robert J. Hurst, President Maxwell L. Anderson, Director Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman >>AD#

title: In Speech, Bush Reiterates Threat Hussein Posed, but Makes No Mention of Weapons Search
description: President Bush today swept aside criticism that the United States overstated the threat posed by Iraq as the work of ''revisionist historians'' and said there was no doubt that Saddam Hussein had been ''a threat to the United States'' for the past dozen years.

title: Debate Starts on Medicare And Coverage for Drugs
description: The Senate today began what all sides hailed as a historic debate on legislation to add prescription drug benefits to Medicare. Liberals and conservatives immediately signaled that they would seek changes in the bill and file more than 100 amendments.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Friday about a State Supreme Court justice's order that Donald J. Trump sell his 50 percent share of the General Motors Building misspelled the justice's surname. She is Karla Moskowitz, not Moscowitz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEONARD, , MICHAEL G.
description: LEONARD--Michael G. Of Huntington and recently of North Palm Beach, FL. On June 15, 2003. Loving husband of Elisabeth. Beloved father of Elisabeth, Mary, and Margaret. Cherished son of Peter and the late Margaret. Dear brother of Lorraine Fusaro, Kathleen, Marilyn Liguori and Peter, and Michelle Cuddeback. Adored uncle of many. Visitation Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9PM at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave, Huntington Sta. Mass Thursday 9:45 at St. Patrick's R.C. Church. In lieu of flowers, Michael Leonard Memorial Trust, Po Box 2318, Radio City Sta, NY, NY, 10101-2318 will be appreciated by the family. >>AD#

title: Clothing Chain Accused of Discrimination
description: Abercrombie & Fitch, the clothing retailer that appeals to the college set with blond-haired, blue-eyed models, was sued yesterday for racial discrimination, accused of favoring whites for its sales floor jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WECHSLER, , ROBERT
description: WECHSLER--Robert. The Board of Directors and members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Robert Wechsler, whose many years of friendship, kindness and enthusiastic spirit will always be remembered. Our deepest sympathies to Doris and the entire family. Beth Z. Post, President Roger H. Tulcin, Secretary >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TARRY, , ALICE
description: TARRY--Alice, Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to her family. Services today, 12:45 PM at the ''The Riverside'', 76th St & Amsterdam Ave Peter Neustadter, Parnas >>AD#

title: Not Winning Puts Woods's Achievements in Perspective
description: Shortly after winning the United States Open, Jim Furyk was holding the trophy. His wife, Tabitha, was holding their daughter, Caleigh Lynn. And Furyk was having trouble holding back tears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCDEVITT, , CAROL LEE (NEE GARDNER)
description: McDEVITT--Carol Lee (nee Gardner), 59, of Glens Falls, NY. On June 16, 2003, after a courageous and valiant battle with a brain tumor. Beloved wife of Peter V. McDevitt, devoted, loving and much-loved mother of Heather K. McDevitt of Manhattan and P. Brent McDevitt of Lake George, NY. Cherished aunt, sister, friend and confidante. Our lives will never be the same without her love, dignity and tenacity. Calling hours will be June 18, 4-8 PM, at Singleton-Healy Funeral Home, 407 Bay Road, Queensbury, NY. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on June 19, at St. Mary's Church, Glens Falls, NY. Burial will follow in Evergreen Cemetery, Lake George, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to High Peaks Hospice, 286 Glen Street, Glens Falls, NY 12801. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMS, , ADELAIDE B.
description: ADAMS--Adelaide B. 93, of New York City, and formerly of Wilton, CT, died peacefully on June 13th after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Daniel P. Adams, and sister of the late Marjorie P. Starr. Cherished mother of Nancy Adams Downey and Marjorie Adams Cooke. Devoted mother-in-law of Robert N. Downey and Caswell Cooke. Loving grandmother of Anne, Nathan, Daniel Jackson and Elizabeth, and four great-grandchildren. A lifelong New Yorker, attended The Brearley School and Vassar College. As Chair of the Research Committee for The Daughters of the Cincinnati's 1978 publication, ''A Salute To Courage,'' she traveled around the country, researching in libraries, private papers, historical societies and universities for almost 12 years to help create a collection of the American Revolutionary War experiences of all the officers on The Daughters of the Cincinnati's roster. Also a member of The Holland Dames, The National Society of the Colonial Dames of America in New York, and the Huguenot Society. A Memorial Service at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, (73rd St), will be at 11 AM, on Tuesday, June 17th. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The Scholarship Fund of the Daughters of the Cincinnati, 122 E. 58th St. NY, NY 10022, or Amnesty International, 322 8th Avenue, NY, NY 10001. >>AD#

title: Singing All About Love, Even When It Hurts
description: Joan Armatrading

title: Lowest-Rated Finals Since '81
description: ABC, in the first year of a $2.4 billion contract to televise the National Basketball Association, drew the lowest ratings for the championship series since games were shown on tape delay more than two decades ago.

title: Hong Kong And China To Sign Pact Easing Trade
description: Top officials from mainland China and Hong Kong will sign a free trade agreement on June 30 that will eliminate all tariffs on many goods and remove restrictions on trade in many services, Hong Kong's leader announced this evening.

title: Latest Restatement for Tyco Shifts $528 Million in Costs
description: Tyco International, one of the world's largest makers of burglar alarms and industrial valves, said yesterday that it would restate financial reports dating back to its 1998 fiscal year by moving $528 million in costs to earlier periods.

title: Beyond Cute: Exotic Pets Come Bearing Exotic Germs
description: Epidemiologists can be such killjoys. Consider, for instance, Dr. Michael T. Osterholm, who has been publicly denouncing prairie dogs since 1997. A prairie dog in a burrow is one thing, but a prairie dog in the house makes Dr. Osterholm a bit edgy.

title: Knicks Set At Guard, Right? Maybe Not.
description: The Knicks spent this afternoon working out another center who stands nearly seven and a half feet tall, Slavko Vranes, not an unexpected move for a team with an undersized front line. But what might have been a surprise were the players who worked out for the Knicks in the morning.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Ban on Corporate Contributions Is Upheld
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the longstanding ban on direct corporate contributions to candidates in federal elections, refusing by a vote of 7 to 2 to create an exception permitting unlimited contributions by corporations organized for the purpose of ideological advocacy.

title: Woman Accused of Leading Smuggling in Which 19 Died
description: Federal prosecutors said today that the ringleader of the nation's deadliest smuggling case was a 25-year-old Honduran immigrant, who told a judge here that she spoke no English and had until recently worked at Levi's.

title: Cheers To Jeers
description: I came to Iraq to see if I could help the coalition forces find those pesky weapons of mass destruction. It would make a great column if I could bring back my own nuke.

Funeral services Tuesday 12:30 P.M. at ''Gutterman's'' 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. >>AD#

description: LEVY--Ludwig, on June 14, 2003. Holocaust survivor. Beloved husband of Hanna, dear brother-in-law of Auguste Hamburger, loving uncle of Miriam Mason, Hanna Hamburger and Debra Beins. Services Tuesday, 11:30am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, a picture caption on Sunday about same-sex marriages in Canada misspelled the surname of a man celebrating with his new spouse and misstated the location of the celebration. The man was Michael Leshner, not Lechner. The couple were in Toronto, not Montreal.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Warrant For Marine In Rape Case
description: The police obtained an arrest warrant for a United States Marine accused of raping a 19-year-old woman on the island of Okinawa. The attack, on May 25, prompted Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to call for tighter discipline among the 47,000 American troops based in Japan. The suspect, who is in military custody, is Lance Cpl. Jose W. Torres, 21. His hometown was withheld. In 1995, a rape of a schoolgirl by three American soldiers created an uproar and fueled calls for the withdrawal of United States troops. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: Prominent Programmer Will Leave Transmeta
description: Linus Torvalds, the Finnish programmer and leader of the shared software movement, is leaving his job with Transmeta, a struggling Silicon Valley chip maker, and taking a position with a consortium developing the Linux operating system for corporations.

title: No Vision, but Better Memory
description: People blind from birth are often able to develop superior abilities at using other senses, like hearing. But a study released yesterday finds that they are also able to enlist parts of the brain usually devoted to vision to bolster their memory, even on tasks that involve no sensory input.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Chile: Mine Project
description: BHP Billiton and the Rio Tinto Group agreed to a $400 million expansion of the Escondida project in Chile, seeking to maintain production levels at the mine. The project, about three miles from the existing mine in the northern desert, will provide higher-grade ores from an open pit. They will be processed at existing plants. It is expected to start producing ore in the fourth quarter of 2005, and has 17 years of reserves.

title: MEMO PAD
description: Airlines Installing In-Flight E-Mail

title: A Trombonist in Conversation With Jazz
description: As of 9 p.m. on June 10 , the Cuban pianist Chucho Valdes, who was scheduled to play the Village Vanguard through June 15, Sunday, still hadn't arrived in the country. This is seemingly almost the norm with the great Latin jazz musician. The State Department has been increasingly scrutinizing visa requests since the Sept. 11 attacks, and Mr. Valdes had to cancel an American tour last fall because he couldn't get a visa in time. Luckily, the musician who was to be a guest for the week, Wycliffe Gordon, a fifth wheel on Mr. Valdes' quartet, was able to fill in with his own band.

title: Market Place; PeopleSoft Revises Offer For Rival as It Battles Oracle
description: Trying to fend off a hostile takeover from Oracle in the increasingly bitter battle to build a powerhouse American supplier of business software, PeopleSoft revised its all-stock offer today to acquire a smaller competitor, J. D. Edwards, by including a big chunk of cash in the deal.

title: Crime Stayed Flat in 2002, F.B.I. Study Finds
description: Crime in the United States remained relatively unchanged in 2002, dropping by a mere two-tenths of 1 percent, a report released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation shows.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Dies After Fleeing Through Window
description: A man died yesterday after falling from a fourth-floor apartment in Upper Manhattan that the police were investigating for drugs, the authorities said. About 4:15 p.m., an officer at 470 West 150th Street in Sugar Hill saw a man leave and re-enter an apartment that the police said was a known drug location. As the officer arrested the man, Andres Abando, 37, another man in the apartment fled through a rear window. That man, Juan Carlos Sanchez Vasquez, 30, of Manhattan, was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said they found drugs and paraphernalia at the apartment. Mr. Abando was charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: 3 Lawyers For Stewart May Be Called As Witnesses
description: Three lawyers who advised Martha Stewart in the early days of the government's investigation into her stock trading may be called to testify in her trial, a person involved in the case said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Parents Of Truants May Face Jail
description: Gov. Bill Richardson's new truancy program could include jail time for parents. Initially, parents would participate in counseling, but if the truancy persists, they would face legal punishment. The governor cited success with similar truancy programs in a handful of New Mexico school districts. The program will be paid for with $1 million from federal tax cut legislation. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: I goofed. In my last column, I referred to comments by Condoleezza Rice on a Sunday television show but misstated the show. It was ''This Week with George Stephanopoulos.'' Mea culpa.

description: To the Editor:

title: Old Rivals in Court, With Nary a Cross Word
description: Given their long and lively history of animosity, it would not have taken much imagination to envision either of New York's two senators, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer, in federal court with one of their predecessors, Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERNBACH, , PAUL
description: BERNBACH -- Paul. The Trustees and staff of the Brooklyn Museum of Art record with deep sorrow the death of esteemed Trustee Paul Bernbach, and extend deepest sympathies to Therese, Elizabeth, Sarah, Matthew, and to all the Bernbach family and friends. title: SARS Advisory Against Traveling to Taiwan Is Lifted
description: HONG KONG, June 17  The World Health Organization lifted its advisory today against all but essential travel to Taiwan, leaving Beijing as the only place that the agency is telling travelers to avoid because of the risk of SARS.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: M.T.A. Security Chief Named
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that William A. Morange had been appointed as the agency's director of security. He replaces Louis R. Anemone, who was dismissed in May after he accused the agency of corruption and of thwarting investigations. Mr. Morange currently works for the New York City Police Department as the bureau chief for organized crime control. He has also served as the department's chief of patrol, overseeing uniformed officers. An advisory board, which included the former police officials Joseph P. Dunne and Patrick E. Kelleher, recommended hiring Mr. Morange. He is scheduled to start next month. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: CELL THERAPEUTICS ANNOUNCES PLAN TO BUY NOVUSPHARMA
description: Cell Therapeutics, a Seattle biotechnology company, said yesterday that it planned to acquire Novuspharma, a publicly traded Italian company, for about $235 million in stock. It would gain a cancer drug that is in the final stages of clinical trials. Novuspharma's leading drug, Pixantrone, which is being tested for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, may have fewer side effects than other chemotherapy drugs in the class known as anthracyclines, Cell Therapeutics said. James A. Bianco, chief executive of Cell Therapeutics, said Pixantrone might reach the market by 2005 or 2006 and complement his company's Trisenox, which is on the market, and Xyotax, the company's experimental treatment for lung cancer. Separately, Cell Therapeutics said that federal regulators would speed their review of Xyotax. The company said in a statement the drug received fast-track status from the Food and Drug Administration. Xyotax is being tested in two late-stage, or Phase III, clinical trials for patients with advanced non-small-cell lung cancer, which accounts for almost 80 percent of lung cancer cases. The company's shares rose $1.73, or 13 percent, to $14.75. Andrew Pollack (NYT)

title: Judge Tells Tax Adviser To Stop Selling Book
description: A federal judge ordered a Las Vegas tax adviser yesterday to stop selling a book that contends income taxes are voluntary and that people can lawfully escape them by filing tax returns listing no income. A civil liberties group said it thought the ruling improperly censors the book.

title: For Lonely Travelers, TV Is Companion Away
description: There is a dirty little secret harbored by many business travelers, and it has nothing to do with abusing their expense accounts or with romantic interludes on the road.

title: U.S., Afghan and Pakistan Generals Study Border Incursions
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Jun.17  Senior American, Afghan and Pakistani generals met today in the Pakistani capital, Islamabad, in the first meeting of a new tripartite commission that represents the first real effort to tackle the problems of crossborder incursions by the Taliban and other militants based in Pakistan.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Radioactive Material Found In Taxi
description: The police have found a large quantity of radioactive material that could be used in making a ''dirty bomb,'' officials said. They said they believed the material, about 170 pounds of cesium 137 and strontium 90, was discovered in a taxi in the capital, Tbilisi, on May 31. The authorities said a quantity of an unspecified poisonous gas was also found. It is suspected that the material was bound for Turkey, where it was to be resold. Officials did not say why they had waited more than two weeks to disclose the seizure. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Pennsauken: Shooting Suspect In Custody
description: A New Jersey man accused of shooting two people on Sunday, including his former girlfriend, turned himself in to the authorities yesterday. The police said the man, Robert Baker, accidentally shot himself in the forearm during the shooting and later sought medical attention. The police were notified that Mr. Baker was at a Plainfield hospital early yesterday morning, said the Pennsauken police chief, John J. Coffey. Mr. Baker was charged with two counts of attempted murder. Mr. Baker, 28, is accused of breaking into his former girlfriend's apartment in Pennsauken and shooting her and a male friend several times. The woman, Karyne Simms, and her friend, Jamar Ward, were listed in stable condition at Cooper Hospital University Medical Center yesterday. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: A Fascination With Forests Finds Fulfillment at Smithsonian
description: As a boy, Cristin Samper rambled through the tropical forests of his native Colombia, marveling at the diversity that surrounded him. Not content to view the flora and fauna only in the abstract, he began what was to become a lifelong obsession and vocation, cataloging the diversity and assembling it into collections that forcefully argue for its preservation.

title: Trading Briefcases For Baby Strollers
description: To the Editor:

title: ZIMMER WILL MAKE FORMAL OFFER TO BUY IMPLANT MAKER
description: Zimmer Holdings Inc., which was spun off from the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company in 2001, said yesterday that it would make a formal offer on Thursday to buy a rival medical-implant maker, Centerpulse of Switzerland, for about $3.1 billion in cash and stock. The offer of 120 Swiss francs ($92) in cash and 3.68 Zimmer shares for each share of Centerpulse was first announced last month, said Ruth Pachman, a Zimmer spokeswoman. Zimmer's offer surpassed the $2.46 billion bid made in March by Smith & Nephew, a British competitor.

title: 2 Former Cabinet Members Say Britain Exaggerated Iraq Claims
description: LONDON, June 17  Robin Cook and Clare Short, the two members of Prime Minister Tony Blair's cabinet who resigned their posts over Iraq, told a House of Commons committee today that Britain made selective use of intelligence to make the case for weapons of mass destruction and justify going to war.

title: In Stores, Private Handcuffs for Sticky Fingers
description: Steps from the pantyhose section of Macy's Manhattan store sits a cool, halogen-lighted room containing two chain-link holding cells. People, some of them minors, are led to this room every day, where they are body-searched, photographed and then handcuffed to a long steel bench.

title: Making a Lost Style Speak to Today's Ears
description: Mordecai Shehori, pianist

title: Of Books, A Disaster And Renewal
description: THE literary spirit was strong yesterday, it being Bloomsday, so it seemed right to spend some time in a bookstore. The place of choice was Coliseum Books (b. 1974, d. 2002, re-b. 2003, on West 42nd Street). More on that later.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Network Start-Up Ships Product
description: Aruba Wireless Network, a start-up company in San Jose, Calif., said yesterday that it had begun shipping its technology, which is used by corporations to build wireless data networks. Aruba joins a growing number of companies seeking to build such networks while minimizing security concerns; if networks are not properly protected, they can be breached by competitors or hackers. Aruba's technology includes a firewall for every user that is set up to prevent intrusion into the system at different access points. The company is backed by Sequoia Capital Partners and Matrix Partners, which led an initial $10 million round of venture capital investment. Pankaj Manglik, the company's founder and chief executive, said Aruba was about to close a second round of financing for about $20 million. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Cavendish Journal; Annes of Japan Come Dreaming of Green Gables
description: It's a long way from home, but this bucolic island of gingerbread cottages and rolling green hills is where generations of Japanese girls have dreamed of getting married, or of simply visiting before they die.

title: Duke of Bedford Is Dead at 63; Ran Family's Woburn Estates
description: Henry Robin Ian Russell, the 14th Duke of Bedford, a diffident British aristocrat who despite ill health combined a lucrative business career in London with successful management of his enormous family seat at Woburn Abbey in Bedfordshire, died on Friday in London. He was 63.

title: Report Finds No Wrongdoing In Search for Texas Lawmakers
description: An internal investigation at the Department of Homeland Security has found no evidence that the department did anything wrong when it agreed to assist in the search for a group of Texas Democratic lawmakers who had fled the state in a partisan dispute, according to a report made public today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the sentencing of Samuel D. Waksal, founder and former chief executive of ImClone Systems, included one person erroneously among the onlookers in the courtroom. His daughter Aliza was not present, a spokesman for Dr. Waksal said.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Reverse Split For Priceline
description: Priceline.com, a seller of discount travel services, has done a 1-for-6 reverse stock split to make the company's shares more attractive to mutual funds and other investors. The action was effective yesterday morning, shrinking the number of shares outstanding to about 37.5 million from 227 million, Priceline.com said. The company, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., updated its second-quarter profit forecast to 12 cents to 18 cents a share to reflect the reverse split. Priceline.com executives met last week to determine the ratio after shareholders approved a proposal for a 1-for-6 to 1-for-9 reverse split.

title: Gingrich Assails State Department and Calls for Overhaul
description: WASHINGTON, June 17  Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House of Representatives, stepped up his criticism of the State Department today, calling for a sweeping overhaul of the department to enable it to explain Washington's policies more effectively in a world of rising anti-American feelings.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Bank Executive Named
description: An Italian bank, Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, promoted Mario Girotti to general manager after the resignation of its chief executive, Davide Croff, on Friday. Mr. Croff stepped down after disagreements with other executives about the need to find a merger partner. His post will not be filled because the bank, based in Rome, cannot have both a chief executive and a general manager, the chairman, Luigi Abete, said at a news conference in Rome, citing the bank's bylaws. Mr. Girotti had been head of commercial banking.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CHAPIN, , ELIZABETH STEINWAY
description: CHAPIN--Elizabeth Steinway. It's been a long decade since you left us. Simeon and Willa have been out of college for four years; Anika now a Junior at Vassar; Zoe off to Connecticut College; Megan bound for Bucknell; Anna, Tess and Moses happy in their schools. In the words of the wonderful old expression: ''No one ever dies who lives in hearts left behind...'' Schuyler, Henry, Ted, Sam and Miles >>AD#

title: North Korea Faces Growing Pressure on Nuclear Weapons
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 17  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States had lined up broad support to pressure North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program, but an American initiative to interdict shipments of nuclear materials brought a new threat of retaliation from the Pyongyang government.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: 2 Held After Bomb Is Found
description: The police were holding two men in connection with a 1,200-pound bomb that was found in an abandoned van at a bridge in Londonderry on Sunday and defused by British Army officers. The explosives were ready for detonation, officials said. Security officials said dissident republican guerrillas, who oppose the Irish Republican Army's cease-fire and participation in peace talks, were to blame. Brian Lavery (NYT)

description: BELLER--Fannie. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft President

title: There's Lots of Blame to Share on the Nets
description: The fluttering confetti fell like taunts on the Nets' hanging heads as they witnessed another championship celebration that was not for them. Crushed by the Spurs' 88-77 triumph Sunday in Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals, some Nets walked disgustedly off the SBC Center court into an uncertain future.

title: Company Escalates Fight With I.B.M. By Revoking License to Key Software
description: In an escalating legal battle, the SCO Group announced yesterday that it was revoking I.B.M.'s license for software essential to a multibillion-dollar business and that it had asked a federal court to block that business permanently.

title: Lehman Aided in Loan Fraud, Jury Says
description: A federal jury in California concluded late yesterday that Lehman Brothers knowingly assisted in fraudulent activities by providing financial backing to an aggressive home equity lender, the First Alliance Corporation, despite warnings about its questionable business practices.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: CHIP MAKER TO LIST SHARES A maker of high-end semiconductors, the NEC Electronics Corporation, will list its shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on July 24. Spun off from its parent, the NEC Corporation, last November, NEC Electronics needs to raise funds to remain competitive with competitors in the United States, Germany, Japan and South Korea. The company will seek to raise 88 billion yen ($749.7 million) to help pay for its investments in next-generation wafers. Another high-technology company, the Seiko Epson Corporation, also announced details of its planned public offering, fueling optimism that the Japanese equity market will continue to rebound from the 20-year lows hit earlier this year.

title: A Trio of Good Rulings
description: The Supreme Court came down strongly on the side of campaign finance reform yesterday, upholding a ban on contributions from advocacy groups. The decision, one of several handed down yesterday, affirmed the government's considerable interest in minimizing corruption in politics. We hope it is a harbinger of how the court will view a challenge to the McCain-Feingold law later this year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Many Applying For Parent Coordinator
description: The Department of Education expects to get 8,000 applicants for 1,200 newly created positions as parent coordinators in city schools, based on the number of applications completed on the department's Web site and submitted in person, Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday. The coordinators will act as liaisons between parents and principals at each of the city's 1,200 schools, and will earn $30,000 to $39,000 annually. An additional 555 people applied to work as one of 10 regional coordinators, who will supervise the coordinators in the schools within the new regions. The regional coordinators will be paid $75,000 to $85,000 annually. The plan is expected to cost $43 million, and hirings will be announced by June 26, officials said. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Asylum Seekers Suffer Psychological Setbacks, Study Finds
description: A study of inmates in the nation's immigration detention centers has found rising levels of depression and post-traumatic stress among victims of torture or persecution who are seeking political asylum in the United States.

description: Fashion's Pet Charity

title: Hitler's Further Thoughts, in a New English Translation
description: In late June and early July 1928, Hitler dictated a sequel to ''Mein Kampf.'' It was taken down by Max Amann, the director of the Nazi party's publishing company.

title: JUSTICES RESTRICT FORCED MEDICATION PRECEDING A TRIAL
description: The Supreme Court placed strict limits today on the government's ability to medicate mentally ill defendants forcibly to make them competent to stand trial.

description: In percent

title: The Beatles' Producer, Still With Stories to Tell; George Martin Has Found Life After the Studio, and Time for Another Autobiography
description: By 1998 there were few record producers more famous than Sir George Martin. His imagination, openness to experimentation and deftness as an arranger had helped transform the Beatles from an energetic regional dance band into one of the most creative ensembles in popular music. But at 72 he was complaining that his hearing had so throughly deteriorated that he could no longer work behind a mixing board. So he announced his retirement that year, and after a final project -- ''In My Life,'' a compilation of Beatles songs performed by other musicians and a few actors -- he packed away his microphones.

title: When Forever Is Far Too Long
description: Wilbert Rideau's rsum reads like this: named ''Person of the Week'' by ABC News; called ''the most rehabilitated prisoner in America'' by Life magazine; co-directed documentary film nominated for an Academy Award; given the George Polk Award, one of the highest honors in journalism. Mr. Rideau is 61. Guilty of a brutal killing committed in the aftermath of a hapless bank robbery, he has served 42 years for that crime. Unless a current legal fight -- a revealing and truth-distorting struggle -- turns his way, he will stay locked up until he dies.

title: Europe and U.S. Will Share Research on Hydrogen Fuel
description: The European Union and the United States agreed today to pool their research efforts into hydrogen fuel cells, despite their widely differing views on what the technology will mean for energy policy.

title: Mayor Suggests Federal Tax Act of His Own
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has gone out of his way to be diplomatic when it comes to his fellow Republicans in Washington, took a measured shot yesterday at one of the most powerful: Tom DeLay, the House majority leader.

title: Ulster Protestant Leader Defeats Challenger
description: David Trimble, Northern Ireland's most prominent Protestant politician, survived a challenge to his leadership of the Ulster Unionists tonight, but the vote left his party divided over whether to take part fully in the province's peace effort.

title: Faith in the Bishops Put to the Fire
description: At a critical turn in the crisis over the sexual abuse of children by rogue priests, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops tried to show their commitment to reform last year by naming a review board of prominent laypeople led by former Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma. A devout Catholic and experienced criminal prosecutor, Mr. Keating was hailed as a dynamic, no-nonsense choice dedicated to holding the bishops accountable in their promises of transparency and rectitude. But since Mr. Keating took on that role a year ago, his frustration grew in the face of determined resistance from some key bishops stonewalling from behind batteries of lawyers as the review board sought a detailed accounting of the hierarchy's handling of the problem.

title: Kmart Says Its Loss Narrowed in Quarter
description: The Kmart Holding Corporation said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter loss narrowed because of lower costs after exiting bankruptcy court protection last month.

title: Public School Confidential
description: It has been a year since New Yorkers lent their support to one of the most sweeping changes in the history of the city's public schools. The often contentious political leadership in the city and state reached bipartisan consensus to eliminate the Board of Education, giving Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg what his predecessors coveted but never got: a school system under the city's direct control. It was a hard-fought and stunning victory. But if reaction to the announcement last Thursday to change the school week is any indicator, the difficult part is only beginning.

title: Relief From an Herbal Compound
description: A Chinese herbal compound, gastrodine, used for centuries to treat dizziness and headaches, may help alleviate mild dementia in stroke victims, data from a preliminary study suggest.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Growth In Thailand
description: Thailand's economy grew 6.7 percent in the first quarter compared with the quarter a year ago, as fiscal stimulus, consumer spending and stronger exports offset the effects of SARS and the war in Iraq. The stronger first-quarter showing, the fastest rate in at least three years, prompted the government to raise its forecast for growth this year by half a percentage point to as high as 5.5 percent. Compared with the fourth quarter of 2002, the economy grew 1.5 percent, down from a 2.1 percent growth rate in the fourth quarter. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Road to Majors Begins at Coney Island
description: At this time last year, Shawn Bowman was a 17-year-old third baseman with the Canadian junior national team, playing in front of small crowds in a rundown ballpark in Quebec. Now, Bowman, the 12th-round pick of the Mets in the 2002 draft, is preparing for his first season of professional ball with the Brooklyn Cyclones, reporting for work 16 miles from Shea Stadium, where he hopes to play someday.

title: Medgar Evers Remembered In Ceremony At Gravesite
description: Family members and admirers of the civil rights leader Medgar Evers gathered today at his gravesite at Arlington National Cemetery to commemorate the 40th anniversary of his burial.

title: A Murderous Group

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: TELECOM SHARES SOLD The Dutch telecommuni- cations giant Royal KPN said that it had begun to sell its 6.48 percent stake in the Czech telephone company Cesky Telecom, reducing its stake to the 27 percent it owns jointly with the Swiss telecommunications operator Swisscom . The sale should raise about $220 million for Royal KPN, which was hurt by overspending for mobile telephone licenses and a German mobile telephone operator. The move set off a 6 percent decline in Cesky's shares. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Two Executives Leave Euro RSCG Worldwide
description: The two senior executives responsible for new-business prospecting at units of Euro RSCG Worldwide in New York have left after only six months in their posts.

title: A Strong Push
description: The stock market continues its push into positive returns with technology stocks generally higher than they were last summer. Page C8.

title: Tuesday's Child? Doesn't Matter
description: Is it more dangerous to give birth on a weekend, when hospitals are less than fully staffed? The answer from a study released last week was no: while infant mortality rates do appear to be slightly higher on weekends, it is not because of any drop in the quality of care.

title: INSIDE
description: Phoenix Bishop Arrested

title: Most Corporate Ethics Officials Are Critical of Top Officers' Pay
description: Most corporate executives responsible for setting ethical standards say that the pay of their companies' senior executives is ''out of control,'' according to a survey conducted for the Conference Board and scheduled for release today.

title: United to Offer E-Mail Access on North American Flights
description: LE BOURGET, France, June 17  United Airlines said today that it would install e-mail service on its entire North American fleet using a system developed by Tenzing Communications, a small technology company based in Seattle.

title: Chairman Resigns At Tierney DeGregorio
description: Tony DeGregorio has resigned as chairman and chief creative officer at Tierney DeGregorio Advertising in Philadelphia after two years in the post, the agency said yesterday.

title: TALES OF DESPAIR FROM GUANTNAMO
description: Afghans and Pakistanis who were detained for many months by the American military at Guantnamo Bay in Cuba before being released without charges are describing the conditions as so desperate that some captives tried to kill themselves.

title: Three Strong Voices, Locked in Sequence
description: The word "Sequenza" can mean sequence, or it can denote the piano trio made up of soloists who gave sequential solo concerts at Bargemusic in Manhattan this month, and ended the sequence with a joint concert there on June 8.

title: Damages Are Due, Appeals Court Says
description: Saying that Haverhill Golf and Country Club had been ''cavalier and callously indifferent about failing to treat women golfers as equals,'' a Massachusetts appeals court has let stand a $1.9 million damage award against the club.

title: French Police in Crackdown on Iranian Opposition Group
description: PARIS, June 17  French authorities today arrested more than 150 members of a long-established armed Iranian opposition group, accused them of organizing terrorist acts, and seized $1.3 million in hundred-dollar bills.

title: Attorney General Is Confirmed After Months of Bitter Feuding
description: After months of bitter partisan feuding and charges that the state attorney general's office had engaged in political intimidation, the State Senate today confirmed Peter C. Harvey as attorney general. He is the first black to hold the office.

title: 13 People Are Slain In Violent Weekend
description: The police said yesterday that 13 people were killed in unrelated cases over about 48 hours in an unusually violent weekend in New York City. The killings came as an annual crime report by the Federal Bureau of Investigation released yesterday showed that the murder rate in the city fell 9.1 percent last year.

title: Lottery Numbers
Behind the Wheel With Freedom at the Fingertips
description: Not long ago, I made a decision that up until that time was unthinkable: give up driving a car the traditional way. Multiple sclerosis has numbed my feet to the point where I can no longer tell without looking whether they are on the pedals, and my hip flexors are so weakened that naturally lifting my leg from gas to brake and back again is impossible.
