description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Sale Opposed
description: About 7,000 workers at Chohung Bank threatened to strike to protest a government plan to sell its shares in the bank to the Shinhan Financial Group. The government acquired 80 percent of the shares in the bank during the 1997-98 financial crisis. Kim Jin Pyo, the South Korean finance minister, said the sale of Chohung would not be delayed and the decision would not be affected by union objections. Workers fear job losses if Shinhan, the fourth-largest bank, takes over Chohung, the fifth-largest and South Korea's oldest financial institution. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Emirates Airline to Buy 41 Airbus Planes
description: Emirates Airline signed a deal today at the Paris Air Show to buy 41 new planes from Airbus Industrie, including 21 A380's, the new 500-to-650 seat behemoth that the European consortium is now building. The order is valued at $12.5 billion, making it one of the largest civil aircraft orders ever placed.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Skipping the Niches, Going for Pop
description: There are two types of pop music. The first is simply the ever-changing, ineluctable tissue of songs that are popular. The second is music that aspires to the classic sound of a previous era's pop band, be it the Beatles, the Beach Boys or even the Spice Girls. It is possible to be too pop to be popular, especially since this decade's best-selling genres are niches like rap and country.

title: Rent Laws Extended Again, in Albany Standoff
description: New York's expiring rent laws were extended for another day today after Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders were unable to resolve their differences over an issue that affects more than a million New York City apartments.

title: Blalock's Batting Hasn't Been Average
description: Texas Rangers Manager Buck Showalter grimaced, as if he were hit in the back with a fastball. A reporter asked Hank Blalock, the Rangers' third baseman, how he could go from hitting .200 and being demoted to Class AAA last season to being among the American League batting leaders this year?

title: A Celebrity School's Students Say Oil Wells Are Making Them Sick
description: Dappled with flower-power colors and set against a backdrop of Century City skyscrapers, the oil derrick rising high above the campus of Beverly Hills High School is more than just a quirky landmark.

title: Harold Ashby, 78, Saxophonist With Ellington Band
description: Harold Ashby, a saxophonist whose long association with Duke Ellington began before he joined Ellington's orchestra and continued after Ellington's death, died on Friday at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: G.O.P. Seeks Budget Cuts To Limit New Jersey Taxes
description: A week before the New Jersey State Senate's last scheduled voting session of the fiscal year, Republican senators today announced their answer to Gov. James E. McGreevey's proposed budget.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose against the euro after a report showed New York manufacturing expanded more than economists forecast this month. In New York, the euro settled at $1.1835, down from $1.1859 on Friday.

title: New York State Manufacturing Is Unusually Brisk
description: Manufacturing in New York State expanded more than expected this month as orders and sales increased the most since January, a Federal Reserve bank branch reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EISENSTEIN, , ENID ROSALINDE
description: EISENSTEIN--Enid Rosalinde June 17th, 1953-May 12th, 1977 Beloved daughter: Without you No rose can grow No leaf be green if never seen Your sweetest face No bird have grace Or pow'r to sing Or anything Be kind or fair And you nowhere Rebe Eisenstein, Loving Family and Friend

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: WebMD Acquisition
description: The WebMD Corporation, which runs medical information Web sites, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the billing services provider Advanced Business Fulfillment for at least $110 million in cash. The agreement includes another $150 million in payments over three years, starting in April 2004, if certain financial targets are met, WebMD said. Those payments will be in stock, options or cash. WebMD is based in Elmwood Park, N.J. Advanced Business Fulfillment, a closely held company based in St. Louis, had $63 million in sales last year. The company helps small health plan administrators print checks and benefit-coverage information and offers advice on payments, said Jennifer Meyer, a WebMD spokeswoman. The company expects to complete the purchase in the third quarter. WebMD shares rose 37 cents to $11.39 in trading on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Rights Body Approved
description: Parliament unanimously approved a law to set up a National Council for Human Rights, and the speaker, Ahmed Fathi Sorour, told the state-run Middle East News Agency that the new law would ''spread the culture of human rights.'' But some rights activists have raised doubts about the government's seriousness. Last week, security officials rejected the registrations of two rights groups, the Land Center for Human Rights, which defends peasants rights, and the New Woman Research Center, which focuses on women's issues. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Statement On Immigrants Denied
description: Umberto Bossi, a government minister, said a newspaper had misconstrued his statements in an interview in which he was quoted as saying that the navy should fire on boats carrying illegal immigrants to Italy. According to the interview, Mr. Bossi said illegal immigrants should hear the blast of cannons and that ''after the second or third warning, boom.'' Mr. Bossi, who penned a tough anti-immigrant law last year and has long been criticized as xenophobic, released a statement that the interview ''by no means reflects my thoughts,'' but the newspaper, Corriere della Sera, said it stood by its article. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Grand Jury Declines To Indict Woman In Killing
description: A grand jury in State Supreme Court decided not to indict a woman who was arrested in the killing of her boyfriend, possibly with her high-heeled shoe, on June 7. Charges will probably be dismissed against the woman, Anna Rhinehart, 40, in the death of Roosevelt Bonds, 51, said a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney's office. Ms. Rhinehart's lawyer, Darren S. Fields, said the grand jury apparently believed she was acting in self-defense during a fight with Mr. Bonds outside a nightclub in Brownsville. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: PENNSAUKEN: SHOOTING SUSPECT IN CUSTODY A New Jersey man accused of shooting two people on Sunday, including his former girlfriend, turned himself in to the authorities yesterday. The police said the man, Robert Baker, accidentally shot himself in the forearm during the shooting and later sought medical attention. The police were notified that Mr. Baker was at a Plainfield hospital early yesterday morning, said the Pennsauken police chief, John J. Coffey. Mr. Baker was charged with two counts of attempted murder. Mr. Baker, 28, is accused of breaking into his former girlfriend's apartment in Pennsauken and shooting her and a male friend several times. The woman, Karyne Simms, and her friend, Jamar Ward, were listed in stable condition at Cooper Hospital University Medical Center yesterday.

Services at 12 noon, Wednesday, June 18th at Hawthorne Funeral Home, Hawthorne, New York. Contributions in his memory may be sent to your favorite charity. title: U.S. Envoy Meets Palestinians in Bid to Revive Peace Plan
description: GAZA CITY, June 17  The American-led peace plan showed signs of reviving slightly today, as Palestinian officials said they were nearing a cease-fire agreement with militant groups, including Hamas, responsible for the greatest number of suicide attacks against Israelis.

title: Turning Hip-Hop Rhyme Against Long Jail Time
description: AT the moment, it is uncertain whether Russell Simmons, the hip-hop magnate, will get to the seaplane on time. It is floating at an East River marina, set to take off at 5 o'clock. Mr. Simmons wants to fly to East Hampton for the weekend, but the timing is not looking good.

title: North Korea Faces Growing Pressure on Nuclear Weapons
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 17  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States had lined up broad support to pressure North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program, but an American initiative to interdict shipments of nuclear materials brought a new threat of retaliation from the Pyongyang government.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Seeking Tamarisk Aid
description: Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell is asking Congress for $20 million to help eradicate tamarisk plants. Tamarisk, also known as Salt Cedar, is a shrubby plant that was introduced to the United States decades ago and is choking out riverbanks in many drought-stricken states. The thirsty weed destroys riverbanks and wildlife habitat along waterways. Mr. Campbell, a Republican, has proposed legislation calling for a State Tamarisk Assistance Program to be established so each state could be eligible for more money and assistance. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEELY, , RUTH TALBOT
description: SEELY--Ruth Talbot. A 50 year resident of Greenwich passed away at the Greenwich Woods Health Care Center on Friday June 13, 2003. She was 85. Born in New York City on November 15, 1917. She was the daughter of the late Benjamin and Elizabeth Holton Talbot. Mrs. Seely was a graduate of Smith College in Northampton, Mass. and was active in the First Congregational Church Evening Guild. She was a member of the Smith College Club, the American Association of University Women and a member of The Innis Arden Golf Club. Mrs. Seely was an avid bridge player. She is survived by her daughter and son-inlaw Carolyn and Malcom Wiener of Greenwich, CT. Her two granddaughters Catherine D. and Elizabeth A. Wiener and her two grandsons Thomas F. and Jonathan P. Wiener all of Greenwich, CT. She was predeceased by her husband Frederic T. Seely in 1975. A graveside service will be held at the First Congregational Church Cemetery, 108 Sound Beach Ave., Old Greenwich, CT on Thursday June 19, 2003 at 3PM. For info Bouton & Reynolds Funeral Home, 2900 Summer St. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perry Ridge Road, Greenwich, CT. 06830 >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOOD, , ROBERT A., M.D., PH.D.
description: GOOD--Robert A., M.D., Ph.D. The Jeffrey Modell Foundation has lost a cherished friend, the world has lost a brilliant immunologist, prolific author and gifted scientist. Our son, Jeffrey, knew him as his caring, compassionate, and dedicated physician. Dr. Robert Good, was an indomitable force for the understanding of Primary Immunodeficiencies for more than 55 years. He authored and coauthored over 2000 scientific papers, 50 books, received 13 honorary degrees and mentored and trained hundreds of students who would go on to have accomplished careers of their own. He performed the first successful bone marrow transplant to cure a child with a fatal PI disease, known as X-linked SCID. He gave all of us the most precious gift which is a greater understanding of disease to make all of our lives better for a brighter tomorrow. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife Bibi and with his dear and wonderful family. Vicki & Fred Modell, Co-Founders Jeffrey Modell Foundation

title: Artists Touched By Amazon Tribe
description: The Yanomami are probably the last example of the myriad Indian tribes that once lived in isolated harmony with the tropical forests of the Amazon Basin. As such, devoted to hunting and fishing and governed by powerful spirits, their natural -- and naked -- way of life has come to be viewed with Rousseau-like nostalgia by many Western anthropologists.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Expense For Chemical Maker
description: The chemical maker Clariant said it would take a charge of 120 million Swiss francs ($92 million) in the second quarter to end a project to make detergent ingredients for the Procter & Gamble Company. Clariant will write off an almost completed plant in Mount Holly, N.C., after failing to meet quality standards as production volumes increased at the factory, a spokesman, Christoph Hafner, said. Clariant will cut travel expenses and managers' bonuses to help make up for the charge, Mr. Hafner said.

title: Court limits forced medication of defendants
description: WASHINGTON:  The Supreme Court ruled Monday that the U.S. government has only a limited right to force mentally ill defendants charged with nonviolent crimes to take medication to make them competent for trial.

title: At Bronx Botanical Garden, Mainstream Doctors Meet Kava and Cohosh
description: It's hard to imagine a doctor more solidly mainstream than Frederick Small, a gynecologist from suburban Tenafly, N.J., with an old-school practitioner's reassuring manner, a grandfather's head of clipped white hair and not much experience with alternative medicine.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Laos: Diplomats See Imprisoned Journalists
description: Western diplomats were allowed to meet with two European journalists and an American who were imprisoned on June 4 after visiting insurgents from the Hmong minority and accused of involvement in the killing of a village guard. French officials said the diplomats were satisfied with the health of the two journalists, Thierry Fallise, a Belgian photojournalist, and Vincent Reynaud, a French cameraman. There was no immediate word on the condition of the American, an ethnic Hmong named Naw Karl Mua who is a Lutheran pastor from St. Paul, Minn. On Sunday the Laotian foreign minister, Somsavath Lengsavath, said charges would be filed soon. ''These people are not journalists,'' he told The Associated Press. ''I don't know what they do outside Laos, but in Laos they were not journalists, so we have to take legal action against them in accordance with the Lao law for murder.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: The Ridiculous Side of Airport Security
description: LIKE most business travelers, I've become good at sailing through airport security without a hitch. With no metal in my pockets, not even the foil on a stick of gum, I invariably step across the magnetometer without setting off the alarm.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Money Manager Acquired
description: The American Express Company agreed to buy a British asset manager, Threadneedle, from Zurich Financial Services for $570 million, the companies said. The deal was a continuation of asset sales by Zurich Financial and will expand American Express's asset management business in Europe. Zurich Financial, which lost $3.4 billion in 2002, has been selling units that have been losing money and that do not fit with its core insurance operations. Threadneedle has about $70 billion in assets under management. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: A Pox Of The Chicken Variety
description: An 11-year-old boy suspected of having monkeypox actually has chickenpox, state health officials said yesterday. The boy, who has not been identified, had the only suspected case of monkeypox in the state. He had lived in the Midwest and was in contact with prairie dogs, thought to carry monkeypox, before he fell ill earlier this month, said Clifton R. Lacy, New Jersey's health commissioner. State health officials had isolated the boy at his northern New Jersey home and sent blood and lesion samples to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, which returned the negative results on Friday.

She had an enormous impact on all our lives-taught us right from wrong, to use our lives productively and to help others. We will miss her tremendously. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PYLE, , DOROTHY COLLINGS
description: PYLE--Dorothy Collings. 91, formerly of the Oranges, Short Hills and Springfield, New Jersey and a summer resident of Mantoloking, NJ, died peacefully on June 12, 2003, in the Health Care Center at Harrogate in Lakewood, NJ. She was born in Riverton, NJ, on March 22, 1912, the only daughter of Llewellyn Willis Collings and Theodora Borden Collings. She was precedeased by her husband, Robert Milner Pyle, in 1991 and her brother, Llewellyn W. Collings Jr., in 1938. She graduated from Dearborn School for Girls in Orange in 1929 and attended Wells College in Aurora, NY, for two years in the Class of 1933. Mrs. Pyle was a former Editor of the Junior League of the Oranges and Short Hills News Sheet and a former Treasurer of the Twig III Overlook Hospital Auxiliary and a devoted member of those organizations for many years. She was also a past member of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club. At her death she was a member of the Short Hills Club, the Bay Head (N.J.) Yacht Club and the above Junior League. She is survived by her son, Robert M. Pyle Jr. of Short Hills and Mantoloking, her daughter, Wendy Pyle of Bay Head, and three grandchildren, Cynthia (Nina) N. Pyle, Laura C. Pyle and Timothy J. Pyle. A memorial service will be held on Friday, June 20, at 11 AM, at Harrogate, 400 Locust Street in Lakewood. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Wells College, Aurora, NY 13026, to The Episcopal Church of St. Andrew and Holy Communion, 160 W. South Orange Avenue, South Orange, NJ 07079, or to the charity of your choice. >>AD#

description: With just 15 days left before New York City's new fiscal year begins and no spending plan in place, budget negotiations between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council remained mired yesterday in posturing and bad blood.

title: Saving Liberia
description: Liberia has long been cruelly governed, but the past week has marked a crisis. Rebels have advanced to the outskirts of Monrovia, the capital. Tens of thousands of people have fled into the capital, but Monrovia is in chaos. Humanitarian workers warn that conditions could produce epidemics of cholera and other diseases.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the difficulties faced by Republicans in recruiting a strong challenger to run against Senator Charles E. Schumer next year referred incorrectly in some copies to a political success they cite with pride, the number of terms won by Gov. George E. Pataki. It is three, not two.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- Richmond; Businesses Rediscovering Easygoing Southern City
description: Richmond's easygoing lifestyle, low cost of living and central location have long appealed to businesses. The city is home to five Fortune 500 companies, including the Circuit City Group, the largest by revenue, and the Capital One Financial Corporation, the No. 1 employer with more than 9,000 workers. While CSX Railroad recently moved to Jacksonville, Fla., Philip Morris U.S.A., returning to its tobacco roots, plans to relocate its headquarters here from New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Telecom Shares Sold
description: The Dutch telecommunications giant Royal KPN said that it had begun to sell its 6.48 percent stake in the Czech telephone company Cesky Telecom, reducing its stake to the 27 percent it owns jointly with the Swiss telecommunications operator Swisscom. The sale should raise about $220 million for Royal KPN, which was hurt by overspending for mobile telephone licenses and a German mobile telephone operator. The move set off a 6 percent decline in Cesky's shares. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Real and Less Real Reforms
description: New York's State Legislature is scheduled to end its work for 2003 this Thursday. Aside from the budget, virtually everything significant remains to be done. Yet it was not until Sunday afternoon that Gov. George Pataki announced his priorities for the end of the session. The governor's critics will say that he's more interested in credit than action. But the important thing is that there are still a few days of legislative life in the capital, and thus a chance to pass reform bills that would allow lawmakers to return home with a modicum of self-respect.

title: One-Hitter With a Twist: Mets Lose This One
description: With arms flying and a high leg kick reminiscent of another left-hander, Vida Blue, Dontrelle Willis went from being the Florida Marlins' best-kept secret to the Mets' worst nightmare tonight.

title: At the Air Show, the U.S.-France Rift Shows
description: Who would have thought that grounding fighter jets and pouring fine wine down the drain would amount to the same thing?

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES. Cocoa gained as traders took advantage of the lowest prices in a year to stock up on beans. In New York, cocoa for September delivery rose $32, or 2.2 percent, to $1,500 a metric ton.

title: Male Breast Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Credit Card Deal Has Initial Approval
description: MasterCard International Inc. and Visa International Inc. have won preliminary approval from a federal judge for their $3 billion agreement to settle a lawsuit by retailers over debit card fees.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WPP Ups the Ante Again In Its Contest for Cordiant

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIGMAN, , SYLVIA
description: ZIGMAN--Sylvia. At the age of 84 years. Wife of the late Morris Zigman. Mother of Warren Zigman and Barbara Zigman. Mother-in-law of April Zigman. Loving grandmother of the two lights of her life, Marisa Zigman and Abigail Zigman. Died peacefully in her sleep on June 14th, 2003. She will be missed. >>AD#

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GEORGIA: RADIOACTIVE MATERIAL FOUND IN TAXI The police have found a large quantity of radioactive material that could be used in making a "dirty bomb," officials said. They said they believed the material, about 170 pounds of cesium 137 and strontium 90, was discovered in a taxi in the capital, Tbilisi, on May 31. The authorities said a quantity of an unspecified poisonous gas was also found. It is suspected that the material was bound for Turkey, where it was to be resold. Officials did not say why they had waited more than two weeks to disclose the seizure. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

title: DANCE: CHANGE AT THE TOP
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FENSTER, , MILTON
description: FENSTER--Milton, passed on June 16th. Beloved husband of Lilian of 25 years. Loving father of Amber, Randese Leoni and Barbara Smithen. Dear uncle of Richard. Loving father-in-law of Serge Leoni and Dr. Charles Smithen. Cherished grandfather of Oliver and Hugh. Step-grandchildren Lindsay, Kevin and Corinne Smithen. Funeral services Wednesday, June 18, 11:15 AM at the ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Rare Bosnia Success Story, Thanks to U.S. Viceroy
description: A decade ago, Samira Hasanvasic said, her parents huddled in a nearby village as Bosnian Serbs hunted down Muslims, torching their houses and driving many into exile. Others they killed, dumping the bodies into the muddy shallows of the Sava River.

title: A Second Opinion on Sunshine: It Can Be Good Medicine After All
description: Can sunshine, now shunned by so many who fear skin cancer and wrinkles, save many more lives than it harms? Most definitely, says a leading expert in the field, Dr. Michael F. Holick, a professor of medicine, dermatology, physiology and biophysics at the Boston University School of Medicine.

title: Bush Names Lobbyist As Leader Of G.O.P.
description: Over the past decade, Ed Gillespie, who was chosen today by President Bush to be chairman of the Republican National Committee through next year's election, has worn many hats, some of them simultaneously.

title: No Headline
Syria's Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VARIAN, , GENE
description: VARIAN--Gene, 52, night crew general assistant for the Metropolitan Opera, after a very long and courageous battle with liver disease. Beloved husband of Kathy and proud, loving father of Sean and Gene Jr. Cherished son of Theresa and the late George Varian. Irreplaceable brother of George and Nanette, brother-in-law of Rosie Varian and Peter Bloch, uncle of Susie and Jenny Varian. His sharp wit and indomitable good cheer carried him through the bad times; we pray that the memory of his unfailing humor and grace will do the same for us. The family will receive friends Tuesday, June 17th and Wednesday, June 18th, from 2-4 and 7-9PM at Williams Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232nd Street, Bronx NY 10463, (718) 548-1100. Religious services Thursday, June 19th, at 9:30AM at the funeral home. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery. Please sign your organ donor card; contributions may be made in his memory to The American Liver Foundation, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 603, NY, NY 10038, or to the ASPCA, 424 East 92nd Street, New York, New York 10128. >>AD#

title: Growing Pains
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Calpers to Vote on New Health Care Rates
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System is expected to approve a big increase today in premiums for its 900,000 members insured by health maintenance organizations.

title: Palestinians Raise Hope of Cease-Fire Deal With Militants
description: The American-led peace plan showed signs of life today, as Palestinian officials said they were nearing a cease-fire agreement with three militant groups, including Hamas, responsible for the greatest number of suicide attacks against Israelis.

title: BLOCKBUSTER OFFERS SUBSCRIPTIONS FOR VIDEO GAMES
description: Blockbuster rolled out a subscription-based service yesterday that permits customers to rent an unlimited number of video games for 30 consecutive days. Blockbuster, a movie and video game rental store chain based in Dallas, announced the Game Freedom Pass, which lets customers get a month of unlimited game rentals for $19.99 plus tax. The Blockbuster rental service follows the success of the DVD rental service Netflix , which permits subscribers to rent any three titles at a time for $19.95 a month. Customers receive and return the DVD's through the mail.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Circuits on June 5 about practices and products that can help alleviate muscle strain, fatigue and stress at the computer used the term iCurve imprecisely. It is the brand name for a laptop stand made by Griffin Technology -- not for a maker of stands.

title: Ex-Pataki Aide to Lead Trade Center Rebuilding
description: Kevin M. Rampe, a lawyer and former aide to Gov. George E. Pataki who also represented Kuwait in claims against Iraq stemming from the Persian Gulf war in 1991, was appointed yesterday to lead the agency overseeing redevelopment of the World Trade Center site.

title: Democratic Candidates Assail Bush Across a Wide Spectrum
description: Senator John Edwards today denounced President Bush's tax-cut program as the ''most radical and dangerous economic theory to hit our shores since Socialism.'' Mr. Edwards, a Democratic presidential candidate, proposed his own program of lower- and middle-income tax cuts, to be financed by rolling back Mr. Bush's tax cuts for wealthiest Americans.

title: Triumph and Failure in the Age of Empire
description: CURZON

title: Texas Eliminates Miami
description: The freshman Sam LeCure held Miami to one run over six and a third innings and closer Huston Street retired all seven batters he faced as the defending national champion Texas beat Miami, 5-1, at the College World Series in Omaha.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on June 3 about a program to reintroduce California condors to the wild in Arizona referred incompletely to its financing. It is supported mainly by private donations, not just by federal and state agencies and zoos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOTON, , THEODORE
description: KOTON--Theodore. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member, Theodore Koton. May He who consults the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to his family. Dr. Harlan J. Wechsler, Rabbi Daniel J. Beller, President >>AD#

title: A Birthday Party Livened, By Interconnecting Arrays
description: The American Composers Alliance has hit retirement age. Ah, let's rephrase that. The organization, founded by Aaron Copland and Roger Sessions in 1937 to further the role of the composer in America, celebrated its 65th birthday last weekend with six concerts of music by past and present members. The anniversary concert itself, on Saturday night, commemorated Sessions with music by him and his ''students and grandstudents'': Milton Babbitt studied with Sessions, George Edwards studied with Mr. Babbitt, and so on.

title: Rights Group Says U.S. Soldiers Twice Used Excessive Force
description: A leading human rights group today accused United States troops of using excessive force in two April shootings that killed 20 Iraqis and wounded at least 86. Commanders said their soldiers were responding to hostile fire from a crowd of protesters in Falluja, a city of 300,000 about 35 miles west of Baghdad.

title: Duels, Revenge and Romance, Fresh From the 17th Century
description: 'The Rover'

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Radio Campaign Against Drug Laws
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, left, the former candidate for governor, said yesterday that a coalition working to revise the Rockefeller-era drug laws would begin broadcasting 60-second radio advertisements today. The ads are intended to pressure Albany to act before the state's legislative session ends; it is scheduled to wrap up tomorrow. In the ads, the coalition, known as Countdown to Fairness, urges listeners to call Gov. George E. Pataki and the top two legislative leaders to urge repeal of the laws, which impose lengthy mandatory minimum sentences even for nonviolent drug offenses. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Nextel to Be Top Sponsor Of Nascar's Elite Series
description: The evolution of Nascar from a Southern phenomenon to a nationally prominent sport will take its next step tomorrow when Nextel, a wireless communications company, is introduced as the title sponsor of the elite stock car racing series now called the Winston Cup.

title: Opening Skies Over the Atlantic
description: It may take some time, but air travel across the North Atlantic is likely to improve dramatically -- with more competitive fares and scheduling -- as a result of changes in the way the European Union regulates aviation. The European Court of Justice has rightly decided that it makes little sense for Europe's single economy to retain an airline system that dates from an age when airlines were owned by governments and treated like national symbols.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: 6 Arrested in Illegal Transfer Of Tens of Millions to Pakistan
description: Three New Jersey men and three New Yorkers, all natives of Pakistan, were charged today with illegally transmitting tens of millions of dollars in cash from the United States to Pakistan by using several unlicensed money-transfer businesses and failing to file the required currency-transaction reports.

title: Regents Give City More Time To Have All Teachers Certified
description: The State Board of Regents voted overwhelmingly yesterday to give New York City another two years to make sure that all its public school teachers are certified.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle Moves Suits To Federal Court
description: Oracle, which has made a $5.1 billion takeover bid for PeopleSoft, moved two lawsuits over the hostile offer from state to federal court in a move that its opponents said was intended to delay the cases. Oracle said it transferred the suits because they dealt with the company's offer for PeopleSoft, which would be regulated by federal securities law. J. D. Edwards & Company, which filed one of the suits, said the move was a delaying tactic and requested an expedited schedule to block Oracle's tender offer. The transfer was the latest step in a skirmish between Oracle and the two software makers, which both sued Oracle accusing it of interfering with PeopleSoft's plan to acquire J. D. Edwards for $1.75 billion.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Doctors Plan Protest
description: New Jersey physicians are planning a 13-day ''rolling'' strike, a one-day shutdown at their offices, starting today, John Shaffer, a spokesman for the Medical Society of New Jersey, said yesterday. The strikes are to begin in Bergen County and continue in other counties until June 30. They are smaller versions of the doctors' earlier statewide walkout. About 10,000 New Jersey physicians canceled routine checkups and rescheduled elective surgery during the week of Feb. 4 in one of the nation's largest walkouts ever by doctors. The doctors want to draw attention to what they regard as ruinously high premiums for needed malpractice insurance. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Beckham Is Newest Star in Real Madrid's Galaxy
description: David Beckham is leaving Manchester United for the Spanish League after all. But he is not going to Barcelona, whose new president desperately wanted him on the field, but to rival Real Madrid, which may not need him.

title: It's Take 2 For Merger Of Actors' Unions
description: The ballots have gone out, the barricades are up, and the sniping has escalated, a sure sign in Hollywood that the perennially feuding members of the Screen Actors Guild are at it again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIENECKER, , RAYMOND H. ''RAY,''
description: RIENECKER--Raymond H. ''Ray,'' 79, of Tierra Verde, FL died June 15, 2003. He worked as a Sales Manager in the Textile Industry and is survived by a loving family. >>AD#

title: As SARS Ebbs, W.H.O. Lifts Its Advisory On Taiwan
description: The World Health Organization lifted its advisory today against all but essential travel to Taiwan, leaving Beijing as the only place the organization is telling travelers to avoid because of the risk of SARS.

title: Plan to Block North Korean Nuclear Shipments Gains Support
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States had lined up broad support to press North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program, but an American initiative to interdict shipments of nuclear materials brought a new threat of retaliation.

title: An Ill Wind Blows Up A Juicy Treat: Loads of Litchis
description: A bumper crop of fresh litchis from Florida, some 2 million pounds, is making its way into stores for an appearance that will be all too brief. These fruit, shown far larger than the normal strawberry size, are thin-skinned, easily peeled and dripping with lush, highly perfumed pulp. Chill them to nibble whole, or remove the pits and use them in a fruit salad or to make sorbet. Always wash the outside before peeling. This harvest is the biggest since farmers in South Florida began planting litchi trees to replace less profitable crops after Hurricane Andrew struck in 1992. Supermarkets have them for as little as $4 a pound (about 18 litchis).

title: Now the Dirtiest of Wars Won't Be Forgotten
description: In an inaugural address notable for its promise of change, it was President Nstor Kirchner's insistence that he intended to exercise power ''without rancor but with memory'' that most struck Argentines. ''I am part of a decimated generation,'' he said, referring to the victims of the 1976-83 military dictatorship here, ''and I do not believe in the axiom that when you govern you trade convictions for pragmatism.''

title: Going Hunting? Wear the Right Shoes
description: No one will accuse Theresa Rebeck of overreaching in her new one-character play, ''Bad Dates,'' which opened on Sunday at Playwrights Horizons. A monologue by a Texas woman transplanted to New York, it's a show with limited ambition but a cozy kind of familiarity.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Gap In Preschool Openings
description: A new report has found disparities in the number of preschool programs available to families in Los Angeles County. Severe space shortages were found to be most prevalent in blue-collar Latino communities, such as El Monte and South Gate, where the number of slots was seven or fewer for every 100 children. In contrast, Santa Monica and affluent parts of the San Fernando Valley reported at least 45 preschool slots for every 100 children. The report by Policy Analysis for California Education, an independent research center, came as Los Angeles County is trying to set up a universal preschool program with about $100 million from tobacco taxes. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: For Those Who Can Afford It, 2 New Chances to Fly to Space
description: An American company and the Russian space agency are to announce an agreement today to resume tourist flights to the International Space Station in 2004 or 2005, lifting a moratorium imposed after the Columbia shuttle disaster.

title: Knowing About Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: Olive Oil Worth a Trip to Uruguay
description: Olivier Baussan heard that olive trees had been planted in central Uruguay about 50 years ago by French immigrants. So, being the founder of Oliviers & Company, a chain of shops specializing in olive products, he decided to investigate. From his visit has come a new golden oil called Los Ranchos. It has a lively, grassy, vegetal flavor that makes it excellent to drizzle on grilled fish with herbs or as a copious pour on vegetable salads. But not too copious, at $29 for 16.8 ounces. The oil is available at the Oliviers stores and soon will be at www.oliviers-co.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISCHBACH, , MARILYN C.
description: FISCHBACH--Marilyn C. The associates and the artists of Fischbach Gallery are extremely saddened by the passing of Marilyn C. Fischbach who died in Paris on June 15th. Marilyn Fischbach, a vibrant art dealer, had the courage to recognize and present young talent. She founded the gallery in 1960, and exhibited the work of many important artists including Eva Hesse, Ronald Bladen, Alex Katz, Robert Mangold, Robert Ryman, Jane Freilicher, and Leigh Behnke. Her unique vision continues to nurture the gallery today. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to her husband, Herbert, her children, Peter, John, Sally and Jimmy, her sister, Sheila, and her entire family. >>AD#

title: 2nd Home Is Searched for Evidence in Yale Bombing Investigation
description: Federal and state officials investigating a pipe bomb explosion last month at Yale Law School have searched a second home in nearby Hamden, Conn., a police official said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Immigrant Boat Sinks
description: The coast guard recovered six bodies off Sicily, the first found after a small boat from Libya packed with as many as 70 illegal immigrants capsized and sank south of the island of Lampedusa. The sinking came as the issue of illegal immigration was renewed with a newspaper report that quoted a government minister, Umberto Bossi, as suggesting that Italy should fire at immigrants' boats. He later denied the comments. Interior Ministry officials countered that the number of illegal immigrants had dropped by nearly half this year. Last night the coast guard said that a boat with 153 illegal immigrants from Africa had arrived in Lampedusa. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: NO CRUISE SHIPS FOR HOMELESS Because of high refurbishing costs, the city has rejected a plan to place homeless families on refitted cruise ships anchored in New York Harbor. Last summer, when emergency shelters were filled with homeless families, the mayor's office proposed placing some temporarily in retired cruise ships. In November, Linda I. Gibbs, the commissioner of homeless services, visited the Bahamas to inspect unused cruise ships and found the idea promising. But the cost of refitting the floating hotels was too expensive, city officials said yesterday. Also, the upper harbor is too shallow for the huge ships, officials said.

title: No Opening Statement for Defense in Church Slayings
description: Today was the day for opening arguments in the trial of a man accused of fatally shooting a Long Island priest and a parishioner last year during morning Mass. But while a prosecutor argued in chilling detail that the man, Peter J. Troy, had burst through the doors of Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church in Lynbrook, pulled out a rifle and fired repeatedly, Mr. Troy's defense lawyer declined to make any opening statement at all.

title: Legislative Time Ticks Away, But To-Do List Seems to Grow
description: With just two days left before the end of session, Albany's power triumvirate emerged from behind closed doors today to announce that a consensus had been reached on being patriotic and on saving trees.

title: As Coach Talks to 76ers, The Talk Is About Kidd
description: While Jason Kidd started to rest his mind and body before thinking of his future, Eddie Jordan, the Nets' top assistant coach, explored his options in Philadelphia yesterday.

title: CANADIAN LEADERS AGREE TO PROPOSE GAY MARRIAGE LAW
description: The Canadian cabinet approved a new national policy today to open marriage to gay couples, paving the way for Canada to become the third country to allow same-sex unions.

title: New Details On Failures In Child Care
description: On the night of Sept. 21, 2002, an officer at a juvenile detention center along the New Jersey shore propped open a door to obstruct the view of a security camera. In the minutes that followed, state records show, the guard allowed one resident to gain access to an adjoining cell and beat the teenage foster child inside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLEISHMAN, , NAOMI
description: FLEISHMAN--Naomi. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Naomi Fleishman, beloved mother of our devoted members, Stanley and Martine Fleishman. To them and the entire family our deepest sympathy. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President >>AD#

title: Judges and Partisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Leading the World but Following It
description: Disparities in the legal treatment of lesbians and gay men in the United States and their treatment in the rest of the world are becoming more pronounced. As the United States Supreme Court considers an important gay rights case, expected to be decided this month, it should realize that much of the globe sees the issue as a matter of basic human rights.

title: Penalties Against Rutgers Accepted by N.C.A.A.
description: The N.C.A.A., citing at least 40 violations of academic eligibility certification policies since 1997 and a lack of institutional control at Rutgers, accepted today the university's self-imposed penalties of two years' probation and the loss of 20 scholarships in 10 sports.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Former Candidates Seek Debate Reform
description: Some former third-party presidential candidates who were excluded from debates in 2000, including Ralph Nader of the Green Party and Patrick J. Buchanan of the Reform Party, are seeking to change the way the debates are run in 2004. In a complaint to the Federal Election Commission, they contend that the Commission on Presidential Debates cannot legally sponsor the forums because it acts in a partisan manner by restricting them to only Republican and Democratic candidates. Election law requires that the group organizing the debates, which has been the commission since 1988, be nonprofit and nonpartisan. John Files (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Campaign Finance Reform
description: The City Council's Committee on Governmental Operations has scheduled a public hearing on various proposals to change the campaign finance program. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (212) 662-4440.

title: The Spirit of Service Betrayed
description: In his 2002 State of the Union address, President Bush spoke with apparent passion about marshaling the new public-spiritedness inspired by 9/11. He vowed to expand opportunities for meaningful national service, including those offered by AmeriCorps, President Bill Clinton's worthy domestic volunteer program. At appearances across the country, President Bush has touted his plan to ''increase AmeriCorps by 50 percent'' -- from about 50,000 members a year to 75,000.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Senate Chooses New Chaplain
description: Rear Adm. Barry C. Black, the chief of chaplains for the Navy, was named chaplain of the Senate today by Bill Frist, the Senate majority leader. A former Seventh-day Adventist pastor in North and South Carolina, Admiral Black, 54, is the first military chaplain and the first black to serve in the position, which pays $130,000 a year. He succeeds Dr. Lloyd Ogilvie, who retired in March. Admiral Black, 54, became a Navy chaplain in 1976. He expects to retire from active duty in the next few days and assume his new post this month. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRONYN, , HUME
description: CRONYN--Hume. With enduring memories of a treasured relationship, the Academy mourns the loss of its esteemed alumnus Hume Cronyn. Through his efforts and support, a Cronyn/Tandy scholarship was established at the Academy in 1988 to help Canadian students. Our heartfelt sympathies go out to his wife, Susan, and the entire Cronyn family. Roger Croucher, President The American Academy of Dramatic Arts

title: Word That U.S. Doubted Iraq Would Use Deadly Gas
description: American intelligence analysts reported to the Bush administration last year that Saddam Hussein's government had begun to deploy chemical weapons but that Baghdad would almost certainly not use them unless the government's survival was at stake, United States officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page capsule summary yesterday for an article about charges brought in a smuggling operation that led to the deaths of 19 people misidentified the starting point of their journey by truck. It was near Harlingen, Tex., not across the border in Mexico.

title: No MSG, Just Cayenne
description: To the Editor:

title: White Tablecloths With Plastic Mats?
description: Plastic or vinyl place mats are on the tables at Nougatine, Craft, Blue Fin and Kitchen 82, restaurants that would never dream of using plastic glassware, dishes or flatware. Sandy Chilewich designed them for her New York company, Chilewich (pronounced CHILL-a-witch), in ways that mimic linen, straw or bark-like basket weaves. All are in neutral tones from pale to dark, and are occasionally shot with colored or metallic strands.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Seton Hall Fire Suspect Out On Bail
description: Six days after he was arrested, one of two men accused of starting the Seton Hall University fire that killed three students was freed yesterday on $2 million bail. Before he was released, however, the suspect, Joseph T. Lepore, 22, of Florham Park, was transferred from the Essex County jail to the Morris County jail. Mr. Lepore was fingerprinted and photographed for a separate assault charge accusing him of driving his car into the vehicle of an arresting officer last Wednesday. A state judge, Salem Ahto, folded the $100,000 bail for that case into the $2 million bail. The other suspect, Sean Ryan, a former roommate of Mr. Lepore, remains in custody on $2 million bail. His lawyer, Michael Bubb, has said he hopes to post the bail today. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Powell Going to Mideast to Press for Gaza Deal
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 18  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that he would travel this week to Israel to try to press for a transfer of security operations in the northern Gaza strip from Israeli armed forces to Palestinian forces under the direction of a new security chief, Muhammad Dahlan.

title: Problem Seen In School Note On Transfers
description: Letters notifying parents about their right to transfer their children to higher-performing schools may have misled some parents to believe that their children could receive free tutoring if they chose not to transfer, a City Councilwoman said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SICHERMAN, , REBECCA
description: SICHERMAN--Rebecca. Wife of the late Sidney. Beloved mother of Irwin, Alan and Ruth Najjar. Adored grandmother of Joshua Najjar, Julie Mancher, Jordan and Jessie Najjar, Eve and Annie Sicherman. Shiva is at the home of Ruth Najjar through Thursday. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 19 about the declining crime rate in the Serbian province of Kosovo under an international police force run by the United Nations misstated the composition of the forces that expelled 70,000 ethnic Serbs from Sarajevo during the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The forces included Bosnian Serb and Yugoslav policemen, paramilitaries and vigilantes, not ethnic Muslim policemen.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BIG TOY STORE TO SELL Hamleys, the 243-year-old emporium on London's Regent Street that calls itself the world's biggest toy store, said it had agreed to be bought for $80 million by its own managers and the Baugur Group, a leading retailer in Iceland. The purchasers can look forward to acquiring a refurbished store bursting with toys. In unusually hectic trading, shares of Hamleys rose as much as 4 percent, to 202 pence ($3.40), after Baugur and the management team said they would bid 205 pence a share, a figure analysts said was on the high side. Under its new ownership, Hamleys, once compared in size and style to New York's troubled F.A.O. Schwarz, may expand outside Britain and open more of its outlets, called the Bear Factory, where shoppers buy teddy bears of their own design.

title: Letters
description: The Wedding Cake Lowdown

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: New Chief At Telecom Company
description: Richard Li, the son of Li Ka-Shing, Hong Kong's richest person, will step down as chief executive of PCCW, the telephone company, but will remain chairman, the company said. Jack So, the chief executive of the MTR Corporation, which operates Hong Kong's subway system, will succeed Mr. Li but will hold a different title as group managing director. He will also become deputy chairman. Mr. So will assume his new posts by Sept. 24. PCCW is the biggest provider of fixed-line telephone services in Hong Kong but has been struggling with a heavy debt load. Mr. Li said two years ago that he would find a new chief executive, and the company acknowledged publicly last month that it was talking with Mr. So. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: 2 Towers Rise in Chicago Despite Weak Market
description: Rents are falling, vacancies are rising and the economy remains in the doldrums. Normally, this would not be looked on as the most opportune moment to commence construction of millions of square feet of new downtown office space.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mad Cow Scare Leads to Pricier Veal
description: THE federal ban on Canadian cattle since the discovery of mad cow disease in a cow in Alberta about a month ago has had little impact on the availability of beef in the United States. But many wholesalers, retailers and restaurants are faced with a shortage of veal, because many of them relied on imports from up north.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans in Iraq:

title: House Committee Approves Drug Benefits for Medicare
description: An important House committee approved a bill tonight adding prescription drug benefits to Medicare after an impassioned partisan debate over the proper roles of government and private industry in delivering health care to the elderly.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Ghana: Ashanti Profit Down 59%
description: The Ashanti Goldfields Company, which AngloGold has offered to buy for about $1.07 billion, said first-quarter profit slumped 59 percent as lower production pushed up its mining costs. Net income dropped to $6.8 million, or 5 cents a share, from $16.5 million, or 15 cents, a year earlier, the Ghana-based company said. Gold production fell 7 percent to 380,929 ounces. Production costs jumped 18 percent to $224 an ounce.

title: Wooing Private Lynch
description: Short of the search for weapons of mass destruction, the most relentless hunt of the Iraq war may be for the rights to tell the story of Pfc. Jessica Lynch. News media and entertainment companies are applying all the synergy at their disposal to try and reach Private Lynch and land her story. CBS even dangled the possibility of a chance for Private Lynch and her friends to be co-hosts on an MTV music special.

title: El Paso Claims Victory in a Proxy Dispute
description: The interim chief executive of the El Paso Corporation declared victory today in a dispute with a large part of the company's investors, effectively preventing the company's highest-ranking managers and board from being ousted in a rare coup attempt by shareholders.

title: G.E. Union Cites Deal to Curb Workers' Share of Health Costs
description: With details of a tentative agreement beginning to emerge, the president of General Electric's largest labor union said yesterday that it had achieved its goal of ensuring that workers would not shoulder a higher percentage of company health costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, , RABBI ISRAEL
description: SILVERMAN--Rabbi Israel. It is with great sorrow that the officers, Board of Directors and staff of the Masorti Foundation for Conservative Judaism in Israel and the Masorti Movement in Israel mourn the passing of Rabbi Israel Silverman, father of our President, Riva Silverman, on June 16, in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada. He is survived by his wife Gloria and other children Judah, Ilana, Aviva, Devorah, their spouses and sixteen grandchildren. Rabbi Silverman was an inspiring leader in Conservative Judaism, and in Canadian Jewry. A scholar, a pastor, a teacher and a lover of Jews in the Diaspora and in Israel, he will be missed by many. Heartfelt sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. May they be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Shiva will be held at Gloria Silverman's home in Canada. Rabbi Gordon Tucker, Chairman of the Board >>AD#

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Court Overturns Extension
description: A federal appeals court has found that the Environmental Protection Agency should not have extended to 2004 a deadline to clean up Atlanta's ozone pollution without reclassifying the city's pollution as severe. The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit said the agency's policy on granting extensions exceeded the agency's authority. If it is reclassified, the state has a year to make an air quality plan that must include use of low-sulfur gasoline and restrictions of vehicle miles traveled in the Atlanta region, said David Farren of the Southern Environmental Law Center, lead lawyer for the plaintiffs. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Restructuring Planned
description: Engage Inc., which makes software for online advertisers, said it was negotiating a financial restructuring that might lead to a filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Shares of Engage, which is based in Andover, Mass., fell 13 cents, or 86 percent, to 2 cents. Engage is majority owned by CMGI Inc., an Internet venture company. Engage is in talks to sell most of its assets, pending bankruptcy court approval, to an unspecified buyer.

description: To the Editor:

title: State Pension Fund to Invest $200 Million in Israeli Fund
description: The state comptroller has decided to invest $200 million of state pension funds in Israeli companies through a private equity fund that will focus on infrastructure projects and other traditional investments, officials said today.

title: Venting at Rent Hearing Is Long, Loud and Personal
description: One after another, the landlords and the tenants in New York City's vast and byzantine rent-regulated world marched to the microphone yesterday at Cooper Union and offered their opinions about the largest rent increases since 1989.

title: Italian Super Cup At Giants Stadium
description: The Italian Super Cup between A.C. Milan and Juventus will be played at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on Aug. 3, the promoter of the game, Charlie Stillitano, said yesterday.

description: As a dozen or so players hammered away on the Westchester Country Club's practice range while preparing for the start of the Buick Classic on Thursday, the scene was a typical one.

title: Moving Quickly Through History
description: TODAY, more than 100,000 New York high school students will take the state global history exam. Richard P. Mills, the state education commissioner, has such faith in this test -- and the state tests in English, math, American history and science -- that in recent years, he has made passage of all five exams mandatory for a high school diploma.

title: Korean Food That's a Cure for What Ails You
description: FOR Koreans who find a night of hard drinking to be a pleasant rite of companionship, the mornings after are an occupational hazard. For many, the solution is a bowl of hae jang gook, a hearty beef-and-tripe soup with a reputation for smoothing the head and soothing the stomach.

title: Teaching Fellows in Training
description: The latest class of New York City Teaching Fellows began its summer training program this week. About 2,500 of the 2,700 fellows are expected to be placed in classrooms next fall, making up a quarter of the new teachers in the school system. All fellows will work in classrooms in high-needs schools, with more than 1,000 in the Bronx. This year, for the first time, fellows will pay for half of their two-year master's degree program through a $4,000 payroll deduction.

title: The Lessons of a Year
description: At the height of the priest sexual abuse scandal a year ago, as the nation's Roman Catholic bishops fought to restore faith in their church, the most radical step they took was to appoint a board of lay Catholics to monitor the bishops' compliance with their own new policies.

title: OFF THE MENU

title: Republicans Dismiss Questions Over Strength of Evidence on Banned Weapons in Iraq
description: Despite growing questions about whether the White House exaggerated the evidence about Saddam Hussein's chemical and biological weapons, President Bush and his aides believe that the relief that Americans feel about Mr. Hussein's fall in Iraq will overwhelm any questions about the case the administration's built against him, administration officials and Republican strategists say.

title: Teach for America Expands
description: Teach for America is doubling its presence in the New York City public schools this fall, to 500 teachers in more than 100 schools. Nearly 30 of the new teachers are native New Yorkers.

title: Hussein's Top Aide Has Been Caught, U.S. Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON, June 18  Saddam Hussein's senior bodyguard, one of the few people the former Iraqi leader trusted completely and a witness of potentially enormous importance, has been captured in Iraq, American military officials said today.

title: Collison Is Auditioning And Hopes to Land Part
description: Nick Collison was a first-team all-American as a senior at Kansas last season. He was named the Big 12 Conference player of the year, was selected the national player of the year by the National Association of Basketball Coaches and helped lead the Jayhawks to the N.C.A.A. championship game. But this is what it is like when you play four years of college basketball in preparation for the N.B.A.

title: Old Enough to Make a Lanyard, and to Do It Nude
description: On the third-to-last day of summer camp, the temperature has risen to 98 degrees, and even the troupers have begun to whine.

title: He Looks Awkward, But Willis Is in Control
description: Dontrelle Willis called his mother in Alameda, Calif., after pitching a one-hit shutout against the Mets on Monday night. Willis had just finished watching ESPN's ''SportsCenter,'' and his quirky, all-arms-and-legs delivery and his overpowering performance had made him one of the top stories on the program.

title: Making Trinkets in China, and a Deadly Dust
description: With his handsome smile and full head of black hair, Hu Zhiguo hardly looks 44, much less gravely ill. The giveaway is his wispy voice, faint from clotted lungs.

description: JUST days before the French conglomerate Vivendi Universal plans to accept formal bids for its American entertainment assets, the company announced lower operating profits yesterday for its Vivendi Universal Entertainment unit and a decline in both revenue and operating income for the Universal Music Group.

description: The FIFA Confederations Cup has struck many as a bothersome tournament that skulks into a packed soccer calendar every two years, unsettling clubs and national programs while adding stress to already fatigued players.

description: WHAT could be better than a day at the beach? How about taking the beachside mood into the kitchen with a summer's worth of new books on cooking at the shore?

description: The Washington Post, which in early April was the first news organizaton to publish reports that Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch heroically resisted her Iraqi captors, yesterday published a lengthy investigation discrediting some of those initial reports, including its exclusive report that she fired back at her attackers.

title: G.M. SETS FURTHER CUT IN OUTPUT OF SATURN ION
description: General Motors will stop producing the Saturn Ion small car for two extra weeks because of slower-than-expected sales of the auto's sedan model. The company, which is based in Detroit, will halt an assembly line at its Saturn plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., for four weeks, starting June 23, including two previously scheduled weeks for the company's nationwide annual summer shutdown. Ion production will resume July 21, said Sherrie Childers-Arb, a spokeswoman.

title: CUNY Trustee Is Approved
description: The New York State Senate unanimously approved MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG's appointment of RITA DiMARTINO yesterday as a trustee of the City University of New York. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Ms. DiMartino graduated from the College of Staten Island -- one of CUNY's 17 undergraduate colleges -- and received her master's degree in public administration from Long Island University's C. W. Post Center. She is a former vice president in AT&T's Law and Federal/International Government Affairs department and is now a consultant there. Last year, PRESIDENT BUSH named her to the J. William Fulbright Foreign Scholarship Board. She was a United States ambassador to the Unicef executive board. Karen W. Arenson

title: Consumer Prices Rose in May, Easing Worries on Deflation
description: Consumer prices, excluding food and energy, had their biggest increase in nine months in May, the government reported yesterday, easing concern that deflation might sap the economic recovery.

title: Boston Archdiocese, Hurting Financially, Warns of Layoffs
description: Underscoring the financial difficulty facing the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston as a result of the sexual abuse scandal in the clergy and a sagging economy, Bishop Richard G. Lennon warned his parish priests today that because almost 100 churches were withholding money from the archdiocese, he would order them to start laying off employees or cut their health benefits.

description: To the Editor:

title: French Banker Acquitted, Clearing Path to Central Bank
description: PARIS, June 18  The governor of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, was acquitted by a Paris court today of charges that he manipulated the accounts of the French bank Credit Lyonnais before its collapse in the early 1990's.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Clamping Down On Fraud
description: The United States and 29 other countries have developed a ''framework for international cooperation'' to curb cross-border fraud, officials said yesterday. The agreement is intended to make it easier for governments to investigate and shut illegal Internet and telemarketing operations involving multiple countries. Some mass e-mailers in the United States, for example, frequently route messages through overseas computers to make it harder for authorities to trace them. Officials from Britain, France, Canada, Australia, Japan and Finland joined officials from the Federal Trade Commission to announce the agreement.

title: Ideal Apricot Is Delectable, Elusive
description: FOR me, fresh apricots are on a par with the Red Sox. I root for them at the beginning of the season and curse them at the end. (Where anticipation is high, disappointment can be keen.)

title: Idealism, Not Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Blacks Are Searched by Police At a Higher Rate, Data Show
description: Blacks continue to be stopped and searched by police officers in New York City at a much higher rate than people of other racial backgrounds, according to records released by the New York City Council.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: PERU: 20-YEAR CONFLICT CLAIMED 60,000 The death toll from a brutal, 20-year conflict that ended in 2000 is now thought to number up to 60,000, far higher than earlier estimates, a Truth and Reconciliation Commission investigating the violence announced at the United Nations. The conflict, which pitted the government against the Maoist Shining Path rebels and the Marxist Tupac Amaru movement, had been thought to have claimed about 25,000 lives until it ended with the capture of top guerrilla leaders. The commission said most of the victims were indigenous Peruvians.    Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Rules On Prescription Counseling Changed
description: New Yorkers filling new prescriptions will get more detailed counseling from their pharmacists, but those refilling old prescriptions will be less likely to talk with a pharmacist, under new rules adopted today by the State Board of Regents.

title: Bush Issues Racial Profiling Ban But Exempts Security Inquiries
description: President Bush issued guidelines today barring federal agents from using race or ethnicity in their routine investigations, but the policy carves out clear exemptions for investigations involving terrorism and national security matters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAL, , MARY E.
description: BAL--Mary E. Died peacefully at home on June 17, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Kenan. Devoted aunt of Nancy and Robert Robertson. Dear friend to all. Funeral services in Toronto. >>AD#

title: Decision Seen Soon on Maker Of Calvin Klein Women's Line
description: The battle for America's women's clothing market is heating up.

title: Sound Is the Driver in a Race for Death
description: It's not every day that you can step into the same plot twice. ''The Sound of a Voice,'' a new opera with music by Philip Glass and libretto by David Henry Hwang, presented in a premiere by the American Repertory Theater at the Loeb Drama Center here, is a twice-told tale.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: General Blames Washington
description: A general forced out of the army after two tons of cocaine disappeared on his watch said at a Colombian congressional hearing that the United States pressured the military to dismiss him. The Colombian media reported that the American government believed that the general, Gabriel Ramn Diaz, might have given safe passage to right-wing paramilitaries who were trafficking the cocaine. Military officials denied the missing cocaine or paramilitary ties had anything to do with the retirement. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Moving to Columbia From N.Y.U.
description: ROBIN D. G. KELLEY, below, an African-American studies scholar and chairman of New York University's history department, is moving to Columbia, where he will join the anthropology department and help shape programs for the university's Institute for Research in African-American Studies. Dr. Kelley said that it was a difficult decision, but he was attracted by the faculty in African-American Studies and Jazz Studies at Columbia and viewed the programs as "two of the most exciting intellectual spaces in the country."

title: Newark Couple Found Dead; Police Question Teenage Son
description: A couple were found dead at their apartment in Newark yesterday, and their troubled 17-year-old son was being questioned about their deaths, the authorities said.

title: Pandemonium Mars Graduation For Brooklyn Elementary School
description: A Brooklyn elementary school graduation became a scene of pandemonium yesterday when members of an overflow crowd, angered by being left outside, confronted at least one security officer and were hit with pepper spray, witnesses said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man And Son Are Shot; Son Dies
description: A man and his adult son were shot in front of a Harlem restaurant late Monday evening, and the son has died, the police said yesterday. The son, Michael Arnold, 30, of East 126th Street, was pronounced dead at Harlem Hospital Center about 11:20 p.m. on Monday, about an hour after the shooting, the police said. The father's name was not released, but the police said he was about 53 and had lived on West 131st Street. The father was shot in the groin and hand and was listed in serious condition, the police said. A police official said a .40-caliber handgun was used in the shooting. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RODRIGUEZ, , DANIEL JUAN

Beloved son of Adrienne and the late Juan Rodriguez. Loving brother of Ronald. Cherished uncle of Candi and Cristina. Beloved friend of Felicia Shelor. Former wife Patricia Rodriguez also survives him. Former employee of IBM and Dynamix Group. Visitation R. Stutzmann & Son, 2000 Hillside Ave., New Hyde Park, NY, Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Religious service Friday, 8 PM, Pastor David Tucker officiating. Private cremation. In lieu of flowers a donation to a charity of your choice would be appreciated. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: West Nile Spraying Begins
description: The city health department will spray marshy areas in Staten Island with larvicide from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. on Thursday and Friday, weather permitting, to battle mosquitoes that might carry the West Nile virus, department officials said yesterday. Today, the department will begin applying larvicide to 135,000 catch basins around the city. The city will use a low-flying helicopter to spray the marshy areas with VectoLex CG, the same product used last year. One area to be sprayed is bordered by Victory Boulevard and South Avenue, near Edward Curry Avenue.

title: United to Offer E-Mail and Data Access on Domestic Flights
description: United Airlines said today that it would use a system developed by Tenzing Communications, a small technology company in Seattle, for an e-mail service it is planning to install in its North American fleet.

title: . . . Or Was That Order New York Style?
description: THE Eleven Madison hot dogs blow the competition right out of the water. That's to be expected, given the high quality of their ingredients. Both styles of hot dog, New York and Chicago, make the pale tubes sold from most carts seem like congealed meat-flavored mousse.

title: Still Plain-Spoken, Still Writing, and Still Busy
description: THE writer Erica Jong, attended by a black, barking poodle that stands waist high, waits in the wings as her maid flings open the door to a sky-lit sanctuary 27 floors above the Upper East Side: Those who harbor a fear of flying will not feel comfy way up here. But Ms. Jong, a matchmaker of good light and great art -- Rivers, Grooms, Grosz and Calder are illumined au naturel -- is clearly in her element.

title: Creditors Approve Bailout Of SK Global of Korea
description: Brushing aside complaints from foreign investors that their assets were being squandered and their rights trampled, creditors of SK Global, the troubled trading company, approved a $2.5 billion plan to bail it out by exchanging debt for new stock.

title: Lottery Numbers
Man Atop Tappan Zee Bridge Tower Causes 3-Hour Closing
description: A distraught man climbed to the top of the Tappan Zee Bridge's superstructure today and forced the bridge to close for three hours during the morning rush as rescue workers talked him down.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Big Toy Store To Sell
description: Hamleys, the 243-year-old emporium on London's Regent Street that calls itself the world's biggest toy store, said it had agreed to be bought for $80 million by its own managers and the Baugur Group, a leading retailer in Iceland. The purchasers can look forward to acquiring a refurbished store bursting with toys. In unusually hectic trading, shares of Hamleys rose as much as 4 percent, to 202 pence ($3.40), after Baugur and the management team said they would bid 205 pence a share, a figure analysts said was on the high side. Under its new ownership, Hamleys, once compared in size and style to New York's troubled F.A.O. Schwarz, may expand outside Britain and open more of its outlets, called the Bear Factory, where shoppers buy teddy bears of their own design. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOOD, , ROBERT A.
description: GOOD--Robert A. Your life touched enumerable friends, students, colleagues, and patients around the world. Who can ever forget such irrepressible generosity and dedication leading to countless contributions to biomedical science. Babette and Marc Weksler >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: No Cruise Ships For Homeless
description: Because of high refurbishing costs, the city has rejected a plan to place homeless families on refitted cruise ships anchored in New York Harbor. Last summer, when emergency shelters were filled with homeless families, the mayor's office proposed placing some temporarily in retired cruise ships. In November, Linda I. Gibbs, the commissioner of homeless services, visited the Bahamas to inspect unused cruise ships and found the idea promising. But the cost of refitting the floating hotels was too expensive, city officials said yesterday. Also, the upper harbor is too shallow for the huge ships, officials said.

title: I.B.M.'s Opponent in Suit Criticizes Linux Advocate
description: In a new court document, the SCO Group criticizes Linus Torvalds, the guardian of the freely shared Linux operating system.

title: Producer Says 'Sopranos' Will Have A 6th Season
description: ''The Sopranos,'' the most successful series in the history of cable television, will not end with its fifth season but will instead have one more, lasting 10 episodes, Brad Grey, one of the show's executive producers, said last night.

title: More Americans Seeking Help for Depression
description: More than half of the Americans who suffer from depression now seek treatment, up from one-third 10 years ago, a new survey says. Yet nearly 60 percent of the people in treatment do not receive adequate care, the researchers found.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Unemployment Rises
description: The economic damage from the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, this spring became more apparent as Hong Kong's unemployment rate rose to 8.3 percent in the period from March through May, compared with 7.8 percent for February through April. The rate of underemployment -- people who settle for part-time jobs because they cannot find full-time work -- rose to 3.8 percent from 3.2 percent. On May 23, the World Health Organization lifted its advisory against travel to Hong Kong. It will probably remove Hong Kong from its list of areas affected by SARS early next week if Hong Kong maintains its current 14-day streak of no new cases of SARS. But tourism has not recovered and businesses like restaurants and travel agencies are still laying off workers. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: HOLLINGER INVESTIGATES CHARGES OVER EXECUTIVES' PAY
description: Hollinger International, the publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times, said yesterday that it had set up a committee to investigate a shareholder's accusations that the chief executive, Conrad Black, and other managers had used the company to enrich themselves. The committee will be led by an independent Hollinger director, the investment banker Gordon Paris, and advised by Richard C. Breeden, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said. Hollinger is based in Chicago. One of Hollinger's largest investors, the Tweedy Browne Company, questioned in a regulatory filing last week why the company had not yet formed a committee to examine Tweedy Brown's assertions that Mr. Black and other officers had received at least $200 million from management fees and side deals.

title: Under Many Roofs
description: When I first moved to the country, more than a dozen years ago, a realtor showed me a grand old farmhouse with an attached barn. The realtor was dreaming to think that I could afford it. But in the way of too-expensive dreams, the memory of that place has stuck with me, especially the thought of walking through what looked like a closet door off the kitchen and being swallowed by the cavernous maw of a beautiful, well-worn dairy barn. The reason I still think about that place is for the simple pleasure of having the animals so close, so collectively, so cooperatively housed.
