description: Once toast in this town, Hillary Rodham Clinton is now the toast of the town. (Or at least the Venus part.)

title: Too Soon To Tell
description: There was a nice little story out of Iraq the other day. An Irish businessman sent his private jet to Baghdad where it picked up eight Iraqi mentally handicapped athletes who wanted to take part in the Special Olympics, which open this week in Ireland. What makes the story even more poignant is the fact that Saddam Hussein's twisted son Uday had been the head of Iraq's regular Olympic Committee, and was known for torturing Iraqi Olympic athletes who did not perform well. At the Special Olympics everyone counts, and everyone is a winner, just for trying. In the old Iraq it was dangerous to be an Olympic athlete if you did not win. Will it be possible to create a new Iraq where it is safe to be a Special Olympics athlete, where it is safe to be vulnerable?

title: Chef's Second Course Is Food for Thought
description: WD-50 arrives to almost absurdly high expectations. Its progenitor, 71 Clinton Fresh Food, single-handedly turned the Lower East Side into an up-and-coming restaurant neighborhood, and it made Wylie Dufresne an overnight star. The food press, as well as serious diners, awaited the sequel like ''Star Wars'' cultists camped out on the sidewalk of their local theater.

title: Ex-Councilman Sentenced To 4 Years in Bribery Case
description: A former city councilman from Brooklyn was sentenced to four years and four months in prison after petitioning a federal judge for mercy yesterday and apologizing for his part in a bribery and extortion scheme that he called ''the biggest mistake of my life.''

title: Doing Better, Not Best
description: New York State's lawmakers are trying to find something to go home and brag about. The possibilities dwindle by the hour as their session comes to an end on Thursday. But revamping the state's lobbying laws is still doable, and eminently worth doing.

title: White Is Not the Only Color for Summer
description: FARES to Europe are creeping up -- make that skyrocketing up. If you haven't booked your vacation by now you may be shocked when you do. Then you'll feel an aftershock when you buy a few euros with your newly anemic dollars.

description: TURNS out the bowl of cherries that greeted analysts and reporters as they gathered yesterday to hear a revised prediction of advertising spending from the dean of Madison Avenue forecasters was not a leading indicator.

description: Adapted from "Lobster Rolls and Blueberry Pie," by Rebecca Charles and Deborah DiClementi (HarperCollins, 2003)

description: It was an inside job, officials said. That is, inside a Rikers Island jail.

title: Canada Builds a Large Oil Estimate on Sand
description: This year's rankings of oil reserves included a surprise that grabbed the attention of some industry experts: Canada had leaped into second place, increasing its reserves from 5 billion barrels to 180 billion barrels.

title: The Oeuf and I: An Old Love Seems New
description: WHILE people travel for many reasons -- for escape, for adventure, for status, or even for relaxation -- many travel to Paris with a single purpose: to eat.

title: Lewis Is 6-5, but Still Looking Up at Next Opponent
description: When the heavyweight champion Lennox Lewis steps into the ring Saturday against the top contender Vitali Klitschko, it will be one of the odder scenes in recent boxing history. Imagine two sturdy basketball power forwards squaring off against each other.

title: Mostly Asian, but Cheese Steaks, Too
description: M2M, a market at 2935 Broadway (114th Street), is a new source on the Upper West Side for Asian products like sesame pastes, frozen dumplings, kimchi and Korean marinades for meat. The name stands for morning to midnight, the schedule at the store, which opens at 7 a.m. The market is a branch of a larger one at 200 East 11th Street and carries many of the same items. To cater to the Columbia University crowd, it also has a larger deli-style counter with a diverse menu including things like cheese steaks and Asian stir-fries. But for fresh baby octopus, fresh lotus root, short ribs trimmed for Korean dishes or marinated pork ready for the grill, you'll have to try the downtown store.

title: WPP Moves Closer to Accord To Buy British Ad Company
description: The WPP Group and Cordiant Communications said today that they were in ''exclusive and advanced'' negotiations for a merger, signaling that WPP has won the battle for Cordiant, the British-based advertising conglomerate that is a successor to Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: So, That'll Be A Chicago Dog For You . . .
description: THE Eleven Madison Park hot-dog cart has a lot in its favor, not least of which is its perfect urban tableau. Rather than wait on some grimy corner, dodging umbrella-wielding tourists as your hot dog is speared from its warm-water purgatory, you stand in airy, leafy Madison Square Park, where a fountain splashes in the sunshine, children squeal and a jazz band plays. Here is a place to fall in love with New York. How could the hot dogs not be wonderful?

title: Microsoft Sues 15 Organizations In Broad Attack On Spam E-Mail
description: Microsoft, the world's largest provider of e-mail accounts, filed lawsuits yesterday against 15 groups of individuals and companies that it says collectively sent its clients more than two billion unwanted e-mail messages.

title: F.D.A. Backs Flu Vaccine Given by Mist, Not a Needle
description: A flu vaccine that is squirted up the nose rather than injected into an arm was approved by the Food and Drug Administration yesterday, providing a new option for some people who dislike needles.

description: Coca-Cola acknowledged yesterday that employees manipulated the results of a market test of Frozen Coke at Burger King restaurants, confirming one of the accusations raised by a former executive who has sued the company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 19 about the declining crime rate in the Serbian province of Kosovo under an international police force run by the United Nations misstated the composition of the forces that expelled 70,000 ethnic Serbs from Sarajevo during the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The forces included Bosnian Serb and Yugoslav policemen, paramilitaries and vigilantes, not ethnic Muslim policemen.

title: SECRECY IS BACKED ON 9/11 DETAINEES
description: A sharply divided appeals court ruled today that the Justice Department was within its rights when it refused to release the names of more than 700 people arrested for immigration violations in connection with the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation won an order from SES Global's Astra system for two satellites to broadcast television and Internet signals to homes across Europe. The satellites will be built at Lockheed's plant in Newtown, Pa., and launched in 2005 and 2006, a spokesman for Lockheed said. Terms were not disclosed.

The three were separate bits of the 2001 Ionesco Festival and last year's Fringe Festival. At Theater 80 Mr. Einhorn's Untitled Theater Company No. 61 makes them seem siblings in a bright production with witty music and puppets galore.

title: U.S. and U.N. Agency Press Iran on Its Nuclear Program
description: The debate over Iran's nuclear ambitions intensified today at the United Nations' watchdog agency on atomic weapons, as the United States and other countries tried to rally support for a resolution urging Iran to accept stricter supervision of its nuclear program.

title: CHARLES SCHWAB RAISES QUARTERLY PROFIT EXPECTATIONS
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, the biggest discount broker by assets, lifted its second-quarter earnings forecast as customers increased their trading 20 percent in May from April. It opened fewer new accounts after reducing advertising spending. ''We are more encouraged by what we see in our business,'' said Christopher Dodds, the chief financial officer. Mr. Dodds said Schwab's earnings per share would probably exceed current estimates by 1 cent to 2 cents. The company, which is based in San Francisco, is now forecast to earn 7 cents a share, unchanged from a year ago, according to 13 analysts polled by Thomson First Call.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: HARRY POTTER AND THE EMPTY TRUCK Nearly 8,000 copies of the new Harry Potter book, "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix," were lifted from a warehouse just days before its eagerly awaited release. The police in Merseyside were on the hunt for a man who posed as a delivery driver and drove off on Sunday with a truckload of the books intended for stores. The trailer was found a day later, abandoned and empty, 18 miles away. The London-based publisher Bloomsbury warned that anyone who tried to sell or buy the books between now and its official release at midnight on Friday could face criminal charges.    Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: The Humble Bay Leaf Lets Loose
description: ONE thing about bay leaves: they are cheap. A dollar's worth lasts most people years, if not a lifetime. Until, of course, you start using them for more than bouquet garni, soups and stews.

title: Gingrich Again Assails State Department, Calling It 'Broken'
description: The former speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, assailed the State Department today as ''a broken institution,'' and called on President Bush to overhaul the agency to promote democratic values more effectively in a world where anti-American sentiment was on the rise.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Harry Potter and the Empty Truck
description: Nearly 8,000 copies of the new Harry Potter book, ''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix,'' were lifted from a warehouse just days before its eagerly awaited release. The police in Merseyside were on the hunt for a man who posed as a delivery driver and drove off on Sunday with a truckload of the books intended for stores. The trailer was found a day later, abandoned and empty, 18 miles away. The London-based publisher Bloomsbury warned that anyone who tried to sell or buy the books between now and its official release at midnight on Friday could face criminal charges. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Irish Trial Begins for Man Accused of Running Real I.R.A.
description: DUBLIN, June 18  After a year of legal delays, Ireland's antiterrorism court began hearing the trial of the man charged with running the Real I.R.A., the paramilitary group behind the 1998 car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, that killed 29 people and maimed dozens more.

title: Ex-Chairman Of Insurer Won't Testify
description: The former chairman of Ullico, a union-owned insurer, refused to testify yesterday before a Congressional committee investigating accusations that the insurer's board members earned more than $6 million through insider trading.

title: A Nose Job Just Scratches the Surface
description: There is something repellent and possibly even sinful about people getting face-lifts, implants and liposuction on television. But expecting ABC, which introduced ''Extreme Makeover,'' to limit itself to nonsurgical procedures is a little like asking nations not to develop nuclear weapons after scientists have split the atom -- sweet, but silly.

title: Interim Executive Takes Over
description: Cornell University named JOHN NEUMAN as chief executive of eCornell, its three-year-old for-profit distance-learning subsidiary. He has been interim chief executive since last November, when FRANCIS PANDOLFI resigned for health reasons. Before joining eCornell, Mr. Neuman was president and chief executive of his own company, 1492 Consulting Group. He has also worked for other consulting firms, including McKinsey & Company, where he was a partner.

title: How Europe Can Stop the Hate
description: Anti-Semitism is the Western world's oldest and most persistent species of hatred. There are larger and more widespread minority groups than Jews -- at 13 million, they comprise about 0.2 percent of the world's population -- but the Holocaust made clear how virulent hatred of them has been. To the extent that anti-Semitism persists, we have yet to fulfill the promise of ''Never Again'' to those who were martyred.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Competition Rankings
description: Europe's competition regulators rank fourth in the world, behind the United States, Germany and Britain, according to a new survey by the British trade journal Global Competition Review. The commission was considered weaker in economics than its American counterparts. This weakness was highlighted last year when the European Commission lost three court cases. The commission was also seen as more instinctively interventionist than the American authorities, according to the survey, which covered 500 executives, lawyers and competition officials. Last year the commission levied about 944 million euros ($1.11 billion) in antitrust fines. American officials levied $102 million in fines. American antitrust procedures, however, were regarded as less open than European procedures and more prone to political interference, the survey said. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Butterworth Memorial
description: A public memorial service for the Rev. Eric Butterworth, a popular minister of the Unity religious movement, is scheduled for 11 a.m. on Sunday in Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center, where he preached. Mr. Butterworth died on April 17 at the age of 86.

title: Experts Say Burial Box for 'Brother of Jesus' Is a Forgery
description: JERUSALEM, June 19  Israel's archaeological experts declared today that an ancient limestone burial box, which bears an inscription suggesting it held the remains of Jesus' brother James, is a modern forgery.

title: Foundations Resist Measure To Increase Charity Money
description: A major trade association for nonprofit organizations here said today that it did not support legislation in the House that would compel foundations to give more money to charity.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Insurance Aid For Rural Doctors
description: The state House has approved a bill intended to offset the costs of malpractice insurance for rural doctors. The measure would set up a $10 million fund to subsidize insurance premiums for doctors, particularly those offering obstetrics. The bill's sponsors contend that large payouts in medical malpractice suits are causing doctors' insurance rates to rise, making it difficult for small rural practices to survive. The bill now goes to the Senate. Dave Miller, a spokesman for Senate Democrats, said it had a good chance of passing. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Newly Confident Amtrak Showing Signs of Revival
description: Screeching, clattering and thumping its way along just south of Wilmington, Del., the Amtrak machine lifted and spread the rails, scooped up the rotting wooden ties beneath, plowed away the gravel, plunked down perfect new concrete ties, gently laid the rails back down, and moved on, leaving tracks on which trains will travel at 125 miles an hour, up from 80 miles per hour now.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Letter To Millions
description: Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin will send a letter to all households explaining the reasons behind the government's plan to overhaul the pension system. The proposed changes have already provoked a wave of strikes, and transport workers, including airline unions, have called for work stoppages tomorrow that are expected to lead to delays and cancellations across France.

description: SOME chefs go into the restaurant business because their childhoods were filled with bad food. Others are drawn by artistic expression, power, or the adrenaline thrill of a kitchen at full tilt on a Saturday night.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: NEW CHIEF AT TELECOM COMPANY Richard Li, the son of Li Ka-Shing, Hong Kong's richest person, will step down as chief executive of PCCW, the telephone company, but will remain chairman, the company said. Jack So, the chief executive of the MTR Corporation, which operates Hong Kong's subway system, will succeed Mr. Li but will hold a different title as group managing director. He will also become deputy chairman. Mr. So will assume his new posts by Sept. 24. PCCW is the biggest provider of fixed-line telephone services in Hong Kong but has been struggling with a heavy debt load. Mr. Li said two years ago that he would find a new chief executive, and the company acknowledged publicly last month that it was talking with Mr. So.

title: Acevedo Lands in Toronto
description: Juan Acevedo, the reliever who lost a one-run lead in Roger Clemens's third attempt to win his 300th game and was released the next day, signed a contract yesterday with the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Oracle Raises Its Hostile Bid for PeopleSoft by 22%

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: FORMER CANDIDATES SEEK DEBATE REFORM Some former third-party presidential candidates who were excluded from debates in 2000, including Ralph Nader of the Green Party and Patrick J. Buchanan of the Reform Party, are seeking to change the way the debates are run in 2004. In a complaint to the Federal Election Commission, they contend that the Commission on Presidential Debates cannot legally sponsor the forums because it acts in a partisan manner by restricting them to only Republican and Democratic candidates. Election law requires that the group organizing the debates, which has been the commission since 1988, be nonprofit and nonpartisan.

title: Police Chief Who Led Sniper Case Quits in Book Dispute

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Up
description: German business confidence kept rising in June, according to a survey of analysts and institutional investors released by the ZWE Center for European Economic Research. The institute's index that measures expectations for economic growth rose 2.6 points, to 21.3 points, the sixth consecutive monthly rise, which exceeded by far most forecasts by economists. The center said the recent interest rate cut by the European Central Bank had bolstered hope for an economic recovery in Germany. Petra Kappl (NYT)

description: A group of large employers headed by Ford Motor, Honeywell, General Mills and PepsiCo announced a campaign yesterday to encourage overweight workers to slim down as a way to improve both their personal health and the corporate bottom line.

title: An Ill Wind Blows Up a Juicy Treat
description: Abumper crop of fresh litchis from Florida, some 2 million pounds, is making its way into stores for an appearance that will be all too brief. These fruit, shown far larger than the normal strawberry size, are thin-skinned, easily peeled and dripping with lush, highly perfumed pulp. Chill them to nibble whole, or remove the pits and use them in a fruit salad or to make sorbet. Always wash the outside before peeling. This harvest is the biggest since farmers in South Florida began planting litchi trees to replace less profitable crops after Hurricane Andrew struck in 1992. Supermarkets have them for as little as $4 a pound (about 18 litchis).

title: Moving to Columbia From N.Y.U.
description: ROBIN D. G. KELLEY, below, an African-American studies scholar and chairman of New York University's history department, is moving to Columbia, where he will join the anthropology department and help shape programs for the university's Institute for Research in African-American Studies. Dr. Kelley said that it was a difficult decision, but he was attracted by the faculty in African-American Studies and Jazz Studies at Columbia and viewed the programs as ''two of the most exciting intellectual spaces in the country.''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Nortel-Unefon Dispute Settled
description: Nortel Networks, the Canadian telecommunications equipment supplier, and the Mexican wireless operator Unefon have agreed to drop lawsuits against each other and resolve disputes over debt repayment, financing and equipment supply. Unefon will make a $43 million payment to Nortel, reducing its debt to $325 million. That debt will be bought by an unnamed private investor group and restructured to mature in 2013. The companies also signed a five-year supply agreement. Unefon agreed to a minimum purchase of $20 million a year and a target of $40 million. Unefon is one of Mexico's largest wireless operators, and the dispute with Nortel had hampered the company's growth prospects. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

She greeted hundreds of international visitors at the train station with their native flags and a smile. And she gave to nearly every artistic endeavor in town.

After the Organization of American States endorsed Argentina's call for new talks, Foreign Minister Rafael Bielsa was successful in persuading a United Nations committee on decolonization to support it. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Murder Conviction Vacated
description: A federal appeals court panel has ordered a man's murder conviction thrown out, ruling that his right to due process was violated because the main witness against him lied. The man, Ruben Ortega, now 28, was convicted in 1991 of shooting Lionel Diaz to death in Brooklyn, and was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison. His conviction was based largely on the testimony of Dana Garner, whose testimony in another case was subsequently discovered to be false, prompting Mr. Ortega's lawyers to ask that his conviction be set aside, a request that was denied. In their decision on Tuesday, Judges James L. Oakes, Guido Calabresi and Robert D. Sack of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit instructed the trial court to vacate Mr. Ortega's conviction. Yesterday, the Brooklyn district attorney's office announced that it would retry the case. Tina Kelley (NYT)

Stones were falling out of the steep stairs that led up the rocky slopes. When people sat on the benches overlooking the Heather and Perennial Garden, there was no garden to see, except monster yews covered with Virginia creeper. And hundreds of Norway maples blocked the view of the Hudson River and the Palisades.

title: Finding Hope in My Faith
description: On Monday, I resigned my volunteer position as chairman of the national review board of lay Catholics charged with enforcing the zero-tolerance charter against child sexual abuse adopted last year by America's Roman Catholic Bishops. I left, after almost exactly a year of service, for two reasons: the need to devote full time to my job, and frustration over the efforts of a small minority of church leaders to obstruct the workings of the board.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIP: HIGH SCHOOL STUDENT STABBED A sophomore at Franklin Township High School was stabbed yesterday after he tried to stop an argument between two other students, the authorities said. The victim, identified as Teron Fuller, 18, was reported in stable condition after undergoing surgery for a collapsed lung and internal bleeding at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick. Moments after he intervened in the argument, in a hallway outside the gymnasium on the last day of the school year, a fourth person came up behind him and stabbed him twice in the back, said the Somerset County prosecutor, Wayne J. Forrest. The police were searching last night for the assailant, whose name was not released.

In soccer games, played on dusty fields by barefoot boys with a homemade ball of plastic bags and twine, his pale feet stood out.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: COURT ASKED TO UPHOLD MICROSOFT SETTLEMENT The federal government yesterday urged an appeals court to uphold its landmark antitrust settlement with the Microsoft Corporation against an attempted challenge of the pact by two computer trade groups. The Justice Department asked the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia to uphold a lower court ruling that the Computer and Communications Industry Association and the Software and Information Industry Association lacked legal standing to challenge the settlement. The two groups had filed friend-of-the-court briefs with Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly arguing in favor of stricter sanctions against Microsoft. In January, Judge Kollar-Kotelly said the trade groups could file a private case against the world's biggest software company if they wanted to pursue the matter further. The appeals court had ruled in June 2001 that Microsoft had illegally maintained its Windows operating system monopoly, but rejected a trial court proposal to break the company in two. In the settlement approved by Judge Kollar-Kotelly last year, Microsoft agreed to measures that include giving computer makers greater freedom to feature rival software by allowing them to hide some Microsoft icons on the Windows desktop. (Reuters)

Similar conditions are suspected in a February explosion and fire that killed seven workers at an insulation factory in Corbin, Ky., board members said.    Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Olympic Executive Named

Ms. Cassani was head of Go until its takeover by its rival EasyJet last year. London is competing with other cities including New York, Paris and Moscow to be the host of the games. The International Olympic Committee is to choose the city by July 2005. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Canada's Celebration of Marriage
description: The landmark ruling came down from the north with some of the simple delight of a June wedding announcement: ''Same-sex couples are capable of forming long, lasting, loving and intimate relationships.'' In unanimously affirming the obvious, an Ontario appeals court opened the way for Canada to end the bar on marriage between partners of the same sex. Final approval of a milestone law striking down discrimination against gay couples is expected within months. But the northward flow by gay couples from the United States has already begun. Canada has no residency requirements for love-struck people intent on marriage, while Belgium and the Netherlands enacted tighter restrictions in pioneering legal gay unions.

The woman, who is in her 30's, testified in Criminal Court that she had gone to see the priest, the Rev. Cyriacus Udegbulem, 38, for advice about annulling her marriage. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Terror Trial Begins
description: After a year of legal delay, Ireland's antiterrorism court began the trial of Michael McKevitt, charged with running the Real I.R.A., the paramilitary group behind the 1998 car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, that killed 29 people. It was the deadliest bombing in the province's 30-year sectarian conflict. Mr. McKevitt, 53, is accused of directing a terrorist group. He faces a possible life sentence if convicted by the three-judge court. Much of the case relies on evidence from an American, David Rupert, an F.B.I. informer. The trial is expected to last at least six weeks. Brian Lavery (NYT)

The governor originally opposed the bill, fearing that it granted the Game Board too much discretion in granting permits, but he was satisfied with the final version, Mr. Manly said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: In Nepal, the Rug Makers Have Been Keeping Busy
description: In the last few months, ABC Carpet & Home has bought 12,000 hand-knotted wool rugs in Nepal, most of them made by Tibetan weavers. ''The prices were too good to pass up,'' Graham Head, the president of ABC, said. ''The rug dealers in Nepal were rug-rich and cash-poor.'' Each week a container of 800 rugs will arrive at ABC. Patterns are not copies of traditional tribal rugs, but are contemporary, like the mosaic 8-by-10-foot rug above ($899). They range from 2 by 4 feet to 12 by 15 feet. Prices are $110 to $5,400. Two years ago, the rugs would have been $250 to $11,000. The sale will continue until all the rugs are sold. ABC Carpet, 888 Broadway (19th Street); (212) 473-3000. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Crooning, Then Growling, The Blues
description: Blues interruptus was the rule at Buddy Guy's scattershot concert on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, a double bill with Los Lobos. Again and again, Mr. Guy started to wring drama from a song. He would reduce it to a near whisper, singing in a smoothly pained voice and playing quiet guitar lines that mewed with suppressed tension. Then he'd open up, letting loose his blues growl and kicking in the distortion. He'd approach the song's payoff of fury or loneliness. And then, just before the cathartic moment, he'd crack a joke, or promise to play blues ''so funky you can smell it'' (a line he used twice) and switch to something else.

title: Ultimate Machines For Serious Gamers
description: IF you want to play state-of-the art computer games in all their glory, not just any computer will do. You need the fastest processor, the best graphics card and the ultimate sound card, plus enough fans and ductwork to keep it all from frying.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Read-Rite Files For Bankruptcy Protection
description: The Read-Rite Corporation, which makes components used in computer disk drives, asked yesterday for bankruptcy court protection while its assets are liquidated. The filing comes as the company's dwindling cash reserves have hurt its ability to buy materials. The company said yesterday in a statement that it was seeking Chapter 7 bankruptcy court protection. It said this month that it had defaulted on a credit agreement with Tennenbaum Capital Partners and that it would extend a furlough for its employees by one week. Read-Rite's cash has declined by 97 percent. The company's shares peaked at $240 in September 1995, and it rejected a $1.23 billion takeover offer in 1997. Read-Rite's shares plummeted 43 cents, or 75 percent, to 14 cents a share yesterday on the Nasdaq. A Read-Rite spokeswoman, Jane Conn, did not immediately return a call.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FITZGERALD, , BROTHER ALOYSIUS, F.S.C.
description: FITZGERALD--Brother Aloysius, F.S.C., June 17th, 2003. Retired Professor of Biblical Studies at Manhattan College and the Catholic University of America. Son of the late Walter and Rose Brady Fitzgerald. Brother of Walter and John Fitzgerald. Uncle of Tracey Sullivan, Joan Clarke and Pamela Fitzgerald. Family will receive friends at the Christian Brothers Center, 4415 Post Road, Bronx, NY, from 2-5 and 7-9 PM on Friday, June 20. Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of the Visitation, Van Cortlandt Park South, Bronx, NY, at 10 AM on Saturday, June 21. Burial in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. >>AD#

title: 30 Linked To Terrorism Stayed in U.S., Report Says
description: Thirty foreign visitors linked to terrorism were allowed to enter the country and to remain here even though their visas had been revoked by the State Department, Congressional investigators reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FENSTER, , MILTON
description: FENSTER--Milton. The LeFrak family always has taken great pride in calling Milton Fenster our friend. We extend our deepest condolences to Lillian, Randy and Barbara. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Rate Cut
description: Brazil's central bank reduced its benchmark interest rate for the first time in a year in a bid to spur economic growth after rising borrowing costs slowed investment and consumer demand. The bank's monetary policy committee, meeting in Braslia, lowered the so-called Selic overnight target rate to 26 percent from 26.5 percent, saying it is convinced that inflation, which has been running at the fastest rate in seven years, is beginning to slow.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: GEMSTAR TO QUIT ELECTRONIC BOOK BUSINESS Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc. , the television programming guide company that once aspired to be the top electronic book supplier, said yesterday that it would quit that business in July. It also said that it had stopped selling devices to read e-books. Gemstar, which had said for months that it would consider options like an outright sale of its e-book business, said it would refund unused parts of prepaid subscriptions. Customers of the service paid to download and read e-books with a portable tabletlike device called a reader. Customers can continue to download books that they have already bought for another three years, Gemstar said. For more than a year, Gemstar has been under a cloud, battered by write-downs for the value of its TV Guide business, losses in major patent disputes and questions over its accounting practices. (Reuters)

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Monday about efforts by CBS News to arrange an interview with Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch misstated the given name of the spokesman for the West Virginia Department of Military Affairs who is helping her family with media requests. He is Randy Coleman, not Ron.

title: Woods, and Not Furyk, Is Still the Focus at the Buick
description: No matter what happens at the Buick Classic this week, don't expect Jim Furyk to be upset.

title: Tableware To Gratify Every Fussy Eater
description: If you and your fianc eat only salads, you may not want a five-piece place setting for your wedding. The ceramist Teresa Chang (far left) is happy to come up with whatever combination a couple wants. Ms. Chang, who hand-throws porcelain plates, cups and bowls, once had a wholesale business in Brooklyn. When she and her husband relocated to Philadelphia, she made her business more personal. Couples who register are sent samples to try at home, assuring eternal bliss, at least with their plates. In a new Jasmine collection (above), a bread plate is $30, and a 14-inch platter is $145. For stores and information, www.teresachang.com; for an appointment, (215) 627-4070.

title: In Defense of Boredom
description: To the Editor:

title: Rank Group Plans Hard Rock's Growth
description: The Rank Group said today that it was expanding its Hard Rock Hotels concept across Europe and the Americas through a joint venture with Sol Melia of Spain.

title: Iraqis Were Set to Vote, But U.S. Wielded a Veto
description: American marines had built makeshift wooden ballot boxes. An Army reserve unit from Green Bay, Wis., had conducted a voter registration drive. And Iraqi political candidates had blanketed the city with colorful fliers outlining their election platforms -- restore electricity, rehabilitate the old quarter, repave roads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEALS, , JARRETT TAHIR
description: SEALS--Jarrett Tahir. Suddenly, on June 9, 2003. Survived by his mother Joanettia Grier, father Jerry Seals, brother Kylan, sister Kia, aunts, uncles, cousins and friends. Memorial service June 21, 10:30 AM at The Riverside Church in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers donations to the Livengrin Foundation Scholarship Fund. >>AD#

title: Recording, In Flavors Of DVD
description: Q.How many Microsoft programmers does it take to screw in a light bulb?

title: The Liberty Bell's Stress Test
description: THIS fall, as part of improvements to Independence Mall in Philadelphia, the Liberty Bell will be moved from its glass pavilion to a new building 200 yards down the street. It's a tricky proposition for the movers, who want to avoid damaging the bell beyond its famous crack.

title: Trial Date Set in Martha Stewart's Criminal Case
description: The criminal trial of Martha Stewart is scheduled to begin on Jan. 12, a federal judge ordered today.

title: A Poor Man's Air Force
description: CAMP DOHA, Kuwait, JUNE 19  The Iraqi missile strike last March at Camp Commando, the Marine headquarters in Kuwait, is one of the most intriguing and overlooked aspects of the Iraq war.

title: INSIDE
description: Italy Shields Berlusconi

title: Blond Ambition On Red Brick
description: LATELY, Richard Meier has been reclaiming the rare quality that he started out with. I mean the quality of radiance: the Apollonian virtues of clarity, order, simplicity and light.

title: Ignoring Classical Tradition For a Revel in Pure Sound
description: Bang on a Can, the loose federation of composers and sometime commissioners of their pieces, can be described only by what it is not. Defenders of tradition, champions of rational systems, scientists of music and saviors of the future are some of the descriptions that do not fit. Academia and its solemnities of purpose are not to be seen at its events. Saturday night's gathering at Symphony Space, where seven pieces by five composers were played, seemed more like a conclave of truants: unsupervised and doing happily what they wanted.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: House Votes to Eliminate The Federal Estate Tax

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Young Woman Slain
description: A 19-year-old woman was found stabbed to death yesterday in her studio apartment at 1099 First Avenue near 60th Street, the police said. The woman, whose name was not released yesterday, had multiple stab wounds, and was last seen alive on Tuesday, a law enforcement official said. Several neighbors said that the woman had been there only a short time, and one, Patrick Zack, said that tenants tended to move in and out frequently, often staying as little as a month. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: U.N. Atomic Agency Urges Iran to Allow Wider Inspections
description: VIENNA, June 19  The International Atomic Energy Agency called on Iran today to allow stricter inspections of the nuclear reactor sites that the United States has asserted are being used to develop atomic weapons.

title: Where Is Everybody? The Wireless Network Might Know
description: FOR most people, Wi-Fi networks are useful for doing work in coffee shops or allowing computers to share an Internet connection at home. But for Iris Junglas and several other researchers, wireless networks are also capable of keeping tabs on wandering computer users.

title: In Defense of Boredom
description: To the Editor:

title: Times Co. Says Earnings Will Not Meet Analysts' Estimates
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter and all of 2003 would fall short of analysts' estimates because of weak advertising demand and higher-than-expected costs. Shares of the company fell 6 percent, their biggest one-day drop since just after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in 2001.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Negotiation Over Journalist
description: The chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, has asked the Indonesian government to ensure the safety of an American freelance journalist who says he fears that the Indonesian military will kill or arrest him if he tries to leave a rebel area in the northern province of Aceh. Indonesian military officials have said they want to question the journalist, William Nessen, 46, who had been encouraged by the military to meet a deadline of last Saturday to leave the area. From his cellphone, he has set several conditions for leaving, including the presence of an American official. ''I have asked for safe passage out of Indonesia,'' Mr. Nessen said. ''Ideally I would like to get in an embassy car and drive out.'' Jane Perlez (NYT)

title: The World's Fastest Man Is Knocked Off Stride
description: As Maurice Greene, the reigning Olympic champion at 100 meters and the former world record-holder in 9.79 seconds, stood at the lectern during a news conference today, a hand went up in back of the room.

title: Economic Scene; Vertical integration worked well in its day; now companies thrive by turning to specialists.
description: SEARS is selling its credit card division, almost certainly to a specialized financial business. To let customers charge their purchases, retailers no longer have to run their own credit operations. Dell Computer doesn't make its own hardware. It assembles circuit boards and disk drives from specialized manufacturers.

title: Scientists Deciphering Atomic Forces Report Hottest, Densest Matter Ever Observed
description: Experiments at the Brookhaven National Laboratory have created the hottest, densest matter ever observed, recreating conditions a fraction of a second after the birth of the universe, scientists announced today.

title: A Democrat Is Wary of Appearing Too Partisan Over White House Handling of Iraq
description: Republican and Democratic leaders in the Senate were locked in a tense, closed-door struggle today over how aggressively to investigate the Bush administration's handling of pre-war intelligence on Iraq.

title: Accounts
description: * Information Technology Solution Providers Alliance, Dallas, an organization of technology companies that was founded this year, to the Richards Group, Dallas, to handle its first brand advertising campaign. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million.

title: Judge Rules Against Wal-Mart On Refusal to Talk to Workers
description: A judge with the National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday that Wal-Mart broke the law by refusing to bargain with meat department workers at its store in Jacksonville, Tex.

title: Stolichnaya shifts campaign from subtle to hard-selling.
description: LITTLE more than a year after introducing a tasteful, low-key campaign for Stolichnaya vodka centered on origami, the brand's North American distributor is abandoning the effort in favor of an amped-up, harder-selling approach.

title: Cable Operator Near Terms To Accept Chairman's Loan
description: Charter Communications, the nation's third-largest cable operator, is close to announcing that it has arranged a mechanism for accepting a $300 million loan from its chairman, Paul G. Allen, according to several industry experts close to the situation.

title: Head to Head; For $2,000 or More, 4 Smooth Operators
description: IN a test of performance, top-of-the-line PC's from Voodoo, Alienware, Falcon and Hypersonic that were used to play Medal of Honor: Allied Assault and Rainbow Six 3 all ran the games at maximum settings and resolutions without a hitch.

title: Roaming TV Set Chats With Command Central
description: With all the accouterments tethered to the TV these days -- DVD players, VCR's, cable boxes -- most people would never think of toting the set from room to room. But a new flat-panel TV from Sharp bring portability to channel surfing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRASNOW, , MIRIAM
description: KRASNOW -- Miriam. Died peacefully in her 96th year. June 18, 2003. Graveside services at Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, New Jersey, Friday, June 20, at 1:30 PM. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELERNT, , JULES, PHD
description: GELERNT--Jules, PhD, 74, of Monroe Twp., NJ (formerly of The Bronx) on June 17, 2003. Retired Professor of English & Comparative Literature and former Chair of English Department of Brooklyn College. Professor Gelernt received his BA and MA in English from City College, and PhD in English & Comparative Literature from Columbia University. His teaching career spanned more than 45 years, continuing after his official retirement, and also extended to his children and grandchildren. Husband of Rosalie (Sacks). Father of Mark David Gelernt and his wife Jana and Karen Gelernt and her husband Moshe BenEzra. Grandfather of Anya, Eva and Edward Gelernt and Sara and Ariel Ben-Ezra. Memorial gifts may be made to National Public Radio or PBS. Services were private. For information Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAYLOR, , SUSANNE
description: TAYLOR--Susanne, 58, died June 17th at her home in Ambler, PA. She is survived by her partner, Dene Harris, her mother, Gladys Lawrence, three siblings, six children, Mary Margaret Bruni, William, Melissa, Susan, Katherine, Thomas Francis Monser, 12 grandchildren. Memorial service will be held Saturday, June 21, at 11AM, at the Emil J. Ciavarelli Family Funeral Homes, 951 E. Butler Pike, Ambler, PA. Visitation from 10-11 AM at funeral home. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, , LEON
description: ROSEN--Leon. Your mentorship, charisma and indefatigable intensity will live on. Randy Ginsburg Glatt >>AD#

title: Remembering the Rosenbergs
description: Today, or, more precisely, a few minutes past 8 p.m. tonight, marks the 50th anniversary of the deaths of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg in the electric chair at Sing Sing. The Rosenbergs, who maintained their innocence to the end, were convicted of conspiring to pass atomic secrets to the Soviet Union, a crime the judge declared ''worse than murder.'' It now seems clear the Rosenbergs were neither as innocent as they claimed nor as guilty as the government alleged.

title: On Health Care, Maine Leads
description: At a time when many states are scrambling to reduce their medical expenditures because of looming budget deficits, Maine has taken the opposite course with a program to provide health insurance for all of the state's uninsured residents. A bill approved by the Legislature this month seeks to make insurance affordable and readily available to all those who don't have it while taking steps to control health care costs and improve its quality. The plan is notable for its boldness in a period of great budgetary gloom in most state capitals.

title: House Votes to End Federal Estate Tax as Senate Battle Looms
description: The House voted today to eliminate the federal estate tax, the third time in a month that Republicans have approved a large tax-cut bill over objections from Democrats that the government is being deprived of its lifeblood.

title: Biological Hazards Ahead
description: The recent arrivals in North America of SARS and monkeypox have understandably alarmed us all. But they should not have surprised us. We already knew that an inevitable side effect of globalization is that emerging infectious diseases can spread more rapidly. We already knew that many human diseases have their origin in close contact between people and domesticated animals. Those considerations have informed public health policy for decades.

title: Ohio Truck Driver Pleads Guilty in Plot With Ties to Al Qaeda
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  Federal law enforcement officials said today that they had uncovered a plot by operatives of Al Qaeda, using an Ohio truck driver as a scout, to destroy the Brooklyn Bridge and other targets as recently as March.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Franklin Township: High School Student Stabbed
description: A sophomore at Franklin Township High School was stabbed yesterday after he tried to stop an argument between two other students, the authorities said. The victim, identified as Teron Fuller, 18, was reported in stable condition after undergoing surgery for a collapsed lung and internal bleeding at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick. Moments after he intervened in the argument, in a hallway outside the gymnasium on the last day of the school year, a fourth person came up behind him and stabbed him twice in the back, said the Somerset County prosecutor, Wayne J. Forrest. The police were searching last night for the assailant, whose name was not released.

title: Editorial Observer; Lights Out Again for Gray Davis? A Wealthy Californian Leads a Recall
description: Feeding off frustration with California's economic crisis, a Republican-backed effort to recall Gov. Gray Davis has gained steam in recent weeks. One poll indicates 51 percent of Californians want to get rid of Mr. Davis, whose approval ratings have plummeted to 21 percent.

title: Mora Hits the Right Spots
description: Once a day, Melvin Mora lets himself enjoy what he has already accomplished for the Baltimore Orioles in a season that has unfolded beautifully and unexpectedly for him. Once a day, Mora peeks at the American League leaders in batting average and sees his name, the name of a plucky but never superb player, listed above everyone else.

title: Report Says More Farmers Don't Follow Biotech Rule
description: A new study, drawn from government data, shows that more farmers are failing to comply with standards governing the planting of genetically modified corn than the industry has claimed.

title: Reyes Impresses and Sparks the Mets
description: Jos Reyes, the Mets' promising young shortstop, continued to make a compelling case to stay in the major leagues tonight.

title: The International Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Inspired by Freedom and the King Legacy
description: Sherman Watkins was overseas in the Air Force during much of the civil rights movement, but when he returned, he felt compelled to paint the era and its leader, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., even though it meant years of hardship.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Tighter Controls On Police
description: Chinese officials plan to reduce the far-reaching powers of the police to detain migrant workers, an apparent concession to public outrage over the death of Sun Zhigang, 27, a graphic artist beaten to death in custody in March. Legal scholars used the case to petition the government to overhaul the system of controlling China's floating population, numbering in the tens of millions. Under current rules, big-city police officers have broad leeway to apprehend, fine and expel outsiders who do not have temporary residential permits. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: $6.5 Million Being Invested In a Venture On Solar Cells
description: A start-up company that is working to develop and produce cheaper solar cells says it will announce today that it has raised $6.5 million from two leading venture capital firms.

title: Congress Examines Tobacco Donations
description: The U.S. Smokeless Tobacco Company, which sells brands like Copenhagen and Skoal, is coming under scrutiny from members of Congress after the company donated snuff to marines in Iraq and ran print ads to publicize the gifts.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Thursday about cakes designed by artists and architects for the Greyston Bakery in Yonkers omitted one designer of a cake bearing a map of New York. It was by Rick Meyerowitz as well as Maira Kalman.

title: The Wind Steals a Moment in 'Lammermoor'
description: It was a classic scene of summer in New York: love, betrayal and murder ringing out over the Great Lawn while thousands of music lovers lay back on blankets under the darkening sky. Only one thing was missing on Monday night when the Metropolitan Opera presented Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' in Central Park: the summer.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Tuesday about an agreement between the United States and the European Union to pool their research efforts into hydrogen fuel cells misstated the United States' action on the Kyoto Protocol, an international treaty calling for sharp reductions in carbon dioxide emissions. The United States did sign the treaty but later rejected it.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Archer Wins Parole
description: Jeffrey Archer, the millionaire novelist, member of the House of Lords and former Conservative party deputy chairman, has been granted parole and will be released from prison next month after serving half of his four-year sentence, the parole board said. Lord Archer, 63, was convicted in 2001 of perjury and perverting the course of justice in his 1987 libel trail against a London newspaper that reported he had paid hush money to a prostitute. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Iranian Rebels Try Suicide By Fire In France
description: Several Iranians set themselves on fire today to protest a sweeping crackdown by France against a long-established armed organization whose goal is the overthrow of Iran's Islamic Republic.

title: Jessica Lynch's Ordeal
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TRUCKMAKER FORECASTS GAIN A leading Japanese truckmaker, the Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation, said it expected profit to more than triple in the year that began in April, helped by demand for new, cleaner diesel trucks. Mitsubishi Fuso said it would earn 5 billion yen ($42 million) this year with truck sales expected to grow 3 percent over all. DaimlerChrysler owns 43 percent of the company. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Selects Chief
description: Britannic, a British life insurer, said the finance director, Paul Thompson, would become chief executive on July 1, replacing Bryan Portman, who held the title of managing director. Mr. Thompson, a former investment banker with Merrill Lynch, will be the fourth person to take over the top position since 1997. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: FINDWHAT.COM RAISES TARGETS; SHARES SURGE FindWhat.com, which owns the FindWhat.com Internet ad- vertising service, raised its second-quarter estimates yesterday and said that it planned to buy Espotting Media Inc. for about $163 million. FindWhat.com shares rose more than 36 percent. The company, which is based in Fort Myers, Fla., said that profit was expected to be 11 cents a share on sales of $17 million. FindWhat.com's previous forecast was for profit of 10 cents a share on $16 million in sales. Shares of FindWhat.com rose $4.88, to $18.57, in Nasdaq trading. Holders of Espotting will get about 8.1 million shares of FindWhat.com common stock and $27 million in cash, FindWhat.com said. Espotting operates Internet marketing services for companies. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter, FindWhat.com said. FindWhat.com helps advertisers promote their business on the Internet. (Bloomberg News)

title: 'Unraveled' by Sex Abuse Crisis In Diocese, Phoenix Bishop Quits
description: Bishop Thomas J. O'Brien of the Phoenix Diocese resigned today, succumbing to a year of turmoil over the sexual abuse crisis in the church and the more personal disgrace of being arrested in a fatal hit-and-run accident.

title: Libeskind to Control Design Of Trade Center's Terminal
description: The architect Daniel Libeskind will set the design guidelines for the new transportation terminal at the World Trade Center site, according to an agreement reached with rebuilding officials yesterday, partly settling an ongoing dispute over Mr. Libeskind's formal role in the rebuilding effort.

title: Gore Reportedly Has Set Sights On Creation of a Cable Network
description: After giving up on making another run for president -- at least this time around -- Al Gore is pondering the life of a media mogul.

title: Long Session in Albany Ends With No Deal on Drug Laws
description: As the clock wound down on the legislative session, leaders of the Assembly and the Senate met for seven hours with the governor and a hip-hop impresario, Russell Simmons, in an unusual attempt to come up with a compromise on overhauling the state's drug sentencing laws.

title: McGreevey And G.O.P. Are at Odds Over Taxes
description: With New Jersey legislators scheduled to begin a series of crucial budget votes on Thursday, Republican lawmakers and the McGreevey administration accused each other today of advocating spending plans that would lead to higher property taxes for homeowners.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on June 10 about the treatment of heart failure with pumps known as ventricular assist devices omitted the primary affiliation of Dr. O. H. Frazier. He is chief of cardiopulmonary transplantation at the Texas Heart Institute, St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital, in Houston.

title: Quebec Pulls Back Business Supports
description: The newly elected Liberal government in Quebec is taking steps that signal a profound change in the province's business climate.

title: Visit by Real Madrid Expected Next Year
description: David Beckham will not be coming to the United States on Manchester United's four-game tour this summer after his transfer to Real Madrid, but he and his new teammates will almost certainly play a series of games in the United States next year.

title: Hamelss Command Belies His Age
description: The Tampa Bay Devil Rays have struggled against pitchers young and old this week. O.K., not against Jeff Weaver of the Yankees, but on Monday 19-year-old Cole Hamels gave the Devil Rays fits and on Wednesday 40-year-old Roger Clemens carried a no-hitter into the eighth inning against Tampa Bay.

title: Banker Cleared, Easing Way to Head European Bank
description: The governor of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, was acquitted by a Paris court today of charges that he helped the French bank Crdit Lyonnais manipulate its accounts before it collapsed in the early 1990's, when he was director of the French treasury.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Company Faces Food Safety Charges
description: Federal prosecutors announced charges against LaGrou Distribution System, a storage company that held 22 million pounds of meat, fish and other foods in what they say was a rat-infested warehouse in Chicago. The authorities say company officials lied to customers, saying food had been damaged by forklifts rather than eaten by rats. No illnesses have been traced to the warehouse, which was shut last summer. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about efforts by CBS News to arrange an interview with Pfc. Jessica D. Lynch misstated the given name of the spokesman for the West Virginia Department of Military Affairs who is helping her family with media requests. He is Randy Coleman, not Ron.

title: HUSSEIN'S TOP AIDE HAS BEEN CAUGHT, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
description: In what American intelligence officials regarded as one of the most significant developments in the hunt for Saddam Hussein, military officials said today that they had captured the former Iraqi leader's closest confidant, Abid Hamid Mahmoud al-Tikriti.

title: Among Film's Ghosts, Its Future
description: MISGUIDED tourists regularly troll the seedy sections of Hollywood Boulevard for bits of film industry lore, unaware that the stars and studios left decades ago. But hidden among the homeless and the sex shops is a structure that is as much a part of Hollywood's future as its past.

title: Police in Canada Search 13 Brokerage Firms
description: The Canadian police searched 13 brokerage firms in the Toronto area today as part of an investigation into illegal activity in speculative over-the-counter stocks.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the acquisition of the English soccer star David Beckham by a Spanish club, Real Madrid, misstated his achievements with Manchester United. The team won six English Premier League titles, not eight, with Beckham as a contributor.

title: Campaign Disqualified At Advertising Festival
description: The award presentations at the 50th International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France, got under way with a misfire, as judges disqualified a campaign that had been selected for a Grand Prix in the print category.

title: Rapist of Victims 11 to 79 Is Sought by Police in Miami
description: The Miami Police Department is investigating a serial rapist who has assaulted at least six girls and women in the city's largely Hispanic southwest neighborhood over the last nine months and perhaps as long as three years.

title: Metro Matters; Mrs. Clinton Is Forgiven, But for a Price
description: DURING her big book party at the Four Seasons on Monday, Hillary Rodham Clinton was asked if she found it painful to relive her rough marital days. ''It was difficult,'' she said. ''It, you know, they were very difficult times; they should have remained personal and private matters. But they were pulled into the public so I felt I had to, you know, write about what was part of the public history.''

title: From Finland, Geometric Patterns of the Past
description: Night of the Skylarks (right) and Mambo (far right) are two distinctive wallpapers distributed by Tapettitalo in Helsinki, Finland, and made at the Pihlgren ja Ritola Oy factory, established in 1930. Skylarks is from 1956, by Birger Kaipiainen, a Finnish ceramist; Mambo is from the 1970's. Other patterns are found in the restored home of the composer Jean Sibelius and the atelier of the architect Alvar Aalto, and turn up in period Finnish movies. The rolls (paper, not vinyl) are 20 1/2 inches wide and 33 feet to 37 feet long, depending on style. These two are $49 a roll, plus shipping. Information, www.tapettitalo.fi; for order inquiries, palvelu@tapettitalo.fi.

title: ENERGY WEST SETTLES LAWSUIT OVER SUPPLY CONTRACT
description: Energy West Inc., which sells natural gas and propane in the Rocky Mountain region, said its Energy West Resources unit agreed to pay $3.2 million to settle a lawsuit over an energy-supply agreement with a subsidiary of the PPL Corporation. The settlement, with PPL Montana LLC, includes an initial $1 million payment, with the remaining $2.2 million due by the end of September, Energy West said. Litigation between the two companies will resume should the second payment not be made, with the initial $1 million forfeited, Energy West said. The lawsuit was filed July 2001. Energy West, which is based in Great Falls, Mont., also announced it was cutting its fourth-quarter dividend to conserve cash. The dividend currently is 13.5 cents, with the fiscal year ending in June.

title: Brutal Crime, Long Punishment (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Talks Tax Cuts in a State He Narrowly Lost
description: President Bush today returned to Minnesota, a state he narrowly lost in the 2000 election, to deliver his third speech of the week promoting his tax-relief plan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEALY, , ROBERT JAMES, S.J.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: FindWhat.com Raises Targets; Shares Surge
description: FindWhat.com, which owns the FindWhat.com Internet advertising service, raised its second-quarter estimates yesterday and said that it planned to buy Espotting Media Inc. for about $163 million. FindWhat.com shares rose more than 36 percent. The company, which is based in Fort Myers, Fla., said that profit was expected to be 11 cents a share on sales of $17 million. FindWhat.com's previous forecast was for profit of 10 cents a share on $16 million in sales. Shares of FindWhat.com rose $4.88, to $18.57, in Nasdaq trading. Holders of Espotting will get about 8.1 million shares of FindWhat.com common stock and $27 million in cash, FindWhat.com said. Espotting operates Internet marketing services for companies. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter, FindWhat.com said. FindWhat.com helps advertisers promote their business on the Internet.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: LAWYER DENIES THEFT Sandra E. Roper, left, a lawyer who ran against District Attorney Charles J. Hynes in 2001, was arraigned yesterday in State Supreme Court on felony charges of stealing $9,000 from a client, then lying about it to a state grievance committee. The client, Mary Lee Ward, said that Ms. Roper had agreed to represent her at no charge in a case against a mortgage lender, but instead took $9,000 in refunds placed in escrow. Maranda E. Fritz, a special prosecutor appointed to the case after Mr. Hynes recused himself, said that after Ms. Ward's complaint to the grievance committee, Ms. Roper submitted a forged retainer agreement. Ms. Roper pleaded not guilty to charges of grand larceny, forgery and filing a false instrument, and was released on her own recognizance. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Associated Press Plans Move
description: The Associated Press announced yesterday that it would move its headquarters from Rockefeller Center, where it has been for 65 years, to a site near the Hudson River. The news agency has signed a 15-year lease for more than 290,000 square feet at 450 West 33rd Street, near 10th Avenue. The move consolidates under one roof news and management services that are now spread among four locations in Manhattan. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about an annual survey showing cities with the highest costs of living referred incorrectly to a comparison with New York in last year's rankings. New York, which was seventh, was not more costly than all European cities; Moscow was second.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Tracking Cause Of Explosion
description: Federal investigators said a buildup of flammable plastic powder above a suspended ceiling was the likely cause of an explosion in January that killed six workers and injured dozens more at the West Pharmaceutical Services plant in Kinston. Samples of powder in the ruins ignited in tests, the investigators said. Similar conditions are suspected in a February explosion and fire that killed seven workers at an insulation factory in Corbin, Ky., board members said. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a show house in New York sponsored by eBay misspelled the surname of a participating designer. She is Laura Bohn, not Bonn.

title: F.B.I. Is Retailoring to Meet New Threats but Stretched Thin, Reports Say
description: The F.B.I. has made strong progress in reinventing itself since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, but doubts remain over its long-term ability to balance terrorism investigations with its traditional crime-fighting duties, two major reports concluded today.

title: Steinbrenner Withholds Praise, Torre Asserts
description: Joe Torre has always believed that his first loyalty as Yankees manager is to the players, not to the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner. If an issue with Steinbrenner does not affect his relationship with the players, Torre can usually shrug it off, or at least keep it to himself.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: OPPOSITION FAILS TO TOPPLE PREMIER Prime Minister Mikhail M. Kasyanov survived a no-confidence vote in the lower house of Parliament brought by the Communists and the liberal opposition party, Yabloko. The number of votes required for the motion to pass was 226; it won support from 172 deputies. The parties accuse Mr. Kasyanov and the government of serving big business and failing to help regular Russians, many of whom are mired in poverty. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Isles Pick Up Gloves Off Ice Before Dropping Them on Ice
description: If bobbing and weaving were envisioned in Rick DiPietro's future when the Islanders made him the first goaltender in N.H.L. history to be drafted No. 1 over all three summers ago, it figured to be at flying pucks, not leather-clad fists.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank Layoffs
description: The continued slump in equity trading and mergers has led the Swiss bank UBS to lay off 500 investment bankers worldwide. A company spokesman did not rule out further cuts. Analysts took the news in stride, saying the culling of the work force is a normal part of adjusting to market conditions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hispanic Population Is Rising Swiftly, Census Bureau Says
description: The Census Bureau released new figures today indicating that growth in the Hispanic population continues at a dizzying rate, having increased by nearly 10 percent in the first two years of the new century.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Chief For Advisory Board
description: Tillie K. Fowler, a former Republican member of Congress from Florida, will head the Defense Policy Board, a team of experts and former government officials who are unpaid advisers to the defense secretary. Ms. Fowler will replace Richard N. Perle, who quit as chairman in March after disclosures that his business dealings included a meeting with a Saudi arms dealer. John Files (NYT)

They are the Washington International Horse Show, not the Washington International Home Show; the Paul Robert Carey Foundation, not the Robert Paul Carey Foundation; C.A.F America, not S.A.F. America; and Publicolor, not PublicColors.

title: Peter Redgrove, 71, a Prolific British Poet
description: Peter Redgrove, a prize-winning British poet and author, died on Monday in Falmouth, in southwest England. He was 71.

description: City officials yesterday announced a rezoning plan that would open the crumbling East River sections of Williamsburg and Greenpoint in Brooklyn to housing and recreation.

description: TO Martin Scorsese, technology -- whether a camera or a computer -- is ''a tool.'' He explained, ''You learn to make it work for yourself, to shape and amplify what you want to say.''

title: 4th Grade Readers Improve, but 12th Grade Scores Decline
description: WASHINGTON, June 19  In a new snapshot of the reading ability of American students, the nation's lowest-performing fourth graders showed steady progress through much of the 1990's, while the performance of high school seniors consistently declined.

description: Eric Silver, a top creative executive who abruptly left Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York two weeks ago, has been named to the new post of executive vice president and group creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi in New York.

title: A New Place for NASA To Hang Its Helmets
description: NASA is a sprawling federal agency, with operations centers and laboratories all over the country. It sprawls across the Internet, too, with more than 2,900 public Web sites containing, at last count, a total of four million pages.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Guard Union Re-Elects Chief
description: The New York City Correction Officers' Benevolent Association announced yesterday that its president, Norman Seabrook, had been overwhelmingly re-elected to a third four-year term. Mr. Seabrook, known for having closer ties to Republican politicians than any other New York labor leader, won with 85 percent of the ballots cast in his 8,600-member union. His campaign focused on his successes in getting the Legislature to enact higher pensions for guards. He received 4,013 votes, Emanuel Archibald received 368, Darryl Bryant 153 and Emmanuel Armfield 109. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: No Time for EBay? Here Come the Agents
description: AFTER making the switch from a five-bedroom house in Arizona to a two-bedroom Manhattan apartment, David and Eileen Garrahan found their closets a bit cluttered. A flyer they spotted in the laundry room of their apartment building promised relief, offering to help them convert treasures to cash on eBay without ever turning on a computer.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Holding Company Regroups
description: The SK Group said it would disband the central office through which its jailed chairman, Chey Tae Won, has long controlled his holdings. The group also pledged to reorganize the conglomerate around two central companies, the SK Corporation, Korea's biggest oil refiner, and SK Telecom, Korea's biggest mobile phone provider. Yu Jeong Jun, the chief financial officer of the SK Corporation, said the company expected a net pretax loss of more than $400 million after exchanging for equity more than $700 million of debt owed by SK Global.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Tuesday about plans by Emirates Airline to buy 41 planes from Airbus Industrie misstated the 2002 results of the airline's parent company, Emirates Group. It posted a profit of $285.7 million on revenue of $2.8 billion -- not $2.9 million on revenue of $2 billion.

title: Convicted in Federal Court, Waterbury Ex-Mayor Now Fights State Sex Case
description: Five days after a federal judge sentenced him to 37 years in prison for using his mayoral power to sexually abuse two girls, Philip A. Giordano was returned today to the city he once ran to plead not guilty to similar charges brought by the state.

title: Making It Easier to Clean Up The Mess After Cutting Pizza
description: The innovative pizza wheel (above) is part of a new line of 24 gadgets from Zyliss USA, including peelers, whisks, spatulas and can openers. The design consultant for the line was Ideo, a Palo Alto, Calif., firm, which helped Apple design its first mouse and helped Palm Computing design the Palm V. Thanks to Ideo's study of the difficulty of washing a whisk, the Zyliss wares are easily cleaned, as well as ergonomic and functional. For instance, the usual pizza cutter's handle puts the user's strength off the axis. With the Zyliss pizza wheel, pressure is applied directly. And it swings apart so the blade can be removed for thorough cleaning. The pizza wheel is $9.99 from Linens-n-Things; other gadgets, $4.99 to $14.99. Information, www.lnt.com or (866) 568-7378.

title: Tension Builds as Priests in Abuse Inquiries Await Their Fate

description: Between 20,000 and 30,000 allied troops from more than a dozen nations will begin arriving in Iraq in mid-August to replace some of the American forces leading the military occupation there, Pentagon officials said today.

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC RAILWAY PLANS ADDITIONAL JOB CUTS
description: Canadian Pacific Railway Ltd., Canada's second-biggest railroad, will cut 520 more jobs as it increases cost-reduction efforts and will reduce the value of track it owns in New York State. The moves will lower second-quarter profit by 152 million Canadian dollars ($113 million), the company said. Higher expenses, mostly for fuel, forced Canadian Pacific to eliminate more jobs as part of efforts to cut operating costs to 73 percent of revenue by next year, the chief financial officer, Mike Waites, said. The company said earlier this year that it would cut 300 jobs. The write-down, which is for 75 million Canadian dollars ($56 million), is on the Delaware and Hudson Railway, a line in the United States that the company might sell.

title: Market Place; A Drug Giant Thinks It Can Grow Still Bigger
description: The global pharmaceutical industry is increasingly divided into two camps: Pfizer and everyone else.

title: Study Says Government Has Improperly Detained Foreign Children
description: Foreign children fleeing violence and persecution in their home countries are often improperly detained for months in bleak detention centers in the United States without access to lawyers or psychological services, a study released today said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Truckmaker Forecasts Gain
description: A leading Japanese truckmaker, the Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus Corporation, said it expected profit to more than triple in the year that began in April, helped by demand for new, cleaner diesel trucks. Mitsubishi Fuso said it would earn 5 billion yen ($42 million) this year with truck sales expected to grow 3 percent over all. DaimlerChrysler owns 43 percent of the company. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: How About a Side Cabinet With a Thousand Faces?
description: The Blink Side Cabinet (below) doesn't just sit there looking pretty. As you move around it, ''Blink rewards your efforts with its display of changing colors, patterns and images,'' said the table's designer, Douglas Homer of Downingtown, Pa. Patterns are digitally spliced into thin bands, printed in a repeating sequence, then mounted behind a panel of acrylic lenses, which show only one at a time. Mr. Homer, a graphics designer, once worked on ''Mister Rogers' Neighborhood'' -- hence the playfulness. Blink is 18 inches wide, 24 inches tall and 17 1/2 inches deep, and it costs $2,000. Other styles are $1,850 to $2,300. Custom work is also available. To order, (610) 873-3795.

description: Iran today rejected American accusations that it had been deceitful in not reporting the extent of its nuclear activities to the United Nations' watchdog agency on atomic weapons.

title: Getting the Most Out of Movement
description: Lionel Hoche stood out among the French choreographers in the France Moves 2001 dance festival in New York. Unlike many of his colleagues, he focused more on formal composition and movement exploration than outright theatricality.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Opposition Fails To Topple Premier
description: Prime Minister Mikhail M. Kasyanov survived a no-confidence vote in the lower house of Parliament brought by the Communists and the liberal opposition party, Yabloko.
