title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Judges Move On Basque Party
description: The Supreme Court moved to dissolve Sozialista Abertzaleak, a party accused of links to the separatist guerrilla group E.T.A., after the Basque parliament refused to act against the party. The court has already frozen the bank accounts of the party, considered a successor to Batasuna, a party outlawed by the court in March for its ties to the guerrillas. The judges also ordered the regional parliament's president to keep six elected members of Sozialista Abertzaleak out of parliament and to withdraw public funds granted the party, about $825,000 a year, according to news reports. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: WATERFORD: NUCLEAR FUEL STORAGE Executives at the Millstone nuclear power plant have taken a first step toward an on-site storage center for spent fuel. Millstone officials told federal regulators in December that they planned to build the site to hold spent fuel until a central nuclear waste depository was ready at Yucca Mountain, Nev., probably not before 2010. Plant officials have notified Waterford and East Lyme that they will seek permission to build, perhaps as early as next year. (AP)

title: U.S. Open Prize Money To Surpass $17 Million
description: This year's United States Open will offer a record purse of $17,074,000, organizers confirmed yesterday.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Battling the Beetles

title: Oil Prices Decline as Inventories Register Biggest Rise in 2 Months
description: Crude oil prices fell yesterday after the Energy Department reported the biggest rise in oil inventories in two months, as high prices attracted imports at a near-record pace.

title: Little Progress on Peace, but Reports of an Israeli Pledge
description: A second day of talks between the new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, and Islamic militant groups continued Wednesday with no agreement, amid reports that Israel has promised Washington to confine assassinations to militants it believes are about to carry out attacks.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Israeli Troops Face Protests as They Dismantle Settlement
description: MITZPEH YITZHAR, West Bank, June 19  In repeated scuffles that often resembled a huge rugby scrum, hundreds of Israeli security force members wrestled today with Jewish settlers trying to prevent the dismantling of the first populated settlement targeted under a Mideast peace plan.

title: 118 Charged in A.T.M. Thefts After 9/11
description: More than 100 members of the Municipal Credit Union were charged yesterday with looting hundreds of thousands of dollars from automated teller machines when a computer failure caused by the collapse of the World Trade Center allowed virtually unlimited access to money, prosecutors said.

title: Hey, You Smokers, Try to Keep It Down!
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Major Firms On Wall Street Say Profits Fell Despite Rally
description: Morgan Stanley reported a 25 percent decline in earnings yesterday and demonstrated how vulnerable the big investment banks can be when they depend on an unpredictable trading environment to drive profitability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROVE, , JOHN L.
description: GROVE--John L. Greencastle, PA, renowned entrepreneur and local philanthropist, died on Monday, June 16, 2003 at his home following an extended illness. Mr. Grove was known worldwide in the equipment industry having co-founded Grove Manufacturing Company in 1946 manufacturing the first hydraulic crane. In 1969 he co-founded JLG Industries Inc, which became the world's leading producer of mobile aerial work platforms. He is survived by his wife of sixty years, Cora I. (Wagner) Grove. >>AD#

title: America's Birth Certificate To Be Acquired by Library
description: The Library of Congress said yesterday it had raised the $10 million needed to complete the purchase of the only surviving copy of the 1507 world map that named America.

description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR
description: A Bridge Centenary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERMAN, , RABBI ISRAEL N.
description: SILVERMAN--Rabbi Israel N. The Rabbinical Assembly mourns with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague, rabbi emeritus of Beth Jacob Synagogue, Hamilton, Ontario. We extend our deepest condolences to his family and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. >>AD#

title: Popular Pesticide Faulted for Frogs' Sexual Abnormalities
description: Scientists from the Environmental Protection Agency say there is ''sufficient evidence'' to conclude that the country's most widely used pesticide, atrazine, causes sexual abnormality in frogs.

title: Alchemy Will Turn a Candy Factory Into Biotech Offices
description: Candy hearts will soon be replaced by cancer drugs. The 500,000-square-foot landmark Necco factory building (top right) in Cambridge, Mass., is changing occupants. Necco has moved its operations to Revere, Mass., and the old building, from 1927, will become a state-of-the-art biotech laboratory and offices for Novartis, the Swiss drug maker. The Cambridge architecture firm of Stubbins Associates, (617) 491-6450, is in charge of the conversion, having recently completed a Novartis building near the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The interior -- for 600 scientists, technicians and a support staff -- will have a six-story, amoeba-shaped skylight atrium (drawing, above). ''The sunlight is a metaphor for enlightenment and discovery,'' said Scott Simpson, the principal architect on the project. The open spaces (drawing, above right) and four all-glass elevators will create an open atmosphere unusual at such labs.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Lawyer Denies Theft
description: Sandra E. Roper, left, a lawyer who ran against District Attorney Charles J. Hynes in 2001, was arraigned yesterday in State Supreme Court on felony charges of stealing $9,000 from a client, then lying about it to a state grievance committee. The client, Mary Lee Ward, said that Ms. Roper had agreed to represent her at no charge in a case against a mortgage lender, but instead took $9,000 in refunds placed in escrow. Maranda E. Fritz, a special prosecutor appointed to the case after Mr. Hynes recused himself, said that after Ms. Ward's complaint to the grievance committee, Ms. Roper submitted a forged retainer agreement. Ms. Roper pleaded not guilty to charges of grand larceny, forgery and filing a false instrument, and was released on her own recognizance. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Irish Schools To Get Broadband Connections
description: The Irish government communications minister, Dermot Ahern, said yesterday that he would provide broadband Internet connections for every school, library and community center in Ireland. Speaking after meeting Estonian officials in Tallinn, Estonia, Mr. Ahern said the connections should not cost more than 30 million euros ($35.4 million), and could be financed by a new tax on telecommunications companies. Despite state efforts to promote the Internet, only 38 percent of the Irish population use the Internet. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIDOFF, , MILTON
description: DAVIDOFF--Milton. Lawyer, political activist and soldier, Milton Davidoff died June 11, 2003, at the age of 97. One of New York University Law School's oldest surviving graduates, he was editor of the Law Review in his senior year (1927) and subsequently practiced law in New York City for 60 years. In the 1930s, he ran unsuccessfully for the United States Congress. During WWII, at the age of 38, Milton enlisted in the Army as a Private, became an infantry company commander in European combat and in the early post-war years participated in the reconstruction of Berlin as a Major in military government. He is survived by his daughter, Linda, his son-in-law John Moore, his devoted companion of many years, Suzette Benhamou, a large and adoring extended family and his many friends. ''Uncle Milton'' will be missed by all of us. >>AD#

title: 2 Programs To Vaccinate For Smallpox Come to a Halt
description: Government officials said today that both the civilian and military smallpox vaccination programs had virtually come to a halt, the military program because it has vaccinated everyone it can and the civilian program because few people volunteered for it.

title: Y Chromosome Depends on Itself to Survive
description: Biologists have made a fundamental discovery about how the human Y chromosome, a genetic package inherited by men, protects itself against evolutionary decay.

title: Ex-Freeman Executive At Saatchi & Saatchi
description: Eric Silver, a top creative executive who abruptly left Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York two weeks ago, has been named to the new post of executive vice president and group creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi in New York.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: REPORT BY E.P.A. LEAVES OUT DATA ON CLIMATE CHANGE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is preparing to publish a draft report next week on the state of the environment, but after editing by the White House, a long section describing risks from rising global temperatures has been whittled to a few noncommittal paragraphs.

title: U.S. Soldier Dies as Military Ambulance Is Ambushed in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 19  In the latest in a series of attacks on American troops here, a soldier from the 804th Medical Brigade was killed today when the military ambulance in which he was traveling came under fire from a rocket-propelled grenade. Two other soldiers were wounded, according to a statement from the United States Central Command.

title: Public Service Panel Orders an Audit of Verizon
description: Citing what it said was Verizon New York Inc.'s difficulty in responding quickly to consumer complaints, the state's Public Service Commission voted yesterday to order an independent audit of the telephone company.

title: U.S. Gays Who Marry In Canada Face Hurdles
description: Gay Americans who visit Canada to marry may revel in their newfound status there, but they will come home to a confusing patchwork of overlapping jurisdictions and competing laws and are likely to face a struggle for recognition, legal experts say.

title: Birmingham Journal; Restoring a Broken God Of a City Bedeviled
description: They bolted Vulcan's head back on this morning, and not a day too soon. All that is left now is for the welders and ironworkers to attach his right arm and the freshly forged spear it grasps -- work that is scheduled for Thursday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Strike Starts
description: Chohung Bank's 7,000 workers went on strike to protest the planned sale of the bank to the Shinhan Financial Group. Strikers tried to block access to the bank's headquarters in central Seoul as nonunion workers, including several hundred retirees, were hired to keep most of the bank's 559 branches open. The government has said it will still go through with the sale by the Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Getting Ready to Bow Out, Hans Blix Speaks His Mind On How U.S. Doubted Him
description: Hans Blix, the retiring chief weapons inspector for the United Nations, has questioned in an interview why American and British forces expected to find large stockpiles of chemical and biological weapons in Iraq when it was clear that his inspectors had failed to report any such discovery.

title: Less Media Variety
description: To the Editor:

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY SELLS LARGE STAKE IN GREAT LAKES
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment and insurance conglomerate run by the billionaire Warren Buffett, sold 2.6 million shares of the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation, more than a third of its stake, according to a regulatory filing. Berkshire sold the stock for $20.68 a share on Friday, raising $53.8 million and reducing its holding in the company to 4.3 million shares, Berkshire said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Berkshire, Great Lakes Chemical's third-biggest shareholder as of March 31, held the shares in its Geico insurance subsidiary.

title: Handspring's Gorgeous New Phone
description: The twisted history of Palm Computing just keeps getting more twisted. The latest news is that Palm and Handspring have agreed to merge. PalmPilot creator Jeff Hawkins -- who left Palm three years ago in a fit of corporate frustration, and founded rival Handspring -- will return to Palm as chief technical officer. The only detail left is naming the combined company. (And no, it wont be called PalmSprings.)

title: In Every Alley, Soldiers Search for Household Weapons
description: ''This is the worst place, these back alleyways,'' Capt. Christopher Prussman said. ''There are too many places for people to get at you. This is where it gets dangerous.''

title: U.S. Pilots Avoid Prosecution for Bombing Canadian Troops
description: WASHINGTON, June 19 — The Air Force decided today not to court-martial two pilots who mistakenly dropped bombs on Canadian troops in Afghanistan last year, killing four.

title: Little Progress on Peace, but Reports of an Israeli Pledge
description: GAZA, Thursday, June 19  A second day of talks between the new Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, and Islamic militant groups continued Wednesday with no agreement, amid reports that Israel has promised Washington to confine assassinations to militants it believes are about to carry out attacks.

title: Music Lasts Longer on a Hybrid Player
description: In the battle between pricey pocket MP3 jukeboxes and less expensive portable CD players, the Sony MiniDisc Walkman pops up with alternatives that match big sound with a relatively small price tag. The five new models in Sony's line of Net MD Walkman music players can all link to a PC through the U.S.B. port to copy files from the computer's MP3 library. After copying the files from the computer and compressing them in Sony's proprietary ATRAC3 format, music lovers on the go can take off with five hours of music on a single 80-minute disc.

title: Israelis Say Burial Box of Jesus' Brother Is Fake
description: Israel's archaeological experts declared today that an ancient limestone burial box, which bears an inscription suggesting it held the remains of Jesus' brother James, is a modern forgery.

title: Digging For Gold In Stilettos And Silk
description: TRADING UP

title: School May Repeat Graduation; Guards Say They Were Attacked
description: Fifth graders at Public School 92 in Brooklyn may get another chance to don their blue and yellow caps and gowns for family and friends. School administrators are considering holding a second ceremony for the students, whose graduation on Tuesday was marred by a fracas between security guards and an angry crowd they kept outside.

title: Shabby Chic
description: In the suburbs of New York, an unlikely exercise in shabby chic.

title: Reality Check
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Lumber Venture
description: Two Canadian forest products companies, Domtar and Tembec, have agreed to combine their lumber operations in Ontario and Quebec in an equally owned joint venture that they say will be North America's fourth-biggest producer of solid wood. The companies said that the joint venture, which is yet to be named, would benefit from a larger market share and lower costs in an industry that is struggling to cope with oversupply and falling prices. The new company will have interests in 20 sawmills and 2 wood manufacturing plants. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUGGIERI, , FRANK
description: RUGGIERI--Frank. The New York Philharmonic notes with sadness the death, on June 18th, of Frank Ruggieri, Second Bassoonist of The Philharmonic from 1949-1972. A graduate of The Curtis Institute of Music, Mr. Ruggieri played first bassoon with the National Symphony in Washington, DC and with the Ballet de Monte Carlo on tour. He was also first bassoonist of The Cleveland Orchestra, and joined The Philharmonic at the start of Dimitri Mitropoulos's tenure. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his daughter, Geraldine Dipersia. Lorin Maazel, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Exec. Dir. Members of the Staff >>AD#

title: Technology Briefing | Services: Key3Media EMerges From Bankruptcy Protection
description: The Key3Media Group, the technology trade show company that produces Comdex, said yesterday that it had emerged from bankruptcy protection and changed its name to Medialive International. The company, now 90 percent owned by the private equity arm of Thomas Weisel Partners, reduced debt by 87 percent and cut annual interest costs by 91 percent during the four-month restructuring. Robert Priest-Heck, the chief operating officer, was named as the new chief executive, succeeding Fredric D. Rosen, who remains on the board. The company filed on Feb. 3 for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, citing falling profits that it attributed in part to declines in the technology sector and cutbacks in corporate travel.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Stock Conversion
description: A leading computer chip maker, the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, has applied to issue $957.6 million worth of American depository receipts, officials at Taiwan's Securities and Futures Commission said. The company said it planned to convert 450 million Taiwan common shares into A.D.R.'s. The commission has three months to decide whether to approve the move.

title: 36 Hours | Milwaukee
description: MILWAUKEEANS are quick to boast about their symphony, ballet and theater, and about the funky new restaurants and converted-loft buildings, many connected by a clever riverfront footpath, that have sparked a reverse migration from the suburbs. But they are perhaps proudest that their city of 600,000 still feels like a small town. Anti-monarchist German immigrants established a tradition of liberalism (in the early 1900's Golda Meir spent her formative years in Milwaukee, absorbing socialist vibes), and activism endures in lively local politics. Other German immigrants started rolling out barrels in the 1840's, and Milwaukee still enjoys its famous locally brewed beer. Whether you drop by a nicotine-yellowed corner tavern or tip back a beer at one of the sleek new clubs catering to young singles, you're sure to tap into the spirit of gemtlichkeit. LOUISA KAMPS

title: Klitschko Looks to Show He Has Brawn and Brains
description: There is something about Vitali Klitschko that immediately catches your attention, and it is not a hairline that is just out of range of a ceiling fan, thanks to his 6-foot-8 frame.

title: Europe Inquiry Into Pokmon Distribution
description: The Topps Company, maker of trading cards and Bazooka bubble gum, said yesterday that the European Union Commission found that the company's Pokmon stickers and cards might have violated antitrust laws.

title: Shopping List | Aqua Fitness
description: WHEN the heat is on, get out of the gym and into the swim with exercise equipment to use in a pool. You'll get the benefits of fitness training without the sore muscles and aching joints, and you'll have fun in the sun with no sweaty clothes to wash afterward. NANCY M. BETTER

title: Adieu, Before Wrinkles Show
description: THE first glimpse of Sarah Jessica Parker is her shoe: a Miu Miu pump that is as preposterously high-heeled and costly as any of the Manolo Blahniks and Jimmy Choos that are to ''Sex and the City'' what the Colt .45 was to ''The Lawman.''

title: UMass Leader Says F.B.I. Wants to Kill His Brother
description: William M. Bulger, the president of the University of Massachusetts and the brother of one of the nation's most wanted men, today testified publicly for the first time about his brother, accusing the F.B.I. of wanting to kill him and calling into question the sincerity of the search for him.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PDF SOLUTIONS, San Jose, Calif., a maker of software used by computer chip makers, agreed to buy IDS Software Systems, Foster City, Calif., a maker of software used to manage data in the semiconductor industry, for $50.6 million.

title: Draft of European Union's Constitution Wins General Support
description: PORTO CARRAS, Greece, June 20  European leaders broadly endorsed the draft of a first-ever constitution for the European Union at a summit meeting here today, calling the evolving document a historic step toward a more coherent identity and role for the union on the world stage.

title: DURA AUTOMOTIVE AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF R.V. PARTS
description: Dura Automotive Systems, a maker of automotive parking brakes and other parts, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Creation Group, a maker of doors and windows for recreational vehicles, for up to $60 million. Dura said it would pay $57 million in cash and an additional $3 million if the business reached certain financial targets. It is buying the business from the Heywood Williams Group of Britain. Creation Group, based in Elkhart, Ind., had about $142 million in sales and $9 million in operating income last year. It has 1,100 workers at 10 factories in Indiana, Ohio and Pennsylvania, Dura said.

title: Hussein Is Probably Alive in Iraq, U.S. Experts Say, Citing Intercepts
description: American intelligence analysts now believe that Saddam Hussein is much more likely to be alive than dead, a view that has been strengthened in recent weeks by intercepted communications among fugitive members of the Saddam Fedayeen and the Iraqi intelligence service, according to United States government officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEDMAN, , ELLIS
description: FREEDMAN--Ellis. The directors and officers of the Aaron Copland Fund for Music, Inc. and the Virgil Thomson Foundation, Ltd. express their sorrow at the loss of one of our founding directors, Ellis Freedman. Ellis' foresight and wise counsel led to the formation of our organizations, and enabled them to continue their strong support of American music and its creators. His gentle humor and his generous spirit will be very much missed, but his devotion to American music and composers will live on in our work. Our sympathies are with his children and grandchildren. The Aaron Copland Fund for Music, Inc. John Harbison, President The Virgil Thomson Foundation, Ltd. Richard Flender, President >>AD#

title: Larry Doby, Who Broke a Color Barrier, Dies at 79
description: Larry Doby, who broke the color barrier in the American League in 1947, three months after Jackie Robinson became the first black in modern major league baseball, died Wednesday night at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 79.

description: REISS--Marsha, on June 18, 2003. Beloved wife of Jamie. Loving mother of Amanda and Evan. Devoted daughter of Edith. Dear sister of Elaine. We love you and we will miss you forever. Service Friday, June 20, 10 AM, ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. >>AD#

title: In Minnesota, Bush Makes Another Economic Sales Call
description: President Bush went on the road again today to trumpet his $350 billion tax cut, the third such trip of presidential salesmanship this week and a sign that the White House remained nervous that the lethargic economy could drag down his re-election campaign in 2004.

title: Critic of Boston Archdiocese Is Found Face Down in River
description: Patrick McSorley, who had accused the Rev. John J. Geoghan of molesting him as a boy and became a tenacious critic of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston in its sexual abuse scandal, was pulled from a river on Wednesday and was unconscious today and on life support.

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: USA Interactive To Change Name To InterActiveCorp
description: USA Interactive, the electronic commerce company run by Barry Diller, will change its name to InterActiveCorp to better reflect its Internet holdings. The company's businesses include the Expedia and Hotels.com online travel services, the home shopping TV network HSN, Ticketmaster and the Match.com online dating service. Investors have said they expect USA to focus on its electronic commerce businesses now that Mr. Diller, the company's chief executive, has stepped down as co-chief executive of Vivendi Universal Entertainment. Business Week reported the name change last week. The company, which is based in New York, will change its stock ticker to IACI from USAI on Monday, and will continue to trade on Nasdaq. USA Interactive shares fell 64 cents, to $38.12.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: GROCER NAMES EXECUTIVE The Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold announced the nomination of a former IKEA executive from Finland as chief financial officer. The executive, Hannu Ryopponen, left, is expected to start work on Sept. 1, succeeding Michael Meurs, subject to shareholder approval. The former chief executive of Royal Ahold, Cees van der Hoeven, and Mr. Meurs both resigned in February after the disclosure of accounting irregularities that resulted in $880 million in overstated earnings. Mr. Ryopponen, 51, is stationed in London as finance director of Industri Kapital Group, a private equity firm. From 1985 until 1998, Mr. Ryopponen served as executive vice president for finance at IKEA, the Swedish furniture giant, where he worked with Anders Moberg, Ahold's acting president and chief executive. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: BED BATH & BEYOND BUYS CHRISTMAS TREE SHOPS
description: Bed Bath & Beyond, the housewares retailer, said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Christmas Tree Shops for about $200 million, giving it a chain of 23 stores in six Northeastern states. The acquisition will add 2 cents a share to earnings this year, Bed Bath & Beyond said. Christmas Tree, based in South Yarmouth, Mass., had sales of $370 million last year. The stores sell seasonal items as well as dcor and houseware products. Christmas Tree has stores in Massachusetts, Connecticut, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Maine and New York. Bed, Bath & Beyond is based in Union, N.J.

title: Now, One Fewer Option For Knicks in the Draft
description: The Knicks staged a workout this afternoon for Marquette's Dwyane Wade, a shooting guard. But they were wondering if he would still be available when they picked at No. 9 in the N.B.A. draft next Thursday. Shortly afterward, the uncertainty of the draft reared its head when Pavel Podkolzine, a 7-foot-5 Siberian center, pulled out.

title: Three Songwriters of Distinctive Instincts
description: ''Never have I been part of any scene,'' Ed Harcourt sang at the Bowery Ballroom, nicely summing up the charms of the self-made songwriter who follows private instincts and idiosyncrasies. Three of them -- Mr. Harcourt, Sondre Lerche and Regina Spektor -- shared the bill on Monday night, each one brimming with intelligent quirks.

title: Spring Street, a Stroll for All Seasons
description: I grew oblivious to Spring Street. It was bound to happen. It's the street I take to leave my neighborhood at the west end of Canal Street, it's the street I take to get home. Over time it became no more than a stretch of cement between me and where I was going. But this year, after a winter like a recession that wouldn't quit, I decided to stretch my legs and walk the length of the street to where it dead-ends at the Bowery.

title: Lessons of War: Iraq as Case Study
description: To the Editor:

title: Rain Dates, Lots of Them; With Gray Skies Above, Life Is Stuck Indoors
description: Like his fellow New Yorkers, Brian Stites woke yesterday to more of the same: rain.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: DEATH SENTENCE IS SWITCHED TO LIFE A man who won a new trial because his lawyer slept through parts of his trial pleaded guilty to capital murder, but will exchange a death sentence for life in prison. The man, Calvin Burdine, 50, was convicted in 1984 and sentenced to die for the stabbing death of his roommate, W. T. Wise. His trial lawyer, Joe Cannon, slept for up to 10 minutes at a time during crucial phases of testimony in the first trial. (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Challenge On Teen Mothers
description: City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. said yesterday that city schools had undercounted the number of teenage mothers by many thousands. The comptroller's report said that at least 8,368 teenage mothers were recorded by the Department of Health between the 1997 and 2000 school years, yet city schools reported an annual average of only 150 pregnant students for those years. In a statement, the Board of Education said it shared the comptroller's concerns and would continue working with him on meeting these students' needs. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Speaking Truth to the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: A Change At the Lake: Alternating Sorcerers
description: American Ballet Theater offered an admirable first ''Swan Lake'' of the season on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Irina Dvorovenko played the dual role of Odette, the Swan Queen, and Odile, the sorcerer's daughter who disguises herself as Odette. Maxim Belotserkovsky was Prince Siegfried, who loves Odette but is deceived by Odile.

title: I.R.S. Seeking Buyers' Names In Tax Shelters
description: The Internal Revenue Service ordered one of the nation's biggest law firms, Jenkens & Gilchrist, yesterday to disclose the names of 600 wealthy clients who bought tax shelters that it considers abusive. The law firm said it would not comply.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Guess Settles Charges In Credit Card Case
description: Guess, the clothing designer and retailer, has agreed to introduce tougher security standards for its Web site, resolving federal charges that it failed to protect customers' credit card information, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday. While Guess had assured visitors to its site, Guess.com, that personal information would be protected from computer hackers, officials said such data had been vulnerable to attack since at least October 2000. ''Consumers have every right to expect that a business that says it's keeping personal information secure is doing exactly that,'' said J. Howard Beales, director of the commission's bureau of consumer protection. ''It is not just good business, it's the law.'' By taking steps to secure its site, however, Guess does not acknowledge breaking any laws.

title: Albany Leaders Say They Fell Just Short on Drug-Law Deal
description: For the third straight year, New York's two top legislative leaders failed today to break a protracted deadlock with Gov. George E. Pataki over changing the state's penalties for drug crimes that all sides agree are overly harsh.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a legal dispute between the SCO Group and I.B.M. involving the Linux operating system misspelled the term for such a system's software engine. It is a kernel, not kernal.

title: Report Due on Betting Fraud
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani will deliver a report on the integrity of electronic wagering in horse racing on Aug. 17 as part of the Jockey Club's 51st annual Round Table Conference in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Washington Memo; Vacancy or Not, Bracing For Supreme Court Fight
description: Senate Democrats and the White House say they have no idea whether a Supreme Court justice will retire at the end of this term, perhaps as early as next week. But that has not stopped them from scrambling to set the table to their liking for what could be a bruising, summerlong battle over the next high court vacancy.

title: Discarded War Munitions Leach Poisons Into the Baltic
description: American teams may be struggling to find chemical weapons and other poisonous materials in Iraq, but tens of thousands of bombs and barrels filled with blistering agents and nerve gas lie scattered in the Baltic Sea and the eastern Atlantic.

title: Independent Panel Calls for Clean Slate at U.S.O.C.
description: An outside commission examining the dysfunction and ethical lapses at the United States Olympic Committee recommended today that the organization's fractious and politically conflicted 124-person board of directors be replaced by a largely independent nine-member panel.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: USA INTERACTIVE TO CHANGE NAME TO INTERACTIVECORP USA Interactive, the electronic commerce company run by Barry Diller, will change its name to InterActiveCorp to better reflect its Internet holdings. The company's businesses include the Expedia and Hotels.com online travel services, the home shopping TV network HSN, Ticketmaster and the Match.com online dating service. Investors have said they expect USA to focus on its electronic commerce businesses now that Mr. Diller, the company's chief executive, has stepped down as co-chief executive of Vivendi Universal Entertainment. Business Week reported the name change last week. The company, which is based in New York, will change its stock ticker to IACI from USAI on Monday, and will continue to trade on Nasdaq. USA Interactive shares fell 64 cents, to $38.12.    (Bloomberg News)

title: Rudolf F. Hoelker, 91, Space Flight Scientist

title: More Than Black and White
description: The growth of the Latino population in the mainland United States has been head spinning. In just two years, from April 2000 to July 2002, the number of Hispanics grew 9.8 percent, nearly four times as fast as the general population. Their ranks have doubled since 1980. This week, as expected, the Census Bureau confirmed that Hispanics -- nearly 40 million of them -- now make up the nation's largest minority group. That is part of a larger trend that makes old views of race, in terms of black and white, incomplete and in need of rethinking.

Here are some great older trails for day hikes, some more difficult than others, but all with scenery bound to please the beholder.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: 3 MORE BURN THEMSELVES IN IRANIAN PROTEST Three more Iranians set themselves on fire in European capitals to protest a sweeping crackdown on an exile group in France, two at the French Embassy in Rome and one in Bern, Switzerland, after failing in an attempt the day before. The three were severely injured. In Paris, the police detained nearly 100 people to prevent further attempts at self-immolation and banned demonstrations by the group, the Mujahedeen Khalq, or People's Mujahedeen. One woman was reported to have died of her injuries after she set herself on fire in Paris a day earlier. A total of seven Iranians have set themselves on fire since raids Tuesday on the French offices of the group, whose goal is the overthrow of Iran's Islamic Republic. The sweep was aimed at preventing attacks on Iranian diplomatic missions in Europe and elsewhere, France's counterintelligence chief, Pierre de Bousquet de Florian, said in the government's most detailed explanation yet for the raids. A spokesman for the People's Mujahedeen denied his comments as "absolutely false claims." (AP)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Less Catholic, More Muslim

The number of Muslims quadrupled, to 19,000, since the 1991 census. The total population was put at 3.9 million people, who, the census found, continue to move into the cities, have smaller families and tolerate divorce more. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Putting 'America' on the Map
description: It's easy to think of reasons why the Library of Congress has bought the first map to use the name ''America,'' even if that map, at $10 million, is the single most expensive item ever purchased by the library. In its day, 1507, the world map compiled by Martin Waldseemller was a technological tour de force, a masterpiece of woodcut printing as well as cartography. Though a thousand maps were originally made, the Waldseemller now exists in only a single copy, which was rediscovered in 1901 in a southern German castle. The map is the first to correctly show that America is a separate continent, and the name ''America'' -- a tribute to the Italian navigator Amerigo Vespucci -- is printed across what we now call Brazil.

description: TO imagine a genteel park at the entrance to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg does in his grand plan for Lower Manhattan, it may help to remember that this was once a genteel neighborhood indeed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBLATT, , LESTER
description: ROSENBLATT -- Lester. MI Engineering mourns a loyal alum whose dedication to the College will be remembered. >>AD#

title: When to Rout Tyrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Torre Has Support From Steinbrenner
description: Joe Torre insisted yesterday that he was not trying to get himself fired as the Yankees' manager when he criticized his boss in a television interview on Wednesday. Apparently, he has nothing to worry about. George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, did not fire back at Torre yesterday, offering encouragement instead.

title: Astronomers Link Gamma-Ray Bursts to Supernovas
description: Alien space wars and antimatter comets are but two of the more exotic explanations that have been proffered in the last three decades for the flashes of high-energy radiation known as gamma-ray bursts that have appeared sporadically in the cosmic night, tantalizing and frustrating astronomers.

title: Senators Take Steps To Reinstate Limits On Media Holdings
description: Moving with unusual speed, the Senate today began the process of reversing the recent decision by federal regulators to loosen media ownership rules and enable the nation's largest newspaper and broadcasting conglomerates to grow even larger.

title: Mideast Talks Revisit Issue Of Israeli Troop Withdrawal
description: On the eve of a visit here by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, negotiations on several fronts of the American-led peace plan picked up pace today, though without any breakthroughs.

title: Tilting At Disaster
description: With documentaries about the making of movies so common on DVD these days, it's interesting to come across one that tells how a movie wasn't made. ''Fell through'' is too mild a term for the filmmaking fiasco chronicled in ''Lost in La Mancha,'' to be released next week by Docurama.

title: G.M. to Offer $10 Billion in Debt to Cover Its Pension Costs
description: The General Motors Corporation , which is struggling to cope with the largest pension fund shortfall in Corporate America, announced today that it would sell $10 billion worth of debt securities next week to help it meet its continuing pension and health-care liabilities.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Grocer Names Executive
description: The Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold announced the nomination of a former IKEA executive from Finland as chief financial officer. The executive, Hannu Ryopponen, left, is expected to start work on Sept. 1, succeeding Michael Meurs, subject to shareholder approval. The former chief executive of Royal Ahold, Cees van der Hoeven, and Mr. Meurs both resigned in February after the disclosure of accounting irregularities that resulted in $880 million in overstated earnings. Mr. Ryopponen, 51, is stationed in London as finance director of Industri Kapital Group, a private equity firm. From 1985 until 1998, Mr. Ryopponen served as executive vice president for finance at IKEA, the Swedish furniture giant, where he worked with Anders Moberg, Ahold's acting president and chief executive. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Tilting at Disaster
description: With documentaries about the making of movies so common on DVD these days, it's interesting to come across one that tells how a movie wasn't made. "Fell through" is too mild a term for the filmmaking fiasco chronicled in "Lost in La Mancha," to be released next week by Docurama.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Talks on Modified Foods End for U.S. and Europe

title: Beckham's eye-catching knack for the soft sell
description: LONDON:  The David and Victoria Beckham phenomenon, having left Hollywood somewhat underwhelmed, touched down at Narita Airport in Tokyo on Wednesday to the tumult of a thousand shrieking girls, fans of the soccer player.

title: Still Blowing Bubbles
description: The big rise in the stock market is definitely telling us something. Bulls think it says the economy is about to take off. But I think it's a sign that America is still blowing bubbles -- that a three-year bear market and the biggest corporate scandals in history haven't cured investors of irrational exuberance yet.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honda Sets Day Off
description: One of Japan's largest carmakers, the Honda Motor Company, said it would halt production for one day at its factories and research centers in the Tokyo area to pre-empt a potential power shortage. Honda will shut 16 factories and research outlets on July 24 and make up the production later. Honda said it would save enough electricity to supply 30,000 households. The Tokyo Electric Power Company, Tokyo's main electricity provider, has warned of possible power shortages this summer. The government forced Tokyo Electric to shut its nuclear reactors after the utility admitted to falsifying nuclear safety reports. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: NORTHWEST FLIGHT ATTENDANTS TO SWITCH UNIONS
description: Flight attendants at Northwest Airlines have voted to oust the Teamsters, their union representative for 26 years, in favor of a new independent union formed by workers unhappy with the national union's oversight. About 55 percent of the voting flight attendants approved the change, with 4,857 ballots for and 3,916 against, said Andy Damis, an attendant and officer with the new union, the Professional Flight Attendants Association. The vote comes as Northwest, the nation's fourth-largest carrier, seeks pay and benefit concessions from unions to stem losses. The Teamsters had refused to enter those negotiations. National representatives of the Teamsters and some flight attendants supporting the new union have sparred for years over issues like national control of the Minnesota office and a Teamsters-backed contract that attendants rejected.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Jun Nguyen-Hatsushiba -- 'Memorial Project, Vietnam'
description: New Museum of Contemporary Art

title: Speaking Truth to the Church
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The TV Watch column on Wednesday, about shows in which people change their appearance, identity or home, misstated a word in the title of a recent movie about a character who slips the bonds of class and profession. It is ''Catch Me if You Can,'' not ''as You Can.'' The column also misidentified the teenager on the show ''Switched'' who asked ''Tepees and stuff?'' when told she was to switch places with a girl on an Indian reservation. She was Ally; Ida was the girl who lived on the reservation.

title: Time Running Out, Albany Is Stymied On Major Measures
description: As the last day of the regular legislative session wore on this morning, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders had not yet reached agreements on a host of major bills, among them one to extend rent regulations. It appeared that the 2003 session was in danger of being notable as much for what had not been done as for what had been done.

title: Sometimes Work Is Just a Drive in the Country
description: FORGET cute towns and mountain views. A really great drive is about giving the car a workout. Driving a beautifully engineered vehicle on a challenging road can be a delicious experience. And around the country, where the pavement climbs and dips and winds, some people take great drives for a living.

title: Choosing Dialing Up Over Lighting Up, Nascar Picks Nextel
description: Nascar officials yesterday used a television studio in Times Square, with green lasers slicing the darkness and giant replicas of cellular telephones hanging from the ceiling, to say they hope to make their growing sport less quaint.

title: Witnesses Tell of Quick Link to Army Suspect in Grenade Attack on Senior Officers
description: Command Sgt. Maj. Bart Womack was just settling down for the night last March 23, tuning in to the Golf Channel, when up went the flap, out shot sparks and an incendiary grenade burst open and ripped through his tent.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Franklin Township: 3 Students Arrested
description: Three high school students have been arrested in the stabbing of a sophomore at Franklin Township High School, the Somerset County prosecutor said. On Wednesday, Teron Fuller, 18, was stabbed twice in the back after trying to break up an argument between two other students, the authorities said. His lung collapsed and he needed surgery at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, where he was in stable condition last night. Later Wednesday, Fitzgerald Elliott, 19, was arrested and charged with attempted murder and a weapons charge, and yesterday, two 16-year-old sophomore boys were arrested and charged with hindering apprehension, said the prosecutor, Wayne J. Forrest. One of the boys was also charged with unlawful possession of a weapon, a knife with a five-inch blade.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Baby Born To Couple Who Want Stem Cells
description: A British woman has given birth to a son after receiving fertility treatment in the United States outlawed in Britain that ensures the baby is genetically matched to an older brother suffering from a rare form of anemia. Doctors hope stem cells from the umbilical cord from the infant, Jamie, above with his brother, Charlie, will help cure the older boy. Michelle Whitaker of Derbyshire in the English Midlands had in-vitro fertilization and screening at the Reproductive Genetics Institute in Chicago after Britain's Human Fertilization and Embryology Authority vetoed the treatment because the older boy did not have an hereditary illness. The agency had approved the technique for another British couple to save their terminally ill son who, by contrast, had a hereditary disease. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: West Side Crime Statistics Were Softened, Police Say
description: More than 200 crimes reported last year in Chelsea and on the western edge of Midtown, mostly thefts and robberies, were improperly downgraded in police statistics to misdemeanors, making that area seem safer on paper than it really was, police officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about the former Route 666 in New Mexico, Colorado and Utah -- now called 491 -- misstated its relationship to Monument Valley. The highway passes well to the east of it, not through it.

title: Testifying in Corruption Trial, Ex-State Treasurer Gives Details of Kickback Scheme
description: Taking the stand today in federal court, Paul J. Silvester, the former Connecticut state treasurer convicted on federal bribery charges, described publicly for the first time how he orchestrated million-dollar kickbacks to himself and politically influential friends in the late 1990's.

title: Religious Leaders Ask White House to Push Child Tax Credit
description: Several of the nation's most prominent Protestant leaders implored President Bush today to seek increased child tax credits for minimum-wage families, urging him to press the Republican leadership of the House for a quick agreement on the issue.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teenager Charges Bias
description: A Queens teenager charged that city school officials violated her rights when they suspended her from school after she wore a T-shirt with the words, ''Barbie is a Lesbian.'' She made the charges in a lawsuit in federal court that her mother filed yesterday on her behalf. The girl, Natalie Young, a lesbian, was removed from class at Middle School 210 in Ozone Park in April 2002 and suspended for a day because she wore the shirt, according to the lawsuit. Ms. Young, 13 at the time, suffered other harassment from students and school staff members, according to her lawyer, Ronald L. Kuby. Lawyers for the city said they had not yet reviewed the suit and had no comment.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about the ''Broadway Under the Stars'' concert held on Monday at Bryant Park in Manhattan misstated its sequence in the summer schedule of outdoor concerts. It was not the first; there were earlier concerts, starting with the Metropolitan Opera's ''Turandot'' in Central Park on June 10 and including a performance by Chris Thomas King on June 14 in the Summerstage series in Central Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRAUSS, , LOU R., JR.
description: STRAUSS--Lou R., Jr., 97, loving husband of the late Arline Schaap, father of Robert S. and Susan L., died peacefully at home on June 18. A Gathering for family and friends will be held at the family home on Sunday, June 22nd from 2-6 PM. >>AD#

title: $100 Million Donation Helps to Establish a Genome Institute
description: In an unusual collaboration prompted by a $100 million donation, Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology will establish a research institute intended to apply knowledge of the human genome to the practice of medicine.

title: Planes Fly Off the Line, But Not Always to the Sky
description: One day they will carry 150 people 37,000 feet above the earth, but at the moment these hulks are no more glamorous than television sets on an assembly line.

title: Hokies Waiting For A.C.C. To Call
description: Virginia Tech officials did little yesterday to dispel reports that it would jump to the Atlantic Coast Conference if the A.C.C. offered it a last-minute invitation to salvage a troubled expansion plan.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Suit For Disabled Students
description: Lawyers for more than 500 disabled preschool children asked a federal judge yesterday to order the city's Department of Education to provide special-education services for their clients immediately. The lawyers have filed a class action suit on behalf of the children, claiming that they are entitled to free special-education services under the federal Individuals With Disabilities Education Act. ''Some have pervasive developmental disorders,'' the lawyers wrote in petitioning Judge David G. Trager. The Education Department declined to comment. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Uneasy Iran: New Strains
description: The jokes crop up all over town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAILEY, , EVELYN H.
description: DAILEY--Evelyn H. Died June 11, 2003, peacefully at home in New York City; Five days short of a century of joy from her adoring family and friends, music, books and handcrafts. Predeceased by her husband Louis B. after a marriage of 63 years. She is survived by her twin sons Robert H., MD of Orinda, Ca. and Thomas H., MD of NYC; her daughters Sarah Diamond of Berkeley, Ca., and Susan Lohse of Portsmouth, NH. Contributions of remembrance may be directed to Concert Artists Guild, 850 7th Ave, NY, NY 10019. >>AD#

title: Belgian War Crimes Law Used Against Foreigners Hits Home
description: BRUSSELS, June 20  Belgium's outspoken foreign minister, Louis Michel, has become the latest politician to be the target of a lawsuit filed under his country's international war crimes law.

title: Jun Nguyen-Hatsushiba; Eric Heist; Lisa Yuskavage
description: Jun Nguyen-Hatsushiba

title: Last Days For a Survivor Of Sept. 11
description: The battered and disfigured Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan, among the last remaining buildings damaged in the Sept. 11 terrorist attack whose fate has not been decided, has been deemed beyond repair and is expected to be taken down beginning next month, according to people involved in negotiations on its future.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Parliament Backs Reforms
description: The Parliament approved a set of human rights measures intended to persuade the European Union to begin membership talks with the country as early as next year. The law clears the way for private broadcasters to transmit programs in the Kurdish language, and it enacts a series of other measures meant to increase protections to the country's Kurdish minority. It allows parents to give Kurdish names to their children, and it abolishes an amendment that allowed the government to prosecute people for speaking in favor of a Kurdish state.

title: Resisting Communism
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Fire Burns Arizona Homes

title: Aide to Kim Dae Jung is accused of bribery and abuse of power : Key figure in Korean summit is arrested
description: SEOUL:  A former presidential aide who engineered the historic North-South Korean summit meeting of June 2000 was jailed Thursday in an investigation into charges that the government paid enormous bribes to persuade North Korea's leader to be host to Kim Dae Jung, then the South Korean president.

title: Europe Moves Toward Issuing Passports With Data Chips
description: PORTO CARRAS, Greece, June 20  European Union governments may soon issue passports containing computer chips embedded with digital fingerprints or eye scans, according to a plan approved by European leaders today.

title: Senate Committee Standoff Delays McGreevey's Budget
description: Republicans on the Senate budget committee held up the Gov. James E. McGreevey's budget today, refusing to vote on several tax proposals that they oppose.

title: Saving Private Jessica
description: I've been roaming Iraq, turning over rocks in my unstinting effort to help the Bush administration find those weapons of mass destruction. No luck yet.

title: Former New Yorker Killed in West Bank Attack
description: JERUSALEM, June 20  Tzvi Goldstein, 47, a technical writer who moved from New York to Israel 11 years ago, was driving a car in the West Bank today, about the time that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was in Jerusalem denouncing Hamas, the Islamic militant group, as the major block to peace. Two gunmen appeared on the road, a friend said later, and fired about 30 bullets into the car.

title: U.N Atom Agency Seeks Wider Scrutiny on Iran, but Is Rebuffed
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency called on Iran today to allow stricter inspections of the nuclear reactor sites that the United States has said are being used to develop atomic weapons. Iran rejected the request.

title: Diaper-Clad Adventurers Heed the Call of the Wild
description: Rugrats Go Wild

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on June 12 about the author Leslie Epstein misstated the involvement of his father and uncle, Philip and Julius Epstein, in three films. They wrote the screenplays, not the original plays, for ''The Man Who Came to Dinner'' and ''Arsenic and Old Lace,'' and they collaborated with Howard Koch on the screenplay for ''Casablanca''; they were not the sole authors.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Hunt For Soldiers In Drug Gang
description: The attorney general's office said 31 soldiers had deserted the army to work for one of the nation's biggest drug gangs. The government distributed wanted posters saying the soldiers had gone to work for the Gulf Cartel, which smuggles billions of dollars' worth of Colombian cocaine into the United States. The posters offer $30,000 rewards and describe the deserters as murderers, kidnappers and thieves. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Please Don't Dent The Heirloom
description: ON a bright cloudless night in June 1997, Jo and Walter Barnes of West Des Moines, Iowa, celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary at a bustling, sentimental event attended by more than 100 friends and relatives. The evening brimmed with sweet nostalgia: stories from a vanished youth, recountings of good times, laughter over scenes long gone and fond memories of the truck.

title: Speaking Truth to the Church (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Back for the Memories at Atlantic Beach
description: FAMILY ties are tight in Atlantic Beach, a seaside village on Long Island just 22 miles from Manhattan, and the tug of memory is strong. Consider the Benensons' story. After years of summering in the Hamptons and on the Connecticut shore, Richard Benenson, a 67-year-old semi-retired real estate developer who lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, is returning there, to the beach of his childhood. He and his wife, Thea, have rented a three-bedroom house a block and a half from the ocean for July and August.

title: In the Silence After Death, Struggling to Find Speech
description: THE DOGS OF BABEL

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: The Heavy In Hulksville

title: With a Constitution to Ponder, Europeans Gather in Greece
description: The leaders of the 15 nations in the European Union arrived here late today to tackle all the usual dilemmas, debates and decisions of their frenetic summit meetings, compressed into a few days about every four months.

title: Saddam's Bombs? We'll Find Them
description: Where are Iraq's weapons of mass destruction? It's a good question, and unfortunately we don't yet have a good answer. There is hope that the capture of Abid Hamid Mahmoud al-Tikriti, Saddam Hussein's closest aide, will provide the first solid clues. In any event, the mystery will be solved in good time; the search for Iraq's nonconvential weapons program has only just begun.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: The Roads Are Alive, With the Sound of . . .
description: PLEASE don't be scared when I tell you that I like to sing karaoke in the car, and that many of the songs are show tunes. If you're ever in my car, I promise to try never to spring a surprise ''Anything You Can Do'' duet on you, and I will keep the precision choreography to an almost imperceptible shoulder-shrug.

title: Powell Says U.S. Will Step Up Efforts for Peace in Mideast
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, promising ''much more engagement'' by the Bush administration in the Middle East, said today that Israel had recently made progress in dismantling settlements in the West Bank and in negotiating a turnover of security to the Palestinians in Gaza.

title: Smith Barney Hires Merkley Newman
description: The Smith Barney division of Citigroup in New York yesterday named Merkley Newman Harty & Partners in New York to handle creative duties on its account, which had been handled since 1994 by McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising in New York. Billings were estimated at more than $15 million.

title: Marilyn Fischbach, 72, Art Gallery Founder
description: Marilyn Cole Fischbach, the founder and former sole owner of the Fischbach Gallery in Manhattan, known for showing work by young artists, died on Sunday in Paris. She was 72 and had lived mainly in Paris for two decades.

title: Publicis Helps Form Global Network
description: The Publicis Groupe in Paris and several independent recruitment advertising agencies have established a network to cooperate on global human resources accounts.

title: Partners Help Apparel Maker Win Klein Line
description: The winner in the fashion industry's most closely watched race has been announced: Kellwood, one of the biggest apparel companies in the world, was chosen yesterday to make the new Calvin Klein women's line of clothing, destined for some of the country's high-end department stores.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the frustrations of Hans Blix, the retiring chief weapons inspector for the United Nations, misstated his age. He turns 75 on June 28; he is not 77.

title: McDonald's Seeking Cut In Antibiotics In Its Meat
description: Responding to public health concerns about the overuse of antibiotics in farm animals, the McDonald's Corporation said today that it would ask its meat suppliers around the world to reduce their dependence on antibiotics.

title: Citigroup Stock Option Dealings
description: The chairman of Citigroup, Sanford I. Weill, earned $4.3 million by exercising options on 561,760 shares of the company two days ago, the company said in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: U.S. Judge Sets January Trial Date for Martha Stewart Case
description: Martha Stewart and her former stockbroker will be tried in January on criminal charges stemming from Ms. Stewart's 2001 sale of ImClone Systems stock, a federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Pattaya Journal; A Famed Resort Where Tourists Fear to Tread
description: It is as if the terrorist attack had already occurred. Beaches and bars are nearly empty. Tour ferries float at anchor in the distance. Even the elephants are idle, with few customers to ride them.

title: L.I. Suspect Pleads Not Guilty In a Fatal Traffic Stabbing
description: A 33-year-old Long Island man was stabbed to death by a stranger Wednesday morning after a traffic dispute on the Sunken Meadow State Parkway escalated to violence, the police said yesterday.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Air Force Academy Did Act On Complaints, Panel Finds
description: A military panel inquiring into accusations of sexual assault at the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs said in Washington yesterday that it had found no evidence of campus officials' ignoring or otherwise mishandling reported attacks on cadets.

title: Defendant Pleads Guilty to Role in '79 Killing of Suffolk Boy
description: Nearly a quarter-century after four teenagers were charged with stuffing stones down the throat of a 13-year-old boy who had seen them steal a minibike, one of Long Island's most disturbing and heavily litigated murder cases drew to an end yesterday.

title: A Traffic Jam Generating Heat as Well as Noise
description: ''Friday Night'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 11; the full text is available online at nytimes.com/movies. The film, in French with English subtitles, opens today at the Quad Cinema, 34 West 13th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of Gregory Peck last Friday characterized the response to one of his movies, ''Duel in the Sun'' (1946), incompletely. While widely disparaged by critics, it was a box-office success, not a flop.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Police Officers Indicted
description: Seventeen Detroit police officers were indicted on federal charges, including conspiracy. They are accused of conducting illegal searches of homes and vehicles, making unlawful arrests, using excessive force, planting evidence and filing false police reports. A yearlong investigation concluded that the officers kept money, guns and drugs confiscated during illegal searches and then falsified their reports. The local United States attorney, Jeffrey Collins, said the convictions of 5 to 10 people appear to have been tainted by false statements from the officers. ''The condition that gives rise to the indictment is despicable,'' Mr. Collins said. If convicted, each of the officers faces a maximum of 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Caitlin Nish (NYT)

title: Rain Stops, But Yanks Don't Play
description: On the day they marked the 100th birthday of Lou Gehrig, who played 2,130 consecutive games, the Yankees decided not to play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARDY, , LYNNE
description: HARDY--Lynne, on June 17, 2003. Beloved mother of Donald Nyer. Devoted wife of the late Joe Hardy. Beloved sister of Marvin Laut and the late Rose Holtzman. Versatile show business performer for more than half century on stage, screen and nightclubs. Viewing on Friday, June 20 at R.G. Ortiz Funeral Home, 235 W. 72nd St, New York City, from 3pm to 9pm. Service will be on Saturday, June 21 at 8:30p.m. Burial at Pinelawn Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. >>AD#

title: For the Yanks, Only Shea Will Be Familiar
description: The uniforms will say Mets, the mascot with the baseball head will roam the stands and the giant red apple will sit in its center-field top hat. The Yankees will know they are playing the Mets tonight, but the other typical Shea Stadium reminders -- the players -- will not help them identify their opponent.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Investor Group Buys Stake In Level 3
description: Level 3 Communications Inc., an operator of fiber optic networks, said yesterday that an investor group including Berkshire Hathaway Inc. had agreed to exchange $457 million of Level 3's convertible bonds for stock now worth double that amount. The company, which transmits telephone calls and data for business customers, will give up a 33 percent stake valued at $1.13 billion while shedding debt paying 9 percent interest. Warren E. Buffett, the head of Berkshire, and his partners, Longleaf Partners Funds and Legg Mason Inc., bought $500 million of Level 3's bonds last July. They are increasing their bet on a company that last year was in danger of violating loan covenants because of slumping sales. Since then, shares in the company, which is based in Broomfield, Colo., have more than doubled, and the company had its first quarterly profit in 20 periods after increasing revenue through acquisitions. Level 3 shares rose 35 cents, or about 5 percent, to $7.40. ''Converting debt into equity is a great thing if you're trying to improve a lower-quality balance sheet,'' said David Epstein, an analyst at the Froley Revy Investment Company.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MIXED EMPLOYMENT DATA FOR MAY The official count of private-sector jobs in New York State shows that they increased in May by 6,900 on a seasonally adjusted basis, according to figures released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. But New York City lost several thousand jobs in May after a gain in April, some economists and the office of the city comptroller estimated. "Despite the optimism brewing on Wall Street, employers are clearly still reluctant to hire," said Barbara Byrne Denham, an economist for Jones Lang LaSalle , a commercial real estate firm. "In fact, the securities industry had one of the largest one-month losses." There were also losses in retail trade, clothing manufacturing and private education, she said. The city's unemployment rate dropped to 8.1 percent from 8.3 percent, while the state's remained unchanged at 6.1 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENEDETTO, , JAMES (''JIMMY RED'')
description: BENEDETTO--James (''Jimmy Red''). Age 64, on June 19, 2003. Well-loved NYC restaurateur. Owned Village landmark ''Googies'' 1962-2003. He opened ''Les Routiers Bistro'' on the Upper West Side in 1990. He is mourned by his wife Susan, son Michael, twin daughters Emily and Katy, mother Mary, and sisters Michele and Phyllis. Visitation Saturday, June 21st, 27PM at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC. >>AD#

title: Spacecraft Give 'Deeper' Picture of the Origin of Galaxies
description: Astronomers unveiled the first results yesterday from what they said was the most searching look yet into the origin of galaxies and how they grew.

title: All-Terrain Gas Pedal
description: Television ads would have you believe that the best evidence of an S.U.V.'s all-terrain prowess is a gravel-slinging blast down an unpaved lane. But brute horsepower is the last thing needed when your wilderness adventure includes crawling over boulders or slogging through goopy mud, both of which demand some degree of low-speed finesse.

title: WPP Reaches Deal to Acquire Cordiant
description: The WPP Group and the Cordiant Communications Group said today that they had agreed to a takeover deal that would value Cordiant, the British agency company, at just 10 million ($16.8 million).

title: ANTIQUES
description: Friend of the Czar, Aide of the Czarina

title: PHARMACEUTICAL RESOURCES SAYS ITS CHIEF IS RETIRING
description: Pharmaceutical Resources, the holding company for Par Pharmaceutical, the maker of generic drugs, said its chairman and chief executive, Kenneth I. Sawyer, would retire July 1 after leading the company for 14 years. He plans to help manage a charitable foundation, the company said. Expenses related to Mr. Sawyer's retirement agreement will cut 6 to 8 cents a share from second-quarter earnings, the company said. Excluding the retirement costs, Pharmaceutical Resources said, profit will rise to 71 to 73 cents a share this quarter, higher than the 64-cent estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call, as sales climbed for the company's generic drugs that treat depression and ulcers.

title: Origins of 'Anchorman'
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Committee Once Again Backs Stringent Penalties for Spam Senders
description: Fueled by rising frustration with the growing commercial clutter in e-mail in-boxes, an antispam bill was voted out of committee today for the first time during this Congressional session.

title: A Retailer Is Dressed Down
description: In an attempt to relive its financial heyday of years past, Abercrombie & Fitch underwent a large image makeover. It no longer wanted to be known as ''The Greatest Sporting Goods Store in the World.'' It wanted to be the modern store for the young and hip, known more for the near-naked models on its posters and catalogs than the fact that Theodore Roosevelt and Amelia Earhart used to shop there.

title: PeopleSoft Accelerates Effort to Buy J.D. Edwards
description: Racing to stay one step ahead of a hostile takeover by Oracle, PeopleSoft yesterday began an all-out drive to gain commitments directly from shareholders of J. D. Edwards in hopes of speeding its friendly deal to acquire the company.

description: BASEBALL

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans in Iraq:

title: Merrill Hires 10 Analysts
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has added 10 analysts to its credit research group to expand its coverage of high-yield and emerging-market debt. One of the analysts, John Maxwell, will be managing director for research of junk-rated companies in the gambling and leisure sectors, Merrill said. He had been head of high-yield research at BNP Paribas. Russell Gorman from Moody's Investors Service and Michael Scarangella from J. P. Morgan Chase were also among those recently hired. In Europe, Merrill hired Peter Burbank from Pictet Asset Management to oversee corporate bond research in the consumer and retail sectors.

title: A Mixed Bag of a Program With an Enthusiastic M.C.
description: In today's classical music world, the programming trend is to arrange concerts around a single theme: ''Settings of Shakespeare,'' for example. Last Friday night, the Orchestra of St. Luke's resoundingly rejected this idea. The program it offered at Carnegie Hall, a conglomerate of pieces with no perceptible connection, resembled less a concert than a variety show.

title: Ashcroft Calls on News Media to Help Explain Antiterrorism Laws

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mixed Employment Data For May
description: The official count of private-sector jobs in New York State shows that they increased in May by 6,900 on a seasonally adjusted basis, according to figures released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. But New York City lost several thousand jobs in May after a gain in April, some economists and the office of the city comptroller estimated. ''Despite the optimism brewing on Wall Street, employers are clearly still reluctant to hire,'' said Barbara Byrne Denham, an economist for Jones Lang LaSalle, a commercial real estate firm. ''In fact, the securities industry had one of the largest one-month losses.'' There were also losses in retail trade, clothing manufacturing and private education, she said. The city's unemployment rate dropped to 8.1 percent from 8.3 percent, while the state's remained unchanged at 6.1 percent.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: INVESTOR GROUP BUYS STAKE IN LEVEL 3 Level 3 Communications Inc. , an operator of fiber optic networks, said yesterday that an investor group including Berkshire Hathaway Inc. had agreed to exchange $457 million of Level 3's convertible bonds for stock now worth double that amount. The company, which transmits telephone calls and data for business customers, will give up a 33 percent stake valued at $1.13 billion while shedding debt paying 9 percent interest. Warren E. Buffett, the head of Berkshire, and his partners, Longleaf Partners Funds and Legg Mason Inc. , bought $500 million of Level 3's bonds last July. They are increasing their bet on a company that last year was in danger of violating loan covenants because of slumping sales. Since then, shares in the company, which is based in Broomfield, Colo., have more than doubled, and the company had its first quarterly profit in 20 periods after increasing revenue through acquisitions. Level 3 shares rose 35 cents, or about 5 percent, to $7.40. "Converting debt into equity is a great thing if you're trying to improve a lower-quality balance sheet," said David Epstein, an analyst at the Froley Revy Investment Company.   (Bloomberg News)

title: Three Violinists Named Winners of Competition
description: The audience at Alice Tully Hall milled around and compared notes on Wednesday evening as the jury of the Walter W. Naumburg 2003 International Violin Competition spent 20 minutes deliberating. The three finalists -- who were among 50 players in the preliminaries and 12 in the semifinals -- had each played a 45-minute set and waited backstage until the judges reached their decision. Just after 10 p.m., Robert Mann, the president of the foundation and the winner of its competition in 1941, announced the winners in reverse order, making his way up to Frank Huang, whose prize includes $10,000, two recitals at Alice Tully Hall, 20 concerts around the country and the premiere of a new unaccompanied solo sonata by Donald Martino. Ayano Ninomiya won the $7,500 second prize, and Sharon Roffman won the $5,000 third prize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIU, , HENRY W.
description: LIU--Henry W. A retired electrical engineer died on June 8, 2003. He was 98. Born on a farm in China, he was the first in the family to attend college, graduating from Shanghai Jiaotong University in 1930. After the communist takeover in 1949, the family fled to Taiwan. They emigrated to the U.S. in the 1950s, settling first in Manhattan and later in Edison, NJ. Mr. Liu received a Master's degree from the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute in 1956. In his retirement he enjoyed gardening, cooking and calligraphy. Mr. Liu is survived by his loving wife, Shan, children Lucy, Bede, Hal and Jane, grandchildren Beatrice, John, and Allison, and great grandchildren Charles, Kate, Emily and Coltrane. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Cuts At Airline
description: Faced with what is likely to be its first quarterly loss, Singapore Airlines said yesterday that it would lay off 414 employees who are based in Singapore in its biggest retrenchment since it began flying in 1972. The impact of the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, on travel has halved the number of passengers flying Singapore Airlines and forced the airline to cut capacity one-third. The layoffs represent 1.5 percent of the airline's Singapore work force, and consist largely of ground staff. Analysts predict additional layoffs. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Wella Rejection
description: Investors in Wella who own more than a third of the company's preferred stock rejected a buyout offer by the Procter & Gamble Company, which took control of the company with a $6.9 billion bid in March. The investors, who own 35.5 percent of the preferred stock of Wella, a German maker of salon hair-care products, repeated their contention that the bid was too low, according to Close Brothers Corporate Finance Ltd., their adviser. The offer was to close at midnight Frankfurt time. Procter & Gamble, which is based in Cincinnati, owns 78 percent of the company's ordinary shares.

title: Corrections

It was Frank Mahoney of Lehman Brothers, the underwriter of the bonds -- not Michael J. Lorenz, a senior executive in the Destiny partnership -- who said: ''Nobody wants to be the first money in'' and ''With this bill it's a lot more likely we will get the other participants interested and to commit to meet the other needs of the project, which could exceed $2 billion.''

title: MARATHON OIL SAYS EARNINGS TO FALL AT LEAST $75 MILLION
description: The Marathon Oil Corporation said yesterday that asset sales in Texas and the dissolution of a venture with Kinder Morgan Energy Partners would reduce second-quarter profit by $75 million to $85 million. Marathon and Kinder Morgan, both based in Houston, will dissolve their MKM Partners venture, the companies said. Kinder agreed to buy the venture's stake in a Texas oil field and a Marathon unit that transports carbon dioxide. Marathon, which owns 85 percent of the MKM, did not disclose the terms of the sale. MKM, which produces oil and natural gas, will be dissolved in the current quarter.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Leaves Reuters
description: The news and financial information provider Reuters Group said yesterday that its chief operating officer, Philip Green, would leave on June 30 and it would eliminate the position to trim costs. The group management committee, headed by the chief executive, Tom Glocer, left, will take over direct control of operations, Johnny Weir, a spokesman for Reuters, said. Mr. Green's departure is part of a plan to simplify the senior management structure, Reuters said. ''We have undertaken to reduce costs, and I believe it is imperative that we cut expenditure at every level in the company,'' Mr. Glocer said.

title: Nefertiti's Bust Gets a Body, Offending Egyptians
