description: PARIS  Finding an acceptable apartment in a pleasant neighborhood abroad can be challenging enough for an expat who wants to hit the ground running in a foreign assignment. And while signing a lease may bring a sigh of relief, expats should take extra care to study local real estate customs and read the fine print of their lease if they want to prevent misunderstandings, unforeseen obligations or even the surprise of a sudden eviction.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Monitor Plant To Close
description: The Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan will close a Mexican computer monitor plant in July, forcing 1,250 employees out of work, because of a drop in sales, a company executive said. The plant produces television-style monitors, and the executive, Oscar Garca, said demand had been hurt by the popularity of flat-panel monitors.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Disease Outbreak Confirmed
description: Guangdong Province announced 18 deaths and 211 cases of mosquito-borne Japanese encephalitis. The outbreak has left people in adjacent Hong Kong concerned because Guangdong authorities declined to comment after local news reports about the disease began last weekend, a response that echoed the province's secrecy last winter over the first cases of SARS. Commonly found in pigs and spread by mosquitoes that bite the pigs and then people, Japanese encephalitis is most common from May to September and infects at least 50,000 Asians a year, with 10,000 deaths. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

The drama revolves around a little girl whose classmates lock her in a closet while the lightening spring passes, condemning her to live a soggy, sunless existence for the remainder of her childhood.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Cat And Dog Mutilations
description: Investigators in Utah and Colorado are looking into a possible connection among animal mutilations in both states. In the Denver metropolitan region, up to 24 cats have been mutilated in the last year, including 4 in the last two weeks. The mutilated remains of 10 cats and a dog were found in the Salt Lake City metropolitan region in the last two years. The animals have mostly been on residential lawns or in parks. A $12,000 reward is being offered in Colorado. The authorities in both states ask owners to keep cats indoors until the cases are solved. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: BRAZILIAN PROJECT TO CAUSE DROP IN HALLIBURTON'S PROFIT
description: The Halliburton Company said yesterday that profit in the current quarter would fall sharply because of widening losses from an oil project off the coast of Brazil. Cost overruns and delays at the Barracuda-Caratinga project for Petroleo Brasileiro, Brazil's national oil company, led to losses of $104 million, which would cut second-quarter profit to 2 cents a share, excluding some one-time items, Halliburton said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call previously expected the company to earn 25 cents a share. Stock in Halliburton, which is based in Houston, fell $1.27, or 5.2 percent, to $23.16 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Bishops' Session Assesses The State of the U.S. Church

title: Yanks Jolt Mets Early and Subdue Them Late
description: Robin Ventura played with the Mets for three years and he faced the Yankees in the 2000 World Series before being traded to them after the 2001 season. He was a favorite among Mets fans for playing through injuries, for never blaming others and for his performance in big games. His time with the Mets produced many highlights, but it did not exempt him from the strong feelings the Mets-Yankees rivalry brings out.

title: Battlefield Aid for Soldiers' Battered Psyches
description: It was only after the fighting stopped that Pvt. Christopher L. Labier began to feel the symptoms, though of what he did not know at the time. He became withdrawn. He lost his energy and his appetite. Worst of all were the images that flashed through his mind. They were not nightmares, since to have nightmares you have to go to sleep. And he could not.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: 2 U.N. Observers Abducted
description: Two United Nations peacekeepers were abducted from their headquarters in Beni, in the east. They were among eight stationed there to monitor a cease-fire between groups battling for control of the region. A spokeswoman for the mission said the motive and identities of the kidnappers were unknown. A diplomatic official in the capital, Kinshasa, said he had been told that the observers, both Africans, were alive. Last month, two United Nations soldiers, from Jordan and Malawi, were kidnapped and killed in the northeastern town of Mongwalu. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: F.D.A. Approves Over-Counter Sales Of Top Ulcer Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved over-the-counter sales of Prilosec, the little purple ulcer and heartburn pill that not long ago was the top-selling prescription medicine in the world. The decision benefits those who pay for the drug -- health insurers and people with no insurance -- and could roil the pharmaceutical industry.

title: MIRANT GETS NOTICE IT DEFAULTED ON CREDIT AGREEMENT
description: The Mirant Corporation said it received notice of credit default as it revised a note-exchange offer and asked banks to approve a possible plan for bankruptcy. Lehman Brothers Commercial Paper Inc., an agent under credit agreements with Mirant Americas Generation, notified the unit on June 6 that it defaulted by failing to deliver first-quarter financial statements, Mirant said in a public filing. Mirant is also asking its banks to approve a prepackaged bankruptcy plan to be used if bondholders refuse an offer of secured notes in a swap that would push back maturities on $1.45 billion in debt, the company said in a separate filing.

title: Senator Ready To Filibuster Over Views Of Court Pick
description: Senator John Kerry said yesterday that he would filibuster any Supreme Court nominee who opposes the legality of abortion or would ''turn back the clock'' on civil liberties, the environment and worker protection.

title: Iraqis Scramble for Scarce Small Bills
description: With a Bradley fighting vehicle behind him and a crowd of spitting-mad Iraqi bank customers in front, an exasperated Sgt. George Rogers tried to break the bad news.

title: Leaders Broadly Back a Draft Charter for the European Union
description: European leaders broadly endorsed the draft of a first constitution for the European Union at a summit meeting here today, calling the evolving document a historic step toward a more coherent identity and role for the union on the world stage.

title: Adjustment tips : Training firms offer help in bridging cultural divides
description: WASHINGTON  The rush and sheer number of things to be done for a move abroad can be overwhelming. Finding a house, locating the right schools, getting work permits and arranging to take only what you actually need are just some of the myriad tasks that consume the months before an international move.

Her breathing became constricted, her face swelled, she broke into hives and she felt a mild sense of panic.

description: Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, gave his strongest indication today that he could return as the team's coach.

They are known as hot drivers, high-tech clubs that propel a golf ball distances once thought humanly impossible, that threaten to make some championship courses obsolete, that are illegal according to the United States Golf Association's high-tech standards.

description: New Jersey Transit today chose two engineering firms to begin environmental impact studies of a proposed new rail tunnel under the Hudson River. The move helped inch forward a nearly decade-old idea that stillis not likely to be a reality for at least another decade.

Powell was in Jerusalem denouncing Hamas, the Islamic militant group, as the major obstacle to peace. Two gunmen appeared on the road, a friend said later, and fired about 30 bullets into the car.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: LAW SIGNED ENDING BERLUSCONI TRIAL President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, left, signed a law that gives Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi immunity from prosecution as long as he holds office. The law, rushed through Parliament, freezes his current bribery trial and shields him from a potentially embarrassing verdict as he takes the helm of the European Union's presidency on July 1. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Day-Night Rematch Is Possible
description: The names may have changed, and certainly the climate around each team has, but the Mets and the Yankees may relive one of the more memorable days in their rivalry next weekend.

title: Suspect in Plot On Bridge Drew Interest Earlier
description: The F.B.I. first interviewed Iyman Faris, the Ohio truck driver implicated in a plot to destroy the Brooklyn Bridge, shortly after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, officials said today. But investigators did not actively focus on Mr. Faris until about a year ago, when other investigations led agents to him, the officials added.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOULD, , BYRDIE
description: GOULD--Byrdie, loving wife, devoted mother and motherin-law, a wonderful grandmother and great-grandmother. A great lady who created love and happiness during the 92 plus years of her life. The memories that her family and friends have will live in their hearts forever. She will be missed and never forgotten by her husband Stuart, her sons Fred and Jay, her daughters-in-law Helaine and Luetta, her grandchildren, their spouses and her eight great - grandchildren. Funeral services will be at Temple Judea in Manhasset on Searingtown Road, just north of the Long Island Expressway, at 9:30 AM on Sunday, June 22.

title: Senate Panel Strikes Deal on Inquiry Into Iraq Arms Intelligence
description: Senate leaders reached a compromise agreement today on the scope of their investigation into the Bush administration's handling of prewar intelligence on Iraq, breaking a political logjam that had threatened the chances for a bipartisan approach to the inquiry.

title: CarMax Reports 21% Profit Rise as Sales Gain in First Quarter
description: CarMax Inc., the used-car retailer spun off from Circuit City Stores Inc., said yesterday that fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 21 percent as the company sold more used vehicles than expected.

title: MOODY'S LOWERS CREDIT RATINGS ON READER'S DIGEST
description: The credit ratings of Reader's Digest Association Inc. were cut to a level below investment grade by Moody's Investors Service as the company, whose revenue fell 5.9 percent last year, struggles to increase its main magazine's profit. Reader's Digest's senior secured rating was cut one level, to Ba1 from Baa3, and its senior unsecured shelf registration rating was lowered two levels, to Ba3 from Ba1. ''Their operating environment has been under pressure and somewhat challenging,'' said Glen Eckert, a vice president and senior credit officer at Moody's. A spokesman for Reader's Digest, which is based in Pleasantville, N.Y., said the action was not unexpected, but should not be a problem for the company. It had long-term debt of $884 million and current liabilities of $932.6 million in its most recent quarterly filing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHIKLER, , BARBARA (PETE)
description: SHIKLER -- Barbara (Pete). To our Grandma on your 75th birthday. A wondrous woman you were and wondrous you remain in our hearts and minds. Isabella and Lane Love from the Shikler-van Ingen Famil

title: Senate Votes Again to Allow Importing of Drugs From Canada
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to let pharmacists import prescription drugs from Canada and resell them in the United States, so consumers here could benefit from lower Canadian prices.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a House vote to repeal the estate tax referred incorrectly to the current rate for estates of at least $1 million. For 2003, estates of $1 million to $1.25 million are taxed at 41 percent; the rate gradually increases until it reaches 49 percent on estates of $2 million or above. (The 49 percent rate does not begin at $1 million.)

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Textile Trade Ruling
description: The World Trade Organization rejected a complaint brought by India that the United States was unfairly protecting its own industry in the $2.6 billion textile trade between the nations, the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, said. India had challenged the way the United States determines the country of origin of imported apparel products, saying the United States rules were protectionist, distorted trade and did not properly differentiate between textiles and other products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKOLNICK, , ISIDORE
description: SKOLNICK--Isidore. The Congregation of Temple Beth El Cedarhurst records with prodound sorrow the passing of its beloved former Principal. We express our deepest sympathy to the family. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Richard Holland, President >>AD#

description: At long last, deliverance. Three years of discombobulation and aching need finally ended at midnight yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Bulgaria: Phone Buyer Selected
description: The Advent International Corporation, a buyout firm based in Boston, was restored as the buyer of Bulgaria's phone company after it appealed a rejection by a state agency a month ago, the Supreme Administrative Court in Bulgaria said. The court said it overturned a decision by the supervisory board of Bulgaria's privatization agency. Advent agreed in April to buy a 65 percent stake in Bulgarian Telecommunications, the state-owned fixed-line phone company, from the government for 210 million euros ($244 million). The Advent bid had beaten a Turkish group's offer and the court held that the contract was valid.

title: Layoffs Averted as Buffalo Gets Control Board
description: Despite dire warnings from the mayor that hundreds of city workers could be laid off, garbage trucks rolled down the streets on schedule this morning, and firehouses and police stations were fully staffed.

title: In Arizona, a Mountain Retreat Is Reduced to Ashes
description: Perched high in the Santa Catalina Mountains, surrounded by towering pines and firs and brushed by cool alpine breezes, the cabins and hamlets of Mount Lemmon were where people from Tucson went to escape the searing heat of the desert.

title: ALBANY EXTENDS LANDLORD POWER OVER RENT CURBS
description: Senate Republicans forced through a measure today that would allow landlords to take thousands more New York City apartments off rent regulation in the next eight years, outmaneuvering Democrats who had sought to prevent a further erosion in rent protections for tenants in a million units.

description: For those used to the ramparts of the snowbound Alps, it does not get lower or much hotter than this.

description: The last pathetic hours of the New York legislative session drove home a rule about life in Albany. The enthusiasm of top politicians for political reform is most intense when they're sure there's no chance of anything becoming law.

description: ONE year later, the Mohawk has grown back into a normal spiky haircut. The body is a little more taut. Clint Mathis, the poor man's David Beckham, is still raising ''havoc'' -- his word, and the appropriate one.

title: 2 Nuclear Weapons Challenges, 2 Different Strategies
description: With his hands full in Iraq, President Bush has now given nearly identical warnings to Iran and North Korea -- that their efforts to build nuclear weapons will ''not be tolerated'' by the United States -- even while he is pursuing very different strategies to stop them.

title: A.C.C. Has Call To Make On Va. Tech
description: The presidents of the universities belonging to the Atlantic Coast Conference have scheduled a conference call for today to discuss adding Virginia Tech to the list of universities they may invite to join the A.C.C., three people with knowledge of the meeting confirmed yesterday.

title: Isolation, an Old Medical Tool, Has SARS Fading
description: Three months ago, SARS appeared poised to sweep the world, a mysterious new disease racing out of southern China for which there was no vaccine, cure or diagnostic test.

description: Protests here spread to at least eight other cities around the country today as a high-ranking imam called for the severe punishment of protesters.

description: Goldman Sachs's ambitious effort to improve the quality of its stock research has faltered.

description: Mike Tyson was arrested at a hotel in downtown Brooklyn early this morning after he got into a fistfight with two men and knocked one of them unconscious, the police said.

description: The first drug that short-circuits asthma attacks before they start was approved by the Food and Drug Administration yesterday, opening up a new chapter in treatment of the disease.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Move To Oust Justice
description: Congress took a first step toward impeaching Julio Nazareno, left, chief justice of the Supreme Court, with the judicial affairs committee of the lower house's unanimous approval of 15 accusations of wrongdoing against him. The action came as President Nstor Kirchner, a critic of the court, moved to limit his own power to appoint justices by allowing civic groups to file objections to his candidates. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Killings Rise In Manhattan, Worrying Morgenthau
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday that he was concerned about an increase in killings in the borough this year that has helped drive up the citywide murder rate by a little more than 5 percent, despite an overall decline in reported crime citywide.

title: STATE OF NEW YORK OPENS INQUIRY ON EXPRESS SCRIPTS
description: Express Scripts Inc., which manages prescription-drug benefits for employers and insurers, is under investigation by the New York State attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, on suspicions of overbilling state health plans. Shares of Express Scripts fell $2.53, or 3.6 percent, to $66.89 in Nasdaq trading after the company disclosed a subpoena from Mr. Spitzer in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Spitzer is examining the company's pricing policies, the attorney general's spokesman, Darren Dopp, said. The company, which is based in Maryland Heights, Mo., said in its filing that Mr. Spitzer's inquiry deals with ''state and federal antitrust and consumer protection laws,'' and that its practices comply with those laws.

title: Thieves and Saboteurs Disrupt Electrical Services in Iraq
description: The electricity system of Iraq, already damaged by the war, is now being torn apart by systematic looting and possibly by sabotage.

title: Ex-Assessor Pleads Guilty To Bribery In Tax Scheme
description: A former city tax assessor has pleaded guilty in a long-running bribery scheme in which city workers took money in exchange for lowering tax bills of some of New York's most valuable buildings, according to court documents.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 12 about an expanded federal cargo security program misidentified the Thai official who signed an agreement allowing American inspectors to work in a Thai port. He was the foreign minister, Surakiart Sathirathai. (Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra attended the signing ceremony.)

title: Nautica Astir After Mention Of Sale Talks
description: After two weeks of rumors, speculation and deals, Seventh Avenue garment executives were breathing a collective sigh of relief yesterday morning: nothing seemed on the immediate horizon, except rain.

title: U.S. and Brazil Each Need A Victory to Stay Afloat
description: Consider it an international soccer rarity: the United States and Brazil each faced with the same ultimatum, albeit unsaid. Each must win its next game or face going home.

title: A Zimbabwe Judge Frees Opposition Leader Jailed by Mugabe
description: A judge in Zimbabwe released the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai on bail today after he had spent two weeks in prison on treason charges stemming from work stoppages and demonstrations he had organized in an attempt to pressure President Robert Mugabe to resign.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: POLICE CHIEF RESPONDS TO ACCUSATIONS Amid calls for his resignation, Chief Clarence O. Bradford of Houston rebutted accusations that he had failed to address problems in the DNA section of the Police Department's crime laboratory. Chief Bradford released records of his efforts to repair problems, including a memorandum documenting a meeting in 1997 with police officials after an audit that showed problems with oversight and handling of DNA evidence. "When you look at the correspondence," the chief said, "you can see that I approved a plan of action. Those things were not done." (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Insurance Jobs Cut
description: The financial company Fortis said that it planned to cut 750 jobs, or 14 percent of the work force, at its Dutch insurance unit to cut costs as domestic demand for life insurance declines and lower interest rates crimp margins. Fortis, with headquarters in Brussels and Utrecht, the Netherlands, will eliminate the positions over the next three years as it integrates ASR Verzekeringsgroep, which it bought in 2000, the company said.

title: In Austria, an International Conference Examines a New Kind of Anti-Semitism
description: In 1938, after Germany annexed Austria, Hitler addressed a cheering crowd from a balcony at the Hofburg royal palace here, a fact much noted by participants in the first major international conference devoted exclusively to the subject of anti-Semitism.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Carmaker's Stock Sells
description: Investors submitted bids for more than 650 million shares in India's largest carmaker, Maruti Udyog, nine times the number available in its initial public offering this week. The company is majority owned by the Suzuki Motor Corporation of Japan. The Indian government sold part of its minority stake in the offering, a closely watched bellwether for the country's privatization program. Demand from individual investors surged even though some analysts said the offering price of 115 rupees ($2.40) a share was too high. Maruti Udyog's share of the Indian car market has fallen in recent years from 90 percent to just over half. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about research on effects of a popular pesticide, atrazine, misstated the assessments of E.P.A. scientists about the chemical's effects on frogs. The scientists said that there was ''sufficient evidence'' that atrazine might cause sexual abnormality in frogs -- not that it actually does so. The article also misstated the location of the University of Guelph, where Glen Van der Kraak, who commented, is a professor. It is in Guelph, Ontario, not Winnipeg, Manitoba.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCARTHY, , PATRICK.
description: McCARTHY -- Patrick. 59. Born in Johannesburg, South Africa. Resident of New York City for the last 23 years. Artist and builder by hand, intellect and heart. Died June 17 suddenly. He is survived by his son Joshua of Toronto, Canada, two brothers in South Africa, his loving and devoted partner Martha McDonald and hundreds of friends in New York, Canada and South Africa. He gave so much in so many ways to everyone he met. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Family and friends will gather at Redden's Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St on Saturday, June 21, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. >>AD#

title: Pettitte Takes Control and Then Takes His Time
description: Yankees pitcher Andy Pettitte quickly took command of the strike zone last night, and perhaps several inches on both sides. Two Mets looked at called third strikes in the first inning, and Jeromy Burnitz was thrown out after grumbling about his strikeout.

title: Support for Capital Vote
description: The House Republican with oversight responsibility for the District of Columbia said today that he favored granting voting rights to a representative from Washington.

title: Massachusetts Legislature Repeals Clean Elections Law
description: The Massachusetts Legislature today repealed the state's Clean Elections Law, which has provoked political squabbling, court battles, a car auction and an imbroglio over state office furniture after voters approved it overwhelmingly in 1998.

title: Court-Martial Is Backed In Fatal Grenade Attack

title: Gale Norton Rouses Congress
description: The Bush administration, in particular its interior secretary, Gale Norton, has always wanted to transfer more control of America's public lands to state and local governments and to open them to a wider range of commercial and recreational uses. But Congressional Democrats and some moderate Republicans are only now realizing that what Ms. Norton is trying to engineer is not just a rebalancing of the scales but a revolution in public policy deeply at odds with a long bipartisan tradition of environmental stewardship and more threatening than anything attempted by James Watt, Ronald Reagan's reactionary interior secretary and Ms. Norton's onetime mentor.

title: A Long Night and Day In a Year of Very Little
description: In the pageant of inaction that was New York's regular legislative session, Exhibit A was Albany's failure to pass a law to shed light on the inner workings of government.

title: Corrections

It is hundreds of millions of dollars, not billions. The article also misstated the estimated annual loss for the corn market. It is $300 million, not billion.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Gale Anne Hurd, a producer of ''Hulk,'' misstated the release year of ''Armageddon,'' another movie that she helped produce. It was 1998, not 1988.

title: SEMCO ENERGY CUTS DIVIDEND AND ISSUES PROFIT WARNING
description: Semco Energy Inc., which distributes natural gas in Alaska and Michigan, cut its dividend and forecast a 2003 net loss yesterday. Its shares fell 21 percent on the news. Semco cited the cost of refinancing debt and lower-than-expected revenue from its construction business. The company, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., also cut its quarterly dividend to 7.5 cents a share from 12.5 cents.

title: U.S. campus life : Binational students face big cultural gap
description: TURIN  Having been a college counselor in Europe for many years, I am always interested in my former students' stories of adjustment to American university life. Often they have lived much of their lives in Europe, and usually come from binational families.

title: William Marshall, 78, Actor In Movies and on Broadway
description: William Marshall, a character actor who performed for more than 40 years on Broadway, on television and in movies, died on June 11 in Los Angeles. He was 78.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Jesse Jackson At Site Of Unrest
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met privately with Benton Harbor officials, urging them to work to improve the quality of life of residents in that mostly African-American city 65 miles northeast of Chicago. The city was torn by two days of rioting after a black motorcyclist, Terrance Shurn, was killed on Monday in a police chase. Mr. Jackson also spoke to a large crowd at a community center and walked with a group of residents and community leaders to the accident site. He called on the town's wealthier neighbor, St. Joseph, to do more to help struggling Benton Harbor. Simon Shifrin (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Conviction In Theater Hostage-Taking
description: A court convicted a Chechen accused of aiding guerrillas who took 800 people hostage in a Moscow theater for more than two days last October. The verdict was the first against anyone charged in the siege, in which at least 129 hostages died, most from a gas used when commandos stormed the building. The Chechen, Zaurbek Talkhigov, was arrested during the siege and accused of telephoning the guerrilla leader and revealing the location of federal forces outside the theater. He was sentenced to eight and a half years in prison. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Ex-Treasurer Says Scheme Aided Campaign
description: Connecticut's former state treasurer, Paul J. Silvester, testified today that he invested state pension money with certain firms to help get jobs for former staff members and campaign donations for Gov. John G. Rowland.

title: TOUCH AMERICA FILES CHAPTER 11 BANKRUPTCY PAPERS
description: Touch America Holdings Inc., owner of a 21,000-mile fiber optic network, filed for bankruptcy court protection and asked a judge to approve the sale of crucial businesses to the 360networks Corporation for $28 million. The company, spun off from the Montana Power Company in 2000, listed $554.2 million in debts and $631.4 million in assets. The Chapter 11 papers for Touch America, which is based in Butte, Mont., were filed Thursday in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Immigration Plan Rejected
description: The upper house of Parliament blocked a controversial immigration bill that would have opened Germany's borders to a controlled flow of skilled foreign workers. The conservative opposition, which controls the house, attacked the legislation for seeking to bring in new foreigners at a time of rising unemployment. The bill, which was approved by the lower house, is supported by many business leaders. Hugh Eakin (NYT)

Dave Polansky, 83, Who Guided City College Team After Scandal

title: DOW CHEMICAL SECURES GAS DEAL WITH ENERGY COMPANY
description: Dow Chemical said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Freeport LNG Development, a Houston energy company, to obtain access to one-third of the capacity of a liquefied natural gas terminal being developed on Quintana Island, Tex. Dow will have the processing rights to 500 million cubic feet of natural gas a day, beginning in 2007, when Freeport's terminal is expected to start operating. The agreement is indicative of efforts by American companies to secure long-term gas supplies amid a current shortage of natural gas. Several projects are under way to build terminals to receive shipments of liquefied natural gas from sources outside North America. Simon Romero (NYT)

Mr. Green's departure is part of a plan to simplify the senior management structure, Reuters said. "We have undertaken to reduce costs, and I believe it is imperative that we cut expenditure at every level in the company," Mr. Glocer said.

title: Further From Heaven
description: IN his 2002 film ''Far From Heaven,'' Todd Haynes turned Douglas Sirk's 1955 tearjerker, ''All That Heaven Allows,'' about a small town's censure of a wealthy woman's romance with her gardener, into a parable about love and race in the civil rights era. His was a meticulous homage, beautifully shot, brilliantly acted -- it wasn't far from a masterpiece -- and yet, something went missing: Dennis Haysbert's gardener was so noble, and so genteel, that he was almost unreal. Julianne Moore's betrayed housewife was equally noble and genteel, and their love affair was unlike any affair that most of us have known. Watching it unfold, there was never a doubt that the two were meant to be together, and that the racism keeping them apart was evil.

description: HENDERSON--Gregory M., 51, of Palm Beach, FL, died Wednesday, June 18, at home. Born in South Orange, NJ, he lived in Rumson for most of his life. Prior to his retirement in March 2000, he was a Senior Vice President of Henderson Brothers, Inc. as well as a member of the New York Stock Exchange for twenty-three years. He was a member of The Breakers Hotel and Club, Palm Beach Yacht Club, Navesink Country Club and a former member of Monmouth Beach Bath and Tennis Club. He was a communicant of Saint Edwards Church, Palm Beach, FL. His brother Charles F. Henderson III predeceased him. He is survived by his loved and loving daughters, Katherine, Lauren and Christin; his former wife, Janet Henderson of Rumson; his parents Mary Louise and Charles F. Henderson of Palm Beach, FL; his three brothers, David of Rumson, Guy of Palm Beach FL, and Jerome of Middletown, NJ, and one sister, Mary Louise Clarke of Short Hills, NJ, and many nieces and nephews. Visitation will be held from 25PM and 7-9PM Monday at John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, NJ. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:30AM, Tuesday, at Holy Cross Church, Rumson. Interment will be held at Mount Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ. Memorial donations may be made in his memory to Christian Brothers Academy, 850 Newman Springs Road, Lincroft, New Jersey 07738. >>AD#

title: 'At War With Ourselves'
description: George W. Bush seemed surprised to get any applause at all. Gazing out at his audience at the United Nations, the president gave what an aide described as his "trademark smirk" as the delegates clapped coolly. There was a definite chill in the air. Only a year before, America had been bathed in sympathy from around the world after the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. Hundreds of thousands of Germans had gathered at the Brandenburg Gate, the site of JFK's "Ich bin ein Berliner" speech, to say that they now stood with America. France's Le Monde newspaper, normally no friend of Washington's, declared, "We are all Americans today." But this was September 12, 2002, a year and a day after the attacks, and the mood was very different. Other nations were angry at what they perceived to be American arrogance, the Bush administration's insistence on carrying a big stick-U.S. might-and talking loudly at the same time. This same week Bush would issue a new national security strategy, one that would mark the most historic shift in American thinking since the early days of the Cold War. While couched in diplomatic language, it was an unprecedentedly frank assertion that American dominance was here to stay, and that it was American values that would define the world.

So it is surprising, and welcome, to see its new president, Nstor Kirchner, take on a sensitive issue from the more distant past -- the criminal behavior of the armed forces during the ''dirty war'' of 1976-83. Mr. Kirchner wants the country's supreme court to nullify the pardons and amnesty laws that protect military violators. He has purged the military leadership to remove the dirty war generation from command positions and is willing to extradite Argentines wanted abroad for human rights crimes.

title: 'When Hollywood Had a King'
description: On a spring day in Chicago in 1922, two young men stood deep in conversation on the sidewalk outside the headquarters of Local 10, a branch of the American Federation of Musicians union. They might have conferred inside the building instead-one of them, James Caesar Petrillo, was the local's vice president-but he thought the walls had ears, and the message he wanted to deliver was confidential. He had sent word to his companion, Jules Caesar Stein, that he wanted to see him. Stein was a recent medical school graduate who booked bands on the side, and, in his relatively short career, he had already run afoul of the musicians union, and gotten caught in the crossfire of Chicago's ongoing, internecine labor wars. It seemed, moreover, to be Petrillo's fire that had caught Stein; the bombs that had recently exploded at several Chinese restaurants where Stein was booking bands were Petrillo's handiwork, Stein was convinced. At one of them, the Canton Tea Garden on Wabash, the damage had been especially severe. But the nature of the band-booking business-and more, of the city itself-was such that Stein had little recourse. If he wanted to continue in this business, he had to make his peace with this, the dominant musicians union. So he was eager to hear what Petrillo had to say.

title: 'A Palestine Affair'
description: 1. Bloomberg came out of the house in North Talpiot and bicycled toward the Arab village of Abu Tor. After ten minutes or so he dismounted and found a spot where the moonlight shone brightest on a stone wall. It was a clear night. He unstrapped his artist's box and retrieved his pallete. Back in London Joyce had carefully, kindly numbered the tubes in white so that he would be able to continue to paint even when the light grew dim. He couldn't love her anymore, although he wished that he could. His withdrawal from his wife was almost embarrassing-a man Bloomberg's age shouldn't be so damaged by the death of his mother. But he was. Late night at the London Hospital, the sky a sheet of midnight blue in the rain-streaked window beside her bed, and his mother, suddenly alert, recognizing him for the first time in weeks: "I will always remember you," she'd said. But of course it was the other way round. It was Bloomberg who would always remember her: the immigrant boy's mother ship and protector, the sails of her broad skirts and him cowering in the hold, gripping the cloth, his face pressed to the side of her leg. Meanwhile, as he mourned, Joyce continued to make small supportive gestures that made him feel sick inside. Her concern and consideration only highlighted his impoverishment of feeling. He was numb to her, and haunted. His mother wasn't the only ghost. Her death had released the others. Six years on from the war's end and here were his dead friends, appearing, like Banquo's ghost, mutilated and bloody, whenever his head snapped into a dream or reverie: Jacob Rosen, his ripped face covered in tawny phlegm; Gideon Schiff, his sweet smile intact but not his body.

A lesser clerical worker -- oh, a mere typist, say -- might have simply accepted her lot. But drawing on her characteristic patience, and plenty of pluck, the Sexy Stenographer is finally back, in Rob Reiner's latest romantic comedy, ''Alex and Emma,'' which opened on Friday.

title: Page Two: June 15-21 -- The Week Ahead; TALK WITH MUSHARRAF
description: President Bush has invited the Pakistani president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to Camp David on Tuesday at a moment when many in the administration worry that the country is a half-ally -- helpful in the war against Al Qaeda but perhaps a nuclear-proliferation risk. In public, Mr. Bush is sure to commend Mr. Musharraf for helping hunt down Osama bin Laden's lieutenants. In private, he will urge him to do far more, and to make sure that North Korea gets no more help from Pakistani nuclear scientists or laboratories (something Mr. Musharraf says has never happened). This is a rare moment: India and Pakistan appear to be talking to each other, but their nuclear rivalry is certain to be discussed Tuesday. David E. Sanger

title: Fast Food, Not Fast Antibiotics
description: Most people who eat regularly at McDonald's don't think of themselves as having much impact on the shape of global agriculture. The appeal of McDonald's has always been immediate gratification, and its basic offerings -- including hamburgers, Chicken McNuggets and French fries -- are usually the despair of nutritionists. Yet behind the scenes, McDonald's, which buys some 2.5 billion pounds of meat a year, has made remarkable strides, influencing the practices of suppliers that provide it with beef, chicken and pork. Last year, for instance, it conducted 500 audits of meat processing facilities globally, checking everything from cleanliness to the treatment of animals.

But Bender, 33, has visions of something homier: ''A forest cabin, but bigger. It would have a big yard, lots of trees and a really overgrown garden.'' A Los Angeles native, Bender likes being a novelist in a screenwriting town. ''They don't know what to do with you,'' she says. ''There's a lot of space for invention and reinvention. I like the freedom that offers.''

title: Traffic Ticket Surcharge Blocked by Legislature
description: A proposal by County Executive Andrew J. Spano to add a $25 surcharge on every traffic ticket to alleviate the $67 million county budget deficit was blocked by Democratic county legislators last week. ''The sense of the legislators was we don t want to levy more taxes after having property tax increased by 15 percent,'' said Lois T. Bronz, a Democrat and chairwoman of the Board of Legislators. Mr. Spano had originally proposed adding 1 percent to sales tax to close the budget gap, but state legislators refused to approve the measure. Since then, the county has cut spending by $15 million and raised the county property tax by 15 percent. Mr. Spano declined to be interviewed through his spokeswoman. Richard G. Wishnie, a Democrat representing Briarcliff Manor on the county board, said it was something else that the board members were hoping for. ''What we were hoping for was state aid,'' he said, ''not permission to further raise taxes.'' Yilu Zhao

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: JOHN SAYLES proves his filmmaking courage with MEN WITH GUNS (1998), a powerful American road movie made mostly in Spanish (with English subtitles). Federico Luppi stars as Dr. Humberto Fuentes, a recent widower who, rather than taking a traditional vacation, decides to look up some of his old students, young doctors he had trained to work with poor Indians in the remote villages of this unnamed Latin American country. He finds people who identify themselves by their labor (Salt People, Sugar People, Coffee People), and he learns that things have gone very badly for his students in this God-forsaken culture where people are frequently shot because, as a boy explains, ''the army was mad at them.'' This is a deadly serious film, but my favorite line belongs to the American tourist (Mandy Patinkin) who asks his wife, an almost fluent speaker of Spanish, ''What's the word for fajitas?'' -- Thursday at 10 p.m. and Friday at 11:45 a.m. and 5:45 p.m. on IFC.

title: But Exfoliating Is Not the Way to Every Woman's Heart
description: IN the film ''Two Weeks Notice,'' Hugh Grant plays George Wade, a piggy real estate developer with a closet the size of a small mid-Atlantic state. He loves shopping but hates to go anywhere alone, so he requires his chief counsel, played by Sandra Bullock, to join him on his retail excursions. She finds his obsession with his sartorial upkeep just short of repellent, and before they can fall in love, he must start to look a little rumpled and assume a few of her more high-minded interests.

title: Business; Crate and Barrel Handles Its Offshoot With Care
description: PEOPLE have been asking Gordon Segal for the last three years when he plans to build the second store of CB2, an eclectic offshoot of the Crate and Barrel chain, which he and his wife, Carole, started four decades ago. The answer is always the same: when he's good and ready.

title: Investing; Online Bond Trading Is Gaining, Despite the Bumps
description: RESEARCHING and trading stocks online became common in the long bull market. During the bond rally of the last three years, a small group of do-it-yourself investors has begun to assemble portfolios of bonds bought online.

title: It's Not Over: Pavarotti Schedules Another Goodbye

So chalk one up for the New York Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall, which stunned even high-level staffers within both institutions with the news that, come 2006, the orchestra would move to the hall and the two powerful entities would become one.

title: Technology Turns Walk in the Woods Into Treasure Hunt
description: LIKE pioneers in the wilderness, Al Rich and Tim Oldroyd forge ahead of the two womenfolk who are dawdling a short distance behind. The men keep a sharp eye out for wild critters and poisonous plants. An animal sprints across their path and Mr. Rich yells: ''Rabbit!'' The women are safe. Mr. Rich then eyes a fish in a nearby stream. He scrambles through the brush to get a better look. ''Trout,'' he shouts.

title: After Cease-Fire Talks Stall, Israelis Kill a Hamas Leader
description: Israeli undercover troops operating in the volatile West Bank city of Hebron shot and killed a senior leader of the Hamas movement who was suspected of organizing several recent suicide bombings, Israeli security sources and Palestinian witnesses said this morning.

title: Kennedy's Stance on Medicare Angers Allies
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Democratic Massachusetts bogyman for generations of Republican candidates, has brought President Bush and the Senate's Republican leadership to the verge of victory on a social issue Democrats have dominated for years.

title: Buenos Aires
description: After 18 months that have been among the most traumatic in Argentina's turbulent history, life in Buenos Aires has finally regained an air of normality. There is a new president, Nstor Kirchner, and a new mood of optimism, and their arrival coincides with the onset today of the Southern Hemisphere winter, which traditionally means a surge in activities in the sophisticated, elegant city that once prided itself on being ''the Paris of South America.''

title: Corrections

She fought federal legislation that had an impact on university research, and Duke faced national scrutiny with the death of 17-year-old Jsica Santilln after a heart-lung transplant at Duke Medical Center failed because of mismatched blood types.

description: SAVING what's left of the Hempstead Plains ''is gardening on a grand scale,'' said Carole Neidich-Ryder, a biologist on the staff of Nassau County Department of Parks, Recreation and Museums.

title: Shirley Horn Tries to Regain Her Other Voice
description: THE last year and a half has been pretty tough for Shirley Horn, the renowned jazz singer and pianist. She lost her right foot because of complications from diabetes. Her bass player of 33 years, Charles Ables, died of cancer, and Ms. Horn recently underwent chemotherapy in her battle with breast cancer. Her record company, Verve, decided not to renew her contract just before she went into the studio to work on her 12th album for it, ''May the Music Never End,'' which is to be released on Tuesday.

title: Lewis Cuts The Deepest And Retains His Title
description: When a slightly pudgy Lennox Lewis began his fight with the challenger Vitali Klitschko, Lewis moved with the speed and urgency of an overworked man taking a long lunch break. This was not a sharp Lewis. This was a tired-looking, cocky Lewis, who looked as if he had eaten one too many hot dogs the past few days, and he fought that way, too.

title: Assemblyman's Study Faults Health Education in Schools
description: More than 60 percent of New York school districts violate state or city rules regulating the way students learn about drug abuse, AIDS and sex education, according to a study of the city school system's health programs for kindergarten through eighth grade.

description: POSITIVE economic news, including upbeat reports on the regional economies in New York and Philadelphia, helped the dollar rally against the euro last week and sent Treasury yields sharply higher.

title: Board Shorts, Refined
description: The heavy surfer influence on fashion, which picked up momentum after the movie ''Blue Crush'' last year, prevails in the men's department, where surfers and swimmers can find modified board shorts, in solids, patterned panels or with tribal stripes across the middle. From Lacoste, swimmers can choose a pieced board short in three shades of blue ($65), right, or a solid blue model with canvas logo trim ($55, both at Lacoste boutiques). Banana Republic offers cargo board shorts in burnt orange, with a jute drawstring and zigzag top-stitching ($45). Vilebrequin puts a Euro-preppy touch on its drawstring shorts, above, with buoyant prints of pineapples, palm leaves and elephants ($120 at Saks Fifth Avenue). But the men's swimwear mecca this season is arguably Old Navy, a source of more than a dozen surfer styles, from solids and side stripes to bright hibiscus prints, all in a brights and neutrals. Best of all, they are $12.50 a pair, so even if you have never stepped on a surfboard, it's easy to look the part.

title: Finding Zen and Flowers in Bloom
description: THE creek, at last! After hiking up a mountain ridge, back down, and through a horse pasture on this hot, hot day, I found myself stepping into cool water, traversing a creek over worn granite stones -- my steps to the other side.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Greenfield Hill, Fairfield; Privacy, Convenience and Dogwoods
description: DURING a rare break in the long-hovering clouds one recent afternoon, Laura Leigh Caissy abandoned her art studio for a weathered Adirondack chair in her backyard on Greenfield Hill. Only her black Labrador retriever, Magenta, was around to notice Ms. Caissy painting pottery in the sun. Two acres of lawn and gardens buffered her from neighbors and the over-the-hedges chitchat that used to distract her when she lived in a more densely populated neighborhood of Fairfield.

title: Renting Wheels By the Hour
description: ''THIS is what the Internet was made for,'' said Robin Chase, a co-founder of Zipcar, a Web-based car-rental business that has been expanding in the New York area.

title: Lauren Ackerman and Paul Forte
description: SHE'S a strict vegetarian, while nothing makes him happier than a juicy rib-eye steak. Her father is a fiercely liberal congressman. His, a conservative, once campaigned against hers. She is Jewish. He is Roman Catholic. But Lauren Ackerman and Paul Forte are an easygoing pair and have similar tastes in humor and style.

title: Signals From Nowhere
description: I used to take a long road trip every year or two, usually in the middle of the summer, with no fixed schedule or specific destination, just a vague intention to try new foods and admire the changing scenery. And though I always took along an atlas, I rarely used it. I navigated by radio.

Emmer and Michael J. Emmer of Brooklyn. Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz will officiate at Wave Hill, the garden in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Nation Builders for Hire
description: The huge effort to restore Iraq's oil industry begins every day two hours south of the Iraq-Kuwait border, at the lavish Crowne Plaza Hotel in Kuwait City. No sooner does the lobby restaurant open at 5 a.m. than a line of middle-aged men in jumpsuits, golf shirts and identical tan caps forms at the breakfast buffet, eschewing the mezzeh and labneh for French toast, home fries and beef bacon. Outside, a couple of dozen silver S.U.V.'s are lined up, and after a quick breakfast the men are off in a swift northbound convoy, each car marked with the sideways V of duct tape that designates American and British vehicles. The road knifes across a packed pebble desert as flat as a griddle, with hardly a plant or a rock gentling the view to a hazy 360-degree horizon. But nobody's minding the scenery.

title: All 50 States Now Warn Of West Nile Virus Threat
description: George Polk, an inspector for the St. Tammany Parish Mosquito Abatement District in Slidell, 30 miles northeast of New Orleans, dips a long-handled ladle into a puddle beside a suburban lawn. He pulls out a cup of motionless black eggs and specks that wriggle like tadpoles. ''These are flood-water mosquitoes,'' Mr. Polk says.

title: Page Two: June 15-21 -- The Week Ahead; FED'S MOMENT

It is widely expected to do so in an attempt to slay the long downturn once and for all. But will the cut be one-half of a percentage point or one-quarter? Either way, short-term rates would fall to their lowest level since the 1950's. David Leonhardt

title: Iran and Nuclear Weapons
description: One of the central challenges of the coming decade is to stop nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of dictators and terrorists. Iran has just shown us the nature of the problem. Under the noses of international atomic inspectors, the Iranians have overcome the single biggest hurdle to building a nuclear weapon: they have developed the capacity to produce their own nuclear bomb fuel. They did so while appearing to comply with the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. The flaws of that treaty, and how to fix them, are now evident.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBBINS, , SHERMAN M.
description: ROBBINS--Sherman M. 57, Editor - In - Chief of Palm Beach Media Group, died suddenly June 18 at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Survived by his wife, Mary Gottlieb Robbins; children Scott Robbins and Stephanie Robbins Antone; step-children Brian Gottlieb and Jeffrey Gottlieb; and sister, Francine Craven. Mr. Robbins joined Palm Beach Media Group in 1996 and was editorial director of the company's 10 titles. He won many writing awards over the years and in 1999 was named Editor of the Year by the Florida Magazine Association. He served as marketing manager of Citibank's New York State commercial banking division and was VP of Citibank's worldwide advertising at Foote Cone & Belding. In 1979, he founded Robbins & Ries, Inc., a New York-based communications company. He is a graduate of Horace Mann High School and Ohio University. Contributions in his memory to Horace Mann High School, 231 W. 246th St., Riverdale, New York 10471. >>AD#

title: Shabalov's Sacrifice Creates Devastating Mating Attack

title: New Driver, New Car: An Expensive Mix

My 16-year-old daughter, Marian, wants that look and that car, and I have not discouraged her. Get a summer job, save some money and we'll talk about it, I said.

description: HAIL America, land of the speedy and home of the shaved, where the list of short things we love keeps getting longer. We love brief wars and abbreviated weapons, instant messaging and prescient gratification. A duchess said you can't be too trim; editors say the same about stories.

title: A Resort in India Becomes Family Friendly
description: WITH the old red stone ramparts of a Portuguese fort rising in the background, an Indian family gathered tentatively at the edge of the Arabian Sea. Intrigued by the novelty of ocean waves, two young girls skipped back and forth, until a rogue wave finally caught them and soaked the hems of their saris.

description: BEFORE the end of the summer, scores of newly minted high school graduates will head off to college, on their own for the first time. How prepared are they to balance a checkbook, handle a credit card or budget an allowance?

title: Savant for a Day
description: In a concrete basement at the University of Sydney, I sat in a chair waiting to have my brain altered by an electromagnetic pulse. My forehead was connected, by a series of electrodes, to a machine that looked something like an old-fashioned beauty-salon hair dryer and was sunnily described to me as a ''Danish-made transcranial magnetic stimulator.'' This was not just any old Danish-made transcranial magnetic stimulator, however; this was the Medtronic Mag Pro, and it was being operated by Allan Snyder, one of the world's most remarkable scientists of human cognition.

title: Kristine Suzuki, Alexander Sasieta

His answer was always no. Yet on June 2 at 4:30 p.m., one and a half hours after the House passed the bill, a teenager was killed when his car smashed into a tree in Brookfield, Mr. Scribner's hometown.

title: Analyzing a Lease Renewal Clause

A month after the lease automatically renewed, I received a letter from my landlord informing me of a rent increase to take effect on April 15. Having paid the increase, does this now make me a month-to-month tenant? If I wish to move, may I do so at any time by giving the landlord one month's notice? . . . Jane Harvey, Forest Hills

title: And the Summer's Most Infectious Single Is . . . ?
description: PINK -- Just when it seemed possible that sullen ballads had gotten the best of her, Pink returns with ''Feel Good Time,'' the most infectious single so far this summer, from the soundtrack to ''Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle'' (Sony). Hard-rock rhythms collide with bubbly new-wave synthesizers, and when Pink sings, ''We get paid to rattle our chains,'' it almost sounds as if she's not complaining. During an exhilarating performance of the song at the MTV Movie Awards, Pink re-enacted many of the best moments from the music video: there was face-licking, hair-pulling and lots of strutting. (See both the video and the live performance at www.mtv.com/bands/az/pink/artist.jhtml.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SQUIRE, , JAMES ROBERT
description: SQUIRE -- James Robert. Born October 14, 1922 in Oakland, California died June 9, 2003 in Houston, Texas after a short illness. James attended Pomona College and served during World War II. He received his Doctorate in English Education from the University of California at Berkeley. He then taught in the Oakland Public Schools and as a lecturer of English Education at UC Berkeley, the University of Illinois, and Harvard University. He served as Executive Secretary of the National Council of Teachers of English and was Editor-inChief and Publisher, of Ginn and Company. He co-authored more than 8 books on English Education. He received a Doctor of Letters Degree from Pomona College as well as many awards from professional societies. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Barbara Squire, a daughter, two sons and two grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to the National Council of Teachers of English. There will be a memorial service July 5 at 11:30 A.M. in the Noble Chapel at Cypress Lawn Memorial Park, Colma, CA >>AD#

title: Ideas & Trends; What We Don't Know About Obesity
description: TRIAL lawyers say there is a clear culprit in the obesity epidemic: a fast food industry that keeps plying Americans with calorie-laden, cheap meals and snacks. The food companies are as bad for Americans' health as the tobacco companies, they say, and the lawyers intend to litigate. A conference this weekend in Boston is examining legal approaches to fighting obesity.

description: EVERYONE knows that calcium is a requirement for strong bones and teeth. Less well known is that it plays an important role in maintaining the normal functions of the heart, nerves, muscles and other bodily systems.

title: The Road to Yossarian
description: With ''Catch-22,'' Joseph Heller (1923-99) delivered perhaps the most original and sardonic war novel of the previous century and added to the cultural lexicon. But his beginnings as a short-story writer are less well known. In CATCH AS CATCH CAN: The Collected Stories and Other Writings (Simon & Schuster, $25), the editors, Matthew J. Bruccoli and Park Bucker, bring us a selection of Heller's earliest fiction -- some of it originally appeared in magazines like Esquire and The Atlantic Monthly -- that includes five previously unpublished stories. As its title implies, ''Catch as Catch Can'' is something of a grab bag. In Heller's juvenilia we see experiments with style and detect hints of the irreverent, frenzied voice that he would eventually make his own. ''A Day in the Country,'' for example, reaches a kind of crescendo of panic as it expresses a heroin addict's anguish. ''MacAdam's Log'' tells of a lonely grandfather who, desperate for a purpose, embarks on imagined sea voyages. And ''Bookies, Beware!'' records how a college student uses ''pure science'' to pick winners at the track. Heller's signature absurdism surfaces only in the later work, notably in a handful of stories and a one-act play spun from his masterpiece. The author's comments on ''Catch-22'' and an affecting essay about growing up in Coney Island make up the rest of this scattered but occasionally fascinating book. Katherine Wolff

With her help, WestLB has transformed itself from a staid local lender into a big hitter in European corporate finance.

description: Those who persistently violate E-ZPass rules are soon going to find bill collectors on their tails.

title: Ang Lee on Comic Books And Hulk as Hidden Dragon
description: ''KIDS don't even read comic books anymore,'' says Ang Lee with a smile. ''They've got more important things to do -- like video games.'' Sitting in a Midtown Manhattan office recently, he's discussing his new film, which features Marvel Comics' garbage-truck-size, emerald-green combination of Mr. Hyde and the Golem, the Hulk. As he speaks, a rumbling of the subway is so pronounced that it seems the Incredible Hulk himself is shaking the building to emphasize his words. ''That's what my sons tell me, and they know. They're comic book geeks,'' Mr. Lee says, with an inflection that's the aural version of a shrug.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICKELSON, , MARILYN STONE
description: NICKELSON--Marilyn Stone. 72. June 20, 2003, in Las Vegas, NV, from complications caused by emphysema. What a lady! She died young. Chronologically she was 72, but her intellectual presence was always with the here and now. Marilyn was born into a conservative midwestern culture in Tiffin, OH. By her college years at Denison she had become a confirmed liberal and activist in Democratic politics that lasted the rest of her lifetime. She was a living example that a first rate public school education could match up with the best that private institutions could produce. Having a wonderful sense of humor she could laugh at a remonstrance of having ''leftist'' views and lived with the premise ''protect me from zealots of any stripe.'' An omnivorous reader and naturally fast, she loved the libraries in whatever community she lived in, often taking a half dozen books at a time for a week's reading. Marilyn could be scathingly effective in argument but she always looked for the best in people. Her greatest compliment to anyone was that ''he has no side.'' We miss her physical presence, but she will always be part of our lives. Her last words ''so what are you thinking?'' provoke staggering introspection. She is survived by her husband James, daughter Claire Wolfenden of Hillsborough, CA, son Stone of Las Vegas, NV, son J.T. of Newport Beach, CA, two granddaughters Abby and Page Wolfenden, sister Mary Radigan of Vermont, and sister Peggy Walker of Florida. Memorial gifts to the New York Society Library, 53 East 79th St, NYC 10021. >>AD#

description: BEFORE the play begins, the voice of Maria Callas is heard, the speaker turned on full blast to drown out ''the sound of garbage men emptying the garbage in the alley,'' to quote the stage directions of ''Gemini,'' Albert Innaurato's well-worn play, which is being reanimated at the Schoolhouse here.

description: IT has been my observation that when Indian restaurants branch out into Southeast Asian cuisines, they sometimes lose their bearings. This came to mind recently during visits to Flute in Monroe, which bills its cooking style as ''Pan Asian.''

description: SUMMER SUITE -- The New York Palace Hotel is taking 50 percent off rates for its 80 suites during summer weekends. title: After 'The Bell Jar,' Life Went On
description: THEY kept going back to that photograph, passing it hand to hand. Taken 50 years ago this month, it shows 20 young women from across the country who came to New York in 1953 to work as guest editors at Mademoiselle magazine. Chosen from 1,500 applicants, they were dressed identically in tartan kilts, and were shot from above in the formation of a star. The woman at the very top of the picture, at the very top of the star, was Sylvia Plath, who immortalized the guest editor program in her autobiographical novel, ''The Bell Jar.'' Some of the others were the real-life inspirations for some of its characters.

title: Revealed: Secrets of the Mini
description: Ever since the 1960's, when Mary Quant invented the thigh-skimming mini, women have flirted with the look -- with varying success. This season, despite (or perhaps because of) dangerously short lengths and body-hugging silhouettes, miniskirts are more popular than ever. They are ''not for the self-conscious,'' cautions Jenny Altman, a freelance fashion stylist, who says slim hips and ''the legs of a 20-year-old, even if you're not a 20-year-old'' certainly help. Here is a guide to some of the season's best and briefest styles.

title: Breaking the Spell
description: Someone had better warn the pediatricians and the emergency rooms. The new Harry Potter, ''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix,'' went on sale yesterday, and at 896 pages, it is significantly longer than Potter IV (''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire''), which was already a serious doorstop. Any day now we can expect to see 9- and 10-year-olds with painfully elongated arms and curved spines from trying to haul the new volume around, or with crushed ribs and bruised sternums from trying to prop it up on their frail, undeveloped chests. If the new book catches on, that is. Potter's publisher, Scholastic, has already printed 8.5 million copies, more than twice as many as the first printing of Potter IV, and advance sales are similarly way ahead of those for the earlier volume. But some booksellers are concerned that the fad may have finally played itself out, and that the two Potter movies in particular have stripped the books of some of their magic. If you've already seen Harry on the big screen, and know exactly what he looks like, what's the point of trying to envision him in your mind's eye?

title: The World; Nuclear Ambitions Aren't New for Iran
description: BEFORE he was overthrown by an Islamic revolution in 1979, Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi of Iran said that his country would have nuclear weapons ''without a doubt and sooner than one would think.''

title: Healer Bishops Are Sent to Ease Churches' Pain
description: Seventeen years ago, the Vatican dispatched a 53-year-old New York priest named Harry J. Flynn to take over as bishop in a Louisiana diocese. His assignment was to rescue the faith of the Roman Catholics there whose children had been sexually violated by the Rev. Gilbert Gauthe, in the first nationally notorious case of a pedophile priest.

title: How to Escape an Office With No Walls

title: Soaking Up Knowledge
description: For those who hate activities like sunbathing but have to go down the Shore for the sake of family harmony, the American Littoral Society has a deal for you. The society (''no, we're not a book club,'' says Tony Totah, its southern New Jersey director) devotes itself to studying and preserving that part of the coast between the high- and low-tide levels, a zone that encompasses tidal pools, sand bars, riverbanks, estuaries and all the wildlife found there. Its Institute of Coastal Education, also financed by Clean Ocean Action, in Cape May County, has exhibits and programs for both young and old. Children can learn how to safely rescue a stranded whale while their parents investigate the making of scrimshaw. In addition, Mr. Totah's office holds a variety of critters, with a brood of new-born octopi as the latest addition.

description: I CAN'T imagine Manhattan without Central Park. Without the park, meadows and lakes would be miles away, instead of just behind the Metropolitan Museum. Without the park, taxis couldn't take those east-west shortcuts that are like sudden short drives into the country. Columbus Circle would be simply a circle, like Piccadilly Circus, instead of an arc opening onto a generous green wood. I would never see the top of the Dakota sticking up out of the trees like a spooky Transylvanian castle.

title: A New Marquee Name: Hirschfeld
description: THE Al Hirschfeld Theater will take its place on Broadway tomorrow, when the Martin Beck Theater at 302 West 45th Street is officially renamed. Hirschfeld, who died on Jan. 20 at 99, chronicled Broadway in caricatures that appeared in The New York Times beginning in 1928.

description: About 2,000 Shiite demonstrators marched on the gates of the Republican Palace here today, demanding that the American and British occupation authorities allow elections under Islamic supervision for the formation of a national government.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: ALCHEMY. By Margaret Mahy. Margaret K. McElderry. $16.95. (Ages 12 and up) Somehow his teacher knew that Roland had shoplifted three pens, a pie and a notebook from a supermarket. In exchange for silence he wants Roland to find out what the problem is with the aloof girl called Jess Ferret. It's another suspenseful tale of magic and the startlingly strange from the skilled New Zealand novelist.

title: Claw Daddy
description: On a summer evening not long ago, I was preparing to grill a dozen or so lobsters for dinner. This meant killing them first, by plunging a knife into the shell just behind the eyes, drawing it forward to split the head in two, then reversing the blade so as to bisect the entire creature, from head to tail. I had piled the lobsters on a counter next to the sink and with no more consideration for their feelings than if I were opening an oyster or peeling a potato, reached for the first victim and proceeded to kill it. To my surprise, the others raised their claws as if in horror at what they were seeing and scuttled backward. Some fell to the floor, others into the sink; I was faced with an ethical dilemma. For it was now plain that these tasty creatures, despite their low standing on the evolutionary scale and unlike the potato, fear death just as we do.

description: WHEN Max Beckmann stepped off the train in New York in August 1949, he considered himself a marked man. On the trip he had written in his diary: ''My time ran out long ago -- and is only prolonged artificially. Outside the crickets chirp away the summer. Beautiful, that sleep-inducing hornlike crackling noise. Could one sleep forever?''

description: JOEL HOWARD and Tracy Tucker, both 40, are partners, co-workers and Texans. They come from proud Suburban-driving, central-air-loving families, from houses with big yards and bigger garages. Their move to New York three months ago, Mr. Tucker said, was as extreme a culture shock as you can have without learning a new language.

description: WHEN Penny Schuster graduated from Lawrence High School in 1970, she was proud of her accomplishment and degree.

description: With continued violence between Palestinians and Israelis threatening Washington's latest drive for peace, King Abdullah of Jordan appealed today to international negotiators to ''stay the course.'' The alternative, he said, ''is that this region will slide back downhill.''

title: The Prequel, and Sequel, to 'Sex and the City'
description: IF you can't wait to find out what happens in the sixth and final season of ''Sex and the City,'' which begins tonight on HBO, there's one way to tell: watch the sequel. It runs on Lifetime up to seven times a day on weekdays and twice a day on Saturdays. It's called ''The Golden Girls.''

description: Kim Gaskin was waffling over what to buy at the Virtuous Woman Bakery in Voorhees. Would it be the 7-Up Bundt cake or the peach cobbler?

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the role of Valry Giscard d'Estaing in the constitutional convention of the European Union likened it imprecisely to Thomas Jefferson's contribution to the United States Constitution. Jefferson wrote the Declaration of Independence, and many of its elements were incorporated into the philosophy of the Constitution. Jefferson also corresponded with James Madison, a principal author of the Constitution, but did not attend the Constitutional Convention. At the time, he was the American minister to France.

title: Espalier Yields Beauty And Taste
description: AN espalier is a plant whose branches are trained to an orderly and ornamental two-dimensional form. Hang fruit on those branches and you have a plant offering not only beauty but also superb flavor, a result of leaves bathing freely in sun and air in favorable balance with fruit.

title: The Melancholy of the Sea
description: FROM illustrations of ancient legends to paintings of naval battles and piracy, the sea has long been a popular subject in art. But it wasn't until the 17th century, with the rise of the Dutch Republic as a maritime power, that marine painting came into its own. It flourished for about a century in Holland before moving to England, after the shift in sea power from the Dutch to the English.

title: The Rising Price of Getting Well
description: IRA ROSENBLOOM is an accountant, not a doctor, but he sees plenty of pain as his clients -- and his own firm -- struggle to pay health insurance premiums that are rising faster than they have in more than a decade.

title: Pension Reserve: What's Enough?
description: ACCOUNTING is a dismal science, pension accounting even more so. But it is increasingly important to penetrate the fog today, when companies are using complex and sometimes hidden tactics to change the way they pay for their pension plans. For the roughly one in five workers in the private sector whose employers have established pension plans, those changes could significantly affect the way they live in retirement.

title: Depression's Second-Class Status
description: To the Editor:

title: One Size Definitely Does Not Fit All
description: ''DID you know that it's Beautiful Women Month?'' a much-forwarded e-mail message asks, before making a few pertinent statements. Here's a sampling: ''Marilyn Monroe wore a size 14''; ''If Barbie was a real woman, she'd have to walk on all fours''; and ''The average woman weighs 144 lb. and wears between a 12-14.''

description: There are only two official long weekends this summer (three if you count Memorial Day), but that won't stop some workers from creating their own extended holidays, a new survey suggests.

description: Dr. Michele Carol Martinez and Dr. Peter Carson Lamport Nohrnberg were married yesterday in New Haven. The Rev. Kim D. Wilson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony in the Dwight Chapel at Yale University.

title: The Nation; Will the Court Move Right? It Already Has
description: IN the intense focus on the Supreme Court's future, with crucial decisions expected this week and speculation at a peak over whether new appointments will soon drive the court further to the right, it is easy to overlook an important element of the court's present: how conservative it is right now.

Jefferson also corresponded with James Madison, a principal author of the Constitution, but did not attend the Constitutional Convention. At the time, he was the American minister to France.

title: Lifting the Lid on Doris Duke's Jewel Box
description: This summer visitors to Rough Point, Doris Duke's 105-room Newport cottage, have a bonus in store. For the past three years they have been able to admire her collections, imagine her feeding her pet camels graham crackers as the Atlantic crashed against the rocks edging the lawn and breakfasting among ormolu-mounted mother-of-pearl furnishings. But they might leave wondering what this intensely private woman was really like. From now until Sept. 30 they can lift the lid on her jewel box and examine more than a hundred of her exquisite baubles in ''Gems of the East and West,'' which is not so much a collection as a scrapbook documenting taste in 20th-century jewelry.

title: Page Two: June 15-21; New Profile Policy: Is Less Really Less?
description: SAY a tip comes in that Middle Eastern terrorists are planning to hijack a plane this week. Say you work for the new Transportation Security Administration at La Guardia. And now say you are screening a man who looks Middle Eastern to you.

description: It has been almost four years since Paul J. Silvester pleaded guilty to having used his office as Connecticut state treasurer to shake down people seeking state business, setting off the first of many scandals to disgrace a member of Gov. John G. Rowland's inner sanctum.

title: Roger Neilson, 69, Innovator As Longtime Hockey Coach
description: Roger Neilson, the coach of eight National Hockey League teams and an assistant coach of four for more than a quarter-century, and one of the game's great innovators, died yesterday at his home in Peterborough, Ontario. He was 69.

It is ''Super Diaper Baby,'' not ''Super Diaper Boy.''

title: Clijsters Defeats Henin-Hardenne
description: Kim Clijsters won the Ordina Open yesterday in Rosmalen, the Netherlands, when justine Henin-Hardenne quit after hurting her left hand during the second set of an all-Belgian final. The rematch of the French Open final earlier in the month ended with a 6-7 (4), 3-0 victory for Clijsters in the grass-court Wimbledon tuneup.

title: Blue Men of Scotland
description: Nine-year-old Tiffany Aching, a farm girl, has decided that she wants to be a witch when she grows up, despite being saddled with a name that she suspects won't work as a witch-worthy moniker because ''people would laugh.'' But Terry Pratchett provides no fancy schools or well-funded training programs for young witches in THE WEE FREE MEN (HarperCollins, $16.99; ages 12 and up), only the power of dreams -- both real and imaginary. In the very first chapter, Tiffany resourcefully uses her sticky little brother, Wentworth, as bait to smack a toothy green sea monster in the face with a frying pan. This minor adventure brings her to the attention of Miss Tick, a full-fledged witch who gives Tiffany some tips about what being a witch is really about: ''Witches don't use magic unless they really have to. It's hard work and difficult to control. . . . A witch pays attention to everything that's going on.'' As Tiffany mulls all this over, she meets a rowdy band of six-inch-tall, kilt-wearing blue men who call themselves the Nac Mac Feegle, or the Wee Free Men, who speak lovingly in their thick Scottish accents about stealing and fighting. Later, when Tiffany must prove herself and rescue Wentworth from the clutches of an evil queen from another dimension, the Wee Free Men and a cranky talking toad with a flair for legal terminology serve as her guides and companions on her quest in the strange land. With its wry wit and acerbic collision of the mystical with the mundane, the latest book in Pratchett's internationally popular Discworld series of fantasy novels, this one specially for young adults, is good solid storytelling done in a style that reads like Celtic mythology fused with the girl power of ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer'' with dialogue by Robert Burns. J. D. Biersdorfer

Only that he's 20 and what the N.B.A. auditors of flesh and bone call ''a freak'' enabled him to even imagine that he could make this play. From a little triangular section of seats right behind the Suns bench, reserved for homeboys, lovers, swindlers and kin, Stoudemire's people looked on. Among them was Marwan Stoudemire, Amare's 14-year-old half-brother, whom Amare brought west with him from central Florida and enrolled in a private Phoenix day school. Marwan is not a freak. He wears a metal cast of the Cartoon Network antihero ''The Brain'' on a chain around his neck, has a heartbreaking smile and soft, ancient eyes, and if anything, he is small and slight for a ninth grader. After the game, when he told his brother's towering teammates that he touched the rim that afternoon, all he got was rolled eyes.
