We refuse to loosen the grip on our hand-held cellular phones while driving. It's been nearly two years since the New York State legislature banned the use of hand-held phones while operating an automobile. It's not as if the law completely bans talking and driving. It still allows drivers to talk using headsets or speakerphones. The problem, the law breakers say, is that those devices just aren't as convenient. You might even miss a call on occasion while fiddling to get the earpiece on.

Up he scrambled, past the lower deck gun ports and an instant stink of stale humanity and bilge water, past the main deck ports, until at last he hauled himself on to the upper deck which suddenly appeared, smooth and shining white under its great banded masts and filigree rigging, the air heavy with the mingled aromas of wood, rope, tar, paint and metal. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Faces Court In Bomb Hoax
description: A 23-year-old man is scheduled to appear in federal court today after his arrest on Saturday in a bomb scare that snarled traffic for most of the day, especially at the Lincoln and Holland tunnels. The police and the F.B.I. yesterday did not release the name of the man, who was charged with lying to a federal agent. About 5 a.m. Saturday, the man called 911 and said he had information about bombs in several locations in New York City, the authorities said. Security was immediately heightened citywide, especially around the tunnels. Traffic slowed, particularly outside the Holland Tunnel. Normal traffic flow did not return there until after 11 p.m. The man was questioned by the Joint Terrorism Task Force, which later described his information as ''not credible.'' Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Beyond the Pale
description: Many of the Bush administration's judicial nominees have been evasive about their positions on abortion, but not William Pryor. description: An apartment building in Sunnyside was evacuated yesterday after a 21-year-old tenant found a hand grenade in the hallway. The grenade was found in a hallway of 42-09 47th Avenue at 11:30 a.m. The 90-apartment building was evacuated for two hours. There was no information yesterday on where the grenade had come from. The police said the bomb squad was checking the device for fingerprints. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLARK, , OLIVE MARION
description: CLARK--Olive Marion. 80, passed to eternal life June 21, 2003, in Lenox, MA. Daughter of Earle and Mildred Roberts, she was born and educated in New York City, where she also studied under George Balanchine at the School of American Ballet and sang in choirs, including the Collegiate Chorale with Robert Shaw and Arturo Toscanini. A graduate of Barnard College (B.A.) and Teachers College, Columbia University (M.A., Ed.D.), she served for 33 years as teacher and administrator in the New York City Public School system. Assistant Professor at Fordham University Graduate School of Education at Lincoln Center. She retired to the Berkshires in 1985. In addition to music and art, her lifelong passion was the care and protection of animals. Survived by her devoted husband Robert I. Clark Sr. of Lenox, her beloved son Robert Francks and his partner Laurence Gleason of New York City, and her cousin Dorothy Somers of Boca Raton, FL. Her beautiful spirit will continue to inspire and guide the many people whose lives she touched with such grace and love. Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated at 11 AM, Wednesday, June 25, at St. Ann's Church, Main Street, Lenox, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Animal D.R.E.A.M.S. description: BENNETT--Pearl. We longtime friends and admirers of Pearl Bennett mourn the death at 92 of our dear and gallant friend. A delight to all throughout her life, Pearl enriched ours with her interest in everyone and everything, especially music and Democratic politics. title: Webdenda
description: Advertising Education Foundation , New York, presented awards last week at its third annual Honors Night, intended to recognize outstanding agencies, advertisers and media companies. Leo Burnett Worldwide , Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe, received the agency award. The United States division of Nestle, Glendale , Calif., received the award for advertisers. Dow Jones & Company won the award for media companies. Also, John (Jock) Elliott Jr. , chairman emeritus of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, New York, part of the WPP Group, received the lifetime achievement award. Valerie Allen was named New York account manager at Smithsonian magazine, New York. She had been advertising sales associate at Teen People, New York, published by the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner. Smithsonian is published by the Smithsonian Business Ventures division of the Smithsonian Institution. Corporate Culture Marketing by Barr Consulting Services and Priscilla Baer Design , both in New York, formed a strategic alliance to help companies and organizations use their anniversaries in marketing and fundraising. Louis Coletti was named fashion category manager at Departures magazine, New York, succeeding Nicole Maggio, who left, the company said. Mr. Coletti had been publishing director at Contents magazine. Departures is part of American Express Publishing, New York, a unit of the American Express Company that is managed by the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner. The Direct Marketing Association , New York, named two new members for its Hall of Fame: Herschell Gordon Lewis , principal at Lewis Enterprises and former chairman at Communicomp, and Fredrick J. Simon , a longtime executive at Omaha Steaks. They will be honored on Oct. 14 at the association's 86th annual conference and exhibition in Orlando, Fla. Eyeblaster , New York, a provider of online advertising technology, opened an office in Chicago, headed by Brenda Coan , as manager for business development for the Midwest. She had been Midwest sales manager at Endemic Media, New York. The Ford Motor Company and the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation took top honors, sharing one gold award and winning another gold each, at the first Cause Marketing Halo Awards , intended to recognize outstanding work promoting non-profit and charity work. Ford and Komen received a gold award in the Best Health Campaign category for a joint campaign to raise money and awareness for the fight against breast cancer. Ford won its other gold award in the Best Joint Message Promotion category, for a campaign with the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children encouraging families to photograph and fingerprint their offspring. Komen received its second gold award in the Best Transactional Campaign category for a collaboration with KitchenAid, part of the Whirlpool Corporation, and Saatchi & Saatchi, part of the Publicis Groupe, to generate donations to help fight cancer. Ronni Heyman was named vice president for new business development at Coyne Public Relations , Fairfield, N.J. She had most recently been communications director at eluxury.com, San Francisco, part of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton. Hill & Knowlton , New York, part of the WPP Group, opened a global practice in corporate social responsibility. There are six executives heading different regions of the practice; in the United States, the practice is being overseen by Eric Borsum, senior vice president. Joan Sheridan LaBarge , corporate publisher for new business development at Gruner & Jahr USA , New York, was named publisher at YM , New York, owned by Gruner & Jahr. Ms. LaBarge, also a former publisher of Rosie magazine, which was closed last year by Gruner & Jahr, succeeds Laura McEwen, who is now the vice president and publishing director at Reader's Digest magazine and other publications owned by the Reader's Digest Association, New York. Gruner & Jahr USA is part of Bertelsmann. Jonathan Mairs , account director at Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide , New York, was named vice president for the corporate practice and financial communications team. Ogilvy Public Relations is part of the WPP Group. Rich Masters was named managing director at Qorvis Communications , Washington. He had been policy and communications director for Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana. Josh McGraw , president for the Jacksonville, Fla., market at Clear Channel Communications , San Antonio, Tex., was named regional vice president for the new Southeast region, composed of six television stations in Jacksonville; Memphis, Tenn.; and Mobile, Ala. Sonya McNair was named to the new post of vice president for public relations and corporate communications at Essence Communications Partners , New York. She had been vice president of publicity and corporate communications at the Fox Broadcasting Company, New York, part of the News Corporation. Essence Communications Partners is a joint venture of Essence Communications and the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner. Thom Moon was named project manager at Nest Marketing , Cincinnati, part of the Critical Mass Media division of Clear Channel Communications. He had been vice president for client services at the Radio Research Consortium, Olney, Md. Frank Puma , media analyst at EarthQuake Media , New York, was named senior media analyst. John Quick was named to the vacant post of director for the health care and pharmaceutical practice at the New York headquarters office of Hill & Knowlton . He had been general manager at Euro RSCG Life NRP, New York, part of Euro RSCG Life, a unit of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas. Hill & Knowlton is part of the WPP Group. Steve Snyder was named executive vice president at CFM Direct , Oakbrook Terrace, Ill. He had been Midwest regional vice president at the Naperville, Ill., office of Donnelley Marketing, part of the InfoUSA Company. Strategy and Beyond , Chicago, an agency specializing in customer acquisition, was opened by Michael Mesic and Ilan Geva . Mr. Mesic had been president at Strategic Solutions Group Consulting, Chicago. Mr. Geva had been principal at CMYK and Beyond, Chicago. The Spar Group , Tarrytown, N.Y., acquired All Store Marketing Services , Greenville, Tex., an agency specializing in in-store events. Also, Darla McCrary , principal at All Store Marketing, was named vice president for in-store event sales for the Texas region at Spar.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MAN FACES COURT IN BOMB HOAX A 23-year-old man is scheduled to appear in federal court today after his arrest on Saturday in a bomb scare that snarled traffic for most of the day, especially at the Lincoln and Holland tunnels. The police and the F.B.I. yesterday did not release the name of the man, who was charged with lying to a federal agent. About 5 a.m. Saturday, the man called 911 and said he had information about bombs in several locations in New York City, the authorities said. Security was immediately heightened citywide, especially around the tunnels. Traffic slowed, particularly outside the Holland Tunnel. Normal traffic flow did not return there until after 11 p.m. The man was questioned by the Joint Terrorism Task Force, which later described his information as "not credible." Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEBOR, , JOHN F.
description: LEBOR--John F. A retired business executive and director of many corporations, died at his home in North Palm Beach, FL, Friday morning, June 20, 2003. He was 97 years old. After a 36 year career in investment management, motion pictures, air conditioner manufacturing, and retailing, he retired as Executive Vice President and Director of Federated Department Stores, Inc., in 1966. In subsequent years he was active on many corporate and philanthropic boards of directors. Mr. Lebor was born in Portland, OR, and was a graduate of the University of Oregon and Harvard Business School. He was a current member of the Queen City Club, Cincinnati, and the Beach Club, Palm Beach. He graduated with distinction from Harvard Business School in 1930 and received the University of Oregon School of Business Administration 50 Year Medallion Award in 1964. He was preceded in death by his wife Violette Steinmetz Lebor, his son John Cook Lebor, and his second wife Dorothy Lebor. He is survived by his son Andrew Lebor of Callawassie Island, SC, three grandchildren, Katherine Scheu of Northampton, NH, John Keith Lebor of Ellicott City, MD, and Todd Nichols Lebor of Chicago, IL. Also leaves four greatgrandchildren, Sara Alexa, Carlyn Francis, Margaret Ann and John Tucker. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to the Greater Cincinnati Foundation, Cincinnati, OH. For information contact Schaefer & Busby Funeral Home, Cincinnati, OH. >>AD#

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Early Departure For Milwaukee Mayor
description: Mayor John Norquist of Milwaukee, whose tenure was tainted by a sexual harassment lawsuit filed against him in 2001 by a former aide, will leave office nearly four months early to take a job with an urban development group. Mr. Norquist, who was first elected in 1988, will leave office on Jan. 1 to work at the Congress for the New Urbanism, a group focused on limiting urban sprawl and improving the quality of life of inner city residents. The group is now based in San Francisco but will move to Chicago next year. The president of the Milwaukee City Council, Marvin Pratt, will preside for the remaining months of Mr. Norquist's term, making him the city's first black mayor. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the accounting practices of Fannie Mae, the mortgage financing giant, referred incorrectly to the recent departure of two executives at its corporate cousin Freddie Mac. While Freddie Mac dismissed its president, David W. Glenn, and accused him of failure to cooperate with an internal accounting investigation, it did not cite that reason in seeking the resignations of Leland C. Brendsel, the chief executive, and Vaughn A. Clarke, the chief financial officer. The company has not elaborated on their departures.

title: CHICAGO: MUSEUM CLOSING
description: The Terra Museum of American Art in Chicago has announced that it will shut its doors next year. About 50 of its most important paintings, including works by John Singleton Copley, George Caleb Bingham and Edward Hopper, as well as its entire collection of 350 works on paper, will be sent to the Art Institute of Chicago on extended loan. James N. Wood, director of the Art Institute, said the donation would allow his museum to present ''one of the most comprehensive and outstanding surveys of American painting and works on paper in the nation.'' Although the Terra Museum will close, the Terra Foundation, which has assets of $200 million, will continue to sponsor American art programs and run its Muse d'Art Amricain in Giverny, France. The foundation has not yet decided whether to sell the desirable space that the museum occupied on busy Michigan Avenue. The Terra Museum failed to attract large audiences, and for the last two years it has been torn by legal conflicts as factions on its board fought over what to do with the collection. STEPHEN KINZER

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: WASHINGTON: MAN USES FAKE GUN TO ESCAPE A man on trial in a kidnapping case escaped from a Tacoma courtroom, using a gun made of paper and cardboard to intimidate court officers and hijack a pickup truck. The man, Harold McCord, 36, was not wearing handcuffs or leg shackles when he broke away during his court appearance, where he was facing a motion hearing, said Lauren Pawlaski, spokeswoman for the Pierce County Sheriff's Department. Tacoma police later recovered the gun. Ms. Pawlaski said he broke away from guards and fled the courtroom but was tackled by another officer in the hallway. He pulled the fake gun, saying, "I'm going to kill you." He then ran into the street. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

Like so many before him, Mr. Drake had a dream of being signed to a major label and traveling the country playing his songs to arenas full of fans who knew the words by heart. After spending two years working full time as a deliveryman for a branch of Pizza Hut in the Nashville suburb Smyrna, Mr. Drake learned to lower his expectations.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Security Breach At Prince's Party
description: The police have apologized to the Royal Family after admitting that a man dressed in an Osama bin Laden costume had managed to scale a wall at Windsor Castle and talk his way past security guards at Prince William's 21st birthday party on Saturday. Aaron Barschak, left, 36, a comedian known for gate-crashing celebrity events, was arrested after he climbed onto the stage where William was making a speech thanking his grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II, for the party. The Scotland Yard commissioner, Sir John Stevens, described the incident as an ''appalling'' breach of security, and Home Secretary David Blunkett, signaling the government's concern, said he would make a public statement in the House of Commons today. title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: F.B.I. Spy Testifies In Terror Trial
description: An F.B.I. double agent began testifying in the trial of Michael McKevitt, the suspected leader of the Real I.R.A., the paramilitary group behind a car-bomb attack in 1998 in Omagh, Northern Ireland, that killed 29 people. The agent, David Rupert, is a 51-year-old American who once ran a trucking company in upstate New York. Amid tight security around Dublin's Special Criminal Court, Mr. Rupert said that he became involved with Irish republicans, who want Northern Ireland to break away from Britain to join the Irish Republic, after traveling to the country frequently, and that he began informing for the F.B.I. in 1994. Mr. McKevitt, 53, faces a life sentence if found guilty of directing a terrorist organization. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Expands
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus expanded 12.5 percent in May from the month a year earlier as growth in exports outpaced the increase in imports. Though Japan's surplus increased to 694 billion yen ($5.8 billion) in the month, exports grew 3.5 percent, which was the slowest growth in 13 months. The effect of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, in Asia was partly to blame. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: FINLAND APPROVES A LILLY DRUG TO FIGHT BREAST CANCER
description: Eli Lilly & Company said its treatment for pancreatic tumors, Gemzar, was approved by Finland for use against breast cancer, the first such approval by any country. The company is talking with the Food and Drug Administration about approving the medicine for breast cancer in the United States. Lilly's drug, combined with Taxol from the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, helps shrink tumors while easing side effects of chemotherapy like hair loss and vomiting, said Denise A. Yardley, an oncologist at the Sarah Cannon Cancer Center in Nashville. The center participated in research for the drug.

title: TOPPS AGREES TO PURCHASE WIZKIDS FOR $29.5 MILLION

WizKids, which is based in Bellevue, Wash., had revenue of about $33 million in 2002. Topps, which is based in New York, also said its first-quarter profit declined by more than half as it reduced product releases and as sales of sports cards fell. Net income dropped to $3.52 million, or 8 cents a share, from $7.34 million, or 17 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 13 percent, the company said.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Request To Reduce Water Use
description: Federal water managers asked farmers in the Klamath Basin, which straddles the Oregon-California border, to cut back on the amount of water they divert for irrigation. Federal officials revised the basin's drought forecast to below average from dry, meaning more water must be left in Klamath Lake and the Klamath River to protect endangered salmon and suckerfish. Jeff McCracken, a spokesman for the Bureau of Reclamation, which oversees the basin, said farmers were scrambling to reduce their water usage. In 2001, the bureau shut off water to 1,000 farmers to help the fish, leading to months of protest. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Electric Fault Shuts Nuclear Plant
description: The Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant remained shut down yesterday, a day after an electrical breaker failed, causing it to lose power, said the Entergy Corporation, the plant's owner. There was no release of radiation. The breaker, which connects the plant to the region's electrical grid, failed late Sunday afternoon. It is unclear what caused the malfunction, said an Entergy spokesman, Jim Steets, but there were no signs of sabotage. The plant is expected to remain closed for several days for repairs, he said. title: The Hawaiian Prints That Wouldn't Fade
description: In the early 1980's, Tony Margolis would languish at his second home, on the Gulf Coast of Florida, and construct a fantasy familiar to anyone who has ever been on a vacation: what if you just never returned to wherever it was you came from? Mr. Margolis had an accomplice in these imaginings: his business partner Bob Emfield, who lived down the shore from him, on Bonita Beach.

title: Argentina and the I.M.F. Dickering Over Debt
description: The International Monetary Fund and the Argentine government began two days of talks here today that included the first face-to-face discussions between the country's new president, Nstor Kirchner, and the fund's managing director, Horst Khler.

title: Williams Won't Return Until His Knee Is Right
description: Raul Mondesi is not a doctor, but he played one in the Yankees' clubhouse today. Mondesi, a right fielder, leaned into a group of reporters surrounding Bernie Williams and gave Williams's left knee a quick examination. ''It's good,'' Mondesi said, nodding his head. ''He's ready.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page news analysis article on Wednesday about a lay board that monitors American Catholic Bishops' compliance with their policies on accusations of sexual abuse gave an outdated affiliation for R. Scott Appleby, who said the board was beholden to the bishops in some degree, and a correction in this space misstated the name of his current center. He is a history professor and director of the Joan B. Kroc Institute for International Peace Studies (not John B. Kroc), at Notre Dame; he left the directorship of the university's Cushwa Center for the Study of American Catholicism last year.

title: 5 Israeli Arabs Accused of Funneling $10 Million to Hamas
description: JERUSALEM, June 24  Five Israeli Arabs were charged today with funneling an estimated $10 million to the Islamic militant group Hamas, a relatively rare instance in which Arab citizens of Israel have been accused of ties to extremist movements.

title: Breeders' Cup Back at Belmont in 2005
description: Hoping to sustain the momentum created by Funny Cide's Triple Crown bid, Breeders' Cup officials announced yesterday that the annual World Thoroughbred Championships would return to Belmont Park in October 2005.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Church Critic Improves
description: A tenacious critic of the Archdiocese of Boston during its sexual abuse scandal who was pulled from a Boston river last week has regained consciousness, his lawyer said. The man, Patrick McSorley, 28, is speaking and has been moved from the intensive care unit, his lawyer, Mitchell Garabedian, said. Mr. McSorley had also been on life support, but no longer needs it, Mr. Garabedian said. He would not comment on the circumstances surrounding the incident but said Mr. McSorley had expressed ''anger'' over the church's reaction to the sexual abuse crisis and was bothered by the antagonism between Cardinal Roger M. Mahony of Los Angeles and former Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma, who recently resigned as head of a lay panel overseeing the Roman Catholic Church's handling of the crisis. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: From Flowing Fluids, Beautiful Images and Unlocked Secrets
description: Granted, quantum mechanics and relativity are fascinating theories, full of philosophical weirdness, as well as practical applications. But a deep understanding of the universe, from the turbulent flow of cosmic jets to the sound raindrops make when they strike the surface of a lake, depends on a seemingly more mundane field known as fluid dynamics.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: TRADE SURPLUS EXPANDS Japan's merchandise trade surplus expanded 12.5 percent in May from the month a year earlier as growth in exports outpaced the increase in imports. Though Japan's surplus increased to 694 billion yen ($5.8 billion) in the month, exports grew 3.5 percent, which was the slowest growth in 13 months. The effect of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, in Asia was partly to blame.

title: College Degrees in Hand, a Class Leaves High School
description: Four years ago they were entering high school. Since then they have read James Joyce and Proust, wrestled with calculus and chemistry, put on plays and volunteered in the community. Their graduation yesterday might have been unremarkable except for the fact that the 93 graduates -- a diverse class of 17- and 18-year-olds born in more than 20 countries and living in New York City's five boroughs -- were walking away with two-year college degrees.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BRUNSWICK CORP., Lake Forest, Ill., maker of Sea Ray and Bayliner boats, said it had acquired Land 'N' Sea Corp., Pompano Beach, Fla., a distributor of marine parts and accessories, for a combination of cash, notes and other consideration valued at $52 million.

title: The Day Harry Potter Turned Up Early
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Tyco Officers Lose Bid to Dismiss Case
description: Two former executives of Tyco International yesterday lost an attempt in court yesterday for dismissal of charges accusing them of stealing $600 million through illegal compensation and stock fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHSCHILD, , WALTER N. JR. ''BILL.''
description: ROTHSCHILD--Walter N. Jr. ''Bill.'' 83 of Syosset, LI, peacefully, on June 20. Husband of Virginia, father of Trip Rothschild of New Millford, CT, Nina Rothschild-Utne of Minneapolis, Suzanne Rothschild of Arlington, MA, and Jane Rothschild of Sydney, Australia, brother of Carol Noyes of Syosset and Phyllis Farley of New York. Grandfather of ten. Services at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th St, 11:30 AM, Tuesday, June 24.

title: Request to Relocate Trial
description: A former banker who has been accused of urging colleagues to destroy documents sought in government investigations wants his case moved from New York to California.

title: Nicotine Without the Smoke
description: A recent study suggests an eyebrow-raising approach to fighting smoking. The government, the study says, should consider allowing smokers to buy inhalers that will give them pure shots of nicotine.

title: Heineken Warns About a Sluggish First Half
description: Heineken, one of the world's biggest brewers, warned today that its profit for the first half of this year had stagnated, saying that woes ranging from weak economies to the war in Iraq were causing consumers to drink less beer rather than more.

title: Excerpts From Justices' Opinions on Michigan Affirmative Action Cases
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court rulings yesterday on two cases involving affirmative action policies at the University of Michigan. The vote in the law school case, Grutter v. Bollinger, was 5 to 4. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the opinion, and dissents were filed by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Clarence Thomas. The vote in the case on undergraduate admissions, Gratz v. Bollinger, was 6 to 3. Chief Justice Rehnquist wrote for the court, while Justice O'Connor wrote a concurring opinion and Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg dissented. The full decisions are on line at nytimes.com/national

title: Cover Your Hair
description: Still no luck in my quest to help the administration find Iraqi weapons of mass destruction. But meanwhile, I'm getting the impression that America fought Saddam, and the Islamic fundamentalists won.

title: Leon Uris, Author of 'Exodus,' Dies at 78
description: Leon Uris, the novelist and screenwriter whose best-known works are "Exodus," a popular novel about Jews trying to establish modern Israel, and "Gunfight at the O.K. Corral," perhaps the archetypal Hollywood Western, died on Saturday at his home on Shelter Island, N.Y. He was 78.

title: Ruling on Religious Markers, but No End to the Fight
description: A legal fight over the placing of Orthodox Jewish boundary markers on public property seemingly came to a close today when the United States Supreme Court declined to hear the case, but the mayor here said that the town still had not decided whether to proceed with further action to have the markers removed.

title: Chicago Striker Razov Is Back on His Game
description: He seems to be the striker who was left behind. ANTE RAZOV was an alternate on Coach BRUCE ARENA's roster last year, but he never made the trip to South Korea for the World Cup. Razov again stayed home this month when the United States national team played three lackluster matches in the Confederations Cup in France.

title: Iranian Terror Group Planned Attacks, French Report Says
description: PARIS, June 24 — An Iranian opposition group operating in France that was the target of a large police operation last week had plans to attack Iranian embassies and assassinate former members working with Iranian intelligence services in Europe, according to a classified report by France's counter-intelligence service prepared two weeks before the crackdown.

title: The Day Harry Potter Turned Up Early (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Reinforces Hormones' Link to Breast Cancer
description: One year after a major study linked postmenopausal hormone therapy to an increased risk of breast cancer, new findings from the same study paint an even more ominous picture of the hormones' role in the disease.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Turning Down the Volume

title: Truth, Lies And the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Car Dealer Pleads In Tax Swindle
description: The owner and president of a large Bronx car dealership pleaded guilty in state court yesterday to evading payment of city and state sales taxes, and was sentenced to house arrest and probation. The dealer, Richard Gidron, was accused of collecting but not paying more than $1.5 million for cars he sold and leased at Dick Gidron Ford from 1995 to 2000. Mr. Gidron, 64, pleaded guilty to three felonies, two counts of grand larceny and one count of offering a false instrument for filing. The dealership, through Mr. Gidron, also pleaded guilty to grand larceny. He was ordered to pay $1.6 million in restitution, and sentenced to three years of home detention with five years of probation.

title: Spending $1 Sensibly
description: To the Editor:

title: Historic Convulsions Seen in Personal Terms
description: MONKEY HUNTING

title: World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: Swiss Freeze Leader's Assets
description: Switzerland announced that it had taken steps to freeze the bank accounts in that country of Liberia's president, Charles Taylor. The Swiss Federal Office of Justice said it had acted on a request from a United Nations-backed war crimes tribunal, which has accused Mr. Taylor of crimes against humanity in connection with the civil war in Sierra Leone. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Seeking Alternatives in Suburbs
description: Suburbanites are more likely than people in cities or the countryside to turn to complementary or alternative medical remedies to help with pain, according to a study in the current issue of The American Journal of Public Health.

title: Peoples of Rain Forest
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARPE, , LIBBY A.
description: SHARPE--Libby A., 81. Loving and devoted wife, mother, grandmother and mother-inlaw. A great woman, she created love, happiness and good humor for her family and friends. Her courage, leadership and strong sense of justice in fighting for equality and responsive government inspired all who knew her and was reflected in over 50 years of leadership in the West Orange, NJ League of Women Voters and in many other civic organizations. She generously applied her talents and support to innumerable charities. She will be deeply missed by her husband Irwin, her children Debbie, Bonnie, Peter and Ken, their spouses Jill, Madeleine and Jeff, and her grandchildren Emily, Julie, Jenny and Sarah. >>AD#

title: Powell Urges Mideast Sides Not to Foil Peace Efforts
description: As the United States pressed an ambitious effort to cement Middle East peace diplomacy with economic reform and free trade, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell urged the Palestinians and Israelis today not to ''blow up the road map,'' the newest set of peace proposals.

title: Already Battered, Tenet Reduces Earnings Forecast For Rest of Year
description: Tenet Healthcare, the struggling for-profit hospital chain, told investors yesterday to expect significantly lower profits this year than they had anticipated. The company, which is under regulatory scrutiny for its Medicare billing practices, blamed higher costs and its limited success in negotiating more favorable prices with private health plans for care.

title: SOME ON THE RIGHT SEE A CHALLENGE
description: The Supreme Court rulings on the University of Michigan admission policies set off a wave of consternation among conservative groups today. As a result, several officials of the groups plan to demand that President Bush choose someone whose opposition to affirmative action is beyond doubt for a vacancy on the court.

title: A burst of sun and smiles at Florence shows
description: FLORENCE  Hollywood, rock 'n' roll and fashion met at the 64th biannual Pitti Immagine Uomo menswear show in Florence. Pitti Uomo had a distinctly LA flavor for the spring/summer 2004 collections with Gela Nash-Taylor, one half of the Juicy Couture duo, blowing into town with her husband John Taylor and the entire Duran Duran posse to celebrate the European launch of their Juicy men's collection.

title: U.S. Presses Saudis to Police Accounts Used to Aid Palestinians
description: The Treasury Department and other federal agencies are pressing Saudi Arabia to monitor closely bank accounts designated for relief aid to Palestinians, senior law enforcement officials say. The American authorities say some of the bank accounts may be conduits for terrorist financing.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: NETHERLANDS/BRITAIN: UNILEVER CUTS TARGETS The consumer products company Unilever cut the sales growth target for its top brands yesterday. Unilever, the maker of Knorr and Hellmann's, reduced the 2003 target for its 400 top brands to 4 percent from 5 percent to 6 percent after a slower-than-expected first half. Unilever , a British-Dutch company, said in a second-quarter trading update that it was still aiming for a low double-digit percentage increase in 2003 earnings. The company said sales growth of its top brands in the second quarter would be about 3 percent. (Reuters)

title: Rice Rips Stanford to Take the Title
description: Jeff Niemann and Wade Townsend, the pitching aces, carried the 67-year-old Rice coach, Wayne Graham, across the field tonight to the dugout while Owls fans chanted Graham's name. Philip Humber, the No. 3 starter who had just pitched the Owls to the university's first N.C.A.A. championship in any team sport -- a 14-2 victory over Stanford -- gave interview after interview while his teammates whooped and celebrated around him.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: SECURITY BREACH AT PRINCE'S PARTY The police have apologized to the Royal Family after admitting that a man dressed in an Osama bin Laden costume had managed to scale a wall at Windsor Castle and talk his way past security guards at Prince William's 21st birthday party on Saturday. Aaron Barschak, left, 36, a comedian known for gate-crashing celebrity events, was arrested after he climbed onto the stage where William was making a speech thanking his grandmother, Queen Elizabeth II, for the party. The Scotland Yard commissioner, Sir John Stevens, described the incident as an "appalling" breach of security, and Home Secretary David Blunkett, signaling the government's concern, said he would make a public statement in the House of Commons today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PACKARD, , JARMILA DAUBEK
description: PACKARD--Jarmila Daubek. The Board of Directors of the Metropolitan Opera Guild mourns the loss of Jarmila Packard, an esteemed member of our Board for 40 years. Jarmila served as First VicePresident, Vice - President, and Capital Assistant Treasurer and for five years was Chairman of the Education Committee. With her grace, charm and dedication, Jarmila commanded the universal respect and affection of her colleagues on the Board and of the Guild staff. In recognition of her service, earlier this spring she was awarded the Belmont Medal, the Guild's highest distinction, created in honor of our Founder, Eleanor R. Belmont. We extend our deepest sympathy to Jarmila's family. Winthrop Rutherfurd, Jr. Chairman Susan S. Braddock, President Rudolph S. Rauch, Managing Director

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Affirmative Action Proponents Get the Nod in a Split Decision
description: Constitutional scholars said yesterday that the Supreme Court's split decision on the University of Michigan's admissions plans was an endorsement of murkiness in government decision-making involving race.

title: Who Really Needs Beauty Sleep?
description: Women appear to bear up better than men under the effects of sleep deprivation, researchers have found.

title: Agassi and Serena Williams Win Opening Matches
description: LONDON, June 23 - The day after one of the biggest upsets in Grand Slam history was more about dodging difficulty than falling victim to it.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: G.N.P. Growth Forecast
description: The Central Bank of Ireland, the government's main financial authority, said yesterday that it expected gross national product to increase 1.5 percent this year, up from 0.6 percent in 2002. It expects gross domestic product, which includes earnings from foreign companies based in Ireland, to increase 2.75 percent, a retreat from its earlier forecast of 3.75 percent. The strong euro and high domestic inflation are making the country a less competitive place to do business, the bank said. Irish prices increased 4.6 percent last year, compared with 2 percent or so in other European Union countries. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: GOODYEAR SAYS EARNINGS FELL AT NORTH AMERICAN UNIT
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said profit declined at its North American unit last month because of higher costs for raw materials and a shift in demand to less-profitable tires, setting off a 7 percent decline in its stock price. The drop in profit from Goodyear's biggest unit follows a 3.7 percent decline in first-quarter sales for the North American tire business. Sales of tires to automakers in North America fell more than the industry's 8 percent decline, reflecting Goodyear's strategy to improve the profitability of that business by selling to select customers, a Goodyear spokeswoman, Tricia Ingraham, said. Goodyear, which is based in Akron, Ohio, feel 45 cents, to $6.19 a share, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRUSSEL, , JOHN F.
description: BRUSSEL--John F. Beloved son of Harrison and Bernice, adored brother of Anne Brooks, dearest love of Terry Phillips. Services Wednesday, June 25, 1:30PM, Temple Sholom, 3480 N. Lake Shore Dr, Chicago, IL. 60657. Shiva Thursday evening, Saturday and Sunday at the Brussel home. Contributions in John's memory to Temple Sholom or North Shore Hospice, 9701 N. Knox Ave, Skokie, IL 60076. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FANTA, , EUGENE, M.D.
description: FANTA--Eugene, M.D. His friends and colleagues at Lutheran Medical Center mourn the loss of Dr. Eugene Fanta. Dr. Fanta was affiliated with Lutheran for more than 60 years. He served as Director of Emergency Medicine for several years and was responsible for the creation of Lutheran's Family Practice Residency Program, the first in New York City. Prior to his retirement, this much beloved physician was honored at the White House as Family Doctor of the Year. He later served as a trustee of the medical center and was named Director Emeritus of Family Practice. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife Charlotte, his sons and their families. Dr Fanta's intelligence, compassion and generosity of spirit will be missed by all who knew him. Howard Smith, Chairman Board of Trustees Wendy Z. Goldstein President and CEO Eugene Gibilaro, MD President Medical & Dental Staff >>AD#

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Apple to Use I.B.M. Chip For Its Newest Computers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, , MARGARET ''MAGGIE'' MOONEY
description: SMITH--Margaret ''Maggie'' Mooney of Ocean Grove, NJ formerly of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Jack Grant Smith. Memorial Mass Sat. June 28 at St. Elizabeth Church, Avon, NJ 10:30 AM. >>AD#

title: Judge Delays Approval of Asbestos Settlement
description: A United States bankruptcy judge withheld approval for ABB's $1.3 billion settlement of more than 130,000 asbestos lawsuits yesterday until ABB provides more information about the accord.

title: Maynard H. Jackson Jr., First Black Mayor of Atlanta and a Political Force, Dies at 65
description: Maynard H. Jackson Jr., who as this city's first black mayor embodied the seismic shift in political power from Atlanta's white establishment to its growing black middle class, died this morning after collapsing at an airport in Washington. He was 65.

title: New Products for Sale in Africa: Company Shares
description: Owino Market is probably most people's idea of an African market. It is open from dawn to dusk, and each muddy, crowded path offers a different cut-rate commodity: rat poison at one stall, used brassieres at the next. ''Shoes here!'' yells one seller. A few feet away a rival is shouting, ''Good pants!'' at the top of his lungs.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Don't Move, Lady! It's Right Over Your Eye!

title: Boy, 15, Drowns Off S.I.
description: A 15-year-old boy out for a swim with friends drowned yesterday in the Arthur Kill, between New Jersey and Staten Island, the authorities said.

title: A Rocky Polish Landfall For a Dutch Abortion Boat
description: For two days last week, the Langenort, a Dutch-registered tugboat, was kept at sea by bad weather off the Baltic coast of Poland. On Saturday, as the winds fell, it was the shipping container bolted to its deck that kept the boat from harbor in Gdansk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERSOHN, , VIRGINIA STRAUS
description: BERSOHN--Virginia Straus, 76. Died at home on June 21. Devoted mother of Malcolm and David. Grandmother of Daniel and Rebecca. A graduate of the Brearley School and Vassar College with a Master's from Cornell, she worked as an educational tester and in volunteer services, continuing to help the homeless during her illness. The funeral will be private. >>AD#

title: The Fed's Next Move
description: Depending on when investors anted up, the recent rally on Wall Street could look like a bull market or the proverbial dead-cat bounce -- the rule that anything will find a market if the price drops low enough. Timing really is everything.

title: Marathon Oil Is Set For Venture in Qatar
description: Marathon Oil, the nation's fourth-largest oil company, will sign a letter of intent to pursue a $4.3 billion joint venture with Qatar to process natural gas into naphtha and diesel, Qatar's oil minister, Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiyah, said yesterday.

title: Siblings Need to Be Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYERS, , DIANE
description: MEYERS--Diane. The Board of Directors and members of Bocaire Country Club Inc. record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Diane Meyers, on Sunday, June 22nd, 2003. We extend condolences to all of her family. Services will be held Tuesday, June 24, at 12 PM at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY. Kurt Merl, President >>AD#

title: Apparel Chain Plans Multicultural Theme
description: American Eagle Outfitters , the retail chain that sells casual apparel to younger consumers, is hiring an outside agency known for multicultural campaigns a week after its principal rival, Abercrombie & Fitch , was sued for racial discrimination.

title: Checkmating Alzheimer's
description: Can regular games of bridge or chess or playing a musical instrument ward off the onset of Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia? That is the provocative implication of a study published in the prestigious New England Journal of Medicine last week. If the findings hold up in more rigorous follow-up inquiries, the day may yet come when doctors will routinely recommend regular mental activity to ward off dementia just as they recommend regular physical exercise to ward off obesity and heart disease.

title: Over Shrimp and Pasta, Hitting the $10 Million Halfway Point for Bush's 2004 Campaign
description: President Bush collected $4 million at a fund-raiser in midtown Manhattan last night, and Vice President Dick Cheney raised more than $1.6 million at separate events in Virginia and Massachusetts. The events brought the White House halfway to its intimidate-the-Democrats goal of raising $20 million in two weeks for Mr. Bush's 2004 re-election campaign.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Vignette Names Chairman
description: The Vignette Corporation, a maker of Internet business software, yesterday named a board member, Michael Lambert, as chairman. He succeeds Greg Peters, who joined Zilliant Inc. as president and chief executive. Mr. Lambert, 50, retired from Dell Computer this year after six years as senior vice president of its enterprise systems group, and has been on Vignette's board since September, the company said. Mr. Peters, 43, a former chief executive of Vignette, led its public offering in 1999. He was named chief executive and president of Zilliant, a closely held maker of pricing software and services, on June 9, to succeed Marvin Newell, who left the company three months earlier for personal reasons. Mr. Peters will remain on Vignette's board. Mr. Lambert was vice president for sales and marketing at Compaq Computer from 1993 to 1996 after working in various executive posts at NCR for 16 years. He is also on the boards of the Western Digital Corporation and the network storage provider Panasas Inc.

title: World Briefing | Australia: Soldier Appointed Governor-General
description: Michael Jeffery, a retired major general honored for bravery in the Vietnam War who later led the Special Air Services, was chosen as governor general, the ceremonial representative of Queen Elizabeth II. He succeeds Dr. Peter Hollingworth, who resigned amid allegations that while he was Anglican archbishop of Brisbane he had acted inadequately against sex offenders. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Billing in Rough Times Can Be Creative Writing
description: If anybody knows about add-on charges that can spark a ''What's this?'' at the hotel check-out counter, it is probably Bjorn Hanson.

title: Meeting Bush May Lift Pakistani Leader's Prestige
description: Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, is to receive a rare honor on Tuesday, meeting President Bush at Camp David, a first for any leader from South Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELUCA, , LORRAINE J.
description: DeLUCA--Lorraine J., 76, of Lindenhurst, L.I., on June 23, 2003. Beloved wife of the late John J. DeLuca. Loving mother of Lyn Eisen, Judy Brochhausen, Joe DeLuca and Lorrie Pilc. Devoted grandmother of Stephanie, Allyson, Adriane, Justin and Joshua. Friends may visit today, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM., at the Claude R. Boyd-Spencer Funeral Home, 448 West Main Street, Babylon, L.I. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 9:00 A.M., at Our Lady of Grace R.C. Church, West Babylon, L.I. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens. Donations appreciated in her memory to the American Heart Assoc. >>AD#

title: Ruling Provides Relief, But Less Than Hoped
description: The relief on college campuses yesterday was palpable, yet far from complete.

title: Verizon and Union Talks Begin With a Clash on Health Care
description: Verizon Communications and its largest labor union began negotiations yesterday and immediately clashed over the company's push to have workers pay more for health coverage and the union's push to make it easier to organize workers at Verizon Wireless.

title: Freeing a Nation From a Tyrant's Grip
description: A brave man recently met with me and described how life in his country has become unbearable. ''There is too much fear in the country, fear of the unknown and fear of the known consequences if we act or speak out,'' explained Pius Ncube, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Bulawayo, Zimbabwe. Yet Archbishop Ncube speaks out fearlessly about the terrible human rights conditions in Zimbabwe, and is threatened almost every day with detention or worse.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chohung Bank Gets New Loan
description: The Bank of Korea lent another three trillion won ($2.5 billion) to Chohung Bank to cover a run on deposits last week during a strike by more than 6,000 Chohung workers. The one-month loan was in addition to the two trillion won that the bank provided to Chohung last week by buying its short-term bonds. Chohung customers withdrew six trillion won from the bank before the strike was settled on Sunday. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: In First Post-Apartheid Treason Trial, Whites Reject the Court Itself
description: A lawyer representing members of a white hard-line group accused of plotting to assassinate the former president Nelson Mandela and advocating the violent overthrow of the post-apartheid government argued in a Pretoria court today that his clients could not be tried by a South African court because they consider the Constitution illegitimate.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day on June 13 about an agreement between Pozen Inc. and GlaxoSmithKline to develop treatments for headaches misstated a provision. Glaxo agreed to pay Pozen up to $80 million if certain sales goals are met, plus an undisclosed amount of royalties on sales. The royalties would not be included in the $80 million.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the British moral philosopher Sir Bernard Williams on June 14 misstated the original name of his first wife, now Baroness Williams of Crosby. She was Shirley Vivienne Teresa Brittain Catlin, not Shirley Brittain. The obituary also misstated his place of death. He was on vacation in Rome, not at his home in Oxford.

title: Let Judges Do Their Jobs
description: I have served as a federal judge for 13 years. Having reached retirement age, I now have the option of continuing to be a judge for the rest of my life, with a reduced workload, or returning to private practice. Although I find my work to be interesting and challenging, I have decided to join the growing number of federal judges who retire to join the private sector.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   OSTRAU, , IRENE
description: OSTRAU--Irene. Love and miss you as much as ever. Stanley and Bert >>AD#

title: Panel Hears Criticisms Of Academy
description: In its first public hearing today, a civilian-led panel examining sexual assault at the United States Air Force Academy questioned the decisions of the authorities and board members at the Colorado Springs academy over the last decade and their seeming failure to heed an array of warning signs that sexual assault was a real and growing problem for female cadets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KURFIRST, , ALYS
description: KURFIRST -- Alys. Beloved wife of the late Saul Kurfirst. Devoted mother of Jaimee Mirsky and Jonathan Kurfirst. Mother-in-law of Jay Mirsky and Beth Kurfirst. Cherished grandmother of Joanna, Daniel, Justine and David. Sister of the late Robert Wien and of Carol Glickman. Services today at 12 Noon at ''Parkside Chapel'', 9860 Queens Blvd (corner of 66th Avenue), Forest Hills. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on May 31 about a Concorde flown by Air France referred incorrectly to the status of supersonic passenger flights. The plane's return trip was the last flight for Air France's Concorde; British Airways will continue to fly its Concorde between London and New York through October.

title: LAIDLAW EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
description: Laidlaw International, one of North America's biggest operators of school buses, public transit systems and ambulances, emerged from bankruptcy court protection yesterday after a two-year reorganization. Previously based in Canada, Laidlaw is now incorporated in Delaware with its head office in Naperville, Ill. The reorganization has wiped out almost $4 billion in debt, leaving banks, insurance companies and other creditors as the company's new shareholders. The creditors have also been paid $1 billion. Laidlaw's new common stock is listed in Toronto. The company, whose units include Greyhound Lines, said it would seek a listing in the United States soon. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: A Mizrahi Comeback, One More Time
description: Isaac Mizrahi, whose haywire fashion career seems apt for Bette Davis's warning about seat belts, is back in the biz. Mr. Mizrahi, naturally, says he never left.

title: Where Blue Collars Grow Endangered; Factory Jobs Decline in Sunset Park
description: About 13 years ago, Eligio Abreu was living in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, where he grew up, and attending college in Manhattan. But after his girlfriend got pregnant, he stopped going to school and started working at a cosmetics factory a friend told him about near his home. He has been there ever since.

title: MORE ON RULINGS
description: VIEW FROM CAMPUS -- On university campuses, administrators said they gained more discretion than expected. In Michigan, students called the rulings a victory. PAGE A26

title: Tougher Rules For Auto Tires To Be Imposed
description: The government laid out its first major overhaul of tire performance rules yesterday to reflect the growing popularity of sport utility vehicles and other light trucks. It said as much as 11 percent of the tires now being produced would not meet the new rules, which take effect in June 2007.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SWENSON, , ERIC P.

description: THE PUBLICIS GROUPE is bowing to a rare display of public displeasure from a large client, the General Motors Corporation, by taking the unusual step of undoing the recent hiring of a top executive.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground-Zero Official Takes New Job
description: Kenneth R. Holden, the New York City administrator who supervised the cleanup and removal of 1.7 million tons of steel and debris from the World Trade Center site, is resigning to take a private-sector job. He will become corporate vice president for real estate and facilities of Continuum Health Partners, which operates seven major hospitals, including Beth Israel Medical Center and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. His successor has not been named. Eric Lipton (NYT)

title: NASA Hoping to Fly Shuttle After Fixing Some Hardware and Shifting Managers
description: Even before the independent panel issues its report on the disaster that claimed the space shuttle Columbia and its crew of seven, NASA has apparently concluded that no enormously time-consuming changes will be required before the shuttle fleet returns to space, perhaps as early as December.

title: Regent Says Board Favors Setting Aside Math Scores
description: The state education commissioner, Richard P. Mills, acknowledged yesterday that the Regents examination in mathematics given last week in high schools across the state was technically flawed, a state assemblyman who spoke with him said.

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: GEAC TO BUY COMSHARE FOR $52 MILLION The Geac Computer Corporation , a Canadian maker of business software, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Comshare for $52 million in cash to expand its line of financial forecasting products. The deal comes amid rapid consolidation among makers of software used to plan business operations. Growth in the overall market has slowed as customers look to a smaller number of suppliers that can offer a broad range of functions. Comshare would provide Geac with a suite of software for planning, budgeting, forecasting, financial consolidation and management reporting and analysis. Officials of Geac, which got its start as a mainframe computer maker, said the Comshare deal would help further transform the company into a broad-based supplier of business planning software, and return it to sales growth next year after three successive years of declines. Geac shares fell 13 cents, or 2.3 percent, to 5.50 Canadian dollars ($4.05). Shares of Comshare rose 92 cents, or 25.3 percent, to $4.56. (Reuters)

title: Lead Poison Is Subject Of Hearing By Council
description: A bill that would make it easier for the parents of children with lead poisoning to sue their landlords finally made it to a City Council hearing yesterday, amid a swirl of politics, recriminations and explanations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   STIEFEL, , BETTY (ELIZABETH MARIE)
description: STIEFEL--Betty (Elizabeth Marie). Our hearts still ache. Your warmth and unceasing optimism nourished everyone you knew. You listened to us--at any hour--and gave us your wisdom. We were content in your company, Mom, and seek to honor your memory by how we conduct ourselves every day. June 24, 2002 Lauren, Stewart, Ethan; Wendy and Dad >>AD#

title: 'Henry V' Preview Delayed
description: The first preview of ''Henry V'' in the 2003 season of free Shakespeare performances at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park has been postponed from tonight until tomorrow at 8 p.m., a spokeswoman for the Public Theater said. The weekend rains disrupted rehearsals.

title: Court Victory for an Adult Home In Its Treatment of the Mentally Ill
description: A state judge has dismissed the main part of a lawsuit filed by the New York attorney general that had sought $12 million from the former operators of a Brooklyn adult home to compensate hundreds of mentally ill residents who had long endured filthy conditions and little if any supervision.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ex-Professor To Serve 6 Months In Jail
description: A former law professor who pleaded guilty in April to 100 counts of possessing child pornography was sentenced yesterday to six months in jail and 10 years of probation. The former professor, Edward Samuels, 54, taught copyright law at New York Law School before resigning. Last June, the law school's computer technicians discovered pornographic images of children on his office computer. Later, in a search of Mr. Samuels's home computer, investigators found more than 100,000 pornographic images of children. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Atwood's Dystopian Warning; Hand-Wringer's Tale of Tomorrow
description: In Margaret Atwood's first attempt at writing a novel, the main character was an ant swept downriver on a raft. She abandoned that book after the opening scene and became caught up in other activities, which she has described as ''sissy stuff like knitting and dresses and stuffed bunnies.'' That certainly does not sound like Ms. Atwood, who is known for the boldness of her fiction. Of course she was only 7 at the time.

title: Shoe Inspections Leave Passengers Fit to Be Untied
description: MAYBE it was that accompanying cartoon of the fat little barefoot baby bouncing merrily out of an airport security X-ray machine that set off the reaction, but last week's column on the commotion over shoe inspections at the nation's airports brought a deluge of responses from readers.

title: CYTEC INDUSTRIES SAYS IT IS BUYING AVECIA BUSINESS
description: Cytec Industries, which makes chemicals and materials for the aerospace and automotive industries, agreed to buy the metal and stabilizers business of Avecia Investments for about $97 million. Cytec, which is based in West Paterson, N.J., said it expected the purchase to add to earnings after this year. The acquisition will include Avecia's plant in Mount Pleasant, Tenn., Cytec said.

title: E.P.A. Calls U.S. Cleaner and Greener Than 30 Years Ago
description: In its first comprehensive analysis of the quality of the environment in the United States, the Environmental Protection Agency said today that the nation's air, water and land were cleaner and better protected than they were 30 years ago but that problems remained with impure waterways, polluted air and the acceleration of suburban sprawl.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Strike Threat At City Power Plant
description: The president of the union representing 131 workers at a KeySpan power plant in Ravenswood warned yesterday that there could be a strike tommorow that closes the plant, which produces a third of the city's demand for electricity. Manny Hellen, president of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union of America, said, ''I fear a strike is unavoidable.'' But Edward Yutkowitz, a KeySpan spokesman, said the company had contingency plans to keep the plant running. ''Our hope and expectation is we'll come up with a settlement amicable to everybody,'' he said. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Triton Buys Wireless Licenses From Lafayette
description: Triton PCS Holdings, a seller of mobile telephone service in the southeastern United States, has acquired 12 wireless licenses from Lafayette Communications to increase capacity in South Carolina, Georgia and Virginia. Triton said in a statement yesterday that it paid the Federal Communications Commission $28.1 million to retire debt associated with the licenses. Lafayette bought back Triton's 39 percent stake in the company, Triton said. The licenses are for areas with 4.3 million people and overlap existing coverage, it said. Triton stock was upgraded last month by Wachovia Securities, which said a $725 million bond sale would help reduce higher-interest debt. Shares of Triton PCS, which is partly owned by AT&T Wireless Services, fell 18 cents, to $5.28. The carrier sells mobile phone service under the SunCom and AT&T Wireless brands in Virginia, South Carolina and North Carolina and parts of Georgia, Tennessee and Kentucky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEDMAN, , ELLIS
description: FREEDMAN--Ellis. We are deeply saddened to lose Ellis Freedman, friend and advocate of composers, spirited supporter of new music. We send our sympathies to his family and friends. Jennifer Bilfield, President Boosey & Hawkes >>AD#

title: PepsiCo Hires Executive
description: PepsiCo said yesterday that it had hired Paula Banks, an executive at BP, to be senior vice president for global diversity and organization partnerships as the company tries to increase sales to minorities.

title: Aspiring Spy Concocts Tale of Terrorist Plot
description: The young Pakistani man's methods seemed to be those of someone who trafficked in secret information: He advised the police officers to meet him in plainclothes at the salad bar of an anonymous 24-hour Midtown grocery. He dropped a piece of paper for them, a note with an address where they could talk. He said he worked with Pakistani intelligence.

title: U.S.-British Project: To Build a Postwar Iraqi Armed Force of 40,000 Soldiers in 3 Years
description: The American and British occupation authority said today that within three years it would create a new Iraqi army of 40,000 soldiers, one-tenth the size of Saddam Hussein's armed forces at their peak.

description: Sofoklis Schortsanitis leaves major impressions wherever he goes.

description: It's hard to quarrel with the idea of Erasmus Hall High School as a monument to history, small ''h.''

title: Peruvian Cabinet to Resign in Move to Bolster Government
description: The prime minister of Peru, Luis Solari, said today that he and the rest of the cabinet would submit their resignations to President Alejandro Toledo, a shake-up intended to shore up a government buffeted by protests and widespread discontent.

title: Cute but Wild: The Perilous Lure of Exotic Pets
description: Perhaps to some people, the strangest aspect of the recent outbreak of monkeypox spread by exotic animals was the idea that someone would want to have a Gambian rat as a pet.

description: The two sides in the battle over requiring libraries to use Internet pornography filters differed sharply today over whether the Supreme Court had limited intellectual freedom or taken a stand to shield minors from obscenity.

description: The summer sun may be out, but the soggy spring has a goodbye kick in store. In waterlogged tire swings and garbage cans, in ditches and discarded beer cans, uncounted millions of mosquitoes are hatching and growing in all that leftover water.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Export Decline Forecast
description: Persistent drought and weaker world resources prices are forecast to reduce the value of Australia's commodity exports by about 5 percent in 2003-4. A report yesterday by the government's Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics said farm and mineral exports were expected to decline to 82.8 billion Australian dollars ($55.3 billion at current rates) from 87 billion Australian dollars last year. The value of agricultural shipments, affected by a two-year drought, is predicted to decline 5.3 percent, with a similar decline in exports by the mineral and energy sectors. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Bulls' Williams May Be Facing End of Career
description: Lying in his bed in the intensive care unit at the Illinois Masonic Hospital, Jay Williams looked up at Bill Cartwright, his coach with the Chicago Bulls, and John Paxson, the team's general manager. This was Friday, a day after Williams, a swift 6-foot-2 guard and one of the young bright hopes of an up-and-coming team, crashed his new motorcycle into a pole on a North Side street. The accident resulted in injuries so serious that the amputation of one of his legs was considered after an ambulance rushed him to the hospital.

title: U.S. Warns Botox Maker About Its Ads
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday warned Allergan, the pharmaceutical company, that its advertisements for Botox were illegal because they minimized the drug's risks and promoted it for uses beyond those the government had approved.

title: 6,300 Miles From Iraq, Experts Guide Raids
description: In two dozen dimly lighted trailers inside a former B-52 hangar here, small teams of intelligence specialists 6,300 miles from Iraq are playing a pivotal role in the postwar combat and rebuilding effort there.

title: Bush and Pakistani Leader Hail 'Special Relationship'
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 — President Bush gave a conspicuous lift today to the Pakistani president, Pervez Musharraf, inviting him to the Camp David presidential retreat and promising to work for a $3 billion aid package in large part to thank the general for his help in "dismantling the networks" of terrorism.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Japanese Press Junta
description: A senior Japanese official met with leaders of Myanmar's military junta, which is under pressure from its Asian neighbors as well as Western nations to release Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the pro-democracy leader who has been in custody for three weeks. The visit by Vice Foreign Minister Tetsuro Yano followed a Foreign Ministry statement saying Japan might ''reconsider our relations'' if no action is taken. Japan is the leading donor country to the former Burma. Seth Mydans (NYT)

But the unveiling of a new Broadway marquee last night on West 45th Street turned out also to be a bittersweet memorial tribute to the dignified artist who sketched in the dark on the aisle.

title: Video-Computer Combo Helps Pianists Compensate for Stress Injury
description: As Gene Rohrer, a professional accompanist, plays a C major scale in the back room of a medical suite near Lincoln Center, even the untrained ear can tell that something is off. The untrained eye notices his ring finger curling stiffly to let the others pass.

title: Joseph Chaikin 67; Actor and Innovative Director
description: Joseph Chaikin, an actor and director who invigorated the American stage with his experimental Open Theater in the 1960's and early 70's, died on Sunday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 67.

Since then they have followed such different directions in life that they suggest some sort of parable or something out of Greek mythology.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Members Of Banned Group Arrested

Those arrested were reported to include engineers, teachers and a doctor. At least 50 members of the group have been arrested this year. The brotherhood seeks an Islamic state through constitutional means. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: A Sure Deal on Brownfields? Don't Forget, This Is Albany
description: It is generally understood that if a member of Albany's all-powerful troika of Gov. George E. Pataki, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno comes out against a potential deal, it is dead on arrival.

title: Court Rejects Law Designed to Help Holocaust Survivors Get Insurance Information
description: The Supreme Court yesterday struck down a California law designed to help Holocaust survivors receive payment on insurance policies that European companies have long denied, saying that the law improperly interfered with United States foreign policy.

description: In today's cynical world, where things seldom justify their hype, we're happy to report the following: ''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix'' rocks!

title: After 77 Years, Cabaret Laws Face Rewrite
description: The Bloomberg administration is poised to rewrite the city's nearly 80-year-old cabaret laws, which regulate all bars and restaurants where revelers dance. The laws, which were used by the Giuliani administration to punish nightclubs and bars where under-age drinking, drug dealing and other crimes were prevalent, have been a source of controversy for years.

title: Up in the Sky! A Yellow Orb? Don't Panic!
description: WOKE up yesterday to a strange phenomenon in the morning sky. It was too early to phone the planetarium, so a concerned call went to the National Weather Service, which left its perch in Rockefeller Center several years ago for the splendors of Brookhaven, on Lawn Guyland.

description: Peanuts Hucko, a jazz clarinetist who worked with Glenn Miller and Louis Armstrong but was probably best known for his association with Lawrence Welk, died on Thursday in Fort Worth. He was 85 and lived in Denton, Tex.

title: The Clocks That Shaped Einstein's Leap in Time
description: What does it mean, Albert Einstein asked in 1905, to say that a train arrives someplace -- in Paris, say -- at 7 o'clock?

title: Bush Seeks Medicare Drug Bill That Conservatives Oppose
description: President Bush raised the pressure today on Congress to pass a Medicare drug bill this week, even as conservatives in his own party criticized the legislation and pushed for changes.

title: Hedi Slimane:'Ich bin ein Berliner'
description: PARIS  'I feel completely autistic because I don't speak German  it helps me to keep a distance," says Hedi Slimane as he reveals publicly for the first time his twin passions: photography and the city of Berlin.

title: Market Place; NBC shows interest in some of Vivendi's entertainment assets.
description: FOUR companies submitted bids for Vivendi Universal's entertainment assets yesterday, but the most intriguing development, in the view of several people close to Vivendi, may have been the mere statement of interest by a fifth -- the NBC unit of General Electric.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, , FORREST L.
description: SMITH--Forrest L. Restauranteur, philanthropist and professional athlete dies at 58. Mr. Smith died Wednesday, June 18 in Florida as a result of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. He was the grandson of Lou Smith, founder of Ithaca Gun Company and twice Mayor of Ithaca, NY. Mr. Smith was Chairman and CEO of Smith Food Corporation, a New York City based food service company. Although he made his living opening and running restaurants, his passion was in helping those who could not help themselves. Most notably Mr. Smith was Former Chairman of the NYC Ronald McDonald House and spearheaded the fund raising efforts for its flagship residence. He was also heavily involved in fund raising for the United Negro College Fund and City Kids, a proactive program to help inner city kids stay off the streets. Not to be forgotten are Mr. Smith's personal endeavors, he was a licensed pilot, avid scuba diver and is presently in the Guinness Book of World Records for the fastest ever personal water craft run at 87 miles per hour. Mr. Smith is survived by his loving wife Kimberly, daughter Diana, son Christian, stepdaughters Sammantha and Blayre Farkas, mother Doris and sister Dr. Sherry Brothers. A memorial service will be held July 2 at 4-6 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NY, NY. >>AD#

description: The United States men's national team is heading home from the Confederations Cup, but not empty-handed.

title: Beijing Effectively Beats SARS, W.H.O. Declares
description: BEIJING, June 24  The World Health Organization declared today that Beijing had effectively conquered SARS, signaling victory over the disease in the country where it originated and took the most lives.

The plane's return trip was the last flight for Air France's Concorde; British Airways will continue to fly its Concorde between London and New York through October.

title: Legs That Go Kick in the Night
description: A new study has found the first physical clue to the cause of restless leg syndrome, a condition that disturbs the sleep of millions of Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBAUM, , ALICE
description: GREENBAUM -- Alice. The Aleph Society mourns the passing of Alice Greenbaum, mother of our esteemed Executive Director, Margy-Ruth Davis. May she and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz Jack Nash, Chairman Ludwig Bravmann, President >>AD#

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Man Uses Fake Gun To Escape
description: A man on trial in a kidnapping case escaped from a Tacoma courtroom, using a gun made of paper and cardboard to intimidate court officers and hijack a pickup truck. The man, Harold McCord, 36, was not wearing handcuffs or leg shackles when he broke away during his court appearance, where he was facing a motion hearing, said Lauren Pawlaski, spokeswoman for the Pierce County Sheriff's Department. Tacoma police later recovered the gun. Ms. Pawlaski said he broke away from guards and fled the courtroom but was tackled by another officer in the hallway. He pulled the fake gun, saying, ''I'm going to kill you.'' He then ran into the street. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Leon Uris, Author of 'Exodus,' Is Dead at 78
description: Author Leon Uris, an immigrant's determined son who made it big with the million-selling "Exodus" and other greatly popular novels, has died, his ex-wife said. He was 78.

title: Unlikely Hitter Has His Way With Clemens
description: To eight of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays' hitters, that was Roger Clemens on the mound at Tropicana Field tonight. That was the familiar mountain of a right-hander, the one with 300 career victories, the one who nearly threw a no-hitter against them last week.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The adult mosquito population is not flying, but resting and staying out of the weather like any other adult with common sense. One of our concerns is that when the weather changes and we get some hot, dry days, they are really going to be out looking for blood.''

title: Cargo Ship Raided by Greece Was Going to Sudanese Capital
description: A ship raided and impounded late Sunday night by Greek authorities was carrying 680 metric tons of explosives through Greek waters, Greek officials said today. The 230-foot vessel was destined for Sudan, a country that has served as a base for terrorist groups, they added.

description: Four people will be charged with murder this week in connection with the terrorist attacks last November at a beachfront resort in Kenya that killed three Israeli tourists and 11 Kenyans, government officials said today.

We all recognize the contribution she has made and send to her family our deepest regrets. Joseph F. Cullman 3rd Former Chairman Emeritus, Philip Morris Companies Inc. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, , JENNIFER WORTHINGTON
description: JOHNSON--Jennifer Worthington, 23, of Greenwich, CT. died on the morning of June 18th, in Jackson, WY. in a car accident. Beloved daughter of Worthington and Maria Johnson, Jennifer graduated from Greenwich Country Day School, Choate Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, CT and Colgate University with honors, where she was also a sister in Kappa Kappa Gamma. Jennifer had been living in Jackson since last September and was passionate about her life and work there. Besides her parents, she is survived by her sisters, Nina Johnson of San Francisco, Handley Johnson and Stephanie Johnson of Greenwich, her fraternal grandmother, Annemarie Cochran of Southport, CT and her maternal grandfather, James R. James, Jr. of St. Louis, MO. A celebration of her life will take place at her parent's home on Saturday, June 28th, 3:00 to 7:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Jen's favorite cause, The Teton Valley Ranch Education Fund. The TVRC Education Foundation PO Box 4915 Jackson, WY 83001 Tel. 307.733.6122 Fax307.733.4517 Email: foundation @ready-to-ride.org >>AD#
