The family will welcome visitors for a memorial gathering on Friday, June 27, from 1:30-7PM at 19 Mayhew Avenue, Larchmont NY. Contributions may be made in Howard's name to: Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, Department of Oncology, Development Office, 600 East 233 Street, Bronx, NY 10466. >>AD#

title: RIBAPHARM REJECTS TAKEOVER BID FROM ICN AS INADEQUATE
description: Ribapharm Inc., maker of the hepatitis C drug ribavirin, rejected a $168 million cash buyout offer from its majority shareholder, ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., as inadequate. The bid for the 19.9 percent of the company that ICN does not already own is ''not in the best interests of Ribapharm's public stockholders,'' the chairman, Daniel J. Paracka, said. ICN offered on June 2 to pay $5.60 for each Ribapharm share. Ribapharm's stock has climbed this month, to close yesterday at $6.56, indicating that some investors anticipate a higher offer. ICN, which extended the deadline last week to July 22, has said it will not raise its bid. Robert O'Leary, ICN's chief executive, said in a statement that the company was disappointed and was reviewing its options. Both companies are based in Costa Mesa, Calif.

title: Tuition Raised 25% By CUNY Trustees
description: In a quick and raucous meeting, the trustees of the City University of New York raised undergraduate tuition for state residents at its senior colleges by $800 a year, to $4,000. It was the first increase in eight years, but critics said that many students could not afford it. CUNY had sought to raise the tuition by less than the $950 authorized by the State Legislature after the university's state operating subsidy was cut by $121 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Comptroller Sees Deficits In Coming Years
description: The state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said yesterday that the $92.8 billion budget the Legislature passed in May over the governor's veto was balanced for this year, thanks to extra federal aid, but would create huge deficits over the next two years. Mr. Hevesi, a Democrat, said because of Congress's recent decision to provide about $1.4 billion in additional aid, the state could end the fiscal year on March 31 with a surplus of as much as $1 billion. Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, had predicted a hole almost that large would open up in the budget later this year. But Mr. Hevesi said the governor had been right about deficits in the next two fiscal years, which the comptroller estimated would be $5.3 billion and $6.9 billion, respectively. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: An Early Heartland of Agriculture Is Found in New Guinea
description: The first farmers raised barley and wheat in the Middle East more than 10,000 years ago. Sometime later, Chinese began cultivating rice, Mexicans corn and beans and South Americans potatoes. Indians in what is now the eastern United States grew crops of sunflower seeds.

description: Advanced Micro Devices, the No. 2 maker of personal computer processor chips behind Intel, cut its second-quarter sales forecast by $100 million yesterday after overestimating demand, especially in Asia.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cordiant Holder Near 25%
description: Active Value Fund Managers, the largest shareholder in the troubled British ad agency company Cordiant Communications, said that it had bought another 2.5 million shares of the company, increasing its stake to 24.53 percent. Active Value has opposed a takeover by the WPP Group, another agency giant, because of the money the deal gives to shareholders. If Active Value owns more than 25 percent of Cordiant's stock, it can prevent the deal. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DONENFELD, , HARVEY
description: DONENFELD--Harvey. Husband of Helen, brother of Belle Nathanson, uncle to many loved nieces and nephews. Harvey and Helen shared a life of love and devotion to each other. Harvey was a man who will be missed by all the lives he touched. Services to be held Wednesday, June 25, 11 AM at The Riverside Memorial Chapels, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. The family will be grateful for charitable gifts in Harvey's memory.

title: A.C.C. To Invite Va. Tech And Miami
description: The presidents of universities in the Atlantic Coast Conference voted tonight to invite Miami and Virginia Tech to join the A.C.C., according to an official with intimate knowledge of the vote. In a surprising last-minute compromise, the presidents excluded Syracuse and Boston College from the expansion plan.

title: A Budget Success, but Bloomberg Gets No Respect
description: Yesterday should have been Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's victory lap. He shook hands with the City Council on a budget deal that closed a $6.4 billion gap, yet left libraries open, health clinics running and trash picked up as usual.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BREWSTER, , DOROTHY GA TINS
description: BREWSTER -- Dorothy Ga tins. Age 89. Of New York City. Died peacefully on June 24, 2003 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Rice Brewster. Sister of Hope G. Simpson. Cherished mother of Ethel Stout Chapin, Hope Stout Connors and Walter R. Brewster, Jr. Loving grandmother of seven and great grandmother of four. She graduated from Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT., and was a life-long supporter of the school. She was a nurse during the Second World War and, for twelve years, was a travel agent and led meticulously planned tours that were enjoyed by the many who joined her. She served the New York community as a director of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work, Grosvenor Neighborhood House and the Woman's Hospital. She was a member of the Colony Club, where she served as the Governor, the National Society of Colonial Dames, the Holland Dames and the Pilgrims of the United States. There will be a Memorial Mass at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th St and Lexington Ave, Monday, June 30th at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Girls and Boys Town, Father Val J. Peter, Boys Town Center, Boys Town, NE. 68010. >>AD#

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Government To Sell Phone Stake
description: The Australian government has decided, in principle, to sell its 50.1 percent stake in Telstra, the national telephone network. The government said it would invest an additional 180 million Australian dollars in Telstra's Internet and cellphone services in rural areas to improve the company's commercial value, and began the legislative process but gave no sale date. John Shaw (NYT)

title: Moody's Cuts Sony Rating, Citing Electronics Outlook
description: The Sony Corporation has long prided itself on its commanding position atop the high end of the consumer electronics market. But there are signs that it may be slipping from that perch.

title: Online Chat With Faces Attached
description: INSTANT messaging certainly has its charms. You and a conversation partner on the Internet type back and forth in a narrow window, your quips scrolling up the screen like a hastily written script. The fact that you can't see or hear the other person is either the best feature or the worst, depending on how self-conscious you are and how your hair looks.

title: Fox, in Shift, to Join Other Networks in Offering High-Definition TV
description: The Fox Television Network, which previously shunned high-definition broadcasting, plans to transmit at least 50 percent of its prime-time schedule in HDTV by the season that begins in the fall of 2004, a company official told federal regulators today.

title: Quiet Freshman Lets Game Do the Talking
description: Chris Bosh had a brief conversation with his role model during the N.B.A. playoffs, and it was exactly the kind of understated exchange he could appreciate.

title: ABC Sports Names New Executive Producer
description: Mike Pearl was named the senior vice president and executive producer of ABC Sports, leaving Turner Sports, where he held the same position.

title: Hussein's Top Aide Got Belarussian Passports, U.S. Officials Say
description: The senior lieutenant to Saddam Hussein who was detained in Iraq last week obtained Belarussian passports for himself and others, possibly including Mr. Hussein's sons, two United States government officials said today.

title: 60 Stitches for Klitschko
description: Vitali Klitschko was still screaming yesterday that he was robbed when his heavyweight championship fight against Lennox Lewis on Saturday night in Los Angeles was stopped after the sixth round because of a grotesque cut over Klitschko's left eye. But a doctor who repaired the cut was more interesting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AGOVINO, , VERA
description: AGOVINO--Vera. The Board of Directors, staff, participants and members of AHRC NYC convey their condolences to the family of Vera Agovino on the occasion of her passing. Her grace, good will, and commitment will always be remembered and appreciated by the Association. Our deepest concerns and prayers go out to her husband, Al Agovino, former President of AHRC NYC, and to her children Toni, Michael, Alphonse Jr., Christopher and Mark. Our thoughts and prayers are with you. Genevieve O'Neil, President Michael Goldfarb, Executive Director >>AD#

title: Bruno Rejects Silver's Call For Conference Committees
description: Declaring this year's legislative session ''a work unfinished,'' the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, called on the Senate's Republican majority today to form conference committees to work out differences on a dozen important pieces of legislation that had failed to pass both houses.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   O'BRIEN, , LOIS
description: O'BRIEN--Lois. It has been seven years since our loss. You are ever in our minds. Time will never diminish our love. Rest in peace, my darling. Jeremiah and Jack >>AD#

title: On a Slim Solitary Gadget, Photos, Music and Movies
description: To tote your portfolio of digital entertainment, including full-length movies, MP3 music and digital photos, Archos has devised a single gadget: the AV320 Cinema to Go.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Expansion Of Smoking Ban
description: Maine has banned smoking in bars, lounges, taverns and pool halls, becoming the fifth state to enact such a law. Smoking is already prohibited in restaurants throughout the state. Gov. John E. Baldacci called the legislation ''good for business'' and said it would protect nonsmokers -- 75 percent of the state's population, he said -- from secondhand smoke. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: A Bunch Of Ex-Grapes, Still on a Stem
description: Deliciously meaty California raisins in grapelike bunches on little woody stems are showing up in produce markets. Called raisins on the vine, they are easier to pick up than loose raisins, making them perfect to serve on a cheese tray or a fruit platter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALL, , ROSALIE A. (LEE)
description: DALL--Rosalie A. (Lee). On June 23, 2003 at age 64. Mrs. Dall was a Dame of Malta, graduate of St. Vincent's Hospital Nursing School and of Marymount Manhattan College. Beloved wife of Robert, mother of Matthew and Christopher. Grandmother of Ivy Arielle and Martha Alice, sister of Thomas Brett, Marie Budis, the late George Brett and sister-in-law of Janet Zimmerman. Friends may call at Frank E. CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street Wednesday and Thursday 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Patrick's Cathedral, 5th Avenue at 51 Street Friday 10AM. Interment to follow at Cemetery of the Gate of Heaven. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Guiding Eyes for the Blind, 611 Granite Springs Road, Yorktown Heights, N.Y. 10598 or the New York City Police and Firemen Widows and Childrens Benefit Fund, Inc., 6 Kim Place, Kings Park, N.Y. 11754-5023 or St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Mixed Results for Drug Used to Prevent Prostate Cancer
description: A drug that doctors had hoped might prevent prostate cancer has been found to be both more effective and potentially more dangerous than expected.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Child Falls From Window
description: A 4-year-old boy died yesterday evening after falling out of a ninth-floor window in Cypress Hills, the police said. Around 6:45 p.m., the boy, whose name was not released, was in his room on Highland Boulevard and apparently leaned on the screen, which gave way and remained dangling, Detective Thomas Kuchma said. There was no window guard in place, the police said. A woman who was not the boy's mother was in the home at the time, with the boy and a 1-year-old child, Detective Kuchma said. The police said the incident did not appear suspicious at this time, but was under investigation. ''It looks like a tragic accident,'' the detective said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: In a Reversal, Verizon Backs Rule to Keep Cell Numbers
description: Verizon Wireless said yesterday that it would drop its opposition to a government plan to allow callers to keep their wireless phone numbers when they switch carriers. The about-face by Verizon Wireless, the nation's largest mobile phone company, probably means that some other mobile phone operators will have little choice but to yield to the arrangement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPPINCOTT, , JOAN B.
description: LIPPINCOTT--Joan B., on June 20, 2003, of cancer at age 70. Widow of David, mother of Christopher, and grandmother of David S. Sister of Carol Ely and Betty Rank. Mrs. Lippincott was a graduate of Smith College ('51) and the Masters School ('47). She had been a member of the New York Junior League, the Cosmopolitan Club, the City Gardens Club, and the Colonial Dames. She will be deeply missed by all those whose lives she touched. A memorial service will be held at the St. James Church, Madison Ave. at 71st St., Wednesday, July 2nd at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the St. James Church, 865 Maidson Ave., NY NY 10021 or the American Cancer Society. >>AD#

title: Press Your Nose Against the Window, and Then Go In for a Treat
description: Robert Morris worked in ice cream stores while he was in college. Now he has one of his own: Peaches & Cream Cafe, 436 Myrtle Avenue (Clinton Avenue) in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the near drowning of Patrick McSorley, a critic of the Roman Catholic Church's handling of the sexual abuse scandal, referred incorrectly in one instance to the defrocked clergyman he accused of having molested him years earlier. The man, John J. Geoghan, is a former priest, not a former bishop.

title: Is It Art? Probably Not, but It's You
description: TOURISTS sitting for a sidewalk sketch in Central Park or on the banks of the Seine must gamble on the skills of an unknown artist. But vacationers on the New England coast and even weekend moviegoers can have their portraits done by the greats -- Leonardo, Rembrandt, Michelangelo or Raphael -- for a few dollars each.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEBLANG, , MACK
description: LEBLANG--Mack. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our Honorary President and Chairman of the Board, Mack Leblang. His leadership was crucial to the development of the Minskoff Cultural Center Rabbi Arthur Schneier Park East Day School. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President >>AD#

title: 'Henry V' Delayed Again
description: Another postponement has set back the first preview of ''Henry V'' in the 2003 season of free Shakespeare performances at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, from tonight until tomorrow at 8 p.m., a spokeswoman for the Public Theater said yesterday. Rehearsals after the weekend's rains abated revealed safety-related problems in the battle scenes, she said.

title: Wide Impact From Combatant Decision Is Seen
description: President Bush's decision to declare a Qatari student an enemy combatant signals a more aggressive approach against terrorism suspects in the face of new threats from Al Qaeda, and it increases the chances that Zacarias Moussaoui will wind up in a military brig as well, officials and legal observers said today.

title: No Link Found Between Cancer And Power Lines on Long Island
description: A study of women on Long Island has found no link between breast cancer and living near high-voltage power lines, extending a long trail of research that has failed to connect breast cancer on the island to an environmental cause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUNSTADTER, , JOHN W.
description: KUNSTADTER--John W., on June 18, 2003 at age 75, philanthropist, physicist and international banker, died peacefully at home. Beloved husband of Geraldine Kunstadter. Loving father of John Jr., Lisa and Chris Kunstadter and Elizabeth von Habsburg. Devoted grandfather of eight. Dear brother of Peter Kunstadter. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, NY 11201. >>AD#

title: Shuttle Board Determines Likely Site of Fatal Damage
description: The Columbia Accident Investigation Board today located within inches the spot on the shuttle's left wing that was damaged by foam on liftoff on Jan. 16 and said the wing came apart at that point 16 days later in the shuttle's re-entry from space.

title: Latest Peace Hopes Thwarted on Africa's Battlefields
description: Today was supposed to mark a new beginning for Bunia, a northeastern provincial town in Congo that has become the centerpiece of international efforts to bring some semblance of peace to that country.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Bank Robbery Thwarted
description: Two detectives in Howard Beach thwarted a bank robbery as it happened yesterday, the police said. The detectives ran from their car and tackled a man as he fled the North Fork Bank branch at 155-14 Cross Bay Boulevard with a loaded handgun and $2,195 in cash. The detectives, James Culliney and Thomas Dolan, were driving another man for questioning to the 100th Precinct station when they saw Darren Scriven, 39, run out the door of the bank. As Mr. Scriven ran between two parked cars, the detectives noticed a wad of cash in his hand, the police said. When the detectives arrested Mr. Scriven, they found the cash, a note demanding money and a 9mm handgun loaded with eight bullets. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Growth Forecast
description: Thaksin Shinawatra, the prime minister, said that he expected the nation's economy to expand an average 6 percent a year over the next six years, helped by rising consumer spending and surging exports. Mr. Thaksin said Thailand's gross domestic product would probably grow to $200 billion by 2009, from $130 billion. The government forecasts inflation to average 2 percent over the next year, he said, as he asked lawmakers to approve his government's budget for the year ending Sept. 30, 2004.

title: Departure From Saatchi and Quick Turnaround
description: The other shoe dropped yesterday in the abrupt departure of Kurt Ritter from the Torrance, Calif., office of Saatchi & Saatchi. He said he would open an independent marketing consultancy that will work for the office's biggest client, the Toyota Motor Sales USA division of Toyota Motor.

title: English Food That's Not a Punch Line
description: I'VE had wonderful food in London. In fact I haven't had a bad meal there in years. And yet as soon as the subject of eating in England comes up, the jokes about the food begin.

title: A Broken Legislature
description: What a way to run a $90 billion operation. After a marathon all-hours session last week, New York State's Legislature produced virtually nothing but embarrassment. The ineptitude was everywhere. As 213 politicians returned home after six months, their only comfort was that most of their constituents had barely noticed they were gone.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Infocus Loss To Widen; Falling Sales Cited
description: The InFocus Corporation, the world's largest maker of multimedia projectors, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss would widen from the first quarter as sales declined on lower prices and the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome. Sales may fall as much as 15 percent in the period, the company said in a statement. InFocus's first-quarter loss swelled to $12.5 million from $7.9 million. Sales fell 8 percent, to $145.1 million. InFocus, whose shares are listed in Oslo after the company bought Proxima of Norway in 2000, said sales were hampered by weak economies, the war in Iraq, SARS and intensifying competition because of oversupply. The company has also been hurt as clients increasingly opt for cheaper products. Shares of InFocus fell 5.2 kroner, or 13 percent, to 35 kroner in Oslo trading. They have dropped 13 percent this year. In Nasdaq trading, shares fell 96 cents, or about 17 percent, to $4.75. Sales were also slowed as Chinese authorities shut down the company's import operation in the country after an investigation. InFocus said it was working with authorities in China and the United States to resolve the matter.

title: A Digital Camera Attuned To Its Mix-and-Match Lenses
description: Digital photographers who want to use single-lens reflex cameras have had two choices: compact models with permanently mounted zoom lenses or bulky models that accepted interchangeable lenses made for the maker's 35-millimeter S.L.R.'s. The Olympus E-1 is neither of the above. It was designed from the outset for digital use and relies on the first interchangeable-lens system to be shared from the outset by several manufacturers.

title: An American Sequel To Cinecitt's Dolce Vita
description: It has been nearly 10 years since Cinecitt Studios here held a wake for its favorite director, Federico Fellini. A somber and surreal occasion, with an honor guard standing between a wooden coffin and a cloud-spotted blue screen, it seemed to suggest an eternal bond between Fellini and the cinematic world he forged here.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are a village at the end of the world and we don't have Saddam Hussein here. We haven't seen him and we are not harboring him.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PHELPS, , PAUL EDWIN
description: PHELPS--Paul Edwin, age 62, passed away June 22, 2003 after a valiant struggle with multiple myeloma. Paul was an award-winning jewelry designer, model-maker, fine jewelry manufacturer, craftsman and inventor holding three patents. He was employed by M.S. Nelkin & Co., and was past president of Osborne-Phelps & Co. He is survived by his wife of 36 years Wendy (nee Osborne), his daughter Jennifer and son-inlaw Luke, son Zachary anddaughter-in-law Tara, brothers James and Daniel, sisters Phyllis Hurd and Carole Mercer and granddaughter Phoebe. Memorial to be held Friday June 27 at 10 AM at the Pinnacle at Heritage Hills in Somers, NY 914-276-3300. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the IMF 12650 Riverside Drive, Suite 206, North Hollywood, CA. 91607 - 3421. www.myeloma.org >>AD#

title: U.S. Silent on Israeli Move
description: The Bush administration said today that it would not comment on the arrest by Israel of 130 Palestinians in Hebron until American experts could inquire about who had been detained and what evidence led Israel to make the arrests.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: New Prescription Drug Plan
description: Gov. John E. Baldacci has signed into law a new version of the state's prescription drug program, Maine Rx, which the Supreme Court endorsed last month. About 275,000 residents will be eligible for the new plan, Maine RxPlus, which officials say will be put in effect by January. Enrollees will be able to buy preferred drugs at a discount of 15 percent to 60 percent. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KINNEY, , FREDERICK G. KRINSKY ''FREDDIE,''
description: KINNEY--Frederick G. Krinsky ''Freddie,'' 77, of Orlando, Florida, and formerly of Manhattan, New York, died June 22, 2003. He is survived by his wife, two daughters, and one sister. Online guestbook @ www.andersonmcqueen.com St. Petersburg, FL. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: A listing of mail-order sources last Wednesday with an article about apricots misstated the shipping cost for a three-pound box from Eden Garden in Tracy, Calif. The $30 price includes shipping.

title: Daughter of Privilege Films Lives of Pain
description: Donna Nazario grew up in Waterbury, Conn., in a family of seven children. When she was 13, she began using drugs; when she was 26, she learned that she was H.I.V.-positive and staring at the specter of AIDS. ''I came home from the hospital and began saying goodbye to my family, to my mother and my son, who I lived with,'' she recalled. ''I lay on the couch, waiting to die.''

title: Ruling Upheld For Philip Morris
description: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Philip Morris USA, a unit of Altria Group Inc., did not illegally keep competitors' brands from prominent display in stores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WADDELL, , HARRY LEE
description: WADDELL--Harry Lee, of Yachats, OR (formerly of NYC, Port Jervis and Garden City), on June 25. A newspaper and magazine editor and executive, he worked for the Buffalo Evening News, McGraw-Hill, Doubleday & Co., and Simmons-Boardman. In 1983 he retired to Port Jervis with his second wife Helene. He moved to Yachats in 1996 to be near his daughters: Nancy of Whidbey Island, WA; Carol of Malibu, CA; Jessica of Yachats; three grandchildren, one great-grandchild. His inquisitive spirit and concern for community and young people will be missed by those who knew him. Memorials to Hospice of Orange County or Alzheimer's Assoc. >>AD#

title: Schools Cut Down on Fat and Sweets in Menus
description: Acknowledging that obesity is epidemic among New York City schoolchildren, the Education Department is reducing the fat content in the 800,000 meals it serves daily and banning candy, soda and other sugary snacks from school vending machines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHIELDS, , PAUL E.

Church (Kingsbridge), Saturday, June 28th, at 9:45 AM. >>AD#

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Military Breaks Silence
description: The armed forces, one of the nation's most secretive institutions, has court-martialed 299 soldiers since December 2000, the military said. The once secret data were released in compliance with Mexico's new freedom of information law. The military trials led to 210 convictions, defense officials told a Mexico City newspaper, El Universal. Of those tried, 33 were charged with murder, 31 with insubordination, 26 with fraud, 24 with desertion, 22 with robbery and 21 with drug-related offenses. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: U.S. Animal Lab Accused Of Firing a Whistle-Blower
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton charged yesterday that the Plum Island Animal Disease Center fired a worker who complained of safety problems and handed out union leaflets, despite the center's promise that it would not penalize him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYONS, , THOMAS H.
description: LYONS--Thomas H. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas H. Lyons, associated with The Times from March 1999. >>AD#

title: Labor Escapes Givebacks, But Future Battles Loom
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reached a deal yesterday to close this year's budget gap without getting the concessions he wanted from the municipal unions, but the mayor and the unions are sure to clash again in the future as the city faces ballooning deficits.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hospitals Set Disaster Plan
description: One of New York City's major hospital chains has reached a $380 million agreement with I.B.M. that includes the creation of a disaster operations center in Rochester, where duplicate records will be kept and the hospitals' data centers can relocate in an emergency. Mount Sinai NYU Health is the latest in a long string of businesses to invest in such remote backup data centers -- in this case, for Mount Sinai Hospital, NYU Medical Center and NYU Downtown Hospital. The deal, to be announced today, was prompted in part by the terror attack of Sept. 11, when NYU Medical Center had to evacuate its main data center in Lower Manhattan. The I.B.M. pact also includes several other research and information management projects. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Interest Rate Cut
description: Norway's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate yesterday by one percentage point, the biggest reduction in more than a decade, and signaled that it might cut rates further to revive its faltering economy. The bank, Norges Bank, cut its benchmark deposit rate to a five-year low of 4 percent from 5 percent. The period of monetary easing is continuing, said Svein Gjedrem, the central bank's governor, in the bank's report.

title: FedEx Profit Rose 19% in 4th Quarter
description: The FedEx Corporation, the world's largest overnight-delivery company, said yesterday that profit rose 19 percent in its fiscal fourth quarter.

description: MARCUS--Irving. Of Hewlett, NY and Palm Beach, FL. Passed away on June 24, 2003 after a brief illness. Loving husband of 63 years to Gertrude. Devoted father of Joel, Marilyn and Stuart. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Elyse, Michael, Jordan, Lauren and Andrew. Dear Brother of Al Marcus and the late Rose Flaxman. Donations may be sent to Brandeis University in Waltham, MA. Shiva to be at the home of Joel Marcus. >>AD#

title: Russian Economy Builds on 3 Years of Growth
description: President Vladimir V. Putin appears to be off to a strong start on his newly announced capitalist plan to double Russia's economy in a decade.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Iraqis' desperate hunt for small-denomination dinar bills misstated the value of the currency. A 10,000-dinar note is worth about $7.50, not $75.

title: Pediatrix Says Medicaid Billing Is Under Federal Investigation
description: The Pediatrix Medical Group, which provides care for premature babies, said yesterday that a federal prosecutor was conducting a civil investigation into its Medicaid billing practices. Its shares fell 24 percent.

title: Suggested Tuition Increase for SUNY Is Lowered
description: Five months after recommending a $1,400 tuition increase for next year, Robert L. King, the chancellor of the State University of New York, yesterday scaled back his recommendation to $950 -- the amount the Legislature has said would be the maximum acceptable.

description: The killing of six British military policemen today in southern Iraq along with an ambush of British paratroopers threatened to raise new questions among Britons about the deployment of their troops alongside United States forces. The incidents also add to the political woes confronting Prime Minister Tony Blair over his reasons for sending British troops to Iraq in the first place.

title: Iranian Rebel Group Had Attack Plans, French Report Says
description: An Iranian opposition group operating in France that was the target of a large police operation last week had plans to attack Iranian embassies and assassinate former members working with Iranian intelligence services in Europe, according to a classified report by France's counterintelligence service prepared two weeks before the crackdown.

title: Paying Homage to a Departed Jewel, a Single Facet at a Time
description: More than 15 performers covering the pop-jazz spectrum gathered at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening in the JVC Jazz Festival's homage to Norma Deloris Egstrom, the platinum blond sphinx better known as Peggy Lee. They ranged from the English pop star Petula Clark to the folkie Maria Muldaur to the rocker Deborah Harry to the jazz diva Shirley Horn. Each evoked a different facet of the enigma.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer Maintains Forecast
description: The Belgian brewer Interbrew stuck to its earlier forecast of organic sales and profit growth this year. Sales during the first half of this year have been strong, especially in Russia, Ukraine and Central Europe, the company said, while market share in France and exports to the United States declined. Analysts said that after a profit warning on Monday from a rival Dutch brewer, Heineken, the market had expected similar pessimism from Interbrew. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Help For Economy
description: Thailand has set up a 100-billion-baht fund ($2.4 billion) to invest in troubled sectors of the economy. As that fund, the Phoenix Fund, was announced, Thailand's stock exchange said it would create a 700-million-baht fund to invest in the shares it lists. The exchange said the investment was part of an effort to increase revenue as interest rates on its bank deposits fall. The Thai government has already announced plans to sell mutual funds to individual investors to raise part of the 100 billion baht it plans to use to invest in local stocks as part of its plan to prop up stock prices. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

description: Senate Republicans stepped up the maneuvering on federal judicial candidates and future Supreme Court vacancies today when the Rules Committee approved a proposal to make it easier to break filibusters that prevent votes on administration nominations.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: More Officers For Gang Effort
description: Chicago officials announced a plan to deploy 100 highly trained police officers to the city's most gang-ridden neighborhoods in an effort to curb violent crime. Mayor Richard M. Daley said he planned to reassign 450 gang crimes officers to the city's most troubled communities. Chicago has had 272 murders this year, up from 267 at the same point last year. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a photograph on Monday with an obituary of George Axelrod, a writer of plays and screenplays, was reproduced in mirror image. The clock should have appeared at the left of the typewriter.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Television And The City
description: NYC TV has replaced Crosswalks Television as the city's official television network, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. NYC TV features some new original programming, ranging from live mayoral news conferences from City Hall to improved Off-Track Betting programs to live traffic reports, known as City Drive Live. On Fridays at 10 p.m., the station will feature vintage documentaries, news conferences, and other historical moving images, like Alfred Hitchcock's visit with Mayor John V. Lindsay or Muhammad Ali's sparring on the steps of City Hall. NYC TV comprises five channels, and is available in 1.8 million households in New York City, reaching all cable subscribers in the five boroughs. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: KROLL TO BUY FACTUAL DATA FOR $115 MILLION
description: Kroll Inc., which provides security and investigative services to companies and government agencies, will acquire the Factual Data Corporation for about $115 million in cash and stock. Factual Data shareholders will receive $14 in cash and $3.50 in stock for each share held, or about $17.50, Kroll said. The purchase will allow Kroll to offer mortgage and consumer credit reports and employment screening to businesses and consumers.

description: East Side Farmer's Market

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Bank Indicted
description: The Dexia Bank of Belgium said it had been indicted in a criminal investigation into fraud at the technology company Lernout & Hauspie, which is bankrupt. The prosecutor's office said the indictment concerned the activities of Artesia Banking, which was taken over by Dexia in 2001. Artesia is suspected of having had dealings with Lernout & Hauspie from 1998 to 2000, when the accounting fraud there reached its peak. Dexia said that it was extremely surprised, and it dismissed the indictment as groundless. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: 'Fac Brats' Recall Childhood in School of Soft Knocks
description: Some came to apologize for 45-year-old slights or to talk about things they could not talk about back then, like parents who drank too much or teachers they considered sadistic. But everyone at the First Unofficial Faculty Brat Family Reunion at Phillips Exeter Academy here came to reminisce about growing up with an extended family of teachers, common rooms instead of living rooms and a quad as a backyard.

title: Taking Action While Action Is an Option
description: In rounding up at least 130 Palestinians today in what it called a sweep for Hamas terrorists, the Israeli Army once again rattled fragile negotiations among Palestinians over halting violence against Israelis.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Concorde May Land On Intrepid
description: British Airways and the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum are negotiating to place a retired Concorde on the deck of the aircraft carrier turned museum. John Lampl, a British Airways spokesman, said, ''It would be our desire to have an airplane at the two ends of the main route, and certainly the USS Intrepid would be a great place.'' Air France has taken the plane out of service, and British Airways plans to do so in October. A Concorde could be floated by barge from Kennedy International Airport to the Hudson River, and hoisted by crane onto the Intrepid at Pier 86, near 46th Street and 12th Avenue. But a long list of museums want Concordes, and British Airways has only seven. The Museum of Flight in Seattle, for example, wants one and so does the Smithsonian's new annex at Dulles Airport near Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROADBENT, , WILLIAM W., SR.
description: BROADBENT--William W., Sr., 77. Retired Insurance Executive. Died of cancer on June 22, 2003 in New London, NH. Mr. Broadbent was vice president of Estate, Business and Financial Planning for the Guardian Life Insurance Company of NY. He retired in 1995 after 31 years with the company. Born in Maplewood, NJ, Mr. Broadbent received his BA from Dartmouth College and his LLB from Columbia Law School. He was a World War II veteran and an active volunteer for local church and civic organizations in both Maplewood and New London. Surviving is his wife of 47 years, Clare (Smith) Broadbent; two sons, Wallace M. and William W.; a daughter, Elizabeth A. Heymann; a sister, and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Morrow Memorial Church, 600 Ridgewood Road, Maplewood, NJ on June 29th at 2:00 P.M. Memorial contributions may be made to The First Baptist Church, P.O. Box 336 or Habitat For Humanity, P.O. Box 1513, both in New London, NH 03257. >>AD#

title: LOCKHEED AND BAE TO WORK JOINTLY ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation and BAE Systems, Europe's biggest military company, agreed to work together to develop systems for defending against missile attacks. Lockheed, based in Bethesda, Md., and BAE, of London, will study which of their capabilities are compatible and consider joint investments in technologies to improve missile-defense programs, the companies said. The partnership will help Lockheed compete outside the United States with Boeing. Boeing, based in Chicago, agreed a year ago to work with the European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Company, Europe's largest aerospace company, on missile-defense programs. Lockheed and BAE already work together on the United States missile-defense program, and both are on a team studying the feasibility of a multinational missile-defense system for NATO. The companies will now consider other opportunities to collaborate on missile defense.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: 38 Accused Of Insurance Fraud
description: The State Division of Criminal Justice announced yesterday that 38 New Jersey residents had been indicted on charges of participating in an elaborate automobile insurance fraud. Insurance companies paid more than $660,000 on fraudulent theft claims. The accused, who were indicted on June 12, face charges ranging from theft by deception to receiving stolen property. During an eight-month sting operation, 46 luxury cars and sport utility vehicles, valued at more than $1.1 million, were recovered. In several instances, lessees and owners with outstanding loans, mileage charges and theft insurance coverage gave their vehicles to middlemen, then reported their vehicles missing or stolen, the authorities said. The middlemen sold many of the vehicles for $800 to $1,500 to a Jersey City auto dealer, which served as the cover for the government's sting, the authorities said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Tunnel Is Proposed as Option In Rebuilding of West Street
description: The State Department of Transportation released preliminary plans yesterday for two alternative overhauls of West Street from the World Trade Center site south to Battery Park, one of which would place part of the street in a tunnel that would cost $860 million and take nearly five years to build.

description: A jury today convicted a former mental patient of two murders in the shooting of a priest and a parishioner during a morning Mass at a church in Lynbrook last year.

description: The New York Racing Association yesterday criticized a report by Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, calling the report's findings of misconduct and negligence by the association inaccurate and unfair.

description: Sometimes a theatergoer has to take the dopey with the smart. A case in point is ''St. Crispin's Day,'' an antiwar comedy by Matt Pepper that fuses Shakespeare and Monty Python to only infrequent good effect.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: AIRLINE TO CUT JOBS AND FLEET Switzerland's national carrier, Swiss International Air Lines, said that it would cut its work force and fleet by nearly a third. The airline said it would cut 3,050 jobs and 34 aircraft to save $1.2 billion. On Monday, trading in its shares was suspended for two days in anticipation of the cuts. Swiss International has been plagued by problems since it was formed in March 2002 on the foundation of the collapsed Swissair. It employs about 9,500 people. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu Wins Verizon Order
description: A unit of Fujitsu Ltd., Fujitsu Network Communications, said it won a major order to supply equipment and software for the new fiber optic network of Verizon Communications. The deal is worth ''hundreds of millions of dollars over several years,'' a Fujitsu spokesman said. The equipment will help Verizon build a synchronous optical network that can handle voice calls and data. Fujitsu has lost money the last two years, partly because of a downturn in spending on telecommunications equipment. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   POST, , SHELDON
description: POST--Sheldon. 9/5/36-6/25/88 Founder, Chelsea Pines Inn. Chair, NYC Gay Men's Chorus. Board, Congregation Beth Simchat Torah. 15 years gone: a moment, a lifetime. As we celebrate Gay Pride this week, we recall those in our community who were lost too soon in the ongoing war against AIDS. Sheldon dreamt of a better world, a world where we could all live and love in harmony, and fought hard to make it happen. He would have shed tears of joy and astonishment to see how far we have come. My cherished companion of seven years, devoted son, brother, uncle, friend, proud to be a gay Jew. Please join Tom Klebba and me as we remember so many others gone too soon: Mark Fuschetti, Peter Monette, Gary Olde, Jon Flaherty, Gary Brubach, Benn Brown and Wayne Kell, Tom Bradley, Garon Douglas, Jay ''Peggy Sue'' Farrar, Dean X Johnson, Allan Kendric and Ron McSwiggen, Bob Levine, Eddie Peters, Quinton Johnson, Norman Sweet, Eddie Tilchen, Martin Teitel. ''And all I ever dreamed I'd be, the best I ever thought of me, was every minute there to see...'' Sheldon, rest well knowing that you and all our friends will be remembered and celebrated as long as we live. Jay Lesige

title: H&R BLOCK SETTLEMENT IN TEXAS IS APPROVED
description: A judge approved H&R Block's settlement of lawsuits that accused it of overcharging and deceiving Texas customers, despite complaints that consumers are getting too little compensation as their lawyers reap $23 million in fees. The judge, Manuel Banales, in Kingsville, Tex., said the settlement, allowing about 700,000 Texans to divide $26 million and receive coupons for tax services and guides, was a ''fair and reasonable'' resolution of complaints about a loan program tied to anticipated tax refunds. H&R Block executives estimated in court that each consumer was eligible to get coupons worth as much as $500. H&R Block officials were accused in the case of hiding loan-referral fees from customers. The company has been sued in six states and in federal court since 1992 over the program, which lent customers money until their tax refunds arrived.

title: Market Place; Oracle, in Pursuit of PeopleSoft, Relents on Merger

Edwards, a rival maker of business software. Oracle also left open the possibility that it would increase its $6.3 billion bid for PeopleSoft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCEWEN, , O. CURRIER, M.D.
description: McEWEN--O. Currier, M.D. The faculty and staff of NYU School of Medicine express their deepest sadness over the death of O. Currier McEwen, M.D., former Dean of the School of Medicine and a distinguished member of the faculty for thirty-eight years. Dr. McEwen graduated from the School of Medicine in 1926, completed his internship at Bellevue Hospital and joined the faculty in 1932. In 1937, at the age of thirty-five, he became the youngest man ever to be appointed Dean of a leading American medical school, up to that time. His service as Dean was interrupted during WWII, when he served as a Colonel with the renowned Bellevue Hospital Unit. Before retiring as Dean in 1955, Dr. McEwen's many accomplishments included the establishment of what is now NYU Medical Center. He was one of the nation's leading authorities on rheumatic diseases, and through his research, patient care and academic pursuits, he made many outstanding contributions to this field. Dr. McEwen retired in 1970 as Professor of Medicine. He embodied the finest traditions of the medical profession throughout his career, and his many years of service to NYU will always be remembered with respect and admiration. Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean, NYU School of Medicine >>AD#

title: Doing It Right in Congo
description: For more than four years, the deadliest fighting since World War II has raged in the vast Central African nation of Congo. More than 3 million people are dead. In some parts of the country, organized society has collapsed, with tribal vengeance giving way to genocide. For those in the war's path, childhood ends abruptly. Parents are butchered in front of their children and militias turn the orphans into killers by their early teens. Neighboring countries are inflaming the conflict, arming rival militias and looting resources.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: DO NOT REMOVE UNDER PENALTY OF LAW The Senate Rules Committee moved closer to issuing this warning to lawmakers: Do not remove from the United States Capitol furniture, paintings and other historic items. "We are not supposed to steal from the Capitol," Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, said after the panel sent the proposed rule to the full Senate for consideration. The rule specifically tells lawmakers and others that they may not remove any art or other listed historical items. Lawmakers often manage to take home a piece of furniture for a discounted price after it has been declared surplus. Other times, items just seem to disappear. (Reuters)

On July 7, she replaces Paula Zahn as co-host of ''American Morning,'' CNN's answer to the ''Today'' show and its a.m. peer group. Change is good, but after 15 years at NBC, where she made a memorable live debut in 1993 -- in a sports bar crammed with drunken San Francisco Giants fans she was groped by a prospective interviewee, froze and forgot her questions -- change can be moderately confusing.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Education Workers Learn Status
description: Hundreds of the city's special education workers packed into a hot room in Brooklyn yesterday to find out where they will be employed next year. Their positions as education evaluators were eliminated in April. On Sunday night, the Department of Education announced a four-day hiring hall on Court Street. Some evaluators waited more than three hours yesterday to learn about their new placements. Others with less seniority were told to come back. Most of the 1,100 evaluators are expected get new positions as teachers or guidance counselors. Mark Glassman (NYT)

title: A Foodie's Trip Up the Hudson
description: The Hudson Valley is a magnet for food lovers, who can pick fruit in season, visit farmers' markets and produce festivals, and sample locally made cheeses and wines. A new guide, ''Hudson Valley Harvest: A Food Lover's Guide to Farms, Restaurants and Open-Air Markets,'' by Jan Greenberg (Countryman Press, $18.95), is divided into chapters according to types of foods and describes farms that are open to visitors. The author also explains how the demand from chefs for high-quality foods helped encourage boutique farming in this area. A guide to restaurants is included, but maps would have been useful, as would a concise list of the farms.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Journalist Leaves Aceh Rebels
description: An American freelance journalist, William Nessen, left the separatist rebel group he had been traveling with in the northern province of Aceh and turned himself over to the Indonesian military. Mr. Nessen, 46, had said in telephone interviews from the jungle that he feared for his life if he were to be taken into custody by the Indonesian Army. The American Embassy said United States officials were present when Mr. Nessen was escorted out by the Indonesian commander in Aceh, Bambang Dharmono. Indonesian military officials have said they want to question Mr. Nessen. The Asia representative of the Committee to Protect Journalists, Lin Neumann, who went to Jakarta to talk to the military about Mr. Nessen, said: ''We're happy he's safe and glad the Indonesians have kept their word so far that he would not be harmed. The next step is to allow him to leave the country as soon as possible.'' Jane Perlez (NYT)

title: F.D.A. FINDS FAULT WITH JOHNSON & JOHNSON'S PROCRIT ADS
description: Johnson & Johnson used misleading information to advertise its Procrit anemia treatment for chemotherapy patients, federal regulators said. In a letter to Johnson & Johnson's Ortho-Biotech unit, the Food and Drug Administration criticized the company for promotional materials that suggested doctors use Procrit to help anemic chemotherapy patients increase their red blood cell levels to normal. ''We received the communication from the F.D.A. on June 20,'' a company spokesman, Mark Wolfe, said. ''We're assessing the content and working to address the matter as quickly as possible.'' Procrit is cleared only for use in increasing cell numbers from dangerously low levels. There is no data to show an additional benefit for patients treated until they reach a normal blood cell count, the F.D.A. said.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Says Quarterly Loss Narrows
description: Palm Inc., the world's largest maker of hand-held computers and the software that runs them, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss narrowed and sales outpaced its forecasts. Shares rose as much as 10 percent. The net loss narrowed to $15 million, or 51 cents a share, in the quarter ended May 31 from $27.5 million, or 95 cents, a year earlier, Palm said. Sales fell 3.2 percent, to $225.8 million from $233.3 million, a smaller drop than its March forecast. Palm's chief executive, Eric Benhamou, said that the hand-held computer industry was recovering from a slump in demand that left Palm with a loss of $442.6 million this year. Shares of Palm, which peaked on the first day of trading in March 2000, rose as much as $1.59, to $17.29 in after-hours trading after the release of the results, before slipping to $16.79. They fell 57 cents, to $15.70 in regular trading.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Seiko Epson Opens Strong

They closed at 3,510 yen ($29.79), up 910, or 35 percent. The listing, worth 132 billion yen ($1.1 billion), was one of the largest initial public offerings this year. Seiko Epson, which makes ink-jet printers, sold shares under new, more relaxed criteria that permit money-losing companies to list. title: Argentina Agrees to Talk Reform With I.M.F.
description: Argentina and the International Monetary Fund agreed today to begin negotiating a multiyear agreement that will force the new government here to make politically unpopular decisions the country has been avoiding for nearly two years.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Public Offering
description: The government-owned Bank Mandiri, Indonesia's largest bank, raised 2.23 trillion rupiah ($270 million) yesterday in the biggest initial public offering in Indonesia since 1996. Fund managers signed up to buy 3.3 billion Mandiri shares for 675 rupiah each, with bids outnumbering shares available by almost 10 to 1, underwriters said. Most orders came from the United States, Europe and elsewhere in Asia. Next week the bank plans to sell an additional 700 million shares to Indonesian retail investors, raising the sale to 4 billion shares, or 20 percent of the bank. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Official Convicted Of Corruption
description: A federal jury has convicted a county official of passing $10,000 in bribes to the former Hudson County executive, Robert C. Janiszewski, in 1999. During a three-week trial, the official, Nidia Davila-Colon, 49, a Hudson County freeholder, admitted she had passed the bribes to Mr. Janiszewski. The bribes came from Dr. Oscar Sandoval, a Union City psychiatrist, several weeks after he was awarded a $2.3 million county contract, said United States Attorney Christopher J. Christie. Ms. Davila-Colon was convicted on Monday of mail fraud and aiding and abetting extortion. Dr. Sandoval cooperated with the authorities and has not been charged, Mr. Christie said. Ms. Davila-Colon will be sentenced on Sept. 29. John Holl (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fox Television to Add HDTV To Prime Time by Fall 2004

title: Panel Staff to Urge Big Change In How Elections Are Handled
description: Staff members of a commission looking at the future of elections in New York City will recommend dramatic changes, including a move to nonparty elections and a fast timetable that will make the changes effective either in time for the 2005 elections or, at the latest, four years later.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: No Action On Budget
description: With six days of negotiating time before a balanced budget must be in place, legislators postponed action yesterday on Gov. James E. McGreevey's $24.1 billion plan. While leaders of the evenly divided Senate bargained, resuming a session that started Monday night, Republicans in a budget committee hearing blocked proposed new taxes on hotel and motel rooms, cigarettes, telephone bills and real estate transfers. The Republicans are trying to whittle down what they maintain is $800 million in new or increased taxes in Mr. McGreevey's budget, while the Democrats accuse them of failing to offer specific budget cuts. The negotiations continued last night. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: CITING FLAW, STATE VOIDS MATH SCORES
description: Moving to defuse a crisis for thousands of high school students, New York State's education commissioner, Richard P. Mills, yesterday set aside the results of last week's Math A Regents exam for seniors and juniors. The test is required for graduation, and many educators had described it as inordinately difficult.

title: Financial Times sets out to tell U.S. readers that it is indispensable.
description: SINCE introducing a United States edition in 1997, The Financial Times has achieved strong brand recognition for its international perspective and a high-income subscriber list. But with a circulation still dwarfed by that of The Wall Street Journal, the paper has embarked on its first American consumer ad campaign in three years, part of ambitious growth plans that include two new printing plants in the United States.

title: Immigrants Feel the Pinch of Post-9/11 Laws
description: Jorge, an illegal immigrant from Honduras, walked into the Department of Motor Vehicles here this month and applied for a driver's license. Friends of his had in the past been granted licenses, so he was surprised when he was turned away, along with more than a dozen other Central American migrant workers.

title: Newcomer Charges Bosnia Business Barricades
description: When Benjamin Herzberg concluded in 2001 that the air had gone out of the Internet bubble, he decided to quit his job at a software company in New York City and follow his wife to another high-wire destination: Bosnia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Bertelsmann's offer of its Times Square headquarters building for sale misspelled the surname of the company's former chief executive. He is Thomas Middelhoff, not Middlehoff.

title: Animal Welfare's Unexpected Allies
description: The cameras are rolling here at Purdue University's animal research center, tracking a half-dozen pigs, each with an ink streak slathered across its back for identification.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: AIRLINE ADDS FLIGHTS Cathay Pacific Airways said that it would resume 90 percent of its flight schedule by August and restore all of its service in September as it works to recover from the traffic slowdown caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS. Cathay said passenger traffic dropped 75 percent in May, compared with figures from a year earlier. The airline canceled thousands of flights, although the outlook has improved as Hong Kong emerges from the shadow of SARS. Cathay has not predicted when it will be profitable again. The World Health Organization removed Hong Kong from its list of infected areas on Monday. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a reduction in the Eastman Kodak Company's profit forecast referred incorrectly to its use of outside manufacturers. While Kodak has contracted with others to assemble some lower-priced single-use cameras, it still makes all of its own film.

title: Tribute to Chicago Icon and Enigma
description: How better to teach people, at last, about Jean Baptiste Point DuSable than to build and name a park for him right in the center of Chicago, his city, where the river meets the lake?

title: Rap Impresario Meets With Albany Leaders and Learns a Hard Lesson About Politics
description: By all accounts, it was a bizarre meeting, the likes of which had not been seen in Albany in decades: A rap impresario, elected by no one, sat at the table in the governor's office with the chief executive and legislative leaders, hours after they wanted to quit, exhorting them to keep negotiating until they agreed to revamp the state's drug sentences.

title: Bad Planning
description: President Bush is sure lucky no weapons of mass destruction have been found yet in Iraq.

title: A Winery Profits as India Adapts to New Tastes
description: Educated in Silicon Valley but seduced by Sonoma Valley, Rajeev Samant decided to come home to these dry hills northeast of Bombay to try making wine in India, a nation where annual wine consumption works out to one teaspoon per person.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDEN, , HOWARD N.
description: GOLDEN--Howard N. The partners, associates and staff of Golden & Mandel, LLP mourn the loss of their beloved senior partner, Howard N. Golden, on Monday, June 23, 2003. Howard was a friend and mentor to all of us, and his memory will be cherished as an inspiration to compassion and decency. >>AD#

title: Judge Rules City Erred By Firing 3 For Blackface
description: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the First Amendment rights of a police officer and two firefighters were violated by city officials when they dismissed the three men for wearing blackface on a float in the Labor Day parade in 1998 in Broad Channel, Queens.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Casino Deal
description: A bingo and casino operator, the Gala Group of London, is teaming up with Harrah's Entertainment to build eight casinos in Britain. Each of the gaming companies will invest $500 million in the 50-50 partnership. Sites for the casinos and time frame for development have not yet been decided.

title: At a Hearing, Ostrich Plumes And Pleas for Freer Cabarets
description: Opponents of New York City's longstanding cabaret laws, some dressed in fishnet stockings and ostrich plumes, spoke at a forum about the laws yesterday evening, carrying signs with slogans like ''The Waltz is Illegal in New York City.''

title: Newark Officer Dies After Car Is Hit at Intersection, Police Say
description: A Newark police officer responding to a call died yesterday after his car was struck in an intersection by a vehicle running a red light, the police said. The driver of the other car, who the police said was drunk, was arrested and charged with felony murder.

title: Do Not Pass Comfortable. Go Directly to Hot and Sweaty.
description: We lost her.

title: Bush Offers Pakistan Aid, but No F-16's
description: President Bush offered Pakistan a tightly conditioned package of $3 billion in aid today, a move that seemed intended to bolster an unsteady ally that only two years ago was still under strict American sanctions for defying the United States by developing its own nuclear weapons program.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Medicaid Money To Cover Raises
description: Gov. Tom Vilsack will move more than $15 million in state Medicaid money to help cover the personnel costs for state employees, including a 2 percent raise. Mr. Vilsack has said that he expects to have a $15 million Medicaid surplus at the end of the year and that if he does not make the transfer the state will be forced to lay off workers. State Representative Bill C. Dix said that the Medicaid budget had been in the red for years and that he was skeptical it would produce a surplus. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Bush's Fund-Raising
description: To the Editor:

title: D'Amato Overcomes Opposition To Plans for Oceanfront House
description: Ever the master of political arts, Alfonse M. D'Amato has overcome much of the opposition to his planned oceanfront home on Long Island.

title: PARK PLACE SAYS EARNINGS WILL DROP LESS THAN FORECAST
description: The Park Place Entertainment Corporation, the world's biggest casino company, said second-quarter earnings might fall less than it had forecast because business improved in May and the first half of June. Net income in the period ending next Monday will decline to a range of 11 cents to 15 cents a share from $96 million, or 31 cents, a year earlier, the company said. Last month, it estimated earnings of as much as 11 cents. Park Place, based in Las Vegas, owns and manages casinos under the Caesars, Bally's and Hilton names.

title: They're Not Champagne, but They Sparkle
description: ONLY one country can make Champagne. And we all know which one that is. But almost every country that makes the other kinds of wine thinks that it, too, can make, if not Champagne, a terrific alternative. No one has done it yet, but some have come close. Recently, the Dining section tasting panel decided to see just how close that might be.

title: Senate Rebuffs Bid to Close a Gap in Medicare Drug Coverage
description: The Senate rejected a Democratic effort today to make a new Medicare drug benefit more generous by closing a substantial gap in coverage for elderly people with high drug costs.

description: The Italian police arrested six suspected members of a militant Islamic cell in Milan, charging them with raising funds for groups linked to Al Qaeda and promoting international terrorism.

description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, in an energetic endorsement of prewar intelligence on Iraq, said today that ''virtually everyone'' had agreed that Baghdad had ''weapons of mass destruction programs.''

title: Exonerated, but Locked in Shadow
description: Photography has not been good to these men. Their lives were nearly destroyed by mug shots, perp shots or ordinary snapshots. So once their ordeals were over, why in the world did they consent to having their pictures taken by the photographer Taryn Simon and displayed at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center?

title: Chain in Accord on Workers' Required Clothes
description: Abercrombie & Fitch, the trendy retailer for the college set, has agreed to pay $2.2 million to settle an investigation in which the State of California accused it of illegally requiring employees to buy and wear its clothes.

title: Liberty Doesnt Take Last-Place Team Lightly
description: The mind-set was there for the Liberty going into last nights game against the Phoenix Mercury: do not take the team with the poorest record in the league lightly. Phoenix was 2-9 in the Womens National Basketball Association and had never defeated the Liberty at Madison Square Garden in seven meetings.

title: Youth Arrested In Death of Boy In a Fistfight
description: The police arrested a Harlem teenager yesterday and charged him with manslaughter in the death of a youth who fell and hit his head during a fistfight on Monday night.

title: Finally, a Ballpark Gets a Neighbor
description: Since 1994, the red-brick stadium that is home to the Texas Rangers has loomed majestically over more than 200 acres of parking lots and vacant land that were part of the development package. But now the ballpark is about to get its first neighbor: a division of Siemens, the German electronics company.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Washington Township: Crash Snarls Traffic
description: An accident involving a tractor-trailer and seven cars caused traffic delays on the New Jersey Turnpike for much of yesterday, a turnpike spokesman said. No one was seriously injured in the accident, but traffic was backed up for 18 miles southbound and 7 miles northbound. The accident happened shortly after 10 a.m. in the southbound lanes near interchange 7A when a convertible lost control, struck another car and was hit by the tractor-trailer, which fell on its side and blocked two lanes, said the spokesman, Joseph Orlando. All lanes were reopened at 2 p.m. but delays affected evening traffic. John Holl (NYT)

title: Voting and Running at Same Time Tests Six Democrats
description: Senators John Kerry and Bob Graham took the Senate floor on Friday to sharply criticize the major Medicare bill that is on the table, describing it as insufficient and riddled with gaps in insurance coverage.

title: SONY ERICSSON VENTURE TO CLOSE SITES AND CUT 500 JOBS
description: Sony Ericsson Mobile Communications Ltd., a mobile telephone joint venture of the Sony Corporation and Ericsson, said it would stop making some phones for the United States market and would close two research centers in the United States and Europe. Sony Ericsson, which is based in London, will close sites in Munich and in Research Triangle Park, N.C., eliminating 500 jobs, the company said. The venture will halt the production of handsets for C.D.M.A, or code division multiple access, technology in the United States, where sales were less lucrative, one analyst said.

description: To the Editor:

title: Holder Raises Cordiant Stake To Level Needed to Block Deal
description: Active Value, the largest shareholder in the Cordiant Communications Group, the British advertising agency company, said today that it had increased its stake. The purchase gives it enough shares to block a buyout of the company by the WPP Group.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Cuts At Airline
description: The Dutch airline, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, said it might cut as many as 4,500 jobs, about 50 percent more than announced in April, as demand for travel falls because of a global economic slowdown and a respiratory-disease epidemic. The airline wants to reduce costs by 650 million euros ($750 million) a year.

title: Lasers Set Cells Aglow for a Biopsy Without the Knife
description: IT takes time to do a proper biopsy: typically, several days for a tissue sample to be removed, preserved, sliced, stained with labeling chemicals and placed under a microscope to be interpreted by a pathologist.

title: A World Map to Outwit Web Censors
description: IN recent years, Internet censorship has been an increasing focus of scholarly research. At Harvard, the Berkman Center for Internet and Society has identified Web sites -- some surprisingly tame -- blocked by the governments of Saudi Arabia and China. At the University of Toronto, the Citizen Lab has developed a tool that will enable users to determine whether a Web address is blocked in any of 15 countries.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Touch America To Receive Loan From Qwest
description: Qwest Communications International will provide bankruptcy financing to Touch America Holdings Inc. as part of an agreement that resolves billing and other disputes between the phone companies. Qwest will lend an undisclosed amount of money to Touch America and the companies will continue to sell each other network services, Qwest said in a statement yesterday. The agreement still needs approval by the court overseeing Touch America's bankruptcy. Touch America, owner of a 21,000-mile fiber optic network, sought protection from creditors last week, listing $554.2 million of debts in the filing. The agreement settles billing disputes without any payment from Touch America and relieves Qwest of the obligation to buy Touch America's interest in a wireless joint venture for $23 million, the companies said. Shares of Qwest, the biggest seller of local calling in 14 Western states, rose 8 cents, to $4.84.

title: Departure From Saatchi And Quick Turnaround
description: The other shoe dropped yesterday in the abrupt departure of Kurt Ritter from the Torrance, Calif., office of Saatchi & Saatchi. He said he would open an independent marketing consultancy that will work for the office's biggest client, the Toyota Motor Sales USA division of Toyota Motor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOAN, , NANCY BETH
description: SLOAN--Nancy Beth, 48, illustrator, freelance design consultant and lifetime Manhattan resident, died June 21st. Survived by her sister Carol Hurst, brother-in-law Larry Hurst and her nephews Kenneth and Kevin Sweet. Memorial service June 26th, St. Peters Church, Citicorp Building, 54th and Lexington, 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in Nancy's name be sent to the Art Students League of NY, 215 West 57th Street, New York, NY 10019, 212-247-4510. >>AD#

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Judge Approves Dice's Plan To Exit Bankruptcy
description: Dice Inc., an Internet job-search service that sold for more than $54 a share in March 1999, won a judge's approval of its plan to exit bankruptcy as a private company and hand ownership to creditors and shareholders. Under the recovery plan, approved yesterday by Judge Burton R. Lifland of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, Dice will swap all of its $69.4 million of 7 percent convertible subordinated notes due in 2005 for 95 percent of the shares in the reorganized company. Dice said it expected to leave bankruptcy on June 30. ''We will emerge as a privately held, essentially debt-free company with a solid financial position,'' the chief executive, Michael P. Durney, said. Dice sought bankruptcy protection on Feb. 14 after failing to make a profit for 17 consecutive quarters. The company listed $38.8 million in assets and $82.1 million in debts in Chapter 11 papers. The company's recovery plan was supported by the hedge fund Elliott Associates and its international affiliate, which hold about $33.6 million, or 48 percent, of the notes. Elliott, Dice's largest creditor, will receive 46 percent of the new shares.

title: The Skin Isn't Great, But the Heart Is Pure Gold
description: THE avocado is an archaic anomaly. Botanically and popularly regarded as a fruit, it is typically used as a vegetable. It can hang on the tree for 16 months or more -- roughly the gestation period of a rhinoceros -- but ripens only after picking, when its reptilian hide belies the buttery flesh within. Indeed, scientists theorize that this extravagantly rich pulp evolved to entice megafauna like mastodons and ground sloths to swallow the fruit whole and disperse the giant seeds.

title: A 70 Percent Failure Rate? Try Testing the Testers
description: ''TAKE another tissue, Kim,'' said the guidance counselor at Long Beach High School, Patricia Kronick. ''It's going to be O.K., sweetie.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: MIG's From Germany
description: Poland's Air Force will receive 23 MIG-29 fighter jets from Germany to help it fulfill its NATO obligations. Under the agreement, Poland, which joined NATO in 1999, will have free use of the aircraft until 2014. The single-seat, Soviet-built MIG's originally belonged to the East German Army and were scheduled to be phased out in Germany by next year. Hugh Eakin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Rates Unchanged
description: The Bank of Japan left its monetary policy unchanged after a one-day meeting as rising stock prices and stronger-than-anticipated first-quarter growth eased pressure on the bank. The central bank will continue to leave as much as a 30-trillion-yen surplus ($254 billion) in the money markets for banks to borrow, and buy 1.2 trillion yen in government bonds every month from the market. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Lottery Numbers
With Paint, Seeing Isn't Always Believing
description: AS anyone who has ever painted a room knows, the problem with color is that if it's off by even one shade, it's a disaster. It might as well be black.

title: U.S. and Other Countries Outline Program to Curb Carbon Emissions
description: An array of industrialized and developing countries agreed today on the outline of a cooperative research program aimed at capturing and storing carbon dioxide, the main smokestack emission linked to global warming.

title: Veil of Secrecy Around Village Hit in U.S. Raid
description: On a desolate panorama of hardtack desert along the Syrian border here, the United States military has cordoned off part of this village, evicted five families whose houses were bombed six days ago and refused to say what is going on.

title: California Turmoil: Budget Talks Stall, Recall Drive Gains
description: Sacramento is in a state of near-perfect political meltdown.

title: Scotland's New Chefs Take Its Riches to Heart
description: THE titles on a shelf of cookbooks at the store on George Street in Edinburgh prepared me for the meals to come. ''Good Food,'' ''Simple Food,'' ''Classic Cooking,'' they read, which is precisely what many of Scotland's best restaurants are delivering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNOWLTON, , ERICA
description: KNOWLTON--Erica. Widow of Hugh Knowlton, loving and beloved stepmother of his four children, died peacefully on June 14, 2003. She will be greatly missed by her extended family and many friends. Gifts in her memory should be sent to The Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60 St, New York, New York 10022. >>AD#

title: A Frustrated Piazza Ponders Future
description: Fans hoping to get an autographed picture of Mike Piazza at an electronics store stood patiently in line yesterday in the clammy weather along West 45th Street.

title: Masterpiece or Empire, It's All Up to the Player
description: From the paper-and-dice days of early Dungeons and Dragons to the fluid graphics of The Sims Online, role-playing games have offered a chance to shed your skin and become somebody new, even if for just a few hours. Second Life, a new online game from Linden Labs that made its official debut this week, combines Internet socializing with rambles in its 3-D virtual society. Players can roam through the game with an onscreen body that looks as much (or as little) like themselves as desired.

title: Mayor Steps Back From English Immersion
description: Reversing his position on how children who do not speak English should be taught, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday announced plans to strengthen programs for 134,000 students who need to learn English that emphasize bilingual instruction and classes taught in native languages instead of requiring total immersion in English.

title: South Korea Indicts Aides to Ex-President in Summit Inquiry
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 25  Two aides to former President Kim Dae Jung, who spearheaded a drive for reconciliation with North Korea, were indicted today on charges of transferring $100 million to North Korea as a payoff for its agreeing to a June 2000 inter-Korean summit meeting between Mr. Kim and President Kim Jong Il of North Korea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISH, , KATHRYN RUTH
description: FISH -- Kathryn Ruth, of Larchmont, NY, passed away on June 23, 2003 at age 78. She was the wife of the late Robert B. Fish and mother of the late Deborah Ruth Fish & is survived by her daughter Judith, and granddaughter Justine. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Emanuel of Westchester, Rye, NY on Sunday, June 29 at 2 PM. Memorial donations to Congregation Emanuel. >>AD#

title: From Potato Chips to Fruit Dessert, Keeping It Simple for These Wines
description: MAKERS of sparkling wines that are not Champagne must distinguish their wines in some way. Many do it by price, which never hurts, and some do it by producing a wine that is friendly, soft on the brain and light as cool water. Its effervescence feels more like a nervous flutter to Champagne's prickly bubbles. And its fruit is there for the taking, rather than appearing as a ponderous suggestion on the finish.

title: The Sinister Evolution of the Most Intimate Form of Political Violence
description: ''Human Weapon,'' a gripping and important documentary, examines the history of suicide bombing as a tool of warfare and comes to some unsettling conclusions. The premise of the movie, directed by Ilan Ziv, a New York-based Israeli filmmaker, is that this most intimate expression of political violence, like other forms of warfare, has systemically evolved as a technique. Initially applied to military and political targets, it has only in the last decade expanded to include the intentional slaughter of civilians.

title: Likely Accord On City Budget Averts Cuts
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council neared a budget agreement yesterday in which the mayor agreed to cut fewer city services and the Council to scale back some demands.
