title: CNN's Ad Sales Chief Says He Will Retire
description: Larry Goodman, president of the advertising sales force at CNN for the last eight years, is retiring, he said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Verity Shares Plunge On Lower Forecast
description: Shares of Verity Inc., a maker of Internet search-engine software, fell as much as 22 percent yesterday in extended trading after the company forecast fiscal first-quarter and full-year earnings and revenue below analysts' expectations. The shares fell $3.45, to $13.88, in extended trading, after dipping to $13.45 earlier. The stock rose 33 cents, to $17.33 in regular trading. Verity forecast earnings, excluding costs, of 4 cents to 6 cents a share in the period ending in August, on revenue of $26 million to $28 million, the company said. On that basis, Verity was expected to earn 11 cents on revenue of $28.2 million, the average estimate of six analysts polled by Thomson Financial.

title: Ruling in '98 Blackface Case Finds Favor in the Community
description: Residents of the enclave of Broad Channel in Jamaica Bay expressed approval yesterday of a judge's decision that three residents' First Amendment rights were violated when they were fired for racial depictions in the 1998 Labor Day parade.

title: Conflict Over New Jersey's Budget Moves to the Airwaves
description: Listen to enough drive-time radio in New Jersey these days, and you might assume that elected officials had decided to work out the state's fiscal problems by holding a schoolyard taunting match.

title: Death of Newborn Is Ruled a Homicide
description: The city medical examiner has ruled that the death of an infant born on April 4 in a bathroom at Cardinal Spellman High School in the Bronx was a homicide, the police said yesterday.

description: What a cunning man Clarence Thomas is.

title: Internet Filters and Free Speech
description: The Supreme Court dealt a blow to free expression and put librarians in a serious bind this week by upholding a law requiring libraries to use filters on all computers with Internet access. The law's goal, preventing children from accessing pornography, is perfectly legitimate. But the court's ruling will also deny adults the ability to see a substantial amount of information online. Libraries have a duty to minimize the decision's impact on freedom of expression. They should also consider bringing another challenge to the law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINTER, , PHILIP L., ESQ.
description: WINTER--Philip L., Esq. Formerly of Larchmont, N.Y. passed away Tuesday, June 24, 2003 in Jensen Beach, FL. He was predeceased by his wife Sarah ''Scat'' Winter and their daughter Jeanie. He is survived by two grandchildren, his stepson and two nieces and nephews. He graduated Harvard College in 1944 and Harvard Law School in 1949, served in the U.S. Army as a Japanese interpreter during WWII, and practiced entertainment law in New York City before moving his practice to Larchmont, N.Y. and Estes Park, CO. Funeral services and interment will be held in Estes Park, CO. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Hospice Care

title: Fred Sandback, 59, Sculptor Of Minimalist Installations
description: Fred Sandback, a sculptor internationally known for his Minimalist works made from lengths of colored yarn, died on Monday at his studio in New York. He was 59.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Hotel Operator Seeks Protection
description: The Aoki Urban Development Corporation, which runs the Westin Hotel Osaka, has filed for protection from creditors, according to Teikoku Databank, a credit research agency. The privately held developer had liabilities worth 31.5 billion yen ($267 million), about five times its income. The Westin Osaka has suffered from a downturn in the travel industry and the economy generally, the agency said. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: At Trial of 'Real I.R.A.' Leader, Testimony on a Grisly Bombing
description: At a trial in Ireland's special antiterrorist court, an F.B.I. informant offered new details today about the guerrilla groups that have broken away from the Irish Republican Army and destabilized Northern Ireland's fragile peace effort with terrorist attacks here and in Britain.

title: China and India Edge a Bit Closer to a Border Accord
description: India emphasized today that Tibet is part of China and China agreed to begin trading with India's northeastern state of Sikkim, as the world's two most populous countries tiptoed toward a settlement of their politically explosive border disputes.

title: Still Absorbent After Most Towels Quit
description: Fresh from the package, the Chef Towl feels like an unyielding piece of felt. But wet it and wring it out, and you have a supple, miraculously absorbent lint-free wipe for tasks like cleaning up spills and drying glassware. It is made of viscose, a nonwoven material that can soak up enormous amounts of moisture, then be wrung out and reused. It is also machine washable. Pacific Dry Goods of Hayward, Calif., makes the brightly colored towels and other products including sponges, pool towels, baby bibs and cloths to take camping and traveling. The towels are $6.95 for a package of two (10 by 14 inches) at Gracious Home, Zabar's and Art of Cooking in Manhattan, and elsewhere at Sur La Table and Trader Joe's. They can also be ordered by calling (877) 367-8695 Monday through Friday, noon to 8 p.m. New York time.

title: NBC Said to Seek Alliance With Vivendi Units, Not a Purchase
description: NBC is intent on joining the bidding for the nonmusic entertainment assets of Vivendi Universal, but wants to form an alliance with Vivendi rather than buy it out, according to several people briefed on NBC's plans.

description: SOME restaurants where diners can try Scotland's new  and old  tastes are listed below. All dialing codes are 011-44.

title: Mayor Steps Back From English Immersion
description: Reversing his position on how children who do not speak English should be taught, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday announced plans to strengthen programs for 134,000 students who need to learn English that emphasize bilingual instruction and classes taught in native languages instead of requiring total immersion in English.

title: Freddie Mac Says It Understated Profits by Up to $6.9 Billion
description: Freddie Mac , the nation's second-largest financier of mortgages, understated its operating profits for the last three years by as much as $6.9 billion, in part because it wanted to report those gains in future years, the company said today.

title: In Death, Homeward Bound; Most Mexican Immigrants Are Sent Back for Burial
description: In a world of specialization, the R. G. Ortiz chain has won clients by catering to a particular travel niche: transporting the dead from anywhere in the New York metropolitan area to final resting places anywhere in Mexico.

title: GERMANY: TERROR SUSPECT ON TRIAL
description: A former member of Al Qaeda who turned informant after his arrest by the German police went on trial in Dsseldorf, Germany. The suspect, Shadi Abdullah, is charged with membership in a terrorist organization and passport forgery. Mr. Abdullah, 26, a Jordanian, is accused of belonging to the Tawhid group, a militant Palestinian movement led by a fellow Jordanian, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi. Investigators believe that Mr. Zarqawi still has a leadership role in Al Qaeda.

title: The Long Road Back for a Seton Hall Heroine
description: TIME has a way of healing some wounds and nurturing others. But there is no time for Dana Christmas, or distance, not yet. The agony of the fire at Seton Hall University three years ago, which left three students dead and 58 students and four rescue workers injured, is a present agony. The arrests of two men on June 12, charged with felony murder and reckless manslaughter for setting the dormitory blaze, do not alter for her a new and difficult way of being.

title: 25 Years Ago, Landmarks Law Stopped a Skyscraper
description: NEW YORK CITY'S landmarks law took effect in 1965 but gained its real power 25 years ago today.

title: China Has Quelled SARS, World Health Agency Says
description: The World Health Organization declared today that Beijing had effectively conquered SARS, signaling victory over the disease in the country where it originated and took the most lives.

title: Leon Uris, 78, Dies; Wrote Sweeping Novels Like 'Exodus'
description: Leon Uris, the high school dropout who became a brand-name novelist with his best-selling ''Exodus,'' the 1958 historical pageant about the founding of modern Israel, died on Saturday at his home on Shelter Island, N.Y. He was 78.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Teenager Charged With Murder
description: A 17-year-old boy was arrested yesterday in connection with a fight that left an 18-year-old fatally injured in front of his house, the police said. About 7 p.m. Tuesday, the two were in front of 3353 Fort Independence Avenue, near Jerome Park Reservoir, when they began arguing. The 17-year-old, Leon Wagner, had a gun, the police said. During the dispute, Murod Dunlap, 18, was shot in the back, and Mr. Wagner was shot in the abdomen and buttocks. Both were taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where Mr. Dunlap died. Mr. Wagner was released from the hospital yesterday and charged with murder and criminal possession of a weapon, Detective Thomas Kuchma said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hyundai Strike Planned
description: Workers at Hyundai Motor, Korea's dominant vehicle manufacturer, voted to strike today, seeking an 11 percent wage increase and a 40-hour workweek, down from the current 44 hours. The Korea Confederation of Trade Unions said the 39,000 workers at Hyundai plants would stop work for four hours, along with thousands of workers at smaller companies elsewhere. President Roh Moo Hyun, above, ordered crackdowns on illegal strikes as subway workers staged partial walkouts in Pusan and Inchon. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: 4 Transcripts Are Released In Case Tied to 9/11 Hijackers
description: The North Jersey man who admitted he sold fake identification cards to two Sept. 11 hijackers has been out of jail since March. The month before, Passaic County prosecutors agreed to a plea deal and five years' probation for the man, Mohamed el-Atriss, even though they had testified in closed hearings that he might have links to terrorists.

title: Gladys Heldman, 81, a Leader In Promoting Womens Tennis

Graduate of Xavier High School, Class of 1944, and University of Notre Dame, Class of 1950. US Navy Veteran of WW II, past President and 25 year member of the Board of Directors of Little Flower Children's Services. Fifty year member of the Knights of Columbus. Eucharistic Minister and active member of the parish of St. Joseph, Garden City. Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Fairchild Chapel at Franklin Ave. at 12th St., Garden City. title: Blair Offers More Troops for Iraq Despite Killing of 6 Britons
description: LONDON, June 25  After the killing of six British soldiers in disputed circumstances in southern Iraq, Prime Minister Tony Blair pledged today to maintain Britain's military presence in southern Iraq and offered to send reinforcements if commanders on the ground asked for them.

title: Violence in Iraq Spreads; 6 British Soldiers Are Killed
description: Iraqi gunmen killed six British soldiers today in southern Iraq as violence and unrest spread to areas of the country that had been largely quiet since the war ended almost two months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LECKEY, , THOMAS PHILIP
description: LECKEY -- Thomas Philip, suddenly on June 23, 2003, in Arlington, VA. He was born in Manhattan on May 15, 1934 to Tom and Molly Leckey of the Bronx. A graduate of Fordham Preparatory School, Columbia College and the University of Notre Dame, he maintained a life-long love of history. From 1958 to 1989 he was a financial manager for the Dept. of the Navy, mostly with the Office of Naval Research. He was a charter member of the Senior Executive Service. A committed and knowledgeable community activist, he served on the Arlington Planning Commission in the 1970's, as well as on the Fiscal Affairs Committee. Upon retirement, Tom began a distinguished second career as a volunteer. In 1989, he and a small group of friends founded the Arlington Partnership for Affordable Housing (APAH); Tom was the organization's first CEO. When APAH was well established, he turned his time and attention to the Arlington Street People's Assistance Network (ASPAN) where he served as treasurer until 2001. Tom's home and family were cherished by him, and he worked diligently to help others know that kind of comfort. In 1997, Arlington County recognized him as the first community hero, for his work on behalf of the vulnerable members of society. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 46 years, Dolores (Conklin) and his dear children Mary Kate Marcellus, her husband Ronald and their sons Cameron and Conor; Dr. Celia Leckey and her son Samuel X. Brase; Thomas J. Leckey and his wife Dr. Margaret Kabalin Leckey and their daughters Monica and Grace, Dr. Colum Leckey, his wife Donna Bible and their children Roman and Maria. Tom also leaves behind his brother John J. Leckey and his wife Myra and their children Shannon, Courtney and Sean; and his sister Mary Jane Cannon and her sons Donald, Terry and Alex. Countless friends, colleagues and Arlington citizens also mourn his passing. The wake will be held at Our Lady Queen of Peace Catholic Church in Arlington on Thursday, June 26, from 7-9PM. The Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated there at 11AM on Friday, June 27. Donations in his memory may be made to APAH or ASPAN, both located in Arlington, VA, or to the scholarship fund at Fordham Prep. Tom's infectious laugh, keen intellect, generous heart and Irish singing will be greatly missed. He often quoted St. John of the Cross: ''In the evening of life, only love matters.'' >>AD#

description: Canada's economy is growing more slowly than expected, but the government will balance its budget anyway, Finance Minister John Manley said today in a speech to a business group here.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Turnpike To Pay WorldCom
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority will pay $1.66 million to WorldCom, the telecommunications company that ran the state's troubled E-ZPass system until March of this year, said Joseph Orlando, a turnpike spokesman. The payment, announced this week, is for buying unused E-ZPass equipment, lane maintenance, shutting down customer service centers and other work WorldCom and its partner, J. P. Morgan Chase, performed after the state terminated their contract, Mr. Orlando said. ACS, a Dallas company, currently operates the electronic toll system. The state has a $402 million lawsuit against WorldCom pending in bankruptcy court stemming from various problems with the E-ZPass system, Mr. Orlando said. A telephone call to WorldCom seeking comment was not immediately returned yesterday. John Holl (NYT)

title: Child Welfare Changes Have Teeth This Time
description: The last thing Gov. James E. McGreevey needed this month, as he struggled with his second austerity budget, was the additional expense of $10 million to revamp New Jersey's distressed child welfare system.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Red Cross Sees Opposition Leader's Aide
description: Officials of the International Red Cross met with U Tin Oo, a top aide of the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, in a prison in northern Myanmar, the former Burma, a Red Cross representative told The Associated Press. He said Mr. Tin Oo appeared to be unhurt and in good health. Like Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, he has been held since an attack on their supporters on May 30 that killed and injured scores of people. The Red Cross has not been permitted to visit Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, who is reportedly being held at the largest prison in the capital city, Yangon. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: ACTION DELAYED ON PROPOSED MICHIGAN TAKEOVER LAW
description: A proposed law in Michigan that would strengthen Taubman Centers' defense in a $1.16 billion hostile takeover by a rival mall owner, the Simon Property Group, will not be acted on before September, the state's Senate majority leader, Ken Sikkema, said yesterday. The bill would amend a law governing acquisitions of publicly held Michigan corporations by allowing shareholders to form voting blocs to oppose hostile takeovers. The bill, which was passed by the House of Representatives, would make moot a ruling by a federal judge that blocked the founding family of Taubman Centers from voting its 33.6 percent stake in the company against the offer by Simon Property. Any sale requires two-thirds voter approval.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday in the special Women's Health section about reasons for exercising misplaced the quotation marks in citing an advertisement for the New York Sports Club. The ad read: ''Exercise reduces the risk of cancer. Not to mention the risk of saggy butt.'' (Both sentences were part of the quotation, not just the first.)

title: British Regulator Gives Edge To Small Bidder for Safeway
description: British regulators weighed in on the battle for Safeway today, indicating in a letter to bidders that a combination with William Morrison Supermarkets stood the best chance of winning approval.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Iraqis' desperate hunt for smalldenomination dinar bills misstated the value of the currency. A 10,000-dinar note is worth about $7.50, not $75.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Climate Rises
description: The German business climate is brightening, showing unexpectedly strong growth in June's Ifo index after pessimistic assessments over the past three months. The Ifo Institute's survey said the overall index rose to 88.8 from 87.6 the previous month, returning to its level in February. Both the current assessment and expectations contributed to the increase. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: MOODY'S LOWERS CREDIT RATING OF SONY BY ONE NOTCH
description: Moody's Investors Service cut the credit rating of the Sony Corporation for the first time in 17 1/2 years, citing concerns about cash flow and deteriorating earnings at the company's electronics business. Moody's cut Sony's long-term credit rating one level, to A1 from Aa3. The outlook for the rating, which is the fifth-highest of Moody's 10 investment-grade levels, is ''negative,'' meaning Moody's is more inclined to lower it. The cut may raise Sony's borrowing costs just as it pours money into semiconductor development.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Parolee Sentenced In Assault
description: A parolee pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court yesterday to sexual abuse and assault and was sentenced to 32 years to life in prison. The man, Stephan Peppaceno, 49, of Flanders, N.Y., was charged with raping and stabbing a woman last June, after meeting her in a Greenwich Village bar. Investigators said Mr. Peppaceno, who has a long criminal record, had told the woman he was a police officer on Long Island and a Vietnam veteran. The woman was seriously injured but survived. He was arrested last November, just hours after he was featured on the television program ''American's Most Wanted.'' A man in a Queens bar recognized Mr. Peppaceno. Susan Saulny (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: SCHLUMBERGER TO SELL SEMICONDUCTOR-TESTING UNIT
description: Schlumberger Ltd., an oil field services company that is shedding assets to cut debt, agreed to sell its NPTest semiconductor-testing unit to a group led by Francisco Partners and Shah Management for $220 million in cash. Schlumberger said the sale would reduce its second-quarter profit by $12 million. The buyers may pay an additional, undisclosed sum if they sell the unit or raise money through an initial public offering of NPTest shares. Schlumberger, based in New York and Paris, withdrew an initial public offering for NPTest. That offering, which was delayed for more than a year, was expected to raise as much as $575 million, according to a regulatory filing.

title: Goodyear Found Liable
description: A jury in Denver has found the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company liable for $4 million for defective rubber hoses used in home heating systems, the third such verdict against the company in the last 18 months. The jury's award arose from failures of Goodyear's Entran II hoses, a product the company has discontinued. Homeowners in 19 states have filed other Entran II-related suits against the company, which is based in Akron, Ohio, seeking more than $200 million in damages, lawyers said. The jury ruled Thursday in favor of 34 homeowners.

title: A Coalition of the Women Gives Life the Raspberries
description: Confident self-mockery seems to be the dominant tone in the dozens of theatrical events in the Fuse festival, a joint venture of Here and Dixon Place, which these two downtown theaters bill as a ''celebration of queer culture.''

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MAINE: EXPANSION OF SMOKING BAN Maine has banned smoking in bars, lounges, taverns and pool halls, becoming the fifth state to enact such a law. Smoking is already prohibited in restaurants throughout the state. Gov. John E. Baldacci called the legislation "good for business" and said it would protect nonsmokers  75 percent of the state's population, he said  from secondhand smoke. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Athleticism With Chamber Music
description: The Pilobolus Dance Theater opened a season at the Joyce Theater on Monday night with a presentation that was both a chamber-music concert and a dance program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTMAN, , EDWIN J.
description: ALTMAN--Edwin J. On June 24, 2003 at age 90. Beloved husband of Glen, cherished father of Pat Falkenberg, Ginny Aaron and Tracy Warner. Dear father-in-law of Edward Falkenberg, Roger Aaron and Greg Warner. Loving grandfather of Chris, Kai and Merrill Falkenberg, Peter and Todd Aaron, Haley and Amanda Warner and greatgrandfather of Talia. He was a man of sharp mind with a commanding grasp of history and quick sense of humor. A keen business sense, always tempered by his fairness and integrity, earned him the admiration and affection of colleagues in the jewelry business for over 65 years, and the love of those with whom he worked closely. A raconteur who truly enjoyed people, he personified the glamour of New York throughout his life. His charm, his innate kindness, his smile, his unconditional love will be sorely missed and long remembered. Services on Friday, June 27, at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Arugula Italian Style: Teeth at the Edge, and a Little More Bite
description: The arugula that is common in the United States, with oval, dark-green leaves, is not typical in markets and restaurants in Italy. There, the arugula is more likely to have narrow, toothed, dandelion-style leaves and a more peppery flavor. It is often called wild arugula, and some growers here are now cultivating it from Italian seed. It not only lends more flavor to a salad, but also has a more resilient texture, meaning that it will not wilt so readily once dressed with a vinaigrette or tossed in a pasta dish. Mountain Sweet Berry Farms, which is at the Union Square Greenmarket on Wednesdays and Saturdays, has it for $8 a pound. At Agata & Valentina it is available on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays at $2.99 for four ounces.

description: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON will always have Wimbledon but only if she chooses to dwell on the way she blasted into the semifinals at age 18, maybe even thinking her career was always going to be that way.

Shares of Catapult dropped $2.88, or 22 percent, to $10.05. Catapult expects $9.6 million to $10.2 million in revenue this quarter. It had forecast $12 million. Sales in the United States and Europe were postponed, Mark Sue, an analyst at CE Unterberg Towbin, said in an interview.

Martinez, 36, of Long Island, who worked for L & L Painting, was the first worker to die at the site of the World Trade Center since September 11, 2001, said the spokesman, Pasquale DiFulco. Mr. Martinez was found early Tuesday morning, shortly after midnight, he said. The Port Authority police and the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration are investigating the death.

description: GERMANY: TERROR SUSPECT ON TRIAL A former member of Al Qaeda who turned informant after his arrest by the German police went on trial in Dusseldorf, Germany. The suspect, Shadi Abdullah, is charged with membership in a terrorist organization and passport forgery. Mr. Abdullah, 26, a Jordanian, is accused of belonging to the Tawhid group, a militant Palestinian movement led by a fellow Jordanian, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi. Investigators believe that Mr. Zarqawi still has a leadership role in Al Qaeda.

title: Affirmative Action: The Ruling and the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Wall at Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Cuts Rates by Quarter Point to Lowest Level in 45 Years
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Trying to deal a deathblow to the long economic downturn, the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates by one quarter of a percentage point this afternoon, taking them to their lowest level since 1958.

title: Aux Lyonnais Recalled
description: To the Editor:

title: The Road to Oceania
description: Walking along Henrietta Street recently, by London's Covent Garden, looking for a restaurant, I found myself thinking of George Orwell. Victor Gollancz Ltd., publisher of Orwell's early work, had its offices there in 1984, when the company published my first novel, a novel of an imagined future.

title: The Last Hard Case: Bleak, Stubborn Belfast
description: In other parts of Europe, workmen on ladders hammering nails into roof beams at this time of year are doing springtime house repairs after harsh winter months.

title: Fed Cuts Rates by Quarter Point to Lowest Level in 45 Years
description: WASHINGTON -- The Federal Reserve cut a key short-term interest rate Wednesday by a one-quarter percentage point to its lowest level in 45 years. The aim is to energize consumer spending and business investment and help the economy snap out of a funk.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Worker Dies
description: A painter at ground zero died while working at the site, and the cause of death is unclear, a Port Authority official said. The painter, Hugo V. Martinez, 36, of Long Island, who worked for L & L Painting, was the first worker to die at the site of the World Trade Center since September 11, 2001, said the spokesman, Pasquale DiFulco. Mr. Martinez was found early Tuesday morning, shortly after midnight, he said. The Port Authority police and the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration are investigating the death. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Group Vows to Monitor Academia's Responses
description: The conservative public interest law firm that challenged affirmative action at the University of Michigan is vowing to monitor academia's responses to Monday's Supreme Court rulings. The group, the Center for Individual Rights, also promises further lawsuits against institutions that overstep the rulings' limits on considering race in university admissions.

title: More Than Oil in Downtown L.A.
description: A number of postwar downtown office buildings are going residential.

title: Personal Shopper: Don't Hide The Sun
description: Shades add color and glow to the home.

title: Action? Affirmative!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Big East Trawling for 2 Members
description: There is no doubt the Atlantic Coast Conference has wounded the Big East Conference by inviting two of its members, Miami and Virginia Tech, to jump to the A.C.C.

title: Recording Industry to Sue Internet Music Swappers
description: The struggling recording industry intensified its efforts to combat online piracy yesterday, announcing that it planned to sue individual computer users who share substantial amounts of music online.

title: A Winery Profits as India Adapts to New Tastes
description: Educated in Silicon Valley but seduced by Sonoma Valley, Rajeev Samant decided to come home to these dry hills northeast of Bombay to try making wine in India, a nation where annual wine consumption works out to one teaspoon per person.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: HOSPITALS SET DISASTER PLAN One of New York City's major hospital chains has reached a $380 million agreement with I.B.M. that includes the creation of a disaster operations center in Rochester, where duplicate records will be kept and the hospitals' data centers can relocate in an emergency. Mount Sinai NYU Health is the latest in a long string of businesses to invest in such remote backup data centers — in this case, for Mount Sinai Hospital, NYU Medical Center and NYU Downtown Hospital. The deal, to be announced today, was prompted in part by the terror attack of Sept. 11, when NYU Medical Center had to evacuate its main data center in Lower Manhattan. The I.B.M. pact also includes several other research and information management projects.   Richard Pérez-Peña (NYT)

title: CITY BUDGET DEAL CLOSES BIG DEFICIT WITHOUT BIG CUTS
description: After months of warnings of dire cuts to city services, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the New York City Council agreed on a budget last night that was remarkable not for how many services were cut, but for how few.

title: $1 Billion Settlement in I.P.O. Price-Fixing Case
description: About 300 companies that sold new shares to the public during the late 1990's agreed today to pay $1 billion to settle an investor lawsuit contending that the stock offerings' prices were artificially inflated.

title: For Norah Jones, Nights Are Made for Sentiment and Slow Dancing
description: Halfway through Norah Jones's concert on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, her five-member band left her alone onstage. She sat at the grand piano and played Duke Ellington's ''Melancholia,'' singing her own lyrics about not missing a lover who had checked out. ''Melancholia'' is one of Ellington's slow, exotic songs with chord changes that make it too weird for standard repertory. And Ms. Jones's voice -- bright, precise and drawling -- did very well by it.

title: Shares Decline as Fed Eases Rate Less Than Anticipated
description: Stocks dropped yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by less than some economists had expected. General Electric and Microsoft led the decline.

title: A Budget Success, but Bloomberg Gets No Respect
description: Yesterday should have been Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's victory lap. He shook hands with the City Council on a budget deal that closed a $6.4 billion gap, yet left libraries open, health clinics running and trash picked up as usual.

title: People
description: * Jack Griffin was named president of the Meredith Magazine Group, New York, a Meredith Corporation division that oversees publications like American Baby, Better Homes and Gardens and Ladies' Home Journal. He will succeed Jerry Kaplan, who will retire at the end of the year. Mr. Griffin had been president at Parade Publications, New York, part of Advance Publications, and publisher of its flagship, Parade, the Sunday newspaper magazine.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Friday about rising demand for auto parts made in India misattributed a forecast for exports. The figure -- $25 billion in exported auto parts by 2023 -- came from Arvind Kapur, a member of the executive committee of the Automotive Component Manufacturers Association of India, not from the association itself.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the decision to set aside the results of the New York State Regents Math A exam misstated the number of questions on the test. It was 35, not 85.

title: An Ultimate Sad Sack, Hopelessly Indefatigable
description: A TRAGIC HONESTY

title: There's More than Oil in Downtown Los Angeles
description: First the 1952 Superior Oil building in Los Angeles was turned into the trendy Standard Downtown hotel. Now other postwar downtown office buildings are going residential, thanks to an adaptive-reuse ordinance passed in 1999. The Pegasus Apartments, inset top left, opened last week in the former Mobil Oil Corporation building of 1949, by Welton Becket (designer of the Capitol Records building), opposite the Standard. The Kor Realty Group, developer of the Avalon, Maison 140 and Viceroy hotels, is a developer of the Pegasus, which retains features like the vertical aluminum fins on the building and nickel-plated doorknobs. The interior designer of the hotels, Kelly Wearstler, did the restrained Pegasus interiors, above in a model apartment. Rents range from $1,100 a month to $6,500 for a penthouse.

title: Moody's Cuts Sony Rating, Citing Electronics Outlook
description: The Sony Corporation has long prided itself on its commanding position atop the high end of the consumer electronics market. But there are signs that it may be slipping from that perch.

title: On Draft Day, the Nets Await Kidd's Decision
description: Rod Thorn, the Nets' president, will accept phone calls from league executives on draft day as usual, but one call will draw more interest than any young shooter, backup point guard or big man the Nets are coveting at No. 22 in tonight's draft.

title: Worth a (bike) trip, 100 years later
description: MONTGERON, France:  The steak at the Reveil Matin in the Paris suburb of Montgeron is tender, the house wine thin but acceptable, the service no worse than the usual inattentive, the bill a bit less than it would be in a more chic and higher-rent restaurant in the capital.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a Republican bill to revise Head Start referred incompletely to the views of Amy Wilkins, executive director of the Trust for Early Education. She is critical of the bill's application process for states that want to take over their Head Start programs, arguing that it should include measurable goals and annual monitoring. But she supports the bill's evaluation process for such programs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Sir Denis Thatcher, Gleeful 2nd Fiddle to British Leader, Dies
description: LONDON, June 26 — Sir Denis Thatcher, steadfast husband of former prime minister Margaret Thatcher and a man who embraced his role as second fiddle with aplomb and humor, died today in a London hospital. He was 88.

title: A Spitfire and an Antagonist Well Matched in Fairyland
description: American Ballet Theater staged frolics in forests in two of the works it presented on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Embassy Reopens
description: The American Embassy in Nairobi reopened after closing for several days in response to fears of a terrorist attack. The embassy, which replaced one destroyed by Al Qaeda bombers in 1998, is designed to withstand attack. Kenyan soldiers stood guard as diplomats returned to work. Meanwhile, the presidents of Kenya and Tanzania criticized the American and British governments for issuing warnings against travel to east Africa, likening the advisories to economic sanctions. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Stamps.com Files Breach Of Contract Suit Against eBay
description: Stamps.com, which sells postage stamps over the Internet, has sued eBay and its PayPal electronic payment service, saying they breached a 2002 licensing agreement that would have permitted PayPal customers to use their accounts to buy stamps. The lawsuit was filed yesterday in a state court in Los Angeles, Stamps.com said. Stamps.com accused PayPal of not starting within a reasonable time a service that would have permitted PayPal customers to buy and print electronic postage onto envelopes, labels and documents. Stamps.com, which has about 300,000 customers, had $1.5 million in costs related to the venture, its chief executive, Kenneth McBride, said in an interview. Shares of Stamps.com declined 33 cents, or 6.3 percent, to $4.92.

description: ''Do you think anybody in Washington has any idea what people on a limited

title: ABC Sports Names Executive Producer
description: Mike Pearl was named the senior vice president and executive producer of ABC Sports, leaving Turner Sports, where he held the same position. Pearl, a 15-time Emmy award winner, previously worked at ABC Sports in the 1980's, mostly under Roone Arledge. ''With the challenges offered to me, this was a chance to go back to where I worked during the golden age of television sports,'' Pearl said.

title: Panel Staff to Urge Big Change In How Elections Are Handled
description: Staff members of a commission looking at the future of elections in New York City will recommend dramatic changes, including a move to nonparty elections and a fast timetable that will make the changes effective either in time for the 2005 elections or, at the latest, four years later.

Widow of Joseph Kresevich and Joseph Zambetti. Loving mother of Felix L. Zambetti. Dear grandmother of Audrey Zinman, the late Marc Zambetti, Jonathan Zambetti and Claudia Fouty. title: Labor Escapes Givebacks, But Future Battles Loom
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reached a deal yesterday to close this year's budget gap without getting the concessions he wanted from the municipal unions, but the mayor and the unions are sure to clash again in the future as the city faces ballooning deficits.

title: Mosquito Time
description: Humans -- especially metropolitan humans --like to think of themselves as living at the top of the food chain. But this is the season when it becomes clear that we're really at the top of the menu. It's mosquito time again. And while the food available to mosquitoes -- us -- hasn't expanded much in the past year, their habitat certainly has, thanks to a June of record rainfall. Every outdoor receptacle, natural or unnatural, that could possibly contain water now actually does. Anything that holds water for the few days needed to incubate mosquito eggs is doing so. The Northeast is a giant mosquito nursery. All those billions and billions of larvae, hanging head down in still water, are just beginning to metamorphose into pupae and adults. We, in turn, are just beginning to itch.

title: The Un-Doom Boom
description: NOT so long ago Pedro A. Arellano, 20, wouldn't have thought much about turning to his cellphone to indulge his penchant for video games. He had been raised on a rich diet of visually explosive games for sophisticated consoles by Sega and Nintendo. He had also found himself playing even more interactive games that required joysticks, mice and keyboards plugged into hulking desktop computers.

title: Strength in Trading Propels Goldman to 23% Profit Rise
description: The Goldman Sachs Group reported a 23 percent increase in its second-quarter earnings yesterday, propelled by another robust period of trading profit, which set it apart from other big Wall Street firms that experienced reversals of growth.

title: Trachsel And Reyes Give Mets A Victory
description: The Florida Marlins thought it would be a good idea to intentionally walk Tsuyoshi Shinjo, batting .179, to load the bases in the sixth inning last night and pitch to Jos Reyes, who was batting all of .192.

title: Showtime Networks Names New Head of Entertainment
description: Showtime Networks, long in the creative shadow of its main premium-cable rival, HBO, announced yesterday that it had hired a veteran television executive, Robert Greenblatt, to be its head of entertainment.

title: Celebrating Modernism, Promoting Conservation
description: Jonas Hauptman, a designer who teaches at the Southern California Institute of Architecture, said he was ''trying to develop socially and environmentally responsible products that celebrate a Modernist design style.'' His Reseat lounge chair, below, is made of molded reconstituted Aspen tree flakes, on a stainless-steel tube frame. (Another version will use recycled palm fronds.) Reseat is $455 (matching ottoman, $200) at Yolk, at 1626 Silverlake Boulevard, Los Angeles; www.jonashauptman.com or (323) 660-4315.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Abortion Boat Fined
description: The authorities in the Baltic port of Wladyslawowo levied a $3,000 fine on a visiting Dutch ship carrying a mobile abortion clinic. The harbor master said the boat had failed to obey his orders to tie up away from antiabortion demonstrators who pelted the boat with rocks and paint on Sunday. The boat, organized by the Dutch abortion rights group Women on Waves, has stirred a controversy since it came to bring birth control and pregnancy counseling to the Roman Catholic country, where abortion is outlawed. Women on Waves has said that it will take women seeking abortions into international waters and administer abortion-inducing drugs. On Monday, customs officials sealed the boat's supply of pills. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Pet Therapy Sets Landlords Howling
description: IAN NETUPSKY, a 36-year-old bond salesman, recently drove up to his home in Huntington Station, N.Y., to find a knot of curious neighbors standing outside. Up went Mr. Netupsky's anxiety level -- and down went his black Labrador, Quinn, coaxed quickly into lying low to avoid detection.

title: Very Richest's Share of Income Grew Even Bigger, Data Show
description: The 400 wealthiest taxpayers accounted for more than 1 percent of all the income in the United States in the year 2000, more than double their share just eight years earlier, according to new data from the Internal Revenue Service. But their tax burden plummeted over the period.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AGARD, , DAVID S.
description: AGARD--David S. June 24, 2003. Beloved husband of Edith; father of three loving daughters and five grandchildren, Avid reader of the Times for 45 years. >>AD#

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JUPITERMEDIA CORP., Darien, Conn., a provider of research to the information technology and Internet industries, said it would buy ArtToday, a supplier of online images, from International Microcomputer Software Inc. for $13.9 million in cash and stock.

title: Face Recognition and Me
description: Two weeks ago, the old phrase, "David Pogue is on vacation" appeared beneath the "State of the Art" column in the Circuits section of The Times. I was 4,000 miles away -- on a cruise ship in the middle of the Pacific Ocean.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Washington Township: Crash Snarls Traffic
description: An accident involving a tractor-trailer and seven cars caused traffic delays on the New Jersey Turnpike for much of yesterday, a turnpike spokesman said. No one was seriously injured in the accident, but traffic was backed up for 18 miles southbound and 7 miles northbound. The accident happened shortly after 10 a.m. in the southbound lanes near interchange 7A when a convertible lost control, struck another car and was hit by the tractor-trailer, which fell on its side and blocked two lanes, said the spokesman, Joseph Orlando. All lanes were reopened at 2 p.m. but delays affected evening traffic. John Holl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KINNEY, , FREDERICK G. KRINSKY ''FREDDIE,''
description: KINNEY--Frederick G. Krinsky ''Freddie,'' 77, of Orlando, Florida, and formerly of Manhattan, New York, died June 22, 2003. He is survived by his wife, two daughters, and one sister. Online guestbook @ www.andersonmcqueen.com St. Petersburg, FL. >>AD#

title: A Riotous Floral Tribute, In Seat Cushions
description: Flowers were a favorite of the late Lillian Disney, the widow of Walt Disney. Her gift of $50 million started the fund to build the Walt Disney Concert Hall in downtown Los Angeles and so Frank Gehry, the architect who designed the hall, has honored her memory with a bold graphic pattern named Lillian for the upholstered chairs, above, and the carpet throughout the building. Three vivid color palettes -- magenta, orange and green -- were assigned randomly by computer to the seating to create the effect of a wild garden. The seating fabric was made by Kvadrat by Maharam; the carpet was made by Brintons U.S. Axminster. The concert hall is scheduled to open in October. Another homage to Lillian Disney can be found outside, in Mr. Gehry's fountain, built in the shape of a rose.

title: Conflict Over New Jersey's Budget Moves to the Airwaves
description: Listen to enough drive-time radio in New Jersey these days, and you might assume that elected officials had decided to work out the state's fiscal problems by holding a schoolyard taunting match.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: DuPont Photomasks Names New Chairman
description: DuPont Photomasks, which makes materials used to produce semiconductors, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Peter S. Kirlin, had resigned and that Marshall C. Turner had been named to succeed him. The moves are effective immediately. Mr. Turner, 61, was DuPont Photomasks' interim chairman and chief executive from June 1999 through May 2000, when Mr. Kirlin, 42, assumed those positions. The company declined to elaborate on the reasons for Mr. Kirlin's departure.

title: Al Qaeda Remains a Global Threat, U.N. Report Says
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 26  Despite "marked successes" in the fight against the Al Qaeda network, a new generation of Al Qaeda-trained terrorists as well as veterans of the Islamic extremist group continue to threaten the global community, according to a report released here today by a United Nations monitoring group.

title: Blair Says Reinforcements May Go to Iraq
description: After the killing of six British soldiers in disputed circumstances in southern Iraq, Prime Minister Tony Blair pledged today to maintain Britain's military presence there and offered to send reinforcements if needed.

title: MetroStars Acquire Angolan Player
description: Edgar Bartolomeu, a left-footed midfielder/defender, was acquired by the MetroStars yesterday and will join them for training today at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. He will be available for Saturday's match against Chicago in Naperville, Ill.

title: Trenton Court Refuses to Ease Requirements for Poor Schools
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has turned down the state's request to relax curriculum requirements that it ordered five years ago for the poorest school districts, leaving many school administrators scrambling to comply over the summer.

title: Federal Regulators Uphold California Energy Contracts
description: Federal energy regulators today rejected a request by California to invalidate more than $12 billion in energy contracts signed at the height of the state's electricity crisis, even though they have determined that widespread manipulation helped drive prices higher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUNSTADTER, , JOHN W.
description: KUNSTADTER--John W., on June 18, 2003 at age 75, philanthropist, physicist and international banker, died peacefully at home. Beloved husband of Geraldine Kunstadter. Loving father of John Jr., Lisa and Chris Kunstadter and Elizabeth von Habsburg. Devoted grandfather of eight. Dear brother of Peter Kunstadter. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing, Brooklyn, NY 11201. >>AD#

title: City Is Ready To Recycle Plastic Again
description: After scaling back its recycling program in hard economic times, New York City is poised to restore the curbside recycling of glass and plastic.

title: U.S. Likely to Charge 2 Ex-Boeing Workers
description: Two former Boeing workers will be charged with illegally obtaining Lockheed Martin documents to help their company win a government contract for launching military satellites, the United States attorney's office in Los Angeles said yesterday.

title: Far Cry From Days of 'Firemen': Woman Becomes Battalion Chief
description: Rochelle T. Jones was working as a secretary at a Manhattan bank when she first learned that the New York Fire Department was accepting job applications from women. Back then, firefighters were called firemen, and many were vocal about their desire to keep it that way.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEW BRUNSWICK: TURNPIKE TO PAY WORLDCOM The New Jersey Turnpike Authority will pay $1.66 million to WorldCom, the telecommunications company that ran the state's troubled E-ZPass system until March of this year, said Joseph Orlando, a turnpike spokesman. The payment, announced this week, is for buying unused E-ZPass equipment, lane maintenance, shutting down customer service centers and other work WorldCom and its partner, J. P. Morgan Chase , performed after the state terminated their contract, Mr. Orlando said. ACS, a Dallas company, currently operates the electronic toll system. The state has a $402 million lawsuit against WorldCom pending in bankruptcy court stemming from various problems with the E-ZPass system, Mr. Orlando said. A telephone call to WorldCom seeking comment was not immediately returned yesterday.   John Holl (NYT)

title: Animated Icons Add Spice to IM Conversations
description: Forget about abbreviations and punctuation marks. For instant-messaging devotees, the tools for adding a smile or a wink will soon turn emoticons into animation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Working Vacation
description: Pope John Paul II plans to pass the summer at Castelgandolfo, his retreat outside Rome, working on a book about his life as a bishop, the Vatican said. The 83-year-old pope, who published a collection of poems this year, used to hike around the northern mountains in summer but has lost much of his mobility to ailments. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: No Link Found Between Cancer And Power Lines on Long Island
description: A study of women on Long Island has found no link between breast cancer and living near high-voltage power lines, extending a long trail of research that has failed to connect breast cancer on the island to an environmental cause.

title: Dear Republican Donor
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: SUMMIT MEETING CHARGES Park Jie Won and Lim Dong Won, top aides to the former president, Kim Dae Jung, left, who spearheaded a drive for reconciliation with North Korea, were indicted on charges of transferring $100 million to North Korea as a payoff for its agreeing to a 2000 summit meeting between the president and Kim Jong Il, the leader of North Korea. Chung Mong Hun, an heir to the Hyundai fortune, was also indicted, for having passed on the money. Eight people now face trial in the case, which has raised doubts about Kim Dae Jung's "sunshine" policy toward North Korea. He received the Nobel Peace Prize four months after the meeting. But the prosecutor in effect cleared him of direct complicity, citing a lack of evidence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYERS, , DIANE
description: MEYERS--Diane. The Board of Governors of Middle Bay Country Club of Oceanside, NY, on behalf of its membership, wishes to express its sympathy and condolences to the family of its esteemed member, Diane Meyers. She will be sorely missed. >>AD#

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Indiana: Universities To Study Brain Drain
description: The Lilly Endowment will give $40 million to the state's public and private universities to find ways to keep educated residents in the state. Lilly, based in Indianapolis, will distribute the money at year's end after hearing proposals in October. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Child Falls From Window
description: A 4-year-old boy died yesterday evening after falling out of a ninth-floor window in Cypress Hills, the police said. Around 6:45 p.m., the boy, whose name was not released, was in his room on Highland Boulevard and apparently leaned on the screen, which gave way and remained dangling, Detective Thomas Kuchma said. There was no window guard in place, the police said. A woman who was not the boy's mother was in the home at the time, with the boy and a 1-year-old child, Detective Kuchma said. The police said the incident did not appear suspicious at this time, but was under investigation. ''It looks like a tragic accident,'' the detective said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Casino Deal
description: A bingo and casino operator, the Gala Group of London, is teaming up with Harrah's Entertainment to build eight casinos in Britain. Each of the gaming companies will invest $500 million in the 50-50 partnership. Sites for the casinos and time frame for development have not yet been decided.

title: On a Slim Solitary Gadget, Photos, Music and Movies
description: To tote your portfolio of digital entertainment, including full-length movies, MP3 music and digital photos, Archos has devised a single gadget: the AV320 Cinema to Go.
