title: Court Endorses New Approach to Redistricting
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The Supreme Court endorsed a new approach to racial redistricting today by holding that in drawing new legislative boundaries, states can consider overall minority influence in the political process, not just the percentage of minority voters in a given district.

title: Bruno Rejects Silver's Call For Conference Committees
description: Declaring this year's legislative session ''a work unfinished,'' the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, called on the Senate's Republican majority today to form conference committees to work out differences on a dozen important pieces of legislation that had failed to pass both houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AGOVINO, , VERA
description: AGOVINO--Vera. The Board of Directors, staff, participants and members of AHRC NYC convey their condolences to the family of Vera Agovino on the occasion of her passing. Her grace, good will, and commitment will always be remembered and appreciated by the Association. Our deepest concerns and prayers go out to her husband, Al Agovino, former President of AHRC NYC, and to her children Toni, Michael, Alphonse Jr., Christopher and Mark. Our thoughts and prayers are with you. Genevieve O'Neil, President Michael Goldfarb, Executive Director >>AD#

title: Lehman Said to Be Negotiating To Acquire Neuberger Berman
description: Lehman Brothers is negotiating to buy Neuberger Berman, a money-management firm based in Manhattan, executives close to the deal said yesterday. The price under discussion is more than $3 billion in cash and stock, the executives said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTMAN, , EDWIN J.
description: ALTMAN--Edwin J. On June 24, 2003 at age 90. Beloved husband of Glen, cherished father of Pat Falkenberg, Ginny Aaron and Tracy Warner. Dear father-in-law of Edward Falkenberg, Roger Aaron and Greg Warner. Loving grandfather of Chris, Kai and Merrill Falkenberg, Peter and Todd Aaron, Haley and Amanda Warner and greatgrandfather of Talia. He was a man of sharp mind with a commanding grasp of history and quick sense of humor. A keen business sense, always tempered by his fairness and integrity, earned him the admiration and affection of colleagues in the jewelry business for over 65 years, and the love of those with whom he worked closely. A raconteur who truly enjoyed people, he personified the glamour of New York throughout his life. His charm, his innate kindness, his smile, his unconditional love will be sorely missed and long remembered. Services on Friday, June 27, at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Holder Raises Cordiant Stake To Level Needed to Block Deal
description: Active Value, the largest shareholder in the Cordiant Communications Group, the British advertising agency company, said today that it had increased its stake. The purchase gives it enough shares to block a buyout of the company by the WPP Group.

title: Top Bush Aide Calls On Europe to Ban All Parts
description: LONDON, June 26  Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, said today that the political wing of the militant Palestinian group Hamas should be added to the European Union's list of terrorist organizations. She called the group the single biggest threat to peace between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Paris Journal; Who's Humming at Opera? Believe It or Not, Bees
description: It is balmy in Paris and the birds and the bees are busy. All around the Palais Garnier, the baroque Second Empire opera house in the center of town, couples are engrossed in the city's most famous pastime: falling in love.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: CASINO DEAL A bingo and casino operator, the Gala Group of London, is teaming up with Harrah's Entertainment to build eight casinos in Britain. Each of the gaming companies will invest $500 million in the 50-50 partnership. Sites for the casinos and time frame for development have not yet been decided.

title: A Wade on The Wild Side
description: ''IT'S 'The Matrix,' only it isn't black,'' said a woman in glasses with plastic zebra frames, sipping a cocktail Tuesday evening at a party for Light-Wing, the new outdoor installation at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens. At sunset, colored spotlights went on and the metal mesh canopy began to shine like a flame-colored cloud.

title: Japan Halts Aid to Burmese Over Democracy Leader's Detention
description: Japan took a new hard line today against Myanmar, suspending all economic assistance and increasing international pressure over the continued detention of the leader of the democratic opposition, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREED, , SARA ANN (WEISSMAN)
description: FREED--Sara Ann (Weissman). On June 25, 2003. Beloved wife of Ira. Dear stepmom of Michael. Survived by four loving brothers and one sister and cherished by countless friends, colleagues and writers. She will be remembered at a memorial service on September 17, 2003 at a location to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to the Caring Community, 20 Washington Square North, New York, New York 10011. >>AD#

title: Bush, Skeptical of Report of Hamas Cease-Fire, Asks Europe to Sever Ties
description: President Bush pressed European leaders today to cut off all support to the Palestinian militant group Hamas, and dismissed news of a possible cease-fire agreement involving Hamas and other militants as irrelevant to Middle East peace.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: RATES UNCHANGED The Bank of Japan left its monetary policy unchanged after a one-day meeting as rising stock prices and stronger-than-anticipated first-quarter growth eased pressure on the bank. The central bank will continue to leave as much as a 30-trillion-yen surplus ($254 billion) in the money markets for banks to borrow, and buy 1.2 trillion yen in government bonds every month from the market. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPPINCOTT, , JOAN B.
description: LIPPINCOTT--Joan B., on June 20, 2003, of cancer at age 70. Widow of David, mother of Christopher, and grandmother of David S. Sister of Carol Ely and Betty Rank. Mrs. Lippincott was a graduate of Smith College ('51) and the Masters School ('47). She had been a member of the New York Junior League, the Cosmopolitan Club, the City Gardens Club, and the Colonial Dames. She will be deeply missed by all those whose lives she touched. A memorial service will be held at the St. James Church, Madison Ave. at 71st St., Wednesday, July 2nd at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the St. James Church, 865 Maidson Ave., NY NY 10021 or the American Cancer Society. >>AD#

title: Luckily the Cable Cars Still Run; A Book Recalls San Francisco
description: It has been more than 40 years since Miroslav Sasek created ''This Is San Francisco,'' the classic illustrated city guide for children.

title: Knicks Are Using Homecourt Advantage
description: The most promising prospects in tonight's N.B.A. draft converged in Manhattan yesterday and were whisked around the city for a series of appearances and interviews. A few had more work to do.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lehman Is in Talks to Buy Money Management Firm

title: Measure Calls for Wider Access to Federally Financed Research
description: A group challenging the power of established scientific journals says legislation will be introduced to make the results of all federally financed research available to the public.

title: Briefly Noted
description: MALAWI: U.S. FLIES OUT 5 QAEDA SUSPECTS Five men accused of funneling money to Al Qaeda were taken out of Malawi by the American authorities, even though a judge had barred their deportation from the southern African country, officials said. The men were arrested Sunday night in an operation involving the C.I.A. and Malawi's National Intelligence Bureau. The Malawian authorities handed over the men, who were identified as being from Sudan, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Kenya, to American officials Monday night, said Fahad Assani, Malawi's director of public prosecutions. The men were immediately flown to nearby Botswana on a chartered Air Malawi flight, Malawian intelligence officials said on condition of anonymity. Mr. Assani said he did not know the men's whereabouts. Robin Diallo, spokeswoman for the American Embassy in Malawi, refused to comment, and American Embassy officials in Botswana did not return a phone call. Officials in Malawi said the men were on the C.I.A.'s "watch list" since the twin 1998 bombings at the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. The American authorities blame Al Qaeda for the attacks, which killed 231 people, including 12 Americans. Malawi does not have an extradition treaty with the United States.

title: Freddie Mac Understated Pretax Profit
description: Freddie Mac, the second-largest financier of mortgages, understated its pretax profits for the last three years by as much as $6.9 billion, in part because it wanted to report those gains in future years, the company said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN: AMTRAK RIDERSHIP UP Ridership on Amtrak's Springfield line is up 38 percent since the introduction of decreased fares and the addition of more trains, the railroad reported yesterday. Fares dropped in April by an average of 40 percent and five trains were added to the line, which runs from New Haven to Springfield, Mass. Ridership on the line increased to an average of 7,962 in the seven weeks after the fare reduction, from an average of 5,759 in the six weeks before, according to the railroad.   (AP)

title: British Scientists Suggest a Pill for What Ails the Heart
description: Two British scientists have proposed a radical strategy for preventing cardiovascular disease: a daily pill that would be prescribed to everyone over the age of 55, regardless of their risk of heart attack or stroke.

title: A.I.G. to Buy General Electric's Life Insurance Unit in Japan
description: The American International Group, one of the world's largest insurers, is expanding its already robust operations in Japan by buying the Japanese life insurance business of General Electric, people who have been briefed on the transaction said yesterday.

title: Sludge Spread on Fields Is Fodder for Lawsuits
description: The farmers outside Augusta, Ga., say the hay had a musty chemical odor and was dark and mottled. But they fed it to the cows. Then the cows started to waste away, growing so thin that their ribs could be counted through their skin, the dairy farmers say. The cows died by the hundreds.

title: A Digital Camera Attuned To Its Mix-and-Match Lenses
description: Digital photographers who want to use single-lens reflex cameras have had two choices: compact models with permanently mounted zoom lenses or bulky models that accepted interchangeable lenses made for the maker's 35-millimeter S.L.R.'s. The Olympus E-1 is neither of the above. It was designed from the outset for digital use and relies on the first interchangeable-lens system to be shared from the outset by several manufacturers.

title: Treatment of Detained Immigrants Is Under Investigation
description: The Justice Department's inspector general said today that his office was investigating possible abuses by federal prison guards in Brooklyn against illegal immigrants detained after the Sept. 11 attacks, but the head of the federal prison system vigorously defended his agency's handling of the inmates.

title: Adventurous Soloists Reined In by a Backbeat
description: It could have been a dance party, but it took place at the Apollo Theater, where the seating and the ushers prevent that sort of thing. Still, Roy Hargrove and Maceo Parker put on an entertaining show on Tuesday night, and it's not their fault that the audience mainly took it sitting down.

title: Big East Goes Trawling for Two New Members
description: There is no doubt the Atlantic Coast Conference has wounded the Big East Conference by inviting two of its members, Miami and Virginia Tech, to jump to the A.C.C.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Last Danube Debris Cleared
description: The last debris has been cleared from navigation channels in the Danube River, four years after the American-led bombing campaign in Kosovo and Serbia destroyed bridges in Novi Sad, limiting shipping on the river to smaller ships and barges. The Danube Commission, which coordinates shipping, said the Danube was now entirely free of debris. But traffic is still far below prewar levels, limited by a pontoon bridge being used as a temporary measure until all the bridges are rebuilt. The pontoon bridge is removed just three times a week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROMAINE, , THEODORE C. JR.
description: ROMAINE--Theodore C. Jr. Holland Lodge #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROADBENT, , WILLIAM W. SR.
description: BROADBENT -- William W. Sr., Services will be held on Sunday at 12 Noon at Morrow Memorial Church, 600 Ridgewood Road, Maplewood, NJ. >>AD#

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Terror Suspect Wins Ruling on Questioning Qaeda Figures
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  A federal appeals court today rejected for the time being the Bush administration's request that it prohibit Zacarias Moussaoui from interviewing captured Al Qaeda figures to support his defense that he was not involved in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist plot.

title: A Romantic's Wry Musings on Love's Sweet Song
description: Given the early curtain time on Tuesday night for the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater, it might have been possible to rush across Lincoln Center Plaza as soon as George Balanchine's full-evening ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' ended and catch American Ballet Theater dancing Sir Frederick Ashton's one-act ''Dream'' at the Metropolitan Opera House. One fan in the City Ballet audience proposed that. But in the case of these two ballets, comparisons are not only invidious but also pointless.

title: Trade for Miceli Brings Bullpen Relief
description: The Yankees' need for bullpen help was obvious on Tuesday, when Manager Joe Torre had no reliever to trust in the late innings of a wild game. Torre's bullpen improved today when the Yankees acquired Dan Miceli from the Cleveland Indians, and the bench also received a boost.

title: HEAD OF A ROYAL AHOLD SUPERMARKET CHAIN IN U.S. RESIGNS
description: Royal Ahold said yesterday that the chief executive of its Tops supermarket chain in the United States had resigned after the company discovered that the unit had used promotional allowances to inflate profit last year. The executive, Frank Curci, will be succeeded by Max Henderson, the company said. Mr. Curci is the latest executive to leave Ahold since February, when the Dutch retailer said its distribution unit in the United States had inflated earnings for three years.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: KENYA: EMBASSY REOPENS The American Embassy in Nairobi reopened after closing for several days in response to fears of a terrorist attack. The embassy, which replaced one destroyed by Al Qaeda bombers in 1998, is designed to withstand attack. Kenyan soldiers stood guard as diplomats returned to work. Meanwhile, the presidents of Kenya and Tanzania criticized the American and British governments for issuing warnings against travel to east Africa, likening the advisories to economic sanctions.

title: Interview With the Interviewer (Hands to Yourself)
description: SOLEDAD O'BRIEN, her pretty face fixed in a pristine pout beneath a professional makeup job, has forgotten where her new office at CNN's Midtown studio complex is: upstairs, down, neither? On July 7, she replaces Paula Zahn as co-host of ''American Morning,'' CNN's answer to the ''Today'' show and its a.m. peer group. Change is good, but after 15 years at NBC, where she made a memorable live debut in 1993 -- in a sports bar crammed with drunken San Francisco Giants fans she was groped by a prospective interviewee, froze and forgot her questions -- change can be moderately confusing.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: HEALTH AND EDUCATION SPENDING The House Appropriations Committee approved $138 billion in discretionary spending on health and education programs for next year, despite the objections of Democrats who said the measure would short-change schools and deny health coverage to low-income children. Republicans rejected amendments, offered by Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, that would have increased spending by reducing tax cuts for 200,000 Americans who earn more than $1 million a year.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CHANGES ROLES OF 2 EXECUTIVES
description: The American Express Company, preparing for its planned acquisition of a British fund manager, said yesterday that it had changed the responsibilities of two executives. Jim Cracchiolo, the chairman and chief executive of American Express Financial Advisors and currently the group president for global financial services, will focus solely on expanding the financial services business, the company said. Ed Gilligan, group president for global corporate services, will lead the international consumer card business and international operations, bringing together the international card businesses for individuals and companies. American Express, which is based in New York, said last week that it would buy Threadneedle Asset Management Holding from the Zurich Financial Services Group for about $570 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Climate Rises
description: The German business climate is brightening, showing unexpectedly strong growth in June's Ifo index after pessimistic assessments over the past three months. The Ifo Institute's survey said the overall index rose to 88.8 from 87.6 the previous month, returning to its level in February. Both the current assessment and expectations contributed to the increase. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: With Paint, Seeing Isn't Always Believing
description: AS anyone who has ever painted a room knows, the problem with color is that if it's off by even one shade, it's a disaster. It might as well be black.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRIS, , EVELYN J.
description: STRIS--Evelyn J. On June 24, 2003 at age 87. Beloved wife of the late Peter K. Stris, devoted mother of William and Nicholas and the late Peter K., dear sister of the late George Jervas and sister-inlaw of the late Gertrude Jervas, loving grandmother of Peter K. Stris. Reposing at George Werst Funeral Home, Cooper Avenue at 72nd St, Glendale, New York, Thursday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral service Friday 10 AM at St. Demetrios G.O. Church, Jamaica, NY. Interment in Cypress Hills Cemetery. >>AD#

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Bank Robbery Thwarted
description: Two detectives in Howard Beach thwarted a bank robbery as it happened yesterday, the police said. The detectives ran from their car and tackled a man as he fled the North Fork Bank branch at 155-14 Cross Bay Boulevard with a loaded handgun and $2,195 in cash. The detectives, James Culliney and Thomas Dolan, were driving another man for questioning to the 100th Precinct station when they saw Darren Scriven, 39, run out the door of the bank. As Mr. Scriven ran between two parked cars, the detectives noticed a wad of cash in his hand, the police said. When the detectives arrested Mr. Scriven, they found the cash, a note demanding money and a 9mm handgun loaded with eight bullets. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Recall Of One Million Car Seats
description: The Dorel Juvenile Group Inc. said it would recall more than one million infant safety seats because of faulty handle locks. Dorel, of Columbus, Ind., said it had received 400 complaints and reports of nine injuries caused by broken handles. The voluntary recall was announced by the company, the Consumer Product Safety Commission and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. All combination infant carrier and car seats made before January 2000 and sold under the Cosco Arriva and Turnabout brands are involved, officials said. John Files (NYT)

title: Editor of US Weekly Resigns From Magazine
description: Bonnie Fuller, the editor of US Weekly who has raised the celebrity magazine's circulation and profits in her 16-month tenure, resigned today, and will join the company that owns The National Enquirer as editorial director.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: RULING IN PREGNANCY CASE A severely retarded rape victim who was thrust into an abortion debate when Gov. Jeb Bush said he wanted a guardian appointed for her fetus will be allowed to carry her pregnancy to term, a judge ruled. The woman's court-appointed guardian made the recommendation. The judge said there was no legal basis for appointing a guardian for a fetus. (AP)

title: RUSSIA: GROUP SAYS TERROR ARRESTS WERE STAGED
description: A leading Russian human rights group has accused the Russian government of staging a mass arrest of Islamic militants this month in an attempt to show that Russia is an energetic player in fighting terrorism. The rights group, Memorial, said its research on the arrests of 55 men described by the police as ''members of the Islamic Liberation Party'' showed that 47 were quickly released and six others were released the next day. Two were charged with possession of explosives. Memorial said that the two denied owning any explosives and that the material found under their beds might have been planted by the police agents. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUPPEL, , PHILIP FREDERICK
description: RUPPEL--Philip Frederick. On June 25, 2003. Beloved husband of Anne (nee Dennin). Loving father of Elizabeth Anne Weinberg and her husband Peter and Christopher Dennin Ruppel. Wonderful and loving Poppy of Margit, Raymond and Emily Ann. Dear brother of Joseph. Visiting Friday, 2-4, 7-9 PM at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. 2080 Boston Post Rd, Larchmont, NY 10538. Mass Saturday, 10:15AM at Sts John & Paul Church in Larchmont. Interment at Gate of Heaven cemetery. >>AD#

title: Rebels in Liberia Attack Capital; Shell Refugees in U.S. Annex
description: Fighting between government and rebel factions for control of Monrovia, the Liberian capital, erupted today, and people ran frantically through the streets in search of safety.

title: Court Throws Out Death Sentence, Citing Lawyer's Flaws
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 — The Supreme Court spared the life of a convicted killer in Maryland today, declaring that his inexperienced lawyers had let him down at his trial 14 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCEWEN, , O. CURRIER, M.D.
description: McEWEN--O. Currier, M.D. The faculty and staff of NYU School of Medicine express their deepest sadness over the death of O. Currier McEwen, M.D., former Dean of the School of Medicine and a distinguished member of the faculty for thirty-eight years. Dr. McEwen graduated from the School of Medicine in 1926, completed his internship at Bellevue Hospital and joined the faculty in 1932. In 1937, at the age of thirty-five, he became the youngest man ever to be appointed Dean of a leading American medical school, up to that time. His service as Dean was interrupted during WWII, when he served as a Colonel with the renowned Bellevue Hospital Unit. Before retiring as Dean in 1955, Dr. McEwen's many accomplishments included the establishment of what is now NYU Medical Center. He was one of the nation's leading authorities on rheumatic diseases, and through his research, patient care and academic pursuits, he made many outstanding contributions to this field. Dr. McEwen retired in 1970 as Professor of Medicine. He embodied the finest traditions of the medical profession throughout his career, and his many years of service to NYU will always be remembered with respect and admiration. Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean, NYU School of Medicine >>AD#

title: Ruling in '98 Blackface Case Finds Favor in the Community
description: Residents of the enclave of Broad Channel in Jamaica Bay expressed approval yesterday of a judge's decision that three residents' First Amendment rights were violated when they were fired for racial depictions in the 1998 Labor Day parade.

title: What's on the Menu?
description: Command Shortcuts

title: Metro Matters; In Spanish Or English, Double Talk
description: TO figure out what's happening to bilingual education in New York, listen to the political background music, not the words. Because the words won't help much.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Abducted Girls Released
description: Dozens of schoolgirls who were abducted by a rebel group in the northeastern Soroti district this week have been released, but the authorities said that six girls remained in the hands of the rebels, the Lord's Resistance Army, a quasi-religious group that kidnaps children to reinforce its ranks. The rebels have been fighting the government since 1988, but there has been an increase in violence since President Yoweri Museveni announced a crackdown on the rebels last year. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: N.B.A. Recruits Near and Far for New Draft Class
description: For the three heralded teenagers caught up in the heady world of stock exchange openings, news conferences and photo shoots in Manhattan for the past two days, there is little suspense left in tonight's N.B.A. draft, only anticipation.

title: Questions Remain On A.C.C. Invitations
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference officially asked Miami and Virginia Tech to join it yesterday, a day after the A.C.C.'s university presidents voted, 7 to 2, to extend those invitations.

title: Delayed Reisinger Winner Picks Up Defense's Signal
description: The final of the Reisinger Knockout Teams in New York City was played on Sunday at the Town Club, 9 East 36th Street, and victory, by a margin of 34 imps, went to Brian Glubok, Aaron Silverstein, Jonathan Greenspan, Adam Wildavsky and John Fout. The losers were David Rosenberg, Allen Kahn, Jeffrey Rothstein and Janet and Mel Colchamiro.

title: Foreign Countries Doing Better Job Prepping Players
description: Donn Nelson, an assistant coach and the president of basketball operations for the Dallas Mavericks, has been a major figure in the booming development of international basketball players. He has coached international teams and coached against them and has led clinics overseas.

title: Martha Stewart's New Magazine Carries the Taste Of Comfort Food
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia plans to announce today that its latest magazine, Everyday Food, has been a success and will expand to 10 issues a year, a move that distances the company from its rarefied but tarnished image.

title: U.S. STEEL'S PURCHASE OF SERBIAN COMPANY IS CHALLENGED
description: A group of foreign creditors of Serbia's biggest steel maker challenged the government's sale of the company to the U.S. Steel Corporation, seeking a new public tender, in a bid to recoup their $100 million claim. The creditors, including WestLB and the HVB Group of Germany, BNP Paribas of France, KBC Bancassurance Holding of Belgium and Standard Bank of Britain, said assets of the steel maker, Sartid, could have been sold for more than the $23 million offered by U.S. Steel. U.S. Steel, based in Pittsburgh, agreed to buy Sartid in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDBACK, , FRED
description: SANDBACK -- Fred. The Trustees and Staff of Dia Art Foundation mourn the loss of a great artist and friend, Fred Sandback. All of our lives have been enriched by Fred's life, spirit, energy, and work, and he will be deeply missed. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to Fred's family. Leonard Riggio, Chairman Michael Govan, Director Lynne Cooke, Curator >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOAN, , NANCY BETH
description: SLOAN--Nancy Beth, 48, illustrator, freelance design consultant and lifetime Manhattan resident, died June 21st. Survived by her sister Carol Hurst, brother-in-law Larry Hurst and her nephews Kenneth and Kevin Sweet. Memorial service June 26th, St. Peters Church, Citicorp Building, 54th and Lexington, 4 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in Nancy's name be sent to the Art Students League of NY, 215 West 57th Street, New York, NY 10019, 212-247-4510. >>AD#

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, , IRVING
description: MARCUS--Irving. Of Hewlett, NY and Palm Beach, FL. Passed away on June 24, 2003 after a brief illness. Loving husband of 63 years to Gertrude. Devoted father of Joel, Marilyn and Stuart. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Elyse, Michael, Jordan, Lauren and Andrew. Dear Brother of Al Marcus and the late Rose Flaxman. Donations may be sent to Brandeis University in Waltham, MA. Shiva to be at the home of Joel Marcus. >>AD#

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISH, , KATHRYN RUTH
description: FISH -- Kathryn Ruth, of Larchmont, NY, passed away on June 23, 2003 at age 78. She was the wife of the late Robert B. Fish and mother of the late Deborah Ruth Fish & is survived by her daughter Judith, and granddaughter Justine. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Emanuel of Westchester, Rye, NY on Sunday, June 29 at 2 PM. Memorial donations to Congregation Emanuel. >>AD#

title: U.S. Expected To Sue Enron Over Losses By Workers
description: The Labor Department is expected to sue about 20 officials of the Enron Corporation and its retirement plans today, arguing that they breached their fiduciary duty to protect Enron employees from the huge losses they incurred when the company's stock price collapsed.

title: Economic Scene; Do workers really make hay while the sun shines, or just clock out sooner?
description: A CORE tenet of supply-side economics is that people will work more if their take-home pay rate rises.

title: Democrats Urge Bush To Press Hard On Tax Credit
description: The top two Congressional Democrats, along with most of the House Democratic caucus, demanded today that President Bush intervene to deliver an increased child tax credit for low-income families this month, but Republican officials said a decision on credits would have to wait for weeks, if not longer.

title: Hulk Vanquishes an Evildoer For Bootlegging His New Film
description: The powerful superhero known as the Hulk smote his enemy yesterday with help from a rather mundane source: the copyright laws of the United States.

title: The Return Of the Pink Poodle
description: Phyllis Morris was in her heyday as a designer to the Beverly Hills set in the 1960's and 70's, but her furniture business was started in the 50's with a pink plaster poodle lamp, right, that was modeled on her own poodle, Pinky. Now her daughter Jamie Adler has revived the business with a more contemporary and restrained line called Circa, but is remaking the flamboyant poodle lamp. ''The pendulum is swinging back toward bold, glamorous and whimsical design,'' she said. The lamp is $650 in a limited edition of 500 (pink only) from Phyllis Morris/Circa at 8772 Beverly Boulevard, West Hollywood (310) 289-6868 and from www.phyllismorris.com.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Challenge To Immunity Law
description: The Milan bribery trial of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi reopened, but Mr. Berlusconi did not attend. His lawyers deemed his presence unnecessary since the Parliament has passed a law giving him immunity from prosecution. The Milan prosecutor urged the judges trying him to consult the Supreme Court about the new law, in the hope that the court will deem it unconstitutional and force Mr. Berlusconi back to the courtroom. The opinion of the Supreme Court is expected to be sought on Monday, a day before Mr. Berlusconi takes over the rotating presidency of the European Union. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: A Tyrant in the Shadows
description: Residents of this village of mud huts know that Saddam Hussein even changed the weather. Under a vindictive Iraqi sun, the gale-force north wind sandblasts everything in its path. Crops no longer grow. Children in this parched community not far from the Iranian border huddle in the lee of a clay wall, unable to play. The temperature today is a suffocating 120 degrees.

title: Forgiveness and the Church Crisis (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: They Aim to Last Beyond an Instant
description: POLAROID has a new camera called the Polaroid One, but some fear it may be the Polaroid Last. Introduced last month, the simple fixed-focus camera carries a suggested price of $49.99 (plus $14.99 for film) and is aimed mainly at family snapshot shooters. Polaroid hopes it will revive sales among those who will not spend $150 for a digital camera with automatic electronic focus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WADDELL, , HARRY LEE
description: WADDELL--Harry Lee, of Yachats, OR (formerly of NYC, Port Jervis and Garden City), on June 25. A newspaper and magazine editor and executive, he worked for the Buffalo Evening News, McGraw-Hill, Doubleday & Co., and Simmons-Boardman. In 1983 he retired to Port Jervis with his second wife Helene. He moved to Yachats in 1996 to be near his daughters: Nancy of Whidbey Island, WA; Carol of Malibu, CA; Jessica of Yachats; three grandchildren, one great-grandchild. His inquisitive spirit and concern for community and young people will be missed by those who knew him. Memorials to Hospice of Orange County or Alzheimer's Assoc. >>AD#

title: Coaster With a Message: Your Table Is Ready
description: IT'S early on a Wednesday night and the wait for a table at Jaleo, a popular Washington tapas restaurant, is 20 minutes and growing. Along the bar, customers line up three deep for pitchers of sangria.

title: Bush Escapes Fury That Batters Blair
description: This week in London, Foreign Secretary Jack Straw has been forced to acknowledge publicly that a paper published by the British government to make the case against Saddam Hussein was ''an embarrassment.''

title: Corrections
description: Two pictures with the National Briefing column yesterday were reversed. Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa, who decided to transfer $15 million from the state Medicaid fund, was shown at the right. Lt. Gen. John W. Rosa, whose nomination to lead the Air Force Academy received Senate approval, appeared at the left.

title: On Appeal, Diocese Can Keep Abuse-Suit Documents Sealed
description: Connecticut's Appellate Court ruled today that a state judge erred last year in deciding that sealed court files containing specific allegations of sexual abuse by several priests in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport should be opened to the public.

title: Fred Sandback, 59, Sculptor Of Minimalist Installations
description: Fred Sandback, a sculptor internationally known for his Minimalist works made from lengths of colored yarn, died on Monday at his studio in New York. He was 59.

title: An Environmental Report Card
description: On her way out the door, Christie Whitman has issued the Environmental Protection Agency's first statistical assessment of the nation's environment. The bottom line is that although much remains to be done, things are greatly improved from 30 years ago. The air is healthier, the water cleaner. But underneath the numbers, and of course unobserved in the report, lies an exquisite irony: what has brought us here are the landmark environmental laws of the early 1970's -- laws that the industries bankrolling the Bush administration have been fighting tooth and nail ever since, laws that the administration itself has tried to amend or weaken.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Interest Rate Cut
description: Norway's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate yesterday by one percentage point, the biggest reduction in more than a decade, and signaled that it might cut rates further to revive its faltering economy. The bank, Norges Bank, cut its benchmark deposit rate to a five-year low of 4 percent from 5 percent. The period of monetary easing is continuing, said Svein Gjedrem, the central bank's governor, in the bank's report.

title: Pettitte Gives the Yankees Enough to Gain a Victory
description: It is as if the Yankees' starters have an unspoken understanding. Since the last game Antonio Osuna pitched, on June 13, the Yankees have had no dependable right-handed setup man. In order to win, the starters have to work at least seven innings. In 8 of the 10 games since then, the starter has done that.

title: 73rd Home Run Ball Sells for $450,000
description: The star attraction was nestled on a black velvet pedestal, which was locked and enclosed in an air-tight glass case that stood 6 feet tall and, being the headliner, shined under the lights of the room. It was placed beside the auctioneer's stand at the ESPN Zone restaurant in Times Square, and starting about 6:30 last night, it was about to be sold to the highest bidder.

title: Wall Street Now Runs Through Campus
description: Charges of tampering, litigation, back-room deals, broken promises and bait-and-switch tactics were the milestones the Atlantic Coast Conference set on its road to expansion. Tuesday night's vote by nine university presidents did more than allow the conference to invite Miami and Virginia Tech into its fold; it made official what most already knew: college athletics has turned pro.

title: Accounts Suggest 6 Massacred British Soldiers Were Fleeing an Angry Crowd
description: Details began to emerge today about the fighting that led to the deaths of six British soldiers and four Iraqis on Tuesday in the center of this town in southern Iraq.

title: G.I. Killed, 8 Injured in One of Three Attacks in Iraq
description: An American special operations soldier was killed and eight were wounded southwest of Baghdad today in one of three incidents involving attacks by militants, a coalition task force spokesman said.

title: Medicare Drug Plan Far From Cure-All, Irate Retirees Find
description: After 85 years on this earth, 36 of them as a schoolteacher, and more than 60 as a taxpayer, Vela Fox figures the government ought not forget her in her old age. Asked about efforts by Congress to give older Americans some relief from the high cost of prescription drugs, the normally mild-mannered Mrs. Fox lets loose with a tirade that could shake the magnolia blooms off the trees.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on June 5 about an effort in Congress to overturn the Federal Communications Commission's new regulations on media ownership referred incorrectly to the president's role in adopting a ''resolution of disapproval,'' a parliamentary move that would repeal the F.C.C.'s decision. His signature would indeed be required. (The resolution could also could go into effect if Congress overrode a presidential veto.)

title: L.I. Man Convicted in Killing Of a Priest and a Parishioner
description: A jury today convicted a former mental patient of two murders in the shooting of a priest and a parishioner during a morning Mass at a church in Lynbrook last year.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Growth Forecast
description: Thaksin Shinawatra, the prime minister, said that he expected the nation's economy to expand an average 6 percent a year over the next six years, helped by rising consumer spending and surging exports. Mr. Thaksin said Thailand's gross domestic product would probably grow to $200 billion by 2009, from $130 billion. The government forecasts inflation to average 2 percent over the next year, he said, as he asked lawmakers to approve his government's budget for the year ending Sept. 30, 2004.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Keeping Bamboo in Its Place

title: Is It Art? Probably Not, but It's You
description: TOURISTS sitting for a sidewalk sketch in Central Park or on the banks of the Seine must gamble on the skills of an unknown artist. But vacationers on the New England coast and even weekend moviegoers can have their portraits done by the greats -- Leonardo, Rembrandt, Michelangelo or Raphael -- for a few dollars each.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer Maintains Forecast
description: The Belgian brewer Interbrew stuck to its earlier forecast of organic sales and profit growth this year. Sales during the first half of this year have been strong, especially in Russia, Ukraine and Central Europe, the company said, while market share in France and exports to the United States declined. Analysts said that after a profit warning on Monday from a rival Dutch brewer, Heineken, the market had expected similar pessimism from Interbrew. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Lottery Numbers
Forgiveness and the Church Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Opera With Confetti and Leather
description: Berlioz and Wagner seemed to have gotten wrong directions on their way to San Francisco over the weekend. On Friday, Berlioz's ''Damnation de Faust'' ended up at the War Memorial Opera House, when it may have been more at home on the symphonic stage across the street. Wagner's ''Flying Dutchman,'' an opera put on as a concert the next night, needed all its powers of suggestion to make Davies Symphony Hall behave like a theater.

title: MOODY'S CUTS RATING ON TENET DEBT TO JUNK STATUS
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation's debt was cut yesterday to junk, or below investment grade, by Moody's Investors Service after the hospital chain reduced profit forecasts for the third time since November. Moody's cut its rating on Tenet's senior unsecured debt three levels to Ba3 from Baa3, the lowest investment grade, and said it might reduce the rating further. Tenet, whose Medicare billing is being investigated by federal regulators, said two days ago that second-quarter and full-year profit would be lower than forecast. Tenet, which is based in Santa Barbara, Calif., said profit excluding some costs was 2 cents a share in April and May.

title: Mixed Reaction in Pakistan to U.S. Pledge of $3 Billion in Aid
description: ISLAMABAD, Afghanistan, June 26  The announcement that President Pervez Musharaff had won a $3 billion economic package from the United States has produced a mixed reaction at best here, reflecting the sharp political opposition to the president and a popular view that American owes Pakistan much more for its perceived loyalty.

title: As Elections Approach, Russians See Corruption Crackdown
description: State television today featured majestic shots of a compound of brick dachas, an all-weather tennis court and an azure swimming pool -- all built by police colonels with official salaries of about $300 a month.

title: A Prickly Courtship For Orchestra and Hall
description: The marriage of the New York Philharmonic and Carnegie Hall is showing early signs of strain. That at least was the impression left by separate recent telephone interviews with Zarin Mehta, the executive director of the Philharmonic, and Robert Harth, the executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Health and Education Spending
description: The House Appropriations Committee approved $138 billion in discretionary spending on health and education programs for next year, despite the objections of Democrats who said the measure would short-change schools and deny health coverage to low-income children. Republicans rejected amendments, offered by Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, that would have increased spending by reducing tax cuts for 200,000 Americans who earn more than $1 million a year. Sheryl Gay Stolberg (NYT)

title: Higher Spending Seen on Campaigns
description: In another indication that the advertising economy is improving, TNS Media Intelligence/CMR, a division of Taylor Nelson Sofres that tracks ad spending, revised upward its forecast for this year.

title: Finally, a Public Resting Place for History's Motherboards
description: AT the new headquarters of the Computer History Museum in Silicon Valley, the ghosts of technologies past still roam the grounds.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: A Concorde May Land On Intrepid
description: British Airways and the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum are negotiating to place a retired Concorde on the deck of the aircraft carrier turned museum. John Lampl, a British Airways spokesman, said, ''It would be our desire to have an airplane at the two ends of the main route, and certainly the USS Intrepid would be a great place.'' Air France has taken the plane out of service, and British Airways plans to do so in October. A Concorde could be floated by barge from Kennedy International Airport to the Hudson River, and hoisted by crane onto the Intrepid at Pier 86, near 46th Street and 12th Avenue. But a long list of museums want Concordes, and British Airways has only seven. The Museum of Flight in Seattle, for example, wants one and so does the Smithsonian's new annex at Dulles Airport near Washington.

title: Cramming It All In At the Biennale
description: I usually skip the previews for the Venice Biennale, when the art world descends for two or three days on the public gardens and former shipyard where the show mostly takes place. Last time, about 14,000 people jammed the preview. The day after the show opened to the public there were 800 visitors wandering in a relative oasis of calm amid the honeysuckle and jasmine in the gardens.

title: Netflix's Patent May Reshape DVD-Rental Market
description: In the brewing battle in the online DVD-rental marketplace, Netflix, the market leader, has been given a potentially significant new advantage.

title: Masterpiece or Empire, It's All Up to the Player
description: From the paper-and-dice days of early Dungeons and Dragons to the fluid graphics of The Sims Online, role-playing games have offered a chance to shed your skin and become somebody new, even if for just a few hours. Second Life, a new online game from Linden Labs that made its official debut this week, combines Internet socializing with rambles in its 3-D virtual society. Players can roam through the game with an onscreen body that looks as much (or as little) like themselves as desired.

title: Liberty Fights Off Stubborn Mercury
description: The Phoenix Mercury entered last night's game with a 2-9 record, the worst in the Women's National Basketball Association, and had never defeated the Liberty at Madison Square Garden in six meetings. By game's end, the won-lost record was worse and the drought at the Garden was still intact.

title: Do Not Pass Comfortable. Go Directly to Hot and Sweaty.
description: We lost her.

title: Crude Oil Prices Increase 4% On Surprising Fall in Inventories
description: The price of crude oil traded in New York had its biggest gain in six weeks yesterday after an Energy Department report showed that inventories declined unexpectedly last week. Oil in United States refineries, terminals and pipelines fell 4.1 million barrels, to 284.2 million barrels, the report said. Most analysts surveyed had forecast an increase.

title: Merger of Nestl and Dreyer's Gains F.T.C. Support
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it would allow Nestl to proceed with the $2.8 billion merger of its United States ice cream business with Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream.

title: Safety Program Will Link 10 Bodegas to 911
description: In an effort to protect bodegas from robberies, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced a pilot program yesterday that will equip 10 stores in the most frequently victimized neighborhoods with video cameras and panic buttons linked to the city's 911 emergency system.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 12 about confirmation hearings for William H. Pryor, Alabama's attorney general, who has been nominated for a federal judgeship, referred incorrectly to Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, a member of the Judiciary Committee. He indeed appeared at the hearing, and questioned Mr. Pryor. (Mr. Specter had told a reporter that he was not going to attend because he was busy, but as the hearing was near an end, he decided to go.)

title: Tax Cutting Is Complete, Nominee Says
description: Joshua B. Bolten, President Bush's nominee for director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget, said today that the administration had no plans to push for tax cuts beyond those it had already proposed.

title: Editorial Observer; Championing Children for Whom Reading and Learning Are Difficult
description: How old are you? Ninety-nine percent of us answer this question reflexively, without having to think. A reporter who put this question to Peter W. D. Wright several years ago was stunned when Mr. Wright, an education lawyer, resorted to a calculator before answering. When I asked his age over the phone earlier this month, he called to his wife -- ''Pam, how old am I?'' -- then said: ''I am 57. I have trouble with math.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELFANT, , GERSON
description: HELFANT--Gerson, peacefully, on June 24. A graduate of Erasmus Hall High School, attended Syracuse University. A self-made success as CEO of Bennett Utilities, served as president of Westhampton Beach Rotary, Commodore of Westhampton Yacht Squadron. Survived by his wife Judith, daughters Ida Shuve, Lisa Turpin, brother Mike, three grandsons and a great grandson. Visitation Thurs, 7-9pm, Sinnickson's Moriches Funeral Home, Centre Moriches, NY. Funeral Friday 10AM. >>AD#

title: Corrections
description: A program listing, highlight entry and picture caption on Sunday in the Thursday pages of the Television section for the MTV series ''Who's Got Game'' has become outdated. The series will be shown today at 12:30 and 6 p.m., not at 10:30 p.m.

title: A.C.C. Makes Invitations, but Questions Remain
description: The Atlantic Coast Conference officially asked Miami and Virginia Tech to join it yesterday, a day after the A.C.C.'s university presidents voted, 7 to 2, to extend those invitations.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Help For Economy
description: Thailand has set up a 100-billion-baht fund ($2.4 billion) to invest in troubled sectors of the economy. As that fund, the Phoenix Fund, was announced, Thailand's stock exchange said it would create a 700-million-baht fund to invest in the shares it lists. The exchange said the investment was part of an effort to increase revenue as interest rates on its bank deposits fall. The Thai government has already announced plans to sell mutual funds to individual investors to raise part of the 100 billion baht it plans to use to invest in local stocks as part of its plan to prop up stock prices. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Outfield Could Become More Crowded for Reds
description: The Cincinnati Reds already have two very impressive homegrown outfielders in Adam Dunn and Austin Kearns, and their crowded outfield has forced Dunn and Wily Mo Pena, another young outfielder, to try out first basemans mitts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HABER, , IRVING, ESQ.
description: HABER--Irving, Esq. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Devoted father of Samuel and Jacqueline and Peggy. Dear brother of Estelle Kattelson. Cherished grandfather of Alana and Jake. Services Friday 10AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island. >>AD#

title: South Africa Faces Test As Zimbabwe Deteriorates
description: Each day brings a fresh sign of misery in Zimbabwe. Yet South Africa, Zimbabwe's prosperous and stable neighbor to the south, has done little to defuse the situation despite having the most to lose if Zimbabwe descends into chaos.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: STAMPS.COM FILES BREACH OF CONTRACT SUIT AGAINST EBAY Stamps.com, which sells postage stamps over the Internet, has sued eBay and its PayPal electronic payment service, saying they breached a 2002 licensing agreement that would have permitted PayPal customers to use their accounts to buy stamps. The lawsuit was filed yesterday in a state court in Los Angeles, Stamps.com said. Stamps.com accused PayPal of not starting within a reasonable time a service that would have permitted PayPal customers to buy and print electronic postage onto envelopes, labels and documents. Stamps.com, which has about 300,000 customers, had $1.5 million in costs related to the venture, its chief executive, Kenneth McBride, said in an interview. Shares of Stamps.com declined 33 cents, or 6.3 percent, to $4.92.

title: Lasers Set Cells Aglow for a Biopsy Without the Knife
description: IT takes time to do a proper biopsy: typically, several days for a tissue sample to be removed, preserved, sliced, stained with labeling chemicals and placed under a microscope to be interpreted by a pathologist.

title: Keeping Vladimir Putin on Track
description: The royal reception for President Vladimir Putin in Britain coincided neatly with the spectacular launch of the latest Harry Potter saga. The world loves a fairy tale, whether it be about an abused kid who turns into a heroic wizard, or a spook who becomes president and gets treated like a king. This is fine. Mr. Putin and Russia need all the relief they can get. But the key is to make sure that carriage ride with Queen Elizabeth is not a free ride. It's also a chance to talk to the Russian president about Iran's nuclear program, about the latest television station he closed down, about North Korea, about what's happening inside Russia.

title: Mideast Talks Make Progress Despite Attacks
description: Israel and the militant group Hamas continued to trade blows today, even as Palestinian officials said that an agreement among Palestinian factions to suspend violence against Israel was all but sealed.

title: Erasing Limits on Prosecuting Child Molesters Is Ruled Illegal
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The Supreme Court dealt a serious defeat today to prosecutors who pursue suspects accused of molesting children, ruling 5 to 4 that the government cannot erase statutes of limitations retroactively.

title: Online Chat With Faces Attached
description: INSTANT messaging certainly has its charms. You and a conversation partner on the Internet type back and forth in a narrow window, your quips scrolling up the screen like a hastily written script. The fact that you can't see or hear the other person is either the best feature or the worst, depending on how self-conscious you are and how your hair looks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINTER, , PHILIP L., ESQ.
description: WINTER--Philip L., Esq. Formerly of Larchmont, N.Y. passed away Tuesday, June 24, 2003 in Jensen Beach, FL. He was predeceased by his wife Sarah ''Scat'' Winter and their daughter Jeanie. He is survived by two grandchildren, his stepson and two nieces and nephews. He graduated Harvard College in 1944 and Harvard Law School in 1949, served in the U.S. Army as a Japanese interpreter during WWII, and practiced entertainment law in New York City before moving his practice to Larchmont, N.Y. and Estes Park, CO. Funeral services and interment will be held in Estes Park, CO. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Hospice Care.

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Fine In Miners' Deaths
description: The United States Mine Safety and Health Administration fined Jim Walter Resources $435,000, saying it had committed eight safety violations that contributed to 13 deaths in coal mine explosions in Brookwood, Ala., on Sept. 23, 2001. Mine safety officials, who accused the company of interfering with mine ventilation, said they had imposed the maximum $55,000 penalty for seven of the eight violations. They said they would also seek penalties on 19 less severe violations. Jim Walter officials said they would appeal. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Agency Is Selected for Napster Revival
description: Roxio , in Santa Clara, Calif., plans to announce today that it is hiring Venables, Bell & Partners in San Francisco as agency of record on the account of Napster, the defunct online music service that Roxio plans to revive this year. Spending on the account has not been determined, but the company has said it will spend up to $20 million on the reintroduction.

title: Youth Arrested In Death of Boy In a Fistfight
description: The police arrested a Harlem teenager yesterday and charged him with manslaughter in the death of a youth who fell and hit his head during a fistfight on Monday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BREWSTER, , DOROTHY GA TINS
description: BREWSTER -- Dorothy Ga tins. Age 89. Of New York City. Died peacefully on June 24, 2003 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Rice Brewster. Sister of Hope G. Simpson. Cherished mother of Ethel Stout Chapin, Hope Stout Connors and Walter R. Brewster, Jr. Loving grandmother of seven and great grandmother of four. She graduated from Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT., and was a life-long supporter of the school. She was a nurse during the Second World War and, for twelve years, was a travel agent and led meticulously planned tours that were enjoyed by the many who joined her. She served the New York community as a director of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work, Grosvenor Neighborhood House and the Woman's Hospital. She was a member of the Colony Club, where she served as the Governor, the National Society of Colonial Dames, the Holland Dames and the Pilgrims of the United States. There will be a Memorial Mass at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th St and Lexington Ave, Monday, June 30th at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Girls and Boys Town, Father Val J. Peter, Boys Town Center, Boys Town, NE. 68010. >>AD#

title: U.S. Predicts Cancer Deaths at Proposed Plutonium Plant
description: The radiation doses that the Energy Department estimates for workers at a new plutonium factory that it wants to build would cause about one fatal case of cancer for each four and a half years the plant operates, according to the draft environmental impact statement.

title: European Union Overhauls Agricultural Subsidy Program
description: BRUSSELS, June 26  European Union officials announced today what they described as "historic" changes in their common agricultural policy, the world's largest and most costly farm subsidy program.

title: Corrections
description: Two pictures with the National Briefing column yesterday were reversed. Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa, who decided to transfer $15 million from the state Medicaid fund, was shown at the right. Lt. Gen. John W. Rosa, whose nomination to lead the Air Force Academy received Senate approval, appeared at the left.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOPP, , LANI JOY SALZBERG
description: HOPP--Lani Joy Salzberg, on June 25. Beloved wife of Robert, loving mother of Dana and Jenna, cherished daughter of Sylvia and the late David Salzberg, dear sister of Barry and Jane Salzberg. Services Friday, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 N. Station Pl., Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Salzberg Cancer Research Fund of Hadassah, 50 West 58 St., NYC 10019.

title: Editor of US Weekly Resigns From Magazine
description: Bonnie Fuller, the editor of US Weekly who has raised the celebrity magazine's circulation and profits during her 16-month tenure, resigned today from Wenner Media, the magazine's publisher.

title: Heavyweight Dreams
description: Michael Rothberger works the night shift driving a truck for a fruit company in the Bronx and fights for $100 a round. He sleeps during the day, when he can, in his apartment or, in tougher times, in the back of his Chevy Blazer parked in the street because bad luck does not seem to change when you wake up in the dark.

title: Young Potter Fans See Hero Maturing Along With Them
description: Mari Stein bought the new Harry Potter book just after it went on sale at midnight on Friday, and started reading it when she got up the next morning. By 9 o'clock Saturday night she had finished all 870 pages of ''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix.''

title: Rusedski Loses Focus, To Roddick's Benefit
description: It has been a year for testing the boundaries of etiquette at Wimbledon. On Monday, Robby Ginepri became the first man to play in a sleeveless shirt at the All England Club. Today, Greg Rusedski of Britain unleashed an expletive-heavy tirade against the chair umpire on Center Court during his straight-sets loss to Andy Roddick that was off-color enough to move a BBC spokesman to apologize to its viewers.

title: Agency Is Selected For Napster Revival
description: Roxio, in Santa Clara, Calif., plans to announce today that it is hiring Venable, Bell & Partners in San Francisco as agency of record on the account of Napster, the defunct online music service that Roxio plans to revive this year. Spending on the account has not been determined, but the company has said it will spend up to $20 million on the reintroduction.

title: Lester Maddox, Whites-Only Restaurateur and Georgia Governor, Dies at 87
description: Lester Maddox, the Atlanta restaurant owner and archsegregationist who adopted the pick handle as his symbol of defiance in a successful bid for the Georgia governorship in 1966, died on Wednesday in Atlanta. He was 87.

title: Corrections
description: The Votes in Congress chart on Sunday gave incorrect positions in some copies for Senators Jon S. Corzine and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer of New York on a failed Democratic amendment to a bill creating a Medicare prescription drug benefit. They voted yea, not nay. The amendment would have strengthened the federal government's role in delivering the benefit.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day yesterday about a judge's approval of a plan by Dice Inc., an Internet job-search service, to exit bankruptcy misstated the title of Michael P. Durney. He is chief financial officer, not chief executive.

title: President Leads the Roundup for Votes to Add Drug Benefits to Medicare
description: With President Bush acting as lobbyist in chief, House Republican leaders worked feverishly today to allay conservative qualms and round up the votes needed to pass a bill to add drug benefits to Medicare.

title: Sorenstam Will Make Sure She Has the Last Word on 2003
description: Annika Sorenstam knew this would be a year worth remembering. So in January she started keeping a diary.

title: 25 Years Ago, Landmarks Law Stopped a Skyscraper
description: NEW YORK CITY'S landmarks law took effect in 1965 but gained its real power 25 years ago today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Teenager Charged With Murder
description: A 17-year-old boy was arrested yesterday in connection with a fight that left an 18-year-old fatally injured in front of his house, the police said. About 7 p.m. Tuesday, the two were in front of 3353 Fort Independence Avenue, near Jerome Park Reservoir, when they began arguing. The 17-year-old, Leon Wagner, had a gun, the police said. During the dispute, Murod Dunlap, 18, was shot in the back, and Mr. Wagner was shot in the abdomen and buttocks. Both were taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where Mr. Dunlap died. Mr. Wagner was released from the hospital yesterday and charged with murder and criminal possession of a weapon, Detective Thomas Kuchma said.

title: Forgiveness and the Church Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Further Attacks on Allies Predicted by U.S. General
description: The man nominated to be the next senior commander of United States forces in Iraq warned today of continuing attacks against American and British soldiers and said a large occupation force would keep a prolonged presence there.

title: Inaction in Albany: Time for a Change
description: To the Editor:

title: If That's the Sun, There's No Reason to Hide It Now
description: AFTER a relentlessly cold winter and damp spring, summer has arrived with blessed relief. All hail the sun! But summer sunlight can raise air-conditioning bills, and ultraviolet rays cause fabrics to fade. Screens and scrims reduce these effects while allowing rooms to glow with suffused light. Some screens are neutral, while others provide a shot of color for days when the sun refuses to shine.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Government To Sell Phone Stake
description: The Australian government has decided, in principle, to sell its 50.1 percent stake in Telstra, the national telephone network. The government said it would invest an additional 180 million Australian dollars in Telstra's Internet and cellphone services in rural areas to improve the company's commercial value, and began the legislative process but gave no sale date. John Shaw (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Cuts At Airline
description: The Dutch airline, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, said it might cut as many as 4,500 jobs, about 50 percent more than announced in April, as demand for travel falls because of a global economic slowdown and a respiratory-disease epidemic. The airline wants to reduce costs by 650 million euros ($750 million) a year.

title: New York State Failing City Schools, Court Says
description: New York State has failed to meet its constitutional obligation to educate all its children, leading to a "systemic failure" in New York City's schools that has deprived students of their right to a "sound basic education," the state's highest court ruled today. It gave the state until July 2004 to find a remedy.

title: Every Backyard a Water World
description: AFTER several unusually mild winters in the Northeast, and the drought last summer, we were due for a change. And we finally got it. The first snow came in November, and the bare ground wasn't seen again until April. There are advantages to snow cover -- it forms a great insulating mulch for plants. It also, however, protects weed seeds and hibernating creatures (read, ticks).

title: Inaction in Albany: Time for a Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Small Games Room to Stretch
description: Nintendo's GameCube console was designed for elaborate games with state-of-the-art graphics and impressive visual effects, but now the company has added something new: the ability to play primitive games with simple graphics.

title: Canada Is Losing Ability to Fill U.S. Gas Needs
description: For years, Canada has been the safety valve for the United States natural gas market, pumping supplies across the border to ease shortages and keep prices reasonably stable. But the recent surge in gas prices suggests that the days when Americans could look north for relief are over.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Turnpike To Pay WorldCom
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority will pay $1.66 million to WorldCom, the telecommunications company that ran the state's troubled E-ZPass system until March of this year, said Joseph Orlando, a turnpike spokesman. The payment, announced this week, is for buying unused E-ZPass equipment, lane maintenance, shutting down customer service centers and other work WorldCom and its partner, J. P. Morgan Chase, performed after the state terminated their contract, Mr. Orlando said. ACS, a Dallas company, currently operates the electronic toll system. The state has a $402 million lawsuit against WorldCom pending in bankruptcy court stemming from various problems with the E-ZPass system, Mr. Orlando said. A telephone call to WorldCom seeking comment was not immediately returned yesterday. John Holl (NYT)

title: Big Media's Silence
description: Over the protests of 750,000 viewers and readers, three appointees to the Federal Communications Commission last month voted to permit the takeover of America's local press, television and radio by a handful of mega-corporations.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: 50-Year-Old Scotch? Get Us a Fresh Bottle

title: Supreme Court Strikes Down Texas Law Banning Sodomy
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 — The Supreme Court struck down a Texas law today that forbids homosexual sex, and reversed its own ruling in a similar Georgia case 17 years ago, thus invalidating antisodomy laws in the states that still have them.

title: Paradise Regrouted
description: IF a home says a lot about a person, Ricky Boscarino's can't shut up. It's his agent.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Summit Meeting Charges
description: Park Jie Won and Lim Dong Won, top aides to the former president, Kim Dae Jung, left, who spearheaded a drive for reconciliation with North Korea, were indicted on charges of transferring $100 million to North Korea as a payoff for its agreeing to a 2000 summit meeting between the president and Kim Jong Il, the leader of North Korea. Chung Mong Hun, an heir to the Hyundai fortune, was also indicted, for having passed on the money. Eight people now face trial in the case, which has raised doubts about Kim Dae Jung's ''sunshine'' policy toward North Korea. He received the Nobel Peace Prize four months after the meeting. But the prosecutor in effect cleared him of direct complicity, citing a lack of evidence. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Putting All Your E-Mail in One Basket
description: PENELOPE FINNIE had to give up something precious recently: her work e-mail address.

title: Tax Cut Casualties
description: The juxtaposition was perfect.

title: Sports of The Times; Broadway Joe Wants a West Side Stadium
description: IN rejoining the Jets as their ambassador at large, Joe Namath returned to the site of his New York baptism. Beyond a wide window in the Renaissance New York Hotel, noontime traffic moved through Times Square, the same but now different background used for the memorable Sports Illustrated cover heralding his rookie season in 1965 as a $427,000 quarterback.

title: Federal Reserve Lowers Key Rate To 1%, Lowest Level Since 1958
description: Trying to bring the long economic downturn to a halt at last, the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates by a quarter of a point today, taking them to their lowest level since 1958.

title: Airbus and Boeing Vie Aggressively for Big AirTran Order
description: Sales executives from Airbus SAS and the Boeing Company , the two competing commercial plane makers, have been meeting with AirTran Airways throughout the week to work out details of what would be one of the largest aircraft orders this year, Airbus and AirTran officials said today.

title: Court Won't Rule on Corporate Free Speech

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: New Sars Case
description: Just one day after the World Health Organization lifted its warning about travel to Beijing and declared that China had effectively won its battle against SARS, the country reported a fresh case of the disease. The case occurred in the southern province of Guangdong, where SARS originated late last year. The Chinese authorities and W.H.O. officials minimized the significance of the latest case, arguing that it just confirmed a diagnosis of a patient who had already been isolated. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Blair and Putin Say Their Disagreements Are Behind Them

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Gates Seeks Measures To Fight Spam
description: Bill Gates, who said unsolicited commercial e-mail was a ''spreading plague that feeds off the unique power of the Internet,'' has called on the technology industry to develop a strategy of self-regulation to deal with the problem. In a letter posted yesterday on the Microsoft Web site, Mr. Gates pointed to some of the measures his company has taken against spam. They included improved technology and more than a dozen civil lawsuits filed against companies and individuals that Microsoft asserts sent billions of spam messages in violation of state and federal laws.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hospitals Set Disaster Plan
description: One of New York City's major hospital chains has reached a $380 million agreement with I.B.M. that includes the creation of a disaster operations center in Rochester, where duplicate records will be kept and the hospitals' data centers can relocate in an emergency. Mount Sinai NYU Health is the latest in a long string of businesses to invest in such remote backup data centers -- in this case, for Mount Sinai Hospital, NYU Medical Center and NYU Downtown Hospital. The deal, to be announced today, was prompted in part by the terror attack of Sept. 11, when NYU Medical Center had to evacuate its main data center in Lower Manhattan. The I.B.M. pact also includes several other research and information management projects. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Senate Panel Approves Bill For Students With Disabilty

title: In London, Letting the Palm Trees Sway
description: What qualifies as a ''California-style'' building in London? It avoids ''the uptight rules of British architecture,'' said Piers Gough, of the London architects CZWG, who designed Fulham Island, a development in West London. There are Chilean palm trees in the courtyard, stainless steel planters and blue office buildings with oval windows. The complex, above, was developed by Manhattan Loft Corporation, which sold New York-style lofts in London in the 1990's. Fulham Island, Mr. Gough said, is intended to evoke the spirit of Southern California with brightness, color, window walls, seen in the apartment, inset, and ''a funky and laid-back look.'' One occupant is the expatriate American food critic and television host Loyd Grossman, who sits on the English Heritage Commission with Mr. Gough. The lofts sell for $1.2 million to $2 million; www.manhattanloft.co.uk.

At Harvard, the Berkman Center for Internet and Society has identified Web sites -- some surprisingly tame -- blocked by the governments of Saudi Arabia and China. At the University of Toronto, the Citizen Lab has developed a tool that will enable users to determine whether a Web address is blocked in any of 15 countries.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: CHALLENGE TO IMMUNITY LAW The Milan bribery trial of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi reopened, but Mr. Berlusconi did not attend. His lawyers deemed his presence unnecessary since the Parliament has passed a law giving him immunity from prosecution. The Milan prosecutor urged the judges trying him to consult the Supreme Court about the new law, in the hope that the court will deem it unconstitutional and force Mr. Berlusconi back to the courtroom. The opinion of the Supreme Court is expected to be sought on Monday, a day before Mr. Berlusconi takes over the rotating presidency of the European Union.

The stones that Mr. Rhodes, a principal of Rhodes Architectural Stone, a Seattle salvage firm, sought out were often to be found in quarries. Six years ago, though, Mr. Rhodes was in China hunting down a specific type of granite to use in building a house for Larry Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Rises
description: Brazil's jobless rate rose to 12.8 percent in May, its highest in more than a year, as high interest rates appeared ready to push the economy into recession. The government statistics agency IBGE said 2.7 million Brazilians were seeking jobs in May, compared with 2.6 million in April, when the unemployment rate was 12.4 percent. The average monthly income fell to 841 reais, or $290, 3 percent lower than in April and nearly 15 percent lower than May last year, the agency said. The central bank has raised its benchmark interest rate in recent months to a high of 26.5 percent. Last week it lowered the rate by 0.5 percentage point. Economic output contracted 0.1 percent in the first quarter and many economists are predicting more contraction in the second quarter. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Editor Is Leaving Us Weekly to Try Her Hand at Tabloids

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Capital Restrictions
description: Moving to regulate the flow of speculative capital, the Economy Ministry said that all foreign money coming into the country must stay for at least 180 days before being repatriated. A recent surge in short-term investments has contributed to an increase of more than 20 percent in the value of the peso against the dollar this year. That in turn has affected the government's anticipation of increased revenue from taxes on exports. ''The risks of a fluctuating exchange rate are quite serious, and we want to take preventive measures,'' Economy Minister Roberto Lavagna said. The controls will go into effect next week. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: The Nuclear Finds in Iraq
description: American officials were quite right to stress that the discovery of nuclear-related components and plans buried in an Iraqi scientist's garden in Baghdad is not a ''smoking gun'' that proves that Iraq had a nuclear weapon or an active program to develop one. Indeed, it looks more like the opposite, namely evidence that Iraq had abandoned for more than a decade its efforts to build a nuclear weapon but was hoping to start the program again later.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Sale Reconsidered
description: South Korea said it might shelve plans to sell a 9.3 percent stake in Kookmin Bank, the nation's largest commercial lender, after its shares plunged. ''Share prices have fallen so much,'' Byeon Yang Ho, the Finance Ministry's director general, said at a briefing in Seoul. ''We'd be doing the public a disservice by selling it now.'' South Korea, which agreed to sell control of Chohung Bank last week for 3.4 trillion won ($2.9 billion), is having second thoughts about Kookmin after a surge in bad loans pummeled bank shares this year.

description: The International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda will receive 18 backup judges to help speed up its work prosecuting central figures in the mass killings of ethnic Tutsi and moderate Hutu that took place in Rwanda in 1994. The General Assembly approved the additional judges in an effort to expedite a backlog of cases before the tribunal, which was set up in 1995 in Arusha, Tanzania. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Nasdaq Europe Closing
description: Nasdaq Europe, the struggling pan-European exchange based in Brussels, will be shut, its parent, the Nasdaq Stock Market of New York, said. Some of the 35 companies listed on the exchange have already found alternative listings and Nasdaq will help others move, the exchange said. The chief executive, Robert Greifeld, said Nasdaq would be concentrating on the United States market, where an increasing number of European companies are showing an interest in listing. The future of Nasdaq Deutschland, the German exchange, will be decided by the end of the year, Mr. Greifeld said. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Justices Void Prison Term Given Gay Teenager in Kansas
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  In one of the first consequences of its landmark ruling on gay rights on Thursday, the Supreme Court today set aside the lengthy prison sentence imposed on a gay Kansas teenager for having had sex with a younger boy.

title: Panel Supports More Spending on the Military
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  House members endorsed another increase in military spending today as the Appropriations Committee approved a $368.7 billion measure for the next fiscal year that is packed with new hardware and added money for special operations forces playing an increasing role in the military.
