description: ALIN--Edith. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, loving mother of Joyce Cohen and Richard and Susan Alin. Cherished grandmother of Andrea, Steven, Richard, Michael, David and Jon. title: European Union Votes 14-1 to Reform Agricultural Policy
description: Fourteen of the European Union's 15 governments voted today to overhaul their $49 billion common agricultural policy. And they challenged the United States to match what officials called their ''historic'' reforms. Only Portugal voted against the new rules.

title: Officials in India Divided On Sending Troops to Iraq
description: Opponents say it would betray the legacy of India's 60-year struggle against British colonial rule, or worse, send Indian soldiers home in body bags.

title: FEARS ASIDE, CITY AVOIDS STEEP CUTS
description: Fire marshals will no longer investigate most car fires. There will be 3,500 fewer police officers compared to three years ago. Inmates on Rikers Island will not get intensive drug counseling. And most city libraries are now open five days, instead of six.

title: Mixed Views In Pakistan On Amount Of U.S. Aid
description: The announcement made at Camp David on Wednesday that President Pervez Musharraf had won $3 billion in aid from the United States elicited a mixed reaction today in Pakistan, reflecting both political opposition to the president and a popular view that America should do more.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a hearing in South Africa for the first treason trial since the end of apartheid misstated the nature of the 1994 government change there. The transition was from white minority rule, not white majority rule.

description: HARDMAN--Virginia Mishnun. On June 23, 2003, in Gloucester, MA. Survived by two nephews, Joel and Harry Yohalem, and their families. Memorial service at 2 PM Sunday, June 29, at The Workmen's Circle, 45 E. 33 St. Contributions may be made to the International Rescue Committee, 122 E. 42 St., NY, NY 10168, or The Caring Community, 20 Washington Square North, NY, NY 10011. >>AD#

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: UrbanQ Agrees To Settle Rebate Case
description: UrbanQ, an Internet retailer, has agreed to settle charges that it neglected to send rebates it had promised to thousands of consumers, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday. As part of the settlement, UrbanQ, which is based in Cedarhurst, N.Y., must pay $600,000 in consumer redress. The operators of the Web site www.urbanq.com offered customers rebates on more than half the items for sale -- some of the rebates were for the total purchase price. ''A rebate is part of the deal with the consumer,'' said Howard Beales, the director of consumer protection at the trade commission. ''It's not just bait.'' UrbanQ sells clothes, toys, electronics and jewelry, among other items. The New York attorney general's office assisted the commission in its investigation. The settlement, which was filed in federal court in New York, requires approval from a judge there.

title: Gays Celebrate, and Plan Campaign for Broader Rights
description: Gay men and lesbians poured into the streets today to celebrate a Supreme Court decision striking down or strictly limiting the country's last remaining sodomy laws in 13 states.

title: Sports of The Times; A Hollywood Ending England Would Love
description: AN Englishman will win Wimbledon next year. Not only that, but the celebration has already taken place, with a bunch of people, draped in Union Jacks, cheering at Center Court.

title: Laundering Of Billions Is Alleged
description: A Midtown financial corporation was indicted yesterday on charges of illegally transmitting at least $3 billion from shell companies, private investors and foreign exchange houses to offshore accounts, cheating the city, state and federal governments out of tens of millions of dollars in taxes in what prosecutors called the largest scheme of the sort to be uncovered in New York City.

description: Two British scientists have proposed a radical strategy for preventing cardiovascular disease: a daily pill that would be prescribed to nearly all people older than 55, regardless of their risk of heart attack or stroke.

title: House and Senate Pass Measures For Broad Overhaul of Medicare
description: After a severe test of President Bush's influence on Capitol Hill, the Senate and the House today approved the biggest expansion of Medicare since its creation nearly four decades ago, passing legislation to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly and give private health plans a much larger role in the program.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Manhattan once teemed with Southern restaurants serving fried chicken, biscuits, baked Virginia ham and coconut cake. French chefs owned the top rung of the status hierarchy, but Southern cooks ran a not-too-distant second. It was taken for granted that Southerners cooked better, and ate better, than anyone else.

title: Gaffes Undermine Rookie's Debut
description: Hours before making his major league debut, Aaron Heilman sealed himself off from the outside world with a pair of padded earphones strapped to his head, his focus on painting the toe of his cleats with black shoe polish by his locker.

title: Fighting for Fairness at School
description: More than 40 state governments have been sued for failing to provide poor districts with enough money to educate their children up to the standards articulated in their state constitutions. About half of those states have been required to rewrite financing formulas, improve teacher training and do whatever it takes to provide all children with access to quality schools.

title: Drug Maker In Ireland Is Facing A New Crisis
description: The Elan Corporation, the financially troubled Irish drug maker whose shares trade in London, New York and Dublin, said today that it would be late in filing its annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission because it had not come to an agreement with the commission about how to account for some partnerships.

description: For about 40 years, John Ryan and his relatives have owned a wood-shingled summer house at the end of Surfside Avenue here. They have often spent their days playing touch football in a spacious yard between the deck and the bluffs that look out on the ocean. At night they have fallen asleep to the crashing of waves.

description: Everybody, it seems, wants a piece of Wimbledon's profits. While representatives of the men's tour are negotiating for a bigger chunk, British tax authorities are trying to determine which of the hundreds of village residents who rent their houses for the fortnight are not declaring the windfall.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Court Bars A Guggenheim Museum
description: A court in Rio de Janeiro ordered a halt to the city's plan to build a branch of the Guggenheim Museum at a waterfront site downtown, saying that as written, the contract with the Guggenheim Foundation violated Brazilian law. Mayor Cesar Maia said the municipal government would appeal the ruling but for the first time also expressed doubt about the future of the $160 million project, which left-wing parties argue is elitist, too expensive and a waste of public funds. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Laundry Union Drive
description: The Teamsters' union announced in Chicago that it was forming a partnership with the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, known as Unite, to seek to unionize Cintas, the nation's largest uniform rental company and industrial laundry. The Teamsters will try to organize about 7,000 truck drivers at Cintas while Unite tries to unionize about 10,000 production workers in the laundries. Cintas, based in Cincinnati, says unionization will hurt the spirit of cooperation within the company. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Putin and Blair Bury the Hatchet on Iraq, Citing Big Oil Deal
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said today that they had put their differences over Iraq behind them, and they pointed to new energy deals that will make Britain the world's largest foreign investor in Russia.

title: For Knicks, Draft Day Ends With Growth Spurt
description: As fans streamed into the Theater at Madison Square Garden for the N.B.A. draft last night, they were handed orange flyers proclaiming the availability of Knicks season tickets. It seemed like a safe bet that those who passed through the doors weren't buying any on the way out.

title: L.P.G.A. Looks at Wie and Sees Future
description: Sitting in front of a crowded room of reporters this afternoon, Michelle Wie answered questions deftly, looking almost as comfortable as she does on the first tee.

title: HCA AGREES TO PAY $631 MILLION TO RESOLVE FRAUD CLAIMS
description: HCA Inc., the hospital chain, will pay $631 million to resolve health care fraud allegations, the Justice Department said yesterday. HCA, based in Nashville, announced the settlement in December, though it still required approval from Justice Department officials in Washington. The agreement resolves allegations that the company filed false Medicare reports and paid doctors kickbacks to refer patients to company hospitals. HCA, formerly known as Columbia/HCA Healthcare, pleaded guilty to 14 criminal counts in December 2000 and later reached a separate settlement with Medicare. The company said yesterday it took an aftertax charge of $468 million in its fourth quarter, which ended in December.

title: $1 Billion Offered to Settle Suit on I.P.O.'s
description: Some 300 companies that sold new shares to the public during the late 1990's agreed yesterday to pay $1 billion to settle an investor lawsuit contending that the stock offerings' prices were artificially inflated.

title: London Journal; Cricket for Our Time: It's Highly Condensed
description: Fiona Boddy believes herself to be a woman of unusual patience. Yet, years after the fact, she still remembers the paint-drying tedium of the cricket match she attended in which nothing appeared to happen for hours on end.

title: Shopping List | Ice Cream
description: SCOOPS up! Independence Day, on the way, is the unofficial opening of ice cream season. It's the day to celebrate every American's birthright food, and for laggards, it's a chance to start fulfilling the annual per capita consumption: about 23 quarts per person. And that's not counting sorbet, Italian ices or other frozen treats which, this year, can be created in any number of cool ways. SUZANNE HAMLIN

title: For Shakers, Elegance Was Plain
description: ''The peculiar grace of a Shaker chair is due to the fact that it was built by someone capable of believing that an angel might come and sit on it,'' Thomas Merton, the American essayist and Trappist monk, once wrote.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Suspect Sought In Livery-Cab Robberies
description: The police yesterday sought the public's help in identifying a man who they believe has robbed three livery-cab drivers. In all three robberies, a man hailed a livery cab on the street at night, told the driver to take him to a remote area, and then, threatening the driver with a gun, demanded money and the car keys and ran off. The first two robberies took place in Harlem on May 13. The third, in which the suspect shot and injured the driver, was in the Bronx on May 15. The police have a photograph of the suspect, and asked anyone with information about the robberies to call 1-800-577-TIPS (1-800-577-8477). Michael Brick (NYT)

title: G.M. Raises $17.5 Billion In Huge Corporate Bond Sale
description: General Motors sold $17.5 billion worth of bonds yesterday as investors lined up to buy securities that were yielding as much as four full percentage points over comparable Treasuries.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bomb Scare At United Nations
description: The police swarmed the United Nations building yesterday after the discovery of a package that turned out to be a small bag and a canister filled with water. Guards called the police when the bag, found inside the visitors' entrance around 8 a.m., appeared to test positive for low levels of radiation. Fire officials said the false positive occurred because the bag was close to an X-ray machine. The visitors' center was closed while the bag was tested, but no other buildings were evacuated, a United Nations spokesman, Farhan Haq, said.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: POLICE BLAMED FOR CHILD STARVING TO DEATH Two policemen were dismissed and detained for investigation after a 3-year-old girl starved to death while her mother was in police custody, the local authorities said. The incident happened in the southern city of Chengdu after the police arrested the mother, who had a record as a drug addict, for theft. She told police officers that her young daughter was alone in their apartment with no relatives to care for her. But the police failed to contact any relatives or to rescue the child, who was found dead this week.    Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Israel and Palestinians Agree on Pullback in Gaza Strip
description: JERUSALEM, June 27 - Israeli and Palestinian leaders reached agreement tonight for Israeli forces to begin withdrawing from areas of the Gaza Strip and returning security control to Palestinian officers, officials close to the negotiations said.

title: Spinning Storytelling Yarn for a New Generation
description: ''Flow,'' a narrative monologue in rap written and performed by Will Power, is about how stories are passed down from one generation to another and about how storytelling changes. It's about the evolution of a culture, the new stories encompassing the old and adding to them, the new storytellers having not only new stories to tell but new ways to tell them.

title: Jos Tras Monge, 83, Puerto Rico Chief Justice
description: Jos Tras Monge, a former chief justice of Puerto Rico who helped create the island's commonwealth relationship with the United States but later denounced it as thinly disguised colonialism, died on June 24 in Boston. He was 83.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teenager Injured In Fall
description: After a night spent cruising Manhattan in a limousine after his high school prom in Suffolk County, a 17-year-old boy was critically injured when he fell from a Parsons Boulevard overpass onto the Grand Central Parkway, the police said yesterday. The boy, whose name was not released, his girlfriend and six friends had taken the limousine into Manhattan to go to a comedy club but were turned away, the police said. On the way back to Suffolk County, around 2:15 a.m. yesterday, the boy and his girlfriend argued. With the car parked on a service road, the boy got out, climbed a fence and fell from the overpass, the police said. He was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was treated for head injuries and was listed in critical condition. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Fed Minutes From Meeting in May Show Optimism
description: Federal Reserve policy makers kept the benchmark interest rate unchanged at their May 6 meeting because they expected that the end of major fighting in Iraq would lift the gloom overhanging businesses and accelerate the economic expansion, according to the meeting minutes released yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Britain Lifts Flight Ban
description: Kenyan officials rejoiced with the announcement that Britain had lifted a ban on flights to Nairobi put in place because of fears of a terrorist attack. The American Embassy said it was still reviewing its travel warning on Kenya. The advisories have caused significant damage to the country's important tourist industry. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: DELAY IS FORCING RAYTHEON TO TAKE $90 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Raytheon Company, the defense contractor, will record costs of $90 million in the second quarter because completion of a power plant in Massachusetts will be delayed by as much as a month. Raytheon said it would not be able to complete the plant, the Fore River plant in Weymouth, Mass., by June 30 because of unspecified technical issues. The plant will be finished in July, Raytheon said. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., still expects to meet or exceed its second-quarter forecast for profit, excluding some costs, of 24 to 26 cents a share. Costs for the plant and another that was recently completed have more than quadrupled to more than $1.3 billion. Raytheon sold the unit that was building the plants to Washington Group International Inc. in 2000 and was forced to complete the projects itself when Washington Group declared bankruptcy a year later.

title: Pillow Talk, Pillow Fight, All French, Of Course

title: A Cook Who Could Not Quit
description: ''MORE olives!'' my mother ordered. ''You need more olives!'' She was at the edge of the kitchen at my brother's house, and I was at the counter, already in a sweat. I had drained and diced the tomatoes, opened the tins of anchovies and a bottle of fancy capers and heated the olive oil in a big saucepan. The oven was preheating to 400 degrees.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the 4-year-old reign of King Abdullah II of Jordan misidentified his relationship to Abdullah I. The current king is his great-grandson, not his grandson.

title: SALE OF MEXICAN RAILROAD TO U.S. COMPANY ADVANCES
description: Mexico's Federal Competition Commission has approved the purchase of the Mexican railroad Grupo Transportacin Ferroviaria Mexicana by Kansas City Southern. Kansas City Southern will merge the Mexican railroad into its two United States lines to form Nafta Rail. Under the deal, announced April 21, Kansas City Southern will pay Ferroviaria's owner, the Mexican transport and logistics company Grupo TMM $200 million. TMM will have a 22 percent stake in the combined railroad. The deal still needs approval from Mexico's Foreign Investment Commission and from the Surface Transportation Board in the United States. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Long-Distance Service In Minnesota
description: Qwest Communications International Inc. won approval from federal regulators yesterday to sell long-distance service in Minnesota, where it is the biggest local carrier. Qwest and other regional phone companies must prove they have opened networks to rivals in states where they are the dominant local carriers before they can sell long distance in those areas. Qwest is now cleared to offer long-distance service in 13 of 14 states where it is the largest local operator, leaving Arizona as the only state where it needs approval from the Federal Communications Commission. The big local carriers are trying to sell more long-distance services after losing millions of lines to AT&T and other, new competitors in the local market. Minnesota regulators had argued for rejection of Qwest's application because of the company's failure to disclose discounts given to two local rivals who rent parts of Qwest's network in the state. Those actions resulted in a $26 million state fine that Qwest is appealing. Shares of Qwest rose 13 cents, to $4.90.

description: The Senate Commerce Committee approved a long list of new regulatory requirements today that would pressure automakers to improve safety on several fronts, including making sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks less prone to rolling over and less dangerous to other vehicles in collisions.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: East Hartford: Teenager Drowns In Pool
description: A 14-year-old boy drowned in a swimming pool yesterday afternoon, despite efforts of people nearby and rescue workers to revive him. The police and firefighters were called to 233 Ellington Road, the Gateway Apartment complex, by someone saying CPR was being performed on a child who had drowned. Rescuers continued efforts to save him, and he was taken to Hartford Hospital, where he was later pronounced dead, the Hartford police said. His name was not released last night. Tina Kelley (NYT)

description: Nextel Communications Inc., the only nationwide seller of a combined walkie-talkie and mobile telephone service, said yesterday that it expected to meet or beat 2003 forecasts with more customers and less spending. Nextel plans to sell by August an updated Direct Connect walkie-talkie phone service that will let users reach each other from anywhere in the United States, the chief executive, Timothy M. title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: BRAZIL: JOBLESS RATE RISES Brazil's jobless rate rose to 12.8 percent in May, its highest in more than a year, as high interest rates appeared ready to push the economy into recession. The government statistics agency IBGE said 2.7 million Brazilians were seeking jobs in May, compared with 2.6 million in April, when the unemployment rate was 12.4 percent. The average monthly income fell to 841 reais, or $290, 3 percent lower than in April and nearly 15 percent lower than May last year, the agency said. The central bank has raised its benchmark interest rate in recent months to a high of 26.5 percent. Last week it lowered the rate by 0.5 percentage point. Economic output contracted 0.1 percent in the first quarter and many economists are predicting more contraction in the second quarter. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: World Briefing | South Pacific: Troops To The Solomons
description: Australia and New Zealand said they would undertake an armed ''cooperative intervention'' in the Solomon Islands at the request of the government of the island republic, which is losing control to a three-year insurgency by rebel police and armed militants. The deployment of 2,000 troops will start next month. A meeting of the foreign ministers of South Pacific nations will discuss details in Sydney on Monday. ''There is no point in undertaking an operation like this in a half-hearted way,'' the Australian foreign minister, Alexander Downer, above, said on television. The Solomons, a former British protectorate, is an archipelago of several hundred islands scattered over 900 miles. It has a population of 500,000. John Shaw (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Cincinnati
description: HAS any city been more maligned by the media over the last 25 years than Cincinnati? On those rare occasions when it has merited any national coverage, journalists have snickered at the city's beady-eyed provincialism (the Robert Mapplethorpe trial), the outspoken former owner of the Reds (Marge Schott) who was forced out of baseball, and a pro football franchise that has become a punch line (the Bengals). The city's most visible export to the nation at large is probably Jerry Springer, who served as mayor from 1977 to 1981 and had his first talk show at the Westin Hotel on Fountain Square. Larry Flynt started Hustler magazine in this buttoned-up Republican burg. Not so funny is a history of racial polarization that gutted the downtown in the 70's and led to riots against police brutality in 2001. Well, for once the news from Cincinnati is upbeat and decidedly not sleazy. New art and architectural projects have put the city back on the cultural map. These attractions complement a distinguished group of well-established institutions, including the country's second oldest opera company. With an enviable array of public parks tucked among its many hills, and the temperamental Ohio River as a backdrop, the Queen City, as Longfellow dubbed it, is recovering some of its former luster. RICHARD B. WOODWARD

All have excellent views of the lapping waters of Prince's Bay, because they are built high atop poles. But the most striking thing about these dwellings is that they are the size of dollhouses. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aon Opens Office In Lower Manhattan
description: Aon Corporation, which lost 176 employees in the World Trade Center attack, celebrated the opening of its Lower Manhattan office at 199 Water Street yesterday, where 700 people will work. Aon, a large insurance company, had 1,151 workers in 2 World Trade Center, according to a New York State Web site, which noted that Aon would receive $15 million in city and state tax benefits over 15 years for staying in Lower Manhattan. ''It's a remarkable commitment to Lower Manhattan,'' Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development and rebuilding, said in an interview last night. ''It sends a critical signal to the rest of the business world that Manhattan's coming back, but it also says something really meaningful about the character of that company.'' Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Rice Urges European Union to Classify Hamas as Terrorist
description: Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, said today that the political wing of the militant Palestinian group Hamas should be added to the European Union's list of terrorist organizations. She called the group the single biggest threat to peace between Israel and the Palestinians.

title: Abbott to Pay $622 Million To End Inquiry Into Marketing
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it planned to pay $622 million to settle an investigation into sales practices for liquids needed to feed the seriously ill.

title: More Violence On Both Sides As Cease-Fire Is Awaited
description: As Palestinian officials said they were finishing the details of a three-month suspension of all violence against Israelis, Palestinian militant groups increased their attacks on Thursday, and Israeli forces killed three militants here today.

title: A Nowhere Striving to Be a Somewhere
description: AS Interstate 80 rolls out through the flat, monochromatic landscape of middle Nebraska, a 460-mile journey best made at the fastest speed possible, there is little to catch the eye but sagging telephone lines, askew fence posts and the occasional abandoned farmhouse decaying amid the fields.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Congressional committee testimony by a top State Department expert on chemical and biological weapons misstated the response of other officials from several intelligence agencies who were asked whether they had been pressured to tailor their analysis on Iraq and other matters to conform with the Bush administration's views. All said no; they did not remain silent.

title: Iraqi Says Hussein Planned to Revive the Nuclear Program Dismantled in 1991
description: The White House said today that an Iraqi scientist who led American forces to blueprints and prototype equipment for enriching uranium claimed Saddam Hussein had intended to revive his nuclear program as soon as the United Nations lifted sanctions against Iraq.

title: Justices Throw Out a Murderer's Death Penalty, Saying His Defense Was Inadequate
description: The Supreme Court spared the life of a convicted killer in Maryland today, declaring that his inexperienced lawyers had failed to represent him adequately at his trial 14 years ago.

title: U.S. Says 11 Trained for Terrorism Overseas
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Federal agents carried out raids in three states early today, rounding up men who officials said belonged to an anti-American terror group and were practicing for attacks in other countries.

description: The Hours

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: NEXTEL EXPECTS TO MEET OR BEAT FORECASTS Nextel Communications Inc. , the only nationwide seller of a combined walkie-talkie and mobile telephone service, said yesterday that it expected to meet or beat 2003 forecasts with more customers and less spending. Nextel plans to sell by August an updated Direct Connect walkie-talkie phone service that will let users reach each other from anywhere in the United States, the chief executive, Timothy M. Donahue, said. Sales will be $9.3 billion this year, with at least 1.7 million subscribers added, Nextel said in April. Shares of Nextel rose $1.21, or 7.1 percent, to $18.16.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALTMAN, , EDWIN J.
description: ALTMAN--Edwin J. On June 24, 2003 at age 90. Beloved husband of Glen, cherished father of Pat Falkenberg, Ginny Aaron and Tracy Warner. Dear father-in-law of Edward Falkenberg, Roger Aaron and Greg Warner. Loving grandfather of Chris, Kai and Merrill Falkenberg, Peter and Todd Aaron, Haley and Amanda Warner and greatgrandfather of Talia. He was a man of sharp mind with a commanding grasp of history and quick sense of humor. A keen business sense, always tempered by his fairness and integrity, earned him the admiration and affection of colleagues in the jewelry business for over 65 years, and the love of those with whom he worked closely. A raconteur who truly enjoyed people, he personified the glamour of New York throughout his life. His charm, his innate kindness, his smile, his unconditional love will be sorely missed and long remembered. Services on Friday, June 27, at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

description: One of the appealing qualities about the Jewish Museum is its ability to temper its gravitas by bringing humor -- satire, even -- to its shows and collections.

title: State Underfinancing Damages City Schools, New York Court Finds
description: New York State's method for financing education has shortchanged New York City to the point of creating systemic failure in its schools and depriving students of their constitutional right to a decent education, the state's highest court ruled yesterday.

title: Radio Ad Revenue Was Flat in May
description: Advertising revenue for radio was flat in May, the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York reported yesterday.

title: A Wheelchair User Can't Get on a Bus, So He Blocks One
description: The lack of access for disabled riders on New York City buses is a longstanding complaint of wheelchair users, but it is not an issue that normally makes headlines.

title: Differing Musical Bents in Tuneful Coexistence
description: An armistice in jazz's doctrinal disputes was apparently declared on Tuesday night when the trumpeter Randy Sandke led the Inside-Out Jazz Collective, topping a JVC Jazz Festival triple bill at Kaye Playhouse. Musicians associated with tonal, mainstream jazz and musicians associated with wild-eyed experimentalism cheerfully performed side by side, without fisticuffs or stylistic clashes.

title: On the Plains, Wily Buffalo Are Outfoxing Indians
description: People who live on the Umatilla Indian Reservation, a few miles from here on a vast grassy plain tucked in the high desert of northeastern Oregon, are used to seeing large animals on the loose. Elk, mountain sheep, deer, coyotes, cougars and the occasional wolf pass through these foothills of the Blue Mountains.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Detective Suspended
description: A detective was suspended last night and accused of failing to safeguard a prisoner, after a man who was being interviewed and fingerprinted in connection with an unarmed robbery escaped from the 25th Precinct station house on East 119th Street in East Harlem, the police said. The detective, Vincent King, was suspended, with pay, seven hours after the 22-year-old prisoner, whose name was not released, escaped from the second- floor interview room yesterday afternoon. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Charlie Chaplin, All Dressed Up
description: In the beginning (of DVD), some of Charlie Chaplin's feature films were released by Image Entertainment. Those DVD's were made from masters used for laser discs. ''They were top of the line in 1992, but what was good on laser disc doesn't translate well onto DVD,'' said George Feltenstein, senior vice president for classic catalogs of Warner Home Video.

title: U.S. Executive Berates Korean Businesses and Unions
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 27  In unusually blunt remarks, the American insurance executive Maurice R. Greenberg berated South Korean regulators and labor unions today for tactics that he said discouraged potential foreign investors from going into business here.

title: Mystery Persists: What Happened To Woman Found in River?
description: The city medical examiner's office said yesterday that it has been unable to determine whether a woman who vanished on the Upper East Side earlier this year and was found in the East River died in an accident, a homicide or a suicide, leaving unresolved one of the year's most perplexing mysteries.

title: WPP GROUP REACHES AGREEMENT WITH CORDIANT LENDER
description: The WPP Group, one of the world's largest advertising and marketing companies, said the last remaining lender to Cordiant Communications Group agreed to sell its debt for 90 million ($149.5 million) including fees, paving the way for WPP's acquisition of the company. WPP, which is based in London, said last week that it planned to buy Cordiant for 266 million in debt and stock to expand its reach in Asia and Latin America. That amount did not include 11 million in fees and costs announced today.

title: Driver's Ed That Was Covered in Blood
description: The best way to see ''Hell's Highway,'' which opens today in Manhattan, might be on a double bill with ''2 Fast 2 Furious.'' Yes, one is a scholarly documentary and the other a dunderheaded action picture, but both, in their different ways, offer testimony to the love affair between the movie camera and the automobile. ''2 Fast'' celebrates the thrills of recklessness and speed, while ''Hell's Highway'' examines their grisly consequences.

title: Courting the Rare Big Order for Planes
description: Sales executives from Airbus and Boeing have been meeting with AirTran Airways this week to try to land what would be one of the largest aircraft orders this year, Airbus and AirTran officials said yesterday.

title: Sons and Daughters Of the Successful
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Limits the Prosecution Of Sexual Abusers of Children
description: The Supreme Court dealt a serious defeat today to prosecutors who pursue people accused of molesting children, ruling 5 to 4 that the government cannot erase statutes of limitations retroactively.

title: Happy Days Are Virtually Here Again
description: Political wonks eagerly await the government's quarterly report next week on the fund-raising totals by the nine Democratic presidential candidates. For Americans not engaged by raw money as a worthy denominator of political life, there is an alternate universe of pre-primary competition at work -- a virtual primary on the Internet this week run by a pressure group on the Democratic left called MoveOn.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Emissions Law Is Enacted
description: Gov. John Baldacci signed legislation that requires the state to reduce carbon dioxide emissions to 1990 levels by 2010, and an additional 10 percent by 2020, making Maine the first state to pass a comprehensive law addressing global warming. The legislation is one of a number of state-level climate change initiatives that have emerged since the United States pulled out of the Kyoto Protocol. Maine officials said they were motivated partly by evidence that climate change might already be affecting the state's environment. According to the federal Environmental Protection Agency, the average temperature in Lewiston has risen by 3.4 degrees in the past century, and rainfall has fallen by up to 20 percent in many parts of the state. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEN, , CAROL LEE
description: SHEN--Carol Lee. 56, of Brooklyn Heights, NY passed away on June 25, 2003 of cancer. We will remember Carol for her loving and caring nature, her grace and generosity of spirit, her unpretentious and patient approach to life, her delight in seeking and encouraging the best in those around her, and her ability to make us laugh. She has been and will always be our inspiration, and will remain forever in the hearts of family and friends, especially her husband Ted, her daughter Carla, her father Chin, her brother Glenn, and her sister Barbara. A memorial service will be held in the chapel of The Packer Collegiate Institute, 170 Joralemon St, Brooklyn, NY on July 10th at 4:30 PM. Contributions may be made to The Hope Program, 1 Smith St, Brooklyn, NY 11201, or to the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, New York 11238.

title: Spared by a Virus But Not by Mankind
description: When ''28 Days Later'' is not scaring you silly, it invites you to reflect seriously on the fragility of modern civilization, which has been swept away by a gruesome and highly contagious virus while the hero lies peacefully in a coma. Four weeks after a laboratory full of rage-infected monkeys has been liberated by some tragically misguided animal rights militants, the whole of London -- and possibly every place else -- has been substantially depopulated. The churches and alleyways are littered with corpses, and fast-moving, red-eyed ''infecteds'' roam the streets looking for prey. Even the rats flee from them, and the few healthy humans face a Hobbesian battle for survival.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Categories Added For Violent Games
description: The United States industry group that assigns ratings to video games added new categories yesterday to distinguish the violence in cartoon-style games from the graphic depictions in titles like Doom and Grand Theft Auto: Vice City. The Entertainment Software Rating Board, an industry-financed group that has been applying ratings to games since 1994, is placing new titles in four categories -- cartoon violence, fantasy violence, intense violence and sexual violence -- to give buyers a better idea of the games' content. Washington State passed a law last month aimed at keeping children from buying games that depict violence against police, more than two years after St. Louis banned the sale of violent titles to minors. The ban was struck down by a United States appeals court, which said the measure was prohibited by the Constitution. Violent video games are often among the industry's top sellers and draw publicity as improving computer graphics make it possible to produce more lifelike images.

title: New York Summer of World Music Live
description: A wide variety of world music artists are scheduled for concerts in New York City this summer. Many will perform at Summerstage, in Central Park at the Rumsey Playfield, midpark at 69th Street, (212) 360-2777, and Celebrate Brooklyn!, at the Prospect Park Bandshell, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street, Park Slope, (718) 855-7882, ext. 45. Unless otherwise noted, Summerstage concerts are at 3 p.m. Admission to Summerstage and Celebrate Brooklyn! concerts is by donation ($3 suggested). Other sites include Makor, 35 West 67th Street, (212) 601-1000; admission $15 unless noted; and S.O.B.'s (Sounds of Brazil), 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940; tickets $18 in advance, $22 on the day unless noted. A festival of Brazilian music sponsored by Lincoln Center will take place from July 16 to 20 at the La Guardia High School for the Performing Arts, Amsterdam Avenue and 65th Street. Tickets to all but one performance are $30 ($20 for students); a July 19 concert is $35. Information: (212) 875-5766 or (212) 721-6500. ''Pa' Colombia: Ritmo, Sabor y Sentimento,'' a concert featuring the Colombian artists Joe Arroyo, Aterciopelados, Los Internacionales Diabilitos, Charlie Zaa, Grupo Gale and La India Meliyara y Su Sonora, is scheduled for July 19 at Madison Square Garden, 33rd Street and Seventh Avenue; information: (212) 465-6741. Screenings of the film ''Amandla! A Revolution in Four-Part Harmony'' (2002) are planned at Makor from July 14 to 17; tickets, $9.

title: United Way to Form Its Own Social Programs
description: In a major overhaul aimed at increasing its effectiveness and accountability, the board of the United Way of New York City voted yesterday to abandon its traditional role of middleman between donor and charity and set up its own social welfare programs instead.

description: With vows to carry on the fight for closed firehouses and laid-off employees, the New York City Council overwhelmingly passed a $43.7 billion budget yesterday that includes income, sales and property tax increases but maintains many services.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BIDS FOR TOY STORE The British book- store owner Tim Waterstone entered the bidding war for Hamleys, a leading operator of toy stores, with an offer of 230 pence a share. The bid from the owner of the Waterstone's chain topped that of Soldier Ltd., which had raised its own offer earlier in the day to 225 pence a share from 205 pence after Mr. Waterstone said he was considering a bid of his own. Soldier, a management buyout company, is backed by an Icelandic retailer, Baugur. Stock in Hamleys, which has its flagship store on London's Regent Street, rose by 11 percent, to 232 pence. Alan Cowell (NYT)

description: The state's Board of Education passed a resolution asking schools to stop using Indian names for logos, mascots and other insignia. Although the resolution is not enforceable, the board apparently hopes that the approximately 75 schools and universities in Michigan that use Indian names will change. Caitlin Nish (NYT)

title: Palestinians Urge Smaller Factions to Join Truce
description: JERUSALEM, June 28  Seeking the first complete suspension of Palestinian violence against Israelis after 33 months of conflict, Palestinian leaders reached beyond Hamas and Islamic Jihad today to persuade other, smaller factions to join in an announcement planned with those two groups for Sunday, Palestinian officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: SK Global Plan Is Protested
description: Foreign creditors of SK Global, meeting in Hong Kong, said the company's plan for disposing of $2.4 billion of its debt was inadequate. The creditors, who are owed $762 million, demanded more than the equivalent of 38 cents on the dollar, the terms accepted by the company's domestic creditors. A spokesman for Hana Bank, the main domestic creditor, said he still hoped for a compromise with the foreign creditors. If SK Global were liquidated, he said, the creditors would get far less. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Chief Justice Leaves
description: With the start of his impeachment trial on 22 charges of malfeasance and illegal conduct while in office less than two weeks away, the chief justice of the Supreme Court resigned. Julio Nazareno, a close associate of the disgraced former president, Carlos Menem, stepped down three weeks after the new president, Nstor Kirchner, accused him of attempting political blackmail in hopes of staying in office. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Even Upstate, a Summer Snowbank Is an Oddity
description: There are few things in nature as ugly as a snowbank in late June. What was once the whitest white is now a muddy berm with fissures and cracks, melting into puddles of brown water.

title: 17-Year-Old in Critical Condition After Jumping Onto Parkway
description: ALong Island teenager remained in critical condition yesterday, a day after he jumped from an overpass and onto the Grand Central Parkway, a police detective said.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: A Diamond Rally
description: Shares of Ashton Mining of Canada Inc. more than doubled after the company, which explores for diamonds, said it found a stone estimated at four carats in an ore sample taken in Quebec. The company found the stone while sorting through 17 tons of samples at its laboratory. The diamond is still embedded in ore, so its exact measurements and weight have not been determined, an Ashton Mining spokeswoman, Salimah Lalli, said. The discovery eased concern that the diamond deposit in the Otish Mountains is too small to mine profitably, said Barry Allan, a mining analyst at the Research Capital Corporation. Ashton Mining's shares rose 1.44 Canadian dollars, to 2.56 Canadian dollars, on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
