title: National Briefing | Politics: Online Vote Goes For Dean
description: Former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont led Democratic presidential contenders in an online primary organized by a liberal group. But strong support for Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio kept Dr. Dean from securing the endorsement. The group, Moveon.org, said it would endorse any candidate who drew at least 50 percent of the votes. The group and its 1.5 million members have raised millions of dollars for left-leaning candidates. More than 300,000 ballots were cast by e-mail, the group said. Dr. Dean received 44 percent, and Mr. Kucinich 24. Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts finished third with 16 percent. The other six candidates failed to crack the single digits. John Files (NYT)

title: Adequacy in Education: Why Is Clear. But How?
description: The landmark ruling on Thursday by New York's highest court that the state is shortchanging New York City's school system was a much-needed victory for its 1.1 million students. But in itself, the ruling is not a remedy. It's just one step in a complex and uncertain process that dozens of states, from New Jersey to California, have been struggling with for years.

title: Long Island Gym Teacher Is Acquitted of All Charges in Sex Case
description: A Long Island elementary school gym teacher who had been accused of inappropriately touching nine young girls during class was acquitted of all the charges yesterday in Nassau County District Court in Mineola, his lawyer said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDFIN, , ALFRED
description: GOLDFIN--Alfred ''Shakey'' on June 25, 2003. Husband of the late Dollyann (nee Micklin) Goldfin of Moorestown. Father of Hugh Scot (Sonny) Goldfin, Robin Ellis Goldfin, Pamala (Jack) Goldfin Clowar, Avery Austin Goldfin, Craig Julian Goldfin and Glen Marc Goldfin. Brother of Joyce Goldfin. Grandfather of Micky Goldfin and Shayne Skylar Clowar. Al was the founder and president of Alfred Goldfin, Inc. Born in the Bronx, he was a 1947 graduate of Stuyvesant High School. Relatives and friends are invited to services Sunday, 12:30PM, Platt Memorial Chapels, Inc. 2001 Berlin Road, Cherry Hill, NJ. >>AD#

title: Pakistanis Protest Offer Of Iraq Force
description: President Pervez Musharraf's suggestion this week that Pakistan might send troops to Iraq has set off a storm of protest here with opposition parties saying the president had no right to pledge such a force.

title: Nassau Reaches Tentative Pact With Union on 5-Year Contract
description: Nassau County officials have reached a tentative agreement with the county's major labor union for a five-year contract that they say includes the smallest pay increases in county history and is a giant step toward solving its fiscal crisis.

title: A Knicks Draft Pick Is Still an Ocean Away
description: The wait seemed endless for Maciej Lampe. As each selection was announced in the N.B.A. draft on Thursday night, he would wait to hear his name, then slump in disappointment until he was finally chosen by the Knicks with the first pick of the second round.

title: Strom Thurmond, Senate Institution Who Fought Integration, Dies at 100
description: Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, a central figure in the political transformation of the South and the longest-serving senator in American history, died on Thursday in Edgefield, S.C. He was 100.

title: Inflation Eases, But Other Worries Build Up in Brazil
description: A clash this week between Rio de Janeiro riot police and some 15,000 desperate unemployed people jostling to sign up for jobs as street sweepers and garbage collectors was a stark sign that President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva needs to take swift action to get Brazil's sputtering economy growing again.

title: Crime Scene Or Rescue? Man in Chimney Causes a Clash
description: It started with a hapless would-be burglar stuck in a chimney in Queens. Add a few hours in the sweltering city, a scuffle between members of elite police and fire rescue units and a descending horde of television cameras, and all of a sudden the mayor was calling an emergency meeting with his top police and fire officials.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Medicare Legislation Goes To Conference Committee

title: Ulcer Drug
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Thurmond Lived, Died and Was Forgiven
description: When Strom Thurmond died yesterday, it was like the ocean drying up.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Congressional committee hearings on chemical and biological weapons misspelled the given name of a Democratic representative from Texas who questioned officials from intelligence agencies. He is Silvestre Reyes, not Silvestro.

title: Powell Hails Man Who Cited Pressure on Iraq Data
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has offered public support for the department expert who told Congress that he felt pressured to make his intelligence reports on Iraq and other matters conform to administration policy.

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: ECONOMY SHRINKS Canada's economy contracted in April for the first time since late 2001, Statistics Canada said. Gross domestic product dropped 0.2 percent, adjusted for inflation, after being unchanged in March. The growth rate for the year to April was 1.8 percent. Manufacturing and oil and gas exploration were among the weakest sectors. Hotels and restaurants were hit hard by the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, in Toronto. In recent years, Canada has posted the strongest growth among major industrial countries. But the slowdown in the United States and a sharp appreciation of the Canadian dollar have put a brake on the economy. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Dollars Are Driving A.C.C. Dispute
description: The conflict between the Big East and Atlantic Coast Conferences has been more difficult to follow than a game of three-card monte, and has often been just as unseemly. Who is in and who is out? Who is going where? And which colleges, exactly, are the plaintiffs and which are the defendants in a lawsuit filed to halt the A.C.C.'s expansion?

title: Roll Call in Central Park
description: Six people were clustered around a tree in Central Park yesterday, enraptured by a fungus, when Jeffrey James Keyes happened by. He stopped and observed the group's behavior, making no sudden movements. The mushroom enthusiasts continued chatting and gesturing excitedly. They ignored him completely.

title: Both Income And Spending Were Higher Last Month
description: Consumers spent more money in May for a third consecutive month and incomes rose, pointing to a second-half pickup in the economy, government figures showed yesterday.

title: Sara Ann Freed, 57, an Award-Winning Editor of Mystery Books
description: Sara Ann Freed, an award-winning editor of crime fiction, died on Wednesday. She was 57 and lived in New York City.

title: Want Something Healthy With That?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEN, , CAROL
description: SHEN--Carol. The Trustees and staff of the Brooklyn Museum of Art record with deep sorrow the death of our wonderful friend and volunteer, the loving wife of Trustee Theodore Shen, and mother of Carla, and extend heartfelt sympathies to all the members of the Shen family and friends. Robert S. Rubin, Chair Arnold L. Lehman, Director >>AD#

title: Saving the Whales, Again
description: The International Whaling Commission has decided to give whale conservation another chance. The commission tried to curtail the killing of these endangered creatures with a moratorium on commercial whaling in 1986, but it had too many loopholes and some countries just ignored it. Now it has decided to devise and oversee specific conservation strategies, in concert with international environmental organizations.

title: New York Lobbying Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Aid Gives United's Parent a Profit
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, yesterday reported a net income of $64 million for May, helped by $300 million in federal aid for costs related to the Iraq war. It also said it met bankruptcy loan terms for the fourth straight month.

title: By Bank of Japan Standards, New Chief Is an Activist
description: The rarefied world of central banking is an intentionally opaque one, and it can take months or years to discern whether a new bank governor is succeeding or falling flat. Their public utterances are generally few and obscure, and the causal links between monetary policy and the performance of the economy are unclear.

title: Milking the Barest Chance With the Sneakiest Ruse
description: The strongest tournaments, judged by the playing records of the stars, have always been the world championships and the American Nationals. There is now another. It is the European Open Championships, which are drawing to a close in Menton, on the French Riviera. Hundreds of national and international champions are taking part.

title: Rain Forest Is Losing Ground Faster in Amazon, Photos Show
description: Newly released satellite images show that the Amazon rain forest is disappearing at an increasing rate, with about 10,000 square miles lost mainly to pasture land, soybean plantations and illegal logging in the 12-month period that ended last August.

title: NESTL TO SPEND $150 MILLION TO REORGANIZE DREYER'S
description: Nestl plans to spend $150 million this year and in 2004 to cut jobs and combine factories at its ice cream business in the United States after buying Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc. for $2.8 billion. The changes, which also include $47 million in asset write-downs and charges for combining the companies' delivery networks, will produce savings of $185 million annually by 2006, the chief financial officer, Wolfgang Reichenberger, said on a conference call. Nestl, the maker of Hagen-Dazs, and Dreyer's will control about a fifth of the $21 billion ice cream market in the United States.

title: Incredible Hulk of a Budget
description: The $43.7 billion spending plan that Mayor Michael Bloomberg and the City Council finally agreed on late this week was the biggest ever, and so was the monster $6.4 billion budget gap that made getting to a balanced bottom line a Herculean feat. The mayor and Gifford Miller, the Council speaker, brought a civilized end to a daunting process that could easily have turned ugly. More important to New Yorkers, services from trash collection to senior centers, destined for cuts just weeks ago, were saved.

title: BMC INDUSTRIES TO SHIFT WORK FROM EUROPE TO NEW YORK
description: BMC Industries, a maker of eyeglass lenses and components for television screens, said yesterday that it planned to move some operations to New York from Europe, affecting 375 employees. The company also said it had hired an adviser to explore options that include the sale of some assets, and that it might fail to meet the terms of its loan agreements. BMC, which is based in Minneapolis, said its Buckbee-Mears unit would begin using a plant in Cortland, N.Y. The company hired William Blair & Company to help evaluate its alternatives. Expenses related to moving the operations will reduce pretax profit in the second quarter by $22 million to $27 million, the company said. A plant in Tatabanya, Hungary, will be closed, BMC said.

title: San Francisco Drops Charges Against Most War Protesters
description: The district attorney's office today dismissed infractions against 407 people arrested in March in antiwar protests here and also indicated that it would not pursue charges against all but about 20 of the others who were arrested.

title: Mets See The Good And Bad In Reyes
description: Jos Reyes said he thought about a double when he saw that his ground ball would go slightly to the left of second base and into left-center field, forcing Yankees center fielder Hideki Matsui to chase it. Reyes sped down the first-base line and kept going to second, surprising Matsui, who casually threw the ball in as Reyes slid in safely headfirst.

title: Small-Town Humanity In Easy Song
description: Neil Young has never put on a show like ''Greendale,'' the self-described ''musical novel'' he performed at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. For about 95 minutes he and his band, Crazy Horse, played all 10 songs from ''Greendale,'' which he will release as an album and a DVD in August. Around them, a cast of dozens acted out the skein of narratives and lip-synched Mr. Young's vocals and harmonica, with homey sets (a front porch, a jail) and video backdrops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GABA, , DORA L.
description: GABA--Dora L. Peacefully on June 26, 2003, at age 99. Beloved wife of the late Herman Gaba. Cherished mother and mother-in-law of Daniel and Rhoda Schiff Gaba, Richard and Barbara Kahn Gaba; loving grandmother of Marjorie and Stephen Shapiro, Suzanne and Dr. James Aisenberg, Steven Gaba and Amy Beckman, Michael and Dr. Nancy Gaba; adoring greatgrandmother of Clifford and Edward Shapiro, Jonathan and Nathaniel Aisenberg, Ethan and Naomi Gaba, Jacob and Joshua Gaba; dear aunt of Joseph and Rita Cohen. A Woman of Valor--To Dora With Love! Funeral services, Sunday, June 29, 2003 at 1:00 PM ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY. >>AD#

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Approval For Shipping Channel
description: The Army Corps of Engineers said the channel where a charter boat, the 32-foot Taki Tooo, capsized in 15-foot waves was safe for navigation. The corps advanced its annual survey of Tillamook Bay one month after the accident on June 14 that left nine people dead and two missing. Sonar found the channel deeper than the required 18 feet, a corps spokesman, Luke Wilson, said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: In Fallout From Draft, Bucks Trade Cassell
description: Sam Cassell, that well-traveled scoring machine, is on the move again. In a deal that helped clarify Thursday night's N.B.A. draft, the Milwaukee Bucks traded Cassell and Ervin Johnson to the Minnesota Timberwolves for Joe Smith and Anthony Peeler yesterday.

title: Ways to Flout Cabaret Law As Varied as Dance Steps
description: When Michael Cavadias was spinning records in New York's illegal dance clubs, he used a secret weapon to evade the city's cabaret laws: the Beatles.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VALERO ENERGY CORP., San Antonio, said it had won court approval to purchase a 185,000-barrel-a-day oil refinery and fuel inventories in Louisiana from Orion Refining Corp., Norco, La., for $530 million.

title: INSIDE
description: Charges in Terror Inquiry

title: Grand Stage for Pitching Prospect's Yankee Debut
description: When Brandon Claussen takes the mound at Shea Stadium tonight, 57,000 people will be watching him, Tom Glavine will be pitching against him and the pressure of a crosstown rivalry will be on his shoulders. No matter what, it will be a memorable major league debut.

title: Strom Thurmond's Century
description: There was a time when Strom Thurmond was famous for resisting desegregation. There was a much longer time when Strom Thurmond was famous merely for being old. Yet the most interesting thing about Mr. Thurmond's long life and public career -- nearly half his 100 years were spent serving South Carolina in the United States Senate -- is the way it reflected the profound changes in the world around him. Though there was nothing particularly grand about Mr. Thurmond, his story traces the historic evolution of a Southern culture crippled by prejudice into something healthier and more welcoming.

title: Nevada Turns to Brothels as a Budget Fix
description: Dennis Hof is known around the state of Nevada as ''America's pimp,'' an honorific he holds to be a statement of fact, and he works hard to maintain his title.

title: Hiding In Plain Sight
description: I know, roughly, where the most wanted fugitives from the war in Bosnia are hiding. It is clear that NATO and the authorities in Serbia and Montenegro know even more about their whereabouts. Yet these fugitives, Radovan Karadzic and Gen. Ratko Mladic, are still at large.

title: Inquiry Into Currency Trading Ends
description: FXall, an electronic currency trading system set up by some large banks, said yesterday that the Justice Department dropped a three-year investigation into how the firm handled trading in the $1.2-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market.

title: A Library In Cuba: What Is It?
description: One of the last places you might expect a debate over free expression is the American Library Association, the world's oldest and largest organization of its kind and a longtime champion of open access to information. But when the subject is as politically charged as Cuba, anything is possible.

title: Pentagon Delays Releasing 5 Syrians Hurt in U.S. Raid
description: The Defense Department has delayed the release of five Syrian border guards wounded last week in an American attack on an Iraqi convoy near the Syrian border, American officials said today.

title: The Memories of a Jew, Now Honored by Vienna
description: THE stories do not stop any more than history does for Frederic Morton, whether they spill from his writer's pen or are drawn from his immense store of memories and anecdote-rich knowledge of Vienna itself.

title: A Seeker of Music's Poetry in the Mathematical Realm
description: ''I am sorry now that I did not write an opera with her every year,'' Virgil Thomson once wrote about Gertrude Stein. ''It had not occurred to me that both of us would not always be living.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOSELSON, , JUDITH
description: NOSELSON--Judith (nee Lesnow), having just celebrated her 70th birthday. Beloved wife of Kal Noselson for 46 years. Adored and adoring mother, grandmother and mother-in-law of Betsy, Michael, Katie and Max Hockstein; Susie, Rob, Fannie and Moe Koltun; and the late Adam Noselson. Also survived and already missed by an extended family of cousins and friends. A family gathering of remembrance will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, consider a donation to the NYU Cancer Institute. >>AD#

title: NBC Is Said To Be Pressing Vivendi Offer
description: Intent on surviving the first cut in the bidding for Vivendi Universal's entertainment assets, NBC is seeking to reaffirm the seriousness of its proposal for a joint venture, according to senior executives close to NBC's strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLBERT, , MELVIN H.
description: GOLBERT--Melvin H. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Devoted father of Ellen Magdassi, Stan, and the late Steven. Loving grandfather of Dana, Talia, and Noa. Brother of Helen Goldsmith. Services Sunday, 2:00 PM at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: $1.6 Billion Deal Creates Area's 2nd-Biggest S.&L.
description: The New York Community Bancorp said yesterday that it was buying the Roslyn Bancorp for $1.6 billion in stock, forming one of the largest savings and loan associations in the New York area.

title: Board Named to Investigate Crash of a Plane Prototype
description: NASA has named an investigative board to look into the crash of a record-setting, remote-controlled wing plane that was lost off Hawaii on Thursday during a test flight, the agency announced today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Telecom Stake Offered
description: The German telephone company Deutsche Telekom is offering to sell its 24.8 percent stake in the Philippine cellular company Globe Telecom to its partners, Singapore Telecommunications Ltd. and the Ayala Corporation. Singapore Telecommunications, Southeast Asia's largest phone company, said that with Ayala it would decide within 45 days whether to take up the offer. Deutsche Telekom has been selling assets and cutting spending to help it return to profit, after posting the biggest loss in European history last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEDULD, , SADIE
description: GEDULD--Sadie. Musician, mother, grandmother and sister. Services Sunday 11:30AM at I.J. Morris, Hempstead, L.I. >>AD#

title: Into Africa
description: To the delight of its liberal critics, the Bush administration has taken a constructive interest in the problems of Africa. Mr. Bush's trip to South Africa, Botswana, Uganda, Niger and Senegal early next month symbolizes that concern. So does the administration's promises of increased aid, its global H.I.V./AIDS initiative and its outspokenness for African democracy.

title: Zimbabwean Urges U.S. to Act Cautiously Against Mugabe
description: Seizing on President Bush's call for a change in leadership in Zimbabwe, the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai said today that his Movement for Democratic Change was developing a plan it hoped would lead to a peaceful transition of power in a country rocked by political and economic strife.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: CHIEF JUSTICE LEAVES With the start of his impeachment trial on 22 charges of malfeasance and illegal conduct while in office less than two weeks away, the chief justice of the Supreme Court resigned. Julio Nazareno, a close associate of the disgraced former president, Carlos Menem, stepped down three weeks after the new president, Nestor Kirchner, accused him of attempting political blackmail in hopes of staying in office. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bids For Toy Store
description: The British bookstore owner Tim Waterstone entered the bidding war for Hamleys, a leading operator of toy stores, with an offer of 230 pence a share. The bid from the owner of the Waterstone's chain topped that of Soldier Ltd., which had raised its own offer earlier in the day to 225 pence a share from 205 pence after Mr. Waterstone said he was considering a bid of his own. Soldier, a management buyout company, is backed by an Icelandic retailer, Baugur. Stock in Hamleys, which has its flagship store on London's Regent Street, rose by 11 percent, to 232 pence. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 21 about a fund-raising event for President Bush on the Reynolds Plantation in Greensboro, Ga., misidentified the setting. It was the Ritz Carlton Lodge, not the Four Seasons Hotel.

title: At 13, She Already Has Tiger in Her Sights
description: She has been a teenager for only eight months, but golf aficionados already know her as much by sight as by name.

title: In Brooklyn Woman's Path, A Story of Caribbean Striving
description: It all began in the Glamor Girl lingerie factory back in Trinidad, where friendships formed amid the ceaseless procession of nighties and negligees. A young checker, Beulah Reid, began dreaming of a house of her own. And a web of personal connections wove itself around her.

title: A Major Victory for Gay Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Want Something Healthy With That?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Few Gay Americans Tie the Knot in Canada
description: Linda Chopra and Linda Sperry, a lesbian couple from Cleveland, were planning to come to Toronto for a librarians' convention anyway. But when they read the news that Canada was now recognizing same-sex marriage, they decided to fill their trip with a whole lot more than the latest tips about reference books.

title: David Newman, 66; First Screenplay Was 'Bonnie and Clyde'
description: David Newman, the screenwriter who collaborated with the director Robert Benton on the groundbreaking crime-spree film ''Bonnie and Clyde,'' died yesterday in Manhattan. He was 66.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GORDON, , KENNY
description: GORDON--Kenny. 6/28/7212/20/98. Darling Kenny, your loss has left an irreplaceable void in our hearts. The warmth of your love and the joy of your laughter are always with us. We miss you more with each passing day. Love, Mom, Dad and Jonn

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Extend Decision On Gay Rights and Equality
description: In an immediate application of its new protective approach to gay rights, the Supreme Court today vacated the sodomy conviction of a Kansas teenager who received a 17-year sentence for having oral sex with a younger boy.

title: Russia Arrests Two in Killing Of an Opposition Lawmaker
description: A Russian court issued warrants today for the arrest of two men suspected of killing an opposition member of Parliament. It was the second set of arrests this week in the politically charged case.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: High-Speed Web Use Grows
description: The number of Japanese using high-speed Internet connections topped 10 million in May, a tenfold increase from two years ago. Three-quarters of all high-speed connections use asymmetric digital subscriber lines, with the remainder connected via cable or fiber optics. More than 22 percent of homes in Japan now have broadband access. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Grass Surface Suits Roddick and Federer Just Fine
description: A change in surface can change a young tennis star's mood in a hurry. A month ago, Andy Roddick and Roger Federer could not win a match between them on clay at the French Open, but on the grass of the All England Club, they have been the most impressive performers during the first week of Wimbledon.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: BRIDGESTONE RAISES OUTLOOK Japan's largest tire maker, the Bridgestone Corporation , raised its profit forecast by 10 percent, to 77 billion yen ($642 million), citing improvement in exports, brisk sales in North America and benefits from the rise of the euro against the yen. The new profit target for the year ending Dec. 31 represents a 70 percent increase from last year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: About New York; First Summer Of the Rest Of Her Life
description: LEARNING the correct time can be a challenge at Public School 29, thanks to its collection of free-spirited wall clocks. It might be 8:45 at one end of the hall, 11:04 at the other end, and 6:35 in the classroom. At any given moment a student might want to eat breakfast, finish that quiz, or just call it a day.

title: Plan Urged to Repair Shuttle During Flight
description: The board investigating the loss of the space shuttle Columbia gave NASA its most difficult recommendation yet: to develop a way to repair the shuttle while it is in space.

title: Mr. Diversity
description: Whatever you think of the jurisprudence of Clarence Thomas, his dissent in the University of Michigan Law School affirmative action case this week is surely one of the most poignant documents ever issued by the U.S. Supreme Court. It is the angry exclamation of a black man who feels personally patronized and demeaned by what he sees as racial gerrymandering.

title: A Major Victory for Gay Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about abandoned buffalo on the Umatilla Indian Reservation in Oregon misspelled the name of the Indian nation in Washington State that was consulted about rounding them up. It was the Yakama, not Yakima.

title: G.I. Dies, Others Are Wounded in New Ambushes in Iraq
description: American soldiers came under fire again today across Iraq, with one soldier shot in the head and wounded while shopping and another killed in an ambush late last night near the southern city of Najaf.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of the following Americans in the Iraq theater of operations:

title: Wilderness Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: Coleman Leads a Quartet Even as He Eludes It
description: Time turns slippery in Ornette Coleman's music. A headlong rush drifts into contemplation. A step-by-step exposition veers off on a tangent. A swinging passage surreptitiously pulls free of the underlying beat.

title: The Medicare Measures
description: The Senate overwhelmingly approved a bipartisan bill to provide prescription drug coverage under Medicare this week while a partisan Republican bill barely squeaked through the House by a one-vote margin. That sets the stage for a bitter struggle in a conference committee where one can only hope that the bipartisan spirit prevails.

title: UBS HIRES EXECUTIVE FROM INSTINET GROUP
description: An executive at Instinet Group, Will Sterling, president of the company's Island ECN and trade-execution business for securities firms, has left to run the institutional electronic equities trading businesses at the UBS investment bank. Mr. Sterling had been chief technology officer of the Island electronic-trade matching system when Instinet bought it last September, and was promoted to president and head of its execution businesses for other brokerage firms two months later. Instinet said its executive vice president for strategic planning, Alex Goor, will assume Mr. Sterling's duties.

title: Landlords To Be Liable For Injuries On Sidewalks
description: Landlords, rather than the city, will soon be liable when pedestrians are injured because of poorly maintained sidewalks abutting their property, under a bill passed yesterday by the City Council.

title: Iraqi Saboteurs' Goal: Disrupt the Occupation
description: Saddam Hussein's intelligence agency devised a plan to challenge the allied occupation of Iraq: sabotage its own country.

title: Calculating The Irrational In Economics
description: When the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston invited the leading behavioral economists to a Cape Cod golf resort this month to make their case, it was plainly a signal moment. ''It has the feeling of being summoned by the king,'' said Colin F. Camerer, a star behaviorist who teaches at the California Institute of Technology. ''Sort of like: 'I understand you're the finest lute player in the region. Will you come and play for me?' ''

title: A Major Victory for Gay Rights (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge in New Jersey Hears Arguments on Gay Marriage
description: A day after the nation's highest court overturned a Texas sodomy law, expanding rights for gay men and lesbians, a state judge here heard arguments on a potentially groundbreaking case that could lead to the legalization of same-sex marriage in New Jersey.

title: Baseball Analysis; Now It Is Alomar Who Should Be Looking Up to Soriano
description: For most of Alfonso Soriano's life as a baseball player and a baseball fan, he idolized Tony Fernandez. Fernandez was a deity to Soriano because, like Soriano, he was a slick shortstop from the Dominican Republic. So whenever Soriano played baseball with his friends, he was the first to announce that he would emulate Fernandez for the day.

title: Pitting Fuel Economy Against Safety
description: For years, automakers have cited studies contending that thousands of people die annually because fuel economy regulations force the companies to make cars that are not heavy enough.

title: Another Quick Loss For Rothberger
description: Michael Rothberger was furious, shouting through his mouthguard, minutes after his match against William Perry was stopped in the second round at Jimmy's Bronx Cafe on Thursday night.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bridgestone Raises Outlook
description: Japan's largest tire maker, the Bridgestone Corporation, raised its profit forecast by 10 percent, to 77 billion yen ($642 million), citing improvement in exports, brisk sales in North America and benefits from the rise of the euro against the yen. The new profit target for the year ending Dec. 31 represents a 70 percent increase from last year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Different Cast, Same Ending as Yankees Handle Mets
description: The final confrontation came down to the Yankees' closer and the Mets' No. 3 hitter, just as it had in the last game of the most meaningful series between these teams. In Game 5 of the 2000 World Series, Mariano Rivera faced Mike Piazza. Last night, Dan Miceli went against Ty Wigginton.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on June 6 about Natalya Reshetovskaya, the first wife of the author Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, misstated the year of his arrest for criticism of Stalin's war strategy. It was 1945, not 1941.

title: A Quick California Campaign Swing Adds to Bush's Coffers
description: President Bush scurried down the coast of California today to collect more than $5 million for his 2004 campaign, bringing the Bush-Cheney re-election effort totals to more than $18 million, and within sight of the campaign's latest goal of up to $30 million by the end of the month.

title: A Battle of 0 and 300
description: Jeremy Griffiths grew up in Ohio as an Indians fan, so he was quite familiar with the Yankees. Although he said he was ''not tremendously'' anxious about making his first major league start today at Yankee Stadium, he found the matchup with Roger Clemens, the Yankees' 300-game winner, interesting.

title: Chucho Valds Ends the Wait
description: The Cuban virtuoso Latin-jazz pianist Chucho Valds will be playing tomorrow night at the Jazz Gallery, at 290 Hudson Street.

title: Catching Prospect Moving Up
description: Prospects keep moving through the Mets' system. Justin Huber, the organization's top catching prospect, was promoted to Class AA Binghamton from Class A St. Lucie this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDBACK, , FRED
description: SANDBACK--Fred. International Print Center New York extends its deepest sympathy to Trustee and Founding Member Amy Baker Sandback and her family on the loss of Fred. Janice Oresman, Chairman Anne Coffin, Director >>AD#

title: Grubman in Hamptons, but This Time on the Air
description: After the Manhattan publicist Elizabeth S. Grubman backed a sport utility vehicle into a crowd of Hamptons clubgoers in July 2001, she became the object of relentless media scrutiny, as reporters dissected the contents of her closet and camped outside her Upper East Side apartment building.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Officials Say People Caused Fire
description: Investigators said that a 32,700-acre fire that began on June 17 was caused by people but that they have no suspects or other details. The fire destroyed 322 houses in Summerhaven, a vacation community on Mount Lemmon about 17 miles northeast of Tucson. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Homeless Woman Masquerading As Officer Robbed 4, Police Say
description: A 56-year-old homeless woman has been masquerading as an undercover police officer and robbing elderly people, mostly in and around Greenwich Village, since March, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEICHTNER, , CARL
description: LEICHTNER--Carl of New Rochelle. Died June 26, 2003 at age 78. Husband of Ursula (nee Moses) Leichtner, father to Ronald Leichtner and Jacqueline Leichtner-Falco, grandfather of Jaimie Lynn, Steven, Samantha and Julie. Graveside funeral Service Sunday 11 AM at Mt. Eden Cemetery in Valhalla. Zion Memorial Chapel of Westchester, 914-381-1809. >>AD#

title: Administration Lawyer Lauds Affirmative Action Ruling
description: Alberto R. Gonzales, the White House counsel, sought to appeal to a largely Democratic audience of Hispanic officials here today by praising the Supreme Court's decision this week upholding affirmative action in university admissions.

title: Playing Up the Contrasts In Beethoven's Sonatas
description: Daniel Barenboim has spent most of June at Carnegie Hall with the Beethoven Piano Sonatas, playing all 32 in eight concerts and discussing them and coaching students in master classes.

title: Mayor Courts Votes With a Bit of Spanish
description: If he pronounces ''bodega,'' boo-DEH-gah instead of bo-DAY-gah, if those R's just refuse to roll, if he greets rapid-fire Spanish with a sheepish grin, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has an explanation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, , JOSEPH B.
description: SMITH--Joseph B. on June 25, 2003. Beloved husband of Catherine (nee McAuliffe) loving father of Kathy, Betty Maffeo, Joseph and Michael. title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY ACQUISITION PLAN MOVES AHEAD
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. moved closer to buying the mobile home maker Clayton Homes Inc. as a Delaware judge refused to stop shareholders from voting on the $1.7 billion acquisition on July 16. Orbis Investment Management Ltd. sued earlier this month, contending Berkshire's offer of $12.50 a share was too low. Orbis had asked a judge to make Clayton hold a regular annual meeting first to allow a vote on a proposal to require the merger's approval by a majority of independent stockholders. Judge Stephen Lamb said at a hearing in Wilmington, Del., that shareholders already have the opportunity to vote against the proposal if they choose. A spokeswoman for Berkshire Hathaway said the company's chairman, Warren E. Buffett, was not available to comment.

title: Kidd's Visits Don't Worry Scott (Yet)
description: Byron Scott said he was retooling his game so he could challenge Jason Kidd on the golf course. In typical Scott fashion, he was not worried about the possibility that Kidd would leave the Nets.

description: Josh Evans, a starting defensive tackle for the Jets, was suspended indefinitely by the National Football League yesterday for his third violation of the league's substance-abuse policy.

title: Liberian President Defies Call by Bush to Give Up Post
description: A day after President Bush urged him to step down for the sake of peace, a defiant President Charles Taylor, still reeling from a rebel attack on his capital, called for the United States ''to do everything in its power to help Liberia and Liberians out of this mess.''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Economy Shrinks
description: Canada's economy contracted in April for the first time since late 2001, Statistics Canada said. Gross domestic product dropped 0.2 percent, adjusted for inflation, after being unchanged in March. The growth rate for the year to April was 1.8 percent. Manufacturing and oil and gas exploration were among the weakest sectors. Hotels and restaurants were hit hard by the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, in Toronto. In recent years, Canada has posted the strongest growth among major industrial countries. But the slowdown in the United States and a sharp appreciation of the Canadian dollar have put a brake on the economy. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: I. Bernard Cohen, 89, Dies; Pioneer in History of Science
description: I. Bernard Cohen, a Newton scholar and Harvard educator whose life's work molded the history of physical science as an academic discipline in the United States, died on June 20 at his home in Waltham, Mass. He was 89.

title: GENENTECH CANCER DRUG TO GET ACCELERATED REVIEW
description: Genentech Inc., the biotechnology company, said the Food and Drug Administration gave the experimental cancer medicine Avastin its ''fast track'' designation. The status means the F.D.A. will help the company to more quickly submit its application for approval. The designation also leads to a quicker review. Genentech, which is based in South San Francisco, Calif., said last month that Avastin helped patients with colon cancer live longer. Genentech says that Avastin may reach the market next year.

title: ACCORD REPORTED ON ISRAELI PULLOUT FROM GAZA AREAS
description: Israeli and Palestinian leaders reached agreement tonight for Israeli forces to begin withdrawing from areas of the Gaza Strip and returning security control to Palestinian officers, officials familiar with the negotiations said.

description: Allied forces dropped leaflets last night on the southern city where six British soldiers and four Iraqis died in a gun battle this week, telling residents that the military would return to the city, Majar al Kabir.

description: The Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that it was reviewing procedures used by coal processors to qualify for synthetic-fuel tax credits and might withdraw credits for operations that failed to meet federal standards.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Bailout Approved
description: The Financial Services Agency approved a restructuring plan submitted by Resona Holdings and Resona Bank as part of the 2 trillion yen ($16.7 billion) taxpayer-financed bailout the government organized this month. According to the plan, which runs through March 2005, Resona promised to lend more to small companies, dispose of more nonperforming loans and improve its profitability. Because of the fund infusion, the Japanese government now holds a controlling stake in the banking group, which is the country's fifth-largest lender. Ken Belson (NYT)

The police said that after midnight on June 14 Mr. Said impersonated an employee to steal formula books from the Morabito Baking Company plant in Norristown, Pa. title: San Francisco
description: A sound not heard in San Francisco for two years reverberated along the waterfront 12 days ago. The clock on the historic Ferry Building, frozen during a renovation completed in March, was set in motion and once again chimes on the hour and half-hour. The clock had been stopped only three times before, by earthquakes, and its chiming signals the Ferry Building's rebirth. Though its soaring interior still feels slightly empty after being closed for three years, the Ferry Building is slowly filling with permanent vendors who will turn it by summer's end into a showplace of Bay Area food.

title: LAWSUIT SETTLED
description: As part of a sweeping settlement to a lawsuit, Governor McGreevey announced last week the creation of an independent panel to oversee the state's troubled child welfare agency. He also agreed to spend more than $23 million to hire more social workers and recruit foster parents. The five-member panel will help the Division of Youth and Family Services set policy and hold it accountable for meeting improvement targets. If the panel determined that the division was not improving fast enough, a federal judge could order the state to take further action to revamp the agency. The suit, filed in 1999 by Children's Rights Inc., said the state's foster care system had left children in serious danger of abuse and neglect. Richard Lezin Jones

title: Bicycling in Denmark, Or on a Virtual Tour
description: For four days beginning July 1, bikers throughout Westchester will be cycling -- in groups, solo, even on stationary bikes -- on a Virtual Bike Tour in conjunction with the Shriver Family Bike Tour for Sarcoma Research, taking place in Denmark at the same time. These coordinated events were organized by Bruce and Bev Shriver of Ossining. Their 36-year-old daughter, Elizabeth (Liddy), received a diagnosis of Ewing's Sarcoma, a cancer that is rare and difficult to treat in adults. Liddy Shriver, a cycling enthusiast whose cancer began in her thigh and has metastasized to her lungs, is traveling with her family to Denmark to join Team Sarcoma, consisting of 24 cyclists from across the globe. Their mission, and that of the cyclists biking with them in Westchester and throughout the United States and the world, is to raise awareness about sarcoma and the lack of young adults in related clinical trials. Information: e-mail biketour@theshrivers.us, or visit theshrivers.us/virtual--bike--tour.htm or www.curesarcoma.org. Susan Hodara

title: Page Two: June 22-28; IRAQ: A RISING TOLL
description: Scattered attacks on American and British soldiers escalated throughout Iraq, with the violence spreading to areas that had been largely quiet since major combat ended on May 1. An Army soldier killed late Thursday in a small town near Najaf became the 19th soldier to die since May 1. Earlier in the week, gunmen killed six British soldiers in an ambush in southern Iraq. Separately, an American soldier was killed and eight others wounded by a bomb near the Baghdad airport.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Chevrolet Corvette; At 50, You Should Look So Good
description: THE Chevrolet Corvette, a balm applied to countless egos bruised by midlife crisis, is celebrating its own 50th birthday this weekend in Nashville with caravans, parades, vintage-car displays and a rock concert. To reach the half-century mark, America's iconic sports car has persevered through trying times, starting with a so-what initial reception from buyers and, in later years, the upheaval created by antipollution regulations, all the while fending off rivals' repeated attempts to dethrone it.

title: Frozen Assets
description: One of my most vivid food memories is of the peach ice cream my mother made in an old-fashioned freezer (it was electric but it required ice and rock salt) one summer when I was either 10 or 11 years old. It is a memory made more vivid by the fact that we never ate it again, a sad truth I'm sure my mother will dispute. Making homemade ice cream for your family and friends is a wholesome, thoughtful, all-American thing to do, she will reason, the kind of thing she actually did for us often. So surely, she will insist, she must have made it more than once. She did not. We returned to scooping Borden's out of its square carton and greeted the opening of the first Baskin-Robbins in our town with excitement bordering on the ridiculous. Homemade ice cream became, for me, a rarefied delicacy; certainly not something people actually made or ate all the time.

title: A SLUDGE PROPOSAL
description: The state Agricultural Development Committee wants to lift a ban on using sewerage sludge as fertilizer on farms that are part of the farmland preservation program. The sludge is left over after water and contaminants are removed from sewage at treatment plants. But opponents fear that contaminants may remain in the sludge. A hearing is set for July 28. Karen DeMasters

The smokers and lovers can trace their new status to Thomas Jefferson's manifesto, in particular the four-word phrase that rounded out his list of inalienable rights. As participants in what we have come to call the culture wars, they are the losers and winners of the pursuit of happiness.

Real life tends to fade out into entropy, all loose ends, and grief for what should have been, could have been, had things turned out just a little differently. title: 'The Man of Feeling'
description: Idon't know whether I should tell you my dreams. They are old dreams, old-fashioned dreams, more suited to an adolescent than to a grown man. They are at once elaborate and precise, leisurely, but highly colored, like those dreamed by an over-imaginative but basically simple soul, a very orderly soul. They are dreams that become somewhat tedious after a while because the person dreaming them always wakes before the end, as if the dream impulse had worn itself out in the representation of all those details and lost interest in the final result, as if dreaming were the only truly ideal and aimless activity left. So I do not know how my dreams end, and it might be inconsiderate of me to tell you about them, knowing that I can offer neither conclusion nor lesson. But they strike me as both inventive and vivid. The only thing I can say in my defense is that I am writing out of the particular form of timelessness-the place of my eternity-that has chosen me.

title: Did You Hear the One About the Suicide Bomber?
description: In this anything-goes culture, I'm not surprised that even after Sept. 11 a comedian can gain success and fame exploiting this horrific event for money and laughs (Marshall Sella, June 15). But what I found even more obscene is what the article tells us about the coarsening of our society and our journalism. Just imagine if a Japanese-American woman in 1943 had hit the nightclub circuit with an act about looking for juicy targets in Hawaii. She would have been run out of town. Would The Times have run a sympathetic article about what a smash she had become? Your writer gave only the most cursory mention to objections about such ''comedy.'' Why not interview survivors of Sept. 11 to see if they found her act hilarious? But celebrity now apparently trumps good taste.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IDOL, , CHARLES WILLIAM SR.
description: IDOL--Charles William Sr. Died on June 20, 2003, in Vero Beach, Florida, at the age of 85. He was born in High Point, North Carolina, and raised on a 500-acre farm with his six brothers and seven sisters. Mr. Idol graduated from The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1941. He played basketball and football for the university and was voted Most Valuable Player by his football team. Upon completion of his studies, Mr. Idol enlisted in the United States Navy and served in World War II, rising to the rank of Ensign. He was awarded the World War II Victory Medal American Theater. Mr. Idol had a distinguished 30-year career as a senior executive in charge of its New York and Chicago operations with Acme-McCrary Corporation of Asheboro, North Carolina. Acme-McCrary, founded in 1909 and privately held, manufactures private label and licensed branded hosiery names for many of the nation's leading retailers. Mr. Idol was a resident of Old Brookville, New York, for 15 years. He retired to Vero Beach, Florida, with his wife of 53 years. Mr. Idol is survived by his wife, Agnes Ann Idol of Vero Beach, Florida; two sons, Charles William Idol Jr. of Hagerstown, Maryland, and John Debus Idol of Manhasset, New York; two daughters, Christine Marie Hindin of McLean, VA, and Virginia Idol Laytham of Arlington, Virginia; and eight grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10 AM, on Monday, June 30, 2003, at St. Mary's Catholic Church, Manhasset, New York. Interment will take place immediately following the service at 12:30 PM, at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Visiting Nurses Association & Hospice of Indian River County, 1111 36th Street, Vero Beach, Florida 32960. >>AD#

title: The Hungriest Critic of Them All

On a sunny afternoon at the end of May, I sat in a noisy cappuccino bar on the edge of the town's bustling business district, chatting with Clive James, who was performing that evening, with his songwriting partner, Pete Atkin, at the municipal theater. A stout, chipper woman from another table came over and asked Mr. James to autograph her ticket, which he happily did. A few minutes later, as we walked up a quiet lane toward the theater's backstage entrance, the proprietor of a rival coffeehouse popped onto the sidewalk with his camera, requesting a snapshot of Mr. James for his establishment's collection of celebrity portraits. Then, a few paces on, a nervous, eager man appeared with a large red autograph book, a rubber band marking the page reserved for Mr. James, who took all the unsolicited attention with the gracious, faintly self-mocking air of one long accustomed to the intrusions and obligations of fame, making genial small talk and duly signing whatever was put in front of him.

title: A Brotherhood of Ham
description: When I was 12 years old I failed my amateur radio license test three times because I could not master Morse code. I wanted desperately to be a ham, so I saved up, bought an old Hallicrafters shortwave rig and made up my own call sign, which I then had printed on QSL cards -- personal calling cards that ham operators mail to each other to confirm their airwave encounters. Hams wallpapered their radio shacks with these cards to show just how far and to whom they reached. (I decided to accumulate as many as possible, but cheated by ordering hundreds of QSL's from an advertisement in the back of a ham magazine.) Most QSL's were beautiful -- not because of their artistic design but because the odd juxtaposition of letters and numerals, along with graphics and cartoons of antennas, radio waves, lightning bolts and technical doodads, gave them the allure of a secret society. Reproduced in HELLO WORLD: A Life in Ham Radio (Princeton Architectural Press, paper, $24.95), by Danny Gregory and Paul Sahre, they have acquired a curious folk-art quality. This book is a profusely visual, clever and handsomely designed (the title on the book cover is not set in words but in Morse code) paean to ham radio presented through reproductions of hundreds of QSL cards and other ephemera collected and annotated for more than 70 years by an avid New Jersey enthusiast and found by the authors at a flea market after he died. Instant messaging and e-mail have made ham radio virtually obsolete, but these QSL's from all over the world recall the days when strange and wonderful voices filled the airwaves. Steven Heller

title: Songs of Norway
description: WHEN I was a child taking piano lessons, one of my favorite recordings was ''Rubinstein Plays Grieg.'' The longest selection was the stormy 15-minute Ballade in G Minor. The rest of the album offered a dozen of Grieg's numerous Lyric Pieces, short works that evoked the character of his native land. To me it was the most beautiful, yet saddest, music imaginable. ''Shepherd Boy,'' which I especially loved, was downright tragic. Even sprightly pieces with happy titles, like ''Spring Dance'' and ''Little Bird,'' were tinged with sorrow.

The ''Napalm Elegies'' are the best known of these paintings, their title inspired by his fellow American abstract painter Robert Motherwell's ''Elegies to the Spanish Republic,'' a series of over 100 black-and-white paintings created in reaction to the Spanish Civil War.

title: A Moderate Term on the Court
description: ''Th' supreme coort,'' Mr. Dooley famously observed, ''follows th' iliction returns.'' A century after Finley Peter Dunne's fictional Irish saloonkeeper made the point, the court has put an interesting spin on Mr. Dooley's theory. At a time when President Bush and his Republican majority in Congress are continually arguing that they have the mandate to appoint extreme conservatives to the federal bench, the highest court of all has surprised many people with its moderation. The Supreme Court, it appears, is better at reading the election returns than some elected politicians.

Only after their landlord put her family's longtime rental house in Edison, N.J., on the market did her search for a place for her own reach the breaking point. ''It was time,'' she said, ''for me to leave home.''

title: Lawrence Has the Money For Student Performance
description: ''A School District Stares Into the Abyss'' [June 22] conjures up a picture of a group of people sitting in a circle, each pointing a finger at the person next to him. I am a resident of Lawrence and find myself with neither the public school side nor the private school side of the issue. I come down on the side of quality education and am willing to pay what it takes to achieve this, despite the fact that our four children are now past school age and raising our grandchildren. We are spending $19,000 to $20,000 per child to educate the children in the Lawrence system. Freeport and Roosevelt, with a potentially far more difficult student base to educate, spend about half of this on each of their students, and yet came out roughly equivalent to our Lawrence students in the recent test scores of fourth and eighth graders.

His 1908 complete redesign and renovation of an existing building -- which he did for himself -- was a major achievement for Sterner, then a newcomer to New York, who would go on to bring a touch of color to several of Manhattan's drab brownstone side streets. Now four years of renovations to the building are nearly complete, and new owners moved in last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEND, , ELEANOR B.
description: FRIEND--Eleanor B. On midafternoon, June 23, 2003, Ellie Friend was taken from us. She was dearly loved. She didn't know a stranger. Ellie cared for everyone she knew, everyone she met and everyone she could help in whatever way was possible. She was a wonderful wife, a wonderful friend, a wonderful sister who gave in any way she could. She loved people, she loved travel, she loved other people's love and she wanted to give to anyone in need in any way possible. Her gift of caring, her warm and tender words for grown ups, for children, for animals, for people of all walks of life made her a true disciple of all that is good within our special place under the sun. Whatever you wanted, whatever you needed, whatever you cared about was what Ellie wanted, needed and cared about because she was wanting you to be happy. Her special place ...and the way she was...made the world a better world for having enjoyed holding her in its arms. God bless her soul and keep her nourished as an example for all who follow her treasured life on this earth. A Memorial Service will be held at 12:00 noon on Monday, June 30th at the Danzansky - Goldberg Me morial Chapels, 1170 Rockville Pike in Rockville, MD. title: Aretha: A Natural Woman Once More
description: CAF TACUBA -- The Mexican band that transfigured rock en Espaol has tucked the instrumental experiments from its 1999 album, ''Reves/Yosoy,'' back into concise songs on its album ''Cuatro Caminos'' (MCA). As lyrics ponder the meaning of life, love and apocalypse, Caf Tacuba's music capers along, looking back to the Beatles and Beach Boys and sideways to the loops and asymmetries of indie rock. With drummers (including Joey Waronker, of Beck's band) replacing the band's usual drum machine, Caf Tacuba sounds more seriously lightheaded than ever.

In his tooth-and-claw resolve, the Texas Legislature has been summoned into special session tomorrow by Gov. Rick Perry, a DeLay ally, to once more take up Mr. DeLay's hubristic plan to remap Texas' Democratic Congressional majority out of existence.

Professor of English at University of Michigan. Beloved husband of Professor Christine Verzar; loving father of Dr. Paul Fader and his wife Laurie Brown, Lisa Fader, and stepfather of Ben Bornstein; cherished grandfather of Caitlin and Zachary Fader; beloved brother of Dr. Howard Fader and his wife Ruth; and loving uncle of Joel and Tracy Fader, Susan and Bradley Feild, and Betsy and Steven Goldstein. title: Ideas & Trends: Test of Time; Fixing the Race Gap in 25 Years or Less
description: THE Supreme Court decision upholding affirmative action in university admissions seemed to carry an expiration date. ''We expect that 25 years from now the use of racial preferences will no longer be necessary to further the interest approved today,'' Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote in her 5-to-4 majority opinion last week.

title: Hi, I'm George, and I'll Be Your Dead Person Tonight
description: IF pop culture has its way, the list of inevitable things will soon be whittled down to one, and the only sure-fire bummer in store for any of us will be taxes. Well, to be scrupulously accurate, people still die in best-selling books like ''The Lovely Bones'' and television shows like the new Showtime series ''Dead Like Me,'' but they manage to keep pretty busy afterward. What's the primary occupation of the dead? Why, taking care of us, of course. Humanity has been spinning stories about what happens after we depart this world for nearly as long as we've been been explaining how we got here in the first place. But now more than ever, we seem to prefer envisioning the dead as members of a service profession, dedicated to making our lives a little bit easier.

title: The Handyman Of New York Dance Is Heading West
description: DAVID WHITE was once a lithesome lad who spoke in sentences of 20 words or less. I knew him before he became the executive director of Dance Theater Workshop and one of the movers and shakers in dance here and abroad, when we participated in a roving program in dance writing in the early 1970's, taught by the dance critics Deborah Jowitt and Marcia B. Siegel. I had not begun to write about dance but loved the art and wanted to see more on the stage. David, as he is universally known in dance, recalls that he was also looking for something more, and what he found was a way of looking at dance that helped him place it in the larger world.

description: BY midweek, as Long Island baked in its first sustained warm weather of the year, it was almost possible to forget the soggy chill that enveloped it for much of the past two months. But the incessant spring rainfall has left a trail of businesses soaking in anything but profits. Among the losers were the usual suspects: the drenched golf courses, the wilted garden-store sales and the shuttered shops along beaches and boardwalks.

title: A Mighty Wind
description: I don't have a house overlooking Nantucket Sound or a yacht to sail its waters. But whenever I walk along the shores of the sound, I become more convinced that this priceless natural resource is simply not the place for the controversial wind-turbine development proposed by Cape Wind Associates. At the same time, I realize that there are strong arguments pro and con that should be hashed out in a robust dialogue. So I was disappointed at the way you covered this issue. Your writer came across as unabashedly biased in favor of the massive project and scornful of those who oppose it. She tried to make poor Walter Cronkite sound like an indecisive old fool. She compares an opposition spokesman with Woody Allen. At the same time, she makes the developer Jim Gordon sound like Johnny Appleseed. This is a complex story that deserves more than a glib ''he said, she said'' treatment.

title: A Wild Anniversary

title: Woodstock Art Colony Tells Its Story
description: While most of the country came to think of Woodstock, N.Y., as synonymous with cultural activity in the 1960's, its history as an arts haven dates back 100 years -- to the opening of the Byrdcliffe Arts Colony. Artists have been at home in Woodstock since Ralph Radcliffe Whitehead opened a 30-building utopian center for the Arts and Crafts movement in 1903, as an exhibition celebrating Byrdcliffe's centennial shows.

title: How to Learn From Closed-End Funds, Without Buying

title: Yachters' Club

On Wednesday night, models in miniskirts relaxed there on teak Balinese daybeds, grooving to European house music. Potted palms and banana trees stood nearby, and yachts were moored at a dock down below.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: BEING an aspiring young actor or actress in New York is not easy, but if there's anything worse than being rejected day after day, it's having your best friend succeed. That's what the title character has to face in Griffin Dunne's hilarious mock documentary LISA PICARD IS FAMOUS (2000). Just as Lisa (Laura Kirk) has won a small part in a Melissa Gilbert television movie, her pal Tate (Nat DeWolf) stages his dreadful one-man show about homophobia and it's a hit. Mr. Dunne plays the filmmaker documenting the adventures of Lisa, who proves to be highly self-absorbed. The film includes appearances by Sandra Bullock (accosted at the post office), Carrie Fisher, Buck Henry, Spike Lee, Mira Sorvino and Ms. Gilbert -- Saturday at 9 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4 a.m. on Sundance.

title: Katonah-Lewisboro Offers Revised Budget to Voters
description: ONE of the big reasons people move to Westchester is its generally strong public school systems. So it's not surprising that voters in all but two of the county's school districts passed their school budgets on June 3. What is surprising is that the two districts that rejected budgets, Katonah-Lewisboro and Valhalla, are far from being troubled districts, and in fact have solid academic reputations. The rejections are perhaps even more surprising given that statewide, 94 percent of the school districts passed their budgets successfully, despite the difficult economy. And Valhalla passed its budget on the second try last Tuesday.The budget defeat in Katonah-Lewisboro reflects a number of issues in a complex , far-flung set of diverse communities, with somewhat attenuated ties to the school district as a whole, people in the district say. The 4,200-student district covers 54 square miles, encompassing Katonah as well as hamlets like Vista, South Salem and Cross River. The district is economically diverse, with lavish weekend homes, modest cottages as well as new houses that sell for $825,000 in recently built housing developments. It can take a half-hour to drive from one end of the district to the other.

title: CONVICTION IN HUDSON COUNTY
description: Freeholder Nidia Dvila-Coln of Hudson County was convicted last week by a federal jury in Newark of mail fraud and aiding and abetting an attempted extortion. The state Attorney General's Office and County Prosecutor Edward DeFazio wasted no time in demanding that she resign. Ms. Coln, who could receive three to five years of jail time when she is sentenced in late September, has been a freeholder since 1984. After a monthlong trial, she was found guilty of delivering $10,000 from a county contractor, who was her boyfriend, to former County Executive Robert Janiszewski. Debra Nussbaum

title: 'Curzon'
description: George Nathaniel Curzon was born on 11 January 1859 at Kedleston, the Derbyshire estate his family had owned for more than seven hundred years. Proud of his birthplace, one of the finest country houses in England, and of his birthright, he once admonished an historian who had failed to trace the Curzons back beyond the fifteenth century. The family's descent, he wrote, went 'straight back to a Norman who came over with the Conqueror', while Kedleston had belonged to the Curzons, most of whom were buried in its church, since the twelfth century. 'I think there are only two or three families in England', he added, 'who can prove a similar descent. Each stage of ours was verified some years ago at the College of Heralds.'

As the euro has risen, so has the value of assets denominated in it. But the euro's strength has also increased prices outside the euro zone for goods produced in the region, depressing sales and profits and ultimately share prices.

Mr. Estess, white-haired and with a generous belly, is used to mountains; they seem to bolster his optimism. This particular pile of dirt, dotted with broken bricks and three-foot-tall weeds, was no exception. In a year and a half, it will become an $11.3 million center that provides housing and support for homeless adults. So, the smirk.

title: Rebuilding Iraq With Iraqis
description: Almost two months have passed since L. Paul Bremer took over as chief administrator in Iraq, and American authorities are still digging themselves out of a very deep hole. Water and electricity haven't been fully restored and are subject to continuing sabotage. Millions whose livelihoods depended on the old regime remain unemployed and unpaid. Living standards haven't recovered even to depressed prewar levels. Plans for an Iraqi-run interim administration have been shelved. Meanwhile, in too many places, police duties are being carried out by foreign soldiers untutored in local mores and trained to respond to threats with overwhelming force, not calming words.

title: How To Kill Orchestras
description: AS American orchestras lick their wounds, or die of them, the blame falls on fleeing contributors, bad management and disappearing audiences. Maybe these are symptoms, not causes.

title: Red, White, Blue (and Profitable)
description: FOR the last couple of summers, the Fourth of July has been especially enjoyable and relaxing for the Franci family of West Haven. That is because Pete Franci no longer has to smuggle contraband home to celebrate.

title: The Earth Moves In Asbury Park
description: The owners of the vaunted Stone Pony rock club in Asbury Park have agreed to sell the business to the redeveloper of the city's blighted waterfront. The deal, which all but guarantees that the club will be moved from its Ocean Avenue site, the only address it has ever had, is not likely to sit well with fans of Bruce Springsteen, Southside Johnny and other musicians who have contributed to the club's mythic status.

title: A Mighty Wind
description: If Rembrandt and other Dutch masters thought landscapes with windmills were aesthetically appealing, perhaps future generations will look upon the windmills in Nantucket Sound as objects of beauty.

title: Corrections
description: Part of an answer in the Q & A column on June 15 about an Arabian horse event in Germany in late August confused the identities of two municipalities named Marbach, both near Stuttgart. The site of the event is a village two miles southeast of Gomadingen and about 30 miles south of Stuttgart. (The Marbach that is near the Ludwigsburg Palace and the Nestor Hotel in Ludwigsburg is 19 miles north of Stuttgart.) Places to stay in addition to Stuttgart include inns in Reutlingen and Bad Urach. More information: www.schwaebischealb.de .

title: INSIDE
description: Europe Ages Into Upheaval

title: Going for Broke
description: Dan Klores, a public-relations maven and a consultant to Andrew Cuomo, says that he accepted Gov. George E. Pataki's offer to try to get his son into an elite nursery school and admits that, as a result, he never did ''go negative'' on him during the campaign (Jennifer Senior, June 15). If there was ever anyone who deserved to have a negative campaign run against him, particularly on the issue of education, it is the governor. In essence, Pataki has so starved the New York City public schools that acceptance into a private nursery school has become the prize that it is.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Ludivine Sagnier; City of Light's Bright Star
description: FIRST there was Brigitte Bardot, then Catherine Deneuve, then Audrey Tautou. Now, it's Ludivine Sagnier, the latest in a long line of cinematic French exports to America. Her first name means divine light, and many would say it's apt. But her friends just call her Lulu.

title: On Every Parade, Some Rain
description: Hell is a gay bar on Gansevoort Street, and it's where Derek Hartley, a good-looking advice columnist for the gay Web site Planet Out was being ignored by a smart young crowd on a recent Friday. As someone who hears about relationships all the time, he does not have much faith in gay romance. Hookups, yes. Making it to a third date, no. The problem may be an excess of choice, especially with the Internet now encouraging men to treat dating like day trading.

title: At the Wheel
description: To the Editor: ''Tips on Driving While Abroad'' (June 15) by Susan Catto diminishes one of a traveler's best experiences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERENBERG, , GUS
description: BERENBERG--Gus, Bayside, NY, June 17, 2003. Survived by loving son, Dr. Barry Baker; daughter-in-law, Joanne; grandsons, Jon and James. Dr. Barry's fight for you gave you three months more. We miss you. >>AD#

title: Floyd Strikes Out
description: The first time Cliff Floyd became upset with Umpire Eric Cooper's interpretation of the strike zone yesterday at Yankee Stadium, Mets Manager Art Howe rushed out and stood between them. ''Be fair,'' Floyd said he told Cooper. ''Give us a chance.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TENDRICH, , MAX A.
description: TENDRICH--Max A. On Monday, June 23, 2003, of Leisure World, Silver Spring, MD, formerly of New York. Beloved husband of Mary Tendrich. Devoted father of Joanne S. (Lewis) Taub of Cliffside Park, NJ, and Robert I. (Joan M.) Tendrich of Rockville, MD. Loving grandfather to Andrew and Ryan. >>AD#

title: Why So Many Elections? Just Try to Change That
description: When last heard from in this space, some people who like to think about politics were lamenting the low turnout in primary elections this month as well as the general trend toward declining turnouts. Unless you subscribe to the view that the fewer meddlesome voters the better (more on that later), New Jersey, with a populace that is one of the richest and best educated in the country, ought to be able to do better than barely beat the national average of 49 percent.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Buyer vs. Developer: Heading Off Rivalry
description: WITH the economy uncertain and real estate booming, some Long Island developers say they are sometimes competing against their own customers, who buy more than one house in a development and then turn around and resell them at a higher price. Developers say they are hoping to curtail the practice.

title: A New Chef and Other Pleasing Changes
description: THE Ruby Room in Roslyn Estates has morphed into Lisenda, and Long Island diners are the beneficiaries. In addition to the name, changes include a new chef, menu and prices. Paul Paskins, who had been executive chef at the Kitchen on Pine Street in Long Beach (now closed), has created a menu of traditional dishes made exciting by unusual accompaniments. A cocktail of four, firm jumbo shrimp arrived in a martini glass atop a chunky avocado salsa fresca and a salad of cold poached asparagus in a lemon vinaigrette included halved hard-boiled quail eggs, pistachio nuts and small cubes of Spanish Manchego cheese. A scattering of crispy bits, resembling frizzled leeks, turned out to be deep-fried peelings from the asparagus. Both yummy appetizers were welcome openings to the meal.

description: Celia Ellen O'Donnell, the daughter of the Celia H. O'Donnell and the Rev. Thomas F. O'Donnell, was married yesterday to Edwin Torres Jr., the son of the late Hilda Santiago Torres and the late Mr. Torres, both of the Bronx. The bride's father, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Big Moose Community Chapel in Eagle Bay, N.Y.

title: Friendship Envy
description: There is a kind of friend that women make in college and through our 20's that for many of us becomes one of life's most important relationships. Unlike in grade school and high school, where you wind up friends with the girl who sits next to you on the bus or the one you're thrown together with in gym, these are the friends we truly choose. Separated from our families, we decide we can make a family of our own. These new sisters are the recipients of the enormous energy and time we have to pour into relationships. The idea is simply this: if you talk to someone long enough, sooner or later you'll know everything about her.

title: DataBank; Major Indexes Fall as Investors Grab Profits
description: The three major market indexes dropped last week as investors took profits after a long run-up in prices -- and as the end of the quarter approached.

title: Authentically Offensive
description: I was happily reading ''Hell at the Breech,'' Tom Franklin's suspenseful new novel, based on actual events, about a bush war in Alabama in the 1890's, when something about it began to feel a bit off. There are people who find historical fiction unbearably affected, but not me -- not, at least, as long as the author avoids sinning outrageously against verisimilitude. ''Hell at the Breech,'' which is told from the points of view of a handful of characters in language meant to sound more or less like their own, sounds a few wrong notes, but none glaring enough to ruin this otherwise tough, smart, niftily plotted tale. It wasn't the presence of an objectionable word or expression that kept tripping me up. It was the absence of a word, or, to be more precise, the highly selective presence of a particular, very objectionable word, a word many Americans consider to be the worst in the English language.

title: Misogyny Plus Girl Power: Original-Recipe 'Angels'
description: Let us now praise kung-fu bimbos! Actually, let's not get carried away -- let's faint-praise them. Because whatever its nostalgic charms, the 70's femme adventure series ''Charlie's Angels'' is not quality television. The mystery plots make (to quote that latter-day martial arts expert Buffy) the kind of sense that is not, the action sequences are laughably clunky, the jokes are stale as vaudeville. Historically speaking, the series is most notable as a hazardous influence on vulnerable fashion designers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 1 about living in Kinnelon, N.J., misidentified the SAT tests on which four students achieved perfect results, and misstated their numerical scores. Two students had maximum scores on SAT I reasoning tests -- one in the verbal section and the other in math. Two others had the maximum score on the SAT II proficiency tests in biology. Each score was 800, not 1,600.

title: From the Land of Bi Bim Bop
description: THIRTY-SIX PERCENT of the population of Palisades Park is Korean, according to the Asian American Federation of New York. That statistic brings smiles to the faces of bi bim bop lovers throughout Bergen County and beyond.

title: Hey, Watch Who You're Calling Wicked
description: AS soon as the curtain rises on ''Wicked,'' the new musical about the Wicked Witch of the West, it's clear we're not in Kansas anymore.
