description: All year long, J. P. Morgan Private Bank offers its wealthy clientele dozens of research reports on equities, emerging markets, derivatives and the like. But for the summer its suggested reading list goes beyond the scope of investments.

title: Affirmative Action: A Corporate Diary; Thankful for the Opportunity
description: Carl H. Ware, who until his retirement in February was the highest-ranking African-American executive at Coca-Cola, is a contemporary of Justice Thomas.

title: Litchfield Looks Back at Its Past, And Its Architecture of the Future
description: LITCHFIELD, a picturesque village known for its Colonial architecture, may seem an unlikely place to look for important modernist architecture. But turn off North Street onto Beecher Lane, and at the bottom of the hill, you'll find a flat-roofed, light-filled home designed by Marcel Breuer in 1949, more than a decade before he designed the Whitney Museum of American Art in Manhattan.

title: From Junkies to Zombies, Always With Style
description: EVEN people who know that Danny Boyle directed ''Trainspotting'' aren't likely to know much more -- no clue what he looks like or even how old he is. He is so identified with that film -- an improbably gleeful movie about heroin addicts in which a skinheaded Ewan McGregor dives head-first into what the movie calls ''the worst toilet in Scotland'' to retrieve drugs -- that a photographer hired to shoot Mr. Boyle in April finds a backdrop to reflect its ambience. It is the smelliest alley in London, a vile cul-de-sac where flies buzz around trash cans.

title: The Summer of Screamo
description: A year on the road can test the constitution of even a 21-year-old, and three hours before showtime, Bert McCracken, lead singer of the Used, is sick. Not rock-star ''sick,'' either -- McCracken swore off drugs years ago -- but so genuinely ill that the Used's road manager can't even get him to the arena; he has to leave McCracken propped up in the hotel bathtub while he sees to the rest of the band. The concert at Sam Boyd Stadium in Las Vegas is an all-day affair, with 10 acts on the bill, and the backstage atmosphere is frenetic; but this is show business, and so questions regarding McCracken's whereabouts are met by the road manager with a veteran's shrug -- of course he'll show up, because not showing up just isn't an option. Sure enough, when the Used hit the stage at 6:30, McCracken is somehow there. ''I have to apologize right off the bat,'' he tells the crowd. ''I have SARS.''

title: On the Green, Putters, Blasters and Hungry Hawks
description: DURING a drought in the mid-90's, we didn't have rain for some 90 days in a row. The hawks on the golf course were acting very strangely. They'd swoop down and grab a golf ball, then realize what it was and drop it. This summer, there's a hawk nesting on our south course who keeps the squirrels away. Right now, she has plenty on the menu.

title: A Teenage Driver Learning To Be Safe at Any Speed
description: ''Only two things scare me,'' the car racer growled. ''Nuclear war and carnies.''

title: The Executioner's I.Q. Test
description: Most people will never take an I.Q. test, and if they do, it probably won't have a big impact on them. Generally speaking, I.Q. tests do not carry much weight anymore. Not with vague charges of cultural bias still clinging to them. Not at a time when multiple intelligences -- that happy, inclusive vision in which nearly everybody is good at something -- are on the ascendancy. If you do take a Stanford-Binet or a Wechsler, and you score in the average range, well, there you'll be, with hardly a reason to mention it. If you score high, the particular number won't matter much -- unless you're the sort to join Mensa, and then it will matter only to your fellow Mensa members. But if you are in the bottom 3 percent of the population that scores 70 or lower, your actual I.Q. number will mean a great deal. Scores in that range will most likely lead to a diagnosis of mental retardation, and that diagnosis will entail many things, starting with mandated special education. Since last June, across the United States, it has also entailed exemption from capital punishment. And so, for someone who has committed a capital crime, an I.Q. score can mean the difference, quite literally, between life and death. It can mean, if we want to be blunt about it, that there is such a thing as being too dumb to die, at least at the hands of the state.

title: Quietly Celebrating A One-Night Stand
description: AT a time when more and more movies seem made on the assumption that everyone in the audience has a bad case of attention deficit disorder, the French director Claire Denis isn't afraid to take it slow. Her best films, like ''Chocolat'' (1988) and ''Beau Travail'' (1999), aren't leisurely so much as lingering, deliberate, simultaneously savoring and holding back. They're intensely sensual, and like good sex, they let the tension build.

title: RESPONSIBLE PARTIES -- SUNNY GOODE and DEDE DAVIS; An Artisan In Every Can Of Their Paint
description: MASTERING the rarefied world of decorative arts can be as easy as shuffling cards, say Sunny Goode and Dede Davis, who have created a do-it-yourself line of wall glazes, color washes and finishing paints.

title: Vote and Go
description: To the Editor: Marcy Webster's ''Democratizing the Family Trip'' (June 1) reminds me of a family trip during the summer of 1968, when our children were 12 and 14.

title: A Shortcut Over a Marsh Turns Into a Giant Joy Buzzer
description: A few days ago, Marie Persans and a friend were strolling the newly renovated pathway that serves as a shortcut over the marshy stretch between the north end of 103rd Street and the A train station in Howard Beach, Queens, when a man approached them.

title: Measuring the Time Needed to Succeed
description: THE secret to Jagdish (Jay) Patel's formidable stamina and reliability is a strong constitution, the ability to get by on six hours sleep and the jigger of scotch that he says he drinks every night before retiring. Clears the head, he says, and keeps a small businessman from ''thinking too much'' about his business.

title: Costly Insurance in the Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Chariots of Fire' Trek In the Pyrenees
description: NO, this just can't be Spain. The usual suspects -- the familiar red clay, the olive trees, the baking Spanish sunshine -- are nowhere to be found. Instead, as we hike down from a mountain pass, the Coll de Contraix, we're in a moonlike world made of stone and water. The stone is gray granite: the sheer rock towers of the Spanish Pyrenees. But what's really surprising is the water -- because water is everywhere.

title: Rediscovering Things French
description: THE burial ground at Old St. Peter's Church in Van Cortlandtville contains unmarked graves holding the bodies of at least seven French soldiers who died during the Revolutionary War, according to local lore. Growing interest in their fates has prompted members of the Van Cortlandtville Historical Society to research the men's backgrounds and family histories in the last few years; the third observance to honor their sacrifice and this part of France's role in American history will be held on Thursday, the day before the Fourth of July.

title: Body Found at La Guardia
description: A headless body, and a head, floated to the surface of the East River near a runway at La Guardia Airport yesterday morning, the authorities said, but it was unclear whether they were from the same person.

title: Online and in the Dark About Privacy Issues
description: Americans go online to do everything from shopping to paying bills to researching vacation destinations. Yet a new study finds that many people know little about how dot-com companies track their movements online and use the information gathered.

title: Annette Ezekiel and Jeremy Parzen
description: ANNETTE EZEKIEL drifted into her 30's prepared not to marry. ''I was completely accepting of that,'' she said. ''My mother is divorced, and I was used to being on my own. I'm a tough girl.''

title: 'The Great Mayor'
description: Fiorello H. La Guardia was not only a man of many traits and attitudes; he was a man of many religions. His father was a lapsed Roman Catholic, his mother a nonpracticing Jewess, his first wife a devout Catholic, his second a Lutheran, and he himself an observant though unconfirmed Episcopalian. What a person believed theologically was to him of monumental unimportance. La Guardia's concern was not with one's religious orientation but with one's ethical orientation.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about movies featuring stenographers and secretaries carried a photo archive's misidentification of an actor in the 1925 film ''His Secretary.'' He was Willard Louis, not Lew Cody.

title: The Fine Art of Selling Art in the Hamptons
description: RILEY McDONOUGH and his wife, Courtney Gibson, didn't see anything they had to have at the opening last weekend for the new show featuring seven artists at the Lizan Tops Gallery, although in the past they have snatched up paintings from the gallery for their Park Avenue apartment and East Hampton house.

title: Dry, White And Simple
description: Draining a bottle of 2001 Franzen Riesling Dry is easy. This simple, everyday $15 German white from a talented northern Mosel producer, Ulrich Franzen, is feather-light and redolent of apricots. Alternatively, a bone-dry $11 nonvintage riesling sekt (sparkling wine) called Alice, from Fitz-Ritter, a vintner in the Pfalz region, is virtually all-purpose at meals.

title: 'Living History'
description: Bill Clinton was hard to miss in the autumn of 1970. He arrived at Yale Law School looking more like a Viking than a Rhodes Scholar returning from two years at Oxford. He was tall and handsome somewhere beneath that reddish brown beard and curly mane of hair. He also had a vitality that seemed to shoot out of his pores. When I first saw him in the law school's student lounge, he was holding forth before a rapt audience of fellow students. As I walked by, I heard him say: "...and not only that, we grow the biggest watermelons in the world!" I asked a friend, "Who is that?"

title: New York, New York, It's Still Frank's Town
description: OH, sure, this is how any person from out of town would give a dinner for 33. We were at the Roxy Suite, the private apartment built in the 1930's above Radio City Music Hall, with 20-foot ceilings and burled maple paneling, decorated with Donald Deskey's haute Deco furniture. Two chefs were at work, one to cater the cocktail hour and the other to prepare dinner. And the titular hostess for the evening, Tina Sinatra, who has just turned 55, knew almost none of the New York crowd. In fact, they were there to meet her.

title: Closed Since 9/11, a PATH Station Is Set to Reopen Today
description: The PATH station at Exchange Place in Jersey City, closed since the September 2001 terror attack, is set to reopen today, a move that should ease commuting in and out of Manhattan.

title: Plenty of Books for Sale, but Few Buyers
description: SUSAN SLAVIN, a civil rights lawyer from Centerport, had long kicked around the idea of opening a used bookstore with her friend and fellow bookworm, Carol Dewey, a computer analyst from Huntington. Neither woman intended to leave her full-time job.

title: Where the Menu and the Scene Beckon
description: LODGED between a coin-op laundry and an auto detailing shop, the Lexington Square Cafe, with its handsome brick facade, has earned a reputation as a yuppie oasis with a thriving bar scene. What I witnessed on recent weekend nights, however, was fairly tame, with kids in lacrosse and baseball uniforms wolfing down burgers and silver-haired patrons in cashmere sweaters picking delicately through mesclun salads.

title: Corrections

title: Orchestral Survival: It's Not Simply The Economy, Stupid
description: THEY were successive entries in Andante.com's news summary one recent Thursday: ''San Antonio Symphony Declaring Bankruptcy,'' ''Oregon Symphony Musicians Take Pay Cut.'' Scrolling back to Wednesday brought ''Bailout of Florida Philharmonic Making Progress.'' (The orchestra has since declared bankruptcy.) On back to Tuesday: ''Louisville Orchestra to File for Bankruptcy.'' (The orchestra has since saved the situation.)

title: The Crucial First Clue To 'Henry V'
description: OLIVIER played it for laughs. Kenneth Branagh staged it like an Oliver Stone conspiracy. One Royal Shakespeare Company actor played it with a blackboard. This summer in Central Park, the Public Theater will do it with multiple, detailed display charts.

''This Million doubling, suppose but once in 25 Years, will in another Century be more than the People of England, and the greatest Number of Englishmen will be on this Side of the Water.''

She was a woman of extraordinary generosity, wisdom and determination, and her legacy lives on at Vassar and throughout the larger world that she touched so effectively. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TREDANARI, , LEONARD J. ''LEE'' ''TRED''
description: TREDANARI -- Leonard J. ''Lee'' ''Tred''. Age 79. Of New York City and East Hampton, N.Y. On June 14, 2003. Born in South Philadelphia. Decorated WWII veteran. Live TV director in the '60's for JFK's presidential campaign and leading programs including ''Person to Person'' and ''Voice of Firestone''. Vice President of Doyle Dane Bernbach 1965--1972, where he also created and ran The Director's Studio. Accomplished winemaker, sculptor, singer. Renaissance man. description: Thanks to North Face, the south face of the Ansonia has never looked so elegant. At least not since that day, decades ago, when the graceful yet powerful cast-iron window frames -- including a 27-foot arch -- were immured behind masonry.

description: Manager Joe Torre rested third baseman Robin Ventura for each game of the doubleheader and will also give him today off.

But a visit to the office of Majdi Atari, the Palestinian security chief in this biblical town, shows how 33 months of fighting have complicated efforts to return to the status quo that existed before the bloodshed began in September 2000.

description: THE Supreme Court's decisions on affirmative action brought a raft of social issues to the fore last week. But what of the economic consequences?

title: Pregnant Woman, 28, Found Fatally Shot
description: A Brooklyn woman who was nine months pregnant was found shot dead early yesterday inside her home in Flatlands, the police said.

title: Accent, Please
description: To the Editor: ''Traveling With an Accent '' by Rob Nixon (June 8) rang a bell.

title: Starting Small, With Wary Stripers on the East End
description: It isn't easy finding a colorful fishing joint in a town as fiercely intoxicated with affluence -- glorious, discreet, smells-like-new-leather wealth -- as this leafy beach community, but my friend David Blinken managed. As he patiently filled the gas tank of the flats skiff from which we would soon be casting flies to striped bass and bluefish, I admired the simple old black-and-white sign hanging above the busy service station: Sam's Auto. A similar one, clearly added later, hung nearby: Mrs. Sam's Tackle.

title: Page Two: June 22-28; The Court Takes The Nation's Pulse
description: THE essential debate about the proper role of American courts has always involved how much freedom judges should have in interpreting the original words of the Constitution when applying them to actual cases tossed up by life.

title: Yankee Prospect Outpitches Glavine
description: A group of men entered Shea Stadium through an open outfield gate at 6:25 last night and strolled down the right-field line, as if they were in no particular hurry to find their seats. The fans who had arrived early began to recognize some of them.

Sheldon of Sacramento and the late Dan A. Sheldon. The Rev. Edwin B. Harris, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Meadowood, a resort in St. Helena, Calif.

description: Classical/Opera

title: The Game in Spain

This simple phonetic change may one day be seen as the beginning of a greater metamorphosis in the life of David Beckham, or ''Beckhan'' as he is already being represented on the lips of his new team's fans.

description: To the Editor:

title: 'Wheels for the World'
description: think the wheels were in his head," Margaret Ford Ruddiman explained about her big brother Henry's lifelong mania for tinkering. Indeed, from the early days of his youth, the wheels in Henry Ford's head were turning, in his fascination with farm tools and engines, gadgets and machines, and automobiles. And after that, with business, industry, and society; always, in sum, with how the world, and everything in it, works. Some of the flawed notions his mental gears ground out may detract from Ford's legacy as a human being, but even his worst failings cannot lessen the impact of his brightest ideas or of Ford Motor Company, which he founded to express them. Through the company or his own constant activity, the influence of Henry Ford was felt on American history and on human civilization, for good and ill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEN, , CAROL LEE
description: SHEN--Carol Lee. 56, of Brooklyn Heights, NY, passed away on June 25, 2003, of cancer. We will remember Carol for her loving and caring nature, her grace and generosity of spirit, her unpretentious and patient approach to life, her delight in seeking and encouraging the best in those around her, and her ability to make us laugh. She has been and will always be our inspiration, and will remain forever in the hearts of family and friends, especially her husband Ted, her daughter Carla, her father Chin, her brother Glenn, and her sister Barbara. A memorial service will be held in the chapel of The Packer Collegiate Institute, 170 Joralemon St, Brooklyn, NY, on July 10th at 4:30 PM. Contributions may be made to The HOPE Program, 1 Smith St, Brooklyn, NY 11201, or to the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, New York 11238. >>AD#

title: A Mighty Wind
description: Here's what I don't get: wind turbines are among the most graceful structures being built in the world today. That mock-up of the wind farm out in the sound is breathtaking. If it gets built, I'd happily bring my tourist dollars up to see, and celebrate, the beginning of clean energy production in our region.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Mary Dixie Carter and Stephen Robert Kempf misstated the surname of a co-author of ''Paper Doll,'' a play in which the bride's mother, the actress Dixie Carter, appeared this year at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. (The error also occurred in a review of the play in the Connecticut section on March 23.) She is Barbara J. Zitwer, not Switzer.

title: The Luck of the Irish? Not This Summer
description: FOR 12 days, Ciaran Brennan had a routine. Mr. Brennan, a 21-year-old Irish student in Montauk on a work-exchange program, woke up and combed his wavy brown hair. He pulled on his creased black trousers and white knit shirt, left the small room at the Montauk Motel that houses him and five friends and went to look for work. And everywhere Mr. Brennan went, he heard the same thing: Come back in a week.

title: Camping Outdoors or In
description: Summer is here, and the season's activities can begin. Here are some new takes on the familiar trappings of bunk life.

title: Camino de Santiago Pilgrim Route
description: Following the footsteps of the devout to Santiago de Compostela, pilgrims enjoy the sights along the way.

title: Memories of an Internment Camp
description: The Minidoka Relocation Center in southern Idaho, which housed 13,000 Japanese-Americans during World War II, is now the Minidoka Internment National Monument. Over the weekend, about 110 internees and relatives made a pilgrimage to the site.

title: Liberia War Chokes the Life of Monrovia
description: The old public hospital here in the Liberian capital stands on a hill overlooking the Atlantic, with a pair of stone lions perched alongside its wide majestic steps. It was once the seat of the health ministry. A generation of Liberians was born in its wards.

title: Gays and Lesbians Parade With a New Sense of Pride and Possibility
description: Rainbow flags, samba drag queens, politicians, gay grandparents and a lavish flow of discordantly thumping floats made their way down Fifth Avenue yesterday, as they do every year. But there was an added hop of jubilation this time.

title: Roulade of Salmon
description: Aroulade is simply a rolled, stuffed item  usually meat, but in this case, fish. Salmon has the texture and flavor to stand up to this stuffing mixture, which is quite flavorful. In the video segment, Chef Sailhac has cut the salmon into thinner slices, but you will probably find the rolling easier if you leave the fish in 4 ounce strips.

title: Sex and Death Just Like HBO, But Showtime Gets No Love
description: The sixth season premiere of ''Sex and the City'' on HBO this month did not just represent the return of a popular sitcom to television. It was a cultural happening.

title: Forecasts for '03, '04 Are Revised Upward
description: Another forecast of advertising spending for 2003 is being revised upward, this time by ZenithOptimedia, the media services agency in London.

title: People
description: Micky Marks is resigning as president at the New York and San Francisco offices of PHD, the agency said, effective in a month. He had held the post, which will not be filled after he leaves, since PHD was formed last year by the Omnicom Group. Before that, Mr. Marks had been president and chief executive at Creative Media, New York, which was acquired by Omnicom and merged into PHD.

title: White House Letter; Run, George, Run, But Not Too Fast
description: President Bush arrived at his 1,600-acre ranch here close to 1 a.m. on Saturday, when he crawled in next to the first lady -- ''she'll be the lump in the bed next to me,'' he memorably said to 800 political donors in Burlingame, Calif., on Friday afternoon -- then got up later in the day to continue his rehabilitation work on a sports injury that has slowed the first runner.

title: Stanford's Start Settles Nerves and Outcome
description: Thanks to a glorious start, Angela Stanford's first career victory looked as easy as one, two, three.

title: Courts' Rulings Buoy A Gay Pride Parade
description: The United States Supreme Court's ruling to strike down laws against sodomy and Canadian decisions in support of same-sex marriages contributed to a more celebratory tone at New York City's gay and lesbian pride parade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCH, , PHILIP J.
description: HIRSCH--Philip J. Died on June 27 after a brief illness at home in Scottsdale, Arizona. Devoted and loving husband, father and grandfather, he is survived by his wife, Judith; son, Lawrence; daughter-inlaw, Iva, and grandchildren, Adina and Rebecca. He leaves behind many served wisely and faithfully and many shaped by his example as a distinguished lawyer with a lifelong commitment to charity. Private services will be followed by interment in Tucson, Arizona. Donations in his memory may be made to the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAYPOL, , CYNTHIA OTIS
description: SAYPOL--Cynthia Otis. 72, on June 28, 2003. Adored life partner of Ed Krones. Beloved mother of Cathy Saypol and Amy Tompkins, and mother-in-law of P. F. Bentley and Richard Tompkins. Loving friend of Ed's children, Leah Becker and Mark Krones. Wonderful ''Grammie'' to Jimmy Tompkins and Leah's daughter Dakota. Dear sister-in-law of Margo Otis and aunt of Steven, Tracy, and Martha Otis. Best childhood friend of Joan Baron. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St, on Tuesday, July 1, between 3 and 5 PM, and 7 to 9 PM. Interment private. >>AD#

title: New Jersey Foster Children Lingering in Mental Wards
description: At Trinitas Hospital in Elizabeth, N.J., roughly three dozen patients are in the children's psychiatric ward, and more than half of them are foster children stuck there simply because the state has nowhere else to put them.

title: Movements With Mystery and Surprise
description: Frankie Hart has made her name as a choreographer in Cleveland and now in Tampa. The four pieces she presented on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio suggested the virtues and pitfalls of shaping an artistic profile outside a dance hub like New York.

title: A House Divided, and for Sale; Real Estate Splits Jewish Group and Synagogue
description: A bitter dispute between an Orthodox Jewish congregation and its umbrella movement, the National Council of Young Israel, has spilled into court. It is a fight encompassing money, clashing rabbis and divergent laws -- ancient Jewish law and the inexorable law of Manhattan real estate.

title: Keeping the Vision at Ground Zero
description: As the two-year anniversary of Sept. 11 draws near, New York City -- and the world -- may well imagine that the site of the terrorist attack is on its way to transformation. Everyone has seen the thrilling structures planned by Studio Daniel Libeskind, including the exposed slurry wall that will remind history both of how deep the wound was and how solid the city's physical and social foundations proved in time of attack. Everyone is expecting the selection of a memorial to the victims that will be equally powerful. New Yorkers also trust that the leaders of the development will be able to combine these projects with a larger rebuilding of Lower Manhattan. The greatest memorial of all to the victims will be a grand, vibrant, diverse community of residences, businesses, cultural institutions and parks. But although our vision of what is supposed to be coming gets clearer every day, the process of getting there still faces some of the same problems it did in those first weeks after the tragedy.

When a soldier she's trying to apprehend punches her in the nose and she fights back in an impressive show of hand-to-hand combat. When a snobbish woman says disdainfully of Jo's father: ''A dead greengrocer. Sad.'' And when McDonagh confesses to a colleague that her career inspiration was Linda Hamilton in ''Terminator II'' (for the upper-body development and the guns).

Howe argued that Mets center fielder Timo Perez had thrown out Alfonso Soriano at third base in a close play, although television replays showed that Soriano was safe.

description: In a far-reaching tribute to George Balanchine, who founded the New York City Ballet with Lincoln Kirstein, the company will celebrate the centennial of Balanchine's birth in its 2003-4 season with a variety of guests and 81 ballets. title: Patents; Insurance protection for terrorism, divorces, frivolous lawsuits and excessive gambling losses.
description: PATENTS for methods of carrying out an idea have long generated controversy because they award exclusive ownership to a way of doing things, not a mechanical, electrical or chemical innovation. Patents have been granted for methods of doing surgery, business, scientific experiments, even cutting hair and brushing teeth.

title: 12 Die in Chicago As Crowded Decks Collapse at a Party
description: One moment, Eric Mersmann said, he was talking to friends on a crowded back porch on one of the first summery Saturday nights the city had seen. The next moment, the floor beneath him vanished, dropping him three stories to the ground, pinning him up to his ribs in planks of wood, and leaving him calling out to the moaning, screaming people buried beside him in the dark.

title: A Positive Approach to the Negative Double
description: A theoretical argument concerns the right course of action when one no-trump is overcalled at the two-level in a suit. Traditionally a double is for penalties, making the overcall a risky exercise. In tournament play most experts prefer to use a negative double, suggesting moderate values with length in an unbid major suit.

title: The Week's Economic Events
description: MONDAYNone

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 16 about negotiations toward an Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip omitted the name of the television broadcast on which Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, discussed the matter. It was ''Fox News Sunday.''

title: U.S. Chill Flattens Mood at French Wine Fair
description: Something was missing from the country's largest wine fair here this week, and it wasn't just the air-conditioning (in one of the exhibition halls, temperatures rose so high that corks popped on their own). The usual contingent of American wine merchants were mostly absent, confirming to many at the fair that American ill will over France's opposition to the war in Iraq bruised more than egos.

title: Trichet Is Selected For Group of 10 Post
description: Central bank governors from the Group of 10 nations chose the governor of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, as their chairman, the Bank for International Settlements said yesterday.

title: British Minister Presses Iran To Allow Nuclear Inspections
description: Britain's foreign secretary, Jack Straw, urged Iran today to sign ''quickly and unconditionally'' an additional protocol to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty that would lead to more aggressive United Nations inspections of its nuclear sites.

title: Fielder Cook, 80, Director Of Films and TV Dramas
description: Fielder Cook, an award-winning director of films and television dramas, died on June 20 in Charlotte, N.C. He was 80 and lived in Charlotte and San Francisco.

title: AMERICAN FORCES CARRY OUT RAIDS IN CENTRAL IRAQ
description: American forces carried out an aggressive series of predawn raids across central Iraq today, aiming to root out groups that have been attacking American and British soldiers and to project an intimidating display of power.

title: MediaTalk; A Test Story Morphs Into a Heady Rumor
description: The week before last, a rumor swept Washington that Ronald Reagan had died. The story first wound its way through Republican circles, then moved on to the State Department, and finally reached House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert's office.

title: Behind a Troubled Bench, an Arcane Way of Picking Judges
description: This was supposed to be the year things finally started to change in the clubby world of Brooklyn politicos who pick the Democratic Party's candidates for State Supreme Court -- which in overwhelmingly Democratic Brooklyn means they pick new Supreme Court justices.

title: Siblings At Odds, A Stranger Uninvited
description: Despairing about the future of the theater? Find the business of the stage too cynical, merely a capillary of the vast, widget-making entertainment complex? It might do you good to pop in on ''St. Scarlet,'' a play by Julia Jordan at the Ontological Theater at St. Mark's Church.

title: Laos Jails 2 Journalists and American Aide
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 30  A court in Laos sentenced two European journalists and their American interpreter to 15-year prison terms today after arresting them while they were reporting on an ethnic insurgency, according to news service reports from Laos.

title: Intel Plans to Introduce 2 New Microprocessors
description: Intel plans on Monday to introduce two versions of its microprocessors for corporate and scientific markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAXT, , GEORGE
description: BAXT--George. 80, an acclaimed screenwriter and mystery novelist, most widely known for his Pharaoh Love detective series, died in New York on June 28 from complications following heart surgery. Memorial service at later date. >>AD#

title: Political Memo; G.O.P. Senate Bid May Take the Fall, for Bush's Sake
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the Republican machinery he controls are determined to rally a huge voter turnout for President Bush next year, in a bid meant to bring New York Republicans the sort of national stature that has eluded them since the days of Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: Coca-Cola tries selling sexiness in promoting Dasani in the competitive bottled-water market.
description: DECADES after 7Up was sold as ''wet and wild,'' a brand of bottled water is being pitched in much the same suggestive way, bringing soft-drink marketing tactics to an increasingly competitive fray.

title: The Legacy of Hans Blix
description: Today is the last day of work at the United Nations for Hans Blix, the septuagenarian Swedish diplomat who led the team of international inspectors that was searching for biological and chemical weapons in Iraq until the eve of the invasion. With an intense allied search for ''weapons of mass destruction'' in Iraq still under way, it is too early to reach a final verdict on his legacy. But with each passing day that the allies fail to find any ''smoking gun'' evidence of terror weapons in Iraq, the carefully calibrated judgments of Mr. Blix and his inspectors are looking ever more credible.

title: The Bedroom Door
description: The Supreme Court has just slammed America's bedroom door. Sodomy -- defined in the new 11th edition of Merriam-Webster's Collegiate as ''anal or oral copulation with a member of the same or opposite sex'' -- when practiced between consenting adults, straight or gay, is none of the government's business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERLIN, , JOSEPH

title: Sports of The Times; Roddick Displays Attitude Of Contender
description: ANDY RODDICK is learning the ropes of Grand Slam tournaments. For one thing, they last two weeks -- or, as people say around here, a fortnight.

title: EBay Faithful Unshaken Despite Ever Slimmer Profits
description: As the recession has slowed industrial activity, Lloyd Graff has found one way to revive sales at his machine tools dealership: auctions on eBay. He has been able to find buyers for everything from $100 accessories to $55,000 precision rotary tools. It is great, he said, to reach many more customers. The only problem is the customers are far more informed about prices.

title: French Win Title, But Victory Is Somber
description: Souvenir stands outside the Stade de France tonight hawked green T-shirts with Marc-Vivien Foe's No. 17 on them. Inside, Cameroon's players warmed up in Foe jerseys and the crowd chanted his name.

title: A Tabloid King Looks Beyond Elvis
description: David J. Pecker, the head of American Media Inc., is not the typical chief executive of a media company. He trained as an accountant, worked as an auditor for Price Waterhouse and has never been a sentimentalist about editorial content or the people who produce it. But the green eyeshade he wears allows him to see opportunity where others do not.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Real Estate Group Names Chief
description: The Real Estate Board of New York, a trade group primarily representing real estate agents based in Manhattan, said that John E. Zuccotti would succeed Burton P. Resnick as the group's chairman for a two-year term starting in January. Mr. Zuccotti, 66, was a first deputy mayor under Mayor Abraham D. Beame. He is chairman of Brookfield Financial Properties and a senior counsel at the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges. A graduate of Princeton University, Mr. Zuccotti has a law degree from Yale and is a member of the board of trustees of Columbia.

title: Cubs Avoid Sweep With Victory in Chicago Series Finale
description: A few things were clear, even before the first bat cracked today at U.S. Cellular Field in the finale of this year's interleague matchup between the Cubs and the White Sox: the battle for bragging rights was already over; the merciless derision by White Sox fans aimed at Sammy Sosa because of his use of a corked bat was not over; and, at least for now, the Sox were hot and the Cubs were not.

title: Liberty's Big Bet
description: As the Vivendi Universal board prepares to meet in Paris tomorrow to begin examining bids for its entertainment assets, Liberty Media is still considered by many industry executives and analysts to have the strongest chance of winning.

title: '1984' Has Come to Pass
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VANDER POEL, , HALSTED BILLINGS
description: VANDER POEL--Halsted Billings. 91, died at home in Washington, D.C., on Friday, June 27, 2003. Following a distinquished stint in the navy during World War II he then went on to serve in the Executive Office of the President of the United States (1951-1954). Mr. Vander Poel served under Presidents Truman and Eisenhower, compiling the first War Book for the Presidency. In 1957, he came to Rome with his family, becoming affiliated with Professor Giuseppe Cellini in a project of restoring several important frescoes in Roman churches. He was a member for twenty-two years of the Rome Committee for the administration of The John Keats Memorial House at the Spanish Steps. In 1964 he joined the group occupied in the establishment of the St. Stephen's School, an American secondary school accredited to universities and colleges in the United States, for which he prepared the initial school catalogue. During this period he established several of the major prizes for academic and athletic excellence. In 1960 Mr. Vander Poel assumed responsibility for the continuation of the life-work of the Russian archaeologist Prof. Tatiana Warscher in the Campanian field of archaeology and later continued this work following the death of the celebrated Italian epigraphist Prof. Matteo Della Corte. A friend of Prof. Michael I. Rostowtzeff of Yale University, Mr. Vander Poel rescued the MSS of the volumes prepared by Prof. Della Corte for publication in East Berlin, and especially concerning later works on the ancient walled-city of Pompeii. Since 1959 he was occupied in the RICA (Researches in Campanian Archaeology) series of publications in Pompeian Topography, having produced several volumes on the subject as well as delineated maps of Pompeii and its environs. His most recent contribution comprises the production and analysis of the Giornale degli Scavi (from 1861-1867), which had never been published. He was honoured by election to the German Archaeological Institute of Rome (KM) in 1981. A lifelong collector of rare books and scholarly archeological materials, Mr. Vander Poel donated his architectural library (The Vander Poel Campanian Collection) to The Getty Research Institute in 2001. Until his death, he was the longest tenured member of the Grolier Club. Halsted B. Vander Poel was born in 1911 on his grandfather's, the C.K.G. Billings' estate on Manhattan Island, N.Y., the present site of the Cloisters. He attended St. George's School and went on to get a degree from Yale University. He was very happily married for 50 years to his late wife, Dorothy Marlatt Vander Poel, and is survived by his three daughters, Jane Stuart Lenzetti of Washington, D.C., Virginia Stuart Muse of Aurora, Colorado, Deborah Billings Jorgensen of King William, VA, a son, Halsted B. Vander Poel II of Lakewood, Colorado, and a sister, Wendy Russell of Oyster Bay, NY, and six grandchildren. The funeral will be held at Christ Church, 3116 O Street N.W., Washington, D.C., on July 2nd at 11:00 am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Washington Home & Hospice, 3720 Upton Street N.W., Washington D.C. 20016. >>AD#

title: Webdenda
description: The New York chapter of the American Marketing Association named new officers for 2003-4. Eugene Duncan , president at Godiva Chocolatier, part of the Campbell Soup Company, was named president; he had been president-elect. Mr. Duncan succeeds Jim McDowell, vice president for marketing at the BMW North American unit of BMW. Lee Ann Daly , senior vice president at ESPN, part of the Walt Disney Company, was named president-elect, in line to become president for 2004-5. Ms. Daly had been first vice president. Gary Steele , executive vice president at McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, was elected first vice president. McCann-Erickson is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Patrick Beers and Mary Alice Lawless were named senior vice presidents and managing directors at Solara , Parsippany, N.J., a new pharmaceutical division of CommonHealth. They had been managing partners at Customer Focused Strategies, New York. CommonHealth is part of the WPP Group. Laura Bowles , vice president and management supervisor at Crispin, Porter & Bogusky , Miami, was promoted to group account director. Deutsch promoted two employees and hired another. At Deutsch LA, based in Marina del Rey, Calif., Tristan McManaman , vice president and group media director, was named senior vice president. In New York, Jeremy M. Sebiri , associate director for national buying, was named vice president and group director for national buying. And Javid Arain was named vice president for customer and data strategy at DirectDeutsch , New York, the agency's direct marketing unit; he had been vice president for analytical services at Affinitas, Omaha. Joan Dufresne , executive vice president and planning director at Lowe & Partners Worldwide , New York, was named director for strategic services, succeeding Richard Lee, who left, the agency said. Lowe is part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Francis X. Farrell was named publisher at National Geographic Adventure , New York, succeeding Christopher Sachs, who left, the company said. Mr. Farrell had most recently been senior vice president, publisher and general manager at The Sporting News, New York, part of Vulcan Inc. National Geographic Adventure is part of National Geographic Magazines, a unit of the National Geographic Society. Rick Haskins , executive vice president for the Lifetime brand at Lifetime Entertainment Services , New York, was promoted to the added new post of general manager. Mr. Haskins's duties include overseeing day-to-day operations and handling branding and marketing. Lifetime Entertainment is a joint venture of the Hearst Corporation and the Walt Disney Company. Steve Honig , senior vice president at Bender/Helper Impact, Los Angeles, was named general manager at Entertainment Impact , an agency being opened by Bender/Helper that will specialize in integrated entertainment marketing campaigns.

title: One Man's Opinion
description: Late in his dissent to the majority opinion upholding the affirmative action policy at the University of Michigan's law school, Justice Clarence Thomas rehearses and rejects the familiar conservative argument that ''in the absence of racial discrimination in admissions there would be a true meritocracy.'' There are, he points out, numerous exceptions to the merit standard, including the exception given to children of alumni who are admitted, as George W. Bush was by Yale, as ''legacies.'' Justice Thomas calls this exception ''unseemly,'' and for a moment it seems that he will join those on the liberal side who point to the illogic of allowing one exception based on identity and birth and striking down another; either both should be permitted, they argue, or neither should be.

description: FORNATARO--Betty Seeley. 73, of Oakhurst NJ, died Friday, June 27 at her home. She was a loving wife, mother and grandmother. Betty was a member of the local election board in Oakhurst for many years, and an active participant in the Democratic Party. She was a member of the First Reformed Church in Long Branch for over sixty years, remaining active in the Church until her passing. She was predeceased by a sister Alice Seeley Davidson and two brothers Mervil and Howard Seeley. Surviving are her husband of over 55 years John C Fornataro, former Postmaster of Oakhurst, a daughter Nancy Fornataro of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, three sons and a daughter-inlaw, Stephen Fornataro of Asbury Park, Ken Fornataro of New York and David and Linda Fornataro of Neptune; a grandson Kyle Fornataro, and a sister Lois Seeley West of Lakewood. Visitation will be Tuesday, July 1st from 7 to 9 PM at the Worden-Hoidal Funeral Home, 236 Monmouth Road, Oakhurst. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, July 2nd, at 10 am at the funeral home. Thanks for a lifetime of love, support, moral guidance, wisdom and wit. You never wavered in your belief that every person deserves an equal chance to pursue life, liberty and happiness. We're grateful Kyle got to know and love you before you left us. We know you'll be watching over him, and the rest of your family, in Heaven. >>AD#

title: Freddie Meeks, 83, Ex-Sailor Who Was Pardoned, Dies
description: Freddie Meeks, a former sailor whose presidential pardon four years ago recalled the largest mutiny case in American history and the plight of black servicemen in the segregated military of World War II, died on June 19 in Los Angeles. He was 83.

title: Vatican Said to Be Near Decision on New Boston Archbishop
description: ROME, June 30 — Pope John Paul II plans to appoint a new leader for the scandal-racked Archdiocese of Boston as early as Tuesday, several Vatican officials said today. One of those officials said the position was almost certain to go to Bishop Sean P. O'Malley of the Diocese of Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Global Partnership Puts RealNetworks's Media Player on Vodafone Handsets
description: RealNetworks Inc. plans to announce a partnership on Monday with the Vodafone Group, the world's largest cellphone operator, that would place RealNetworks's Real Media Player in handsets using the Vodafone service.

title: Bremer Says More Attacks Won't Deter The Allies
description: The American civilian administrator of Iraq, L. Paul Bremer III, warned tonight that attacks against allied targets in Iraq could escalate, but vowed that the resistance would not deter the country's reconstruction.

title: With 2004 in Mind, Bush Promotes Drug Plan in Florida
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 — President Bush campaigned in Florida today for two causes at the top of his agenda: a prescription-drug plan under Medicare and his re-election in 2004.

title: Melodic Landmarks, Ballad to Turbulence
description: Wayne Shorter played brilliant hide-and-seek in his JVC Jazz Festival concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday, the festival's last night. At times he placed his saxophone lines in plain view, caressing one of his serpentine melodies or buttonholing his quartet with insistent notes to signal the next turn. Just as often he burrowed into the ensemble, making quick ribbons of arpeggios or lightly puffed notes part of the full-group flux. The music was filled with abstruse harmonies and variable rhythms, but it didn't flaunt its convolutions. It used them to map a mental landscape where instability was a source of endless revelation.

title: Bush Looking to His Right To Shore Up '04 Support
description: A systematic effort by President Bush to enlist members of his party's conservative wing in the White House, and to champion touchstone conservative issues, has produced a unified base of support for him from this sometimes wayward faction of the Republican Party, conservative leaders say.

title: Spanish Judge Sends Argentine to Prison on Genocide Charge
description: The former Argentine naval officer extradited from Mexico was jailed without bail today pending his trial here on charges of genocide and terrorism relating to the years of Argentina's military dictatorship.
